title: KNICKS TRIUMPH OVER KINGS
description: The Knicks, running the fast break better in the third quarter last night than they have all season, routed the Kansas City Kings, 114-97, at Madison Square Garden.

title: MULTIMEDIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The shr earnings figures reflect 50 percent stock divd to be paid Feb 15

title: PENNZOIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Q & A
description: Q. Why is there light and dark meat in poultry?

title: RIGGINS UNSURE ABOUT '83 SEASON
description: Twelve hours after his team had won Super Bowl XVII, and he had won a red sports car as its most valuable player, John Riggins was sleepy and sore and unsure of his future.

title: ORION RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
News Analysis
description: Only a month into his administration, Governor Cuomo moved swiftly, both his aides and outsiders say, to construct a proposal for a balanced state budget that, for better or worse, is clearly his.

title: BELL, W, & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
DEVILS WIN ON 3 IN 2:37
description: In a game that was of major league caliber only in the last seven minutes, the New Jersey Devils scored three goals within 2 minutes 37 seconds late in the game for a 3-2 triumph over the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: PLESSEY GAINS A U.S. FOOTHOLD
description: The purchase by the Plessey Company P.L.C. earlier this month of a stake in Scientific-Atlanta Inc., the American cable television and satellite-equipment concern, is small beer, as far as American acquisitions go.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Co. has elected Gary A. Beller executive vice president.

title: Girl Is Born to Susan Ford
description: Susan Ford Vance, daughter of former President Gerald R. Ford, gave birth today in Washington to a 5-pound, 8 1/2-ounce girl, a spokesman at the family home here said. The baby, Heather Elizabeth Vance, is the fourth grandchild for Mr.Ford and his wife.

title: PRIVATE RAID ON LAOS REPORTED
description: Four American soldiers of fortune with some backing from Clint Eastwood and William Shatner led a secret mission into Laos last November but failed to free 120 Americans reportedly being held there, news reports and Thai officials said today.

title: Warwick Joins Alliance
description: Warwick Advertising, with its billings of $120 million, has become the United States partner in Alliance International, a new Swiss company based in Brussels. Alliance is jointly owned by six ad agencies and Lopex Ltd., a publicly owned British investment firm that specializes in communications companies and, indeed, owns a minority piece of each of the six agencies. The other agencies are the Kirkwood Company in England; CFRP in France; LVH & Partners in Belgium; Prad in the Netherlands, and Arks Ltd. in Ireland.

title: BETZ LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
2 Ex-Redskins Elected to Hall
description: Two former Washington Redskins, Sonny Jurgensen and Bobby Mitchell, have been elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame, an official confirmed today.

title: REPUBLIC RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
NUCLEAR METALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Indiana Pacers, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7:35 P.M. For the Nets, this is the first of three games in February with the Pacers, whom they beat in their first meeting, 121-114. (Radio - WVNJ, 620; 7:30 P.M.) College Games: Columbia at Seton Hall, 8 P.M. (Television - MSG Cable, 11 P.M., tape. Radio - WKCR-FM, 89.9; 7:55 P.M.) Pennsylvania at Princeton, 8 P.M. (Television - New Jersey Network, Channels 23, 50, 52, 58.) St. John's at Pittsburgh (Television -USA Cable, 8 P.M. Radio - WNYE-FM, 91.5; WGBB, 1240, 7:55 P.M.). Southern Methodist at Texas (Television - USA Cable, 10 P.M., tape). Kansas State at Oklahoma State (Television - ESPN, 9 P.M.). Florida at Louisiana State (Television - ESPN, 11:30 P.M., tape). Local Games: Queens at Baruch, 8 P.M.; Manhattanville at Stony Brook, 8 P.M.; Southern Connecticut State at Bridgeport, 8 P.M.; New York Maritime at John Jay, 5 P.M. Hockey Islanders vs. Flames, at Calgary, Alberta. The Islanders, winners of their last three games on the road, seek to continue their recent surge in which they were 9-1-1. (Television - Sports@Channel, 9:30 P.M. Radio - WMCA, 570; WGBB, 1240; WALK - FM, 97.5; 9:30 P.M.) Rangers vs. Kings, at Los Angeles. The struggling Rangers, who have scored only 13 goals in their last nine games, are opening a fivegame trip. (Television - Channel 9, 10:30 P.M.) Other Events Boxing: Golden Gloves, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street.

title: REAGAN'S LETTER TO EUROPEANS
description: Following is the text of a letter that President Reagan addressed to the people of Europe and that Vice President Bush read today in a speech in West Berlin:

WITCO CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for 1982 include the operations of the Richardson Co acquired in Dec 198

title: Charlotte Curtis; Nureyev At the Barre
description: THE ballet class had begun, and the star slipped in, rubbed his dancing slippers on the crunchy rosin and took his place at the barre, ahead of the other men and directly in front of the mirror. Whether or not he tried to be unobtrusive, he wasn't. His arrival was as momentous as a lion's suddenly appearing among the daffodils on the back lawn, and Rudolf Nureyev can't help that.

title: CHARMED THOUSANDS
description: Astor, the Bronx Zoo's mischievous, inquisitive baby elephant, who charmed children and their escorts with his high-pitched cries and ear-flopping romps through the Wild Asia area, has died, apparently of heart disease. He was 17 months old.

title: SAYS HE WON'T ENTER POLITICS
description: President Yitzhak Navon, who has been mentioned as a possible challenger to Prime Minister Menachem Begin, announced today that he would leave the presidency when his term expires in May, but had no plans to enter politics.

title: ATLANTIC ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NORTHERN INDIANA PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Because of preferred divd requirements there were no comparable shr earnings for the earlier period; rev figures represent operating revs

title: HOBO TRANSIT IS NEITHER NOR SOFT
description: To the Editor:

title: Siemens-Allis Adds Gould Unit
description: Siemens A.G.'s subsidiary, Siemens-Allis Inc. of Atlanta, has taken over the distribution and control division of the Gould Corporation of Rolling Hills, Ill., according to the managing board chairman of Siemens, Karlheinz Kaske.

title: TOSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes extraordinary credits of $245,000 for the qr and $11,496,000 for theyr and a gain of $110,000,000 or $4.84 a shr on the sale of a stake in the Colony Oil Shale Project...C-Inclu des gains from the liquidation of LIFO inventory quantities carried at lower costs of $25,362,000 or $1.08 a shr for the qr and $29,444,000 , or $1.33 a shr for the yr

title: Comings and Goings
description: Dave Herman, a former offensive lineman for the Jets who once served as an analyst for Jet broadcasts, will offer commentary during broadcasts of the ew York Generals' games over WOR. ... Sergei Pavlov, chairman of the Soviet National Olympic Committee for more than 14 years, has been removed from the post and replaced by a former propaganda official, Marat Gramov, Tass, the official Soviet press agency, reported. No explanation for the change was given. ... The mile field at the Olympic Invitational meet at the Meadowlands on Feb. 12 has attracted four of the elite at that distance.

title: ANALYSTS ARE MIXED ON BUDGET
description: Wall Street economists gave President Reagan's budget mixed reviews yesterday. On the one hand, analysts were pleased with Mr. Reagan's recognition of the economic threat posed by rising Federal budget deficits and the economic projections upon which those figures were based. On the other, they said the size of those deficits, and the prescriptions offered to cope with them, did not offer much hope for the future.

title: CROWN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RICHARD PARRISH, EX-UNION OFFICER
description: Richard F. Parrish, former vice president of the American Federation of Teachers and a leader of a movement in 1963 to open a ''freedom school'' for blacks in Prince Edward County, Va., died of a heart attack Saturday at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in Teaneck, N.J.

title: PLAN WOULD REQUIRE STUDENTS TO PAY MORE OF SCHOOL COSTS
description: The Reagan Administration proposed today that low-income students be required to finance a large share of their college costs before becoming eligible for Federal grants.

title: Gulf Buys Interest
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation said it had agreed to acquire half of Texaco Inc.'s 45 percent interest in Beaufort Sea tract 203 for an undisclosed cash sum. Gulf said the tract, acquired in outer continental shelf lease sale 71 in October, lies about 45 miles northwest of Prudhoe Bay, off Alaska's North Slope. In the same area, Gulf said it had recently purchased interests in three leases from the British Petroleum Company P.L.C. Gulf said the purchase of interests in the four tracts will give it representation on different positions on the Mukluk structure.

title: News Analysis
description: With his budget for the fiscal year 1984, President Reagan is declaring that the enormous Federal deficits ahead cannot be reduced without help from some of his severest critics in Congress. Thus, Mr. Reagan is proclaiming a new era of bipartisanship that White House officials say could clear the way for significant revisions of the budget by Congress in the areas of taxes, military spending, domestic spending and jobs programs.

title: NORTH CAROLINA NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Text of letter, page A8.
description: President Reagan, in an open letter read here tonight by Vice President Bush, called on Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, to meet him to sign a treaty banning all intermediaterange, land-based nuclear missiles.

title: Cyanide Suspect Enters Plea
description: Richard Bowen, who is accused of attempting to kill his wife by putting cyanide in her medicine, pleaded not guilty to the charge today in Santa Clara County Superior Court. Mr. Bowen, 29 years old, was freed on $15,000 bail.

title: B-1 Contracts
description: The Rockwell International Corporation was awarded a total of $2.3 billion in three contracts by the Air Force for B-1 bomber production, the Defense Department announced. The department also said that the Boeing Company had received a total of $211 million in two contracts by the Air Force for B-1 bomber avionics.

title: T.I.'S COMPUTER RIVAL TO I.B.M. UNIT
description: Texas Instruments Inc. yesterday introduced a computer capable of performing several functions through spoken commands.

title: USP REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from the sale of properties of $85,556 for the qr and $419,759 for the yr

title: TIGER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $32,200,000 for the qr and $37,900,000 for the yr and a provision of $20,000,000 for expected losses from the phase-out period of the company's general aviation business for the qr...C-After aloss from discontinued operations of $8,600,000 for the qr and $13,700,000 for the yr

title: EATING TOO MUCH SALT? TRY ANOTHER SHAKER
description: MANY experts link high blood pressure, at least in part, to excessive use of salt. Health specialists have devoted much time and effort to lectures and sermons on the evils of the excess salt cooked in food or added at the table.

title: Advertising; Novel Way To Market A Liqueur
description: A year ago the distinctively different, surrealistic magazine advertising campaign for Bombay Gin broke in about a dozen of the country's better magazines and on bus stop shelters and billboards. It was created by TBWA Advertising on behalf of Carillon Importers.

title: KOCH STUDY ASSERTS LAYOFFS WOULD HURT SERVICES IN CITY
description: Many services in New York City have improved in recent months, but those gains are virtually certain to be eroded if the city is forced to carry out the work-force reductions it has planned, according to a Koch administration study released yesterday.

title: IT'S A COLD WINTER FOR SUNNY PUERTO RICO'S TOURIST INDUSTRY
description: Long before the Christmas lights came down from the palm trees and storefronts here, hoteliers and restaurateurs had decided that the holidays held little to celebrate.

title: THE BIGGEST SPENDER
description: Sometimes Ronald Reagan is a better performer in the White House than he was on the silver screen. When he acts, for example, as if he's not responsible for the huge budget deficits expected in this and coming years, he must be still hoping for the Academy Award he never received.

title: NOBILITY HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
WINIFRED BRYHER, AUTHOR, 88
description: Annie Winifred Ellerman Bryher, an English historical novelist who signed her books ''Bryher,'' died Friday at her home in Vevey, Switzerland, at the age of 88. A Briton who lived in Switzerland most of her life, Mrs. Bryher did not write the first of her nine novels, ''The Fourteenth of October,'' until she was 58 years old.

title: VESTGRON MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FEET OF CLAW
description: Every time a new President or Governor prepares to move into the official manse, stories appear in the press that the newcomers are appalled at the tackiness of their predecessors' furnishings. The new occupants then immediately deny the stories, ascribing them to the media's lurid appetite for gossip and sensationalism.

title: 'A DELICIOUS RANGE OF THINGS' TO DO
description: Howard H. Baker Jr.'s hideaway in the Capitol has a magnificent view down to the Washington Monument, the Lincoln Memorial and across the Potomac to Robert E. Lee's house. Mr. Baker, a Tennessee Republican, talked there the other day about his recent decision to leave the Senate and the majority leadership in 1985.

title: CYCLOPS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $4,345,000 for the qr and yr from the discontinuance of certain operations...C-Net income

title: WITH STAKES HIGH, RACE IS ON FOR FASTEST COMPUTER OF ALL
description: THE fastest computers in the world are today built in the United States, but these symbols of American ingenuity may soon be found only in museums. The Japanese Government last year unveiled a $200 million program aimed at cornering the world market in supercomputers with machines 1,000 times more powerful.

title: ZENITH NATIONAL INSURANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings are adjusted for a 10 percent stock divd payable Jan 31

title: COVERAGE WORTHY OF EXCITING GAME
description: O ver the years, the Super Bowl has been showcased on network television as everything from a sports event to an entertainment spectacle. On Sunday, NBC Sports wisely decided to treat Super Bowl XVII as a football game.

title: Quake Hits Greek Isles
description: An earthquake shook the western Greek islands today but no casualties or damage were reported. The Athens Seismological Institute said the quake measured 5.8 on the Richter scale and was centered in the seabed southwest of Cephalonia, one of the Ionian islands.

title: GULF TRIMS PRICE PAID FOR U.S. OIL
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation said yesterday that it was lowering the price it would pay for domestically produced crude oil by $1 a barrel, to $31 for its standard grade.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bally Manufacturing Corp. said it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire Health and Tennis Corp. of America, a privately held company, for about $140 million.

title: Get Moving on Picture Licenses
description: New York is one of the few states that still refuse to require photographs on drivers' licenses. That plainly encourages fraud, makes the highways more dangerous and makes the drinking-age laws harder to enforce.

title: MONUMENTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Grey Network Expands
description: Grey Advertising, the world's 13th largest, announced yesterday that it had become majority owner in Gramm & Grey, a West German advertising agency with almost $100 million in billings and the country's fifth-largest shop. Bernd Michael, who has 16 years with the business, has become managing director and chief executive. The shop is the largest in Grey's international network, which is now made up of 56 offices in 27 countries.

title: Italian Prison Warden Slain
description: Nicandro Izzo, a prison warden, was shot and killed in Naples today on his way home from work, the police said. In Rome, female prison wardens went on strike because of the killing of one of their colleagues on Friday.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Bit of Candor

title:
AID OLD, POOR WOMEN;
NORTON, Mass. - As Congress considers corrective legislation for financing Social Security, it should not overlook a serious national problem: the plight of older women.
description: Many older women who receive Social Security nonetheless live in poverty. About 2.8 million women over the age of 65 live in poverty as compared with 1.1 million men, partly because women tend to live longer and incomes for the very old tend to be small. One out of five aged widows is poor.

title: Truck Output to Rise
description: Domestic auto makers plan to build 174,000 trucks next month, the most since February 1980, when 174,000 also were assembled, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. Last February's output was 145,000 trucks.

title: Islanders Make a Point
description: The way the referee saw it in Vancouver Saturday night, it was pretty much a one-sided scuffle between Billy Smith, the Islander goalie, and Dave (Tiger) Williams of the Canucks. When it was over, Williams was ejected and assessed 27 minutes in penalties and Smith was penalized four minutes, two for roughing and two for slashing.

title: REAGAN PROPOSES EASING CUTS IN AID FOR THE ARTS
description: In a gesture that proponents of Federal aid to the arts found encouraging, President Reagan proposed today in his 1984 budget more funds for the National Endowments for the Arts and the Humanities than he had sought in either of his first two years in office.

title: COMMERCIAL DECAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SALVADORAN CITY SEIZED BY REBELS
description: Rebels captured the eastern city of Berlin today despite heavy air force bombing. The Red Cross estimated that at least 65 civilians had been killed or seriously wounded since fighting erupted Sunday between 500 guerrillas and the city's depleted national guard garrison of just 70 defenders. The Red Cross also said some 10,000 people had fled the city.

title: ISLANDERS, ON ROAD, SHOW BETTER BALANCE
description: When the Islanders started on this five-game road trip, their longest of the season, they hoped to gain 9 points from a possible 10 in five games. But they were not sure how realistic that target was.

title: REGION FACING THE LOSS OF MILLIONS FOR MASS TRANSIT UNDER BUDGET PROPOSALS
description: President Reagan's new budget proposes a reduction of $1 billion in funds for mass transit, an amount almost equal to the increase passed by Congress last year, according to New York and New Jersey officials.

title: ARMS NEGOTIATORS RETURN TO GENEVA
description: Both the American and Soviet negotiators suggested today on returning from a two-month recess in the strategic arms reduction talks that progress depended on the attitude of the other side.

title: MARK TWAIN BANCSHARES INC (ST LOUIS, MO) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SCATTERED VIOLENCE REPORTED IN INDEPENDENT TRUCK STRIKE
description: Independent truckers began parking their vehicles today in a nationwide strike to protest higher taxes on gasoline and diesel fuel, excise taxes on trucking equipment and increases in registration fees on large trucks.

title: ROE V. WADE: 'GOOD INTENSIONS RUN AMOK'
description: To the Editor:

title: Clarence J. McCormick, 80; Held No. 2 Agriculture Post
description: Clarence J. McCormick, who was Under Secretary of Agriculture in the Truman Administration, died Sunday at the age of 80.

title: What's an Arms Controller?
description: Presidents deserve wide latitude in appointing officials to carry out their policies. In appraising the appointment of Kenneth Adelman to head the arms control agency, therefore, the Senate ought not so much beat up an obviously unprepared nominee as learn whether this casual designation fairly defines President Reagan's approach to the issue.

title: MOOG INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
2-Week Shutdown For Indian Point 2
description: Consolidated Edison is closing its Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant for two weeks because of a problem with a seal in one of its four reactor coolant pumps, a spokesman for the utility said today.

title: NADER GROUP CRITICIZES CHANGES BY U.S. IN MEAT INSPECTION PRACTICES
description: Changes in Federal policy under the Reagan Adminstration are affecting the quality and safety of the meat and poultry sold in this country, a report released here today by Ralph Nader's Center for the Study of Responsive Law contends.

title: Running Scared
description: Greg Foster has made a career of chasing Renaldo Nehemiah in the high hurdles. Adding to the former U.C.L.A. track star's frustration is the fact that he thinks Nehemiah gloats over the victories in their rivalry and could use a little more humility.

title: AMERICAN EQUITY INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including gains of $374,278 for the latest yr and $1,916,308 for the previousyr on the sale of securities

title: NALCO CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $6,240,000 for the qr and yr

title: PREACHERS HAIL REAGAN ON ABORTION AND PRAYER
description: President Reagan, urging the nation to ''face the future with the Bible,'' received repeated standing ovations from a convention of Christian broadcast preachers today. He vowed to renew his efforts for a ban on abortion, for restoring classroom prayer and for tax credits for parochial school tuition.

title: NUVEEN, JOHN, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Amicon Backs Bid
description: The Amicon Corporation said its board had approved its previously announced acquisition by W.R. Grace & Company for $25 a share. The company also said it had filed with the Securities and Exchanged Commission its preliminary proxy materials for a meeting of stockholders to approve the transaction. The shareholders meeting is scheduled for the week of March 7, with closing expected soon after, Amicon said.

title: Profits Scoreboard
State Cutting Arts Support
description: A proposed cut of 13.8 percent for the New York State Council on the Arts - which helps to support 1,200 organizations ranging from the Metropolitan Opera in New York City to local historical societies in small upstate counties - will reduce its funds from $32.5 million to $28 million for the 1983-84 fiscal year, according to the executive budget that Governor Cuomo is submitting to the State Legislature today.

title: SCHERING-PLOUGH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After foreign currenty translation losses of $2.5 million for the qr and $25.7 million for the yr...C-After foreign currency translation losses of $3.4 million for the qr and $21.6 million for the yr

title: BASIC BUDGET: HOT ITEM FOR A SELECT AUDIENCE
description: Presentation of the Federal budget, contained this year in four royal-blue volumes weighing 7 pounds, 9 ounces, is the occasion for an annual scramble among lobbyists, trade association executives, reporters and others whose appetite for this statistical mountain keeps them and their copying machines busy for days.

title: UNFAIR WAGE CEILING IN SOCIAL SECURITY
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Re-creating an Era

title: MCCORMICK OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Xerox Copier
description: The Xerox Corporation said it was introducing for the United States market a new model of its series 10 Marathon copier.

title: Bridge: Even Experts Could Learn From Some Books by Peers
description: Many top-ranked American players - indeed, perhaps most - are sure they know just about all there is to know about the game. Consequently, they never read a book because they do not believe they will learn anything useful from their peers.

title: PORTEC INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
TIME INC. NET OFF 18.6% IN QUARTER, UP FOR YEAR
description: Time Inc., the diversified communications and forest products company, said yesterday that its net income for the fourth quarter fell 18.6 percent, to $43.2 million, or 68 cents a share, from $53.1 million, or 86 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter was $975.7 million, up 6.8 percent from $913.6 million.

title: Farmers' Prices Up By 0.8%
description: Prices that farmers receive for raw products rose an average eight-tenths of 1 percent in January, the first increase in four months, the Agriculture Department estimated today. But the price index was still 3 percent below a year ago.

title: PHONE LINKS A KEY IN TRIAL OF JUDGE
description: Government prosecutors presented further evidence today that a Federal district judge accused of soliciting bribes from a defendant in a racketeering case had, on the dates of rulings in that case, made telephone calls to the man accused of being his co-conspirator.

title: POLL IN WESTCHESTER FINDS WIDE DOUBTS ABOUT NUCLEAR PLAN
description: Westchester County residents living within 10 miles of two Indian Point nuclear plants in Buchanan indicated in a poll released today that they were confused about a publicized evacuation plan and unlikely to follow it once informed.

title: VILLANOVA BEATS GEORGETOWN
description: Ed Pinckney, a sophomore guard, sank a pair of free throws with eight seconds remaining tonight that gave Villanova its first lead and a 68-67 victory over Georgetown in a ragged Big East Conference game at the Palestra. Pinckney led all scorers with 27 points and had a game-high 22 rebounds.

title: McDonnell Jet
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said it had introduced its Super 83 jetliner, a new extended-range addition to the Super 80 twin-jet line.

title: Man Said to Offer Bribe to Police
description: A 27-year-old Queens man was charged with attempting to bribe a police officer, the police said yesterday. A police spokesman said Joseph Miceli of 103-46 104th Street, Ozone Park, had been charged with attempted bribery, possession of a weapon and driving a car with no license plates.

title: DILLINGHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $274,000 for the qr and $544,000 for the yr and a gain of $3,124,000 for the yr from discontinued operations...C-Including a tax credit of $1,209,000

title: WEBB CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chess: Byrne and Gurgenidze Tie For Zimbabwe Open Title
description: The Soviet Georgian grandmaster Bukhuti Gurgenidze and I tied for first place in the Zimbabwe Open International Tournament held at the Monomatapa Hotel in Harare. We each scored 8-1 in the nineround, 100-entrant, Swiss system event, but I was awarded the winner's trophy for superior tie-break points.

title: UNIROYAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: B-After a pretax charge of $10,000,000 for the qr and a pretax gain of $25,000,000 for the yr from the divestment, in the first qr of two commodity chemical operations...C-Net income after a pretax charge of $15,000,000 for planned divestments and plant consolidations

title: Norton Cutbacks
description: The Norton Company of Worcester, Mass., which employs 11,000 in the United States and 9,000 abroad, said it was cutting its worldwide work force by 650 employees. Most will be in administrative, technical, professional and management positions. The company makes abrasives, diamond drill bits and other products for the petroleum and mining industries, as well as being a principal producer of performance plastics and other chemical and health-care products.

title: FRANK J. ROGERS, 49, DIRECTED STATE CRIMINAL JUSTICE SERVICES
description: Frank J. Rogers, Commissioner of New York State's Division of Criminal Justice Services, died of peritonitis Sunday at the Booth Memorial Hospital in Queens. He was 49 years old, and lived in Flushing, Queens, and Southold, L.I.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As a kid, they always came to me and said you're the best drummer, but we have to make Bobby the drum sergeant because you're a girl.

title: ADAC LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Suriname Regime Seizes 15 More as Plotters
description: Fifteen more people have been arrested for supposedly plotting to assassinate Suriname's military leader, Lieut. Col. Desi Bouterse, the country's official radio reported today.

title: VIDEO CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes an extraordinary gain of $9,000...C-Net loss

title: Sir Alan Cunningham; Palestine Commander
description: Gen. Sir Alan G. Cunningham, Britain's last High Commissioner in what was then Palestine and a commander in World War II, died yesterday at the age of 95, military colleagues reported today.

title: Tiger International Loses $82.3 Million
description: Tiger International Inc., burdened by slack demand for its commercial transportation services and by heavy debt, today reported an $82.3 million loss for last year's final quarter, and a $136.2 million loss for the full year.

title: Eastern Sets Preferred
description: A spokesman for Eastern Airlines said last night that the company was in the process of filing a new issue of preferred stock with the Securities and Exchange Commission. He indicated that the registration could be announced in the next several days.

title: CULBRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: B-After income of $54,527,000 or $17.05 a shr, from discontinued operations

title: ALLIED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Togetherness
description: Just as they sat on opposite benches during Super Bowl XVII, the Washington Redskins and Miami Dolphins sat at separate tables at an unusual post-game party Sunday night. The Super Bowl winner traditionally throws itself a party.

title: Sears P.L.C. Plans Mail Order Unit
description: Sears Holdings P.L.C., a British holding company with interests in retailing, engineering and real estate, said it had proposed forming a new British mail order company through a merger between Empire Stores (Bradford) P.L.C. and Grattan P.L.C., backed by a nearly $40 million capital injection from Sears.

title: RESEARCH EMPHASIS IS ON THE MILITARY
description: The Reagan Administration's budget proposals for research and development emphasize military over civilian projects, and basic studies in physical sciences and engineering over biology and biomedicine.

title: NOVA FUND INC reports earnings for As of Dec 31
HOME SALES LOW IN '82 BUT A RECOVERY IS SEEN
description: American builders sold only 413,000 new single-family houses last year, the fewest in the 20 years the Government has been keeping track, the Commerce Department said today.

title: UF1 Conoco Oil Search Plan
description: Conoco Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed with three companies to invest $234 million to explore for oil and natural gas on 80 domestic properties this year. Conoco, a unit of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, said it would form limited partnerships with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company, with Conoco acting as general partner. It also plans a separate working interest agreement with a United States subsidiary of AGIP S.p.A., Italy's state-run oil company.

Killers of 8 Newsmen In Peru Cite Police Role
description: Peasants in a central Andean village told reporters today that they were following police orders to kill strangers when they attacked and killed eight Peruvian journalists last week.

title: MADAM SCOUTMASTER?
description: Catherine Pollard, 64 years old and an accomplished bugler, is fighting to become the first woman in the nation to hold the rank of scoutmaster, and the Boy Scouts of America are being something less than helpful, friendly, courteous, kind, obedient, cheerful or even thrifty about it.

title: W.A. Clark Jr., Energy Expert
description: Wilson Ayres Clark Jr., an energy specialist, environmentalist and author, died in an automobile accident near Leesburg, Va., Sunday night when he tried to avoid a deer on the highway. He was 36 years old.

title: MONTGOMERY STREET INCOME SECURITIES INC reports earnings for As of Dec 31
DEWEY ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split

title: JOBLESS AND POOR FACE BUDGET CUTS
description: President Reagan's new budget would reduce not only the growth but also the actual level of Federal spending on education, job training and employment programs, welfare, food stamps and legal services for poor people.

title: PLAN TO CREATE HEROES MISFIRES
description: to-man pass coverage had been studied, the offensive plan for the Miami Dolphins yesterday included a way to challenge the Redskin secondary: Over the top.

title: DANCE: SAN FRANCISCO BALLET'S 50TH BIRTHDAY GALA
description: Ballet lovers had good reason to rejoice on Saturday night, for the San Francisco Ballet celebrated its 50th birthday with a gala performance at the War Memorial Opera House. It was an evening of nostalgia and merriment that concluded with the entire company waltzing happily on stage while fireworks exploded, showers of confetti fell and doves flew through the auditorium.

title: FOR JOE GIBBS, A MATTER OF RESPECT
description: LOS ANGELES I n his words, the coach of the Super Bowl XVII champion Washington Redskins was ''still on a high'' yesterday morning. ''I haven't been to bed,'' he said, ''and I'm enjoying it.'' When his news conference in the Los Angeles Marriott ballroom ended, Joe Gibbs entered an elevator with a few friends for the ride up to the lobby. Among them was another passenger, a middle-aged woman who thought she recognized the face she had seen so often on television during the Redskins' 27-17 victory.

title: LAW TYING DRAFT REGISTRATION TO LOANS CHALLENGED
description: ANEW law denying Federal grants and loans to students who have failed to register for the draft has produced conflict between the Federal Government and some of the country's leading colleges and universities.

title: STANDARD HAVENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BASEBALL
description: CINCINNATI (NL) - Signed Frank P astore, pitcher, to a one-year contract. LOS ANGELES (NL) - Signed Dave S tewart, pitcher, Mark Bradley, outfield- e r, and Ross Jones, infielder. PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Signed Tony P erez, free agent pinch-hitter, to a one- y ear contract. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Signed Dale B erra, shortstop, Randy Niemann, pitch- e r, and Trench Davis, outfielder. TEXAS (AL) - Samuel G. Meason re- s igned as executive vice president for b usiness operations.

title: Excerpts from message, page B4
description: Governor Cuomo proposed a $31.5 billion state budget today that would cut 14,000 jobs from the state payroll to help close a deficit he put at $1.8 billion. He also suggested tax increases and other measures to increase revenues by more than $900 million in the next fiscal year.

title: Chopping the Wrong Deficit
description: A year ago, Congress recoiled in terror at the $92 billion deficit in President Reagan's budget and rejected it without even voting. Yesterday Mr. Reagan submitted his budget for fiscal 1984, estimating a deficit of $189 billion, and leaders on Capitol Hill call it ''realistic.'' Upside down would be more like it. The President proposes, harmfully, to do too much about the short-term deficit - and too little about the fat deficits for future years, after the recession is conquered.

title: Burning Iron
description: Iron is not widely recognized as a fire hazard, but when large quantities of fresh metal shavings are tightly packed into a ship's hold they can heat sufficiently from oxidation to ignite flammable material or even melt the ship's hull. Since 1968, 21 ships loaded in American ports with such material have caught fire.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF COLORADO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Prices Decline For Eurobonds
description: Prices of United States dollar Eurobonds fell by 1/4 to 3/8 point today despite a flurry of activity among outstanding zero-coupon issues.

title: Bill Rates Increase; 6-Month at 8.225%
description: Rising interest rates in the market for Treasury securities will mean that higher rates may be offered on a variety of new savings deposits beginning today.

title: 2 High Reagan Aides to Wed
description: Two high-ranking Reagan Administration officials, Anne Gorsuch, the administrator of the of the Environmental Protection Agency, and Robert F. Burford, director of the Bureau of Land Management, have announced plans to marry, the E.P.A. said today. Mrs. Gorsuch, 39 years old, and Mr. Burford, 60, both former Colorado state legislators, will be married Feb. 20.

title: U.S. TURNS DOWN NEW YORK'S PLAN TO CLEAN ITS AIR
description: A plan designed to bring New York City's air quality into compliance with national standards was described as inadequate yesterday by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency.

title: PENNEY PLANS $1 BILLION CHANGE-OVER
description: The J.C. Penney Company, the nation's third-largest retailer of general merchandise, yesterday announced a $1 billion program over the next five years intended to increase sales of apparel and related merchandise.

title: KOCH WANTS A TAXI CHIEF INSTEAD OF CITY PANEL OF 9
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that the nine-member independent board that oversees taxicabs in New York City should be abolished in favor of a single taxi commissioner ''who reports directly to the Mayor.''

title: MIDCON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ATARI HIRES INVENTOR OF MICROPROCESSOR CHIP
description: Marcian E. Hoff Jr., the inventor of the microprocessor chip and an executive at the Intel Corporation, is joining Atari Inc. as vice president of research and development, Atari announced last night.

title: Natalia Makarova to Return to 'Toes'
description: Natalia Makarova, the ballerina who was injured by falling scenery during a performance of ''On Your Toes'' soon after the 1936 revival opened last December at the John F. Kennedy Center in Washington, will rejoin the cast when the show begins previews in New York on Feb. 27.

title: Teamster Fund Rejects Insurance Pact Terms
description: An agreement reached Friday by the Teamsters Union Central States Health and Welfare Fund to purchase the insurance company owned by Allen M. Dorfman, who was killed in a Chicago suburb Jan. 20, fell through late tonight.

title: A Chief Is Chosen At Black & Decker
description: The board of the Black & Decker Manufacturing Company chose one of two contenders yesterday for the post of chief executive. The winner was Laurence J. Farley, a financial officer who joined the company in 1978.

title: CITY BALLET: DANCERS TRY OUT NEW ROLES
description: CASTING that could only be called imaginative made the New York City Ballet's matinee on Sunday especially interesting. The range of dancers trying out new roles at the State Theater went from the company's new young virtuoso, Gen Horiuchi, in ''Stars and Stripes'' to a very regal Maria Calegari in ''Swan Lake.''

title: MUBARAK'S SADATISM, ADJUSTED
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, who visited Washington last week, remains a poorly understood figure in the United States. Americans underestimate his willingness to serve our interests and wrongly fear that he will do away with Anwar el-Sadat's policies.

title: Boy's Eyes Said To Be Improved
description: A 13-year-old boy who was going blind because of a degenerative eye disease has gained slightly clearer vision from a second round of eye injections in Moscow, his mother said today.

title: Mobile Offers Response To Blacks' Bias Suit
description: Mobile officials submitted a proposal today to a Federal district judge that asks for the election of city commissioners from districts, rather than at large. Blacks said the existing system had kept them out of office.

title: Artistic Hazard
description: It's one thing trying to get your racquet on Ivan Lendl's blur of a serve, even if you're John McEnroe, crouched and ready. It's another problem just trying not to get smacked by the cannonball if you're an artist trying to paint a picture about 12 feet behind the baseline.

title: Vietnam Troops Attack Cambodia Refugee Camp
description: Vietnamese troops and artillery launched an assault against the biggest refugee camp on the Thai-Cambodian border today and thousands of Cambodians were reported fleeing into Thailand.

title: 2 EX-LEADERS IN PHILADELPHIA SENTENCED IN ABSCAM
description: Two former City Council leaders, George X. Schwartz and Harry P. Jannotti, were sentenced today to prison terms and were fined for accepting kickbacks in the Federal Bureau of Investigation's Abscam investigation.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Washington Talk page Saturday about the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development incorrectly described its employees' salaries. At mid-career, the typical non-American employee earns $45,000 a year, tax-free under United States law. For an American citizen at mid-career, the average salary is $60,000, which is taxable.

title: Talking Business with Mrs. Alman-Stern of Allied Stores; Fashions From Japan
description: Japanese companies are becoming a major force on the world fashion scene, showing the same care and workmanship that they have in other fields. Many American and foreign stores are selling Japanese-made high fashions, and some American retailers predict that Japan may become an important fashion arbiter.

title: Cosmos to Retain Mazzei
description: Julio Mazzei will be retained as coach of the Cosmos for next season, the North American Soccer League champions will announce today at a news conference in midtown Manhattan, according to sources in the Cosmos organization. It will be his third tenure as the team's coach.

title: Jordache Leader Hopes Shipping Will Recover
description: ''I got into the fashion business without knowing anything about it,'' said Joseph Nakash, who, with his brothers, built the Jordache jeans empire. ''This is the same thing.''

title: G.M.-TOYOTA TALKS ALARM COMPETITORS
description: The likelihood of an agreement between the General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Company to jointly assemble a subcompact automobile in the United States is causing jitters among G.M.'s competitors. Any such agreement might be challenged on antitrust grounds.

title: Making Oases
description: An Israeli forestry expert, using a technique like that of the ancient Nabateans who successfully grew crops in the desert, has dotted the brown rolling hills of the Negev desert near Beersheba with green bouquets of thriving trees despite an average annual rainfall of 10 inches or less.

description: The domestic steel industry today temporarily withdrew a petition for import protection from Japan to give the United States trade representative, Bill Brock, time to try to negotiate a voluntary limit on steel shipments from Japan.

EXCERPTS FROM GOVERNOR CUOMO'S BUDGET MESSAGE TO THE STATE L EGISLATURE
description: Following are excerpts from Governor Cuomo's budget message to the Legislature today: The unique challenges before us demand a shared and unqualified acceptance of the sacrifices required to guide this state toward a less hostile future. The steps we must take will test the limits of our ability to govern equitably, decisively and compassionately.

title: TRANSOHIO FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Roving Boy Out of Derby
description: Roving Boy, the champion 2-year-old colt of 1982, underwent surgery for a broken cannon bone today and, although the operation was successful, he will miss the Kentucky Derby and other Triple Crown races.

title: REAGAN SEEKS RISE IN ARMS SPENDING IN BUDGET MESSAGE
description: President Reagan formally sent Congress his budget for the fiscal year 1984 today, calling for a 10 percent increase in military spending and proposing freezes or cuts in most domestic programs. His message counted on economic recovery rather than broad job-creating measures to combat unemployment.

title: EARLIER CRITICISMS SURFACE IN REACTIONS TO BOOK ON DR. MEAD
description: AN undercurrent of professional criticism of Margaret Mead's research methods and intentions has come to the surface as anthropologists reacted yesterday to a new book assailing the late, revered anthropologist's pioneering work with adolescent girls in Samoa. She may have been the dominant figure in the profession for many decades, until her death in 1978, but for years she had been under some attack in academic circles for using what were considered unscientific, impressionistic approaches to the study of primitive cultures. Dr. Mead was aware of such criticism and sought to defend herself in a new preface to the 1973 edition of her classic book, ''Coming of Age in Samoa.''

title: SPRINGS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: B-Includes gains of $2,900,000 for the qr and $5,600,000 for the yr from the recovery on sales of the company's frozen foods businesses and a gain of $2,200,000 for the qr and yr from nonrecurring items

title: IN PARIS, COUTURE ECHOES THE BEST OF THE PAST
description: An Appraisal

title: Duran, Lighter, Enjoys It More
description: ''He was carrying a sack around his middle and all he had to do was take it off to look like Roberto Duran again,'' said Teddy Brenner after watching the somewhat slimmer former lightweight and welterweight champion knock out Pipino Cuevas in four rounds Saturday night.

title: U.S. General Honors His Italian Rescuers
description: Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier of the United States made a surprise visit to Rome today to award Defense Department medals to the 14 Italian policemen who rescued him from a Red Brigades hideout a year ago.

title: RECITAL: ELMAR OLIVEIRA
description: THE violin is a fiendish device that sometimes seems to have been specifically invented to torture all those who study it and all who find themselves within hearing range. Although many learn to manipulate it well enough to please themselves and occasionally others, it is rare to find a violinist who has mastered the instrument's problems to such an extent that all its difficulties are hidden. Elmar Oliveira, who gave a recital last night at Carnegie Hall, is one such wonder. It is always a pleasure to hear someone play any instrument at transcendental technical levels and Mr. Oliveira's program was rich in such satisfactions.

title: COMINCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income including a special gain of $5.6 million for the qr and yr the sale of interst in a subsidiary...C-Including a restated special gain of $18.1 million on the sale of oil and gas properties by a subsidiary

title: Orono Keeps Title
description: Rafael Orono retained his World Boxing Council super-flyweight championship tonight by knocking out Pedro Romero of Panama in the fourth round.

title: Another Honor for Riggins
description: Gov. John Carlin today declared Tuesday as John Riggins Day in Kansas to honor Super Bowl XVII's most valuable player. Riggins is a native of Centralia, Kan., and played at the University of Kansas.

title: DOLPHINS CONCEDE BETTER TEAM WON
description: The day after Super Bowl XVII, the Miami Dolphins seemed befuddled as they tried to explain their 27-17 loss to the Washington Redskins Sunday. They agreed almost to the man that they had simply been outplayed.

title: TYPING AS A PROGRAM CALLS THE TUNE
description: THERE was this elderly blond Valkyrie of positively operatic proportions hovering around my shoulders while my fingers tripped over each other with greater frequency than they did the typewriter keys. ''What all of you must realize,'' she said as I x-ed out a line in frustration, ''is that this typing class is probably the most vital in your whole high school curriculum.'' Considering what little I remember from my high school education and what less I use today, perhaps she was right, although none of us would have agreed with her then. In any case, that episode was what crossed my mind as my daughter Genevieve sat down in front of the Apple II Plus to try out Typing Tutor II ($24.95 from Microsoft, Bellevue, Wash. 98004, telephone 206-828-8080).

title: DOW UP 10.95, TO 1,075.70, IN LATE RALLY
description: The stock market staged a late rally and ended moderately higher yesterday with some of the blue-chip and technology issues posting the best gains.

title: MONTAGUE CASPER
description: Montague Casper, a lawyer who practiced in Manhattan for more than 50 years, died of cancer Friday at Biscayne Medical Center in Miami.

title: BUDGET PROVES A BIGGER HIT IN CITY THAN IN SUBURBS
description: Mayor Koch said today that he was pleased with Governor Cuomo's executive budget, but officials in Nassau and Westchester Counties were less enthusiastic.

title: News Analysis
description: The budget for the fiscal year 1984 that President Reagan sent to Congress today projects deficits of a size unimagined even a year ago, roughly $200 billion a year for three years, and contains assumptions about the economy more cautious than those made by most past Presidents.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: No Immunity for Boxes

title: YIELDS UP ON TREASURY ISSUES
description: Yields for Treasury securities rose a tenth of a percentage point and more yesterday as securities dealers continued to cut prices in an effort to attract more investors to a heavy supply of new Treasury notes and bonds to be sold this week.

description: FROM YUGOSLAVIA

title: ARROW AUTOMOTIVE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
ZIMBABWE IS SHORT ON WATER, LONG ON BAD BLOOD
description: It is summer in Zimbabwe, one that will long be remembered for its record-breaking heat and for its shortages. The country is running out of petroleum products. It is also dangerously short of water.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: WHAT looked good last week? Not quite a million things, but almost, starting with the beaded e vening sweater Yves Saint Laurent paired with a long crepe skirt in h is spring couture collection in Paris. After two years of u nremitting ball gowns from anyone who ever hoped to be a designer, t hat simple sweater and skirt looked like the most modern way to d ress at night.

title: Illinois Governor Barred From Cutting Budget
description: Gov. James R. Thompson's plan to cut $160 million from the Illinois budget was blocked today by a judge acting on a lawsuit filed in behalf of two recipients of state Public Aid.

title: Market Place; 2 Phone Stocks Attract Notice
description: THE reorganization of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, due for completion by Jan. 1, will result in a slimmed-down version of A.T.& T. and seven independent regional holding companies that will own the Bell subsidiaries that provide most of the nation's local telephone service. That, of course, is widely known.

title: NATIONAL BANK OF NORTH AMERICA (NYC) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: National Bank of North America is a wholly owned subsidiary of the London basedNational Westminster Bank PLC

title: Murphy, Braves Agree
description: ''Huge'' is the term the Atlanta Braves are using in describing an agreement they have reached with the center fielder Dale Murphy. How huge? According to The Atlanta Journal, Murphy, the National League's most valuable player last year, will receive close to $8 million over five years, which would make his the richest pact ever offered by the Braves.

title: 2 OTHER INSURANCE MARKETS
description: Since the founding of the New York Insurance Exchange in 1980 two others have been established, in Illinois and Florida. Each is attempting to concentrate on a different aspect of the reinsurance market, as well as to handle some direct underwritings.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Honor Among Thieves

title: PINE POINT MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEW THERAPIES FOR THE ADDICT GO FAR BEYOND MERE ABSTINENCE
description: The longstanding notion that addictions are incurable and can be controlled only by abstinence is now being challenged by the success of therapies that go far beyond abstinence to help addicts cope with life without falling back on their compulsions. The new approaches offer psychological insight and behavioral guidelines, in addition to time-honored group support, to treat a wide variety of compulsions, including addiction to alcohol, drugs, gambling, cigarettes and food.

title: 60-Second Debate
description: David Durenberger Republican Senator from Minnesota and chairman of the Senate subcommittee on health

title: CHINESE FAVOR SAN FRANCISCO FOR RENEWED TRADE
description: Century-old ties between this West Coast city and China have proven to be an obstacle difficult for other ports to hurdle in trying to get a piece of the recently reopened trade between the Far East nation and the United States.

title: Kean to Remain In Livingston
description: Governor Kean said today he and his family would reside at his home in Livingston for the duration of his term and announced the appointment of a three-member cabinet committee to study the best way to use Drumthwacket, the Governor's official residence in Princeton.

title: CHICAGO'S LOOP IS COMING BACK ALIVE, EVEN IF IT HASN'T GONE FULL CIRCLE YET
description: If there is one symbol that has been associated with this city for generations, it is Chicago's Loop, that square downtown business core where the rich shopped, Frank Sinatra sang, New Year's crowds gathered and the screeching elevated trains of the city's transit system rocked along overhead.

title: WATKINS-JOHNSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ABOUT EDUCATION
description: AT first glance, the film, ''Before the First Word,'' looks like nothing more than a skillful and loving portrait of Sullivan Street in Lower Manhattan's Little Italy. Starting with an elderly couple who grew up on the street, met, courted, married and lived there happily ever after and who would not want to be anywhere else, the lens wanders to an old man who has made sandwiches in the local deli for 40 years and who feels trapped. It shows people and shops, the constant and the changing values, the influx of Portuguese immigrants and their slow integration. It is a mosaic of much happiness and a measure of sadness.

title: ROBERT T. STEVENS, FORMER ARMY SECRETARY, DIES AT 83
description: Robert T. Stevens, a former Secretary of the Army who became a major figure in the 1954 Army-McCarthy hearings that led to the condemnation of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and the collapse of his anti-Communist campaigns, died Sunday at his home in Edison, N.J. He was 83 years old.

title: Inco Sells Exide
description: Inco Ltd., the Canadian mining concern, announced the sale of its Exide Corporation unit for an undisclosed amount of notes to a new company formed by the First Chicago Investment Corporation and principals of the Spectrum Group. Inco said the sale of Exide, which had sales of $250 million in 1982, completed its withdrawal from the battery and related products businesses. Inco said it would hold a substantial but minority interest in the new company.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 1, 1983
description: International President Reagan offered to meet with Yuri A. Andropov, the Soviet leader, to sign a treaty banning all intermediate-range, land-based nuclear missiles. The open letter was read in West Berlin by Vice President Bush on the first full day of his 12-day tour of Europe. (Page A1, Column 2.) A pledge on arms accords was made in Tokyo by Secretary of State George P. Shultz. He told Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone that Washington would never negotiate an agreement with Moscow for reducing medium-range missiles in Europe at the expense of the security of Japan or other countries. (A9:1-3.)

title: CLEVELAND-CLIFFS IRON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MOROCCO EMERGING AS CLOSEST ARAB ALLY
description: The United States is apparently succeeding in its intensified effort to make the Kingdom of Morocco its closest and most useful ally in the Arab world.

title: REDSKINS' WINNING GAMBLE
description: A t least once in every football game there is a moment the coach senses is pivotal. Does he choose the percentage play? Or does he make a bolder decision that can determine the outcome of the game?

title: THEATER: 'SONS AND FATHERS OF SONS'
description: AS a general rule, plays that don't get going in the first half hour or so never do. So it's startling to experience what happens near the end of the first act of Ray Aranha's ''Sons and Fathers of Sons'' at the Negro Ensemble Company. After offering more than a few plodding scenes, this play not only comes suddenly alive but it also starts to crush the audience between laughter and sorrow with masterful skill, holding us totally in its grip. And the grip is tightened for much of the second act as well, until, in the final 20 minutes, the author loses control again and goes almost entirely haywire. It would be inexact to say that ''Sons and Fathers'' demands that we take the bad with the good: this is a play that mixes the dreary with the exceptional.

title: WISCONSIN ELECTRIC POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bid for Miami Coke Bottler
description: The Coca-Cola Bottling Company of Miami Inc. said it had reached an agreement in principle to be acquired by a private investor group for $154 million.

title: Seven Are Invited To Mets' Camp
description: The Mets invited seven nonroster players to their spring training camp yesterday, including Ron Darling, the former Yale pitcher, who is one of the prime prospects in the Mets' farm system.

title: SHULTZ SAYS U.S.-SOVIET ACCORD WON'T HURT JAPAN
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz promised Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan today that the United States would never negotiate an agreement with the Soviet Union on reducing medium-range missiles in Europe at the expense of the security of Japan and other non-European countries.

title: ALLIED NET OFF 22%
description: Stockholders of the Allied Corporation voted overwhelmingly at company headquarters here today to approve a $1.8 billion merger with the Bendix Corporation, formally ending one of the most bizarre merger battles in American corporate history.

title: No Headline
description: REAGANS GREET THE REDSKINS

title: INDUSTRY-ACADEMIC TIES: PROFIT OVER PROGRESS?

title: 5 FILM DIRECTORS NOMINATED FOR PRIZE
description: Nominations for the 1982 Directors Guild of America award were announced Sunday and contained one major surprise. The surprise nominee was Wolfgang Petersen for ''Das Boot'' (''The Boat''), a German-language movie about a U-boat crew during the final months of World War II. The last foreign-language nominee for the guild award was Lina Wertmuller for ''Seven Beauties'' in 1976. Mr. Petersen had not been labeled a likely contender. ''Das Boot'' was released in America by Triumph, the classics division of Columbia Pictures.

title: AT BUDGET'S UNVEILING, FEW SECRETS WERE LEFT
description: Once a year, in late January, the President sends Congress a closely guarded matter of state, his message giving the details of his new budget. When Congress received the budget for the fiscal year 1984 today, however, there were few secrets left.

title: BUDGET PROPOSES SPACE FOR ADDITIONAL 2,300 PRISONERS

title: 5-YEAR ARMS PLAN REAFFIRMS GROWTH
description: The five-year program of military spending that President Reagan proposed to Congress today reaffirmed his intent to continue expanding the nation's might even though the cost has been shaved somewhat by reduced inflation and Congressional pressure.

title: Decision File; Clearinghouse For Energy Fraud
description: The Federal Trade Commission has formed an ''energy fraud clearinghouse'' to share information on get-warm-quick schemes. The clearinghouse will keep files on energy-saving products that don't save energy or, at least, don't save as much as their advertisers contend. As part of the program, it will compile and share laboratory tests on various products and supplement the F.T.C.'s program of policing the energy marketplace.

title: INCREASE IN HEARING LOSS AMONG INFANTS PUZZLES DOCTORS
description: MEDICAL experts at three major hearing treatment centers report that the number of cases of severe hearing loss in infants has increased dramatically in the past year. The doctors are concerned and puzzled about the cause.

title: BRANIFF AND PSA PLAN WINS COURT APPROVAL
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge today approved a plan to put some of Braniff's planes and employees back to work, flying new routes for Pacific Southwest Airlines. It has been more than eight months since Braniff Airways, burdened by $1 billion of debt, quit flying and asked for court protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy law.

'Farm' Is Not the Same as 'Rural'
description: ''We must strive,'' the President said in his State of the Union Message, ''to restore health and vitality to rural America.'' What he must have had in mind was farm America. For while Mr. Reagan wants to spend about $15 billion on agri-aid - a sum equal to 100 percent of net farm income last year - relatively few rural Americans will benefit. Indeed his newest initiative, the Payment-in-Kind program, may hurt the rural majority who are not full-time farmers living on large properties.

description: With many clothes again made of natural fibers, which wrinkle more than synthetics, travelers are packing irons. Sanyo makes a travel iron with several attractive features. Best of all, it folds flat, measures 6 by 1 by 2 3/4 inches folded and weighs a pound. It's priced at $40 in the Lee Bailey section at Bendel's.

title: CONCERT: RICCI IS SOLOIST WITH NATIONAL ORCHESTRA
description: OTTORINO RESPIGHI is one of those marginal composers who tend to be associated in the public's mind with their worst music. Anyone who was ever subjected, for instance, to his brutally nasty ''Feste Romane'' might be forgiven for not hurrying out to the next concert on which his name appeared. And yet Respighi wrote a handful of highly respectable, entertaining works, among which his ''Concerto Gregoriano'' may be counted. This piece, for violin and orchestra, rarely turns up either in concerts or on records, which made Ruggiero Ricci's performance of it last night with the National Orchestra of New York a welcome event.

title: VIOLENCE SPREADS IN TRUCKER STRIKE
description: Violence spread today as independent truckers tried to enforce their efforts to shut down the trucking system to protest scheduled increases in Federal fuel taxes and user fees.

title: NO SECOND USE - UNTIL
description: The United States and its North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies should adopt a policy of ''no second use'' of nuclear weapons - that is, ''no second use until...'' Under this policy, we would not authorize the launching of nuclear weapons, even in response to an assumed nuclear attack, until we could determine whether a reported attack was real or imagined and, if real, deliberate or accidental. The purpose of the change in policy would be to minimize the immense dangers of a hair-trigger strategy - for example, a strategy of launch-on-warning - that could begin a nuclear war for the wrong reasons.

title: CITY BALLET: 3 GENERATIONS' 'CELEBRATION'
description: THERE was a strong sense of time - past, present and future - in the New York City Ballet's performance Sunday night at the New York State Theater. Jacques d'Amboise's new ''Celebration,'' for instance, is dedicated to current and deceased faculty members of the City Ballet-affiliated School of American Ballet, and featured three generations of dancers, some of them performing the ballet for the first time.

title: REAGAN'S ARMS BUDGET ASSAILED AT SENATE HEARING
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger had hardly settled in his chair for the opening Congressional hearing on the new military budget this morning when the assault began from all sides.

title: NBC Shelving 'Taxi'; To Go to a New Time
description: TV announced yesterday that it was temporarily withdrawing the Emmy Award-winning comedy series ''Taxi'' from its schedule on Feb. 12.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: CHRISTOPHER CROSS was an unknown rock singer and guitarist grinding out copies of the latest hits for the patrons of various Texas bars at the end of 1979, when Warner Brothers records released his first album. That disk, simply titled ''Christopher Cross,'' went on to sell four million copies, and at the end of 1980 Mr. Cross made an unprecedented sweep of the Grammy awards. He was voted best new artist of the year, ''Christopher Cross'' was named best album, and his song ''Sailing,'' one of four hit singles from the album, won best-record and best-song awards. Never before had a new artist risen to such heights from utter obscurity in less than a year.

title: 6 Price-Fixing Bakeries Ordered to Feed Needy
description: Six wholesale bakeries that had been charged with price-fixing in supplying doughnuts and pastries to nearly all the coffee shops and restaurants in the metropolitan area must provide the needy with up to $1,200 worth of free baked goods each week for the next two years, a Federal judge has ruled.

In fact, the Gallo brothers probably produce more of their so-called ''chablis blanc'' in one year in Modesto, Calif., than the Chablis district yields in five years.

title: The Elderly in the Cold

description: EATING is a perfectly natural activity, we all have natural urges to eat, and we should be able to satisfy those urges simply and naturally without shame and anxiety and numbing self-consciousness, either alone or with one other person or two or (if we prefer, and it's strictly a matter of personal preference) with larger groups. It should be a joyous life-affirming experience, not (as I'm afraid it is for so many) A Problem.

description: John Read Foley, a former vice president of R.H. Macy & Company, died of emphysema on Sunday at his home in Manhattan.

title: PITTSBURGH UPSETS ST. JOHN'S
description: Pittsburgh gained its biggest victory since joining the Big East Conference this season, upsetting nationallyranked St. John's, 72-71, tonight.

description: Massachusetts, a leader in extending schooling to the masses, is torn by debate over a proposal to limit admission to the state university to students with a minimum combined score of 800 on the Scholastic Aptitude Test.

title: Accord on Wages Ends Mutiny on a Freighter
description: The owners of the freighter Eastern Nav agreed Monday to pay back wages to 22 mutinous South Korean crewmen and fly them home, ending a violent rebellion aboard the 500-foot ship.

title: Stingley Rescued In Apartment Fire
description: Darryl Stingley, the disabled former pro football player, was rescued tonight from a fire in a high-rise apartment building in which two people died.

OHIO CASUALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Poles Rush to Buy Soap As Rationing Ends
description: Rationing of soap ended in Poland today with Poles reacting as the Government had feared by buying up most of the supplies.

2 VANS WITH MORE THAN $400,000 IN ANTIQUES STOLEN AFTER SHOW
description: Two vans carrying paintings and furniture valued at more than $400,000 back to their owners from the Winter Antiques Show in Manhattan have been reported stolen.
