CHILD SEXUAL ABUSE PREVALENT, STUDY FINDS
description: AN ambitious study of 521 Boston families presents new evidence of the prevalence of child sexual abuse and offers the first detailed portrait of parents' knowledge and attitudes about the problem.

title: UNIVERSAL SECURITY INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
An Easy Rider
description: Naturally, Jocko Maggiacomo knew the auto-racing expression ''driving by the seat of your pants,'' meaning a feel for the car rather than a reliance on the instruments. After all, he had been a racing driver since 1972 and the Sports Car Club of American Trans-Am champion in 1976.

title: PHILADELPHIA RACE WIDENS FOR G.O.P.
description: Former Representative Charles F. Dougherty announced tonight that he was entering next May's Republican mayoral primary, giving his party the unwonted luxury of a third serious contestant for a prize that few have wanted for decades.

title: CENTRAL ILLINOIS PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
TEXAS FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Walsh and Tune Named To Replace Peter Sellars
description: Thommie Walsh and Tommy Tune have been named co-directors of ''My One and Only,'' replacing Peter Sellars, who withdrew a week ago as director.

title: UNITED NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After a loss of $1,411,000 for the qr and $1,343,000 for the yr from discontinued operations...C-After income of $85,000 for the qr and $932,000 for the yr from discontinued operations

title: Herbert Rogers, 53, Pianist; On Music Faculty at Hunter
description: Herbert Rogers, a concert pianist and associate professor of music at Hunter College, died at his home in Manhattan last Saturday. He was 53 years old.

title: SCOTT PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hostile Attempt to Buy Home Federal Cleared
description: An official of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board has given a green light to a hostile takeover bid for the Home Federal Savings and Loan Institution of Palm Beach, Fla., in an action that could make takeovers of publicly traded thrift institutions easier.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I now know the answer to what it takes to move a slightly cantankerous, slightly bewildered, aging elephant - a question that I have been asking myself for over a year.

title: WESTERN AIR LINES reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After pretax gains of $7,400,000 from property sales and $15,900,000 from thetermination of a pension plan...C-After pretax gains of $16,900,000 from property sales and $5,500,000 from the sale of tax benefits

title: AN ARMS NEGOTIATOR DETERMINED TO GET HIS WAY
description: How is it that an American arms control negotiator can take a walk in the woods near Geneva with his Soviet counterpart, work out an understanding that almost totally violates his instructions, be rebuked by the White House and then lobby half the world to change the Administration's negotiating strategy - all without being dismissed and, in the end, even convincing the Administration to give him new negotiating flexibility?

title: BIG THREE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ARGENTINA'S 200% INFLATION
description: Pedro Fischer, a leading Argentine textile manufacturer, had a simple explanation of how he does long-term business planning in a country that has an inflation rate of more than 200 percent: He doesn't.

title: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 2, 1983; International
description: Four Arab members of OPEC threatened to cut oil prices by $4 a barrel by next Wednesday unless other members of the group accept production ceilings. The threat seemed to indicate that the four, including Saudi Arabia, are ready to abandon OPEC's official price structure. Meanwhile, nine U.S. companies lowered the price they will pay for domestic crude. (Page A1.) In Western Europe, a decline of a few dollars a barrel would create more winners than losers, economists said. (D1.)

title: POP-JAZZ SERIES: '12 DAYS OF TORME AND FRIENDS'
description: THE ''12 Days of Torme and Friends'' series in the Orrie de Nooyer Auditorium in Hackensack, N.J., which ended last weekend, was a oneof-a-kind marathon that demonstrated the full range of Mel Torme's musical talents. Each of the four weekends highlighted a different aspect of Mr. Torme's musical personality, with entirely new repertory and different luminaries from the pop and jazz worlds joining the singer for at least one number.

title: BUSINESSES IN THE CITY MAKE CONTRIBUTIONS TO THE NEEDIEST CASES
description: Among the many who make donations to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are the city's business and professional establishments. Doyle Dane Bernbach, the advertising agency, and Freeport-McMoRan, a mining company, each contributed $15,000 to the fund's 71st annual appeal.

title: COASTLAND CORP OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Yr to Nov 3
description: B-After a loss of $582,000 from discontinued operations...C-Net loss after a loss of $1,013,000 from discontinued operations

title: AWAY FROM ISRAEL, DISPUTE ON DISSENT
description: The head of an international Jewish organization said today that because Israel was powerful and secure, Jews outside Israel were ''free to debate'' Israeli policies and dissent from the Israeli Government.

title: NATOMAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a $32.9 million charge against income made in anticipation of a settlement of an Indonesian tax dispute...C-Net income...D-Includes $86.7 million incharges from third qr writedowns of U.S. petroleum and coal assets and also includes the $32.9 million charge taken in the latest fourth qr

title: ATLANTA ISSUE SOLD
description: Major new tax-exempt bond issues this week included a $150 million issue of the Metro Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority, which was tentatively priced by Salomon Brothers to yield from 5.75 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 10.20 percent in 2005, with 7 percent bonds due in 2011 priced at a discount price of 73.675 to yield 9.75 percent while 10 1/4 percent bonds due in 2020 were offered at 100 to yield 10.25 percent. The authority, known as ''Marta'' to bond traders and underwriters, is rated A/A+.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: MILITIAMEN CLASH IN LEBANON
description: Christian and Druse militiamen battled with artillery, rockets and grenades in Lebanon's central mountains today, killing 17 people and wounding 34, the Lebanese police reported.

title: Kenya and Albania Set Ties
description: Kenya and Albania established diplomatic relations on an ambassadorial level today, the first formal exchange of diplomatic missions between the two countries, the Kenyan Government said.

title: 5 Badly Burned In Queens Fire
description: Five members of a Hollis, Queens, family were badly burned yesterday when a fire broke out in the top-floor apartment of the two-and-a-half-story frame house they shared with another family.

title: National Steel Cites Deficit
description: The National Steel Corporation has reported that it lost $282 million in 1982's fourth quarter and $462.8 million for the entire year.

title: JAZZ: DON PULLEN AND HIS QUINTET
description: THE pianist Don Pullen unveiled his new quintet in a two-and-ahalf-hour set at the Kitchen Saturday. The group features the trumpeter Jack Walrath, a colleague from Mr. Pullen's tenure with Charles Mingus.

title: VAUGHAN-JACKLIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A.& P. Picks President Of Its U.S. Retail Unit
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company said yesterday that it had named Alan C. Goulding to the new position of president and chief operating officer of its United States A.& P. retail operations.

title: SOUTHWEST BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE NO. 3 AT CHASE TO RESIGN
description: William S. Ogden, vice chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, said last night that he will soon resign from the bank and its parent holding company, the Chase Manhattan Corporation.

title: G.M. Styling Plan
description: The General Motors Corporation is planning to introduce intermediate, front-wheel-drive cars in the 1987 model year that will share one undercarriage but use changeable body parts to differentiate them, the American Metal Market's Metalworking News reported. Currently, the extent of styling changes on sister cars at GM is to make the cars' front and rear ends different. The new vehicles, about 15 feet long with room for five, might allow the auto maker to change whole parts of cars, such as quarter panels.

title: TRANS-CANADA RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
ALL-WHITE JURY RULES AGAINST SUIT BY BLACKS IN GEORGIA RIGHTS TRIAL
description: A jury of 12 whites decided today against 48 blacks who had sought damages from a white sheriff and 10 others accused of leading a mob in an attack against demonstrators at the Johnson County courthouse square in nearby Wrightsville almost three years ago.

title: NOBLE AFFILIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a gain of $3.9 million from insurance on the loss of a drilling rig

title: FEDERAL WORKERS RALLY FOR THE 'BIGGEST FIGHT'
description: They have sponsored a radio blitz, besieged Congressional offices, held letter-writing campaigns, arranged a satellite-linked lobbying seminar, sent spokesmen on national tours, organized mass rallies at the Capitol and hired a Washington advertising firm. And that, they say, is only the beginning.

title: TOROTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STERLING ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: F.T.C. Seeks Auto Data
description: The Federal Trade Commission is seeking information from auto makers in anticipation of a possible deal between the General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Company of Japan to build a small car in California, spokesmen for the Ford Motor Company and the Chrysler Corporation said today. While there is no formal antitrust investigation, the F.T.C. may be asked to begin one by G.M. competitors if G.M. and Toyota reach an agreement.

title: FINNING TRACTOR & EQUIPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Judge on Trial Blocked In Bid to Reopen Defense
description: Alcee Hastings, a Federal district judge who is on trial for bribery conspiracy, lost a bid to reopen the defense today, then lost a motion for a mistrial on the ground that the rulings of the presiding judge favored the prosecution.

title: TV: MOVIE ABOUT NAZIS AND PAPAL DIPLOMACY
description: IT is Rome, 1943. The Vatican, officially neutral, is edgy. Only diplomacy and a painted white line keep the Germans outside its boundaries, and even this fragile peace is threatened: escaped Allied prisoners, seeking sanctuary, are trying to cross the white line. Msgr. Hugh O'Flaherty, an Irish priest, comes to their aid. His is a true story of adventure and faith, told tonight on ''The Scarlet and the Black,'' a three-hour movie beginning at 8 o'clock on CBS-TV.

title: Senate Supports A Bryant Forest
description: The Senate voted today to rename the Talladega National Forest in Alabama in honor of Paul (Bear) Bryant, the longtime University of Alabama football coach who died last week.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: TO French cooks, garnishes and decorations have always been important. They can take many forms, from a simple sprig of parsley or watercress to an ice sculpture or a pastry that is molded into an architectural shape and baked.

title: 15.91 DROP PUTS DOW AT 1,059.79
description: The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 15.91 points yesterday, to 1,059.79, amid profit taking, investor apprehension over rising interest rates and cuts in oil prices.

title: GIBSON-HOMANS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest yr include operations of A.Z. Bogert Co; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect an accounting change on foreign currency translations

title: VILLAGES IN INDIA NO LONGER 'SLUMBER ON'
description: To the Editor:

title: Early-Music Ensemble Plays French Baroque
description: Though the program played by the Ensemble for Early Music's Grande Bande in Alice Tully Hall Saturday night had the fetching title ''Les Fetes Galantes et Amusantes,'' these festivities from the French Baroque were only intermittently gallant and often somber.

title: Amax Mine
description: Amax of Canada Ltd., an Amax Inc. unit, said its molybdenum mine in Kitsault, British Columbia, which was shut in November, would remain closed indefinitely because of continued high molybdenum inventories and weak demand. Current industry market forecasts indicate that the market may not improve substantially until the second half of this year. Amax, based in Greenwich, Conn., is a worldwide natural resources and minerals development company.

title: Walts Advances
description: Butch Walts eliminated Sandy Mayer, the No.8 seed, in the second round of the $370,000 United States Pro Indoor tennis championships.

title: LOCTITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: A foreign exchange net loss of $76,000 was recorded for the latest yr against arestated loss of $159,000 in yr earlier period

title: WARFIELD AND BELL GAIN HALL OF FAME
description: The wide receiver Paul Warfield, the linebacker Bobby Bell and a coach, Sid Gillman, will be inducted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame along with Sonny Jurgensen and Bobby Mitchell.

title: TRAFFIC AND HOUSING WOES TARNISH COAST'S SUBURBAN 'UTOPIA' OF 60's
description: California's Orange County, the futurists of the 1960's said, was going to be America's quintessential suburb of the late 20th century: a master-planned, growth-controlled, automobile-oriented utopia of clear skies, new towns and high-technology jobs.

title: Lining Up Teams
description: ''By March 1, we will have our teams,'' said Les Unger, a spokesman for the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, talking about the Kickoff Bowl at Giants Stadium in August between two of last season's best college football teams. Unger did not say that one of the teams the Meadowlands was interested in was the University of Georgia, but obviously a game with Herschel Walker would command quite a television fee, and Unger did say that ''television dollars are important to this deal.''

title: RUVOLDT DENIES BRIBERY CHARGES IN JERSEY COURT
description: Harold J. Ruvoldt Jr. today denied that he extorted $115,000 from a New York real-estate developer in 1979, a year before he became Hudson County Prosecutor.

title: IC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $7.5 million for the qr and $20.6 million for the yr...C-After losses from discontinued operationsor the qr and $1.5 million for the yr; included in pretax income for the latestqr and yr were gains of $9.6 million and $63.5 million respectively, from the sale of tax benefits; results for 1981 included a gain of $33.9 million in the qrfrom the sale of tax benefits

title: AMERICAN PETROFINA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GENERALS, 96 STRONG, OPEN FLORIDA CAMP
description: The opening of training camp today for a new team in a new league, the New Jersey Generals of the United States Football League, had different meanings for different players.

title: CONSOLTEX CANADA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
GREAT NORTHERN NEKOOSA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Koch Going 'Fact Finding' In Israel This Month

title: Careers; How to Tie Humanities To Science
description: AT a time when many liberal arts majors are worrying about their job prospects, an engineering school with a small liberal arts program is starting a new, deeper liberal arts curriculum to help such students gain precise technical and scientific knowledge.

title: Quaker Oats Deal
description: The Quaker Oats Company has acquired the Ralston Purina Company's European pet food business for approximately $22.5 million, according to a Quaker spokesman, Ron Bottrell.

title: Federal Leasing
description: Insurance underwriters at Lloyd's of London have settled all litigation between themselves and Federal Leasing of the United States and will pay Federal Leasing $11.5 million, Lloyd's said in a statement. The settlement ends four years of litigation based on claims of up to $550 million in damages by Federal Leasing on the ground that its business suffered because of Lloyd's failure to pay immediately on claims falling due on its computer leasing insurance policies.

title: No Headline
description: ISLANDERS IN TIE WITH FLAMES

title: NETS WIN BY FOILING PACERS' RALLY
description: For all the frustration the Indiana Pacers have endured in a 14-30 season, they remain resilient. Tonight against the Nets, they rallied from a 15-point deficit at the start of the final period and pulled to 4 with just over a minute left. But the Nets scored the game's last 5 points and triumphed, 120-111, before 9,163 fans at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Bella Davidovich Offers Russian Piano Music
description: As might have been expected from a Russian emigre pianist, there was no shortage of Scriabin and Prokofiev on Bella Davidovich's Sunday afternoon concert in Carnegie Hall. But Miss Davidovich had more on her mind than fiery pyrotechnics, so both composers were represented by some of their most restrained and lyrical works.

title: Chairman of Miles Plans to Step Down
description: Theodor H. Heinrichs, chairman and chief executive of Miles Laboratories Inc., said yesterday that he planned to step down at the March meeting of the board of directors.

title: TINA THE ANGRY ELEPHANT DEPARTS LIKE A PUSSYCAT
description: Tina, the Central Park Zoo elephant who had been rejected by zoos all over the country because of her reputation as a grump, boarded a truck bound for California yesterday to start a new life in a 65-acre wildlife park.

title: Avon Products
description: The RCA Corporation and the Avon Corporation announced that Avon Products Inc. would purchase 15,000 RCA videotape recorders for more than $8 million. The units, which will be placed in the homes of Avon managers and leaders around the United States, will be used to show tapes for training, sales strategy and new product introductions.

title: ROBINS, A H, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SWINE FEVER VICTIM
description: Question: You spent Super Sunday glued to your television set? Answer: Almost, but not entirely. Because of the length of the game I twice had to take time out to shave. Q. You thought the game was too long? A. Watching a fleet of automobiles take off from the deck of an aircraft carrier is interesting once. I was particularly anxious to see if they would bomb the Chesapeake Bay Bridge, which seemed to lie on the horizon. Watching the cars take off a second time was a bit much since the bridge was still intact. When they showed the third takeoff - the bridge still undamaged - it began to feel longer than World War II.

title: CUOMO NOMINEE FOR U.D.C. ASKS REAGAN TO AUDIT AGENCY
description: William Stern, Governor Cuomo's nominee to run the Urban Development Corporation, asked State Comptroller Edward V. Regan today to conduct an audit within 60 days to guide him in a reorganization of the agency and two subsidiaries.

title: BRAISING: AN IDEAL COOKING TECHNIQUE FOR WINTER FARE
description: BRAISING is a cooking method that is little understood and much neglected by Americans, A useful technique at any time, it is especially well-suited to both the winter season and the chilling state of the economy. The long, slow, moist process fills the house with warm scents of simmering meats, vegetables and herbs and yields in robust main courses that include rich sauces and gravies to be asborbed by potatoes, rice or noodles. And because the moisture tenderizes the meat, even the least expensive cuts gradually take on savory overtones.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Silver-Lined Dream In a Polluted Waterway

title: ROBINSON NUGENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings and shrs outstndg are adjusted retroactively to reflect a 10 percent stock divd paid Jan 28, 1983 to shrhldrs of record on Jan 5, 1983

title: PANCHO'S MEXICAN BUFFET (RESTAURANT CHAIN) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec
Economic Scene; The Hazards Of Forecasting
description: THE forecasting by the Reagan Administration during its first two years could scarcely have been worse, as the Administration's new budget for the fiscal year 1984 acknowledges. It says that ''the unanticipated recession of 1981-82,'' the projected modest economic recovery for 1983 and the rapid fall in inflation have resulted in a ''drastic shortfall'' of nominal gross national product, which it now expects to be $482 billion lower by the fourth quarter of this year than it expected in March 1981.

title: CONCERT: FIRKUSNY, CHAMBER SOCIETY
description: known composer to produce a work of this type for the similarly handicapped Otakar Hollmann. Janacek's Capriccio for Piano Left-Hand, Flute and Brass, dating from 1926, is a sardonic little piece, shot through with pessimistic humor. Sunday, Rudolf Firkusny, in tandem with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, delivered a precise, unsentimental performance of this work in Alice Tully Hall, never underplaying its set grimace, yet giving lyrical passages their due.

title: WEBB CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Xerox Prices Cut
description: The Xerox Corporation said it had cut the retail price on its 9200 and 9210 duplicators by 21 percent, effective immediately. It added it was not carrying out a previously announced 6 percent rise in the price of its Xerox 9400 and 9500 duplicators, postponed from Jan.1. A 6 percent rise in the rental price of the 8200 copier/duplicator, which had been in effect since Jan. 1, will be cut to 3 percent from March 1.

title: ANALYSIS DETAILS EFFECTS OF CUOMO SCHOOLS PLAN
description: Governor Cuomo's budget officials released details of his school-aid plan today, amid criticism from legislators who represent school districts that would lose funds if the proposal is adopted.

title: ALCO STANDARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
3 QUICK GOALS INSPIRE DEVILS
description: I t wasn't even close to the record -after all, Boston once got three goals in 22 seconds - but when the Devils scored three times in 2 minutes 37 seconds Monday night, it was enough to give them their first victory in six games.

title: A FINE STAGE FOR FOOD
description: ESTHETICS in food has received a great deal of attention in recent years, in part a legacy of the artsy nouvelle-style approach to French cooking and the increased influence of other visually exciting cuisines such as that of Japan.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Cleveland Cavaliers, at Richfield, Ohio. The Nets' string of four games in six nights continues with their second opponent, the Cavaliers, whom they have beaten 11 straight times, three times this season. The last Cleveland victory over New Jersey was Jan. 22, 1981, in Richfield. (Television - Sports@Channel, 8 P.M. Radio - WVNJ 620; 8 P.M.) Knicks vs. Spurs, at San Antonio. The first stop on a threegame trip to Texas, where the Knicks have not had much success in the last five years. Their records during that time are 2-9 at San Antonio, 2-12 at Houston and 1-1 at Dallas. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M.) College: Connecticut at Syracuse (Television - USA Cable Network, 8 P.M. Radio - WNYE-FM, 91.5; 8 P.M.). Fordham at Army (Radio - WFUV-FM, 90.7; 7 P.M.). Minnesota at Ohio State (Television -ESPN, 8 P.M.). La Salle at Notre Dame (Television -ESPN, 10 P.M., tape delay). Manhattan vs. Hofstra, 7:30 P.M. and Dowling vs. Southampton at Hofstra (Television - Cablevision 7:30 P.M. and 9:30 P.M.). Boston College at Providence, Fairleigh Dickinson (Rutherford) at St. Francis (Brooklyn), L.I.U. at Marist, St. Peter's at Fairfield, Baltimore at Wagner, Loyola (Baltimore) at Siena, Lehman at City College, Medgar Evers at Hunter, William Paterson at Kean, Monmouth at Rider, Montclair State at Ramapo, Mount St. Vincent at New Jersey Tech, New York Tech at Mercy, New Paltz at Rutgers-Newark, Staten Island at York, Fairleigh Dickinson (Madison) at Upsala, Glassboro at Jersey City State, all at 8 P.M. Pratt at Pace, 7:30 P.M. Women: Holy Cross at Manhattan, 7:30 P.M. Indoor Soccer Arrows vs.

title: ELECTRONIC DATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SERVICE MERCHANDISE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
INSIDER CASE GUILTY PLEA
description: A 36-year-old engineer from Greece has pleaded guilty to conspiring to buy stocks with ''insider'' information from two investment bankers who worked for Morgan Stanley and Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb.

title: LAST DEBATE SIGNALS FINAL STAGE OF CHICAGO'S ACRIMONIOUS DEMOCRATIC MAYORAL RACE
description: With its acrimony factor mounting, the race for the Democratic mayoral nomination ended its series of public debates Monday night and moved into the final three weeks of a campaign to control the nation's second largest city for the next four years.

title: ALASKA AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bigger Marathon
description: Fred Lebow, director of the New York City Marathon, said yesterday that the field for the annual event, scheduled for Oct. 23, would be increased by 1,000, to 17,000 contestants. ''With the cooperation we have received from the City Government, the Police Department, the corporate sponsors and the people of New York City, I'm sure we'll have no problem handling the additional 1,000 runners,'' said Lebow. Last year, 60,000 entries were received.

title: POLICE INTENSIFY PATROLS AT LARGE SHOPPING MALLS
description: When Police Chief Joseph J. Delaney talks to civic groups here about safety at the five suburban shopping malls in this borough, he sounds like a New Yorker telling an out-of-towner about Central Park.

title: TENNECO UP 10.8%
description: The Natomas Company reported yesterday that an extraordinary charge caused a loss of $8.4 million in the fourth quarter, in contrast to earnings of $48.8 million, or 90 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenues in the latest quarter remained virtually even, at $441.3 million.

title: EQUITY FOR INDIANS
description: Thanks to an offhand remark by Interior Secretary James Watt about Indian reservations as an example of failed Socialism, there is likely to be, in the next few months, some fairly intense reviewing of the direction Federal Indian policy should take in the decades ahead.

title: NEW YORK IS BUENOS AIRES FOR FILM ON TIMERMAN
description: There were bullet holes in the oil paintings and red lingerie was draped across the furniture. Stale food, dead flowers and broken liquor bottles had been strewn everywhere. The owners of the apartment were sensible enough to have vanished, rather than watch their Park Avenue duplex, once featured in Architectural Digest because of its beauty, temporarily turned into a shambles. All that remained of the usual atmosphere was one very bewildered-looking family dog.

title: TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Control Data
description: The Control Data Corporation said it had agreed in principle to purchase Medix Schools, an operator of three private health-career schools in Maryland, for an undisclosed amount. Control Data already operates 26 vocational schools nationwide.

title: Glass Slivers Allowed As Brink's Evidence
description: Glass particles that authorities contend provide evidence placing Kathy Boudin at the scene of the $1.6 million Brink's armored-car robbery in Nanuet in October 1981 are admissible as evidence at her trial, a judge ruled today.

title: DAVIS, 17, MAKING HIS MOVE IN THE 400
description: Cliff Wiley walked up to Clinton Davis during the Wanamaker Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden last Friday night and said, ''Welcome to the big time.'' Wiley was America's top-ranked quartermiler last year and No. 4 in the world ranking; Davis was a relatively unknown high school senior from Homestead, Pa.

title: Harvester Stock
description: The International Harvester Company has not entered into negotiations about the sale of its farm machinery unit, a company spokesman said.

title: People
description: * John J. Fisher appointed president of Frank J. Corbett Inc., Chicago, a wholly owned subsidiary of BBDO Health and Medical Communications Inc.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 2, 1983
description: International Moscow rebuffed Washington's call for a mutual ban on medium-range, land-based nuclear weapons, deriding the proposal as ''the same 'zero option' '' that the Kremlin had already found ''patently unacceptable.'' Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, accused President Reagan of treating the question of a summit meeting lightly by making it conditional on acceptance of the American negotiating position. (Page A1, Column 1.) The President said he was responding to Soviet propaganda in expressing his willingness to sign a nuclear arms control pact with Moscow. Mr. Reagan said he was sending no new signal to the Kremlin. (A8:4.)

title: EUROPEANS ASSESS SLIDE IN OIL PRICES
description: A decline in oil prices of a few dollars a barrel would produce more winners than losers in Western European economies, economists on the Continent say.

title: RANGERS GAIN TIE ON HEDBERG'S GOAL
description: For the second straight game, the Rangers took a lead in the third period and failed to protect it. But tonight, they emerged with a 5-5 tie instead of a loss, getting a goal against the Los Angeles Kings in the final minute.

title: Shaller Rubin Wins Monarch Wine Account
description: Shaller Rubin Associates was not out of the liquor business for long.

title: SCHWARZ SAYS BUILDERS' SUITS ARE COSTING THE CITY MILLIONS
description: Many construction contractors who do business with the city routinely submit low bids for projects, then promptly prepare lawsuits against the city to gain higher payments, the Corporation Counsel said yesterday.

title: COATS WITH A SWASHBUCKLING AIR
description: ONE of the biggest fashion success stories of this mild winter is Perry Ellis's swashbuckling cloth coat. It comes in two versions.

title: SHELL CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revs figures were not reported

title: REAGAN AIDES HEAR BIPARTISAN VOICES FAULT 1984 BUDGET
description: President Reagan's senior economic officers and his Defense Secretary went before Congress today to defend the Administration's proposed 1984 budget and ran into criticism from both parties on military and other spending plans.

title: NORTH AMERICAN PHILIPS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $1.302,000 from discontinued operations...C-Af ter a gain of $25,456,000 on the sale of discontinued operations

title: THE 1983 GROUNDHOG POLL
description: 1. % OF GROUNDHOGS seeing own shadow 46 2. % OF GROUNDHOGS not seeing shadow 38 3. % UNDECIDED 16 4. % OF NEW YORKERS who have ever laid eyes on a groundhog .03 5. % OF NEW YORKERS who can differentiate be- tween a groundhog and a woodchuck .02 6. % OF NEW YORKERS who can differentiate be- tween a groundhog and a woodchuck (without said animal's American Express Card) .01 MARLENE FANTA SHYER BROOM SONG Today even your trash seems important: rose petals, husks of garlic, nut shells, dust fallen from sun shafts. There is something here - what is not quite clear. These seemingly daft bits of magic crust, as mentioned above, seem full of portent. You sweep and endure. Before very long you have a broom song.

title: Indian State Gets New Chief Minister
description: As part of a continuing shake-up of the ruling Congress Party, followers of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi today elected Vasantrao Patil, a former party secretary, to the chief ministership of the prosperous western state of Maharashtra.

title: CBS and A.T.&T.  In 2d Videotex Test
description: CBS Inc. and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that they had begun the second phase of a joint market test of a computerized home-information system, offering the addition of several home-banking services and some other new options.

title: Making the Victims Pay
description: The dirty little secrets of President Reagan's new budget are neither little nor much of a secret, but they are dirty: this budget would bleed the poor.

title: A CITY DETERMINED TO COLLECT ALL IT IS OWED
description: To the Editor:

title: WALTER TERRY HONORED
description: Walter Terry was remembered in a memorial Monday at City Center as a ''crack journalist'' and a critic who both ''glamorized and humanized'' the world of dance. In anecdotes that drew laughter from the dancers, colleagues and readers who filled the theater he was most often remembered as an exuberant friend.

title: Coward Shoe Sold
description: The Coward Shoe Company, a chain of 22 retail shoe stores, has been sold by its parent company, The Limited Inc., to a Coward management group for cash and notes totaling about $4.9 million, The Limited said yesterday.

title: JAPANESE BROKERS IN AREA GROW WITH JAPANESE INFLUX
description: In Japan it would not be unusual for the chairman of the board and the president of a major company to share an office. It is a custom that Japanese real estate brokers in New York can turn to their advantage. Knowing the customs and tastes of their clients helps Japanese brokers to court them.

title: VIDEO CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes an extraordinary gain of $9,000...C-Net loss

title: Semiconductor Computer Plans
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said its National Advanced Systems unit would stop manufacturing mainframe computers, which it had made since 1977. The subsidiary will continue to sell general purpose business computers made by Hitachi Ltd. of Japan, it said.

title: North Korea Puts Forces On State of 'Semiwar'
description: North Korea today put its entire armed forces on what it called ''a semiwar state'' after the United States and South Korea started a major military exercise involving 188,000 troops in the South.

title: UNITED STATES & FOREIGN SECURITIES CORP reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Asset figures represent net assets

title: G.I.'S JOIN HONDURAN SOLDIERS IN MANUEVERS ON NICARAGUAN BORDER
description: The United States and Honduras began joint military maneuvers today near the Nicaraguan border. Much of the exercise - which involves 1,600 American troops, 4,000 Honduran troops and an array of sophisticated armaments and communications equipment - is being staged within a dozen miles of the boundary. Rarely peaceful, the border has been especially tense in recent weeks, with Nicaragua charging that the United States and Honduras are mounting covert operations against the Sandinist regime.

title: SEWARD GROVES BYAM
description: Seward Groves Byam, a former executive with E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company in Wilmington, Del., who helped develop a synthetic rubber called Neoprene, died Jan. 22 at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 88 years old.

title: FOREMOST CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax creidt of $1,172,000 for the qr and yr

title: Esso Leaving London
description: Esso Petroleum, the British subsidary of the Exxon Corporation, said today that it planned to move its headquarters out of London to escape high rents and property taxes.

title: A Bonanza for Baines
description: He is the youngest player in the history of the Chicago White Sox to end a season with 100 runs batted in and he is even more impressive on defense, and now Harold Baines is going to get a contract that reflects such an impressive performance. According to his agent, Jack Sands, the agreement the 23-year-old outfielder is scheduled to sign with the White Sox today will bring him a minimum of $2.5 million over the next four years and has enough incentive provisions and attendance clauses to raise the total by $2 million.

title: CPC INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Budget Named Cuomo
description: In a month, Governor Cuomo has produced a budget that bears his own clear mark. It would raise excise taxes and cut spending to yield the required balance between New York's (non-Federal) revenues and expenditures at $18.5 billion, with the state assuming some Medicaid and other local costs of caring for citizens in trouble.

title: INTERNATIONAL SHIPHOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a gain of $1,370,000 for the qr and yr from the sale of tax credits...C-Including a tax credit of $4,622,000

title: GILBERT ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
DAWSON GEOPHYSICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dollar Eurobonds Lower
description: Fixed-interest dollar Eurobonds ended above the lows, but still lower on the day, after a session of quiet and cautious trading today, dealers said.

title: SAVE-WAY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Douglass D. Paige, 65, Dies; Editor and English Professor
description: Douglass D. Paige, an editor, translator and former professor of English at Middlesex Community College in Middletown, Conn., died Sunday at Middlesex Memorial Hospital in Middletown. He lived in Cromwell, Conn., and was 65 years old.

title: Milwaukee Magazine Finds a Purchaser
description: For a while there, it looked as if Milwaukee would be doing without a monthly city magazine, which it had had since April 1979. The board of City Magazines of Cleveland, which had acquired it from Douglass Cofrin, then owner of radio station WFMR, in the fall of 1981, decided last October that the crunch was coming and it would be best to sell off half of its properties - the Milwaukee and Tampa magazines.

title: GENERAL HOUSEWARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COMPELLING REASONS FOR A NAVAL BUILDUP
description: To the Editor:

title: Switch by Arguello
description: Alexis Arguello, who believes he overtrained for his attempt to win a record fourth boxing title and thus was stopped in the 14th round by Aaron Pryor, has changed trainers. Exit Eddie Futch, the 71-yearold trainer who works the corner of the heavyweight champion Larry Holmes, and enter Janks Morton, who used to train Sugar Ray Leonard.

title: No Headline
description: PART OWNERSHIP OF U.P.I. SOLD

title: HOUSE UNIT BEGINS HEARINGS ON SOCIAL SECURITY PROPOSALS
description: Congress took the first step today in its effort to restore the Social Security System to financial health amid warnings that a Presidential commission's recommendations should not be substantially tampered with.

title: ZAPATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-AFter losses from discontinued operations of $597,000 for the latest qr and $876,000 for the yr-ago qr

title: TENNECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $10,000,000 for the qr and $21,000,000 for the yr...C-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $6,000,000 for the qr and $15,000,000 for the yr

title: BY LAND AND SEA, THEY STREAM FROM NIGERIA
description: Tens of thousands of hungry and impoverished people who have been expelled from Nigeria hurried today along the seaside road that leads to the frontier with Ghana at the edge of this normally quiet West African capital.

title: BRIEFING
description: Warning on Filibusters

title: Smokin' Joe Jr.  To Make Debut
description: A news conference will be held Feb. 15 to announce the professional-boxing debut of Smokin' Joe Frazier Jr. It will be in the same slaughterhouse in Philadelphia where Smokin' Joe Frazier worked before he turned to boxing and became the heavyweight champion of the world.

title: AMDAHL NET OFF 57.1%
description: The Amdahl Corporation announced yesterday that fourth-quarter net income fell 57.1 percent, to $2.7 million, or 13 cents a share, compared with $6.3 million, or 31 cents a share, for the same 1981 quarter.

title: A Knick Stays Home
description: Since Bernard King hurt his ankle Jan. 14, the Knicks have learned to win without their top scorer. After losing three of the first four games after his injury, the Knicks won four of the next five and have now gone 5-4 without him.

title: REAGAN IS DENYING THAT HE SENT SOVIET NEW SIGNAL ON ARMS
description: President Reagan said today that he was simply responding to Kremlin propaganda when he had Vice President Bush announce his willingness to sign a nuclear arms pact with the Soviet Union.

title: ALABAMA'S BRYANT AND RACIAL ISSUE
description: ''T hroughout the 1960's and 1970's, these two men were the dominant figures of public life in Alabama and the state's main representatives to the nation,'' wrote Howell Raines, referring to George Wallace and Bear Bryant in the Jan. 24 issue of The New Republic magazine. ''In that time, they so dominated the consciousness of the state that it is only in relation to Wallace that we can understand the service that Bear Bryant did Alabama and how, like so many lesser men, he also failed that state in the midnight of its humiliation.''

title: FOOD NOTES
description: A Taste of Mississippi

title: PRODUCTION OPERATORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FATAL L.I. CRASH LINKED TO DRAG RACING
description: Two young motorists who the police said had been drag racing at 65 miles an hour on a Long Island highway slammed simultaneously into another car, killing a 35-yearold woman, the police said today.

title: WRIGHT, WILLIAM E, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VIETNAMESE BURN CAMBODIAN CAMP
description: More than 4,000 Vietnamese troops have overrun and burned an armed anti-Communist camp a mile inside Cambodia near the Thai border, driving more than 20,000 Cambodian residents into Thailand.

title: CHEAP RAIL RATES ON CANADA'S WHEAT ENDING
description: For wheat growers on Canada's prairies, an 86-year-old free lunch appears to be over. The federal Government announced today that, over the next eight years, the rate that farmers pay railroads to transport their grain to eastern markets will likely quintuple, after remaining unchanged since 1897.

title: CONVICTED ANALYST GETS RIGHT TO PUBLISH ADVICE
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that an investment adviser convicted of defrauding clients and other crimes cannot be prevented by the Securities and Exchange Commission from publishing investment advisory newsletters.

title: LANE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: In the latest qr the effective tax rate was adjusted resulting in additional income of 15 cents a shr; results reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective Dec 31, 1982

title: MAZZEI APPOINTED AS COSMOS' COACH
description: Julio Mazzei, who twice had taken over as interim coach of the Cosmos, was named coach for the coming season yesterday. Mazzei replaced Eddie Firmani 11 games into the 1979 season, and Hennes Weisweiler last February. When given the interim job a year ago, he said, ''I'm the Bob Lemon of the Cosmos.'' Yesterday he said, ''I could be the Billy Martin.''

title: THE TAX FACTOR IN THE STING OF A MANUFACTURER
description: To the Editor:

title: SONG RECITAL: MIXED BILL
description: THE soprano Marie Traficante performed an intriguing program in the Merkin Concert Hall Sunday afternoon; half of it was composed of German Romantic songs inspired by gypsies - crucial figures in 19thcentury European musical culture. In Italian and French opera and in these lied, the gypsy was an outsider, but one who also embodied bourgeois society's most authentic passions and desires.

title: Italians Arrest a Turk In New Plot on the Pope
description: Italy arrested a Turkish citizen today on charges of plotting an attempt to assassinate Pope John Paul II in a scheduled visit to Milan in May.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have on my shelf of liqueurs a pink syrup called grenadine. I am not certain of the origin of this syrup nor precisely what it is to be used for. Can you tell me?

title: PUBLIC TV CONFIDENT ON EASING BUDGET CUTS
description: Public television officials are optimistic about the prospect of combating the cutbacks in Federal funds for public broadcasting contained in President Reagan's 1984 budget.

title: Hearings on Boxing
description: Ever since Duk Koo Kim died of brain injuries after being knocked out in a boxing match last November, there have been demands for a variety of reforms, including some proposals that boxing be outlawed. Now the matter is to get an airing at the Federal level. Representative James Florio, Democrat of New Jersey, the chairman of a House subcommittee that has jurisdiction over professional sports, announced yesterday that he will conduct a series of hearings beginning Feb. 15 to explore a possible Federal response to what he called ''an issue that Congress can no longer ignore.'' Mr. Florio, who was an amateur boxer in the Navy, said initial witnesses would include representatives of the American Medical Association, Floyd Patterson, the former heavyweight champion, and Howard Cosell, the sports broadcaster who said he no longer wanted to cover boxing.

title: Profits Scoreboard
TIRE-RATING SYSTEM, RELIABILITY DISPUTED, IS SUSPENDED BY U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration today suspended a grading standard that provides consumers with information for comparing the durability of tires.

title: TALKS ARE IMPERILED
description: Basque terrorists bombed a telecommunications center today and threw two grenades at a patrol car, then sprayed it with machine-gun fire, killing a civil guard and seriously wounding two others, the police said.

title: PEOPLES ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hail the Mayor Who'll Drive the Cabs
description: Two cheers for Mayor Koch. He aims to do something about New York City's atrocious taxi service and proposes to make himself responsible by abolishing the failed taxi commission.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They were going for milk and honey and they are coming back weeping tears.'' - The Rev. Anastasius Dzodofe of Ghana, commenting on his expelled countrymen. (A13:6.)

title: Dr. Clark Uses Walker And Pedals Exercycle
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark took 10 steps with a walker, pedaled an exercycle for five minutes and went for a wheelchair ride today, the beginning of his third month of life with an artificial heart.

title: Barclays Bank Appoints Chief for North America
description: Barclays Bank International, which has expanded rapidly in the United States in the last decade, has named a new chief executive officer for North America.

title: Braniff-PSA Pact
description: Federal Judge Eldon Mahon said attorneys for the Braniff International Corporation and PSA Inc. have agreed to defer the closing of their accord until two business days after he rules on it. He set hearings tomorrow and Friday on the pact, which requires his approval after being cleared Monday by a Federal bankruptcy judge. The accord provides for PSA to lease 30 Braniff planes.

title: THE DANCE: LICHINE BY HARLEM
description: EVERY ballet company seems to feel the need for a creampuff ballet, and the Dance Theater of Harlem's choice is David Lichine's wellknown ''Graduation Ball'' which had its company premiere Tuesday night at the City Center.

title: LOUISIANA SCHOOL PLAN REVISED
description: The Justice Department has revised the school desegregation plan it proposed for Baton Rouge, more strictly defining racial percentages and changing schools that are to be closed.

title: FLORIDA ROCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BORN-AGAIN CHESTS
description: WHAT with all the custom built-in furniture and erector-kit storage facilities that abound, people seem to have forgotten about the mundane chest of drawers. One exception is Joel Wolf, an antiques dealer who recently opened a shop on the Upper West Side.

title: KNIGHT-RIDDER NEWSPAPERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BABY DOE GETS HOME
description: Blood tests prove that a sickly child born to a Michigan woman was not fathered by the man who paid her to be a surrogate mother for his baby, lawyers agreed today, and the mother said she would now seek custody.

title: TV: MALRAUX ON REMBRANDT
description: FOR the past month, Telefrance USA, the French cable-television network, has been holding an Andre Malraux Festival. ''Andre Malraux's Journey Into Art'' is a 14-part series based on the thoughts, in writing and in person, of the late novelist, Government minister and philosopher of art. Having navigated the Renaissance in the first four episodes, tonight at 10 o'clock Malraux takes on Rembrandt, the first of four artists whose life and works are to be explored here. Still to come are Goya, Manet and Picasso.

title: MATRIX SCIENCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ORBANCO FINANCIAL SERVICES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Knight-Ridder Net Up 23.2%
description: Knight-Ridder Newspapers said yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter increased 23.2 percent, to $36.1 million, or $1.09 a share, from $29.3 million, or 90 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1981. Revenue rose 9.8 percent, to $364 million, from $331.6 million.

title: KANSAS CITY POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dorothy L. Salisbury, 80, Dies; Artist and Fashion Illustrator
description: Dorothy Lathrop Salisbury, a fashion artist who illustrated advertisements for Saks Fifth Avenue, Bonwit Teller, Lord & Taylor, Best & Company and other stores during the 1930's and 40's, died of cancer Sunday at her home in Summit, N.J. She was 80 years old.

title: IT'S STAGE CALL IN SUBURBS AND HIDDEN TALENTS RESPOND
description: For the stage-struck in the suburbs, this is the hour of angst. Auditions for the spring season are at hand, and they're enough to make make even the most seasoned amateur thespian shudder.

title: CROMPTON & KNOWLES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest yr reflect a gain from the termination of the pension pla

title: Cashman's Milestone
description: In the 58-year history of the Boston Bruins only one player has appeared in as many as 1,000 games: John Bucyk, who made 1,436 appearances in his 21 seasons, from 1957 to 1978. Tonight, when the Bruins play at home against Quebec, Bucyk will be getting some company.

title: LAWMAKERS CLASH ON RETIREMENT AGE
description: The question of increasing the retirement age for Social Security in the next century emerged today as a major issue in the Congressional effort to address the system's financing problems.

title: KING RADIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Because of a change to the LIFO method of accounting for inventories adopted in1982, net income was reduced by $645,000 and shr earnings were reduced by 24 cents a shr

title: Advertising; Digest: Remember Tulsa!
description: IF the Reader's Digest has its way, Tulsa will become to the magazine crowd what the Alamo is to Texans. That's because media use in that Oklahoma oil town proved that while cable television availability caused an erosion of prime time network television viewing, it had no effect on magazine readership.

title: Mrs. Gandhi's Son Named to Party Post
description: Rajiv Gandhi, the son of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, was named a general secretary of her governing Congress Party today.

title: QUILTING: LATEST BEE IN THE CITY'S BONNET
description: ''ISN'T it strange to be doing this in the middle of New York?'' Paula Perlis was saying. ''I mean downtown, in a major city?'' Mrs. Perlis, a food consultant, and four of her friends were sitting around a quilting frame, stitching a colorful patchwork quilt together. It is something they do every Wednesday night in the kitchen of Laura Priko, an expert quilter who lives on Vandam Street in Lower Manhattan.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: NEW NATIONAL GALLERY SPACE OPENS
description: Honore Daumier's 36 pint-size busts of French parliamentarians are aligned in their new display case like rows of attentive, bored or mischievous schoolchildren. This eccentric, not altogether flattering human comedy, which probably took shape as Daumier molded and kneaded clay in the parliament building itself, is everything any artist may have wanted to say about political life.

title: GHANA REFUGEES MAY REACH 2 MILLION
description: Ghanaian military and civilian officials trying to organize the often-chaotic repatriation of refugees from Nigeria said today that the number of Ghanaian citizens expelled might be as high as two million, possibly more.

title: PIANO RECITAL: MISS CANDIDO
description: LOVE of the piano and its music would seem a prerequisite for anyone taking up the instrument, but there are few pianists in whose playing that care can be heard. Domna Candido is one of their number, as she showed in Carnegie Recital Hall Sunday night.

title: Dollar Bonds Off in Europe
description: Fixed-interest dollar Eurobonds and zero-coupon bonds fell in active trading today.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WHEN stairs creak in use it is usually more of a nuisance than a serious structural problem, but there are situations in which making the necessary repairs promptly can help remedy a potential hazard or ward off a more extensive breakdown.

title: PLYMOUTH RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: B-Net income which includes tax credits of $1,000 for the qr and $516,000 for the yr

title: GERULATIS SAYS HE IS EXPECTING DRUG INDICTMENT
description: Vitas Gerulaitis said yesterday that he expected to be indicted soon, possibly today, on a Federal charge involving a conspiracy to buy about $20,000 worth of cocaine.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: IN THE BACKYARD OF BEVERLY HILLS, SECURITY AND FITNESS ARE THE FOCUS By JOSEPH GIOVANNINI

title: BOONTON ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AETNA CITED ON DAMAGE TO CLIENT
description: A New York Federal court jury yesterday awarded what is believed to be the first punitive damages ever assessed against an insurance company for its refusal to pay a claim.

title: OGLEBAY NORTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DR. PAUL GROSS
description: Dr. Paul Gross, former professor of clinical dermatology at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, died of a heart attack Monday at Presbyterian Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: Stokely Clears Bid
description: Stokely-Van Camp Inc. said its board had approved a revised merger proposal of $55 a share from a private investor group led by William B. Stokely 3d, the company's chairman.

title: 6 Guatemalan Rebels Given Stay of Execution
description: The Guatemalan Government announced today that six reputed leftists due to face a firing squad at dawn had been granted a stay of execution so their appeals could be considered.

title: A DOCILE AND SOMBER EXODUS
description: They came from lands that were broken, lured by a dream of riches in a nation that glittered with the slick sheen of oil. In hundreds of thousands, Africans poured into Nigeria, the continent's wealthiest and already most populous nation, in quest of fortunes withheld by poverty at home. But, last month, the mirage crumbled before them. Nigeria, ensnared in economic crisis, ordered aliens living illegally within its boundaries to leave, and a great exodus began.

title: REAGAN SUPPORTS FEDERAL RESERVE ON RECOVERY AIMS
description: President Reagan, in his second Economic Report to Congress, gave strong support today to the Federal Reserve's efforts to foster an economic recovery. He rejected arguments that Fed policy was becoming inflationary.

title: U.S. Shifting Oil Dependence
description: The United States has made strong progress in reducing its dependence on foreign oil, Interior Secretary James Watt told the Senate Energy Committee today.

title: Shooting In a Dream Situation
description: It was, Seth Greenberg said, the opportunity that every kid dreamed about: ''Here you are on television, against a nationally ranked team. You're fouled. Your team's up by 2 points. The whole game is on the line and all eyes are on you.''

title: VEECO INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SENATORS WEIGH 'CURES' FOR THE PAC 'ADDICTION'
description: Charles McC. Mathias Jr., chairman of the Senate Rules Committee, is a Maryland Republican whose doleful countenance seems appropriate to the subject of campaign finance.

title: United Satellite
description: The General Instrument Corporation said it had received a $600 million initial order from United Satellite Communications Inc. for electronic systems that carry television programs by satellite transmission to home receiving stations. The company said delivery of the systems would begin this summer and continue for three years. The contract also calls for General Instrument to supply receiving equipment for the service during a 10-year period.

title: SOLITRON DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After extraordinary credits from capital losses of $68,000 for the qr and $204,000 for the 9 mos...C-Net income which includes extraordinary credits from capital losses of $78,000 for the qr and $130,000 for the 9 mos

title: STEEL UNION HINTS AT '83 CONCESSIONS
description: Local leaders of the United Steelworkers of America, gathered here from around the nation, today approved new bargaining guidelines suggesting that contract concessions might be necessary. But the leaders said that if concessions must be made, any wage or benefit reductions would have to be restored before the contract expired and savings from concessions must be reinvested in the steel industry.

title: Market Place; Surprising Life In Tool Stocks
description: AN intriguing thing about the stock market is its perversity. Consider, for example, the way it's treating machine tool stocks: Nobody on Wall Street is rushing out these days with ''buy'' recommendations.

title: GALILEO ELECTRO-OPTICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $160,000 for the latest qr and $42,000 for the yr-earlier period

title: BRIEFING
description: An Off-Limits Benefit

title: F.T.C. Query By Chrysler
description: A potential joint venture between the General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Company of Japan has prompted the Chrysler Corporation to ask the Government about the deal. The Ford Motor Company has already said that it complied with a Government request to hand over documents for use in any antitrust inquiry.

title: REPORTS ON INSIDER TRADING
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: KEARNEY-NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The full yr net of 1982 was increased by about $470,000 from the effects of certain liquidation

title: 2 Democrats File For Queens Race
description: Two Democrats, City Councilman Sheldon S. Leffler and Douglas E. Schoen, the pollster, filed independent nominating petitions at the Board of Elections yesterday for the March 1 special election for the House of Representatives in the Seventh District in Queens.

title: SETON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'AFRO-AMERICAN QUILTS,' A SHOW OF A BOLD CRAFT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Gretchen E. Freeman is completing a master's degree in folk-art studies at New York University. By GRETCHEN E. FREEMAN

description: A Synagogue's Fight

title: A CALENDAR OF EVENTS: CITY'S HISTORIC BUILDINGS
description: Metropolitan Historic Structures Association, Citibank, 30 Fulton Street (Water Street), 212-244-4020.

title: Tornadoes Strike Florida As Snow Hits Midwest
description: By the Associated Press Twenty-six tornadoes touched down in Florida yesterday, killing one person and injuring dozens, while a snowstorm in the Middle West piled up more drifts in a storm that has continued for three days and claimed 17lives.

title: MARYLAND CUP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split to be paid Feb 15

title: SALANT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
ENTEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'NOT CREATURES BUT CREATORS OF OUR DESTINY'
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ENDURING ALLURE OF PERENNIALS
description: WITH gardeners busy planning for spring, Barbara Damrosch has a thought to encourage them: perennials. ''Economy is probably the main reason,'' said the enthusiastic gardener, who manages her own landscape design business in New Preston, Conn. ''Perennials last more than one year. Once gardeners plant them, they know they will not have to spend money to replenish every year. Besides there are free gifts - divisions from established perennials, which can be spread around or shared with neighbors.''

title: NETS DEFEAT CAVALIERS
description: Buck Williams scored 22 points and Otis Birdsong added 21 as the New Jersey Nets defeated the Cleveland Cavaliers, 118-105, tonight.

title: REAGAN BIDS ISRAEL HALT ALL WEST BANK SETTLEMENT
description: President Reagan called on Israel today to demonstrate good faith and halt all new settlement in the West Bank of the Jordan River, and he appealed to King Hussein of Jordan in turn to step forward and negotiate directly with Israel.

title: CASINO PANEL PPRESENTS PLAN FOR HOUSING IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: A $205 million plan to rehabilitate slums and ease a critical housing shortage was outlined at a public meeting tonight by a consultant hired by the Casino Control Commission.

title: HERS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- The Hers column was designed as a forum for writing by women. For the next several weeks, it will be written by Barbara Lazear Ascher, a freelance writer and nonpracticing lawyer.

title: TEXT OF ECONOMIC REPORT SENT CONGRESS BY THE PRESIDENT
description: Following is the text of President Reagan's Economic Report sent to Congress today:

title: ESPEY MANUFACTURING & ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Anthropology of Anthropology
description: Margaret Mead's classic study of Samoa has come under attack in a not yet published book by an Australian anthropologist, Derek Freeman. The dispute has the trappings of scandal, because Mr. Freeman alleges that some of Miss Mead's findings are ''demonstrably false.''

title: VS SERVICES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
Hearing Is Held In L.I.R.R. Dispute
description: Leaders of unions still without contracts with the Long Island Rail Road explained at a hearing before the National Mediation Board yesterday at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel why they had rejected the recommendations of a Presidential Emergency Board toward a settlement.

title: RATES REDUCED 9% BY ALLIED VAN LINES
description: Allied Van Lines, the nation's leading mover, has cut its rates 9 percent, a move that industry leaders say could touch off airline-like price wars in an already depressed industry.

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC
description: BEETHOVEN was a different sort of genius from Mozart, for whom composing seems to have been eerily easy. Especially in his greatest works, Beethoven can often be heard struggling to do what he knew he must. Those messy notebooks of his testify almost too painfully to his battles with his material. There is even a sense in which it can be said that if a work such as the Ninth Symphony goes down too smoothly it has been done serious harm.

title: Loss Narrows At Texas Air
description: The Texas Air Corporation, the parent of Continental Air Lines and New York Air, said yesterday that it lost $17.4 million in the fourth quarter of 1982 compared with a loss of $25.7 million a year earlier. The company, citing sluggish traffic, industry fare wars and heightened competition, said revenues declined 13.2 percent, to $333.3 million, from $384.1 million.

title: SPARTAN MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After income of $325,000 from discontinued operations...C-Net income after loss of $717,000 from discontinued operations

title: REAGAN'S COGENT ANTI-COMMUNISM
description: To the Editor:

title: MIXED MEDIA: FOUR BENEFIT CONCERTS
description: AFTER Public School 122 was closed in 1976, the building at the corner of First Avenue and Ninth Street was transformed into the 122 Community Center, which houses five organizations, three of them artistic. One of them is Performance Space 122, which has become a lively center for downtown performance art, dance and music.

title: CENTRAL AMERICA: NEW U.S. 'LIP SERVICE'
description: To the Editor:

title: KENCOPE ENERGY COS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Oakland Paper's Chief Heading Purchase Deal
description: The publisher of The Oakland Tribune said today that he was heading a local group of investors to buy the faltering newspaper from the Gannett chain.

title: TRW RISES 17.1%
description: The Lockheed Corporation said yesterday that it earned $62.9 million, or $3.20 a share, in the fourth quarter compared with a deficit of $360.5 million in the corresponding 1981 quarter. The loss in the 1981 quarter included an extraordinary charge against earnings of $412 million from discontinuance of the company's L-1011 commercial aircraft operations.

title: FEDERATED GUARANTY LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STAGE: HARE'S 'FANSHEN' THE CHINESE REVOLUTION
description: ''EVERY revolution creates new words,'' writes David Hare in the published text of his play ''Fanshen.'' What makes this work so unusual is its author's insistence on examining a revolution - the Chinese - almost entirely in terms of its words, new and old. While ''Fanshen'' contains scattered gunfire, it generally portrays a nation's violent upheaval by showing us how one community searches for the language that's needed to institute a new order. It's not often that one sees a play in which a citizenry's decision to redefine the term ''middle peasant'' constitutes a major dramatic event.

title: CONGRESS CAUTIONED ON TRADE REPRISALS
description: President Reagan's Economic Report to Congress said today that this country's trade problems were not the result of unfair trade practices by other countries and that reprisals contemplated by Congress would hurt this country more than help it.

title: CLASSES FOR CHILDREN AND THEIR PARENTS
description: Parents who want to share a creative weekday or weekend with their children can choose from a variety of crafts and cultural programs being offered around town.

title: S.E.C. ACCUSES 13 OF INSIDER TRADING
description: The former chairman of the Texas International Company, George Platt, and Barry Switzer, the football coach at the University of Oklahoma, were among 13 people accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission of making an illegal $700,000 profit by trading on insider information in the stock of Phoenix Resources, an Oklahoma oil and gas company.

title: Durfee & Solow Gets $1 Million Lotus Job
description: Years ago, when he was United States ad director of the Fiat car, John A. Spiech was very impressed by James Durfee, a founder and president of Carl Ally Inc., his ad agency.

title: Cranford Man Guilty in Drowning
description: A Cranford man was convicted today of causing the drowning of a 17-year-old youth who was prevented from climbing out of a lake last spring after an argument about a campfire.

title: QUEBEC WORKERS REJECT PACT
description: Representatives of 85,000 nonmedical hospital workers voted today to reject a tentative agreement with the provincial government. They will decide Thursday whether to resume an illegal strike.

title: MAN AND SON FACING CHARGES ON SHELLFISH DUG IN JAMAICA BAY
description: A Queens man and his son were arrested early yesterday and charged with taking clams from unsafe waters in Jamaica Bay, according to a spokesman for the State Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: UTILITY INCREASES ATOM PLANT COST BY $500 MILLION
description: The estimated cost of the Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear power plant on Lake Ontario was raised by $500 million today by the principal utility involved in building it.

title: SALVADOR SETBACK AROUSES CONCERN OF REAGAN'S AIDES
description: Administration officials told Congress today that they were anxious about the situation in El Salvador following the fall of the southeastern town of Berlin to guerrilla forces.

title: '10 COMMANDMENTS' OF DUBIOUS ORIGIN
description: To the Editor:

title: MADELEINE GARDNER
description: Madeleine Gardner, former dean of University College at Adelphi University, died of cancer Saturday at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. She was 63 years old and lived in Garden City and Southampton, L.I.

title: Auto Recovery Pessimism
description: Nearly half of the 230 United States car dealers questioned in a survey believe auto sales will not rebound until next year, an industry trade journal said today.

title: COMPUTER MEMORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss; shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split on Nov 16

title: MICHIGAN ENERGY RESOURCES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
