description: B-Including income of $324,000 from discontinued operations...C-After a loss of$16.5 million from discontinued operations...D-Net income including income of $80,000 from discontinued operations

title: TRANS-CANADA PIPELINES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
PRECISION CASTPARTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHANGE IS HINTED IN ANGOLAN STAND
description: Angola is showing signs of accepting the Reagan Administration's basic principle that Cuban forces be withdrawn from Angola ''in parallel'' with a settlement on independence for South-West Africa, according to a State Department memorandum.

title: Fare Catalog Is Computerized
description: Official Airline Guides Inc. demonstrated a new electronic data bank yesterday that makes it possible for anyone with a computer terminal to find out the latest airline fares and schedules for every route in the world.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: APARTMENT dwellers who don't feel like making a trip to the basement laundry room or householders homebound by bad weather will find folding portable drying racks a boon. Several new racks hold more than towel bars, shower curtain rods or those little clotheslines favored by apartment dwellers.

title: CITY EMPLOYEES AMONG 7 HELD IN STAMP THEFT
description: Four employees of the city's Sanitation Department were among seven people charged yesterday in connection with the theft of $150,000 worth of postage stamps that were supposed to have been destroyed in a city incinerator.

title: CHESAPEAKE CORP OF VIRGINIA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Puerto Rican Bonds Yield Up to 10 3/8%
description: An unusually high-quality issue of tax-exempt bonds from Puerto Rico was tentatively priced yesterday with a maximum yield of 10 3/8 percent for bonds due in 2015, according to underwriters led by Matthews & Wright Inc.

title: Marsh Acquisition
description: Marsh & McLennan Companies said it had acquired National Economic Research Associates Inc., an economic consulting firm, for common stock valued at $18.7 million. Marsh said the new unit would become part of its Consulting and Financial Services Group, reporting to A.J.C. Smith, group vice president. It said Irwin M. Stelzer would continue as president of the subsidiary, which has more than 200 employees.

title: NICARAGUA SUPPORTED FOR $30 MILLION LOAN
description: A $30 million loan from the Inter-American Development Bank to Nicaragua, which the Reagan Administration has blocked twice in the last 18 months, will almost certainly be approved later this month, according to delegates to the bank.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE PARTNERS. Inside America's Most Powerful Law Firms. By James B. Stewart. 395 pages. Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: AS VIETNAM TRIES TO RESCUE ITS ECONOMY
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERNATIONAL RECTIFIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
ARMORED-CAR GUARD AND FRIEND ARRESTED IN $11 MILLION THEFT
description: The guard who was on duty on the night of an $11 million theft at a Bronx armored-car company and a friend of his were charged yesterday with stealing the money and attempting to camouflage the crime as an armed robbery.

title: DR. WILLIAM S. VINCENT
description: Dr. William Shafer Vincent, who in the 1950's was executive officer of the Citizenship Education Project, which was directed by Columbia University's Teachers College, died of respiratory failure Jan. 26 at St. Joseph's Hospital in Phoenix. He was 75 years old and lived in Rio Verde, Ariz.

title: ICY DAY
description: The lifeless bodies of Norman and Anna Peters were found, wrapped in tattered blankets against the January cold, on the icy seats of the dilapidated 1971 station wagon that had become their home. With no resources and no place to go, they had died of carbon monoxide poisoning, presumably while running the car's engine in an effort to keep warm.

title: MATHEMATICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TEXAS AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WESTMORELAND COAL CO reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income...C-Net loss

title: FOR LIBERALS, PARTY'S FEUD STILL A THREAT
description: ''Sure, there's a war, believe me, it's only just begun,'' said the Rev. Dr. Donald S. Harrington, the Liberal Party state chairman. The ''war'' pits Dr. Harrington and his allies in the Liberal Party against Raymond B. Harding, a vice chairman, who has been the de facto leader of the party, and his supporters. And it threatens the party's existence, according to some Liberal Party members.

title: Driver Wins Seven Races
description: John Campbell won seven harness races at the Meadowlands tonight to set a track record.

title: Timely Award
description: Dale Murphy picked the right time to be the National League's most valuable player. The center fielder could have been a free agent in a year, and the Atlanta Braves decided he was too valuable to lose.

title: WHERE TO FIND NEW YORK DEALERS
description: Following are the addresses of 50's dealers mentioned in the above article. Beige Gallery, 119 Greenwich Avenue, 212-691-5488.

title: LOUISIANA LAND OFFSHORE EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect the conversion of the company's convertible subordinated debentures

title: KUHLMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BORG SAYS TENNIS IS NO LONGER FUN
description: Last November, in a Stockholm hotel room, Bjorn Borg woke up one morning and told his wife, Mariana, that he wanted to retire from tennis.

title: ACTIONS TO BAN 'SILVER' TOWERS VOTED BY PANEL
description: Zoning amendments to ban ''sliver'' buildings - tall, narrow residences that tower above their neighbors - were approved unanimously yesterday by the City Planning Commission and sent to the Board of Estimate for final action.

title: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1983; The Economy
description: President Reagan, in his second Economic Report, voiced strong support for the Federal Reserve's efforts to foster recovery, rejecting charges that the Fed's current policy is inflationary. His chief economic adviser, Martin S. Feldstein, said recovery appears to have begun. (Page A1.) The report asserted that U.S. trade problems were not the result of other countries' unfair trade practices. (D19.)

title: CITY PROPOSAL TO REBUILD HARLEM GETS STONY COMMUNITY RESPONSE
description: A city proposal to foster commercial and residential development in Harlem has met with sharp community criticism, and Mayor Koch said yesterday that he was disappointed by the response.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 3, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad hoc committee on the Indian Ocean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: MONOCLONAL ANTIBODIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ACID RAIN FALLOUT: BIRTH OF A LOBBY
description: When confronted with a problem in the nation's capital, the thing to do is to lobby. When confronted with a really big problem, the thing to do is form an organization, enlist members, raise money, run a public relations campaign and then lobby.

title: Moving Misery in Africa
description: When times were good in Nigeria, in the 1970's, no one paid much attention to immigration laws. To find jobs and money unobtainable at home, more than a million unemployed Ghanaians were drawn to Lagos, Nigeria's booming capital.

title: Letter Bombs in London
description: Letter bombs were sent to the Soviet Embassy and the offices of the newspaper Soviet Weekly and were defused by bomb-disposal experts, Scotland Yard announced. A Scotland Yard spokesman said the devices were ''unlikely to kill'' but could have caused serious burns.

title: GRI CORP reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
Merger of Sorts In the U.S.F.L.
description: In Orlando, Fla., where the New Jersey Generals and the Boston Breakers share the same hotel and training complex, there is an easy way to tell the two fledgling United States Football League teams apart.

title: U.C.L.A. Center Faces Stress
description: Of all the conversations that have taken place between Stuart Gray, the 7-foot sophomore center for U.C.L.A., and Larry Farmer, his coach, perhaps the most productive one took place a little more than a month ago.

title: Technology; Car's Air Bag: How It Works
description: WHEN Mercedes-Benz announced last week that it would offer an air bag restraint system in some of its 1984 cars, company officials said they knew the move would intensify a debate that has been under way for the last 14 years. But, they said, the technology that is at the heart of the argument has been tested successfully in more than 20 million miles of driving, and the only thing that remains uncertain is customer demand.

title: AXIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
G.E. to Begin Engine Repairs
description: The problem that has led to the removal of some 10 of the General Electric turbofan engines that power the new twin-engine Boeing-767 airliner has been pinpointed and a solution worked out, a G.E. spokesman said late yesterday.

title: British Oil Output Up
description: British oil production rose 15.7 percent last year to top 100 million tons for the first time, the Department of Energy said today. Oil output was 103.4 million tons in 1982, up from 89.4 million in 1981. Domestic use of petroleum fell by 4.3 percent, to 19.3 million tons.

title: F.D.A.  D.A.  A.
description: Our President places great stock in voluntarism as a means of justifying drastic cutbacks in Federal programs for the poor and disadvantaged. But few people realize that his Administration relies on voluntarism to replace Government enforcement of major health and safety laws. Nowhere is this trend more evident than at the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Raises Won by Labor Are Lowest Since '68
description: Labor contracts negotiated for 3.3 million workers by unions last year produced average first-year pay increases of only 3.8 percent, the lowest since the Government began compiling such statistics in 1968.

title: POLICY ON NINTH GRADERS GETS TANGLED IN POLITICS
description: Ninth grade is education's in-between year, when some students remain in junior high school and others go on to high school. Educators cannot agree which approach works better.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: WHODUNITS

title: N.B.A. Decline Noted
description: In his 12 years as a pro, Fred Brown has seen better basketball than he has been seeing lately as a reserve guard with the Seattle SuperSonics, a team that has lost 13 of its last 15 games. Brown thinks he knows why the game is poorer.

title: No Headline
description: N. Carolina Rallies For 84-81 Triumph

title: MCI Places Order
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said it had placed its second major order for optical fiber, purchasing 90,000 miles of fiber and cable casing from the Siecor Corportion.

title: Thrift Unit Expansion
description: California Federal Savings and Loan Association, one of the nation's largest thrift units, was given Government permission today to expand its operations into Nevada. The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said it had let the Los Angeles-based company cross state lines to acquire Family Savings and Loan Association of Reno. It was the first interstate merger involving thrift units this year; there were 16 in 1982.

title: 4 Protesters Jailed For Damaging Sub
description: A judge today ordered four nuclear weapons protesters to serve one-year jail terms because they refused to pay for repairs to a Trident missile submarine they damaged at the Electric Boat shipyard here.

title: SOUTHWEST FOREST INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NELSON RESEARCH & DEVELOPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After tax credits of $3,000 for the qr and $5,000 for the yr...C-Net income which includes tax credits of $63,000 for the qr and $146,000 for the yr

title: Nephew of Mayor of Boston Discovered Slain in Jamaica
description: A Roman Catholic priest, who was a Boston native and the nephew of Mayor Kevin H. White of that city, was found beaten to death early today in the rectory of the church he served in Kingston, Jamaica, the police said.

title: BRIBERY PLOT CASE AGAINST U.S. JUDGE GOES TO JURY
description: A Federal jury today began deliberating the Government's charges against Alcee L. Hastings, the first sitting Federal judge to be tried on criminal charges. After deliberating for just over an hour, the jury recessed for the night.

title: AMERICAN BUSINESS PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ROGERS CABLESYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CRANSTON ENTERS PRESIDENTIAL RACE
description: Senator Alan Cranston declared his candidacy for the 1984 Democratic Presidential nomination today, saying his goal was ''to bring ourselves and our children out from the dark shadow of nuclear war.''

title: A Costly Canine
description: The $120,000 Greyhound Grand Prix, the most important event of the year in dog racing, will be held Saturday night at the Palm Beach Kennel Club in Florida. Eliminations over the last week have left eight survivors from the original field of 46 dogs from 23 tracks in 12 states.

title: 15 Are Injured In Manhattan Fire
description: A blaze that the Fire Department described as suspicious swept through a five-story apartment building at 25 Clinton Street on the Lower East Side just before 6 A.M. yesterday, sending five residents to the hospital. Seven other residents and three firefighters were treated at the scene of the fire.

title: CENTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $3,252,000 for the qr and 9 mos on the retirement of debt

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Desperation, Forgiven

title: THAILAND'S KUOMINTANG WARLORDS GO RESPECTABLE
description: Tigers and opium poppies abounded in the neighborhood when this mountaintop community in remote northern Thailand was settled in 1961. But the most dangerous creatures were the settlers - soldiers of the Chinese Nationalist Fifth Army who fled China, and later Burma, after Mao's victory in 1949.

title: The (Sigh) 1984 Campaign
description: When John Kennedy was elected President in 1960, a calendar joke made the rounds in Washington: First we'll have Jack for eight years, then Bobby for eight years, then Teddy for eight years -and then it will be 1984. Well, here it is 1983, Orwell's Big Brother is nowhere in sight and J.F.K.'s little brother is not running. But though the election is 21 months away, plenty of other people are and it's time (sigh) to look up. Formally, the 1984 Presidential campaign began yesterday.

title: HANNA MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a $36.9 million provision for a mine closing...C-Net income; In 1982, nonrecurring charges totaled $59.7 million, including the $36.9 million plant closing charge; the company in 1981 had nonrecurring gains of $10.4 million

title: SALVADORANS MOVE TO RECAPTURE CITY
description: A Government force of 1,500 to 2,000 troops reportedly began a counterattack today against the guerrillas who seized the southeastern city Berlin on Monday.

title: NICARAGUA SAYS EXILES STEP UP BORDER ATTACKS
description: A Nicaraguan official said today that anti-Sandinist exile groups had intensified their assaults this week on Nicaraguan military posts near the Atlantic coast where United States-Honduran maneuvers are under way.

title: SHOW CELEBRATES SCHOOL'S CRAFTSMEN
description: The current exhibition at the Craftsman's Gallery in Scarsdale, N.Y., is a celebration of the intensive arts and crafts program at the Rhode Island School of Design. Featured are 150 works by 50 graduates and former faculty members, most of whom have received international recognition and are represented in museums.

title: DANIEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: American Can Co., Greenwich, Conn., elected to its board Joseph A. Califano Jr., a Washington attorney and a former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare in the Carter Administration.

title: THE PRINCIPAL BENEFIT OF EDUCATION VOUCHERS
description: To the Editor:

title: For $75, Californians Get Time in Nicer Jails
description: Drunken drivers are being encouraged to pay $75 a day for the privilege of serving their sentences in local police station cells rather than in the crowded county jail.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1983
description: International Anxiety over El Salvador since guerrillas seized the town of Berlin Monday was expressed by Reagan Administration officials at a Senate hearing. Under angry questioning by several Senators, the officials acknowledged that American policy in El Salvador was ''confused'' and generated ''mixed signals.'' (Page A1, Col. 2.) The number of Ghanaians expelled by Nigeria might be as high as two million or more, according to Ghanaian officials trying to organize the often-chaotic repatriation of the refugees. The officials are trying to feed and cure and find transportation for the tens of thousands of refugees who pass each day through an improvised, sometimes violent, camp. (A1:3-5.)

title: INTERSTATE POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Founder of Heck's Retires From Chain
description: Fred Haddad, a founder of the Heck's Inc. discount store chain, retired yesterday with a $7.7 million payment, and Russell L. Isaacs succeeded him as chairman and chief executive.

title: CUBIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago shr earnings has been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in Oct

title: Correction
description: A recipe for braised calf's heart in Living on page 17 yesterday incorrectly described the cream to be used. It should be sour cream.

title: SELLING THE FABULOUS 50's
description: XCEPT for Stanley Coren, who was born in 1920, most of the dealers now stocking furniture and accessories from the 50's were children when the objects they sell made their debut. Yet, to them, that era of design represents one of the last great sentimental periods, a time of optimism, innocence and exuberance.Indeed, the 50's were a decade of discovery, the problemsolving age, when good design, household gadgets and mass-produced products became popular, when cars and toasters, ice buckets and coffee tables reflected a similar style. The kidney, amoeba and boomerang forms that developed in the late 40's became the signature shapes in furniture and accessories of the next decade.

title: U.S. AND CHINA AGREE ON NEED FOR 'SOLID AND ENDURING' TIES
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Foreign Minister Wu Xueqian agreed today at the outset of four days of talks that, despite problems and disagreements, Chinese-American relations ''should continue to develop on a solid and enduring basis.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * Burroughs Corp. said it had introduced a new computer in its B-90 series of small-business computers, the B-96, which has three times the main memory and twice the speed of the other B-90 models.

description: B-After securities losses of $12,624 for the qr and $13,994 for the yr...C-Net income

title: TREASURY ISSUES RISE IN PRICE
description: Signs of revived investor demand for Treasury securities led to a sharp increase in prices and a drop in yields for notes and bonds yesterday afternoon.

title: WALKER, HIRAM, RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KENNETH F. GAUTIER
description: Kenneth F. Gautier, a former senior vice president at United States Lines Inc., died of cancer Friday at his home in Manhattan.

title: BUSINESS EXECUTIVES SEEK TIGHT CONTROLS ON MILITARY BUDGET
description: A group of businessmen gathered in a Fifth Avenue apartment Tuesday night to support a new organization pledged to lobby for costeffective management of military spending and for reducing the risk of nuclear war.

title: THE HAZARDS AND PAINS PLAGUING AN ACTOR'S LIFE
description: YOU do tend to forget that every trade or profession has its special little hazards, its particular pains. I was reminded of the fact while watching Eli Wallach, who is an actor, playing an actor in Murray Schisgal's ''Twice Around the Park.'' Mr. Wallach, I thought, was bringing a special pathos to a part he thoroughly understood, having - no doubt - suffered all the vicissitudes of a player's life during his score or more of years on the boards.

title: U.S. Satellite Receives $45 Million Investment
description: The United States Satellite Television Corporation said yesterday that the Prudential Insurance Company of America had made a $45 million investment in the company, thereby becoming its largest investor.

title: Koch Nominates 4 For Judgeships
description: Mayor Koch nominated four people yesterday for judgeships in Criminal and Family Courts.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Detroit Pistons vs. San Diego Clippers, at Pontiac, Mich. The lastest report is that Bill Walton, the Clippers' center who is attempting another comeback, will sit out the game on his doctor's orders. (Television - USA, 8 P.M.).

title: Washington Unites to Salute Redskins
description: It is one measure of the following enjoyed by the Washington Redskins that students were allowed to skip school today to watch their Super Bowl victory parade, getting permission from the same schools that refused to allow them to attend President Reagan's inauguration two years ago.

title: INSTRUCTIONAL TAPES FOR HOME TV USE
description: ALONG with movies - recent hits like ''Chariots of Fire'' and vintage fare like ''Casablanca'' - there is a growing selection of instructional programs available for playback on home video equipment. The how-to demonstrations, typically conducted by experts, are viewed with a video-cassette recorder or videodisk player hooked up to a television set.

title: GOTT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DEFENSE FOR EX-C.I.A. AGENT TO CALL RAMSEY CLARK
description: The defense for Edwin P. Wilson, the former intelligence agent charged with smuggling 20 tons of plastic explosives to Libyan terrorists, indicated today that it would call another former agent and a former Justice Department official to bolster its contention that Mr. Wilson acted as a ''de facto C.I.A. agent'' when the shipment was made in 1977.

title: QUOTRON SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results reflect a 2-for-1 stock split on Oct 19, 1982

title: ASIA'S GROWING TASTE FOR BEER
description: The Japanese love baseball and the Japanese love beer. It is the kind of winning combination that the Anheuser-Busch Company, the owner of the St. Louis Cardinals and America's best-selling beer, hopes to exploit next week when a delegation of former and current Cardinal players, including Stan Musial and Lou Brock, and the team's manager, Whitey Herzog, arrive in Japan for a weeklong promotion of Budweiser beer.

title: A MARINE, PISTOL DRAWN, STOPS 3 ISRAELI TANKS
description: A United States Marine Corps captain drew and loaded his pistol, then climbed aboard an Israeli tank near the Lebanese University Library in Beirut and ordered an Israeli lieutenant colonel to remove his three tanks, the Defense Department reported today.

title: SAB HARMON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-There are no comparable results because the company changed its fiscal yr-endto Dec 31 from Sept 30; for the yr ended Sept 30, 1981, the company reported a net income of $1,395,458 or 60 cents a shr, which includes a gain from discontinued operations of $20,801 on sales of $29,844,865

title: Rangers Score but Struggle
description: For the Rangers recently, if it isn't one thing it's another. For eight games, they had a serious problem with scoring goals. Now they have started scoring them again, but they cannot keep them out of their own net.

title: Pope Refuses to Cut Number of Holy Days
description: Pope John Paul II made last-minute changes in the revised code of canon law, rejecting a recommendation that the Roman Catholic Church reduce the number of holy days of obligation from 10 to two, church sources reported today.

title: Justice Powell Suspends Alabama School Prayer
description: A Supreme Court Justice today ordered a halt to state-sponsored prayer sessions in Alabama public schools.

title: HOLLYWOOD TAKES ON HBO
description: It has always been rough to break into the movies, and no welcome mat was put out in the early 1970's when Time Inc. started a subsidiary to show films on cable television. But today, Home Box Office, the largest pay television network and a moneymaker for Time, is firmly entrenched in Hollywood - and the movie companies are fighting back.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I have several brass floor lamps that have dark spots. Does this mean the brass coating has worn away, and is there any way to remove the dark spots?

title: No Headline
description: Bolivia Delays Ouster Of Ex-Chief of Gestapo

title: JUDGE ORDERS TWO WOMEN JAILED FOR FAILING TO TESTIFY ON F.A.L.N.
description: A self-described ''revolutionary'' was immediately ordered to jail by a Federal judge yesterday after he found her in contempt of court for refusing to testify before a grand jury looking into the F.A.L.N., the terrorist group seeking independence for Puerto Rico.

title: G.M. Canada Plan
description: General Motors of Canada Ltd. will begin a $150 million change-over of its Oshawa assembly operations Aug. 4 to eliminate production of large cars in favor of midsized models, a spokesman said. The production shift would result in a 12-week layoff of about 3,800 workers at the plant. The change-over, presented today to the United Automobile Workers union, is consistent with reports that its parent company, the Detroit-based General Motors Corporation, plans to phase out production of X-cars and concentrate on smaller J-car or A-car midsized models.

title: Comptroller Supports Mutual Fund's Bank Tie
description: J.& W. Seligman & Company, a New York mutual fund adviser, was given Government permission today to set up a national bank, but only to manage private trusts and corporate investment portfolios.

title: Milers Returning
description: The exciting high school mile in last Friday night's Wanamaker Millrose Games will be replayed Feb. 12 in the Vitalis/Olympic Invitational track meet at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. The first five finishers in the mile have accepted invitations to the Olympic Invitational's schoolboy 1,000 meters.

title: UNION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,264,000 for the qr and $2,409,000 for the 6 mos, and extraordinary credits of $518,000 for the qr and 6 mos...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $568,000 for the qr and $812,000for the 6 mos...D-Net income

title: Harvester Sells Some Operations
description: The International Harvester Company said it had sold its Springfield, Mo., engine and enginepart remanufacturing operations to a new company, the Springfield Remanufacturing Center Corporation. It said the new company had been formed by a group of employees at the parts remanufacturing facility.

title: TRUCKERS' STRIKE DELAYS SOME GOODS
description: Sporadic gunfire rang out today as new violence accompanied the attempted shutdown of the nation's trucking system.

title: Dow Closes at 1,062.64, up 2.85
description: The Dow Jones industrial average closed 2.85 points higher yesterday, at 1,062.64, propped up by an institutional buyer's large purchase of stocks in the last 15 minutes of trading.

title: MILLER TECHNOLOGY & COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Swiss Chocolate Sales
description: Sales by Switzerland's 18 chocolate makers fell 1.5 percent in volume in 1982, to 76,605 tons, but rose 1.9 percent in value from the year before, to 861.1 million francs, or about $424.8 million, the industry's association said today.

title: BUSH SAYS REAGAN ARMS OFFER STANDS
description: Vice President Bush, responding to the Soviet rejection of President Reagan's proposal of a worldwide ban on medium-range nuclear missiles, said today that the offer held, but that the United States would listen to any serious new plan from Moscow.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Streetwise

title: Required Reading; A Momentous Day
description: Senator Rudy Boschwitz, Republican of Minnesota, in remarks to the United States Senate, Jan. 31: Mr. President, yesterday was a momentous day in my life, in the life of my family and, indeed, in the annals of the entire world, because yesterday marked the 50th anniversary of the rise to power of Adolf Hitler. Fifty years ago yesterday, Adolf Hitler became Reichs Chancellor of Germany.

title: Milan Questions a Turk In New Plot on Pope
description: A Turkish citizen detained on suspicion of plotting to kill Pope John Paul II in Milan next May was questioned for three hours today, according to ANSA, the Italian news agency.

title: MANHATTAN DEFEATS HOFSTRA BY 77-69
description: Manhattan ended a three-game losing streak tonight with a 77-69 victory over Hofstra. The Jaspers relied on the accuracy of Brinton Huggins and Tim Cain, who combined for 53 points.

title: Comings and Goings
description: A search committee is looking for a successor to the late Paul (Bear) Bryant as athletic director at Alabama.

title: EXXON AND MOBIL TO PAY LESS FOR OIL
description: The nation's two largest oil companies, the Exxon Corporation and the Mobil Corporation, said yesterday that they were reducing by $1 a barrel the amount they are willing to pay for domestically produced crude oil.

title: COMMUNICATIONS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bridge: Minneapolis 'World Series' Saw a Homer at the Tables
description: During the International Team Trials in Minneapolis last fall, a local television announcer described the event as the ''World Series of Bridge.'' It was a fair enough description.

title: AMERICAN STATES LEASING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LOCKHEED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $412 million for the qrand $466.3 million for the yr and an extraordinary gain of $22.8 million for the yr from a debenture exchange

title: FMC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $7 million for the qr and $37 million for the yr

title: UNITED STATES TOBACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $2,650,000 from discontinued operations; the results for 1982reflect a decrease in the tax provision, amounting to 5 cents a shr, resulting from settlement of certain state taxes; shr earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split which occurred on Jan 24, 1983

title: VOLCKER ASKS MORE I.M.F. AID
description: New lending resources for the International Monetary Fund to help debt-plagued countries pay their bills represent a ''bail-in'' for commercial banks and not a ''bailout,'' Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, asserted today.

title: PROFILE OF ONE COLLECTOR AND HER PASTIME
description: ''I'M crazy about these things,'' Giuliana Bertoni said of her 50's finds. ''The colors, shapes and patterns are so happy-looking, so unusual, so extroverted.''

title: WHEN AIDING LATINS
description: President Reagan certified two weeks ago that El Salvador has made reasonable progress in securing human rights. Congress requires this official certification every six months as a condition for further military aid. Yet, although addressing an important question indeed, the requirement is beside the point. It concerns symptoms, not the causes of human rights violations.

title: No Headline
description: JOHN H. COLBURN

title: POPE JOHN PAUL INSTALLS 18 AS CARDINALS
description: Pope John Paul II bestowed the scarlet skullcap and biretta of a prince of the Roman Catholic Church today on 18 cardinals whom he named last month, among them an American, Joseph L. Bernardin, Archbishop of Chicago.

title: HOMESTEAD FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $666,000

title: 'JOSEPH RETURNS'
description: ''When Joseph Returns'' was shown as part of the 1977 New Directors-New Films Series. Following is the review by Vincent Canby in The New York Times of April 15, 1977.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of Rear Adm. Harmon B. Sherry on Monday incorrectly identified his wife. She is Marjorie J. Sherry.

title: LETTERS FROM KEAN SEEK $1,000 GIFTS
description: The Republican State Committee has sent letters signed by Governor Kean to 12,000 business and professional leaders across the state, promising access to himself, his cabinet, Federal officials and legislators for a minimum annual gift of $1,000.

title: FRENCH INVITE THINKERS TO CULTURAL MEETING
description: Intellectuals from non-Communist countries have been invited to Paris by the French Government to discuss how culture can help alleviate the world's economic crisis.

title: STOCKMAN HINTS REAGAN MIGHT GO FURTHER ON JOBS
description: David A. Stockman, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, told Senate Democrats today that an emergency job bill should be aimed at the areas of highest unemployment and should offer temporary, not permanent, help.

title: Great Northern Paper Selects New President
description: The Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation, a leading paper maker, has named Peter F. Yacavone president. He succeeds Robert Hellendale, 65, who continues as chairman and chief executive.

title: Farmers' Profits Rose in 1982
description: Farmers' net income actually rose last year instead of declining as earlier estimates had indicated, according to revised figures, but it may show little change this year, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: No Headline
description: McEnroe and Lendl Gain in Pro Indoor

title: BOLD AFRICAN DIPLOMACY
description: An intricate and ambitious diplomatic venture, one that could affect all of southern Africa, is now approaching the decisive stage. South Africa and the United States, acting separately but in close coordination, are talking with Angola about proposals to stop the fighting there, have Cuban forces leave and bring the neighboring territory of Namibia to independence.

title: Brazil Owes $83.8 Billion
description: Brazil's short- and long-term foreign debt totaled about $83.8 billion at the end of last year, according to central bank preliminary figures published today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Labor of Love For Works of a Genius

title: SUBURBAN AIRLINES reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Sports of The Times; Mancini Reacts To More Tragedy
description: Not that he will ever forget Duk-Koo Kim's death, but until last weekend Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini thought that he might not be asked much about it anymore. Over in San Vicente, Italy, up in the Alps near the Swiss and French borders, where the World Boxing Association lightweight champion has been training to oppose George Feeney of England in a 10-round nontitle bout Sunday, his Italian heritage had eased his escape from the questions. Over there he's been a charming celebrity.

title: DETECTOR ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REAGAN MEDICARE PROPOSALS ARE BROADLY CRITICIZED
description: President Reagan's proposals to reduce the growth in Medicare costs by increasing premiums and other charges to elderly patients were sharply criticized today by several members of Congress and by health professionals.

title: GLENN ON ISRAEL
description: In a year-end ''office pool'' published in this space, I offered as a choice for neatest political trick of the coming year ''John Glenn's attempt to keep Democratic power brokers awake as he explains why he is not anti-Israel.''

title: U.S.-CHINA TRADE DOWN 5.5%
description: Trade between the United States and China in 1982 fell slightly, for the first time in six years, to $5.2 billion, according to figures issued today by the United States Embassy here. The total was down 5.5 percent from the record high of $5.5 billion in 1981.

title: KNICKS DOWN SPURS
description: The Knicks' plan tonight was to disrupt Artis Gilmore and to drive the San Antonio Spurs' 7-foot-2-inch center out of the middle.

title: Three Officials in Florida Charged in Bribery Case
description: Three of Hillsborough County's five commissioners were arrested Tuesday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and charged with accepting a bribe for a favorable rezoning vote.

title: POGO PRODUCING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TENNESSEAN WAS PERSISTENT IN EFFORT TO BUY A THIRD OF U.P.I.
description: According to John Jay Hooker, a Tennessee businessman and political figure who has bought a one-third interest in United Press International, he has been interested in running the news service for at least three years.

title: Rock's New Stir
description: I n a rite going back to the Beatles and the early days of Frank Sinatra's career, 3,500 screaming adolescent girls flooded Kennedy International Airport yesterday morning to greet the latest heartthrobs - a rock group of five 15-year-old boys from Puerto Rico called Menudo. Eventually, 80 police officers were called to the Eastern Airlines Terminal.

title: Lollar Wins a Raise
description: Tim Lollar, the pitcher who won 16 games for San Diego last season, has won his salary arbitration case from the Padres.

title: Joe Clark Is Replaced By Canada Opposition
description: Former Prime Minister Joe Clark was formally replaced as opposition leader today. He was succeeded by Erik Nielsen, a 58-year-old Yukon lawyer who will head the Progressive Conservative Party in the House of Commons until an open convention chooses someone to take the party into national elections, probably within a year.

title: American Airlines
description: American Airlines reported that its traffic rose about 13 percent in January, to 2.7 billion passenger miles, from 2.4 billion passenger miles in January 1982. The airline, a unit of the AMR Corporation, also said its load factor rose 4.1 percent, to 63.3 percent, in January. The airline attributed the heavy volume to low fares and the return of many travelers from vacation.

title: AUGAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REAGAN WILL STUDY PROJECTS SPEEDUP TO MAKE NEW JOBS
description: In response to growing Congressional pressure for programs to create jobs, President Reagan has ordered a study of whether to speed up Government construction projects to make jobs available sooner than scheduled.

title: SEIBELS BRUCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After capital losses of $3,600,000 for the qr and $3,300,000 for the yr and again of $14,000,000 for the qr and yr from the sale of part of the company's interest in Policy Management Systems Corp...C-Includes capital gains of $116,062 for the qr and $232,477 for the yr, and a gain of $2,900,000 from the sale of part of the company's interest in Policy Management Systems Corp; shr earnings have been adjusted for a 25 percent stock divd paid last month

title: OFF-DUTY OFFICER KILLS ASSAILANT
description: An off-duty police officer shot and killed a man when he lunged at her with a screwdriver as she was walking to her apartment in upper Manhattan shortly after midnight Wednesday, the police said yesterday.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 4, 1983
description: International Americans and Israelis agreed to build a formal boundary to separate their military forces in an effort to avert confrontations. The accord came after a series of incidents in which Israeli forces tried to patrol in and around the zone controlled by the 1,300-man Marine Corps contingent of the international peacekeeping force in Lebanon. (Page A1, Column 1.) Salvadoran troops reoccupied the smoldering town of Berlin after 500 guerrillas who seized it on Monday withdrew, according to the Government commander. He said that fighting erupted as some of his 1,000 troops pursued the retreating rebels, and reported that 3 of his soldiers were killed and 13 wounded. He put the guerrilla casualties at 50. (A1:2-3.)

title: LOGICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $94,000 for the qr and $537,000 for the 9 mos

title: News Analysis
description: In the politically charged maneuvering over arms control, both President Reagan and Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, have sometimes dangled the prospect of a summit meeting to sway public opinion, but so far neither side is visibly engaged in serious preparations for such a meeting.

title: Telecom Spending
description: Northern Telecom Ltd. announced plans to increase its capital spending by 23 percent, to $310 million, in 1983. It also said research and development spending will rise to $285 million from $241.4 million last year. Walter F. Light, chairman, told a group of analysts that net research and investment spending was expected to average 9 percent or more of revenues over the next few years.

title: CITY SCHOOLS BEGIN A VARIETY OF MEASURES TO CUT TRUANCY
description: New York City school officials yesterday announced new measures designed to cut down on truancy by forcing greater cooperation between schools and parents.

title: WILLIAMS COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMERICAN STANDARD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
British Woolworth
description: Woolworth Holdings P.L.C. said it was changing the head office and regional management structure of its wholly owned subsidiary F.W. Woolworth P.L.C., centralizing ''essential services'' in London and causing 550 layoffs here, in Birmingham and in Liverpool. Several departments will be trimmed and a new product and market research department will be formed, the comany added.

title: Companies Plan European Venture
description: Telefunken, the United Technologies Corporation and the Diehl Group said they had agreed in principle to form a joint venture company, Eurosil Electronic G.m.b.H.

title: Budget Office Recovery View
description: The Congressional Budget Office predicted today that the nation's economic recovery would be stronger, at least in the short term, than the Administration itself projected in President Reagan's 1984 budget.

title: 11 SCHOOL YEARS: BOON TO PUPILS
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRST BOSTON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Topics; Second Acts; Contempt
description: Attorney General William French Smith has preached consistently against judicial activism. Don't go running to court for an injunction every time you feel pain, he tells Federal lawyers.

title: GUNMAN KILLS FOUR AND WOUNDS A FIFTH AT A WEST SIDE HOTEL
description: A porter at an Upper West Side residential hotel shot four people to death there yesterday morning, beginning with his wife, a young man and a girl in his apartment and ending five hours later with the hotel's owner, the police said.

title: DELTA DATA SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $229,000 for the qr and $94,000 for the 9 mos...C-Including extraordinary credits of $235,000 for the qr and $796,000 for the 9 mos

title: 10 INSPECTORS IN FIRE DEPT. ARRESTED FOR TAKING BRIBES
description: Ten Fire Department inspectors and 12 plumbing contractors were arrested yesterday on bribery charges and accused of overlooking possible safety violations at more than 50 apartment buildings in Manhattan.

title: STATE'S POLICING OF HUDSON POLLUTERS ASSAILED AS LAX
description: Most of the major industries and cities that discharged pollutants into the Hudson River in a two-year period ended in September 1981 exceeded the levels permitted by the state, according to a private environmental group.

title: INVITING LATIN EXTREMISTS
description: From the very beginning, rolling back the revolutionary tide in Central America has been a cornerstone of Ronald Reagan's foreign policy. Yet a recent trip to the region convinced me that the measures taken to shore up forces perceived as friendly to the United States have had the opposite effect.

title: Article 208356 -- No Title
description: Christopher Durang, author of the Off Broadway play ''Sister Mary Ignatius Explains It All for You,'' has won a $25,000 prize from the Kenyon Theater Festival in Gambier, Ohio, for his work in the theater. Joanne Woodward, chairman of the 1982 festival fund, will present the prize to Mr. Durang at a Feb. 14 gala in the Rainbow Room. The prize will be awarded annually to a promising American playwright. Mr. Durang will also share a $25,000 grant from the Hale Matthews Foundation with the playwrights Albert Innaurato, James Lapine, Ted Tally and Wendy Wasserstein.

title: GENERAL RE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BUCKET THEATER TO SHOW ITS STYLE
description: There is more to black dance today than the popular jazz and modern-dance vignettes that evoke the seamier side of life, strutting their characters across the stage to rock songs. Eleo Pomare, for instance, makes dance portraits of everything from a hunted motorcyclist to an Edward Hopper painting. And the choreographer Garth Fagan blends familiar Afro-Caribbean and modern dance elements in a new and distinctive abstract-dance style.

title: Nikolai A. Dondukov, 54, Dies; Was Soviet Aviation Official
description: Nikolai A. Dondukov, a deputy minister of the Soviet aviation industry, died Sunday, the newspaper Sotsialisticheskaya Industriya said. He was 54 years old.

title: ELEGANT RETURN FOR THE CHOKER
description: First it was sleeves that looked like hot-air balloons, then it was the bustle. Thus it is not surprising to encounter the Edwardian dog collar and the pearl choker these days at dressed-up parties.

title: Bridge: A World Title Can Depend On Where One Card Lies
description: In bridge, as in many other aspects of life, an apparently trivial factor can turn out to be of substantial importance. Examining the deal shown in the diagram, one would not think that South's diamond ten has a crucial role to play. But it does.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $27,700,000 for the latest yr and $23,200,000 for the 1981 yr

title: Mt. St. Helens Explosions End Long Quiet Period
description: Mount St. Helens shook with two explosions today that spread a dusting of ash up to 100 miles away and sent a stream of mudfive miles down its snow-covered slopes to Spirit Lake at the volcano's base. The activity ended the volcano's longest quiet period since its eruption in May 1980.

title: ..OR EFFICIENCY AT THEIR EXPENSE?
description: To the Editor: Education Commissioner Ambach's proposal to require children to enter the first grade one year earlier, at age 5, and be graduated from high school at 16, at the completion of the 11th grade, is a shocking example of educational efficiency at the expense of educational effectiveness.

title: GULFSTREAM LAND & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DUN & BRADSTREET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ANDERSON ASSERTS CUOMO IS FAVORING CITY IN HIS BUDGET
description: Warren M. Anderson, the leader of the Republican majority in the State Senate, said yesterday that the state budget proposed Monday by Governor Cuomo benefited New York City at the expense of the rest of the state.

title: RAIL STOCKS CLIMB
description: Stock prices advanced moderately in slower trading yesterday, buoyed by growing optimism that the economy was improving. Helping the upswing were reports that the nation's top four retailers had their best sales gains in January since last summer and that new auto sales for January were up over their 1982 level.

title: Chiefs Get New Coach
description: The Kansas City Chiefs dipped into Tom Landry's staff today and appointed John Mackovic their new head coach.

title: Loss Reported By Grumman
description: The Grumman Corporation said yesterday that it had a net loss of $5.6 million in the fourth quarter, after a loss of $4.2 million from discontinued operations and a loss of $27 million on disposal of assets. A year earlier, Grumman earned $2.7 million, or 18 cents a share, after a loss from discontinued operations of $21.2 million.

title: AMERICAN GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago per shr figures include a gain of 19 cents a shr on the sale of a subsidiary

title: MILD WEATHER BREAKS THE ICE AND A RECORD
description: The signs at the lake in Central Park still said ''Danger, thin ice, keep off.'' But some of them, tacked to police barricades which had once stood on the ice, barely poked through the water's surface yesterday.

title: READING & BATES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a $20,986,000 writeoff of certain foreign petroleum properties for the qr and yr, and gains from the sale of tax benefits of $6,800,000 for the qr and 8,900,000 for the yr

title: DESOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $910,000 for the qr and $2,689,000 for the yr and a gain of $6,743,000 for the yr from a plant fire...C-After a loss of $8,820,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $1,858,000 from a plant fire

title: Inside Japan's Theater
description: ''The World of Japanese Theater,'' an exhibition of costumes, masks, prints and musical instruments, will be on view tomorrow through April 17 at the Queens Museum in the New York City Building in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park.

title: MARRIOTT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for 1982 include a gain of 7 cents a shr resulting from several nonrecurring items

title: BREZHNEV SOUVENIR: VAST, LIMPING TRUCK FACTORY
description: There is an element of irony in the choice of this place to perpetuate the memory of Leonid I. Brezhnev. It could as easily serve as a memorial to his hopes for detente and the pitfalls of planning on a giant scale.

title: At Houston, 'Gliding' for Slam Dunks
description: The mock Phi Slamma Jamma fraternity at the University of Houston is headed by Clyde Drexler, an education major, because he is the slammingest and jammingest of the basketball players who comprise the membership. The junior forward has been the delight of the hometown fans with 32 of the team's 105 dunks in 19 games this season.

title: Market Place; Debt-Free Companies
description: THE Masco Corporation, which makes faucets and other products for home and industry, acquired Evans-Aristocrat Industries in December, and more recently it agreed to buy the Brass-Craft Manufacturing Company.

title: DATA SWITCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in Dec 1982

title: FIELDCREST MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Advertising; Parker Brothers Diversifies
description: AS it moves with strength into its 100th anniversary year, Parker Brothers, the Beverly, Mass., games experts, is making a major diversification move into children's book publishing. And it plans to add an ingredient that it believes has been missing in the field up to now -aggressive marketing.

title: PRIMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes an extraordinary gain of $5,900,000 for the cummulative effect of anaccounting change on yrs prior to 1982

title: Sony Delays Plant
description: The Sony Corporation said it had postponed indefinitely the start of construction work on a planned color television manufacturing plant outside Columbia, S.C. The original $20 million plan announced last year called for work on the plant to start early this year, with production to begin in late 1983 or early 1984.

title: Puerto Rico Bond Yields Are Cut
description: Strong demand for a $203.5 million issue of Aa-rated Puerto Rico Housing Finance Corporation bonds enabled underwriters, led by Matthews & Wright, to reduce yields yesterday by as much as 15 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.

title: BACK TO GOVERNMENT RULE OF THE ECONOMY
description: To the Editor:

title: CHELSEA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: B-After a loss of $229,000 on the recall of debentures and a nonrecurring gain of $820,000 or 34 cents a shr from the sale of a plant

title: FOLK MUSIC: THEODORE BIKEL
description: THEODORE BIKEL'S digressive style of folk presentation weaves songs, stories and remarks into a kind of variety show with a humanistic-historical perspective. Sunday, in the Merkin Concert Hall of the Abraham Goodman House, Mr. Bikel performed a program heavily dominated by Jewish folk music. The evening featured several ''macaronic'' songs that start in one language and go over to another.

title: First Boston's Profit Up 42.2%
description: First Boston Inc. said yesterday that its profit in the fourth quarter rose 42.2 percent to a record $34.7 million, or $6.46 a share, from $24.4 million, or $4.30 a share, in the comparable quarter a year earlier. Revenues rose 56.2 percent, to $178.1 million, from $114 million, in the same period, it added.

title: TEXAS EASTERN CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: Results for 1982 reflect a nonrecurring reduction of $25,000,000 and a provision of $20,400,000 for possible impairment of exploration investment in Sudan and to resolve S.E.C. dispute over North Sea exploration and production accounting

title: POP JAZZ
description: WHEN the Nigerian guitarist Sunny Ade started his own band in 1966 it had eight members, a large number for a band playing the current style of Nigerian dance music, juju. Over the years, though, Mr. Ade added more congas, guitars (including Hawaiian steel guitar), talking drums, maracas and vocals. Tonight, when King Sunny Ade and his African Beats perform at the Savoy - for one of the most eagerly anticipated concerts in recent memory among fans of funk, new wave and pop - they will be 20 strong.

title: U.S. AND ISRAEL SAY THEY'LL ERECT LINE
description: American and Israeli diplomats agreed today to build a formal boundary to separate their military forces in an effort to avert further confrontations between them.

title: Appeal on Schwab
description: The Securities Industry Association, alleging that the Federal Reserve Board did not have authority to approve the BankAmerica Corporation's acquisition of Charles Schwab & Company last year, appealed the decision in the Second Circuit Court of Appeals in New York. The motion contends that the Fed's approval represented, in effect, a change in long-standing banking and securities laws that separate banking and investment brokerage activities.

title: Teacher Is Voted Union City Mayor
description: A 44-year-old high school social studies teacher today was named Mayor of this Hudson County community that has lost two chief executives in recent months when they were convicted on Federal charges.

title: PARTY WHERE BABIES BRING THEIR MOTHERS
description: Carriages and strollers were double-parked recently in the outside hall and foyer of Judy Garb's West Side apartment. Inside, nine babies, ranging in age from 3 to 17 months, and their mothers mingled. The occasion: a mothers and babies party.

title: JAPAN'S GOOD REASON TO CONTINUE WHALING
description: To the Editor:

title: Semiconductor
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said the antitrust division of the Justice Department had requested more information on its bid to purchase up to two-thirds of Data Terminal Systems Inc.'s shares. Both companies said they planned to comply with the request. National Semiconductor agreed Jan. 17 to buy up to 4.3 million Data Terminal shares at $8 each through its new N.S. Development Corporation subsidiary, conditioned on receiving at least 2.7 million.

title: Satellite Channels Acquired by MCI
description: The MCI Communications Corporation, turning to satellites to insure capacity for its long-distance telephone network, today announced one of the largest purchases of satellite channels ever.

title: 2 GUNMEN KILLED IN SHOOTOUT WITH POLICE IN JERSEY
description: Two armed robbers broke into a home on a quiet street this morning, shot and seriously wounded a policeman who responded to a call from a tenant in the house, and then were killed in a fusillade of police gunfire after a five-mile chase.

title: SARAJEVO AND ST. PETER'S
description: In London last week, a British historian warned against pursuing the facts of ''the Bulgarian connection'' in the assassination attempt on Pope John Paul II.

title: Washington Post Net
description: The Washington Post Company reported today that net income for the fourth quarter of 1982 rose 23 percent from a year earlier, to $22.2 million, or $1.57 a share, from $18.1 million, or $1.28 a share. Revenue increased 3 percent, to $224.8 million, from $218.1 million.

title: KILLER TRUCKS, INDEED
description: The American Trucking Associations has responded with outrage and specious ''facts'' to the assertion in this space on Jan. 16 that Congress had unleashed ''killer trucks four times more lethal to human life than a passenger automobile and exponentially more destructive of the roads than any other vehicle.''

title: Public Approval of President Is Found at New Low of 37%
description: Public approval of President Reagan's handling of his job has slipped to a new low, according to the latest Gallup Poll. It found that in mid-January only 37 percent of the public approved of his conduct of the Presidency.

title: N.H.L. Fines Devils And Flyers $2,000
description: Since it was unable to identify the first player to leave the bench at the outbreak of a brawl between the Devils and the Flyers in Philadelphia last week, the National Hockey League yesterday took an unusual step and fined each team $2,000.

title: SALVADORAN TROOPS REOCCUPY CITY AFTER WITHDRAWAL OF 500 REBELS
description: Salvadoran troops walked into this smoldering city Wednesday evening after 500 guerrillas who seized it on Monday withdrew southward, the commander of the Government operation said here today.

title: No Headline
description: WILANDER OUSTED IN U.S. PRO

title: Suffolk Is Shut
description: Horse racing at Suffolk Downs has been canceled until Feb. 11 because of drainage problems. Track officials had thought they had prevented such problems by installing a $1 million all-weather strip. But the combination of heavy rain and unseasonably mild temperatures has turned the strip into a quagmire that, according to Dan Bucci, the track's assistant general manager, is too soft to support the pounding of a horse's hoof.

title: ART: THE SILK ROUTE'S TANTRIC PATHS
description: A SHOW that deals with the spread of Buddhism and its art from India to the countries of Central Asia is not exactly calculated to queue viewers around the block. Yet the topic, until now somewhat neglected in New York, seems to be one whose time has come. Last spring, the Metropolitan Museum staged ''Along the Ancient Silk Routes,'' drawn from the archeological collections of the West Berlin State Museums, and now the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, has opened another stunner, ''The Silk Route and the Diamond Path'' (through April 3), a show that covers the same geographical territory, but with a different emphasis.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 4, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Non-Use of Force - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Cuts at Allied Unit
description: Linotype Paul Ltd., a subsidiary of the Allied Corporation of the United States, is cutting 500 jobs at its two computerized typesetting factories in Cheltenham, the domestic news agency reported.

description: The Dow Chemical Company, which said its business was hurt by the worldwide economic slowdown, reported yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter of 1982 plunged 80.6 percent, while revenues were off 14.4 percent.

UNDAUNTED BY TREE, WATSON CARDS A 67
description: A 9-iron approach shot Tom Watson struck to the 18th green of the Cypress Point Club today hung in a tree and cost him a double bogey - and a share of the lead in the opening round of the 42d Bing Crosby National Pro-Am.

title: 'VIDEODROME,' LURID FANTASIES OF THE TUBE
description: WHEN Max Renn, the hero of David Cronenberg's ''Videodrome,'' stumbles across a Malaysian television station that appears to be broadcasting pure sex and brutality, he is stunned. ''Torture, murder, mutilation!'' he exclaims. ''Brilliant! Absolutely brilliant, and almost no production costs. Where do they get actors who can do this?'' Later on, in a cooler moment, he contemplates this new form of programming and murmurs, ''I think it's what's next.''

title: EFFORT TO QUASH GORSUCH CHARGE BALKED IN COURT
description: Congress won a round in court today in its effort to press a contempt citation against Anne M. Gorsuch, the Environmental Protection Administrator.

title: Military Aide in Suriname Is Said to Commit Suicide
description: Suriname's deputy army commander, Maj. Roy Horb, who had been accused of plotting to oust the Government, hanged himself in his cell Wednesday night and judicial authorities opened an investigation into his death, officials said today.

title: AIR FORCE STUDY SAYS BUDGET, UNCUT, STILL WON'T BUY ARMS IN 5-YEAR PLAN
description: An Air Force study group has concluded that even if Congress does not cut the Reagan Administration's planned military budgets in the next five years, there will not be enough money to buy the planes, missiles and other Air Force equipment contemplated in the Administration's five-year military plan.

title: PAN AM'S LOSS REACHES $272.9 MILLION IN PERIOD
description: Pan American World Airways yesterday reported a loss of $272.9 million in the fourth quarter, much greater than the $82.8 million loss a year earlier and somewhat worse than analysts had expected. Pan Am said the loss was widened by $118 million in special charges.

title: A NAUTICAL LOOK, FROM MICHIGAN, FOR S.I.'S BAY STREET
description: It has fallen to a 32-year-old lawyer from Michigan, backed by a small band of Michigan colleagues, to succeed as the first developer of waterfront housing near the ferry terminal on Staten Island.

title: AMETEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PUBLIC SERVICE CO OF NEW HAMPSHIRE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Topics; Second Acts; Elephant Updates
description: Elephants, once they reach maturity, are not cute. They are dignified. Even one commanded to stand on hind legs conveys an air of noblesse oblige.

title: EGYPT CUTS PRICE
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation has reduced its purchases of North Sea oil in a move intended to put pressure on Britain to reduce oil prices, traders said yesterday.

title: NO WORK. NO HOPE
description: He is 44, white, married, the father of three - two sons and a daughter - all teenagers. His wife is 42. They were both born in a suburb to the west of Boston, met on a blind date in Framingham, also to the west of Boston, and now live in a small town about 15 miles further west. Lately, the word ''west'' has figured prominently in their lives.

title: N.F.L.'s Unsigned At Record Level
description: In normal years, National Football League players and their agents do most of their contract negotiations before and during training camps. That way, most players begin the season with a signed contract.

title: HUDSON COUNTY PROSECUTER EXONERATED
description: Harold J. Ruvoldt Jr., the suspended Hudson County Prosecutor, was acquitted by a Federal jury in Newark last night of charges that he extorted $115,000 from a New York real estate developer in 1979, before he became Prosecutor, to facilitate the construction of shopping malls in New Jersey.

description: The yr-ago results were restated for the acquisition of B.E. Industries on May 18, 1982

title: RABBI SEES WAYS TO GOD FOR DOUBTERS
description: Rabbi Adin Steinsaltz is a diminutive man with a frolicsome spirit and a mind that scans the wisdom of centuries. As a former mathematician who has been hailed as one of the great modern scholars of the Talmud, he walked the path of religious conversion that he now commends to Jews living in a secular age.

title: CONCERT: WASHINGTON MUSIC ENSEMBLE
description: THE ''Scandinavia Today'' celebration has been by no means confined to New York. In mid-January the Washington Music Ensemble, a chamber group based at the American University in Washington, presented three programs of modern Scandinavian music at the university, and Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall the ensemble culled a single-evening highlights program for New York.

title: Crime Victims Need Help, Not Slogans
description: To be a victim at the hands of a criminal is a nightmare. But to then become a victim at the hands of the criminal justice system is an unforgivable travesty. It makes the criminal and the criminal justice system partners in crime.

title: BIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Crossing Some Wires AManhattan lawyer, often in Federal courts, was stopped by a metal d etector yesterday at the Federal Courthouse in Brooklyn. The lawyer,w ho asked to remain nameless, said he had ''got rid of two sets of k eys, a coin purse with change and three small batteries - everythingm etallic but the zippers on my clothing.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Advertising column in Business Day Tuesday gave an incorrect address for Geers Gross Advertising. It is 220 East 42d Street.

title: CORRECTION
description: A an article Tuesday about tourism in Puerto Rico incorrectly described the situation at the Carib Inn Hotel. The hotel, taken over on Dec. 8 by International Hotels of Puerto Rico Inc., is no longer in bankruptcy proceedings, is being refurbished, has opened a nightclub and casino, and reports its occupancy rate as 70 percent.

title: VOCALIST: BILLY ECKSTINE AT 68
description: ALTHOUGH Billy Eckstine will mark his 50th year in show business next fall, his appearance this week and next at Dangerfield's is the first time that he has performed at Rodney Dangerfield's First Avenue club.

title: Globetrotter Arrested
description: Nate Branch, the playing coach of the Harlem Globetrotters, was arrested at Tucson International Airport Wednesday night and charged with possession of two grams of cocaine and two ounces of marijuana.

title: U.P.I. Bureau in Warsaw Closed by Government
description: The Polish authorities closed United Press International's bureau here today, saying the news agency's operation in Warsaw would remain suspended until a correspondent of the official Polish press agency, P.A.P., was allowed back into Washington.

title: Dollar Bonds Firm in Europe
description: Fixed-interest dollar Eurobonds ended firmer today, but were below the day's highs because of disappointment that United States credit markets failed to extend Wednesday's late recovery, dealers said.

title: Albert D. Mehegan Dies at 96; Was F.B.I. Agent for 53 Years
description: Albert D. Mehegan, who served as an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation for 53 years and worked on the investigation of John Dillinger and other underworld figures, died Monday at his home here. He was 96 years old.

title: Profits Scoreboard

description: GEORGE BALANCHINE'S ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' made its first appearance this season Wednesday night with the New York City Ballet at the State Theater - the only full-evening work in the current repertory.

title: NEW REPUBLICAN CHAIRMAN WANTS THE WORD FROM REAGAN ON 1984
description: The new chairman of the Republican National Committee called upon President Reagan today to let the party know ''quite soon'' whether he planned to seek re-election.

description: B-Includes a gain of $12,500,000 for the qr and yr from the sale of tax creditsand a gain of $3,200,000 for the yr from the sale of aircraft

title: Morris's Mother Dies of Cancer
description: Jacquelyn Revis, mother of the imprisoned former football star Eugene (Mercury) Morris, died of cancer Tuesday at St. Francis General Hospital here.

title: What's Good for Mercedes ...
description: America's auto makers, waging a long and thus far successful war against the air bag safety restraint, argue that the systems cost too much and don't work well. Besides, Big Auto insists, nobody wants the darned things except a bunch of self-appointed consumer advocates.

title: Yankee-Alabama Game
description: The Yankees announced yesterday that they would play an exhibition game against the University of Alabama baseball team in Tuscaloosa on March 10.

title: A SHOW FOR CANOES
description: F or those who enjoy moving along a river or a lake without the snarl and fumes of an outboard motor, the 22d Annual Canoe and Kayak Show, Paddlesport '83, will provide a chance to look at some of the craft that have evolved since World War II.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Amcon Group Inc., a subsidiary of Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C. of Britain, said it had increased its stake in Newmont Mining Corp. to 25.1 percent of the common stock through open-market purchases.

title: STAGE: 'ICE CAPADES' AT THE GARDEN
description: WHEN a spectacle has been around 43 times, as the count stands for the unquenchable Ice Capades, which opened this week at Madison Square Garden, there is an implicit challenge, for show and for showgoer. So, what else is new? It is, perhaps, a particular challenge to the American thirst for change in comparison with such European staples as Unter Oberammergau, which got away with the same script for so many eons, but there it is.

title: EXHIBITION: STILL LIFES BY ITALIAN OLD MASTERS
description: MOST people think of still life as incidental to Italian old-master painting. From Botticelli's ''Spring'' to Titian's ''Three Ages of Man'' and Tintoretto's ''Susannah and the Elders'' and on to Caravaggio, there are passages of still life that we never forget. But the action lies elsewhere - in the human figure, in the play of the seasons and in the thunderous drama of Italian architecture.

title: Optimism in rug market.
description: A TURKISH rug woven for Sultan Muhammad V at the turn of the century may sell for $250,000 or more - which would be the highest price ever paid for a carpet at auction in the United States - when it comes up for bidding on Feb. 12 at 2 P.M. at Sotheby Parke Bernet, York Avenue at 72d Street. The palace carpet, which will be exhibited tomorrow through next Friday, is a silk Hereke, measuring 18 feet 8 inches by 12 feet 1 inch. Made to present to the Sultan, who ruled from 1909 to 1918, the rug of bold greens, golds, red and royal blue is awash with stylized flowers and geometric motifs. It also bears two poetic inscriptions to the Sultan, which translate to read, ''I would not worry for the sorrows of the world when I have such a king as you, so benevolent, so good'' and ''Muhammad Khan Sultan Jahan the glorious, with his bow, he has conquered the sky.''

title: Reliance Stake
description: Saul P. Steinberg, the New York businessman, reported through his Reliance Financial Services Corporation that he controlled more than 1 million shares, or 7.85 percent, of Paine Webber Inc.

title: BIG 3 CAR SALES ADVANCE 10%
description: The nation's Big Three automobile manufacturers reported today that sales were up 10 percent in the Jan.21-31 period from the same 1982 period, marking the 10th consecutive 10-day selling period of improved sales.

title: Who Gets the Money
description: The Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance system, or Social Security, as it is commonly called, touches the lives of vast majority of Americans. About 115 million workers and their employers pay taxes into the system. About 36 million retired people, disabled workers and their families receive monthly benefits. Most people receive much more money in benefits during their retirement years than they ever paid in Social Security taxes. The size of retirement and disability benefits are based largely on the income the recipients earned while they were working. People who had high incomes generally receive larger retirement checks than those who made less. But lowincome workers receive at retirement a larger percentage of what they once earned than those who made more money. In recent years, the high rate of inflation has driven benefits up, and the high rate of unemployment has reduced the amount of taxes paid into the system by workers and employers. As a result, the Social Security system has been taking in, and it has had to borrow funds to cover the monthly checks it sends beneficiaries. In Washington this week, the House Ways and Means Committee began hearings on legislation that would reduce benefits and increase revenues so that they system would once more be on a sound financial footing. The Congressional debate is expected to last through the spring. The charts on this page, devised by Nancy Lee, graphics editor of The New York Times, provide an overview of the Social Security system, its history and the reasons for its current financial difficulty.

title: Times Proposes Extension of Pacts
description: The New York Times has proposed a three-year extension of its labor contracts with pay increases totaling $110 a week during that period.

title: RECITAL: MARLBORO'S VERMEER QUARTET
description: THE Vermeer Quartet lived up to its name in Merkin Hall Monday n ight. The music played by these string players was given a texture t hat was as luminous and evocative as their namesake's paintings.

title: PUBLISHING: AGENT SAYS WRITERS ARE CHEATED
description: IN a book to be published this month by Houghton Mifflin, the literary agent Richard Curtis charges that ''publishers have always cheated authors,'' that ''some publishers are still cheating authors'' and that ''many authors are being taken for a ride that I estimate to be in the millions.'' The book is ''How to Be Your Own Literary Agent,'' and in it as well as in an interview Mr. Curtis, the agent for John Jakes and other writers, said that publishers cheated authors by withholding royalties and by withholding from them such vital information as the number of copies printed, distributed, sold and returned. The worst offenders, he said, are paperback publishers.

title: CORRECTION
description: The caption on a picture of Mayor Koch in Metropolitan Report Wednesday gave an incorrect address for the Bronx Museum of the Arts. Its new quarters are at East 165th Street and the Grand Concourse.

CRUCIAL $1 IN A SOCIAL SECURITY PROPOSAL
description: To the Editor: One recommendation in the compromise package of the National Commission on Social Security Reform is to subject 50 percent of the Social Security benefit to income tax in the case of an individual whose income exceeds $20,000 a year and a couple whose income exceeds $25,000 a year. The stated purpose is to recapture a portion of the benefit from the more affluent beneficiaries. v. ithout going into the validity of the purpose, examination readily reveals serious flaws in the proposed methodology. The recapture, as we are given to understand, is to be achieved by adding 50 percent of the Social Security benefit to the adjusted gross income, which then becomes subject to the progressive income tax.

Mr. Blake was quick to insist on a more precise count. ''Ninety-eight and a half, Mr. President,'' he interjected.

description: All week, Democrats and Republicans have been trying to capture the initiative on the jobs issue, at least for the moment the paramount political matter on Capitol Hill. So far, there has been a lot of talk and no action, but all the sound and fury does signify that politicians have read the election returns and do not want to head into the next election cycle without established credentials as a benefactor of the unemployed.

title: Innovative Italian and Art Deco chic.
description: IN the last 20 years, New York has had a great increase in the number of elegant restaurants that have made the luxurious food of northern Italy well known here. Chefs in these newer restaurants rely on costly ingredients, such as cream, butter, white truffles, wild mushrooms, game and fairly complex, showy sauteed preparations, many of which are prepared at the table. But the opening four months ago of Castellano on 55th Street, between the Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue, has introduced to New York yet another version of Italian elegance derived from chic restaurants in Venice and Milan. The style of cooking at this already jammed restaurant, is based on light and simple casalinga (home-style) dishes that do not require costly ingredients.

title: Dome to Sell Stake
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said it and Dome Canada Ltd. would file a preliminary prospectus for a secondary public offering to sell about half of their Transcanada Pipelines Ltd. shares. The two together hold about 20.6 million Transcanada shares, or 46 percent of the total.

title: AN OUTSIDER (SOON TO BE AN INSIDER) STIRS CONCERN
description: The West Wing of the White House, where President Reagan's staff works and tries to decipher America, has all the comforts of Plato's cave. Here are some thoughtful human beings with strong yearnings to shape the Republic, chained to the very heart of the shadow world of Washington politics.

title: CABARET: INSTRUMENTAL COMBINATIONS
description: HANRATTY'S, the restaurant at Second Avenue near 91st Street where solo pianists such as Dick Wellstood, Ralph Sutton and Dave McKenna usually provide the musical entertainment, has just wound up an unusual week in which each solitary pianist was joined by a horn - Mr. Wellstood by the clarinetist Kenny Davern for a night, Mr. Sutton by the cornetist Ruby Braff for a night and by the saxophonist Eddie Miller for two nights while Mr. McKenna was also paired with the saxophonist Dick Johnson for three nights.
