description: The Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Group, Connecticut's largest corporate employer, announced today that it would reduce its work force by 2,300 employees, primarily in Connecticut. The cutbacks will be accomplished by a combination of early retirements and layoffs.

title: BETHLEHEM TO CLOSE 2 MILLS IN MARYLAND
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation announced today that it will stop manufacturing pipe at its Sparrows Point, Md., plant in about three months, putting more than 800 people out of work.

title: Doctor Is Sought In Brink's Hearing
description: A Federal warrant was issued yesterday for the arrest of Dr. Alan Berkman, a physician who has been accused of treating some of the suspects in the Brinks's robbery and murder case in Rockland County.

title: Excerpts from Bush speech, page 5.
description: Vice President Bush, pressing the Soviet Union to revise its positions in the arms reduction talks here, met with the chief Soviet negotiators today and told them the United States was ''deadly serious'' about achieving weapons cuts.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 43. 1. The man in white tie and tails, pictured above, was dressed in sportswear on a red-letter day. Identify him and explain. 2. In one of the largest forced migrations in Africa since the mid-19th century, as many as two million refugees are returning to their homeland from a nation that is the continent's wealthiest and most populous. To what country are they returning, what country are they leaving, and what is the reason for the exodus?

title: Firkusny Recital Is Reset
description: Rudolf Firkusny's piano recital tonight at 8 o'clock in the 92d Street Y has been canceled because of illness and rescheduled for March 27 at 3 P.M. Tickets for tonight will be honored on the new date.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT DOWN IN NEW YORK STATE AND JERSEY
description: The unemployment rates in both New York State and New Jersey dropped last month, but there was little change in the number of people holding jobs in the two states.

title: KNICKS TRIUMPH, 120-101
description: The inside game of Bill Cartwright and Len (Truck) Robinson, who were more dominant than at any time this season, resulted in 50 points tonight and led the Knicks to a 120-101 victory over the Dallas Mavericks tonight.

title: COPPERWELD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; the 1982 results included an extraordinary net charge of $5,688,000 for an unfavorable antitrust decision against the co; the 1982 loss also included a charge of $1,663,000 from closure costs related to the shutdown of tubingfacilities in the Southeast

title: HIGH U.S. ENVIRONMENTAL OFFICIAL QUITS UNDER FIRE
description: Rita M. Lavelle, assistant administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency for solid waste and emergency response, resigned today.

title: News Analysis
description: Politically, the drop in the unemployment rate has strengthened President Reagan's hand for the present and evidently reinforced his resolve to preserve his basic economic strategy in the face of criticism and challenges from Congress.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Identity Regained

title: FUGITIVE INDIAN LEADER SEEKS A REFUGE UPSTATE
description: The 400 or so Onondagas who live here on a sprawling reservation are being drawn into a dispute between a fugitive Indian leader and white authorities that has origins a decade old and 1,000 miles distant in the Black Hills of South Dakota.

title: Times Co. Data Bases Licensed to Mead
description: The New York Times Company has granted the Mead Corporation an exclusive license to sell and distribute its three electronic libraries.

title: HANOI BATTLES CAMBODIANS FOR 3 DAYS IN THAILAND
description: International aid workers here said today that Vietnamese troops and tanks had been battling Cambodian insurgents just inside Thailand for the last three days.

title: 'WINDS' GAINS AS A BOOK, TOO
description: ''The Monumental Best Seller'' - as a new Pocket Books cover describes Herman Wouk's novel ''The Winds of War'' - is about to get more monumental.

title: CRIME IN SUBWAY STATION RISES IN SPITE OF TV MONITORS
description: Can closed-circuit television cameras help fight crime amid the platforms, pillars and passageways of the New York subway system? At the 59th Street-Columbus Circle station, the preliminary answer has been negative.

title: CREWS SELECTED FOR 2 SPACE SHUTTLE MISSIONS
description: Astronauts who flew on the fourth and fifth flights of the space shuttle Columbia were named today to command the 11th and 12th shuttle missions in January and March of next year.

title: Texaco of Britain
description: Texaco announced it would build a new $150 million oil refinery in Wales that will cut the lead content of its gasoline sold in the British market. Lead released into the air from car exhausts can be a health hazard, and Parliament ruled recently that beginning in 1986 oil companies must reduce the lead content of their gasoline. Texaco Ltd., the British subsidiary of the New York-based company, said the catalytic reforming unit at Pembroke, south Wales, would enter service in 1985 with a capacity of 35,000 barrels a day.

title: REAGAN DEFENDS MARINES IN DISPUTES IN BEIRUT
description: President Reagan today defended American marines involved in recent disputes with Israeli troops in Beirut and said the incidents underlined the need for foreign forces to withdraw entirely from Lebanon.

title: ARA SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings are fully diluted

title: E.J. Junior Admits Having Cocaine
description: E.J. Junior, a linebacker for the St. Louis Cardinals and former all-American at Alabama, was sentenced to two years in prison after pleading guilty today to a charge of cocaine possession.

title: WESTERN CASUALTY & SURETY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from investments of $1,862,732 for the qr and $2,037,004 for theyr...C-After losses from investments of $1,697,463 for the qr and $919,476 for the yr

title: Editors' Note: Publishers' View
description: In editing to fit available space, two balancing paragraphs of the Publishing column were omitted from Weekend yesterday. The paragraphs, which should have appeared at the end of the column, said:

title: Shuttle Crew to Carry Spare Spacesuit Torso
description: Space agency officials, trying to make sure they can overcome any more spacesuit failures, said today that a spare spacesuit torso would be carried on the next shuttle mission. A faulty spacesuit forced cancellation of the first scheduled sojourn by astronauts outside the spacecraft on a shuttle mission.

title: PEERLESS CHAIN CO reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
NEWFOUNDLAND TELEPHONE CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
INTERNATIONAL INCOME PROPERTY reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
GUARDSMAN CHEMICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STEAK 'N SHAKE INC reports earnings for QTr to Dec 22
description: The yr-ago qr ended Dec 31 includes an additional seven days of operation compared to the latest qr ended Dec 22 as a result of the company's adoption of 13 four-week accounting periods

title: McEnroe Gains
description: The defending champion, John McEnroe, serving sharply and angling his drives, eliminated Eliot Teltscher, 6-3, 7-6, tonight to reach the semifinals of the $375,000 United States Pro Indoor tennis championships.

title: Shamrock Corp.  Planning Cuts
description: The Diamond Shamrock Corporation said it was studying divestiture of its specialty chemicals businesses and will cut its work force by about 500 employees this month to improve productivity. The company has 14,800 employees.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Initially I thought that the piece might have been written by another Mozart, possibly the great composer's father, but our research has shown that the way the music is written, its type and moods, make us certain that the piece is genuine.'' - Gunnar Thygesen, librarian of the Odense Symphony in Denmark. (11:1.)

title: Bolivia Expels Nazi Sought by France
description: Klaus Barbie, sought by the French Government for war crimes during the Nazi occupation, was expelled from Bolivia today and put on a plane bound for France, Interior Minister Mario Roncal announced.

title: Let Lever House Stand
description: Manhattan changes so fast that practically any building that survives 30 years qualifies as a historical freak. Yet even hardened New Yorkers were shocked to learn that decent people hope to demolish Park Avenue's Lever House and replace it with a bigger, perhaps more useful building.

title: U.S. SAYS EX-BOSTON OFFICIAL TRIED TO THWART GRAND JURY TESTIMONY
description: The United States Attorney here charged today that a ''politically active former city official'' visited another city employee in jail to discourage him from testifying before a Federal grand jury about corruption in Boston.

title: Bridge: New York Loses Weichsel, But a Partnership Goes On
description: One of the country's greatest players was lost to New York recently when Peter Weichsel took up residence in North Miami Beach. This has meant a separation, but not a complete divorce, in his highly effetive partnership with Alan Sontag, who remains in New York City.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Coed Rush at Columbia

title: VIRTUOSITY AND FAME CAME EASILY TO THE YOUNG VLADIMIR HOROWITZ
Quotation of the Day
description: ''Reaganomics - somewhere along the line our economic program got tagged with that label.

title: Four Soup Kitchens Opened In Philadelphia to Feed Poor
description: For the first time since the Depression, the Salvation Army has opened four soup kitchens in Philadelphia to provide at least one daily meal for people without jobs or money.

title: WEIGHING ANCHOR FOR A MAJOR DOWNTOWN ATTRACTION
description: THE evolving South Street Seaport is already the city's leading s howplace of maritime history, but the construction now under way is l ikely to catapult it this summer to a new plateau as an urban a ttraction. And the summer of 1984 will bring an even more dramatic t ransformation.

title: No Headline
description: Arthur T. Hadley's memoir reminded me of my first haggis, in Scotland, during the summer of 1970.

title:
TV VIEW;
'THE WINDS OF WAR'-OPEN TO QUESTION, BUT OFTEN IMPRESSIVE
description: The operative word for Herman Wouk's ''The Winds of War'' is Big. Beginning tonight at 8 on ABC and continuing each night of the week through next Sunday, for a total of 18 hours, this is obviously a gigantic project for television. And, as the network is well aware, it will demand an enormous commitment on the part of viewers wanting to watch all seven episodes. In contrast, ''Gone With the Wind'' was a mere vignette. For that reason, the advance publicity and hoopla on ''The Winds of War'' has been nearly as massive as the project itself. The result, while not as artistically impressive as ''Brideshead Revisited,'' is less manipulative than ''Hololcaust'' and at least as emotionally compelling as ''Roots.''

title: AN UNLIKELY ANALYST
description: MARIE BONAPARTE A Life. By Celia Bertin. Illustrated. 286 pp. San Diego: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $17.95.

title: Bossy's Season Isn't First-Team
description: To the Sports Editor: After reading of Mike Bossy's ''disappointment'' in not being selected to represent the Prince of Wales first team all-stars, I was left disgusted with the all-star selection process and the reasoning it has produced (''A Disappointed Bossy Makes His Case,'' The New York Times, Jan. 29).

title: Diaspora Museum
description: To the Editor:

title: An Opening In the Forest
description: Conservationists charged that the Agriculture Department distorted a Federal court decision last week when it announced that it would abandon a five-year-old wilderness designation program and institute a new one to re-evaluate areas already designated.

title: No Headline
description: Andrew Malcolm's article inadvertently suggested one reason the United States auto industry is having trouble.

title: THE BIG DEFICITS WILL GET SCANT SUPPORT
description: THE 1984 Federal Budget is evidence that President Reagan intends tos tick to his guns despite diminished popular and Congressional s upport. The new budget extends the President's economic policies andp riorities without significant compromise or concern for political r ealities. Thus, like last year, Congress is confronted with tough c hallenges - but the mood and composition of this year's Congress is c hanged.

title: VARIATIONS ON THE NEW DEAL WILL INCLUDE NO PAT HANDS
description: WASHINGTON AS one of its first legislative acts, the House of Representatives of the 98th Congress last week voted to establish a new committee to study the needs of children, youth and families. Congress has created numerous programs and spent countless dollars on such problems. But today appreciation for the fiscal limits of government is growing. ''Take education,'' said Representative George Miller, the California Democrat who heads the new panel. ''We can pour billions and billions into the schools, but if families don't support the schools, there is not much we can do. The idea that government is the 100 percent solution is no longer viable.''

title: TOUCHY QUESTIONS CONFRONT JOB SEEKERS
description: DO you have a good appetite? How are your table manners? Do you believe in the second coming of Christ? Are you a good mixer? How's your sex life?

title: CHALLENGING THE GIFTED
description: WHILE reading '' 'Surplus Ducklings' and the Schools'' recently on the Opinion Page, I felt compelled to rebut the opinion of a 15-year veteran teacher. Virginia Perreca made an analogy of her experience with ordering ''surplus ducklings'' from a university to the teaching of gifted and talented students. She questioned: ''By constantly experimenting with new methods of teaching, new programs with new priorities, do we not risk producing a generation of ''surplus ducklings?''

title: FOCUS IS ON COUNTRY ITEMS
description: TWENTY years ago, any collector on the hunt for fine examples of American flint glass and whale oil lamps had little difficulty finding decorative examples. But today, both lighting devices and glass made in this country before and during the 1840's are good small antiques seldom offered in mint condition.

title: ARTICLE ON ABORTION DRAWS READERS' REPLIES
description: Grace Dermody had many of her facts wrong. The Plainfield Planned Parenthood people said that the article was incorrect about pregnancy being safer than an abortion, and the North Jersey GYN Center in Irvington said: ''All the fetal tissue goes to a crematory and is not used for cosmetics or for experiments.''

title: ALLURE OF THE WHISKERED
description: WITH a New England winter under way, many men may be pondering a parody of Hamlet - to beard or not to beard their faces. It is a question studied by every man who has nearly qualified for a certificate in first aid, merely by coping daily with the nicks, scrapes and other ills that shaven flesh is heir to.

title: KITE LEADS BY 2 ON A RECORD 62
description: In intermittent rain and on a golf course soaked by recent storms, Tom Kite shot a record 62 today and took a two-stroke lead over three other players in the third round of the 42d Bing Crosby National Pro-Am.

title: Developing Respect For Colonial Markers
description: Russell Glitman's article (''Old Markers Imperiled,'' Jan. 9) describing conditions endangering the long-term preservation of our colonial tombstones addresses a very real problem. Though punitive measures are now under consideration in New England legislatures for those convicted of vandalism or theft, with offenders facing jail sentences of up to five years or fines up to $3,000, shouldn't specific preventive actions also be contemplated and put into practice before more senseless destruction occurs?

title: A TOWN VS. A REGION
description: IS Stamford Darien's problem? The question is at the heart of a dispute involving both towns and the advisory planning unit for lower Fairfield County. At issue is the character of Darien as a community almost entirely composed of single-family homes on fairly spacious lots - homes that are worth an average of $165,791, according to the 1980 census. Some resolution may come tomorrow night, when the planning agency is to vote on a proposed regional plan of development that includes the disputed proposals for Darien.

title: Sissy Bostwick Plans Wedding in April
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. George H. Bostwick of Old Westbury, L.I., and Aiken, S.C., of the engagement of her daughter, Marie Stokes Bostwick, to Charles M. Armstrong, son of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Armstrong of Kingsville, Tex.

title: KEMP SEEKS STABILITY AMID YANKEE TUMULT
description: YESTERDAY, Steve Kemp got married. Today, he shaves off his beard. T omorrow? He can start thinking about the next milestone in his life:M aking his debut with the Yankees as a million-dollar-a-year free a gent and, some people suspect, as the designated replacement for R eggie Jackson.

title: Library Gets Tough on Fine
description: Flagrant violators of notices to return books to the Page Public Library could face a fine of $300 and 30 days in jail under a new ordinance.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: WINDMILLS, BRIDGES, & OLD MACHINES Discovering Our Industrial Past. By David Weitzman. Illustrated. 114 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $13.95. (Ages 11 and Up)

title: A May Wedding For Jane Sandler
description: Mr. and Mrs. Barry Sandler of Newton Highlands, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Sandler, to Alexander Charles Frank, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Frank of Weston, Mass. The wedding is planned for May.

title: No Headline
description: Thanks to Russell Baker for his humorous, yet thoughtful, article. Inflation, including current commercial rents, is removing highly skilled artisans from the ranks of entrepreneurs.

title: Last of Soviet Satellite Is Expected to Burn Up
description: The highly radioactive final piece of the Soviet spy satellite is expected to burn up in the atmosphere sometime between Monday morning and Wednesday morning, Air Force officials said Friday.

title: AN EXPERIMENTAL OUTPOST LOOKS BACK
description: As decades go, the 1960's may not have been the profoundest in recent art history, but it was certainly one of the liveliest. It started out with a bang: the self-destruction of Jean Tinguely's suicide machine at the Museum of Modern Art (1960); and it ended noisily, too, with demonstrations echoing the spirit of rebellion in the larger world by artists fired up over the Vietnam war and the small representation of women and black artists in museums. It had a swarm of movements: Happenings, Pop, Color Field, Op, Minimal, Psychedelic, Kinetic, Funk, Conceptual, and numerous ways of promoting them, from the savvy exhibitions initiated in 1962 by the late Alan Solomon at the Jewish Museum to the ambitious performances staged by artists involved with the special-effects-loving group known as Experiments in Art and Technology.

title: NATURAL GAS: A WINTER OF DISCONTENT
description: BLUNK NO. 1 gas well sits forlornly in a snowy field in the outskirts of Hardtner, a small town some 100 miles southwest of here. The well's gray painted valves, meter shed and other equipment are idle and show the rusty signs of deferred maintanance. Although it's the middle of winter, Blunk hasn't produced any of its dirt-cheap gas since Jan. 17.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: SPRUCING up the state's image has been one of Governor Kean's pet themes. For starters, his administration junked ''New Jersey's Got It,'' the slogan trumpeted by Brendan T. Byrne's administration.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: POP MUSIC Arto Lindsay never won any awards as a singer when he was leader of the influential avant-garde rock band DNA. In fact, his deliberately pinched timbres, wildly careening phrasing, guttural attack and fondness for melodies that tug, push and get all twisted up in themselves made his vocals every bit as quirky as the sounds he got by scraping at his deliberately out-of-tune electric 12-string guitar.

title:
GARDENING;
GROWING STRAWBERRY PLANTS FROM SEED
description: LAST year it was potatoes; this year it is strawberries: It is possible for the homeowner to grow both these plants from seed. The new Explorer potato is said to have met with only modest success last year. It remains to be seen how well the new Sweet Heart strawberry will do, since it has not generally been available until this year.

title: GEORGE CUKOR'S LOVING MARRIAGE TO THE MOVIES
description: Garson Kanin is a screenwriter and novelist.

title: G.O.P. MINORITY ELEVATES 4
description: FOUR Long Islanders have emerged as key leaders and staff members in a drastic shake-up of the Assembly Republican leadership and staff.

title: Record for Miss Lynch
description: Shola Lynch, the 13-year-old from Hunter College Junior High who set a national age-group record for the 1,500-meter run three weeks ago, lowered the mark yesterday at Pratt Institute. In leading 228 qualifiers into the Colgate Women's Games finals at Madison Square Garden March 7, she ran the distance in 4 minutes 36.7 seconds, 1.4 seconds faster than her time Jan. 15.

title: REAGAN EXPANDING TRIDENT PROGRAM
description: The Reagan Administration has embarked on an increasingly ambitious and costly program to build more powerful Trident submarines and missiles than previously disclosed, according to Administration and Congressional officials.

title: Sports of the Times; Is Baseball Using a Double Standard?
description: IN the 1950's, New York baseball fans argued heatedly and zealously over which center fielder was better - the Yankees' Mickey Mantle or the Giants' Willie Mays. No one ever won the argument, except in his own mind, but Mays and Mantle will forever be linked in many minds. Now they seem destined to be linked in another way. Mays, since 1980, has been forced to live in exile from the game he enlivened, and Mantle, who equally enlivened it, presumably teeters on the brink of joining him on Bowie Kuhn's Elba.

title: CONDOMINIUM STUDY TURNS THE SPOTLIGHT ON RENTERS
description: AFEAR that the growing number of renters now living in condominiums m ay jeopardize both the quality of life and the financial well-being o f these communities has prompted two organizations to look for ways t o deal with the problem.

title: Kathryn B. Smith To Marry in May
description: The engagement of Kathryn Ballard Smith to Edward Davis Ryan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ryan of Baltimore, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Jennings Talbot Smith of Pelham Manor, N.Y., parents of the bride-to-be.

title: Purdue Elects 9th President
description: Dr. Steven Beering, dean of Purdue University's School of Medicine, was named the school's president Friday. Dr. Beering, who is 50 years old, will be the university's ninth president. He will take office July 1, succeeding Arthur G. Hansen, who resigned last year.

title: Martha B. Gerson, a Lawyer, to Marry Charles F. Lufkin, Investment Banker
description: The engagement of Martha Blythe Gerson, an associate with the New York law firm of Shearman & Sterling, to Charles Francis Lufkin, a New York investment banker, has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel C. Gerson of Millersville, Md., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Col. and Mrs. Daniel H. Lufkin of Frederick, Md.

title: Fight Card Off
description: The fight card scheduled last night at Power Memorial High School had to be canceled after Johnny McQueen, a Philadelphia lightweight, had pulled out of the main event against Louie Hubela of Brooklyn.

title: A TASTE WORTH CULTIVATING
description: Among the handful of vegetables and salad greens that most appeal to our palates is one of the most difficult to cultivate, Belgian endive. In a salad bowl, it is also one of the most civilized and sophisticated, both from the standpoint of taste and of texture. When cooked, preferably braised, it makes a fantastic foil for the likes of an elegant broiled veal chop, roast chicken or grilled tournedos of beef. When glazed with a sprinkling of freshly grated Parmesan cheese, it is one of the ultimate vegetable accompaniments for many foods, and we would happily dine on it as a separate course.

title: Miss Clark, J. P. Lupoff Are to Wed
description: The engagement of Ann Warner Clark to Jeffrey Philip Lupoff has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Cameron Clark Jr. of Fairfield, Conn., and Ocean Reef, Fla., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerrold Irwin Lupoff of Sarasota, Fla.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: CHAMBER MUSIC The week in music offers a variety of pieces created on a smaller scale. Monday at 8 P.M., the Royal Swedish Chamber Orchestra makes its New York debut with a concert at Carnegie Hall. Mats Liljefors will conduct; Andras Adorjan will be the flute soloist; and the program will offer music by Bartok, Shostakovich, Bach and Mercadante and, most especially, by the Swedish composer Kurt Atterberg - his Suite for Violin, Viola and Strings.

title: U.S. JUDGE EXPECTS CHALLENGE TO JOB
description: On the desk in the chambers of Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings is a small sign that reads: ''Succeeding is the best revenge.'' The 46-year-old former storefront lawyer from Fort Lauderdale was confidently basking in the meaning of that motto today.

title: RUTGERS CAUTIONED ON COMPETITION
description: NEW JERSEY'S economic growth is inextricably bound to its highereducation system, a recent report from Rutgers University maintains, adding that the state stands to lose its competitive industrial position if higher education continues to be underfinanced.

title: Closing the Gap On Namibia
description: Periodically, the logjam holding up an accord on South-West Africa has seemed to be breaking up, only to form again. Last week, a State Department memorandum indicated fresh hope for a settlement that could lead to the territory's becoming the independent state of Namibia.

title: EVANGELICALS STRENGTHENING BONDS WITH JEWS
description: After years of mutual alienation and distrust, evangelical Christians have been meeting with Jewish leaders in New York and elsewhere to offer support for Israel and to forge a new relationship with Jewish groups.

title: A COMPUTERWARES TRADE MART
description: A Florida developer who had a frustrating time shopping for a computer system in New York not long ago has come up with a way to make such a search easier in the future.

title: M.T.A. UNIT TO PAY COST OF SUITS AGAINST CONRAIL
description: AGROUP of commuters from the county is suing Conrail for damages, but it will be Conrail's successor who pays if they win. According to Walter E. Zullig Jr., the lawyer for the Metro-North Commuter Railroad, which took over the lines' operation on Jan. 1, Metro North, not Conrail, would have to pay if damages are awarded. Metro North will also be required, under its contracts with Conrail, to pay the costs of the litigation.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
DOWN TO THE SEA
description: During the industry's heyday, from 1836 to 1862, the Cold Spring Whaling Company operated a fleet of ships that sailed all over the world - from the Hawaiian Islands to the Arctic - in search of whale oil. Some of these ships, like the Sheffield - which carried 579 tons and cost $20,000 to refurbish for each two- to four-year voyage - were among the largest in use anywhere and brought the company (and the then 500 residents of the coastal village) more than $1 million in oil and whale byproducts.

title: Vichysoisse
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Candidate Considers Job
description: John B. Anderson, the 61-year-old former Illinois Congressman who became popular with many college students in his 1980 Presidential race, says he is interested in becoming president of San Francisco State University.

title: Coal Slurries
description: To the Business Editor: The articles on coal slurry pipeline legislation by Carl E. Bagge of the National Coal Association and William H. Dempsey of the Association of American Railroads (''Do We Need Coal Slurry Pipelines?'' Jan. 16) echo more than 20 years of debate on the subject in Congress, which has dealt with the issue to no avail.

title: DANCE: THREE PIECES BY ELEO POMARE TROUPE
description: Eleo Pomare's dance works have been marked by a mordant humor and theatricality - qualities that were right up front again at the Symphony Space Friday night in three pieces presented by the Eleo Pomare Dance Company.

title: Wave of Fear, Sea of Sadness
description: Hundreds of thousands of Ghanaians streamed back to their destitute country last week after Nigeria, suddenly gone from oil boom to bust, ordered unauthorized aliens out. Deprived of low-wage jobs they had held without residence permits or working papers, the refugees, mostly young men, fled in fear of vigilantes who threatened to steal their few belongings or kill them. Said a Ghanaian priest as they poured across the frontier, ''They were going for milk and honey and they are coming back weeping tears.''

title:
NUMISMATICS;
GASPARRO DESIGNS WASHINGTON-LINCOLN MEDAL
description: George Washington and Abraham Lincoln have long been favorite subjects for American coins and medals, and now there is a new medal honoring the two men jointly. Coin collectors will find it of particular interest because it was designed by Frank Gasparro, former chief sculptor-engraver of the United States Mint.

title: Specialist Firms
description: To The Business Editor: Tamar Lewin's article (''A Gentlemanly Profession Enters a Tough New Era,'' Jan.16) is slightly off the mark. The greatest threat to large law firms is not competition among such firms, but competition from smaller firms, especially highly qualified single practitioners who specialize in one area of the law. Such individuals do not have to give one-third of their billings to senior partners, and another third for overhead, and they can perform the same services for corporate clients at rates considerably below those of the large firms. PHILIP E. FOSTER New York, Jan. 17

title: RODEO DRIVE: TRUE GLITZ
description: SUSAN HELLER ANDERSON is a reporter for The New York Times.

title: AND BEAR IN MIND
description: The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from 1,600 bookstores in every region of the United States. Other recent books that in the opinion of the Book Review staff are of particular literary, topical or scholarly interest: AARON BURR, by Milton Lomask. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.50.) The second volume of a two-volume biography, this one covering the years 1805-36. ANGER, by Carol Tavris. (Simon & Schuster, $14.95.) A non-Freudian study of the emotion. COURT OF MEMORY, by James McConkey. (E.P. Dutton, $14.95.) Twenty-one autobiographical meditations by the fiction writer and college teacher. IN SUSPECT TERRAIN, by John McPhee. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $12.95.) A popular study of geology by the New Yorker writer. IRONWEED, by William Kennedy. (The Viking Press, $14.75.) A novel of Albany low life in the 30's. THE LAST HERO, by Anthony Cave Brown. (Times Books, $24.95.) The story of Wild Bill Donovan and the O.S.S., the World War II intelligence organization he ran. MINOR CHARACTERS, by Joyce Johnson. (Houghton Mifflin, $13.95.) A memoir of growing up in New York and of life with Jack Kerouac and his Beat friends.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART Sea monsters, devils, zodaical beasts and other odd creatures form the cast of a new exhibition at the Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street (through April 10) that examines the symbolic use of animals in the art, literature and culture of the ancient and medieval worlds. The show, ''Symbolic Animals, Monsters and Demons in Antiquity and the Middle Ages,'' presents works selected from the library's outstanding collection of cylinder seals, reflecting ancient Near Eastern culture during three millennia, and from its splendid holdings of medieval illuminated manuscripts, with some additional outside loans.

title: Mary Louise Montgomery Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. James L. Montgomery of Washington have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Louise Montgomery, to Robert J. @O'Connor Jr., son of Mr. and Mr. O'Connor of Ridgewood, N.J. An April wedding is planned.

title: QUILTING AS A POINT OF DEPARTURE
description: MORRISTOWN ''NEW JERSEY Quilters: A Timeless Tradition,'' an exhibition now on view at the Morris Museum of Arts and Sciences, celebrates the American quilt as a phenomenon of the present as well as the past.

title: Baseball Union Challenges Salary Curb
description: The Major League Baseball Players Association charged Friday that the club owners had created a new way to hold down salaries. The owners said yesterday that they were only trying to insure that all of the clubs maintained a sound financial condition.

title: No Headline
description: ''Celebrating Robert Burns'' brought back an evening at Angus Mills, outside Calcutta, shortly before the end of World War II.

title: Bomb at a Basque Town Bank Kills 2 and Leaves 7 Wounded
description: A bomb exploded at the Bank of Vizcaya here today, killing two employees and wounding seven others among the more than 600 people in the building.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: OH WHAT A PARADISE IT SEEMS. By John Cheever. (Ballantine, $2.50.) Lemuel Sears, described by his creator as ''an old man but not yet infirm,'' battles to save idyllic Beasley's Pond from becoming a dump in this ''very short and often lovely novel,'' John Cheever's last. Cheever is our Chekhov, John Leonard said in his review, ''the poet of our displacement, our sense of a lost past and a 'sacred grove,' our feeling that we came from another country and left a better self behind.'' Acknowledging the book as ''minor art,'' Mr. Leonard declared that ''many of us will never grow up to achieve it.''

title: On Maneuvers In Honduras
description: The Administration last week drew further attention to its growing military involvement in Central America by dispatching more than 1,000 troops to help Honduran forces try out American-supplied weapons and communications equipment warfare along the Nicaraguan border.

title: BLOWING MY WHISTLE
description: Whistleblowers are often successful; by figuratively blowing the whistle on wrongdoing, they cause evil to be rooted out of corporate or governmental bureaucracies. But many are laden afterward with the baggage of suspicion; few whistleblowers are trusted by new bosses.

title: Diane E. Bennett Plans To Wed Marc A. Levy
description: Mr. and Mrs. James C. Bennett of Stanhope, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Elizabeth Bennett, to Marc Aaron Levy, son of Joan H. Leahy of Dallas, and Rene Levy of Boyd, Tex. A May wedding is planned in Woodstock, Vt.

title: Buying Time, Buying Trouble
description: When the Republican Party in New Jersey offered to let people rub elbows with Governor Kean, it rubbed Democrats the wrong way. A letter signed by the Governor and sent recently to 12,000 prospective donors promised periodic meetings with Mr. Kean and at least one invitation to a private session ''with the Governor and nationally recognized public figures,'' all for a $1,000 contribution to the G.O.P. treasury.

title: THE GOVERNMENT'S BAD DEAL FOR U.S. INDIANS
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Capitals Overtake Devils, 5-4

title: 78 RPM DISKS REGAIN ALLURE
description: The nearest thing to incunabula in the record business are those old 78-rpm disks traditionally stashed away in dusty attics. I never came across reference to undusty attics, but in any case, those 78 rpm disks were the standard of phonography for half a century, from about 1900 to 1950, when they were displaced by long-playing records.

title: TRUCKERS CONFIDENT ON STRIKE'S SUCCESS
description: THE Paulsboro truck stop in Gloucester County ''looks like an empty football field,'' said Charles Brown of Bradley Beach, a representative of the Independent Truckers Association, ''and the Bordentown Junction stop looks like the world's largest skating rink.''

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: So Many Lawyers
description: To the Business Editor: The article on changes under way in the big law firms was unusually good.

title: DEATH OF A PSYCHIATRIC PATIENT IS ATTRIBUTED TO UNDUE FORCE
description: A state investigation has concluded that a patient at the Manhattan Psychiatric Center on Wards Island died in 1981 because workers in the state facility's intensive-care ward had used ''undue force'' to restrain him, according to a report by a state commission.

title: A WRITER'S FIRST READERS
description: A WRITER friend telephoned recently. ''What do you do,'' he asked, ''when you feel that if you get one more rejection, you'll just crack?'' I couldn't answer, but in the hope of finding a comforting word, I reached for ''Sexus'' by Henry Miller, that master of swagger, and read:

title: BONJOUR ENNUI
description: THE PAINTED LADY By Fran,coise Sagan. Translated by Lee Fahnestock. 468 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $15.95.

title: CORSICAN SEPARATISTS SEEM TO SCALE DOWN DEMANDS
description: The Coriscan National Liberation Front, the violent separatist group that the French Government banned a month ago, has apparently abandoned its effort to make Corsica an entirely independent state and now says it is willing to accept some form of association between the Mediterranean island and France.

title: JAZZ: JIM HALL ON GUITAR
description: The warm and mellow sound of Jim Hall's guitar does not come entirely from his skill and sensitive fingers. When he opened a stand at the Village Vanguard there was a slightly harder edge than usual to his sound, which he attributed to unsatisfactory strings.

title: INSPIRATION FOR HEROIC DEEDS
description: It is said that Armagnac, the 'other' French brandy, inspired the exploits of the Musketeers. Rich in tradition and high in quality, this product of Gascony is gaining in popularity as an alternative to Cognac. Armagnac is produced from vineyards such as this one in the Tenareze region of Gascony. ARTHUR MIZNER ascony lies in a rustic corner of southwestern France, a land of lush valleys with morning mists, endless fields of grain, vineyards, picturesque castles and a tradition of gastronomy. Its capital is the ancient city of Auch, and high on a hill in that city, on the Place de la Liberation, stands the Hotel de France, a mecca for travelers in search of the best foie gras.

title: CONCERT: AMERICAN CHAMBER
description: The American Chamber Orchestra deserves credit for its commitment to the music of our time. The group, under the direction of Charles Barker, opened its Thursday evening Carnegie Hall program with a taut performance of Aaron Copland's knotty and original ''Short Symphony,'' as reorchestrated by Dennis Russell Davies.

title: FICTION
description: 1 1 19 SPACE, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) The story of the American space program told through fiction. 2 2 13 MISTRAL'S DAUGHTER, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $15.95.) The art world of the 20's and the fashion industry of the 80's. 3 3 13 2010: ODYSSEY TWO, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) A continuation of the tale begun in ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' 4 4 23 MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $15.95.) The hidden truth behind a woman business tycoon's rise to power. 5 5 23 THE VALLEY OF HORSES, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $15.95.) A continuation of the saga of human survival at the dawn of civilization begun in ''The Clan of the Cave Bear.'' 6 6 17 FOUNDATION'S EDGE, by Isaac Asimov. (Doubleday, $14.95.) The struggle to keep civilization alive in a crumbling empire: science fiction. 7 7 14 LIFE, THE UNIVERSE AND EVERYTHING, by Douglas Adams. (Harmony, $9.95.) On a journey through space, two men find answers to all their questions about existence: science fiction-fantasy. 8 9 24 E.T. THE EXTRA-TERRESTRIAL STORYBOOK, by William Kotzwinkle.

title: ST.JOHN'S REGAINS FIRST PLACE, 82-57
description: St. John's, which was knocked out of first place in the Big East Conference last Tuesday night by Pitt, regained the league lead last night by trouncing Seton Hall, 82-57, at Alumni Hall.

title: ECONOMY, NOT ARMS, MAY SWAY BONN VOTING
description: For spectators in Washington and Western European capitals, the West German election March 6 may look like a referendum on American medium-range nuclear missiles, with the Christian Democrats somehow for them and the Social Democrats against. But there are many signs that West Germans are more worried about their listing economy than about nuclear war and will judge parties on how they propose to right it.

title: Israel, Lebanon Will Talk Faster As Risks Rise
description: With the risks and penalties of delay increasingly apparent, Israel and Lebanon last week agreed to speed up their talks on withdrawal of foreign forces. The negotiators will hold three plenary meetings this week instead of two.

title: GUATEMALA REFUGEES REPORTED ATTACKED IN MEXICO
description: The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has protested to Guatemala about what he described as two recent attacks on Guatemalan refugee camps in southern Mexico in which four people were murdered and one was kidnapped.

title: FAMINE AGAIN PERILS THE SUB-SAHARAN REGION
description: Famine is again threatening parts of the the sub-Saharan region that was ravaged by hunger 10 years ago, according to senior officials of the United Nations Food and Agricultural Organization.

title:
DINING OUT;
SERIOUS JAPANESE 'COUNTRY' EATING
description: SINCE our last review of Shimizuya almost two years ago, the restaurant has matured into a serious eating place. The sushi bar now seats 10, and the addition of two large round tables makes sharing and conversation easy for parties of seven or more. The back kitchen work, once uneven, is dependably good, and the menu has expanded to include a number of unfamiliar and interesting dishes.

title: CAMP LIFE IS SMOOTH FOR THE GENERALS
description: ORLANDO, Fla. THE founding of a new team, the New Jersey Generals of the United States Football League, at training camp here last week was as orderly as a sunrise. No one was lost or fined, although 10 players were cut.

title: Boxing: There's Good and Bad, But the Fights Must Go On
description: IN the introduction to his 1956 book, ''The Sweet Science,'' A.J. Liebling wrote: ''If a boxer, for example, ever went as batty as Nijinsky, all the wowsers of the world would be screaming, 'Punchdrunk.' Well, who hit Nijinsky? And why isn't there a campaign against ballet? It gives girls thick legs.''

title: PRINCETON HARBORS A SECRET WORLD
description: PRINCETON SEVERAL times every evening, Monday through Friday, the ''Dinky'' from Princeton Junction pulls into the station on University Place here, discharging well-dressed men and women who head for their waiting B.M.W.'s and Mercedes-Benzes.

title: The Garbage Crisis: Time for Solutions
description: This is written in response to the article ''The Garbage Crisis: Going Beyond 'Good Guys' and 'Bad Guys' '' (Opinion Page, Jan. 16): In the past few years, more and more private citizens and groups have made a conscious effort to become knowledgeable about the problems of and the solutions to solid-waste disposal.

title: The 'T' Is Older Than You Think
description: To the Sports Editor: In his article on Washington and the Redskins (''The Victory That Brought Unity to Washington,'' Jan. 30) Eugene McCarthy, in describing Gerald Ford's football days, wrote: ''before the Tformation was developed or allowed.''

title: Jersey School Beats 2 Records
description: Bernards High School of Bernardsville, N.J., attempted an unusual indoor track double today by going after national indoor distance-medley relay records for both boys and girls in two meets about 100 miles apart.

title: CAN THE MIDEAST TRIANGLE GET OFF SQUARE ONE?
description: JERUSALEM THE triangular relationship linking Israel, the Arabs and the United States has always been governed by a peculiar chemistry of mutual wariness and overlapping interests. From time to time, at crucial moments, it has worked well, notably when President Jimmy Carter acted as a catalyst for an Egyptian-Israeli agreement at Camp David in 1978 and their peace treaty the following year.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: A PIANIST AND A HARPSICHORDIST FROM BRITAIN
description: Two interesting keyboard players from Britain head the list of last week's recital debuts. The more unusual and much the older of the two was the pianist John Vallier. Mr. Vallier has resumed his career in middle age after years of teaching and, Wednesday in Carnegie Hall, he made a rather dangerous entry into New York - with a concert given over to the Chopin repertory at its most familiar.

title: The Unwaged War in Salvador
description: Although the news is of real war, and shrewdly timed guerrilla thrusts, what should mainly concern Americans in El Salvador is the unwaged war: a political campaign to end this inconclusive struggle.

title: SHANKER'S BLOW FOR TEACHER MEDIOCRITY
description: To the Editor:

title: MINORITY OF JEWS IN SURVEY OBSERVE SABBATH
description: Although observing the Sabbath is more important in Jewish law than observing any other holy day, less than 40 percent of the Jews responding to a survey about religious practices said they lighted candles on Friday nights marking the beginning of the Sabbath.

title: PARAGUAY SAYS U.S. HELPED EXILE A DISSIDENT
description: The Paraguayan Government has made public what it says is an intelligence document provided by the United States and used to help justify Paraguay's expulsion last year of a leading Paraguayan writer.

title: Moving Into the Mass Market
description: The scene is Happy Harry's, a drugstore on Delaware Avenue in Wilmington, Del. At the left as one walks in, under a sign that says ''10% Off Paperback Books,'' scores of rack-sized soft-covers are displayed in rows of wire pockets each of which holds up to six copies of a single title; along the top row, a few trade paperbacks occupy unpocketed shelf space. Straight ahead, more shelves hold dozens of hard-cover books; ''20% Off,'' the sign says here. At the right, there's a small free-standing rack labeled ''Best Sellers,'' stocked with 20 paperback titles, each several copies deep. Nearby, three compact fixtures for books - two ''spinners'' that revolve and a ''dump'' that stands in the aisle - house more than 100 romance novels. And up near the front of the store, another 20-pocket rack has assorted top sellers in it.

title: Deirdre Clancy to Wed John Feeney Jr. in May
description: Mrs. James S. Clancy of New York has made known the engagement of her daughter, Deirdre O. Clancy, to John J. Feeney Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Feeney of Albany. A May 21 wedding is planned.

title: NORTH STARS STOP ISLANDERS, 4-2
description: A pair of third-period goals, the second into an untended net, enabled the Minnesota North Stars to beat the Islanders, 4-2, tonight and send them to their first defeat in six games.

title: EFFORT BEGINS ON LINES
description: IN Albany, where he is known as ''Big Z,'' Donald Zimmerman has assisted Senate Republicans three times in the complicated process of reapportionment, the redrawing of political district lines. Now, it appears, he will be working with local Republicans to do the same in Westchester County.

title: Lucy Brown Weds Doctor
description: Lucy Katherine Brown, daughter of Betsy Brown of Ossining, N.Y., and the late Charles H. Brown, was married yesterday to Dr. Lawrence H. Vinis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack T. Vinis of Warrenton, Va. The ceremony was performed at All Saints Episcopal Church in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., by the Rev. William E. Arnold, rector emeritus, assisted by the Rev. Mills R. Omaly.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
AN UNLIKELY PAIRING OF TWO SCHOOLS OF THE 20's
description: Do American photographic modernists like Paul Strand and Edward Weston really have a lot in common with European Constructivists like Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, El Lissitzky and Alexander Rodchenko? To be sure, they all flourished in roughly the same period, the 1920's and 30's, and they share what might be called a period style that resulted, in part, from the efforts both groups made to adapt the effects of Cubist painting to the medium of photography.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent Passbook Savings 5.50 At savings Institutions Tax-Exempt Bonds 10.70 Bond Buyer 20-Bond Index 6-Month Savings Certificates 8.72 Maximum rate Money Market Funds 7.80 Donoghue's Money Fund 7-Day Average Home Mortgage 14.22 Federal Home Loan Bank, national average Unsecured Perosnal Loans Minimum rate, 3-year maturity Chase Manhattan, New York 17.25 Continental Illinois, Chicago 17.00 Bank of America, San Francisco 22.00

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: INJURED and seeking refuge from predators, a graceful water bird paddled in a narrow tidal stream near Barnegat Bay last weekend. Ducks, wary of its long, sharp bill, kept their distance.

title: Article on Abortion Draws Readers' Replies
description: On issues of great moment, like abortion, prevarication is sometimes the unfortunate offspring of desperation. Grace Dermody (Opinion Page, Jan. 16) put forward several statements from the annals of antiabortion mythology that should not be permitted to filter into the public consciousness as fact.

title: LIMITED OPPORTUNITIES
description: WOMEN SCIENTISTS IN AMERICA Struggles and Strategies to 1940. By Margaret W. Rossiter. Illustrated. 439 pp. Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins University Press. $27.50.

title: Turkey Executes 3 Brothers For a 1974 Revenge Murder
description: Three brothers convicted of murder in 1974 were executed in the town of Aksehir today after their death sentences were ratified by the ruling junta, the Anatolian press agency said.

title: TROPICAL TWEEDS
description: RICHARD CONDON's newest novel, ''A Trembling Upon Rome'' (Putnam), comes out this year.

title: LOCAL HISTORY AND 'MAD NAN'
description: Re: ''Close-to-Home History Attracts the Young'': We at the Three Village Historical Society would like to tell you about two of our activities that we believe to be unique. First, our education committee has completed a major project: two years in the making, a 102-page resource guide has been developed.

title: RUSH TO JUDGEMENT AMONG EXPERT WITNESSES
description: WILLIAM C. HEILMAN is an expert on high voltage electrocutions. Charles R. Levesque's field is injuries from deep fat fryers and meat grinders. Norman W. Heimstra specializes in the relationship between clothing color and hunting accidents, while Nixon De Tarnowsky knows all about exploding beer barrels. When it comes to fires started by Christmas tree lights, there's always Robert Weiner.

title: NAMIBIA: NOT A 'SLAP' BUT AN OPENING
description: To the Editor:

title: Wendy S. Schindler Betrothed to Dr. Lloyd Reich
description: Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Schindler of Flushing, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Susan Schindler, to Dr. Lloyd Elliot Reich, son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil Reich of Manhattan. The wedding is planned for May.

title: Laura Gant Plans August Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Gant of New Vernon, N.J., and Amelia Island Plantation, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laura Ross Gant, to Christopher Hall Price, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Price of Mountainhome, Pa.An Aug. 20 wedding is planned.

title: Nancy Schwartz to Marry William Schreier in March
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerrold Michael Schwartz of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Los Angeles have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Lois Schwartz, to William S. Schreier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred A. Schreier of Scarsdale.

title: 2 NEW VAULTS OFFER ALTERNATIVE TO BANK
description: THE private safe-deposit box business is growing in Connecticut. Because of a greater demand for safe-deposit boxes and a shortage of them at many bank branches, two concerns - one in Westport and the other in Greenwich - offer an alternative to banks.

title: PUTTING A STRANGLEHOLD ON SUFFOLK COUNTY LEGISLATION
description: GOVERNMENT and elected officials have traditionally been targets of public contempt in our society. In one respect, this may be seen as something of a conditioned response on the part of an irate citizenry that holds government and its denizens accountable for every public ill. Every now and then, however, some arm of government or elected official commits an offense against the public interest so foul as to lend every legitimacy to that contempt.

title: MR. KEAN AND THE COALITION
description: TRENTON ONE of the oldest political axioms says that the squeaking wheel gets the grease. It means that those who complain loud and long in politics or government usually get at least some of what they want.

title: IN THE CIRCLE OF A CHARMED LIFE
description: ''It was a magical childhood,'' said Honoria Donnelly, who grew up in the south of France in the 1920's in a world peopled by such expatriates as Hemingway, Fitzgerald and Dos Passos. ''Every day was an event,'' she said. ''There was an extraordinary exchange of souls and affection and ideas.''

title: YVONNE DRAPER PLANS A WEDDING IN AUGUST
description: Dr. and Mrs. Edgar Daniel Draper of Dix Hills, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Yvonne T. Draper, to T. Charles Taylor, son of Goldie Mae Taylor of Red Bank, N.J., and the late Sgt. Robert Taylor, U.S. Army.

title: A Correction
description: A caption in the Long Island Weekly section last week incorrectly identified a work at the C.W. Post Center's Hillwood Art Gallery. The drawing is William Tucker's ''Study for Turning.''

title: TERROR SLAYINGS REPORTED IN SIDON
description: Threats, violence and terror tactics are reportedly being used by Lebanese Christian Phalangists against middle-class Palestinians in the coastal town of Sidon in an effort to drive them out of the area.

title: I.R.A. Annuities
description: To the Business Editor: The Personal Finance column of Jan. 23 incorrectly says that with an insurance annuity purchased for an Individual Retirement Account, nothing goes to a person's heirs upon the death of the annuitant. But there are a number of options from which the annuitant can choose that could allow lump sums of money to go to heirs. A. JEFFERSON CORNELL Cornell & Cornell Life Underwriters Manchester, N.H., Jan. 25

title: Susan Percy Engaged To Robert P.F. Rider
description: Mrs. Michael Howes Terry of Essex, Conn., and Stephen Percy of Waterford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Enders Percy, to Robert Patterson Field Rider, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilson Hull Rider of Granville and Otis, Mass. The wedding is planned for April 30.

title: Squirrel Census
description: The Government put out a call for volunteers last November to help with its newest census: a study of squirrels in Lafayette Park, across the street from the White House.

title: 2 TOWNS CLAIM 1ST MEDAL WINNER
description: IN the Revolutionary War, colonists from Enfield and East Windsor were on the same side fighting against the British Redcoats. Now, the two Connecticut towns are at odds over one of that war's heroes.

title: ORDINARY BOOKSHELVES ARE EASILY MADE, AT QUITE A SAVING
description: CONSTRUCTING a professional-looking, decorative set of bookshelves or storage shelves that can also serve as pieces of furniture in the living room or dining room is a project that may call for more-thanaverage woodworking skills. But erecting a sturdy set of bookshelves or utility shelves where appearance is not a primary consideration is actually a fairly simple task that any do-it-yourselfer can easily handle -while saving considerable money in the process.

title: PREMIER OF CHINA WILL MEET REAGAN IN U.S. THIS YEAR
description: The White House announced today that President Reagan and Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang of China would hold a meeting in the United States this year.

title: AN ALTERNATE PLAN
description: UNDER pressure from his own advisers and the business community to r educe the largest deficits in our nation's history, President Reagant ook the opportunity in his State of the Union address to talk of ' 'bipartisanship'' and ''a fair, across-the-board freeze on G overnment spending.'' Sadly, that is all it was, just talk.

title: ARTICLE ON ABORTION DRAWS READERS' REPLIES
description: The article is more frightening than the ''1984'' scenario that Mrs. Dermody alludes to several times. That the article is one-sided is to be expected, since the author is a spokesperson for the New Jersey Right to Life.

title: MObile Gives In On City Elections
description: Leaders of Mobile, Ala. have gone to great lengths, and to the Supreme Court, in defense of at-large elections that effectively block black representation by diluting the minority vote. After seven years, the city called it quits last week and presented Federal Judge Virgil Pittman with a proposal for electing city commissioners by district.

title: By A WELL-TEMPERED BISTRO
description: JANE GROSS, formerly a sports reporter for The Times, is a writer who lives in Brussels.

title: HIS PAINTINGS SPEAK OF A VANISHED RUSSIA
description: To be born at the right time, in the right place and among the right people does not guarantee happiness, but it certainly helps. A case in point is that of Valentin Serov, the Russian painter who was born in St. Petersburg in 1865 and died in Moscow in 1911. Serov has no kind of reputation in this country, where his work is nowhere to be seen and never comes on the market. No one writes about it, talks about it or even thinks about it.

title: LOOKING BACK AT LOOK
description: HE was finishing up his morning reading, browsing among the 40 m agazines and four daily papers that still cross his desk. There weren o editorial meetings on tap; after all, Look, the fabled picture m agazine he guided for 30-odd years, was gone. Calls from the P resident, powwows with world leaders? There were none of those now.

title: ARTICLE ON ABORTION DRAWS READERS' REPLIES
description: The article points out again how using statistics to give misinformation can be dangerous.

title: AN ABORTIVE ATTACK ON 'COMING OF AGE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Georgia Sassen Is to Wed in Fall
description: Dr. and Mrs. Theodore Benjamin of Irvington, N.Y., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Benjamin's daughter, Georgia Sassen, to Dr. Li-Shiang Liang, son of Dr. and Mrs. Kuang-Chi Liang of Bethesda, Md. A fall wedding is planned.

title: WHETHER-AND HOW-TO LEAD A CAR
description: WITH spring approaching and the family car starting to act its age, m any a motorist is beginning to linger over newspaper auto ads. But w ith new-car prices some 60 percent higher than the last time the a verage motorist bought an auto in 1976, many consumers are turning a few more pages in the paper to the auto leasing ads that offer new c ars at relatively modest monthly rates.

title: DOMESTIC TRAVELERS AT NEWARK AIRPORT EXCEED KENNEDY'S
description: Newark International Airport surpassed Kennedy International in domestic passengers by the end of last year, according to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. It was the first time Newark exceeded Kennedy's monthly domestic passenger load in 30 years.

title: A Strong Merger
description: To the Business Editor: Unfortunately, Leslie Wayne's article on the Occidental Petroleum-Cities Service merger (''A Costly Merger for Occidental,'' Jan.23) suggests a broadly held negative opinion of the merger. In addition, the author made a material error in fact concerning the recent sale of an important Cities Service asset.

title: EARLY IMPRESSIONS
description: ''There are some books one needs maturity to enjoy,'' the late poet and humorist Phyllis McGinley once said, ''just as there are books an adult can come upon too late to savor.'' It's funny how the books we read as children and teen-agers somehow lodge in the attics of our memories, dusty and occasionally outgrown, but never really misplaced - eclectic reminders of what we once imagined the world to be.

title: STATE'S FARM INCOME BELIEVED DOWN SHARPLY
description: The net income of New York farmers in 1982 may have fallen as low as $200 million, a 47 percent drop from the year before, according to figures prepared by the State College of Agriculture and Life Sciences at Cornell University.

title: Tana Hoban Is Married
description: Tana Hoban of New York, a freelance photographer and author of children's books, was married yesterday to John G. Morris of New York, former picture editor of The New York Times.

title: CAN THE MAD BE GUILTY?
description: MADNESS AND THE CRIMINAL LAW By Norval Morris. 235 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $20.

title: FOR WOULD-BE NASCAR RACERS, A SHORT COURSE IN DRIVERS'ED
description: From the infield the banking at either end of the mile-long North Carolina Motor Speedway looks as if it rises vertically out of the earth. The stock-car racers just call the track Rockingham, after the sleepy Piedmont town where it is situated. And maybe under their breath a few of the drivers on the Winston Cup circuit curse the tricky oval.

title: THE NATION
description: By Caroline Rand Herron, Carlyle C. Douglas and Michael Wright YOu Heard It From Him First

title: NEW HAVEN SEEKS TO RESTORE CARROUSEL
description: THE brass ring may be within the grasp of New Haven residents again if efforts to bring the flying horses back to Lighthouse Point are successful.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: A Men's Store For All Sizes

title: CUSTOMS CHECK: LEAVE YOUR IDEOLOGICAL BAGGAGE BEHIND
description: WHEN Margaret Mead went to Samoa in 1925 to study adolescence, she was 23 years old and possessed with a vision of the dominant role of culture in human behavior. Anthropology was then passing through its own adolescence, struggling with conflicting ideologies and suffering from inexperience.

title: Maria Guarisco Affianced
description: Maria Thompson Guarisco of Patterson, La., and Peter Victor Guarisco of Morgan City, La., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Maria Cedes Guarisco, to James Douglas Watt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Watt of New York. An April 23 wedding is planned in New York. Miss Guarisco, a dancer, graduated from Westhampton College of the University of Richmond. Mr. Watt is a vice president and financial consultant with Oppenheimer & Company Inc. His father is the drama critic for The Daily News. Brown, is a medical communications specialist and director of

title: TALE OF MAN AND 105 WIVES PACKS COURTROOM
description: A man who says he has married 105 women around the globe begins his fifth week of trial here Monday. Giovanni Vigliotto is charged with bigamy and fraud in his marriage to Patricia Ann Gardiner, a real estate agent in the nearby city of Mesa. Prosecutors say he swindled her out of $36,500, including household valuables and $11,474 in proceeds from the sale of her home in November 1981.

title: Queens Coach Out
description: Floyd Bank, the basketball coach at Queens College, was dismissed Friday for what the school called a lack of cooperation and discipline, and a disagreement over philosophy.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: THE IMPACT OF AIRLINE DEREGULATION
description: Y our air ticket may look the same, but on Jan. 1 it assumed a lot more meaning than in the past. Now in addition to being your permit to travel, it is also your major source of guidance on how to determine and protect your rights, as well as penalties you could face.

title: G.O.P. Appeal Denied On House Assignments
description: A Federal court, citing its respect for ''a co-equal branch of government,'' said Friday it would not rule on a dispute between House Republicans and Democrats over assignments of committee seats.

title: REFUGEES HEADING FOR THAI INTERIOR
description: Twenty-five thousand Cambodian refugees started moving another mile into Thailand by truck tonight after the Thai Government agreed that their six-day-old encampments just inside the Thai border were in danger of being attacked again by Vietnamese artillery.

title: BANK AND EX-ACTRESS BATTLE OVER GROUCHO MARX GIFTS TO HER
description: More than five years after Groucho Marx's death, the battle over his estate is still being fought. In a turbulent jury trial, the bank that is the executor of Mr. Marx's will is suing Erin Fleming, the companion of the comedian's last seven years.

title: REAGAN LOOKS FOR A HANDLE ON HEALTH COSTS
description: PRESIDENT Reagan has arrested inflation more suddenly than even he originally anticipated, but, like his recent predecessors, he has failed to control the price of health care. Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly, and Medicaid, the medical assistance program for poor people, are expected to cost $76 billion this year, or 9.5 percent of total Federal spending. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that the two programs will cost $142 billion in 1988, unless they are changed. In five years, the combined cost of Medicare and Medicaid is expected to rise 87 percent, or twice as fast as total Federal spending. The two health programs are part of the ''social contract'' that President Reagan described in the budget he sent to Congress last week. He asked Congress, in effect, to help rewrite the contract. Following is an attempt to answer some questions about Mr. Reagan's proposals.

title: WHAT THE COMMUTER NEEDS
description: FOR most Long Islanders, this has been an unusually mild and benign winter. But for the thousands who daily take a train to and from Manhattan, no season is ever totally kind. Each delicate snowflake, blustery gust or drop in temperature carries the threat of iced rails, frozen switches or disasters of some other kind. And each points to a pressing need of Long Island Rail Road commuters: a winter survival kit.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: FOUNDLINGS they may be, but the stray cats and dogs that eventually will find their way to the Animal Adoption Center to be built in East Hampton will be housed in a manner befitting the East End. The Animal Rescue Fund of the Hamptons, known as ARF, has announced plans to build a $450,000 complex that, on paper, looks like the last - or first - word in animal-protection havens.

title: STATE ADDS TO STEPS TO SAVE FARMLAND
description: TRENTON AFTER more than a decade of studies and pilot programs, New Jersey has adopted a set of laws designed to keep New Jersey farmland in farming.

title: CITY URGES PRESERVATION OF STATEN ISLAND GREEN BELT
description: The greenbelt area on Staten Island, described as ''one of New York City's most beautiful and irreplaceable natural resources,'' should be preserved and its development controlled by the city, according to the City Planning Commission.

title: Adventures On the Railroad
description: Recently, as a rider on the New Haven line, in addition to wondering if all the wheels on the cars would stay on during the trip, I discovered one also could encounter conductor-attendant problems.

title: 2 of 5 Church Members Guilty in Arizona Assault
description: Five members of a church in Miracle Valley have been found not guilty of aggravated assault, but two of them were convicted of simple assault in an hammer attack on a television news crew.

title: Amtrak's 'All Aboard America'
description: ''All Aboard America.'' Those words constitute a summons from Amtrak to partake of a travel bargain. They are also the title bestowed on an Amtrak reduced-fare program that took effect Feb. 1 and expires May 30.

title: Headliners; Merit Badgering
description: It has been more than six years since the Boy Scouts of America rubbed Catherine Pollard the wrong way, and the 64-year-old Connecticut grandmother is still smoldering. Mrs. Pollard had sought to be named scoutmaster of a troop she had led in all but name for four years, but a female scoutmaster was one thing the Boy Scouts were not prepared for. Last week, as she awaited the outcome of hearings on the matter before a state human rights panel, Mrs. Pollard opined that the Boy Scouts' contention that ''it takes a man to build character'' was ''baloney.'' Jury Acquits Judge

title: SLED-DOG RACES, WITHOUT THE SLEDS
description: FIRST of all, ''we don't yell 'mush!' In fact, I've never heard anybody - except Sergeant Preston of the Yukon -use that word,'' declared Janet Cingel of East Hampton, the driver of a sled-dog team and the president of the Connecticut Valley Siberian Husky Club.

title: THE EVICTION OF A FELLOW TENANT
description: LENORE PERLMAN, a tax accountant who lives at 11 Riverside Drive, h as a problem: A tenant who shares the wing of five apartments on h er floor keeps a number of animals in her apartment, resulting in w hat Mrs. Perlman says is an unpleasant, pervasive odor. In addition,t he animal waste is disposed of in the hall incinerator and, on o ccasion, cat and dog excrement has been found in the area.

title: Jamie Stanforth Weds Thomas J. Shoemaker
description: Jamie Stanforth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Stanforth of New York, was married yesterday to Thomas J. Shoemaker, son of Eileen F. Shoemaker of Villa Park, Ill., and the late Louis H. Shoemaker. The Rev. Randolph Frew performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Holy Apostles in Manhattan.

title: 20 Food Outlets Cited by City As Violators of Sanitary Code
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 20 food establishments last week for violations of the health code. In addition, it named four that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and two that were closed for having failed to do so.

title: Florida Police Arrest 2 In LSD Stamp Scheme
description: Doses of LSD have been found on 67 tiny comic strip character stamps in south Florida, and two men have been arrested, the authorities say.

title:
GARDENING;
GROWING STRAWBERRY PLANTS FROM SEED
description: LAST year it was potatoes; this year it is strawberries: It is possible for the homeowner to grow both these plants from seed. The new Explorer potato is said to have met with only modest success last year. It remains to be seen how well the new Sweet Heart strawberry will do, since it has not generally been available until this year.

title: ALCOHOLISM-TAX BILL OPPOSED BY DEALERS
description: LEGISLATION that would raise the wholesale price of liquor, wine and bottled beer by eight-tenths of 1 percent and use the funds for county alcoholism programs faces strong opposition from the wholesale liquor industry.

title: South Africa Bars a Petition, British Methodist Chief Says
description: The head of the Methodist Church in Britain says he was turned away by South African Embassy officials when he tried to present a petition supporting a South African churchman accused of treason.

title: THE PERFORMING ARTISTRY OF LAURIE ANDERSON
description: Out of the darkness, a voice: ''Our plan is to drop a lot of odd objects onto your country from the air. And some of these objects will be useful. And some of them will just be ... odd. Proving that these oddities were produced by a people free enough to think of making them in the first place. The United States helps, not harms, developing nations by using their natural resources and raw materials.''

title: SHARING THE LIFE OF A NORMAN VILLAGE
description: LAILAN YOUNG is a London-based writer.

title: PODIUM ASSISTANTS TO HAVE THEIR DAY
description: JUST as some theatrical understudies never get to go on for the leads, many assistant or associate conductors remain names on the program. They're ready to jump in to save the day, but rarely get to do so.

title: ARTICLE ON ABORTION DRAWS READERS' REPLIES
description: The war against legal abortion has been waged for more than 10 years, and those who would deny women the right to medically safe abortion, in a clinic or hospital, are getting desperate.

title: MADRID FACING FIGHT FROM RIGHT ON ABORTION ,
description: The new Socialist Government is facing its first major battle with the right-wing opposition over the legalization of abortion in Spain.

title: Leaky Lake
description: For nearly two years, nearby residents watched Staten Island's Silver Lake sink steadily, a foot a month. They asked the city to stop the leak.

title: SHOT BY WESTPHAL DEFEATS ROCKETS
description: Paul Westphal scored the winning basket tonight at the end of his worst shooting performance since he took over the Knicks' playmaking duties 12 games earlier.

title: SEA-POLLUTION SUIT CITES CLAM BEDS
description: A SUIT seeking to halt ocean dumping will cite research that indicates that shellfish taken from federally approved ocean waters off Monmouth County are contaminated with viruses and bacteria and could present a danger to public health. The suit, filed in Federal Court, Newark, in December, will quote material compiled by Dr. Joseph Melnick of the department of biology at Baylor College of Medicine in Houston.

title: CHINA TRADE WARES
description: In the 18th and 19th centuries, tea was what oil is today - the commodity that kept ships sailing and that spawned numerous other business enterprises. Tea was the goal, and in order to acquire it merchants bartered ginseng, furs, metals, spices, sandalwood, opium and tons of silver coins. Most of the China-trade porcelains, silver, furniture, lacquer, ivory and paintings came back as ballast on the ships of these merchants who purchased them as souvenirs of travel.

title: A RENAISSANCE FOR THE CAMELLIA
description: A camellia is a special flower. Even though it has no fragrance and is not commonly grown outdoors in the Northeast, it is usually love at first sight.

title: Cleanup of Reactor to Take 2 Years More Than Expected
description: Cleaning up the damaged reactor at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant will take two years longer than expected, but it will cost slightly less than the $1 billion originally estimated, plant officials say.

title: THEY FILMED AS THE STONES ROLLED
description: ''My initial, basic idea was to make a real good hour-and-a-halflong rock and roll album, and capture some real good images to go with it.'' Hal Ashby, a leading Hollywood director whose credits include ''Harold and Maude,'' ''Shampoo,'' and ''Being There,'' was talking about his latest project, ''Let's Spend the Night Together,'' a chronicle of the Rolling Stones' hugely successful 1981 tour of the United States.

title: Elizabeth Fletcher to Marry
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Dugald Angus Fletcher of Locust Valley, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Thurman Fletcher, to Robert Todd Cronan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Raphael Cronan of Rockport, Mass., and Dublin.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: ONE of six people who will read from the works of prominent black historians at a New Jersey Historical Commission conference on Feb. 19 is a Montclair history buff whose diggings into the past of local blacks were aided by a grant from the commission.

title: Avant-Garde Jazz
description: ''Music Is an Open Sky,'' a series of Sunday and Monday night programs of traditional-flavored avant-garde jazz at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785), will begin tonight with Olu Dara and the Okra Orchestra. Mr. Dara, a cornetist, will lead a septet that also includes Henry Threadgill on saxophones, Phillip Wilson on drums and Craig Harris on trombone, in sets that are likely to encompass funk as well as free jazz. Sets are at 9:30 and 11 P.M. and 12:30 A.M.; there is a $7.50 cover charge and a $5 food or drink minimum.

title: INFRASTRUCTURE: PLANS ABOUND TO SHORE IT UP
description: AFTER years of management by crisis, New Jersey's infrastructure, according to public and private officials, is on the edge of collapse. Most of the state's highways, bridges, sewer and water lines - the components of its infrastructure were built 40, 50 and more years ago. During most of those years, two major factors - a free flow of Federal funds and low interest rates - contributed to the construction and maintenance of the state's public works.

title: Turk Is Charged in Italy With Instigation of Crime
description: A Turk linked to a purported plot to assassinate Pope John Paul II next spring was formally charged today with drug trafficking and instigation to commit crime, legal officials said. The charges do not bear directly on the accusation that he was involved in a plot against the Pope.

title: EX-SPY CONVICTED IN EXPLOSIVES PLOT
description: Edwin P. Wilson, a former agent of the Central Intelligence Agency, was found guilty today of four counts of illegally transporting 20 tons of plastic explosives to Libya in 1977.

title: Miss Bayewitch and Barry Koch, Lawyers, to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Seymour Bayewitch of West Hempstead, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Ann Bayewitch, to Barry Mitchell Koch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving C. Koch of New Hyde Park, L.I. A May wedding is planned.

title: WILL THE MET'S 'ARABELLA' WIN FRIENDS FOR STRAUSS?
description: What is ''Arabella''? ''One of the last sighs of beauty in the 20th century,'' says Otto Schenk. More concretely, of course, ''Arabella'' is an opera - with words by Hugo von Hofmannsthal and music by Richard Strauss. It was the last of their many collaborations, and Mr. Schenck, the Viennese director, has come to New York to restage it. ''Arabella' is 50 years old this season, and this new production at the Metropolitan Opera -conducted by Erich Leinsdorf and with Kiri Te Kanawa in the title role - opens on Thursday.

title: On Productivity
description: To the Business Editor: Richard R. West and Dennis E. Logue (''The False Doctrines of Productivity,'' Jan. 9) ignore what I see as the problem of employee disillusionment resulting from the mass firings and forced retirements now under way as companies enter a ''lean and mean'' mode.

title: LEGISLATURE PLANS TO PAY SUIT'S COSTS
description: ALTHOUGH two school districts - Edison and Old Bridge - are named as defendants in the American Civil Liberties Union suit challenging the law requiring a daily moment of silence in public schools, the Legislature, not the school districts, will assume defense costs, according to the Assembly Speaker, Alan J. Karcher, Democrat of Sayreville.

title:
WEEK IN BUSINESS;
UNEMPLOYMENT DECREASES TO 10.2%
description: Unemployment dropped to 10.2 percent of the labor force in January from 10.8 percent in December. For the first time, the Government is including the military in the figures, and that adds 1.7 million to the employed side of the calculation. The rate for civilians alone, however, fell to 10.4 percent - the lowest since September and the first drop in unemployment in a year. President Reagan said he would study actions to speed Government construction projects to spur jobs.
