title: 2 JUSTICES DEFEND FRIESS AT HEARING ON MISCONDUCT
description: Two State Supreme Court justices testified last week that Alan I. Friess, a former Criminal Court judge, acted properly when he tossed a coin to decide the length of a jail term in one case and asked court spectators in another to vote on which of two men to believe.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: SY MARLOWE invented a process for printing patterns on apparel and the results pleased the eye, but there was a time long before that when he pleased ears for his living. Gene Seraphine is a publicrelations man for several Long Island businesses, but he, too, used to do something else that he liked better.

title: Fighter, 61, Bows Out
description: Officials in Burlington, Vt., had declared 61-year-old Arthur Boynton fit to meet Randy Corey, who is in his 20's, last night in a Golden Gloves heavyweight bout.

title: British Museum
description: To the Editor:

title:
CAMERA;
POINTERS ON PHOTOGRAPHING WINTER SPORTS
The Travelers Is Staying Put
description: Insurance money helped build Hartford and insurance money is helping rebuild it. The Travelers Corporation, the city's second largest employer and taxpayer, last week canceled suburban expansion plans and said it would move into two office towers under construction in the state capital instead.

title: THE HALL OF FAME SNUBS JOE NAMATH
description: 813OOUT in Honolulu this weekend at the Pro Bowl luaus, the five new members of the Pro Football Hall of Fame - Paul Warfield, Bobby Mitchell, Sid Gillman, Sonny Jurgensen and Bobby Bell - are enjoying their deserved tributes. But the most intriguing issue of this year's Hall of Fame voting is not that any of those five were elected, but that Joe Namath was not.

title: AN OLD MAN'S FAITH
description: Chancellor Bruno Kreisky of Austria came in here the other day, battered by his years, but still believing in the possibility of a more orderly world.

title: TWO SCHOOL POOLS SOUGHT
description: ALTHOUGH many of the Island's 129 school districts are grappling with how to stay financially afloat amid declining enrollments, increased costs and decreased Federal aid, officials of the Shoreham-Wading River Central School District have proposed building two indoor swimming pools at the high school at a cost of $2 million.

title: DIFFERENT EXCEPT FOR THE SIMILARITIES
description: THE DRAGON AND THE BEAR Inside China & Russia in the Eighties. By Philip Short. Illustrated. 519 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $19.95.

title: Christine W. Cook, Writer, Weds Alan Curtis, Banker
description: Christine Wyant Cook, a freelance writer, and Alan Curtis, a managing director of the investment banking firm of Dillon Read & Company Inc., in New York, were married yesterday at the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel.

title: STROESSNER HOLDS ON BY MORE THAN FORCE OF ARMS
description: chested man, is head of ''Seccional 14,'' a Colorado Party ward in a poor, somewhat neglected section of this sleepy river city. He predicted that in today's presidential elections, nearly 100 percent of the ward would vote to re-elect his party leader, Gen. Alfredo Stroessner. There seemed little reason to doubt him. The 49-year-old ward leader, born and raised in the barrio, is a cog in a political machine surpassed in the hemisphere perhaps only by Fidel Castro's Communist Party. Of the ward's 20,000 residents, Mr. Aquino said, 15,000 are Colorado Party members. Most of the rest are too young to vote.

title: A Prosecutor's Toughest Case
description: It isn't every day that a prosecutor, upon hearing a verdict of not guilty, extols the virtues of the jury system. But it isn't every day that a prosecutor is tried and acquitted of bribery, extortion and conspiracy.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Boxing Ray Mancini vs. George Feeney, 10 rounds, lightweights, at San Vicente, Italy. A nontitle fight for Mancini, the World Boxing Association champion. (Television - Channel 4, 3 P.M.) Roberto Duran vs. Pipino Cuevas, 12 rounds junior middleweights, at Olympic Auditorium, Los Angeles. (Television - Channel 4, 3 P.M., tape from Jan. 29.)

title: RICHARDSON DEAL IS NEAR
description: For the last few days, the Nets have been attempting to show their owners that no changes are necessary. And to prove it, they have played some of their best basketball of the season. But now it appears that management is ready to make a change nonetheless.

title: College Aid Law Is Opposed
description: The presients of the public colleges and universities in Massachusetts have endorsed repeal of a Federal law requiring students to register for the draft in order to get Federal financial aid. The unanimous vote was taken at a meeting attended by presidents from 27 of the 29 public campuses. John B. Duff, Chancellor of public higher education, said the law is discriminatory because it singles out students who need aid.

title: Elizabeth Cascella And James Auran To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ralph A. Cascella of New York and Quogue, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Anne Cascella, to James Drake Auran, son of Mrs. Richard Auran of Scottsdale, Ariz., and Minneapolis and the late Mr. Auran. A June 4 wedding is planned in New York.

title: Would-Be Kings Of a Little Hill
description: ''The Liberal Party,'' said City Councilman Henry J. Stern, ''is too small to splinter.'' He may only be half right.Raymond B. Harding, the party's vice chairman and de facto leader, and the Rev. Dr. Donald S. Harrington, its chairman, have been feudingfor months - it has been described as a clash of virtually everything but ideologies - over control of the organization and the patronage due from Governor Cuomo, whom the Liberals supported last year.

title: A COMFORTABLE HOMECOMING
description: FRESH from teaching the first session of his favorite class, International Law II, Eugene V. Rostow sat in his third floor office at Yale University Law School in New Haven last Monday. He propped a crutch he has been using because of a recent hip operation against the wall and looked around. Next to his desk was a bust of Winston Churchill with a brown fedora perched on its head.

title: EX-GESTAPO AIDE IS TAKEN TO FRANCE
description: Klaus Barbie, a former Gestapo official whom the French have been trying to bring to trial for war crimes since World War II, arrived here tonight after being expelled from Bolivia.

title: Leonardo Inventions Shown in Westchester
description: An exhibition highlighting the many inventions of Leonardo da Vinci will be on display through next Wednesday in the Pace University Gallery on Elm Road in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. Among the designs and scale models on display are a parachute, an airplane, a printing press, a scaling ladder, a helicopter, a machine gun and a selfpropelled car.

title: PHOENIX REBORN
description: First it was the Level Club, a Masonic organization. Then it became the Riverside Plaza Hotel.

title: FOR ACTORS, THERE IS LIFE AND WORK OUTSIDE NEW YORK
description: When Amanda Plummer left the cast of ''Agnes of God'' on Broadway last December, she received several offers to appear in New York productions. She turned all of them down. Instead, the Tony Awardwinning actress plans to leave the city this summer for the La Jolla Playhouse in California - a former summer stock theater re-opening this year as a 492-seat resident theater.

title: No Headline
description: CARROLL SCORES 40 AS WARRIORS WIN

title: GUARDIAN PROGRAM RUNNING INTO SNAGS
description: SIX months after the demise of the state's Law Guardian Program, which provided legal representation for abused or neglected children, judges charged with looking out for the welfare of these youngsters say they are sorely feeling the loss.

title: WORKS THAT FIT THE SETTINGS
description: ART THAT is intrinsically good can hold its own almost anywhere, but the viewing experience is enhanced when the work fits its site hand-in-glove fashion. Such is the case with two current compact shows - one in Union, the other in Jersey City.

title: China and Vietnam Exchange 50 Captives at a Border Pass
description: China and Vietnam exchanged 50 prisoners today at the Youyi Pass on the border between the two countries, the New China News Agency said.

title: THE SOLITUDE OF LATIN AMERICA
description: Antonio Pigafetta, a Florentine navigator who went with Magellan on the first voyage around the world, wrote, upon his passage through our southern lands of America, a strictly accurate account that nonetheless resembles a venture into fantasy.

title: DANCE: DIANNE MCINTYRE'S TROUPE
description: Dianne McIntyre calls her modern-dance company Sounds in Motion. The title seemed particularly fitting Wednesday, when Miss McIntyre opened the Harlem Cultural Council's two-week Dancemobile Winter Series at Symphony Space with a salute to Eubie Blake that captured much of the wry, matter-of-fact charm of Mr. Blake's music.

title: MARY LYNCH TO WED IN FALL
description: Mr. and Mrs. James W. Lynch of Port Washington, L.I. have announce the engagement of their daughter, Mary Grances Lynch, to Gus Peter Nuzzolese, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Nuzzolese. A fall wedding is planned. Mrs. Lynch in a nurse at the North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. Her fiance is a student at St. John's Unviersity School of Law.

title: Losing the Past
description: To the Editor:

title: RUMOURS AND LITTLE MORE THRIVING IN STEEL TOWN
description: This old mill town, like so many other industrial towns throughout the land, is heavy with despair. Unemployment stands at about 25 percent. About half the population is dependent on government payments, Social Security, welfare, unemployment compensation, and along six blocks of Franklin Avenue more than 30 stores are closed.

title: THE GARBAGE CRISIS: TIME FOR SOLUTIONS
description: I applaud Shelly Feuer Domash's article ''The Garbage Crisis: Going Beyond 'Good Guys' and 'Bad Guys.' '' The state and the Island's elected representatives must address one of the area's most serious environmental problems - the disposal of our solid waste.

title: Permission to Sublet
description: Question: I own a cooperative apartment in Manhattan. I expect to be transferred, possibly out of the country, in the near future. Since I hope to return to New York some day, I would like to rent my apartment for however long I may be gone. My co-op board will not approve long-term rental arrangements, although a few one-year rentals have been approved. Can I challenge the policy of my co-op board in court? ... D.A., Manhattan.

title: 'YOU DON'T HAVE TO BE CRUEL TO BE FUNNY'
description: The way to do a topical revue, says Martin Charnin, the only way, is to do it the way Julius Monk, the doyen of light cabaret did, with utmost restraint. ''Satirical, topical, sophisticated, chic, yes,'' Mr. Charnin explains, ''but it must not be allowed to become so insular that a member of the audience is lost for a frame of reference.''

title: Index; International
description: Three G.I.'s relieved of duties in Salvador after copter incident 3 Lyons awaiting Klaus Barbie, city's former Gestapo chief 3 Paraguay says U.S. gave it intel- ligence data on dissident 4 Around the World 5 U.N. official protests reported at- tacks on Guatemalan refugfees 6 Famine again perils parts of the sub-Saharan region 6 Spanish Socialists face battle with rightists on abortion 10 Thais let Cambodians refugees flee further from border 11 Economy, not arms, may sway West German voters 13 Bush favors continued talks even after NATO deploys missiles 14 Woman says Soviet chess offi- cials deprived her of victory 16 Seven Palestinians killed in in- timidation efforts in Sidon 19 Government/Politics Kennedy vows strong role in aid- ing Democrats in 1984 elections 28 Republicans gear up for '84 with House video tapes 29 City report urges preservation of Staten Island greenbelt 34 Energy Rising prices for natural gas hit Californians 27 General Around the Nation 22 The steel town of Aliquippa, Pa., is heavy with despair 22 Eight relatives charged in kid- napping of rich widow 24 Man who says he has married 105 women on trial for fraud 25 Groucho Marx's companion and bank battle over estate 26 Two justices defend judicial con- duct of Friess 33 Health/Science N.Y.U. Hospital planning to offer only specialty care 35 The death of a hospital patient is attributed to undue force 38 Education/Welfare Norfolk, Va., schools propose plan to court to end busing 23 Donors to Neediest Cases Fund cite desire to ease hardships 47 Arts/Entertainment ''Petria's Wreath,'' Serbo-Croa- tian film about a woman's life 49 ''Resident Alien,'' Marianne Marcellin reminisces 50 Dianne McIntyre's Sounds in Mo- tion performs 51 Music: Debuts in review 54 Style Daughter of Sara and Gerald Murphy recalls her childhood 56

title: TIMES AND UNIONS TO DISCUSS EXTENDING PACTS
description: Unions representing employees at The New York Times are planning discussions with management officials this week on the newspaper's proposal for a three-year contract extension. It would provide $110 a week in wage increases and a pay incentive for early acceptance of the offer.

title: WHITNEY 'SPECTACULAR'
description: Nam June Paik's ''V-yramid,'' the sculpture composed of 40 television sets that attracted wide attention at the Whitney Museum retrospective of his work last year in New York, will be part of a new exhibition opening Friday at the Whitney branch in Stamford.

title: POLL SHOWS LESSENING OF FEAR THAT U.S. MILITARY IS LAGGING
description: The Reagan Administration has begun a costly program to build more Trident submarines. Page 17. By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT

title: Ladds, Peter S. Marlette Engaged to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Preston Ladds Jr. of Buffalo have announced the engagement of their daughter, Helen Compton Ladds, to Peter Stewart Marlette, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Newton Marlette, also of Buffalo. The wedding is planned for Aug. 20.

title: ARTICLE ON ABORTION DRAWS READERS' REPLIES
description: The article distorts the real issue. To state that ''no one argues much any more'' over whether ''an innocent human life'' is destroyed in an abortion ignores the fact that no one today can claim on a scientific basis that at conception, or at any particular point in time, an individual human person comes into existence.

title: HOPE AND SUSPICION MARK PLAN TO REDEVELOP HARLEM
description: THERE are neighborhoods in New York City where the blight and devastation are even more extensive than in Harlem. But in no other community do the city's housing policies have as potentially great an impact as in that storied, predominantly black enclave north of Central Park.

title: Elisabeth A. Fairlie Becomes Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Newman Fairlie Jr. of Upper Montclair, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elisabeth Anne Fairlie, to Frederick George Bannerot 4th, son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Bannerot 3d of Charleston, W.Va.

title: A BALANCHINE MASTERPIECE IS REVIVED
description: American Ballet Theater's new and unexpected staging of George Balanchine's ''Symphonie Concertante,'' 30 years after it dropped out of the New York City Ballet's repertory, restores a major Balanchine work with exciting success to the international ballet scene. The company premiere was part of Ballet Theater's brief season at the Kennedy Center last month, and the work will be seen in New York when ABT comes to the Metropolitan Opera House in May. This revival raises questions about other Balanchine ''lost'' ballets and reminds us how extraordinarily prolific a creative period the mid-1940's were for the choreographer.

title: House Gains On Mrs. Gorsuch
description: With the help of a Federal judge, Congress last week vaulted the legal roadblock raised by the Justice Department and continued its pursuit of Environmental Protection Agency Administrator Anne M. Gorsuch.

title: 'HUMOR AND PLAY IN ART' IS JUST THAT
description: HER name is Yoa, and she is an extraordinary acrobat. Effortlessly, she wraps herself around a swinging trapeze, assuming graceful configurations and odd contortions. As she arches her back, her narrow torso rises toward the ceiling, controlled by a string.

title: Arrest Is Fatal In Suriname
description: In tiny, isolated Suriname, 15 of the most prominent citizens were dragged from their beds in December on suspicion of plotting against the military ruler, Lieut. Col. Desi Bouterse. They were beaten, mutilated, then killed ''while trying to escape,'' as the official account put it.

title: SORRY, WRONG NUMBER-SORT OF
description: WHEN Prof. Victor Reed finally calls after 15 years, are we going to have messages for him! My husband, also Victor Reed, although not Professor Victor Reed, has been receiving the professor's phone calls since 1968 when he (and we) lived in Manhattan. Although Reed is as common a name as one can come across in America, Victor, I thought, lent the name a uniqueness that stood alone, say, in a telephone book. Apparently not.

title: WATT PLANS BROAD CHANGES IN PERSONNEL OF PARK SERVICE
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt is preparing broad changes in the organization and personnel of the National Park Service, according to officials in the service.

title: 2 MORE HELD IN $11 MILLION THEFT
description: In predawn arrests in Miami and on Staten Island, the Federal Bureau of Investigation seized two more men yesterday in the theft of $11 million at a Bronx armored car company.

title: Topics; Compulsions; Marathon Man
description: Not since Ronald Reagan took a month off in the summer of 1981 have Type B's had such comforting news. Marathon runners, an article in The New England Journal of Medicine reports, have a personality disorder similar to that of anorectic women.

title: BEING WOMEN
description: OLD DEVOTIONS By Ursula Perrin. 264 pp. New York: The Dial Press. $14.95.

title: WEINBERGER ON THE RAMPARTS
description: Theodore H. White's most recent book is ''America in Search of Itself.''

title: 96 TRAILER OWNERS FACE EVICTION IN NORWALK
description: NORWALK NEARLY 200 residents of La Porta Trailer Park here are faced with eviction and may have no place to move their low-cost homes. The plight of the 96 mobile-home owners underscores the severe shortage of low- and middle-income housing in the area, and the even greater lack of lots for mobile homes in Connecticut.

title: U.S. World Cup Skiers Sidelined by Injuries
description: Two members of the United States women's ski team, including the Alpine star Christin Cooper, will be sidelined for the remainder of the 1983 World Cup season because of injuries, officials said today.

title: Soviet Women Pull Out Of Luge Competition
description: The Soviet women's luge team withdrew from the 23d World Luge Championships today to protest the disqualification of two members of the four-woman team.

title: STEP BY STEP THROUGH THE ALHAMBRA
description: ROBERT PACKARD is a professor of humanities at Stevens Institute of Technology.

title: WITH A DASH OF CREATIVITY
description: IL CASTELLO opened three months ago in a location that has previously housed at least three other restaurants. Because the last two tenants were Spanish, the decorations of the two small dining rooms were heavy with beams and wrought iron. The new owner, Gino Pena, formerly the maitre d'hotel at La Primavera in East Hills, has lightened the look of the place.

title: CHICKEN LIVERS: CHEAP BUT INTERNATIONAL IN FLAVOR
description: MANY people are familiar with the Jewish delicacy chopped chicken livers. Yet there are many other ways of preparing chicken livers, one of the cheapest meats on the market. Every country has its own special recipe. The French saute them in butter with a dash of vermouth or make them into pate. The Italians cook them with broth and juniper berries and spread the mixture on a hearty peasant bread to make an appetizer called crostini. They also serve them with risatta and as a sauce for spaghetti. In Morocco they are sauteed in butter with cumin and coriander and served on couscous.

title: A Depressing Season to Hunt Bluebill
description: BRANFORD, Conn. WHERE had all the bluebills gone? Oliver (Bud) Beckley, whose home fronts on Long Island Sound and who has hunted those tough, fast and handsome ducks for decades, didn't know, and neither did I.

title: Future Events; All for a Good Cause
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Irish-American Amity Feb. 9 - William V. Shannon, Walter J.P. Curley, John D.J. Moore, William Howard Taft 3d and Raymond R. Guest will be honored at the American Irish Foundation's 20th anniversary dinner at the Pierre for their efforts to strengthen American-Irish relations while serving as ambassadors to Ireland. In lieu of speeches there will be readings by Maureen O'Hara of excerpts from the honorees' favorite poems. The foundation, established to strengthen the historic bonds between the two countries, sponsors cultural projects in Ireland. Tickets, $250, from 755-1190.

title: Gwendolyn A. Fager To Wed in September
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald Joseph Fager of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gwendolyn Anne Fager, to David Steven Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Claude Smith, also of New Canaan. A September wedding is planned.

title: OF LAWYERS, ETHICS AND BUSINESS
description: WASHINGTON LAWYER A, helping his corporate client merge with a smaller, cashrich company, gets some troubling news just hours before the closing. The rosy financial picture of his client that was presented to the stockholders of both companies may be false. Should he tell the stockholders before going through with the deal?

title: COMPARING SYSTEMS FOR CO-OPS
description: THE boards of many cooperatives and condominiums are currently d ebating, amid a sea of uncertainties, whether to install franchised c able or private dish-antenna receiving systems for television.

title: CORPORATE GIFTS LEVELING OFF
description: ''THOUGH we've always upped our pledge by 20 percent a year, in 1982 we had to hold our contributions to the 1981 level.'' The speaker was the owner of a Deer Park metals company, and his response is typical for corporations across Long Island.

title: ALBANY
description: IN outlining his $31.5 billion budget proposal last week, Governor Cuomo returned over and over to what has become one of his favorite images. ''The challenges before us de mand a shared and unqualified acceptance of the sacrifice,'' he said. ''This pain must be shared by each member of our family.''

title: Enforce Speed Laws On the Turnpike
description: As we live a half-mile from the Connecticut Turnpike, in the summer with the windows open there is a constant, irritating roar. So we have a personal sympathy for the people you described (''Living in the Turnpike's Shadow,'' Jan. 16).

title: California Would Accept Warrants for Taxes
description: California will accept registered warrants from taxpayers if the state is forced to issue warrants to cover its bills, a tax board said Friday.

title: MISS WARWICK TO SING
description: Dionne Warwick, who in the 1960's belted out hits by Burt Bacharach and Hal David - songs that were one and the same with that decade's pop sophistication - will appear at the Ritz Theater in Elizabeth on Saturday for two shows (7 and 10 P.M.).

title: Starling Stops Baret in 4 In Welterweight Fight
description: Marlon Starling of Hartford, the welterweight ranked sixth by the World Boxing Council, scored a fourth-round knockout over Jose Baret of New York today.

title: MANCINI SHOWS HIS DESIRE
description: Sunday night in the Palazzo della Sporto in this Alpine village of 5,000, Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini will discover if his fighting skills have been affected since his punches led to the death of Duk Koo Kim almost three months ago.

title: HAMILTON CAPTURES 3RD STRAIGHT TITLE
description: Scott Hamilton dazzled a capacity crowd of 15,719 at Civic Arena tonight and captured the senior men's title at the United States Figure Skating championship for the third straight year.

title: CITIZEN GROUP SAYS CITY PROVIDES POOR CARE FOR HOMELESS FAMILIES
description: The prospects of homeless families finding decent emergency shelter and permanent housing have deteriorated over the past 10 years, and services the city provides these families are often ''unacceptable,'' according to the report of a new study by a childadvocacy group.

title: BUDGET MESSAGE REOPENS DEBATE ON AUTO BUREAUS
description: WHITE PLAINS ONE sentence in Governor Cuomo's 1983 budget message last week has rekindled a controversy over the planned transfer of the county's three motor vehicle offices to state control.

title: CONTRIBUTORS TO NEEDIEST CITE A DESIRE TO EASE HARDSHIPS
description: For many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, a happy family and simple material comforts are at the heart of their happiness and well-being, and they often voice the hope that their donations can ease the loneliness or privation of those less fortunate.

title: De Castella Breaks 15-Kilometer Record
description: Rob de Castella won the 15-kilometer Gasparilla Distance Classic today in a world-record time of 42 minutes, 46 seconds.

title: SCHOOL AID BATTLE HEATS UP IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY BARELY was the ink dry on Governor Cuomo's education aid proposal when a barrage of fierce but polite criticism descended on him from legislators who vowed to oppose it.

title: HARTMAN PLOTS COURSE WITH NEW WORKS
description: IN its struggle to secure a foothold in the regional theater firmament, Stamford's Hartman Theater may be reversing a stereotype, and devising a new strategy for survival.

title: WILDLIFE DISEASES STUDIED AT UCONN
description: TWELVE years ago, a board of fish and game commissioners set up a center at the University of Connecticut at Storrs to investigate diseases that were affecting everything from blue herons to black bears.

title: FEARS OF CONDOMINIUMS ALLAYED
description: In 1979, developers who wanted to put 252 garden apartments on the 17-acre site of the Daurenheim nursey in Wantagh, L.I., met stiff opposition from residents of the area and the Hempstead Town Board refused to change the one-family zoning of the land. A few model homes were erected but did not sell, and the property stood empty, with the old greenhouses on it becoming a target for vandals.

title: NEWS OF RECORDS: NOISE-FREE DISKS
description: While manufacturers and the trade press are all agog with the imminent arrival of compact audio disks played with a laser beam, CBS Records, for one, is not neglecting the ordinary -and not so ordinary - LP. Although it has already sealed an arrangement with Sony to manufacture the compact laser disks in the United States at some time in the future, CBS in the meantime is protecting its flanks by starting a new drive to capture the LP user.

title: Article 212724 -- No Title
description: Prime Minister George C. Price presented a budget to the House of Representatives today that was the equivalent of $97.3 million for the 1983-84 fiscal year. He said the budget represented an increase of 6 percent over the 1981-82 budget. Mr. Price said expenditures would be financed by $50.8 million in locally generated revenue, $12.7 million in expected grants and $33.8 million in loans.

title: CONTENT WITH ONE'S LOT
description: In a triumph of ingenuity, a small masonry house fills a tall order for a Princeton, N.J., couple who asked for - and got - the architectural moon on their shoe- box-sized piece of property. Constructed of buff-gray, scored concrete block, the exterior grid (top) receives doors and windows gracefully. In compliance with a request of the clients, masonry was chosen for its ease of care and for its energy efficiency. An opening in the dining room wall (right) is able to ''frame'' a prized portrait in the living room.

title: HOW SURVEY WAS CONDUCTED
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from Jan. 16 through Jan. 19 with 1,597 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.

title: In a Medieval Mood
description: Medieval music performed on authentic instruments will be presented by Pomerium Musices at 3 P.M. today in Corpus Christi Church, under the direction of Alexander Blachly.

title: N.Y.U. HOSPITAL PLANS TO DIVERT ROUTINE CASES
description: New York University Medical Center is developing a plan under which patients seeking routine care or uncomplicated surgery would be referred to a less sophisticated and less costly hospital, according to center officials.

title:
DINING OUT;
AUTHENTICITY IN INDIAN CUISINE
description: ALTHOUGH Curries n' Spice, the name of a new restaurant in Kingston, sounds rather like a cute Americanism for an Indian-style luncheon or dinner spot, this could not be further from the truth. The owner-chef, Tehmina Alphonse, a native of Hyderabad, opened this appealing little restaurant after much urging from friends and students of her cooking school.

title: Discovering Long Island
description: A good newspaper article has been defined as one that impels the reader to delve more deeply into the subject discussed. That's just what Richard F. Shepard's amusing thumbnail sketch of Long Island history did for me (''About Long Island,'' Jan. 16).

title: McEnroe Meets Lendl in Final
description: Everyone has a piece of advice for John McEnroe these days on how he can beat Ivan Lendl, who will again be McEnroe's opponent in Sunday afternoon's final of the United States Pro Indoor championships.

title: LEBANON: INVITATION TO P.L.O. 'DEVILRY'
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE AFRICA 30 YEARS LATER
description: THE AFRICANS By David Lamb. 363 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: REAGAN STILL CAN'T HOLD SPENDING DOWN
description: THE cynics may be right after all. When the Reagan Administration arrived in Washington in January 1 981, the old-timers pointed out that it was far easier to cut taxes t han to curtail spending. The unprecedented spending cutbacks made int he spring of 1981 seemed at first to deny the conventional wisdom, b ut the new Federal budget confirms the Government's inability to m atch the heroic 1981 tax cuts with spending cuts of similar m agnitude.

title: Double Engagement in Rolland Family
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth S. Rolland of North Brunswick, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Jane Rolland, to Randolph S. Shipper. Announcement has also been made of the engagement of Miss Rolland's brother, Robert J. Rolland, and Cathy Jo Mansfield.

title: Q&A
description: Question:We would like to visit the Marquesas Islands in the Pacific. Where can we obtain information about flights, accommodations and tours? - W.M.H., Chattanooga, Tenn. Answer:The Tahiti Tourist Board (4405 Riverside Drive, Burbank, Calif. 91505; 213-841-8802) can supply you with a general information brochure, a map of the islands, a list of guesthouses, a schooner schedule and the schedule of the local airline, Air Polynesie.

title: A 99 BARGAIN?
description: HOBOKEN THE setting is the show and the audience is the star. People are packed into the back room of the Beat 'n Path Cafe on Washington Street. Some of them carry in their own chairs and drinks from the restaurant in front. During the performance, they cheer, they jeer and they react.

title: STRONG 1984 ROLE VOWED BY KENNEDY
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, taking a leading role even though he is not a 1984 Presidential candidate, said today that the Democrats had to be not only the party of social justice but also the party of economic growth.

title: PERFORMANCE ART: PREMIERE OF 'UNITED STATES'
description: For all the epic breadth of her four-part, two-evening ''United States,'' which received its first complete performance Thursday and Friday nights at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, what seems most striking about Laurie Anderson's performance-art extravaganza is its fragility. That quality manifests itself in part through her own elfin personality -purposeful yet delicate and lonely, too, on that big stage amidst all that larger-than-life equipment.

title: EVEN FLAWED MOLIERE CAN HOLD SURPRISES
description: As a rule, a disappointing production of a classic does more than discredit the people who are performing it, it tends to tarnish the play itself a bit, too - at least for the time being. Watching and growing weary, we begin to wonder if the piece is really and truly the masterwork the textbooks have proclaimed it. Have we been too credulous, do we need to take a sharper, less indulgent look? It may require another 10 or 15 years of theatergoing, and the sudden unpredictable luck of a genuinely superb production, to persuade us that the play is precisely as brilliant as our teachers once told us it was.

title: TWO SHOWS CELEBRATE THE HUDSON RIVER AND ONE OF ITS SCHOOL
description: YONKERS BEING but 315 miles long, the Hudson River is a runt when compared with, say, the Mississippi (2,348 miles). But it was thought noble enough to have a school of painting named after it, not to mention the museum in Yonkers where there are two shows dealing with, respectively, the river and with a representative of the school. Both displays remain through March 6.

title: SHULTZ KEEPS THE LINES OPEN IN ASIA
description: PEKING AS they were seated in the Great Hall of the People for the start of their meeting Friday, Secretary of State George P. Shultz told Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang that he had to express some disappointment. Before Mr. Zhao could inquire, Mr. Shultz said, ''I invested in a new fur hat and haven't been able to wear it because it is so warm.''

title: Loft Warning
description: To the Editor:

title: Lisa Ruth Singer Engaged
description: The engagement of Lisa Ruth Singer to John Fellows Gowen Magoun has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Singer of Woodcliff Lake, N.J., parents of the future bride. Mr. Magoun is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Peabody Magoun 3d of Manchester, Mass. Miss Singer is a film editor in New York. Her fiance is studying for his master's degree in scenic design at New York University's Tisch School of the Arts.

title: Marjorie Aldrich To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Roberts Aldrich of Norwood, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marjorie Elizabeth Aldrich, to Charles Everest Ward, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Douglas Ward of Washington Depot, Conn.

title: Reagan Tries a Different Path To His Goals
description: In Washington last week there was much talk about the Administration's new economics. Equally evident in the numbers and the language of President Reagan's Budget Message and the Economic Report was his old philosophy. Roosevelt was traded for Rousseau and the New Deal ''safety net'' became the 18th-century moralist's ''social contract.'' But Mr. Reagan's guiding principle was one often cited in his Presidential campaigns: Government's first constitutional obligation is the national defense. His $848.5 billion proposal for Federal spending in the 1984 fiscal year includes a 10 percent increase for the Pentagon and a 14 percent reduction in social programs.

title: Wendell Rawls Jr.
description: WENDELL RAWLS Jr. is a national correspondent based in the Atlanta bureau of The New York Times.

title: 71 GREYHOUNDS KILLED IN BLAZE
description: At least 71 greyhounds were killed today in a fire that destroyed a private kennel in this Windham County community.

title: WHY KIMMELMAN IS SILENT
description: NEWARK ''IT HAS been widely reported that I object to the moment of silence as a matter of conscience, that the new law requiring it in the public schools of New Jersey is personally repugnant to me,'' Irwin I. Kimmelman, the state's Attorney General, said. ''This is not true. My objection is totally on constitutional grounds.''

title: THE PHOENIX RISES
description: Has concrete study of limited lines of opening play replaced general understanding of the game? It is truly amazing what success is currently being had with old moves that never enjoyed victories in their own time. This is not a case of roses that are born to blush much later, but of drab plants or weeds of an earlier generation that decades later suddenly take first place in the flower show.

title:
STAMPS;
U.S. TERRITORY RELEASES ITS FIRST NEW ISSUE
description: Palau, a Pacific Ocean island group that had been administered by the United States as a Trust Territory, will begin issuing its own postage stamps sometimes in mid-March.

title: G.O.P. GEARS UP FOR '84 WITH HOUSE TV TAPES
description: Republican officials have been videotaping House floor proceedings since Congress convened last month and cataloging the tapes as possible weapons against Democratic incumbents in the 1984 campaign, a party spokesman says.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 1983
description: International China's Prime Minister will visit the United States this year. The White House announced that Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang had accepted an invitation from President Reagan and would meet with Mr. Reagan at a date ''to be mutually agreed on.'' (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: COURTING THE ELITE AT CONDE NAST
description: THE last issue of Vanity Fair came out in February 1936, the midst of the Depression and, publisher Conde Nast regretfully conceded, no time for Gershwin or Gertrude Lawrence or Gloria Swanson or the frivolous magazine that exalted them all.

title: IT'S NOT ALL CHINESE BANQUETS
description: FOX BUTTERFIELD. chief of The Times Boston bureau, was head of the Peking bureau for two years; he is the author of ''China: Alive in the Bitter Sea'' (Times Books).

title: POLICE OFFICER'S TRIAL IN NEW MILFORD SET
description: ''IT could happen anywhere,'' First Selectman Clifford C. Chapin of New Milford said the other day. ''A few rotten apples in a barrel.'' The situation Mr. Chapin was referring to is the case of three members of the town's 30-officer Police Department who have pleaded guilty to perjury, hindering an investigation or larceny in connection with burglaries in New Milford over a two-and-a-half-year period. The town, in Litchfield County, is northeast of Danbury and just south of Kent.

title: WOMAN SAYS PLEA FOR A VISA COST HER A SOVIET CHESS TITLE
description: Anna Aksharumova says she believes that Soviet chess officials deprived her of the Soviet women's title because of her efforts to emigrate to Israel.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY STILL NEEDS LONG-TERM CARE
description: SOCIAL Security is not going to be the same. That much, but little more, was evident last week in the preliminary skirmishes over the $168 billion bipartisan plan to rescue Social Security from bankruptcy.

title: GUTSINESS IN THE PRE-LIBERATION ERA
description: IAM a woman struggling with the women's movement and my place in it, and I suspect that I have lots of company. As more and more of us go to work outside the home, we find ourselves picking through the cliches of yesterday to find a fair and equitable way for two parties to live together without one or the other collapsing of fatigue.

title: LITERACY-OLD AND NEW
description: NOW that Time magazine has named the computer as its Man of the Year, I feel even more concerned than I did after my 12-year-old son returned last summer from a week at computer camp.

title:
GARDENING;
GROWING STRAWBERRY PLANTS FROM SEED
description: LAST year it was potatoes; this year it is strawberries: It is possible for the homeowner to grow both these plants from seed. The new Explorer potato is said to have met with only modest success last year. It remains to be seen how well the new Sweet Heart strawberry will do, since it has not generally been available until this year.

title: QUILTS: REFLECTION OF THEIR TIMES
description: MORRISTOWN IN 1978, Nan Mutnick, curator of decorative arts at the Morris Museum of Arts and Sciences, undertook a study of the quilt collections owned by more than 200 New Jersey museums and historical societies.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: HARTSDALE FOUR little girls are sitting in a little room. They are wearing an assortment of blue jeans, hair ribbons and T-shirts. They are wiggling in their chairs, pulling at strands of hair and talking about their fathers, who are dead.

title: SOVIET EMIGRES: BEGINNING AGAIN
description: ISAAC GURION PLON was 16 days old, and his parents were fussing over him. Marina Plon, a cardiologist in her native Russia, arranged a yellow coverlet over his shoulders, making cooing noises in his ears. Mark Plon, an anesthesiologist, tickled the baby's chin and grinned with the sort of pride and amazement new fathers are known for. ''He is an American,'' he said to a visitor. ''I am proud to have an American baby.''

title: Bermuda Asks Britain To Recall Governor
description: The Bermuda government has told Britain it wants the Governor, Sir Richard Posnett, sent home while it investigates allegations of a financial scandal, officials here said today.

title: Greece Warns Reagan On Aid to the Turks
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou has told President Reagan that his proposal to nearly double military aid to Turkey will diminish the chances of reaching agreement on the status of United States bases in Greece.

title: No Headline
description: Today, no one disputes the fact that times have changed for the automobile industry. The question is: How do successful dealers such as James Jennings remain viable and what role will successful sales outlets play in supporting an auto recovery?

title: First Jersey's View
description: To the Business Editor: The most interesting aspect of your article about First Jersey's battles with the Securities and Exchange Commission (''An Upstart Broker Battles the S.E.C.,'' Jan.23) was the contrast between the S.E.C.'s allegations - all unproven - and First Jersey's extraordinary performance over the past nine years - all proven.

title: Villanova Relay Wins
description: The Villanova women's two-mile relay team shattered the meet record with a time of 8 minutes 54.7 seconds at the Princeton Women's Relays today. The foursome consisted of Veronica McIntosh, Vickie Brown, Patty Bradley and Joanne Kehs. Princeton and Morgan State tied for first place in the shuttle hurdles in 32.3 seconds, also a meet record.

title: DECIDING TAX ABATEMENTS WITHOUT PRESSURE
description: When Deputy Mayor Kenneth Lipper took over the panel that reviews tax abatements in New York City, he said he wanted to establish several procedural standards. One was that ultimatums would not be tolerated.

title: FROM L.I. TO THE NEW YORK STAGE
description: THE Island has hardly been a standard or successful tryout center for plays that move into the commercial mainstream. Perhaps that's changing. Suddenly, the New York theater season has three new works with Long Island roots.

title: Passers on Display
description: With the teams having had barely a week of preparation, passing is expected to be dominant in the Pro Bowl football game today in Honolulu matching stars of the National Conference against the American. ''When you see Dan Fouts in a game, what do you think he's going to do?'' said Walt Michaels of the Jets, coach of the A.F.C. team, referring to the San Diego quarterback who will be playing for him.

title: POLL FINDS PUBLIC IS CONFUSED ON EVACUATION PLAN
description: IT was after last year's mock emergency at the Indian Point 3 nuclear plant, Lieut. Gov. Alfred B. DelBello recalled last week, that Daniel P. Guido, the county's Public Safety Commissioner, ''said he thought there would be a spontaneous response in the event of an emergency'' at the Indian Point nuclear plants.

title: 2 FATHERS JOIN ZIMBABWE SEARCH
description: Two American men flew today to a strife-ridden region of southwestern Zimbabwe where their two sons were kidnapped by rebels six months ago.

title: Kean Proposes A Budget That Makes No Waves
description: For the past year, the Democrats who control the New Jersey Legislature have bickered with the Republican in the Governor's office over fiscal troubles and what to do about them. Last week, though, they seemed to praise Governor Kean's new budget, if only with faint damns.

title: A HOUSE, ONCE AGAIN, IS JUST SHELTER
description: FOR a long time, equity in a house was like money in the bank, a r eliable asset that would grow steadily and be available for a rainy d ay. When inflation struck, home ownership was even better than moneyi n the bank because house prices kept well ahead of inflation as the v alue of bank balances shrank. But now, for the first time in a generation, housing has gone sour. House prices are stalled or even falling, depending on whose estimate is to be believed. Mortgage rates, though lower than last year's highs, still are so high that many people cannot afford to buy, and real-estate agents make conflicting predictions about how low the rates will have to go before setting loose a flood of ''pent-up demand.'' Meanwhile, owners must cut their prices or sit longer with expensive investments they want to dispose of. The era of guaranteed profits from residential properties has ended.

title: CABLE WOOS THE DAYTIME VIEWER
description: Alexis Greene is a freelance writer who frequently reports on the television scene.

title: 8 POOR CHARGED IN KIDNAPPING OF RICH WIDOW
description: Eight eastern Kentucky residents will be arraigned Monday on charges of kidnapping a relative who had escaped poverty through wealthy benefactors.

title: Heights Addenda
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DEMOCRATS EXPECT TO EASE REAGAN CUTS
description: New York's three Democratic members on the House Budget Committee said today that they were confident they would be able to eliminate in committee those provisions of President Reagan's proposed 1984 budget that would have the worst effect on New York City and the state.

title: COVERED WITH STYLE; photographs by Marc Bulka
description: This spring, hats are more than fashion afterthoughts. With brims that are wide or narrow and shapes that are soft or severe, they add a needed stylish balance to the season's new figure-defining clothes.

title: PROTECTING THE ADVERTISER: A DILUTION OF THE FIRST AMENDMENT
description: THE United States Supreme Court is likely to rule in favor of a New Jersey drug company's free-speech case against a Postal Service regulation that prohibits the unsolicited mailing of advertisements for contraceptives. More's the pity if it does.

title: FIREWORKS ZONE CHANGE EYED
description: SINCE they moved in next door to the Grucci Fireworks Display Company in Bellport 25 years ago, Peter and Marilyn Capizzi have learned to live with the blasts that they say rattle the walls when the Gruccis test their products and with the debris that sometimes falls from the sky afterward.

title: BRITISH MUSEUM
description: To the Editor: In connection with the article about one of my favorite places in the world, the British Museum, I would like to offer some tips to other travelers and visitors.

title: STATION IS SHOWCASE FOR ART
description: WORN volume of signatures dating from 1893, when local residents came to the railroad station to accept their packages, was found in the attic when the Southport station was renovated last year to house a new concept in showcasing art.

title: BY BACK ROADS TO AMERICA
description: BLUE HIGHWAYS A Journey Into America. By William Least Heat Moon (William Trogdon). Illustrated. 421 pp. Boston: Atlantic-Little, Brown & Co. $17.50.

title: HOW DIRECT IS A DIRECT FLIGHT?
description: According to the Official Airline Guide, Northwest Orient's Flight 542 from Las Vegas to Newark starts in a DC-10 in Las Vegas then flies to Phoenix and then to Minneapolis. There is a plane change to a Boeing 727-200, which proceeds to Milwaukee, then Detroit and finally arrives at Newark.

title: MAYOR GETS EARFUL IN BRIDGEPORT
description: THE event was billed as a chance for ''average Joe Citizen'' to say hello and take a quick tour of the Mayor's office, but instead Bridgeport's Mayor, Leonard S. Paoletta, stole a page from Dear Abby.

title: Coming of Age In Anthropology: Doubts on Samoa
description: Those shadings of the word ''academic'' that imply pedantry or merely theoretical importance perhaps come from the fact that intellectual tempests often occur in very small teacups. But from time to time, academic battles acquire Realpolitik dimensions. The ''nature vs. nurture'' contest in the behavioral sciences is one of these, and a new book promises to rekindle old rages.

title: Iona Tops Fordham On Late Rally, 66-64
description: Iona changed tactics in the second half and rallied from a 10-point deficit for a 66-64 victory over Fordham today at Mulcahy Center.

title: March Wedding For Miss Cornell And R.P. Krist
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Cornell of New Canaan, Conn., and Prescott, Ariz., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Candice Cornell, to Robert Peter Krist, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter C. Krist of Westport, Conn., and Quechee, Vt.

title: NEWARK'S BLACK-OWNED CABLE
description: NEWARK WHAT is said to be the first black-owned cable-television system on the East Coast is considered by its president as not only an entertainment medium, but also an opportunity for Newark residents to be involved in their government.

title: Rivalry Is Heated Over Cup Defense
description: Starting at 6 A.M. each day at Jack Lambert's Sport Center, Dennis Conner takes on his crew in racquetball for an hour. After weeks of practice, Conner has become unbeatable. The drive to win is absolute, whether Conner is sailing a 12-Meter yacht or working out with his crew.

title: Mets Sign Hodges
description: As expected, Ron Hodges, who has been a catcher for the Mets since 1973, signed a two-year contract yesterday with an option for a third year. The Mets would not confirm the salary package, but it was estimated to be worth $350,000 for the three years.

title: U.S. SPENDING ON EACH RESIDENT PUT AT $2,591
description: The Federal Government spent an average of $2,591 for each resident of the United States last year, up from $2,414 the previous year, the Census Bureau reports.

title: Ex-U.M.W. Chief in Hospital
description: BARRE, Pa., Feb. 5 (AP) - W.A. Boyle, the former president of the United Mine Workers who was convicted of ordering the murder of a union rival and his family, was admitted to a hospital today, prison officials said.

title: States News Service
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. PRODUCTION of defense systems made in Connecticut would continue in high gear under the Reagan Administration's proposed 1984 budget, even with $55 billion in cuts the President called for in his message to Congress.

title: WHEN THE WORLD CAME DOWN THE STREET
description: ONE day not long ago, I watched several boys and girls - they were probably no more than 14 years old, ride down my street on new, beautifully tooled 10-speed bicycles. Each youngster was dressed in the best athletic clothing and footwear; each carried an expensive, finely lacquered tennis racket. For a moment, this parade of suburban affluence brought me to the edge of shock.

title: QUESTIONS ON THE TOLL ISSUE
description: HARTFORD THE removal of the tolls on Connecticut's parkways and bridges has moved into the forefront of the major issues facing the General Assembly this year.

title: GOOD SPOTS FOR SUNDAY BRUNCH
description: DURING the dreary days of February, Sunday brunch can often be a cheering pick-me-up. And recently, a few Connecticut restaurants have come up with some brunch ideas a bit different from the familiar eggs Benedict. The following are brunches we commend to your attention.

title: Lois Peltz Is Engaged to Jerry M. Brown, a Dentist
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Peltz of Middletown, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lois Beth Peltz, to Dr. Jerry Michael Brown, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving N. Brown of Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: CONCERT: JAVANESE GEMELAN MUSIC
description: Wesleyan University in Connecticut has for years been one of this country's principal centers for the study and performance of non-Western music, and nothing symbolizes that centricity better than the university's Javanese gamelan, which came to the American Museum of Natural History Wednesday night.

title: 18 DIE IN BOMBING AT P.L.O.'S CENTER IN WESTERN BEIRUT
description: At least 18 people were killed and 115 wounded today when a car packed with explosives blew up in front of the Palestine Liberation Organization Research Center, setting the building on fire.

title: Leslie G. Bennett, a Nurse, To Marry Dr. Jack Troper
description: Judge and Mrs. Edwin H. Bennett of Woodside, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Gail Bennett, to Dr. Jack Troper, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Troper of Forest Hills, Queens.

title: SKEPTICISM ON CLEANUP
description: WASHINGTON THE Reagan Administration says that its spending proposals for environmental programs in fiscal 1984 will allow for speedier cleanup of the nation's most dangerous hazardous-waste dump sites, 65 of which are in New Jersey.

title: Nuclear Panel Proposes Fine of Illinois Utility
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Friday it was proposing a $100,000 fine of the Commonwealth Edison Company for violations of rules on inspection and installation of safety equipment at its Braidwood nuclear plant.

title: Celebrating Robert Burns
description: Having grown up in Scotland, I was pleased to read Arthur T. Hadley's article ''Celebrating Robert Burns'' (Jan. 9). I thought readers would be interested to know that Burns Night is not celebrated just in ''New York, Edinburgh, London and Ayr,'' but that I have found that wherever I have been in the world there is an avid collection of Scots people who clannishly gather to arrange some sort of festivity on this occasion.

title: THE CARTOONIST'S ART
description: Original examples of the work of more than 500 cartoonists are on permanent display at the Museum of Cartoon Art in Port Chester, and now, through March 31, there is also a special exhibit on ''The Yellow Kid,'' America's first comic-strip character.

title: 'PETRIA'S WREATH,' A LIFE
description: ''Petria's Wreath'' tells of a Serbo-Croatian woman and her life of almost unbearable hardship, presenting her story in a style that is resolutely plain. Even when events in this story (which is based on a novel by Dragoslav Mihajlovic) are at their most crushingly sad, the film retains a simple dignity that can be quite haunting.

title: GLIMPSES OF AN ALMOST FORGOTTEN ARTISTS'COLONY ON L.I.
description: EVER since the mid-19th century, picturesque locales from Barbizon to Big Sur have attracted groups of like-minded artists whose presence has elevated sleepy rural hamlets and chaming seaside villages to the status of ''art colonies.''

title: Hard Sell in the Showroom
description: I enjoyed Andrew H. Malcolm's article on flagging auto sales, but I think the title was inaccurate (''Hard Sell in the Showroom,'' Jan. 9). Most of today's auto salesman and dealers don't know or understand much about salesmanship, much less ''hard sell.''

title: St. John's on TV
description: The St.John's-Georgetown basketball game Wednesday night at the Capital Centre in Landover, Md., will be available on closed-circuit television at the Redmen's Alumni Hall in Jamaica, Queens, at 8 P.M. Tickets are $5 for general admission and $3 for students and are sold only at St. John's University. The game will also be seen on USA Cable.

title: FREUD IS BETTER IN GERMAN
description: FREUD AND MAN'S SOUL By Bruno Bettelheim. 112 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $11.95.

title: MAKE GRADUTATION RATE THE BOTTOM LINE
description: THE National Collegiate Athletic Association's recent upgrading of academic requirements for college athletes was a courageous effort to stem exploitation. But tighter standards for admission and satisfactory academic progress create new problems, and perhaps more could be done by emphasizing graduation rates of scholarship athletes.

title: IT'S TIME TO OVERHAUL THE PORTFOLIO
description: CENTURY Capital Associates, an investment counseling firm, decided r ecently to sell all its Government long-term bonds from the pool of m ore than $1.6 billion that it manages. And Atalanta/Sosnoff Capital p urged more than $250 million in bonds from its $1 billion p ortfolio, now almost entirely positioned in the stock market.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Turning to TV Films ABC's mammoth mini-series ''The Winds of War'' - an adaptation of Herman Wouk's novel, which deals with events leading up to the United States involvement in World War II as experienced by an American Navy officer and his family - is finally upon us. The 18-hour, seven-night feature will begin Sunday evening at 8. Sunday and Monday's episodes will run three hours; Tuesday through Thursday episodes will last two hours each, and Friday and next Sunday's conclusion is from 8 to 11 P.M. ABC officials say the project cost $40 million -some of this amount will be recouped through commercials that cost $175,000 for 30 seconds.

title: STAGE: 'RESIDENT ALIEN,' REMINISCING
description: In ''Resident Alien'' at La Mama, Marianne Marcellin tells us about her life as a French Jew in Nazi-occupied Paris, as an aspiring actress and, later, as an immigrant to the United States. In outline, her story is a fairly interesting one, but as a playwright she is unable to give it dramatic impetus. The evening sounds like an unedited letter to a friend.

title: TALENT TEAMS UP ON MUSIC FOR MASSED KEYBOARDS
description: Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music and musicians.

title: IN POP, THE McGARRIGLE SISTERS KNOW NO BOUNDS
description: Kate and Anna McGarrigle are a stubborn pair of songwriters. The two sisters don't work like anyone else in pop music; in fact, they don't even work like each other. They are apparently content to tour infrequently and stay home in Montreal -writing songs, making albums, and performing informally - while their reputation is carried by fans, critics, and cover versions of their songs (notably by Linda Ronstadt, who has recorded Anna's ''Heart Like a Wheel'' and Kate's ''Mendocino''). Yet since 1975, they have released an album every few years that quietly defies everything else in pop and folk music.

title: New York Times Magazine February 6, 1983
description: William Safire 9 On Language Blowing My Whistle Russell Baker 12 Sunday Observer Handicappers Theodore H. White 14 Weinberger on the Ramparts Don Shewey 26 The Performing Artistry of Laurie Anderson Her panache is making an avant-garde medium a popular success. Robin Marantz Henig 28 AIDS: A New Disease's Deadly Odyssey Marilyn Bethany 48 Design Content With One's Odd Lot Craig Claiborne 50 Food with Pierre Franey A Taste Worth Cultivating 56 Fashion Covered With Style Terry Robards 58 Wine Inspiration for Heroic Deeds 60 Puzzles Answers, Page 64 78 Letters Cover: Photograph by Harry Benson. Copyright 1980, The New York Times

title: Jane Magennis Is Married
description: Jane Reynolds Magennis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack McAllister Magennis of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday to Gary Allen Moir, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vern Moir of Vancouver, Wash.

title: FINDING THE PEKING BEYOND THE TOUR BUS
description: CHRISTOPHER S. WREN is chief of the Peking bureau of The New York Times.

title: Adair Ann Brown To Marry in May
description: Adair Ann Brown, an assistant sales promotion manager for Blair Graphics in New York, and Dean W. Rowland, an electronics design engineer with Timex in Middlebury, Conn., plan to be married in May.

title: MOTORISTS RIDING OUT UPS AND DOWNS OF GAS PRICES
description: THE price of gasoline on Long Island has dropped an average 5 cents a gallon in recent weeks, but the savings will not last very long. A nickel-a-gallon increase in the Federal gasoline tax is scheduled to go into effect April 1.

title: No Headline
description: Villanova Is Upset in Big East

title: DIVERSION OF FUNDS VEXES FISHERMEN
description: TAXES, licensing fees and fines collected from commercial and sports fishermen who use the Island's salt waters are being diverted to other parts of the state, a number of officials said last week.

title: Lucy Talbot Is Engaged
description: Dr. and Mrs. Timothy Ralph Talbot Jr. of Haverford, Pa., and Deer Isle, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lucy Lee Talbot, to John Williams Myers, son of Mrs. Myron J. Cohn of Albany and the late James Carroll Myers. A June wedding is planned.

title: Data Bank; Feb. 6, 1983
ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: No Need for Panic

title: 3D-WORLD GROUP APPEARS TO EASE RADICAL STANCE
description: In a shift reflecting a move from radical to more moderate leadership, the nations grouped as nonaligned are considering a declaration that implicitly blames the Soviet Union as well as the United States for most of the world's tensions.

title: 3 ADVISORS RELIEVED OF DUTIES IN SALVADOR
description: Two United States warrant officers and a sergeant have been relieved of their duties in El Salvador because of an incident in which another American military adviser was wounded, a Pentagon spokesman said today.

title:
GARDENING;
GROWING STRAWBERRY PLANTS FROM SEED
description: LAST year it was potatoes; this year it is strawberries: It is possible for the homeowner to grow both these plants from seed. The new Explorer potato is said to have met with only modest success last year. It remains to be seen how well the new Sweet Heart strawberry will do, since it has not generally been available until this year.

title: A CEASE-FIRE IN THE FARE WARS
description: Finally, the airline industry seems poised for recovery. Airline travel increased during the holiday season and the gains are continuing. Aviation fuel prices started to drop last year and are expected to keep falling in the months ahead. Many of the nation's carriers have cut costs through labor concessions and more fuel-efficient planes. And, most important, the American economy shows signs of reawakening.

title: The Loss of Jobs
description: To the Business Editor: On behalf of the rail equipment and supply industry, let me explain what coal slurry pipelines would mean to my industry, one of the most deeply depressed in the nation. In 1979, our industry employed close to 500,000. Today, our unemployment rate stands at 61.8 percent.

title: KEEPING TRACK OF TOP RUNNERS
description: ''YOU might say this is my busy time of the year,'' said Ray Lumpp of East Williston. Besides his regular job as athletic director of the New York Athletic Club, Mr. Lumpp is busy with preparations for the Vitalis/U.S. Olympic Invitational track and field meet scheduled for next Saturday at the Brendan Byrne Arena in East Rutherford, N.J. Some of his attention is also focused beyond then, to Feb. 25 and the Athletic Congress indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden.

title: COMPULSIONS; Supply-Side Drug War
description: The Reagan Administration has taken a belated but essential step against illegal drugs, proposing a 43 percent budget increase for the State Department's International Narcotics Control Program. The proposed increase could make much more difference than is evident from the raise in dollars, from $37 million to $53 million.

title: AID TEAM IS READY FOR NUCLEAR MISHAP
description: AFTER several years of planning and meetings, two full-scale emergency exercises and months of subsequent review, a group of volunteers is now in place to assist and advise Governor O'Neill in the event of an accident at one of the state's commercial nuclear power facilities.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: A CHILDREN'S ALMANAC OF WORDS AT PLAY By Willard R. Espy. Illustrated by Bruce Cayard. 243 pp. New York: Clarkson N. Potter. Distributed by Crown. Cloth, $15.95. Paper, $8.95.

title: I.M. Pei Rediscovers China
description: Paul Goldberger's interesting article ''I.M. Pei Rediscovers China'' (Jan. 23) brought vividly to mind our firm's three and a half years' involvement in the planning, design and construction of the Fragrant Hill Hotel in Peking.

title: Sally Radcliffe Sandercock Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Vincent R. Sandercock of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sally Radcliffe Sandercock, to Dr. Robert Erquiaga-Michler of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Erquiaga of San Diego. A May wedding is planned.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Billy Olson, the first man to vault 19 feet indoors, is planning to defend his title at the USA/Mobil Indoor track and tield championships Feb. 25 at the Garden. ... Martina Navratilova, winner of two title tournaments and a losing finalist in two at the Garden in the last four years, has agreed to compete in the $350,000 Virginia Slims championships there March 23. ... Todd Blackledge of Penn State will receive the second Davey O'Brien National Quarterback Award at at the Fort Worth Club in Texas Feb. 15. Blackledge beat out John Elway of Stanford and Dan Marino of Pittsburgh for the award established in memory of the Texas Christian star who won the Heisman, Walter Camp and Maxwell trophies. ... Billy Taylor, former running back with the Giants, has signed with the Boston Breakers of the United states Football League. ... Bjorn Borg, whose retirement from pro tennis has been in the news recently, beat Roscoe Tanner Friday night in an exhibition match in Norfolk, Va., 6-4, 6-4 6-4. Borg served eight aces and Tanner 14.

title: Council Completed Its Assignment
description: I note with interest that Senator Carl A. Zinsser's committee includes the Council of Water Company Lands in the list of do-nothing committees (''Assembly Could End Existence of 7 Boards,'' Jan. 9).

title: AUSTERITY SQUEEZING REALTY WATCHDOGS
description: LAST year, the New Jersey Real Estate Commission revoked the licenses of 12 real-estate agents, one of w hom had failed to show up at several house closings because he had l ost more than $20,000 in down payments while gambling in Atlantic C ity.

title: Must We Stagnate?
description: Reaganomics: After two years of sunny predictions and gloomy results, accented by cheerful supply-side nostrums, the term has become an embarrassment. Now the Reagan team is unfolding a new economic strategy, one that is sober, intelligent and consistent. But by expecting so little, the strategy risks returning even less. Bold steps, not a conservative shuffle, are now needed to lead the world economy out of stagnation.

title: Tire Durability Rules Suspended
description: Most motorists pick tires by brand name, not engineering standards -Goodyear is the one with the blimp, Goodrich the one without. That's what most tire manufacturers want.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: Shark-Proof Suit
description: Ordinarily skin divers have little to fear from sharks; the divers mind their business, and the sharks mind theirs. But there's nothing like an armored skin-diving suit for greater peace of mind, Jeremiah S. Sullivan, a San Diego marine biologist, reasons.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: DESPITE Governor Cuomo's proposed reduction in state funds for the arts, neither Kitty Carlisle Hart, chairman of the New York Council on the Arts, nor Katherine F. Niles, president of the Council for the Arts in Westchester, seemed downcast Tuesday night. The occasion was a reception at the Sarah Lawrence Gallery, in the Performing Arts Center at Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers, to honor the two women and mark the opening of an exhibition, ''The United States of the Arts: The Contribution of the Arts Council, 1963-1983.''

title: Julie A. Black Will Marry Lawrence R. Silverman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Black of Closter, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julie Adrienne Black, to Lawrence Robert Silverman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allyn Silverman of Canton, Mass. The wedding is to be May 1.

title: Virginia B. Riehl Engaged to Arthur J. Bennert Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederic Albert Riehl of Woodstock, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Virginia Bauer Riehl, to Arthur James Bennert Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Bennert of Fairfield, Ohio. A May 28 wedding is planned.

title: THE TWO NATIONS
description: Jonathan Swift might have sent Gulliver to such a place: a country where people exist in the same space but perceive different realities and live by different clocks. That is South Africa.

title: AROUND THE CORNER, AN AGELESS CHINA
description: RICHARD BERNSTEIN, a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The Times, is the author of ''From the Center of the Earth: the Search for the Truth About China.'' By RICHARD BERNSTEIN

title: IN THE WAKE OF JOB LOSS, LOOK UP THE LADDER-NOT BACK DOWN
description: RECENTLY a friend of mine, a 45-year-old executive, was dismissed from his job after 18 years of loyal service to a large multinational corporation. Not wishing to burden his family, and feeling dejected and degraded, Jack continued to commute to New York City every day, taking the 7:31 A.M. train and returning on the 5:12 as if nothing had happened. This initial period of denial lasted until reality occurred and there was no more paycheck. Imagine the shock and hurt of Jack's wife upon learning of their situation.

title: A Matter of Sole
description: Russell Baker's article ''A Matter of Sole'' (Sunday Observer, Jan. 2) managed, with wit, to touch upon a serious problem in New York City - that of escalating store rents. Alas, where is the shoemaker to go when store rents reach skyscraper levels? The only means of survival with high commercial rents is high consumer prices, and yet, who can afford to pay $20 to have a sole repaired or a hem sewn?

title: February 6, 1983
description: NONFICTION THE AFRICANS. By David Lamb. 7 ART, MIND, AND BRAIN: A Cognitive Approach to Creativity. By Howard Gardner. 13 BANNED FILMS: Movies, Censors and the First Amendment.

title: A Man Could Get Hurt Out There
description: Trucking is never a genteel occupation; last week, it became a deadly one. Thousands of independent drivers pulled off the roads in a strike to protest higher Federal taxes. Hundreds of those who didn't were harassed, some with gunfire, and one was killed.

title: 'I KNOW YOU'RE FAMOUS. WHO ARE YOU'
description: YOU would like my friend Alan Cohen. He's a nice guy. That is not very descriptive, and you may well say lots of people are nice. How is he special or different from others? The fact is, Alan isn't very different at all. He looks a bit like half a dozen other people I know - average height with perhaps a tendency toward overweight.

title: No Headline
description: TULANE SURPRISES MEMPHIS ST., 58-56

title: WHERE DOES ART COME FROM?
description: ART, MIND, AND BRAIN A Cognitive Approach to Creativity.By Howard Gardner. Illustrated. 380 pp. New York: Basic Books. $20.

title: Cycle Show at Garden
description: More than 200 motorcycles, including vintage and customized vehicles and this year's models, will be on display today at the first consumer motorcycle show in Madison Square Garden, Seventh Avenue and 33d Street.

title: EL SALVADOR LOSES GROUND, NOT LEAST IN WASHINGTON
description: SAN SALVADOR THE Salvadoran Government suffered setbacks on the ground and in the legislative wars last week. Leftist guerrillas out-maneuvered the army and overran the southern city of Berlin. In Washington, Senate critics assailed Administration policy while House members launched a new attempt to suspend military aid to the embattled country.

title: PROSPECTS
description: The Mighty Dollar

title: A POOL ENJOINED
description: The gleaming 42- by 82-foot swimming pool is ready under its dome and the tanning lounge and exercise machines are all in place. But despite its official opening last December, the Clubhouse Recreation Center at the new Bay Club Condominiums in Bay Terrace, Queens, remains unused.

title: 'Reaganomics' Label Assailed
description: President Reagan defended his economic policies today, emphasizing the drop in unemployment reported Friday, and complained about the use of the word ''Reaganomics'' to describe his program.

title: NORFOLK, VA., SCHOOLS ASK COURT TO END BUSING
description: Once again the Federal courts have been asked to settle this city's 27-year-old argument over desegregation of the public schools.

title: SAVERS OF LAND AND HISTORY JOIN FORCES FOR MEETING
description: ENVIRONMENTAL protectionists and historic preservationists will hold a joint conference in the county next week. And some of the sponsors say it could lead to the creation of a unified lobbying group on behalf of common concerns.

title: Two Ivy Stars Vie For Hockey Award
description: In hockey, Harvard held a 102-55-12 advantage over Yale before their game last night in New Haven. But this season they are more evenly matched, standing first and second in the Ivy League Division of the Eastern College Athletic Conference. Harvard is 9-3-1 and Yale, 8-5. More significantly, their games this season, last night and two weeks hence, are showcases for two top candidates for college hockey's equivalent of the Heisman Trophy, the Hobey Baker Award.

title: AN ORIGINAL SENIOR CITIZEN
Irene Byrne Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward G. Byrne Jr. of Export, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Irene Ann Byrne, to Theodore G. Ohl, son of Lieut. Col. Russell L. Ohl, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Ohl of Vista, Calif. Miss Byrne is a recent graduate of the University of Cincinnati's College-Conservatory of Music. Her fiance is the production manager at the Juilliard School in New York.

title: Celine
description: To the Editor:

title: Second Edition
description: To the Editor:

title: ARMS REACH
description: ALL the military skill in the world could not camouflage the hefty increases in defense spending in a Federal budget proposal marked mostly by cutbacks and by a $189 billion deficit. Even before the budget documents for fiscal 1984 were formally distributed last week, the President's plan to raise real defense spending (after inflation) by 10 percent was drawing fire. It would bring defense to 43 percent of Federal spending if Social Security and net interest payments, so-called uncontrollables, are removed.

title: AIDS A NEW DISEASE'S DEADLY ODYSSEY
description: Robin Marantz Henig is the author of ''Your Premature Baby,'' to be published in the spring.

title: HEBREW POETRY IN ITS ISRAELI PHASE
description: THE STATIC ELEMENT Selected Poems of Natan Zach. Translated by Peter Everwine and Shulamit Yasny-Starkman. 73 pp. New York: Atheneum. Cloth, $12.95. Paper, $7.95.

title: BRITISH MUSEUM
description: To the Editor: The article on the British Museum included many of its great features. But the collection of papers and letters of literary people overwhelmed me. To see the signatures of Shakespeare and the romantic poets and all of Gray's ''Elegy,'' written in the poet's own handwriting was a feast. RENA MAE KREVOR Malba, N.Y.

title: EMISSION INSPECTIONS: WHAT'S NEXT?
description: ITHINK I have finally figured out what upsets me so much about the s tate's new motor-vehicle emissions inspection law. It is not the money - $10, after all, is about half a tank of gas i n today's economy - nor the time involved in driving to, through a nd from the inspection station. It is not even having to display theu nattractive sticker, along with its subsequent pass or fail p roclamation, on my purposely unadorned windshield.

title: RANGERS TIE BLUE AS GRESCHNER RETURNS
description: Ron Greschner returned to the Rangers' lineup tonight after an absence of 360 days and enhanced his comeback by arranging a comeback for the team.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: THEATER ''What manner of person ought we to be?'' That is the question at the heart of Lanford Wilson's ''Angels Fall,'' which has just transferred intact (and undamaged) from Off Broadway's Circle Repertory Company to Broadway's Longacre Theater. You'll care about the answer, because Mr. Wilson, one of the most gifted American playwrights of our era, fills the stage with six fully observed people and draws us totally into their struggles to find meaning and peace in their lives.

title: A FEARFUL CANADIAN ESTABLISHMENT WARY OF QUEBEC'S FUND
description: MONTREAL CANADA has been called ''two solitudes,'' one French and one English. Two head offices located in the heart of this linguistically divided city provide a telling metaphor.

title: Local History And 'Mad Nan'
description: The interesting article ''Close-to-Home History Attracts the Young'' (Jan. 2) makes reference to a Nan Heathworth as being the source of Great Neck's early designation as ''Mad Nan's Neck.'' Anne Hutchinson was her correct name, and ''banned in Boston and evicted from Great Neck'' in a way summarizes her story.

title: Sword and Book
description: To the Editor:

title: MOOD MUSIC FOR A BAD TIME
description: DOWN & OUT IN THE GREAT DEPRESSION Letters from the ''Forgotten Man.'' Edited by Robert S. McElvaine. Illustrated. 251 pp. Chapel Hill: The University of North Carolina Press.Cloth, $23. Paper, $8.95.

title: HANDICAPPERS
description: As Secretary of the Media Handicappers Association, I had the unpleasant task of breaking the news to the Democrats we plan to entertain with in the forthcoming Presidential campaign. I went first to Walter Mondale and gave it to him straight from the shoulder.

title: Gail J. Donnelly Bride of Officer
description: Gail Joan Donnelly, daughter of Mrs. Manfred Beckemeyer of Ringwood, N.J., and James Donnelly of Lincoln Park, N.J., was married yesterday to Lieut. Scott Sackett Kingsley, U.S.N., son of Capt. Stephen Sackett Kingsley, U.S.N., and Mrs. Kingsley of Virginia Beach, Va., and Newport, R.I. The Rev. Thomas Edge performed the ceremony at the Immanuel Evangelical Lutheran Church in New York.

title: WHAT DO 'ECSTASY' AND 'POLTERGEIST' HAVE IN COMMON?
SHULTZ FORESEES CLOSER CHINA TIES
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz, concluding four days of talks with Chinese leaders, said today that a new atmosphere of mutual trust had been established that had ''set the stage for renewed advances'' in relations.

title: LEWIS RUNS FASTES 60-YARD DASH IN 6:02
description: Carl Lewis, running in the event for the first time this winter, overcame a false start, then set a world indoor-best time of 6.02 seconds in the 60-yard dash tonight at The Dallas Times Herald invitation meet.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN PATERSON
description: FOR more than a century, Paterson's history traced the course of A merica's industrial expansion. Its mills, powered by the Great Fallso f the Passaic River, made it a leading textile center, and its i nventors created the Colt Revolver and the Holland submarine.

title: Opposing Prejudice
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSH HOPES ARMS TALKS CONTINUE EVEN IF THE ALLIES DEPLOY MISSILES
