description: Vice President George Bush indicated today that the medium-range nuclear missiles to be deployed by the Atlantic alliance starting late in 1983 could be withdrawn if United States and Soviet negotiators come to an agreement after that.

title: IS IT A HAPPY ENDING IF A MOVIE BREEDS NO SEQUEL?
description: Sylvester Stallone is hard at work directing John Travolta in a follow-up to ''Saturday Night Fever,'' and he also no doubt dreams of a ''Rocky IV.'' Otherwise, though, sequel-making is temporarily on the skids, thanks to a group of recent hit movies that are maddeningly self-contained and complete. Can't we look forward to an ''E.T. II'' or a ''Tootsie II'' or a ''48 More Hrs.''? Sorry, but the prospects aren't bright. It may be that tomorrow's movies, instead of presenting all our favorite characters as they grow older and less amusing, will instead have to be dangerously new.

title: CORRECTION
description: A society-page article last Sunday on the engagement of Katharine Rudkin to Jeffrey Forester Allsopp incorrectly identified the founder of Pepperidge Farm Inc. It was the future bride's grandmother, the late Margaret Rudkin.

title: NATURAL GAS RISES HIT CALIFORNIANS
description: When Eleanor Holley, who lives in suburban Pasadena, invites friends over for a visit, she tells them to bring sweaters because ''I rarely turn the heat on anymore.''

title: A NEW HARDY ORCHID
description: Eric Rosenthal is a freelance writer.

title: KEEPING TRAVEL AGENTS IN TICKETS
description: Under an order issued less than a month ago by the Civil Aeronautics Board, now just about anyone may put out a shingle to sell airline tickets.

title: Jim Ameche Dies at 68; First 'Jack Armstrong'
description: Jim Ameche, who played ''Jack Armstrong, the All-American Boy'' for five years on radio in the 1930's, has died of cancer. He was 68 years old.

title: IN EUROPE, BUSH SEEKS TO KEEP ALLIES IN LINE
description: GENEVA JOHN Adams was on to something. The job, he said, talking about being Vice President, was ''the most insignificant'' ever contrived by man. Whatever the opinion of George Bush, the task he undertook last week - that of talking up Ronald Reagan as the great arms reducer to the European allies - was far from meaningless. But it did require a sense of lowered expectations.

title: Winn Casey Sets Wedding in April To D.D. Cullen
description: Maj. Gen. Raymond Patrick Murphy, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Murphy of Colorado Springs have announced the engagement of Mrs. Murphy's daughter, Elizabeth Winn Casey, to Denis Dyson Cullen, son of June Cox Cullen of Locust Valley, L.I., and the late James Freston Cullen. An April wedding is planned.

title: GRIPPO PLANS 'NICE TRANSITION'
description: ANGELO GRIPPO, the Yonkers Democratic Party chairman who was convicted last month of participating int he extortion of $12,000 from a chain of toy stores, said last week that he would remain in his party post until a successor was chosen.

title: HELPING PATIENTS MAKE COMEBACK
description: WHEN 82-year-old John Gordon of Floral Park lost his left leg to gangrene last October, his greatest fear was that he would become an invalid. He had always been active. For more than 50 years, he had been an operating engineer, taking great pleasure in striding the narrow steel beams of rising skyscrapers.

title: HOW MUCH DO THE WORDS REALLY MATTER IN OPERA?
description: Let's be honest about this. I think it should not be denied that there are many people who enjoy going to the opera but cannot bring themselves to care what, exactly, the characters are up to. These blissful folk could enjoy, say, ''Tristan und Isolde'' almost as much if the words were eliminated. After all, the antiword argument runs, once you know even vaguely what the ''Liebestod'' is about, Wagner's orchestral music spells out the real emotional meanings of Isolde's final scene more effectively than any words could. True enough, as far as it goes, but that is an old, impoverished view of opera, now happily losing ground. I suppose there could be a spectator who enjoyed attending tennis matches blindfolded, simply to relish hearing the ball being thwacked back and forth, but that lover of sheer sound might miss a lot, too.

title: Mary Mudd Betrothed To Charles E. Wallace
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sidney P. Mudd of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Elaine Mudd, to Charles E. Wallace, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Wallace of Yorktown Heights, N.Y. A May wedding is planned.

title: RECENT SALES
description: Manalapan $84,900 *2*1 Revere Way 5-bedroom, 2-bath, 18-year-old *2*bilevel; large fenced yard, deck off kitchen; *2*taxes $1,646. Montclair $130,000 *2*87 Warren Place 6-bedroom, 3-bath, 60-year-old *2*English manor; 5 fireplaces, 2-car garage; *2*taxes $4,857. Ocean Township $80,000 *2*9 Kenneth Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*8-year-old ranch; fireplace in den, *2*2-car garage; taxes $2,300. Ridgewood $78,000 *2*315 Steilen Avenue 1-bedroom, 1-bath, *2*30-year-old Cape Cod; unfinished second *2*story, screened porch; taxes $2,274. Maplewood $117,500 *2*35 Maplewood Avenue 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, *2*40-year-old colonial; remodeled kitchen *2*and bath, central air-conditioning; taxes $3,330. Union City $50,000 *2*518 19th Street 2-family, 50-year-old *2*frame now house; 2- and 3-bedroom; *2*seperate gas furnaces; taxes $2,270. OTHER AREAS Madison, Conn. $144,000 *2*11 Christopher Lane 4-bedroom,2 1/2-bath, *2*18-year-old colonial; in-law suite; *2*1.3 acres taxes $1,443. Putnam Valley, N.Y. $67,576 *2*Glenman Gardens 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 58-year-old *2*frame ranch; family room, den, *2*3-year-old roof; taxes $1,225. Huntington Station, L.I. $90,000 *2*60 Wyoming Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 25-year-old *2*split-level; living room with fireplace, *2*formal dining room; taxes $1,800.

title: MISSED OPPORTUNITIES
description: For more than a century it has been normal in chess tournaments to present a prize for the best-played game. Some European bridge tournaments follow this precedent by making an award for the best hand. The decision is made by an expert panel - which has a very difficult task.

title: Suns 109, Warriors 92
description: Walter Davis scored 8 of his 20 points in the fourth quarter to pace Phoenix. Davis hit two free throws and a field goal early in the quarter to give Phoenix an 89-71 lead, and the Warriors never got closer than 15 points the rest of the way.

title: Mt. St. Helens More Active
description: Mount St. Helens is likely to erupt again within two weeks, scientists at the University of Washington and the United States Geological Survey say, and the eruption could be explosive. ''The rate of seismic energy release, gas emissions, deformation of the dome and the crater floor, and the glow from the dome have increased,'' the scientists' joint statement said Saturday.

title: Scholastic to Deutsch
description: David Deutsch Associates has two new assignments that have never been at agencies: Scholastic, for a new line of educational computer software called Wizware, which will have a $1 million budget, and Anaconda-Erickson, a Greenwich, Conn., company that markets cellular mobile telephone systems, with a $600,000 budget.

title: A STEPPINGSTONE EFFECT DRAWS YOUNG TO CAPITOL
description: WASHINGTON Feb. 6 - For those trying to master the Washington steppingstone game, Craig H. Shaver may just have the perfect plan. Fresh out of Williams College in 1979, Mr. Shaver started work as a legislative assistant to Representative Bill Frenzel, Republican of Minnesota. After three years of exposure to the details of campaigns and legislation, he returned home last fall and won a seat in the Minnesota House of Representatives.

title: THEATER: 'WHAT I DID LAST SUMMER' AT CIRCLE REP
description: AS fans of ''The Dining Room'' know, the writer A.R. Gurney Jr. is a keen-eyed chronicler of the vanishing folkways of the American WASP. That talent remains in evidence in ''What I Did Last Summer,'' the new Gurney comedy which opened at the Circle Repertory Company last night. In this play, which is set in 1945, we learn that World War II was a time of deprivation for WASP households, in part because there were no men left around to repair broken Hitchcock chairs. We meet a mother who views her son's wet dreams (''nocturnal emissions,'' she calls them) as a cue to lecture the boy about laundry, not sex. We also discover that it was WASP's who found the movie ''Mrs. Miniver'' hot stuff.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: In four-ball match-play golf, Player A's ball lands an inch from the pin. The approach shot of Player B, an opponent, strikes Player A's ball and sends it into the cup. What is the ruling?

title: BRIEFING
description: A Boost for Museums

title: DANCE: NEW BUCKET COMPANY WORKS
description: ''DISCIPLINE IS FREEDOM'' was the subtitle of ''Prelude,'' one of the three new works that the Bucket Dance Theater offered Saturday night at Symphony Space as part of the Harlem Cultural Council's Dancemobile Winter Series. This troupe from Rochester was certainly disciplined. Yet it looked totally free in a program of dances by Garth Fagan, its founder and director.

title: Red Wings 3; Maple Leafs 0
description: DETROIT (AP) - Mark Lofthouse scored two goals and the goalie Corrado Micalef recorded his second shutout of the season as Detroit ended a four-game losing streak.

title: BURGER PROPOSES NEW PANEL TO CUT HIGH COURT'S LOAD
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger today asked Congress to create a court with judges temporarily borrowed from other Federal courts as an experiment in easing the Supreme Court's workload.

title: I. Usher Kirshblum, 70, Rabbi and Civic Leader
description: Rabbi I. Usher Kirshblum, spiritual leader of the Jewish Center of Kew Gardens Hills in Queens, died Saturday of heart failure while vacationing in Hollywood, Fla. Rabbi Kirshblum, who was a resident of Kew Gardens Hills, was 70 years old.

title: CHURCHES ORGANIZE TO TACKLE BUDGET
description: When an issue as big as the budget comes before Congress, groups as diverse as the National Pork Producers Council, the Izaak Walton League and the American Psychiatric Association get involved.

title: ILL-CONCEIVED MERGER OF FEDERAL FUNDING
description: To the Editor:

title: CORPORATE PROFITS OFF AGAIN IN '82
description: Corporate profits continued to deteriorate in the fourth quarter of 1982 as the recession aggravated normal cyclical declines in industries such as oil, steel, chemicals, autos and forest products. The deterioration continues a downward trend for corporate earnings since peaking in 1979.

title: CHINA SAYS SHULTZ SOOTHED TENSIONS 'TO SOME EXTENT'
description: China said today that the visit of Secretary of State George P. Shultz had clarified relations with the United States ''to some extent'' but that longstanding differences remained over Taiwan and other issues.

title: Japan Denies Trade Charge
description: Government and industry officials have denied a contention by the United States semiconductor industry that Japan is using unfair trade practices to dominate the world market in computer memory parts.

title: Mortgage Rate Fell in January
description: The average interest rate charged for new mortgages fell to 13.92 percent in January, the lowest level since October 1980, the Government said today.

title: A One-Liner by Broyles
description: When the television miniseries ''The Blue and The Gray'' was filmed in and around Fayetteville, Ark., last spring, the director Andrew McLaglen used many students and employees of the University of Arkansas as extras and bit actors.

title: Iraqi Says Iran Postpones an Attack
description: President Saddam Hussein said today that Iran had postponed a planned offensive against Iraq's Misan Province because Iraq had turned the area into a fortress.

title: N.F.C. Wins Pro Bowl, 20-19
description: Danny White, the Dallas quarterback who sat on the sidelines with an injury as the Cowboys lost the National Football Conference title game last month, threw an 11-yard scoring pass to John Jefferson with 35 seconds remaining to give the N.F.C. a 20-19 victory over the American Conference today in the Pro Bowl.

title: ON A SHOOTING IN ROME
description: To the Editor:

title: JAMES F. HAYES
description: James F. Hayes, retired vice president of Marsh & McLennan, a New York City insurance brokerage, died Friday after a stroke at his home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 82 years old.

title: The Comforting Cookie
description: One of the most famous cookies in Western literature is that mix of butter, flour, sugar and eggs memorialized by one Marcel Proust. Change the proportions, add a few chunks of chocolate and some chopped nuts and you also have the most famous cookie in American life.

title: Turkey Says Greece Has 'Baseless' Fears
description: Greek fears that Turkey poses a threat are ''totally baseless,'' the Turkish Foreign Minister, Ilter Turkmen, said today.

title: HIGH SCHOOLS AND PUBLIC COLLEGES STIFFENING REQUIREMENTS FOR PUPILS
description: State universities across the country are raising admission requirements and many state education agencies are stiffening standards for high school diplomas to emphasize stronger preparation for college.

title: Louisiana Senate Chief Convicted of Mail Fraud
description: The president of the Louisiana Senate, Michael O'Keefe, was convicted by a Federal jury Saturday of mail fraud. The day before, the jury found him guilty of two counts of obstructing justice.

title: NEIL H. SWANSON, BALTIMORE EDITOR
description: Neil H. Swanson, former executive editor of the Baltimore Sunpapers and a historical novelist, died Saturday at Baltimore County General Hospital after a long illness. He was 86 years old.

title: 'CODED MESSAGE' ON RESOURCE RECOVERY
description: To the Editor:

title: SNOW OBLITERATES CITY AREA'S ILLUSIONS OF AUTUMN
description: A fine mist of snow began falling on the metropolitan area early yesterday afternoon, and the National Weather Service said that by the time it tapered off it this morning four to six inches could accumulate.

title: WIDE CHANGES IN FAMILY LIFE ARE ALTERING THE FAMILY LAW
description: Prof. Homer H. Clarke Jr. of the University of Colorado Law School recently set out to revise his textbook, ''Domestic Relations in the United States,'' only to find that he had to rewrite it.

title: STANLEY JAFFE AND THE MAKING OF 'WITHOUT A TRACE'
description: At 27 he produced his first film, ''Goodbye Columbus,'' which became a big hit. At 29 he became president of Paramount Pictures, the youngest head of a major studio in Hollywood history.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE RAGE OF THE VULTURE. By Barry Unsworth. 443 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $15.95.

title: Drug Scene Irks Buck Williams
description: Buck Williams, the Nets' forward, says that he believes ''maybe 20 or 30 percent'' of the athletes in the National Basketball Association use drugs, a figure he says is much lower than he once thought.

title: Nordiques 4, Capitals 4
description: QUEBEC (UPI) - A newly-acquired defenseman, Anders Eldebrink, scored the tying goal at 6:05 of the final period, and Michel Goulet got two goals for Quebec.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: SHULTZ FINDS CHINA ALL BUSINESS
description: As Secretary of State George P. Shultz flew from Peking to Seoul today, he sat in his shirt sleeves musing about his four days of talks with Chinese leaders. He seemed more amused than impressed.

title: HOUSECLEANING, ANDROPOV-STYLE, ROUSING RUSSIA
description: Operating cautiously but methodically, Yuri V. Andropov has succeeded in less than three months in giving a distinct new shape to Soviet government.

title: ISRAELI COLONEL, AFTER BRUSH WITH MARINE, IS REPORTED HURT IN RAID
description: The army said today that the Israeli tank commander who was involved in a confrontation last week with a United States Marine captain was slightly wounded this morning in an attack by terrorists who appeared to have escaped into Marine-held territory near Beirut.

title: Dollar-Dry Dock Link
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has approved the previously arranged merger of the financially troubled Dry Dock Savings Bank into the healthier Dollar Savings Bank.

title: Mrs. Lloyd Defeats Miss Jaeger in Final
description: The top-seeded Chris Evert Lloyd, playing in her first event of the year, defeated Andrea Jaeger, 6-3, 6-3, today to win the $150,000 Murjani Cup women's tennis tournament.

title: SOVIET EMIGRE IS FOUND SLAIN
description: A 24-year-old emigre from the Soviet Union was found shot to death Saturday in the doorway of a commercial building in the Chelsea section of Manhattan. The police said yesterday that the motive for the crime was unclear.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Crumbling Memorabilia

title: NEW ACCOUNTS ALTER ANALYSES
description: The introduction of money market accounts has disrupted the analyses of monetary policy and the economy that investors rely on to estimate future changes in interest rates.

title: WESTPHAL MAKING PLAYS
description: Paul Westphal was an enigma when the Knicks were losing. It appeared to Coach Hubie Brown that Westphal, at age 32, was too old, too slow and that he had lost his shooting touch. Brown, who preferred his guards to be big, quick and able to press, was aware of Westphal's offensive capabilities. But he objected to Westphal's slowness and defensive liabilities.

title: Glemp Holds Mass in Rome
description: Jozef Cardinal Glemp, Primate of the Roman Catholic Church in Poland, celebrated mass for Rome's Polish community today at the St. Stanislaw Church.

title: No Headline
description: GEORGETOWN BEATS DE PAUL BY 71-65

title: WASTE CONCERN IN CONNECTICUT ACCUSED AGAIN
description: After a Connecticut hazardous-waste disposal company came under Federal and state investigation last fall, it stepped up shipments of chemicals to its plant in Illinois, according to the plant's former manager. Many shipments, he said, arrived in drums that were leaking or mislabeled.

title: No Headline
description: AFTER 17 YEARS IN SENATE, BYRD SAVORS RETIREMENT

title: SORT AND REFURBISH TACKLE EARLY
description: FEBRUARY is the month when anglers who live in the snow belt should begin attending to their tackle. Such an early start may seem silly, but as one who has sometimes delayed this endeavor until nightcrawler mounds appear on the lawn, red-winged blackbirds carol from pond-side bushes and terns return from their hegira south, I can assert that it isn't. When you set about this chore too late, all pleasure and much efficiency is lost.

title: Deadly Poisons, Lifeless Enforcement
description: The search for dioxin dumped in Missouri provides a specific drama. Beneath it, a Congressional report now demonstrates, lies a generalized tragedy: laws intended to prevent such environmental disasters are in many places poorly enforced, leaving the public largely unprotected.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We can no longer tolerate the vacuous notion that we can get along with the present structure 'because we have always done it that way.' '' -Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, calling for a new Federal court. (B6:5.)

title: STATE'S DEMOCRATS SEEK '84 INFLUENCE
description: New York Democratic leaders, concerned about what they describe as a tradition of disarray at national party conventions, are making plans to exert greater influence over the choice of the 1984 Democratic Presidential nominee.

title: Immigrant Is Arrested In a Moonshine Case
description: A 60-year-old Portuguese immigrant who, the police say, has been operating the largest moonshine operation they have seen in 20 years, has been arrested on charges of violating alcoholic beverage laws.

title: A Winter's Tale
description: Long periods in foreign environments, dealing with people who don't speak your language and eating unfamiliar kinds of food, are bound to affect a young athlete. But the young men and women, mostly in their late teens, who are on the United States Ski Team and spend winter months in Europe skiing the World Cup circuit, have had something done about it for them.

title: New Film Forum Series Offers Polish Features
description: Andrzej Wajda's ''Man of Marble'' will open a five-week series of Polish films Feb. 16 at 5 P.M. at Film Forum 2, 57 Watts Street. Also on the opening-day bill is Jerzy Skolimowski's ''Identification Marks: None.''

title: Brooklyn College Offers 5 New Chamber Operas
description: Brooklyn College's Conservatory of Music is presenting five new chamber operas this weekend and next, and Friday night's performances showed mostly conservative music, drama that was more talky than active, but some very good singing by the conservatory's singers.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Real Toy Buyers

title: Washington Watch; Feldstein Tune Called Off-Key
description: WASHINGTON WITHIN days of the delivery of the Reagan Administration's economic forecast, Martin S. Feldstein, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, was singing a new, more upbeat tune. But in the Office of Management and Budget, the Treasury and some parts of the White House, it all sounded off-key.

title: Drug Unit Formed In Connecticut
description: A 10-member task force has been formed by the Justice Department to attack high-level drug trafficking in Connecticut, according to Alan Nevas, the United States Attorney.

title: Canada Cement In U.S. Move
description: Canada Cement Lafarge Ltd. of Montreal plans to set up an American parent company in order to expand the number of shareholders and facilitate ''substantial debt and equity financing,'' according to John D. Redfern, president and chief executive officer.

title: CALM ARRIVAL AT COAST ZOO FOR ELEPHANT
description: Tina, the Central Park Zoo elephant rejected by zoos all over the country because of her nasty temperament, arrived yesterday at her new home in Redwood City, Calif. She was reported to be a little stiff but relatively composed and eating well on a diet of hay, vegetables and sourdough bread.

title: JUST PLAYING'S THE THING AT DART TOURNEY IN CITY
description: The matches had been under way for less than two hours, and already the air in the ballroom was gray with smoke. Under the fancy chandeliers, the banquet tables, draped with red tablecloths, were loaded down with empty beer bottles, half-filled drinks and heaping ashtrays. Hundreds of people milled around, almost everyone with the telltale four-cornered ends of three darts sticking out from one pocket or another.

title: Music: By Gandini, Argentine
description: GERARDO GANDINI is an Argentine composer born in 1936. With the Contemporary Music Ensemble of Buenos Aires, he presented several of his works at Carnegie Recital Hall on Friday night. Mr. Gandini is a solid craftsman, but the compositions heard Friday lacked distinct profiles.

title: Spanish Bishops Fight Abortion Law Changes
description: The church has declared its opposition to easing Spain's strict antiabortion laws, setting the stage for a showdown with the Socialist Government.

title: EXCLUSIONARY RULE: OPPONENTS' OVERSTATEMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: THE BABY-STEPPERS
description: The disagreement on arms control centers on the length of the steps to be taken. The baby-steppers believe that only by a series of small, incremental agreements can the arms race be slowed; they are willing to risk the locking-in of a Soviet advantage to achieve some measure of arms control.

title: MADRID'S NEW WORKING CLASS: THE BUREAUCRATS
description: In Spain the title of civil servant has long been a misnomer. They are civil enough. But they rarely serve. Bureaucrats practiced moonlighting to such an extent it turned into sunlighting. It was not unusual for them to hold down two, sometimes three - and in one case, a reliable source swears, four - separate jobs.

title: Spain Backs Bank Bid
description: Banco Hispano Americano received approval from the Bank of Spain for a public bid for the country's ninth-largest bank, Banco Urquijo, this week, a Hispano spokesman said.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Resources Management Corp., Denver, has named J.B. Kimo Smith vice president and general counsel.

title: UNEQUAL GERMANYS
description: To the Editor:

title: Nancy Lopez Gets 26th Career Victory
description: Nancy Lopez, overcoming a shaky start, settled down and shot a 73 today to win the Elizabeth Arden Classic, the second event of the season on the women's golf tour. It was her 26th career victory.

title: U.S. FEARS FORAYS INTO INDOCHINA MAY HARM TALKS
description: The Reagan Administration has become concerned that privately organized expeditions into Indochina in search of missing United States servicemen may upset delicate talks with Laos and Vietnam on efforts to recover more remains of Americans lost during the Vietnam War.

title: RODNEY USHER-WILSON
description: The Rev. Rodney N. Usher-Wilson, an Anglican priest who had been active in the evangelical Moral Re-Armament Movement, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Bronxville, N.Y. He was 75 years old.

title: Hasbro Chief Cites Gain With Traditional Toys
description: As a boy, there were toys all over. That's how it is when your father runs the toy factory. There were toys not only from the factory but gifts of salesmen's samples from other companies. All the Lionel trains you would want, for example.

title: HOW WE COUNT EUROPEAN MISSILES
description: The Soviet Union has proposed an agreement governing intermediate-range nuclear forces in Europe in which the number of Soviet missiles would be reduced to 162, which is precisely the number of missiles that the British and French have. None of the American Pershing 2 missiles and ground-launched cruise missiles now scheduled for deployment beginning later this year would be permitted. The idea is that British and French weapons would balance Soviet ones. It has been suggested, both here and in Europe, that this Soviet proposal is fair, reasonable and constructive. It is none of these things. If put into effect, it would subvert the goals of stability and deterrence in Europe, the goals that our planned deployments are designed to achieve.

title: United Satellite Racing Competitors
description: Francesco Galesi, a real estate developer in New York, does not think it at all unusual that he has entered the business of satellite television.

title: Colavito Charges Brutality by Police
description: Rocky Colavito, batting coach for the Kansas City Royals, says he was beaten by the police when he and Manager Dick Howser were arrested after a traffic accident at Royals Stadium last August.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 1983
description: International The status of Taiwan was among issues that still concern Peking despite China's official announcement that the visit of Secretary of State George P. Shultz had clarified relations with the United States ''to some extent.'' After Mr. Shultz's visit had ended, China's official press agency reiterated virtually all of Peking's complaints about the United States, ranging from restrictive policies in Chinese-American trade to United States support for Taiwan. (Page A1, Column 4.) The Soviet Government is changing and taking a new shape under Yuri A. Andropov, successor to Leonid I. Breznhev. In less than three months in offfice the Soviet leader has begun to stir the stagnation that had accumulated at every level of government. His drive focuses on labor productivity and discipline. (A1:5.)

title: Market Place; Transportation Stocks Higher
description: SOME of the stock market's best moves last week were made, fittingly enough, by transportation companies. Thanks to gains by railroad and airline issues, the Dow Jones transportation average finished the week at a record high of 485.07, up nearly 25 points.

title: Swing Till Dawn Wins Strub at 38-1
description: Swing Till Dawn, at odds of 38-1, led all the way today to win the $290,500 Charles H. Strub Stakes at Santa Anita.

title: Martha Schlamme At Jason's Park Royal
description: Martha Schlamme, the well-known interpreter of Kurt Weill, offered the premiere of a winning new cabaret act Friday at Jason's Park Royal, where she'll be performing for four weekends. Technically speaking, the Viennese-born singer doesn't have much of a singing voice.

title: Fire Kills a Guest In the Texas Capitol
description: A fire burned through an apartment in the century-old state Capitol before dawn today, killing a guest of the Lieutenant Governor's and injuring four firemen and a policeman.

title: U.N. Chief, in Africa, Urges Namibia Solution
description: The United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, called today for a ''prompt solution'' to the problem of independence for South-West Africa.

title: Titles to Zajonc And Miss Martin
description: Miroslav Zajonc of Canada and Steffi Martin of East Germany won the singles titles today in the 23d World Luge Championships at Mount Van Hoevenberg.

title: BEYOND THE FREE MARKET
description: The State of the Union Message, the Federal budget and President Reagan's Economic Report purport to be an annual updating of the nation's goals and plans for meeting them. But they offer neither a credible assessment of the country's prospects for prosperity nor an adequate blueprint for improving America.

title: Advertising; Firstair Switches To C.&W.
description: CUNNINGHAM & WALSH'S Los Angeles office has been hired as the agency for the Firstair Corporation, which intends to fill that gaping service niche between first-class air travel and the corporate jet. Let's call it semiprivate posh.

title: Metrofone to Scali
description: Scali, McCabe, Sloves, which already does advertising for Western Union's Mailgram and computer letter service, has also been assigned both the media advertising and direct marketing of Metrofone, another competitor to the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's long-distance service. Metrofone, previously at Trout & Ries and the DR Group, spent only about $500,000 in measured media last year, according to Leading National Advertisers, but is now being billed as ''a multimillion-dollar account.'' It is the first direct marketing assignment the Scali shop has won since establishing its specialty unit.

title: RICHARDSON IS OBTAINED BY THE NETS
description: In what is perhaps the most critical transaction in Larry Brown's two-year tenure as coach, the Nets obtained Michael Ray Richardson, the former Knick guard, from Golden State tonight.

title: People
description: * Alan Yarnoff promoted to executive vice president at Kornhauser & Calene Inc.

title: RANGERS LOSE TO HAWKS BY 4-1
description: Eddie Mio played another strong game in goal for the Rangers today, but once again he got nothing for his efforts. The Black Hawks beat New York, 4-1, in an afternoon game at Chicago Stadium, to complete a sweep of the three-game series between these teams this season. It was Chicago's fifth straight victory, eighth in the last 12 games (8-3-1), and 35th this season. The last Black Hawks team to win that many games was the 1974-75 group, which finished with 37.

title: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 1983; The Economy
description: Corporate profits deteriorated further in the fourth quarter of 1982. Particularly affected were the cyclically depressed steel, oil, auto and forest products industries. Analysts forecast that, over all, after-tax profits for the quarter should be down 20 percent from a year earlier, to $116 billion. (Page D1.)

title: Kite Wins Crosby By Two With a 73
description: Tom Kite floundered today on the home stretch with three consecutive bogeys, but he came through to win the Bing Crosby National Pro-Am by two strokes. As late as the 14th hole, Kite had held a five-shot lead.

title: VILLAGE FIGHTS A BURGLAR-ALARM BATTLE
description: It all started innocently enough 15 years ago when an owner of one of the large estates here installed a burglar alarm system in his home with a warning hookup in the village Police Department's headquarters.

title: THE PROPER ROLE OF PAROLE
description: To the Editor:

title: CHINA SEEKS INVESTORS FOR ITS HAINAN ISLAND
description: Hainan is an island in the sun that seems to offer something for virtually everyone. It has a balmy climate, miles of unspoiled sand beaches, ample farmland, an array of untapped minerals, and potentially rich oil reserves offshore in the turquoise waters of the South China Sea.

title: FOR 22 MILLION, AN EZ ALTERNATIVE
description: In its continuing efforts to provide taxpayers with a simplified tax form, the Internal Revenue Service developed the new 1040EZ for filing 1982 returns.

title: A CASE FOR U.S. WITHDRAWAL FROM LEBANON
description: To the Editor:

title: Aoki Will Leave Powerboat Racing
description: Rocky Aoki announced today that he was retiring from offshore powerboat racing, saying that the sport will claim the lives of competitors because the boats are no longer safe.

title: FOR DIVORCE, A 'REVOLUTION' IN THE COURTROOM
description: ''In little more than a decade, divorce in the 50 states has been revolutionized,'' says Dr. Doris Jonas Freed, a family law scholar. Following are some of the major changes:

title: HEART RECIPIENT IS BACK ON ROAD TO RECOVERY
description: Almost three weeks after a setback that required surgery to stop a severe nosebleed, Dr. Barney B. Clark, the artificial heart recipient, now seems to be firmly back on the trail to recovery, an official of the University of Utah Medical Center said yesterday.

title: THE GRIEF OF A FAILED PREGNANCY
description: WHEN Dr. Judith N. Lasker, assistant professor of sociology at L ehigh University, is asked if her 3 1/2-year-old daughter is her o nly child, she pauses. ''In my mind, I have two children,'' Dr. L asker said, ''and she is my second.'' Her first child, also a girl, w as stillborn four and a half years ago.

title: TV: 'A CHINESE AFFAIR'
description: TAIWAN has rock music, Christian Dior and hamburgers and french fries; it also has a great many citizens who would love to visit China. They do not, of course, because Taipei and Peking have been almost hermetically sealed from each other since Chiang Kai-shek fled to Taiwan in 1949. Therefore, the Taiwanese have some towering misconceptions about the Chinese. ''A Chinese Affair,'' a documentary on Channel 13, examines all this and other things about Taiwan at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: ACTOR, WRITER AND DIRECTOR
description: Reginald Denham, an actor, playwright and theatrical director, who was best known for suspense dramas, died in Englewood (N.J.) Hospital last Friday after a stroke. He was 89 years old and had lived at the Manor, a nursing home in Tenafly, N.J., for the last six months.

title: King Sunny Ade Band In New York Debut
description: King Sunny Ade and his African Beats have been making popular and influential albums in Nigeria for more than a decade. Island Records, the company that was largely responsible for popularizing the Jamaican reggae star Bob Marley in the United States, signed Mr. Ade to a recording contract last year and issued his first American album, ''Juju Music.'' And late Friday night, Mr. Ade and 18 of the 22 musicians in his band introduced themselves to New York City with a dazzling two-and-a-half-hour performance to a packed house at the Savoy - a performance that will surely be remembered as one of the most significant pop music events of this decade.

title: Bomb Explodes at Residence Of French Envoy in Brussels
description: Bombs exploded tonight at the French Ambassador's residence and at an Air France office in downtown Brussels, the police reported.

title: City's Parking Rules For Holidays in 1983
description: The Traffic Department has made available the dates this year on which alternate-side parking regulations will be suspended: Lincoln's BirthdayFeb. 12 Washington's BirthdayFeb. 21 Passover (First two days)March 29, 30 Good FridayApril 1 Passover (Last two days)April 4, 5 Good Friday (Orthodox)May 6 Ascension DayMay 12 ShabuothMay 18, 19 Feast of the AssumptionAug. 15 Rosh ha-ShanahSept. 8, 9 Yom KippurSept. 17 SuccothSept, 22, 23 Shemini AtzerethSept. 29 Simhath TorahSept. 30 Columbus DayOct. 11 All Saints DayNov. 1 Election DayNov. 8 Veterans DayNov. 11 Immaculate ConceptionDec. 8

title: E.P.A. Aide Was Told To Resign, Report Says
description: Anne M. Gorsuch, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, summoned her top aide, Rita M. Lavelle, to her office late Friday and angrily ordered her to resign, agency sources said tonight.

title: Bruins Extend Undefeated Streak to 15
description: The right wing Rick Middleton scored two goals and had an assist to lead the Bruins to a 5-1 National Hockey League victory over the Buffalo Sabres tonight.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: JAZZ

title: Bristol-Myers Trying Canisters
description: Among the pharmaceutical industry's solutions to the packagetampering problem, the Bristol-Myers Company has taken the most unusual and expensive route. Its plastic-lidded fiber container with a metal pull top is considered the most revolutionary of the designs introduced to meet the Food and Drug Administration's guidelines, which take effect today.

title: Commodities; Oil Futures And Global Disruptions
description: NOWHERE is the disarray in the global petroleum market more visible than in the heating oil and gasoline futures trading pits of the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: PARAGUAY BARS RETURN OF 8 EXILES
description: As Paraguayans voted today for the reelection of President Alfredo Stroessner, eight exiled political leaders arrived in the country aboard a commercial flight, but were turned back at the airport by security agents.

title: POPE TRAVEL PLANS ANNOUNCED
description: Pope John Paul II announced today that he would visit seven Central American countries as well as Haiti from March 2 to 9.

title: STAGE: SNOO WILSON'S 'LYNCHVILLE'
description: THE British playwright, Snoo Wilson, is a satiric fantasist, often creating bizarre and anachronistic worlds that bear a striking resemblance to reality once removed. His new play, ''Our Lord of Lynchville,'' is an indictment of organized religion as represented by a television minister - a star in his own firmament - given to acts of hypocrisy while working as a spokesman for the Moral Majority. As in previous plays, such as ''The Soul of the White Ant,'' Mr. Wilson's aim is apocalyptic, but this time he falls far short of the intended target.

title: MANCINI WINS IN RETURN
description: Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini fought 10 bruising rounds against George Feeney tonight to take home a slim but unanimous decision in his first match since the bout that caused the death of Duk Koo Kim almost three months ago.

title: FEW ISSUES SCHEDULED THIS WEEK
description: Few sizable corporate or tax-exempt issues are scheduled for sale this week. Investment bankers say many corporations are waiting for lower yields, while state and local governments completed much of their borrowing last year.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Weekend's Nosh

title: Karen Goldstein Wed To Dr.Warren Fink
description: Karen J. Goldstein, daughter of Bernard Goldstein of Raleigh, N.C., and the late Harriet Goldstein of Manhattan, was married yesterday to Dr. Warren Fink, son of Rabbi Leon B. Fink and Mrs. Charles Lerner, both of Brooklyn. The bridegroom's father performed the ceremony at the Lotos Club in Manhattan.

title: A Welcome Invitation
description: When the Yankees open spring training later this month, Manager Billy Martin will behold such players as Dave Winfield, Ken Griffey, Steve Kemp, Willie Randolph, Graig Nettles, Jerry Mumphrey, Ron Guidry, Rich Gossage and Jesus Hernaiz.

title: YOUTHS STEALING SUBWAY TOKENS BY SUCKING ON TURNSTILE SLOTS
description: A number of New York City youths are stealing subway tokens - sometimes dozens a day - by sucking them from the turnstile slots, according to transit and police officials.

title: Hospital Is Struck
description: Registered nurses struck Vassar Brothers Hospital today to try to obtain a union contract.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Indiana Pacers, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:30 P.M. In this, the only National Basketball Association game scheduled today, the Knicks will try to continue their recent success.

title: DEVILS GAIN A 4-4 TIE
description: The failure of the Devils to kill penalties in recent games continued tonight as they yielded four power-play goals before gaining a 4-4 tie with the Vancouver Canucks, 4-4, before a crowd of 7,036 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Nina Mizrahi Is Wed To Barnett Brickner
description: Nina Mizrahi, daughter of Blanche Krieger of Tamarac, Fla., and Samuel Mizrahi of Melbourne Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Barnett Brickner, son of Barbara Brickner and Rabbi Balfour Brickner, both of Manhattan. The bridegroom's father performed the ceremony at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, of which he is senior rabbi.

title: Pacifier Recall Set in Connecticut
description: A baby pacifer that state tests show can be sucked into a child's throat will be recalled from Connecticut stores by its manufacturer, state officials said today.

title: THE EXAMPLE PERKINS SET
description: SOME of his players carried him off the field when the team won its last game of the season. Fans greeted him as a hero, the Moses who at least had started the team on the way to the National Football League's promised land. But if the Giants ever reach that promised land, Ray Perkins will not be there with them. He walked the other way.

title: Bush Meets Leaders Of Italy's Parties
description: Vice President Bush met with the leaders of Italy's Social Democratic, Republican and Liberal parties today, but no statements were issued by either side on the talks.

title: Queens Japanese Show
description: ''The World of Japanese Theater,'' an exhibition of costumes, masks, prints and musical instruments, is on view through April 17 at the Queens Museum in the New York City Building in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park.

title: BUDGET PLAN COULD SHIFT AID FOR THE MIDDLE CLASS
description: President Reagan's new budget would cut spending on aid to poor people, as critics assert, but much greater savings are proposed in programs that also benefit the middle class, such as Social Security, Medicare and Civil Service pensions.

title: Mortuary Is Accused Of Mass Cremations
description: Seventy-five people picketed a mortuary here after reports that it had cremated bodies en masse and had given survivors commingled ashes.

title: TARKANIAN LOOKING TO PERFECT SEASON
description: Five and a half years ago, the National Collegiate Athletic Association directed the University of Nevada-Las Vegas to dismiss Jerry Tarkanian, its head basketball coach. Tarkanian fought successfully to keep his job, but he says now that he felt the pressure the N.C.A.A. was applying on his program would prevent it from being a big success thereafter.

title: Hawks Beat Celtics
description: Dominique Wilkins, Dan Roundfield and Eddie Johnson sparked a decisive third-period rally, and the Atlanta Hawks hung on to defeat Boston, 116-111, ending the Celtics' six-game winning streak.

title: REPACKAGING: TEAM TRIUMPH
description: Few events in the quiet history of the packaging industry have shaken it like the deaths last autumn of seven people who swallowed Extra-Strength Tylenol capsules that had been laced with cyanide. Since the first victim died on Sept. 30, a diverse collection of companies in the packaging industry have worked closely and constantly with pharmaceutical concerns, whose products are required to be in tamper-resistant packaging by today.

title: Geer, DuBois Gets Iveco Line
description: Geer, DuBois Advertising, which saw the Mercedes Benz truck business drive away last August after a three-year stay, last week filled its garage with the Iveco line.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: LEGAL SNARL DEVELOPING AROUND CASE OF A BABY BORN TO SURROGATE MOTHER
description: Perhaps Christopher Ray Stiver will be able to go home soon. If he does, Judy Stiver knows she will love him as one of her own, which he is.

title: MUSIC NOTED IN BRIEF
description: Is it possible that theorizing sometimes hurts rather than helps performers searching for authenticity in performing music from eras gone by? The question came to mind Wednesday night when the Kuijken Trio gave a concert in the Abraham Goodman House.

title: A NEW WAVE OF BOUTIQUES ROLLS IN FROM EUROPE
description: ''Anyone who wants to be considered an international business has to be in this market,'' Neal J. Fox said. ''Companies are coming here for the long run. The fact that business is bad now is not a consideration.'' Mr. Fox, president of the American division of Loewe of Madrid, was explaining why European merchants such as Loewe are opening shops in New York at a time when the economic climate is anything but warm.

title: 71 GREYHOUNDS KILLED IN BLAZE IN CONNECTICUT
description: Seventy-one greyhounds housed unattended in a converted chicken coop were killed Saturday night by a fire of unknown origin that swept through a private kennel on a farm near Plainfield Greyhound Park, Connecticut's only dog-racing track.

title: HAMILTON ATHLETE ON ICE
description: Scott Hamilton, who won his third straight national figure-skating crown Saturday night and is already preparing for the attempt to secure his third consecutive world title next month in Finland, plans to have a new look when he competes in Helsinki.

title: ADVICE TO WOMEN AT MIDLIFE
description: Betty Furness, who makes no bones about the fact that she's 67 years old, told more than 200 middle-aged women that they should never turn up their noses at entry-level jobs, should never take no for an answer and should fake only one thing: confidence.

title: YABLANS TO HEAD M-G-M OPERATIONS
description: In yet another upheaval at the M-G-M/U.A. Entertainment Company, the independent producer Frank Yablans has been appointed vice chairman and chief operating officer.

title: The Poorest of the Sick
description: At first glance, the health care proposals in President Reagan's budget seem part of a praiseworthy campaign to bring medical costs under control. A closer look discloses carelessness, if not outright callousness, toward the poor.

title: Philadelphia School Pact Voted Down by Strikers
description: More than 3,000 cheering blue-collar workers tonight rejected a back-to-work proposal and voted to continue their four-day-old strike against the school district.

title: DOCTORS ACCUSED OF STARVING COMATOSE PATIENT
description: Two Los Angeles doctors are facing charges that they killed a comatose, severely brain-damaged patient by withdrawing a respirator and, when he defied expectations by breathing on his own, withholding food and water until he died.

title: MOSCOW'S URGENT MESSAGE
description: A group of Soviet foreign policy experts has been visiting the U.S. for informal talks. Their insistent, central message is that the U.S. hasn't been hearing Moscow's signals.

title: Borg's Tour Predictions
description: Now that Bjorn Borg has decided to call it quits, what looms ahead for 1983 on the men's tennis tour? Last week, Borg gave these assessments of the top players:

title: SHULTZ DECLARES U.S. IS FIRM IN ITS SUPPORT FOR SEOUL'S SECURITY
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz arrived here today from Peking and affirmed the Reagan Administration's commitment to the security of South Korea.

title: Bridge: Games of Board-a-Match Are Challenging But Rare
description: Experts in North America indulge in a form of the game that is virtually unknown in other parts of the world and is approaching extinction here. The board-a-match team game, once scheduled routinely in every small tournament, is now played in three national events and practically no local ones.

title: TV: COMEDY ABOUT FLEEING THE CITY
description: SEARCHING for the better life is a theme that has proved durable from Mr. Blandings building his dream house to the more recent spate of adventures insisting that, among other things, the grass is greener around the septic tank. Tonight at 9 on Channel 2, there is ''Packin' It In,'' a television movie starring Richard Benjamin and his wife, Paula Prentiss.

title: Man Abandons Search For Lost Lottery Ticket
description: Don Temple tossed the last of a small mountain of garbage into a huge trash bin tonight, ending his grimy four-day search for a $10,000 lottery ticket he says he mistakenly threw away.

title: No Headline
description: MAHRES EXCEL IN SKI RACE

title: Canadiens 2, Jets 0
description: Richard Sevigny got his first shutout of the season, and Mark Napier broke a scoreless tie at 7:11 of the final period.

title: SALVADOR CLERIC SAYS BOMBS KILLED MANY
description: The Acting Archbishop of El Salvador said today that his office had concluded that 258 people were killed in fighting in the country last week, most of them in the southern city of Berlin, and that ''many'' of the deaths were the result of ''indiscriminate bombing'' by the Salvadoran Air Force.

title: Patricia Jean Golding Is Wed to Rudolph Staehelin
description: Patricia Jean Golding, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry W. Golding of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Rudolph Max Staehelin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Matthys Staehelin-Halff of Basel, Switzerland. Rabbi Gunter Hirschberg performed the ceremony at Congregation Rodeph Sholom in Manhattan.

title: Jim Thorpe's Family Feud
description: IN sports, the word legend is painfully overworked. But in the minds of all those who know what he was, Jim Thorpe is truly a legend - a muscular young man winning the decathlon and the pentathlon at the 1912 Olympics, a running back in football at the Carlisle Institute and later with the Canton Bulldogs, a big-league outfielder for six seasons, mostly with the New York Giants.

title: U.S. Sets New Estimate For Satellite Remnant
description: The radioactive remnant of a Soviet spy satellite speeded up its descent toward Earth today, leading Pentagon officials to predict it would fall into the atmosphere and burn up by Monday morning.

title: PARADOXICAL MISSION
description: Editor: Why are our Marines in Lebanon? This is the question that must be asked after reading the news articles, especially yours of Jan. 26, about confrontations between Israeli troops and U.S. Marines.

title: A NIXON TV SERIES ON WORLD AFFAIRS TO BEGIN
description: Production is scheduled to begin this week on a television series devoted to world affairs and world leaders, in which former President Richard M. Nixon will participate as anchorman and interviewer.

title: Signal Names Officials Following Frye Linkup
description: ''My career has been nothing spectacular: plain vanilla, one foot in front of the other,'' Michael D. Dingman said modestly the other day. Those footsteps have taken him to the right places. Mr. Dingman is settling into his new job as president and director of the conglomerate known as the Signal Companies.

title: DELAWARE MERGER SUIT IS CURBED
description: The Delaware Supreme Court has significantly limited the rights of shareholders who dissent to the merger of a subsidiary into its parent company.

title: AS FORCED EXIT EASES, AFRICA MALAISE LINGERS
description: A great exodus of Ghanaians and others from Nigeria has all but ended and its conclusion, as its beginning, has no joys.

title: OIL IMPACT ON MEXICAN TOWN
description: Six years ago, when Mexico's economy was last in trouble, large oil discoveries beneath the swamps surrounding this city announced the country's imminent recovery. And in the oil boom that followed, nowhere was growth wilder or faster than in Villahermosa.

title: BALLET: NUREYEV GLOWS WITH YOKO MORISHITA
description: HOWEVER Rudolf Nureyev has been dancing since he opened with ''Don Quixote'' and the Boston Ballet on Jan. 18 (in seven performances a week), he was at his most happily inspired Saturday night at the Uris Theater with his fourth and final new partner - the Japanese ballerina, Yoko Morishita.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 7, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad hoc committee on the Indian Oc- cean - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: FRANCIS WORKS QUIETLY TO PUT WHALERS BACK ON SCOREBOARD
description: HARTFORD THREE years ago, Ron Francis was playing hockey in the Midget League in his hometown of Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario. He was a high school student and a fan who spent most Saturday nights watching the Toronto Maple Leafs on television. The Hartford Whalers were in their first year in the National Hockey League then, and as newcomers to an exclusive club, they were receiving a rough initiation.

title: White House Budget Up 6.7%
description: Despite President Reagan's call for a freeze on nonmilitary spending, the 1984 budget request for the White House itself is going up by nearly $1.5 million because of higher rent, more travel and James S. Brady's medical expenses.

title: '82 TAX FORMS MORE DIFFICULT BUT OFFER WAY TO SAVE MONEY
description: Despite the introduction of a new, simplified form known as the 1040EZ, filling out this year's tax returns is more complicated than ever. Over the last two years, Congress has extensively altered the nation's tax laws, taking away some old tax benefits and creating many new ones. Most of the changes enacted in the 1981 Economic Recovery Tax Act and the 1982 Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act are only now going into effect, giving the average taxpayer a number of new tax provisions to master on this year's returns.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Yale Ingenuity

title: NUCLEAR FREEZE GROUP PLOTS A MORE POLITICAL APPROACH
description: Leaders of the nuclear freeze movement today endorsed an ambitious political agenda that includes seeking to elect legislators and a President in 1984 who are committed to the movement's proposals for ending the nuclear arms race.

title: Jersey Senate Weighs Jobs Bills
description: The State Senate is scheduled to vote Monday on a package of jobs bills that includes measures to train the poor and to attract high-technology industry to New Jersey.

title: BUYERS REPORT OUTPUT AND ORDER RISE
description: Purchasing managers of major corporations reported yesterday that production and the level of new orders rose in January. In its monthly report on business, the National Association of Purchasing Management said that more managers reported higher levels of production than reported lower ones for the first time in a year and a half. Purchasing managers at 250 industrial companies are polled each month.

title: HAGLER IS THE MAIN EVENT IN AN ARENA OF FACELESS CHALLENGERS
description: The Baltimore Civic Center, Nov. 9, 1982: Sugar Ray Leonard abdicating his throne as boxing's biggest star. He talked about the millions and millions he could make by fighting Marvelous Marvin Hagler. Then, all the while looking directly at Hagler, Leonard announced his retirement with these words: ''Unfortunately, it will never happen.'' It was apparent why Leonard had urged Hagler to attend.

title: CUOMO PROPOSAL ON PRISONS GETS SUPPORT BY FINK
description: Key state legislators say they will support Governor Cuomo's proposals to add 7,000 cells to the prison system in the next three years, proposals that include the converting of two mental institutions and two abandoned schools to places of imprisonment.

title: GANDHI PARTY WINS BIG VICTORY IN NEW DELHI
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress Party, defeated in assembly elections in southern India a month ago, today won a sweeping victory in municipal elections in New Delhi.

title: Spectrum Closed
description: After two years of trials and tribulations, Spectrum, a joint advertising sales unit for seven small-circulation magazines, has been closed. In the words of Hamilton Fish 3d, publisher of The Nation, the move follows ''many months of stubbornly slogging our way to the doors of evidently indifferent and occasionally hostile account representatives.'' In addition to his publication, the other magazines are Human Events, The Christian Century, The Progressive, Worldview, America and Present Tense.

title: Wollek Captures Race at Daytona
description: The French driver Bob Wollek, with an unexpected helping hand from A.J. Foyt, survived engine problems and stormy conditions today to capture the 24 Hours of Daytona with a Porsche 935 Turbo.

title: TRINITY COLLEGE DEBATES THE BANNING OF FRATERNITIES
description: Fraternities have been at Trinity College here for 132 of its 138 years. Women have been admitted as students here for 14. The debate dividing Trinity now is whether such brotherhoods can exist in a college pledged to oppose sexual discrimination.

title: MCENROE DEFEATS LENDL
description: When Ivan Lendl's final forehand sailed long, John McEnroe threw up his arms, flung his racquet in the air and let out a huge howl, as if he had just shed an evil spirit. And with a 4-6, 7-6, 6-4, 6-3 victory over Lendl in the final of the United States Pro Indoor Tennis Championships today, maybe he had.

title: BANKS, FLUSH, WOO CONSUMER
description: With many banks flush with cash as a result of the recent authorization of accounts paying money market interest rates, some institutions have stepped up their attempts to lend this money to the public.

title: ALPINE INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
United Rules Out A Business Class
description: United Airlines will not change the seating configuration on its planes to add a business class, a marketing tool to attract business travelers who are not willing to pay for first class seats, John R. Zeeman, senior vice president of marketing, said. According to Mr. Zeeman, the business class represents only about 5 percent of the airline market, and United would rather concentrate on the much bigger market for coach travel.

title: Chain Plans Magazine For Hospital Patients
description: Airlines routinely supply their own magazines, chock full of advertising for their passengers' delight. A number of hotel chains do the same thing, with Holiday Inns coming immediately to mind.

title: INFORMER IS WITNESS AT SENTENCE HEARING FOR TEAMSTERS' CHIEF
description: Government prosecutors put the first of a seris of informers on the witness stand in Federal court here today in an effort to encourage a maximum sentence for at least one of the four surviving defendants in the bribery conspiracy trial of Roy L. Williams, the teamsters' union leader.

title: People
description: * Ron McDougall joined the Burger King Corporation, Miami, as vice president of marketing.

title: STALEY, A E, MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DIANE KEATON CO-PRODUCING COMEDY
description: Diane Keaton will star in and co-produce ''Modern Bride,'' a romantic comedy about a 36-year-old woman who is getting married for the first time just as her parents are divorcing. The movie, which will be directed by Tim Hunter, is based on an original script by Joan Taylor that is now being rewritten by Nora Ephron and Alice Arlen.

title: TRIANGLE PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JAPAN MAY NOT EXTEND CAR CURB PAST 3d YEAR
description: Having signaled that it will extend its program of restraining automobile exports to the United States for a third year, Japan is apparently ready to draw the line there, despite mounting pressure from the American Congress.

title: TORCHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes securities gains of $3,374,000 for the qr and $4,071,000 for the yr...C-After a securities loss of $665,000 for the qr and a securities gain of $377,000 for the yr

title: QUOTATIONS OF THE DAY
description: ''Common sense and common morals tell us that we cannot stand mute while our prior assistance is used in the consummation of a fraud.'' - Randolph W. Thrower, a lawyer and former head of the Internal Revenue Service. (D21:1.)

title: SPENDING BY ALBANY LOBBIES ROSE TO RECORD HIGH IN 1982
description: Spending by lobbyists to influence New York State legislators and bureaucrats rose 13.4 percent last year to a record high of $9.3 million, according to a report released today by the State Commission on Lobbying.

title: Judge Denounces Another's Actions
description: A Federal judge yesterday denounced what he termed the ''improper'' behavior of a State Supreme Court justice in Queens who he said had been reversed in 22 of 27 reported opinions since 1977.

title: BRUSH WELLMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $6,740,000 for the qr and $7,487,000 for the yr...C-Net income including income of $22,000 from discontinued operations

title: SEGA ENTERPRISES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; Sega Enterprises is 91 percent-owned by Gulf & Western Industries

title: Qualities of Einsteinium
description: For the first time scientists have measured the chemical and physical properties of einsteinium, a metal so radioactive it glows in the dark with an eerie blue light.

title: NEWSWEEK, NOW 50, CELEBRATES AT LINCOLN CENTER
description: To celebrate its 50th year of publication, Newsweek gave a party for 2,400 last night at Lincoln Center. No detail seemed to have been overlooked for the elaborate event, which had been in preparation since last August. Newsweek declined to say how much it all cost, but Katharine Graham, chairman of the Washington Post Company, which owns Newsweek, said: ''What we spent is minuscule and is built into our budget for entertaining our advertisers. The party is simply our way of thanking our friends.''

title: SHARED MEDICAL SYSTEMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
G.M. PROFIT UP 49.5% IN 4th QUARTER
description: Despite a sharp drop in auto sales, the General Motors Corporation today reported that its fourth-quarter net income had jumped 49.5 percent, to $145 million, on the strength of the earnings from its auto financing subsidiary.

title: Navy 4-Man Sled Sets U.S. Record
description: The United States Navy sled set an American record today in winning the national four-man bobsled championship at Mount Van Hoevenberg.

title: WHAT AMERICAN DREAM?
description: Almost eight years ago, as a member in good standing of America's fragile middle class, I experienced for what I hope was the first and last time the personal devastation and family deprivation wrought by unemployment. Being an unemployed head of household and watching your middle-class life-support systems erode and collapse - salary, hospitalization, savings accounts, credit cards - is like being three feet tall: There is no way to understand the problems involved, except to live them.

title: M.A.C. Yields Cut On Good Demand
description: A $210 million issue of Municipal Assistance Corporation bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 10 percent for bonds due in 1995 to 10.6 percent in 1999 and 10 7/8 percent for bonds due in 2008.

title: BONE MARROW TRANSPLANTS: NEW MEHTHODS MAY SAVE LIVES
description: EIGHTEEN young children who faced almost certain death in infancy are alive and healthy today because of a new technique used in bone marrow transplantation.

title: Citibank Names Head Of Upstate Subsidiary
description: Daniel A. Saklad, who has been in charge of Citibank's consumer business in Hong Kong for two and a half years, has been named president of Citibank's upstate New York subsidiary.

title: ANTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including gains of $528,000 for the qr and $661,000 for the 6 mos on the saleof assets...C-Including a gain of $2,647,000 on the sale of assets

title: MAKE JOBS, CUT DEFICITS
description: Twelve million unemployed. A $200 billion budget deficit. Congress doesn't know what to do. Raise taxes? Lower taxes? Spend less? Spend more? The ugly truth is that no fiscal measure will both create jobs and cut deficits. Tax increases and spending cuts, social or military, destroy jobs; tax cuts and spending for public jobs and infrastructure enlarge deficits. Budget-neutral measures, like funding roads with gas taxes, are virtually employment-neutral, too.

title: MARINI GETS HIS CHANCE
description: He does not have the creative instincts of Wayne Gretzky or the marksmanship of Mike Bossy. Compared to the dashing young blades in the National Hockey League, the ones who can spray ice shavings like a gold-medal figure skater, Hector Marini of the New Jersey Devils is a pair of galoshes, trusty and practical, but not the type a prosperous league would be expected to show off on a special occasion.

title: ABC MAKING BIG INVESTMENT IN U.S.F.L.
description: A fter appearances last month in Los Angeles, San Francisco, Phoenix and Denver, the United States Football League/ABC road show played Manhattan yesterday. Philadelphia, Washington and Boston will be visited later this week, with Detroit, Chicago, Birmingham and Tampa on tap later this month.

title: CANADA TRUSTCO MORTGAGE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Gross income figures represent investment income; Canada Trustco is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges

title: RATES UP A BIT IN SLOW DAY
description: Interest rates rose slightly in very quiet trading yesterday as dealers concentrated on reducing their holdings of Treasury notes and bonds acquired at last week's auctions.

title: AMERICAN FAMILY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dreyfus Bank Allowed
description: The Government today gave the Dreyfus Corporation permission to set up a new national bank. The action by C.T. Conover, Comptroller of the Currency, further blurs the distinction between securities and banking, and is likely to be opposed by the Federal Reserve Board, which earlier had expressed concern about the legality of any such approval.

title: SIMPSON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quanex's Debt Is Restructured
description: The Quanex Corporation said its debtors had agreed in principle to restructure about $170 million of debt that matures on Nov. 1, 1984, and that is secured by all the company's assets.

title: Defeated Party's Chief Said to Quit in India
description: Former Foreign Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee resigned as leader of the rightist opposition Bharatiya Janata Party today after a heavy defeat in Delhi's local elections, party sources said.

title: DESTRUCTIVENESS, FOR ALL TO SEE
description: To the Editor:

title: DATA PACKAGING CORP reports earnings for Yr to Nov 27
description: B-After a loss of $94,000 from discontinued operations...C-After a loss of $92,000 from discontinued operations

title: 5 Protestant Leaders Ask To Reply to CBS Show
description: Leaders of five Protestant denominations demanded time from CBS News under the ''personal attack'' rules today to answer charges that the National Council of Churches aided Marxist-Leninist groups and governments.

title: T.W.A. Sees A Sizable Loss
description: Trans World Airlines said it could not expect its first-quarter results to improve from the $110 million pretax loss it reported in the first quarter of 1982.

title: CONCERT: MUSICA AETERNA
description: MUSICA AETERNA's concert at the Metropolitan Museum Saturday night gave up two-thirds of its program to a guest soloist, Richard Goode. Frederic Waldman and his chamber orchestra of 20 began with Haydn's Symphony in D, No. 34, and then stepped back to accompany Mr. Goode in two Mozart piano concertos, No. 17 in G (K.453) and No. 18 in B Flat (K.456).

title: LONE STAR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest periods include operations of Marquette Co, which was acquired in Apr

title: SERVICEMASTER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Manic to Become Team Canada
description: The Canadian Soccer Association and Molson Breweries of Canada Ltd., have reached an agreement in principle to transform the Manic, a member of the North American Soccer League, into a national team that will represent Canada in the 1986 World Cup.

title: EUROPEAN TIED TO ILLEGAL ACTS IS SHIELDED BY C.I.A.
description: Over the last two decades, Alfred J. Buhler, a lawyer and businessman from Liechtenstein, has been connected in interviews and documents with stock and tax fraud, illegal arms deals, kidnapping and questionable overseas payments on behalf of American corporations. But the Central Intelligence Agency has prevented law-enforcement authorities from even questioning him.

title: Campbell-Mithun Gets The Jockey for Her Line
description: Campbell-Mithun, the Minneapolis subsidiary of Ted Bates Worldwide, has been named agency for Jockey for Her, a recently introduced line of women's panties from the same people who have been supplying males with Jockey shorts over the years.

title: Peking Disputes U.S.  On Date of Zhao Visit
description: The Chinese Foreign Ministry today denied a White House announcement that the two countries have agreed that Prime Minister Zhao Ziyang will visit the United States this year.

title: GERULAITIS GRANTED A REVIEW
description: A lawyer for Vitas Gerulaitis disclosed in court yesterday that the Justice Department had agreed to review a cocaine investigation involving the tennis star before a grand jury proceeds with the case.

title: Junior May Return
description: If E.J. Junior, who pleaded guilty to possession of cocaine, succeeds in getting his two-year prison sentence converted to probation, the owner of the St. Louis Cardinals, Bill Bidwill, says he will be glad to give him back his old job as linebacker. But the final say, Bidwill said, would be up to the commissioner of the National Football League, Pete Rozelle, who was returning from the Pro Bowl yesterday and was not available for comment.

title: FASTER SCHOOLING WIDELY DEBATED
description: IN light of a proposal by New York State Education Commissioner Gordon M. Ambach to start children in school at age 4 and have them graduate by age 16, educators, psychologists and others are debating whether it is possible or sensible to speed up the learning process in such a fashion.

title: AFTER CRASH FATAL TO 7, OFFICIALS ASSESS HARD-TO-ENFORCE TRUCK SAFETY ; RULES
description: After watching more than 20 trucks pass by, Kurt Greenwald, a civilian inspector for the state police, suddenly bolted through a line of traffic at the Connecticut Turnpike toll plaza here and waved a white tractor-trailer to the side of the road.

title: SNOWFALL LEAVES ITS BIGGEST MARK ON THE SUBURBS
description: The biggest storm of a clement winter draped the New York metropolitan area in 3 to 7 inches of snow yesterday. It snarled traffic and closed many suburban schools but began turning to rainwashed slush in the afternoon and became a pale, fifth-anniversary imitation of the blizzard of '78.

title: CHEMED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $2,917,000 for the qr and $11,233,000 for the yr, a gain of $4,455,000 for the yr on the sale of stock and again of $881,000 for the yr on the sale of interest in a licensee...C-Includingincome from discontinued operations of $1,872,000

title: BROWN REASSURES NET PLAYERS
description: It was barely five months ago that Coach Hubie Brown of the Knicks said that Michael Ray Richardson's talents were not suited to running an offense, especially a complicated one like his. Now, Coach Larry Brown of the Nets says that same player and those same talents will ''make things easier for everyone.''

title: PEPSICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $79,400,000 for the reduction in the net assets of Pepsico's foreign bottling unit, and foreign currency gains of $3,900,000fora the qr and $12,300,000 for the yr...C-Net income

title: MOSCOW PLANS TALKS WITH TOKYO
description: Several days after Secretary of State George P. Shultz ended his visit to Japan last week, the Soviet Union protested strongly against Japanese defense policies and offered talks in the spring on Japanese-Soviet issues, officials here report.

title: U.S.F.L. POLICIES PRAISED BY PLAYERS
description: Wayne Harris and Kent Hull are practicing twice a day with the New Jersey Generals, one of the new United States Football League teams.

title: CITIZENS SAVINGS FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Walesa Gets Summons; May Decide to Ignore It
description: Lech Walesa, who led the outlawed Solidarity labor union, has been called to appear before a military prosecutor in Warsaw at 10 A.M. Thursday.

title: MAYOR NAMES 3 IN REORGANIZING ECONOMIC OFFICE
description: Mayor Koch, trying to invigorate the programs responsible for keeping and attracting jobs and businesses to New York City, announced the appointment of three new commissioners yesterday in a major reorganization of the city's Office of Economic Development.

title: LIFEMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $214,000 for the qr and $818,000 for the yr...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $71,000 forthe qr and $747,000 for the yr

title: I Know It When I Taste It
description: President Reagan likes to say he was elected to get the government off the backs of the people, but that's a joke. He can't even get the Agriculture Department to stop dictating to good Americans what barbecue is.

title: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 8, 1983; Companies
description: G.M. reported a 49.5 percent rise in net income in the fourth quarter, to $145 million. For the year, net soared to $963 million, from $333 million, largely as a result of tax credits and the earnings of its finance unit. The report was in line with expectations. (Page D1.)

title: Metal Markets; Curious Capitalism
description: What should an industry do when it suffers from sluggish demand and enormous excess capacity? Adam Smith (and common sense) would say cut prices and costs. That should perk up sales, generate customer good will and help keep the factories going until better days arrive.

title: AMERICAN MAIZE PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $412,000 for the qr and yr for the provisionfor settlement of class action claims and income of $1,922,000 or 37 cents a shr for the yr from discontinued operations...C-Including income from discontinuedoperations of $757,000 or 14 cents a shr for the qr and $905,000 or 17 cents a shr for the yr

title: CHRISTIAN-DRUSE ACCORD OBTAINED, ISRAELI SAYS
description: The Israeli Army announced today that it had achieved a written peace agreement between Druse and Christian gunmen who have been fighting for control of Lebanon's Israelioccupied central mountains.

title: No Headline
description: OPEC's Flow Is Said to Fall

title: Cluett, Peabody
description: Cluett, Peabody & Company said it had sold its 13-store Lytton's chain in Chicago to Matt B. Kallman, corporate vice president of Associated Dry Goods, and Thomas F. Rafferty, an officer of May Department Stores, for an undisclosed price. The stores have sales of $40 million a year. Cluett said it would invest the proceeds in apparel manufacturing operations.
