description: Inspired by consumer research that shows that the average American automobile is nearly seven years old, Shaw & Koulermos, the agency for local Oldsmobile dealers, is creating a television commercial that ends with the line, ''Get your 1990 automobile - today.''

title: TRANSIT OFFICER SHOOTS TWO AFTER BEING STABBED ON IRT
description: A transit police officer on patrol in civilian clothes shot two teen-agers after they attacked and stabbed him on a southbound IRT local in lower Manhattan yesterday, the police said. A third youth was captured by the officer's partner, who was in an adjoining car.

title: Somali Clashes Reported
description: Guerrillas said today that their forces killed 21 Somali soldiers and captured 21 in two clashes along the Somali-Ethiopian border last week. Radio Halgan, the voice of the Democratic Somali Salvation Front broadcasting from Ethiopia, said the two attacks took place last Thursday and Friday inside Somalia.

title: KEY QUOTATIONS FROM REPORT
description: The American Jewish leaders of that time faced formidable obstacles. Their organizations were small and weakly financed. There was no organized Jewish lobby.

title: A 'DEPRESSING' CAUSE AT U.N.: INDEPENDENCE FOR EAST TIMOR
description: From January to June, Jose Ramos Horta prowls the corridors and lounges here, buttonholing African diplomats, holding long talks with two each day. The rest of the year, he works on lobbying the less promising delegates from Europe, Asia and Latin America.

title: 3 Blacks Slain After a Chase Over 3 Days in South Africa
description: Soldiers and police officers shot and killed three armed black guerrillas trapped in a ravine 30 miles from the Swaziland border today after a three-day hunt, Police Commissioner Mike Geldenhuys announced.

title: INTERNATIONAL FLAVORS & FRAGRANCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BENEFICIAL CORP reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income after a loss of $17 million from discontinued operations...C-AFterlosses from discontinued operations of $109.7 million for the latest yr and $74.4 million for the previous yr

title: WHAT A CAREER MEANS
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: Why is it never mentioned as a possibility in any of the recent barrage of articles on women who leave their careers to stay home with children (the so-called ''postfeminist generation'') that men who have a career and children might also be ''mediocre at both''? We just don't think that way, do we? Why is it still considered primarily a woman's choice and not a couple's decision whether one of them should stay home or not?

title: F.B.I. AGENT ADDS TESTIMONY ON TEAMSTER LINKS TO MAFIA
description: An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified today that Allen M. Dorfman, the insurance executive who was slain last month, was ''ordered to appear'' in 1979 for a dressing-down by Joseph Aiuppa, chief of the Chicago Mafia.

title: U.S. PANEL URGES ON-SITE ATOM TEST CHECKS
description: An interagency panel has recommended to President Reagan that two nuclear testing treaties with the Soviet Union be revised to require on-site inspection before the accords are ratified, Administration officials said today.

title: A Cry of Conscience
description: Painfully and convincingly, Israel has raked through the horrors of Sabra and Shatila and judged itself, harshly, by ''the fundamental principles of the civilized world.''

title: Japan Recorder Exports
description: Japanese makers of videotape recorders are prepared to limit exports to the European Economic Community to help ease trade frictions, electronics industry sources said today. The sources said that in return, the manufacturers wanted Japan's Trade Ministry to push hard in trade talks this week for an end to French import restrictions on their products and also wanted European makers of videotape recorders to drop an action charging them with selling recorders at below cost in Europe.

title: THE FORGOTTEN QUESTION
description: The Democrats are in New York City this week with their leading Presidential candidates for a meeting of their National Committee. This is the Political Exhibition Season, when they look over their players and talk over their tactics. They see great opportunities ahead by day and hear ''Hail to the Chief'' in the night, but they have some formidable problems.

title: Economic Scene; Politics And Policies
description: THE fundamental conflict over economic policy in the United States is over two separate but related issues: the first is whether to give a higher priority to reducing inflation or unemployment, and the second is whether to limit the role of government to controlling a few economic variables, such as the supply of money, or expand its role in an effort to solve such problems as reconciling price stability and full employment, strengthening particular industries or improving the lot of the poor.

title: PHILIP PLEXICO
description: Philip Plexico, a lawyer and partner in the Manhattan law firm of Ford Marrin Esposito & Witmeyer, died of a heart attack yesterday at the New York Infirmary-Beekman Downtown Hospital.

title: SALVADOR LOSES BASE TO REBELS
description: Leftist rebels said today that they had overrun a 50-man military base on the slopes of a volcano east of the capital, killing nine soldiers, wounding six and capturing 33.

title: Advertising; Wells, Rich Is Seeking Atari Job
description: MARKETPLACE reports have it that Wells, Rich, Greene got the Atari personal computer business last week from Young & Rubicam, but that Y.& R. won a stay of execution until it could make another pitch for the business.

title: REPORT CONTENDS U.S. JEWS REACTED SLOWLY TO NAZI PERIL
description: An interim report of the American Jewish Commission on the Holocaust concludes that Jews in this country were slow to react to the mortal danger posed to European Jews by Nazi Germany and never mounted a sustained, all-out mobilization to save the millions of Jews threatened with extinction in World War II.

title: A TENNIS CHAMPION'S WHIRLWIND DAY
description: It is not easy being a top athlete, but Martina Navratilova is thankful that few days are as grueling for her as yesterday was. The problem was that she was not playing tennis, but rather was discharging duties as president of the Women's Tennis Association by helping to promote the Virginia Slims tour, especially the $350,000 tournament at Madison Square Garden March 23. The 10 top-ranked women are scheduled to be in the 16-player championship, and Miss Navratilova, the world's No. 1, was in town to spread the word.

title: U.S. REBUFFS QUEBECER ON SEPERATE TRADE TIE
description: The State Department has issued a statement rejecting a proposal by a Quebec official who wanted to create a common market linking an independent Quebec with the United States as well as Canada.

title: NIGERIAN ACTION WORTHY ON CENSURE BY BLACKS
description: To the Editor:

title: EQUIFAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WESTINGHOUSE CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
President at Cook Resigns After Rift
description: George Jeffers, president and chief executive of financially troubled Cook United Inc., a Middle West discount department store chain, has resigned over ''philosophical differences'' with the board, the company said yesterday.

title: MANTLE TAKES $100,000 JERSEY CASINO JOB
description: Mickey Mantle signed a $100,000-a-year contract with an Atlantic City gambling casino yesterday, primarily to play golf with clients, and was promptly told by the commissioner of baseball to sever any active links to the Yankees.

title: LEVER HOUSE IS INDISPUTABLY A LANDMARK
description: To the Editor:

title: ADDABBO ASKS $15 BILLION CUT FROM MILITARY COSTS
description: The chairman of the House Appropriations Subcommittee on Defense, Representative Joseph P. Addabbo of Queens, said today that Congress should slice $15 billion from President Reagan's plans for military spending in 1984.

title: TV: ANIMAL LIFE OF AUSTRALIA
description: ''AUSTRALIA'S ANIMAL MYSTERIES'' begins very much like a sciencefiction movie, with pictures of a lunar landscape and a narrator talking about ''a land of eternal mystery'' and ''haunting age-old mysteries of life.'' In fact, the documentary goes in more for charm than it does mysteries, and a good thing it does, too: It is entertaining. It will be seen at 8 tonight on Channel 13.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Kenny Cooper, the coach of the Baltimore Blast, will coach the East in the Major Indoor Soccer League's All-Star Game in Kansas City Feb. 22, and Dave Clements of the St. Louis Steamers will coach the West. ... Francie Larrieu, the distance-running star, will serve as consultant and spokesman for the Colgate Women's Games, the largest amateur track meet for women.

title: KAMAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Miss Bellamy Notes Error in Her Tax Plan
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy said yesterday that because of an error her recent proposal to help balance the city budget by imposing a surcharge on the top city income-tax bracket would not bring in as much money as she had calculated.

title: WHO ARE THE FOREIGNERS IN THE SOUTH CHINA SEA?
description: Beyond the southern horizon of this port town on Hainan Island lie scores of barren islets, atolls and coral reefs scattered like stones across the South China Sea.

title: Ferraro Surgery Today
description: Mike Ferraro, the manager of the Cleveland Indians, will undergo surgery Wednesday for removal of his left kidney, in which doctors discovered a small tumor today, the American League team said.

title: 3 in Football Hall
description: Three more coaches have made the National Football Foundation's College Football Hall of Fame.

title: Louis Statham, 75, Inventor And Avid Coast Chess Player
description: Louis D. Statham, whose many inventions included measuring devices used to keep spacecraft on course and whose avocation led to one of the world's largest chess tournaments, has died. He was 75 years old and lived in Lone Pine.

title: Sale by Texas Slow
description: Texas sold $50 million of Aaa-rated bonds that were publicly offered with yields ranging from 5.75 percent for bonds due in 1987 to 7.25 percent in 1993 and 8.3 percent in 1998. Sales of the issue were slow in the first day, and underwriters, led by the Bankers Trust Company, said that $37 million of the issue remained unsold.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: EVERY once in awhile, a pop performer announces that he or she has soul, true soul, a quality so exalted that only a handful of great artists and the most sensitive listeners will ever be able to accurately judge its worth.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: GRETZKY SCORES 4 IN THIRD TO LEAD CAMPBELL STARS
description: After tonight's National Hockey League All-Star Game, everybody was talking about the car - who won it, who deserved it, who almost won it.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: NEXT Monday is Valentine's Day, when one's fancy is supposed to turn to tokens of love. Herewith, then, some suitable suggestions. 1. A Drawstring Bag For any romantic: a heart-shaped handbag. A leather bag designed by Chris Anderson has a drawstring top and a narrow shoulder strap. It's very effective in red and also comes in white, beige and blue. You'll find it at Eddris, 314 East 78th Street, priced at $52.

title: DAMAGE TO TALKS IS FEARED
description: Lebanese reaction to the report by an Israeli commission on the killing of Palestinians at two camps in Beirut in September was muted but there was concern among officials here over possible repercussions on the negotiations on the withdrawal of Israeli and other foreign forces from Lebanon.

title: No Headline
description: IRAQ SAYS IT HAS STOPPED LATEST IRANIAN PUSH

title: TROPICAL PICKINGS AROUND THE TOWN
description: Asian Pear. Unlike the Bartlett, which is buttery and smooth, the Asian pear is closer to a Bosc, with a crisp texture and a skin like sand. In fact, it is sometimes called a sand pear, and sometimes called an Oriental apple pear. When perfectly ripe, some Asian pears have all of the heady bouquet of the best pears and taste a bit like apples. They are from California and France.

title: 14 Horses Entered In the Hutcheson
description: Highland Park has been assigned top weight of 122 pounds and made the early 3-1 favorite for the $66,050 Hutcheson Stakes at Gulfstream Park on Wednesday. The seven-furlong Hutcheson, which drew a field of 14, is the first major race of the season for 3-year-old thoroughbreds training in south Florida.

title: CHAMPION PARTS REBUILDERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss; yr-ago qr and yr results reflect a charge of 62 cents a shr for plant closing and relocations costs

title: 3 Men Found Shot to Death In Jackson Heights Tenement
description: Three men were found shot to death last night in a fifth-floor apartment in the Jackson Heights section of Queens, the police said.

title: WHAT A CAREER MEANS
description: TO THE LIVING EDITOR: I know that I did the right thing for me when I decided not to go back to work but rather stay home to raise our children. But it took years of excuses and explanations to working friends before I lost my anxiety over my decision. Today there is a wealth of information to support the working mother, but little support to the woman who leaves her career for the well-being of her family and children.

title: HAUSERMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $1,411,000...C-Net income; yr-ago results have beenadusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in June 1982

title: CALLS FOR SHARON'S DEPARTURE
description: A special state investigating commission said today that Israel's top civilian and military leaders bore ''indirect responsibility'' for the massacre of Palestinians by Lebanese Christian Phalangist militia in Beirut last September.

title: Japan Says It Permits Visits By Nuclear-Powered Carriers
description: Japan will allow United States nuclearpowered aircraft carriers into its ports, at the risk of setting off anti-American and antinuclear demonstrations, the Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Lebanese Said to Foil a Plot To Sabotage Talks on Pullout
description: The Lebanese Army foiled a plot to fire four Soviet-made rockets at American, Lebanese and Israeli negotiators conducting talks on withdrawing foreign forces in Lebanon, the military prosecutor, Assad Germanos, said today.

title: TV: CLORIS LEACHMAN IN 'MIRACLE'
description: AS an actress, Cloris Leachman has always been determinedly unorthodox. She can play a dizzy, glamorous woman with a pronounced talent for tossing off her lines hilariously, as she did while starring in her own series, ''Phyllis,'' several years ago. Or she can appear, equally persuasive, as the worn-out but still struggling wife of an itinerant farmer, as she also did several years ago in a dramatic production called ''The Migrants.'' Swerving between extremes, she is apt to pop up in the most unlikely of roles in the most unexpected of formats.

title: LAWYERS VOTE FOR DISCLOSURE IF NEEDED TO CORRECT PERJURY
description: The American Bar Association today endorsed in principle a proposal requiring lawyers to disclose their clients' secrets, if needed, to correct perjured testimony.

title: A CURIOUS CASE: HAROLD BROWN AND THE MX PANEL
description: The story of Harold Brown's appointment to, and resignation from, the President's Commission on Strategic Forces is a strange commentary on President Reagan's problems with the MX missile. It illustrates how politics and bureaucratic constraints can collide to produce an unintended result and bruised feelings.

title: European Liberals Urge Release of Shcharansky
description: West European Liberals appealed to Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, today to free Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the imprisoned dissident, and allow him to emigrate to Israel.

title: PULSAR TERMED MOST ACCURATE 'CLOCK' IN SKY
description: Observations of the fastest pulsar, or pulsating star, now show it to be the most accurate natural clock in the sky, more so than most atomic clocks in use on the earth.

title: Away, but Home
description: Closed-circuit telecasts have long been popular in boxing and football. But tonight, with the popularity of college basketball seemingly on the rise, St. John's will show its game against Georgetown from Landover, Md., on a closed-circuit hookup at Alumni Hall on the Redmen's campus.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: In one of the showrooms, with its wall-to-wall carpeting and designer plants, there was a big sign: ''We Have Seen the Future and It Is Smurfs.''

title: Pitt Under Attack
description: The head of the Mobile County School Board in Alabama charged yesterday that Pittsburgh athletic officials had withdrawn an offer of a football scholarship to a local running back, Charles Wilson, after officials at Wilson's high school had refused a Pitt demand for a ''falsified'' academic transcript. School officials at Vigor High School say a Pitt assistant requested another copy of his transcript omitting failing grades in courses Wilson had taken as a freshman and that he later made up in summer school. Pitt's coach, Foge Fazio, denied the charge last night.

title: SATELLITE MAP IMAGES FOUND VASTLY IMPROVED
description: After six months of operation, the Landsat 4 satellite has produced scores of mapping images of the earth's surface that are ''highly encouraging'' for future crop surveys, geological prospecting, urban planning and hydrological studies, according to space agency officials.

title: HOMESTAKE MINING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split to be paid Mar 14

title: Saxon Refinancing
description: The Saxon Oil Company said the Dallas Interfirst Bank had demanded immediate payment of about $89 million of principal and interest and exercised its rights of offset against some of the company's accounts. Saxon said it had requested that the bank rescind its demand and the offset because of continuing negotiations covering a pending trade-creditors agreement and a refinancing agreement with the bank.

title: Super Bowl Replay Plan
description: O.J. Simpson has joined with a top English soccer club in an effort to bring to Wembley Stadium this summer a rematch of the Super Bowl XVII teams. American football has recently become a cult sport in Britain, and Tottenham Hotspur, the current holder of the English Cup and one of English soccer's most famous clubs, wants to cash in on the growing interest by promoting an exhibition between the Washington Redskins and the Miami Dolphins.

title: No Need for a Sub-Supreme Court
description: For 14 years Chief Justice Warren Burger has sought sympathy for the burdens of the ''overwhelmed, overworked'' Supreme Court. Congress, which could provide relief, remains skeptical. The Chief Justice's latest cry for help, in a speech to the American Bar Association, remains unpersuasive.

title: Anheuser Net Up
description: Anheuser-Busch Companies Inc., the nation's largest brewer, reported that 1982 fourth-quarter earnings rose 33.9 percent, to $58.8 million, or $1.12 a share, from $43.9 million, or 97 cents a share, in the comparable quarter a year earlier.

title: Unlikely Target
description: The big, bold letters on the van read, ''John Jay College of Criminal Justice.'' But that didn't keep thieves from ransacking it outside Madison Square Garden recently while Coach Bob Fox and John Jay basketball players were watching the Rutgers-Louisville game.

title: Council Approves Panel on Rents
description: After objections by most members of the Manhattan delegation, the City Council yesterday approved appointment of the nine-member board that supervises rent-stabilized apartments. The board, appointed by the Mayor, is made up of four representatives of tenants, four of landlords and an impartial chairman.

title: CAGLE'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
AMERICAN CYANAMID CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Real Estate; New Status For Puck Building
description: PETER GEE and Paul Serra are longtime friends who have successfully combined careers in the arts with conversions of loft buildings into residential cooperatives in the Tribeca and SoHo areas of Manhattan.

title: WINE TALK
description: ACCORDING to a fable told by Champagne devotees, an ardent young man was pursuing a lady without success until he discovered that she had a passion for Champagne. Not only did she adore the sparkling wine from the verdant vineyards of northeastern France, but she had also studied the subject thoroughly, knew her own preferences and was delighted when a bottle of one of her favorites was presented to her.

title: BankAmerica Revision: Income Much Lower
description: Under pressure from the Securities and Exchange Commission, the BankAmerica Corporation yesterday reported sharply lower net operating income for the fourth quarter than it had reported last month.

title: African Leaders Discuss Nigerian Expulsions
description: Five West African presidents held a hastily arranged meeting today to discuss the crisis caused by Nigeria's expulsion of illegal aliens.

title: U.N. CHIEF REJECTS U.S. NAMIBIA POLICY
description: United Nations Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar today rejected American efforts to link the withdrawal of Cuban soldiers from Angola to independence for South-West Africa.

title: Dow Retreats 11.77, to 1,075.33
description: The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 11.77 points yesterday, to 1,075.33, as investors cashed in some of their recent profits. ''The market was overbought and ripe for a pullback,'' said Ralph J. Acampora, vice president and head of technical research at Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: INTEREST RATES RISE MODESTLY
description: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday, with all of the increase coming in the last two hours of what was an otherwise uneventful trading session, reflecting weak investor demand.

title: KARAJAN VS. THE BERLIN ORCHESTRA
description: In December, 1980, when he celebrated his silver jubilee as principal conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra, Herbert von Karajan spoke of his ''love'' for his players and said he had come to think of them ''like a family.''

title: AMERICAN WATER WORKS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WINE Q&A
description: Q. Last year I began storing several bottles of Chateau St. Jean chardonnay, vintages 1977 and 1978, in the refrigerator because they were getting decidedly too rich and I did not want to drink them just yet. What are the pitfalls of storing wines in the refrigerator, and could red wines also be laid there as temporary relief from too rapid ripening?

title: Tanaka Case Admission
description: A one-time aide to former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka admitted today that he had received $2.1 million for Mr. Tanaka from the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation's Japanese agent.

title: NETS WIN AS RICHARDSON MAKES DEBUT
description: The Michael Ray Richardson watch ended just before 3 o'clock this afternoon, when the newest Net guard arrived at the team's hotel. Richardson said he attempted to get here Monday, but his flight from San Francisco was delayed getting into Denver, so he missed his connecting flight.

title: TELEFLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: B-Includes a gain of $2,914,000 or 62 cents a shr from the sale of investment

title: PAPANDREOU PLAN LURING SOME COMMUNIST EXILES
description: A few thousand of the 30,000 Greek Communists still in exile in Eastern Europe are reportedly applying for permission to return under a repatriation program announced in December by Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: NOT long ago I put together two recipes using veal scaloppine (it was on sale at my local supermarket), both of which were tailored to the one-hour format. It occurred to me that veal is one of the most versatile of meats. Because of its delicate nature the flavor can be altered at will - a sprinkling of an herb or spice, the addition of a bit of wine, the use of mushrooms as an accompanying ingredient, a touch of mustard.

title: PEOPLE OF HOPE GIVEN A NEW MISSION
description: This week, 18-year-old Ann Marie O'Brien began a 30-month sentence with the People of Hope, a Roman Catholic charismatic community that has grown from a handful of adherents to a close-knit group of more than 1,000 people in northern New Jersey.

title: INFORMATICS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
An Appraisal
description: It was back in the 1920's that the first proposal was made to cut a wide, open swath through the center of this city's downtown. The plans got more serious in the 1960's, after Eero Saarinen's 630-foot high Gateway Arch was completed at the edge of the Mississippi River, and the idea of an open vista through the city to the arch seemed like a natural idea. But the Gateway Mall, as the project has been known, has still not come to be, and by now it may be the only urban design project in the country that has been fought over longer than Westway in New York.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: and then, perhaps, just the slightest bit pleased with myself, when nothing ''bad'' happened.

title: COMMUNITY'S ANGER AROUSED BY DECISION TO CLOSE A SCHOOL
description: Split Rock Elementary is an old, brick schoolhouse surrounded by asphalt playgrounds, swing sets, jungle gyms and baseball diamonds -as traditional as could be, right down to the paper snowflakes taped to the windows and the two little boys out back trading bad words and laughing until their stomachs hurt.

title: SMITH INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JONATHAN C. CLARK
description: Jonathan C. Clark, associate professor of history at Vassar College, died Monday of endocarditis at Vassar Brothers Hospital in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. He lived in Poughkeepsie and was 41 years old.

title: KEY DEMOCRAT BIDS CONGRESS HALT TAX CUTS
description: The chief Democratic tax writer in the House of Representatives, Dan Rostenkowski, proposed today that Congress reduce future budget deficits by the repeal or delay of various tax cuts for business and individuals now scheduled to take effect after 1983.

title: EXPERT ON PROTEIN STRUCTURES
description: Margaret Oakley Dayhoff, a biochemist who developed much-used compilations of protein structures, died Saturday of a heart attack at her home in Silver Spring, Md. She was 57 years old.

title: FRINGE GROUP FORCES OUSTER VOTE ON COAST MAYOR
description: To the consternation of City Hall, a small group of radicals from the street wars of a decade ago has collected petitions forcing Mayor Dianne Feinstein into a special election April 26 on whether she should be ousted from office.

title: Starr's Pact Extended
description: Since he took over as coach of the Green Bay Packers eight years ago, Bart Starr has had only two winning seasons.

title: DEFENSE CUT ISSUE: 'GENERALITIES DON'T COUNT'
description: To the Editor:

title: STANDARD REGISTER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
NEW YORKERS, ETC.
description: IF you stop for a moment and think about pennies and subway tokens, you will realize instantly that there are certain things in life that invariably multiply, and others that just as invariably diminish or disappear.

title: MANHATTAN UPSETS IONA, 57-55
description: Manhattan gained its most impressive victory in two seasons under Coach Gordon Chiesa when the Jaspers rallied to beat Iona, 57-55, tonight in a Metro Atlantic Conference game at Mulcahy Center.

title: NEPAL FEARS MOUNT EVEREST COULD BECOME PILE OF TRASH
description: A growing pile of rubbish left behind by climbers on Mount Everest is worrying Nepal's authorities, who want the world's highest mountain kept clean.

title: Armco Plans to Sell Coal Assets to Arch
description: Armco Inc., the nation's seventhlargest steelmaker, said today that it was negotiating the sale of ''substantially all its West Virginia coal properties'' to a subsidiary of the Arch Mineral Corporation of St. Louis, which is 50 percent owned by the Ashland Oil Company, for about $320 million.

title: EXCERPTS FROM REPORT ON ISRAELIS' RESPONSIBILITY IN MASSACRE
description: Following are excerpts from a report made public today by an Israeli commission of inquiry into the slayings of civilians last September in Beirut at two Palestinian refugee camps, Sabra and Shatila, as issued in translation by the Government press office: I

title: STANADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HITACHI GUILTY IN I.B.M. CASE
description: Hitachi Ltd. and two of its employees pleaded guilty in the United States District Court here today to charges that it conspired to steal confidential computer information from the International Business Machines Corporation and transport it to Japan.

title: TEXTRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a gain of $10,300,000 or 28 cents a shr from the exchange of common stock for debentures...C-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $100,000for the qr and $6,000,000 for the yr and a gain of $7,800,000 or 21 cents a shrfor the qr and yr related to a contract terminated by the government of Iran in1978

title: PRESIDENT STUDIES CURB ON GAS PRICES
description: President Reagan is considering a plan under which natural gas prices would in effect be frozen, Administration sources said today, because of the effects on consumers of sharply rising prices.

title: WILLIAM CAREY, FORMER S.E.C. CHAIRMAN, DIES AT 72
description: William L. Cary, the Dwight Professor at Columbia Law School and a former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, died of cancer Monday night at his home in Manhattan. He was 72 years old.

title: WHAT A CAREER MEANS
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I enjoyed your article on women who have given up their careers to stay home with their children.

title: BUSH, IN PARIS, SAYS ALLIES' COMMITMENT ON MISSILES REMAINS FIRM
description: Vice President Bush said today that Washington's invitations to the Soviet Union to make new offers for reducing medium-range missiles were being supported by a Western European commitment to deploy new American missiles starting in late 1983.

title: Missouri Falls in Overtime
description: Barry Stevens, a sophomore forward, scored 40 points, including an 18-foot jumper at the buzzer, to give Iowa State a 73-72 overtime upset of Missouri tonight.

title: U.P.I. OWNERSHIP TRANSFERS SEEM TO INVOLVE LITTLE CASH
description: John Jay Hooker, new chairman of the board of United Press International, says he obtained a 30 percent interest in the nation's second largest news agency last week with virtually no outlay in money.

title: Top-Level Civil Servants In Quebec End Strike
description: Quebec's 9,000 top-level civil servants returned to work today after voting to quit a two-week-old strike of government workers called to protest pay cuts.

title: ANDERSON GREENWOOD & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Wall Street Artworks AWall Street investment banking and securities company, Donaldson, L ufkin & Jenrette Inc., has hired a curator, Carson Joyner, for its a rt collection. Miss Joyner, who has done museum work and graduate s tudies, also worked in the State Department's ''art in embassies'' p rogram.

title: AGEE QUITS ALLIED AND BENDIX JOBS
description: William M. Agee, who agreed to sell the Bendix Corporation to the Allied Corporation to resolve a tangled takeover battle, stepped down yesterday as president of Allied and chairman of Bendix.

title: INVESTORS GROUP LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After special gains of $4,331,000...C-After charge of $8,413,000

title: STARS SIGN BRYANT
description: Kelvin Bryant and Irv Eatman, two of last season's top college players, signed rich multiyear contracts today with the Philadelphia Stars of the United States Football League.

title: Books Of The Times
description: THE YOUNGEST SCIENCE: Notes of a Medicine-Watcher. By Lewis Thomas. 270 pages. Viking. $14.95.

title: Boxer Listed as Critical
description: A 17-year-old amateur boxer was in critical condition here today after surgery to remove three blood clots from his brain.

title: Truck Crashes Kill 32 in India
description: Two truck crashes killed 32 people today in rural India, officials said. Two trucks collided head on, killing 20 passengers and injuring 24, in the village of Bandhani, about 450 miles southwest of New Delhi, while in the eastern state of Bihar a truck fell into the Khaka River near Giridih, 600 miles southeast of the capital, killing 12 passengers.

title: Ford Has Surgery to Correct Football Injury That Acted Up
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford may be back on the golf course in a few weeks after a knee operation needed because of an old football injury, his doctor says.

title: PITNEY-BOWES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-AFter foreign currency translation losses of $568,000 for the qr and $3,000,000 fora the yr

title: 6 Die in Wisconsin Fire At a Nursing Home
description: A late-night fire at a nursing home here killed six elderly residents while five others were led to safety by two young women staff members.

title: Press Wins Delay Of a Court Hearing
description: A bail reduction hearing for James Koedatich, accused of the murder of a woman in Morris County, was adjourned yesterday until the New Jersey Supreme Court hears arguments on whether to bar the press and public from pretrial hearings of murder suspects who could face the state's recently restored death penalty if convicted.

title: E.P.A. Does Its Own Dumping
description: Rita Lavelle, the Environmental Protection Agency official in charge of hazardous wastes, has been fired by the President after refusing to resign, but her ouster will solve none of the E.P.A.'s problems with Congress.

title: DEFENSE CUT ISSUE: 'GENERALITIES DON'T COUNT'
description: To the Editor:

title: SPEEDY WAFFLE IRONS
description: FOR me nothing evokes childhood like the aroma of sizzling waffles. Whenever I smell them I recall my grandmother standing over a wood stove monitoring a thick black waffle iron that oozed lumpy beige batter. I would devour the waffles smothered with jam, powdered sugar and butter, and too much was never enough.

title: HOUSE UNIT SPARS WITH BANKERS
description: Executives of the three largest American banks were told by House legislators today that Congress may not approve a new infusion of resources into the International Monetary Fund without tighter Government supervision of foreign lending.

title: Profits Scoreboard
LeFlore Allowed To Go to Camp
description: A judge today allowed Ron LeFlore to attend spring training with the Chicago White Sox in Sarasota, Fla., as he awaits trial.

title: SHARING DEFENSE OF THE GULF
description: Now that the United States is about to take up the defense of the Persian Gulf in a big way, it would do well to consider why the British abandoned their single-handed defense of the Gulf in 1971.

title: Cav Trade Approved
description: The National Basketball Association has approved the Cleveland Cavaliers' trading their 7-foot-1-inch center, James Edwards, to Phoenix.

title: OHIO FERRO-ALLOYS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ANHEUSER-BUSCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a nonrecurring gain of $13.3 million from the sale of a plant

title: FOOD NOTES
description: High Produce Prices

title: Careers; Tackling Company Problems
description: WHILE in-house management consultants have not taken over the field, they have made definite strides. In 1971 a small group of corporate officials assigned to solve problems within their companies formed the Association of Internal Management Consultants. Early members included Jack W. Enterline, a vice president of W.R. Grace & Company.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Monday about preparing tax returns misstated the income qualifications for using the new, simplified 1040EZ form. It is intended for single taxpayers with taxable income not exceeding $50,000 and no more than $400 in interest income.

title: Milwaukee Road
description: The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul & Pacific Railroad Company said that a deferred tax settlement proposed by Richard B. Ogilvie, Milwaukee Road trustee, had been approved by United States District Judge Thomas R. McMillen. The program will allow Mr. Ogilvie to use $22 million from the Milwaukee Land Company, a subsidiary, to satisfy certain outstanding state and local tax claims against the carrier at 90 percent of the principal amount.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In our view, everyone who had anything to do with events in Lebanon should have felt apprehension about a massacre in the camps, if armed Phalangist forces were to be moved into them without the I.D.F. exercising concrete and effective supervision and scrutiny of them.'' - Israeli commission's report on Beirut massacre. referring to Israel Defense Forces. (A18:6.)

title: LANCASTER COLONY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in Jan 1983

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Neighborhood Prisons

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LITERATURE

title: I.R.A. AND KEOGH PLANS: BENEFITS NOW AND LATER
description: The most important break for the average taxpayer this year comes in the form of retirement savings -specifically, Individual Retirement Accounts and Keogh plans. Starting with the 1982 returns, every taxpayer can deduct up to $2,000, or 100 percent of his salary, whichever is less, if the money is put into an I.R.A. A married couple filing jointly can set up two accounts, with joint limits of $2,250 if only one spouse works, or $4,000 if each earns at least $2,000.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: PORTABLE electric sanding machines can save the do-it-yourselfer hours of laborious work on finishing and smoothing projects, but only if the right machine is used for the job at hand and if it is handled properly and with a reasonable amount of care. Types of Sanders

title: SOVIET QUIETLY RAISING PRICES ON MANY HOUSEHOLD GOODS
description: Without an announcement, the Soviet Government has raised prices on a broad range of paper, steel, cotton and other products. Food is not affected.

title: Pictures in Playboy Help Broker's Sales
description: Marina Verola, a stockbroker with E.F. Hutton, may have drawn unwelcome attention to the firm with the six pages of nude photographs of her in the March issue of Playboy. But, says Mrs. Merola, who is getting lots of notice in the news media, it hasn't hurt business.

title: PUTTING A LABEL ON YOUR LOCAL TREE
description: TO most city dwellers a tree is a tree, often overlooked except in spring, when its new leaves presage a warmer day. But have you ever wondered whether that tree jutting out of the sidewalk in front of your apartment house might be a Tilia tomentosa, a Quercus phellos or Quercus rubra, a Ginkgo biloba, a Pyrus calleryana, a Platanus acerifolia or even an Aronia arbutifolia brilliantissima?

title: Ports Stock Sold Out
description: The $30 million public offering of 49 percent of the state-owned Associated British Ports Holdings was oversubscribed today by 20 to 30 times, bankers said. The Government offered 19.6 million shares at $1.72 each in its program to allow some private ownership of nationalized industries.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1983
description: International Israel's Cabinet was unable to make a decision on a state commission's recommendations Tuesday that Defense Minister Ariel Sharon and three senior generals leave their posts because of their ''indirect responsibility'' for the massacre of Palestinians by Lebanese Christian militiamen in Beirut. The Cabinet members agreed that two of the generals could defend themselves before the Cabinet today. (Page A1, Column 6.) American Jewish spokesmen backed the report by Israel's special commission on the massacre of Palestinians in Beirut. Most of those interviewed agreed reluctantly that Defense Minister Sharon should resign or be dismissed. (A12:1-2.)

title: Cuomo Will Explore A 1989 World's Fair
description: Governor Cuomo has asked aides to investigate possible state support for a New York City World's Fair in 1989 - the 50th anniversary of the 1939 fair.

title: MACRODYNE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Chief At Petrolane
description: R.J. Munzer, the chief executive of Petrolane Inc. for more than 25 years, said yesterday at the annual meeting in Los Angeles that he had relinquished the post to John C. Wallace, the president of the energy company. Mr. Munzer is 64 years old and Mr. Wallace is 53.

title: TRI-STATE MOTOR TRANSIT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ZONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rebecca Taylor's Appeal
description: Last April 27 Rebecca Taylor, the acting principal of Intermediate School 44 on Manhattan's Upper West Side, was notified by the district superintendent that she had been denied tenure. In plain English, she had been fired. Now a State Supreme Court justice has ordered the Community School Board to appoint her permanent principal of the school.

title: Kaiser Cutback
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said one of three aluminum potlines will close this week at a smelter in Ghana run by its 90 percent owned affiliate, Valco. The shutdown at the West African site resulted from continued low water conditions, Kaiser said, adding that the Volta River Authority, which provides Valco's power, had asked the plant to cut its power consumption.

title: SNOW IS A FRIEND OF DORMANT PLANTS
description: NEVER mind the snarled traffic or frayed tempers of those forced to shovel their way out of their front doors. For the city gardener, it is hard to exaggerate the importance of snow.

title: STAGE: 'ICE,' AT RADIO CITY MUSIC HALL
description: IF you are the sort who is usually cool to the idea of ice shows, let ''Ice,'' the superb new skating show that has moved into Radio City Music Hall, thaw you out.

title: TEAMSTER DEFENDANT ACCUSED OF ROLE IN A MURDER
description: A former gangster turned Government informer testified today that he had been told by a member of the Chicago Mafia that Joseph Lombardo ''pulled the trigger'' in a highly publicized shooting in 1973 of Richard Cain, a corrupt former Cook County sheriff's investigator.

title: License Bids Against RKO
description: The Federal Communications Commission said today that it would begin accepting applications from companies that want to challenge RKO General Inc. for the licenses to 13 radio and television stations.

title: Olympic Medal Minted in Silver
description: At 11 A.M. today, a coin-press operator in the San Francisco Assay Office will carefully pick up a round silver blank with tweezers and put the blank on the press. Donna Pope, director of the United States Mint, then will push a button, and the first United States Olympic silver-dollar coin will have been minted.

title: Envoy to Burundi Nominated
description: President Reagan said today that he would nominate James R. Bullington to be the next Ambassador to Burundi. Mr. Bullington, a career Foreign Service officer, was most recently senior adviser for African affairs with Washington's United Nations delegation.

title: STEWART SANDWICHES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GENERAL GROWTH PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $176,000 on the sale of assets...C-Includi ng a gain of $54,000 on the sale of assets and a gain of $295,000 on the early repayment of a mortgage loan

title: INFERTILITY INCREASES IN YOUNG WOMEN
description: More than three million married American women say they want to have babies but are physically unable to conceive, a Government study reported today.

title: Prudential-Bache Plans A Six-Page Spread
description: Today's advertising first comes from a dynamic duo - Prudential-Bache Securities and its agency, Kenyon & Eckhardt Advertising. Prudential-Bache will be the first Wall Street company to use a six-page cover gatefold magazine ad, and if you don't think that's exciting, you expect too much for a Thursday morning.

title: TREASURY ISSUES RISE IN PRICE
description: After a day of extremely quiet trading, with little investor demand for recently auctioned Treasury securities, prices of Treasury issues increased modestly in the last two hours of trading yesterday.

title: RISE AND FALL OF MINNESOTA PUBLISHER LEAVES THE PAPER'S FUTURE UNCERTAIN
description: Of all the human interest stories The Minneapolis Star and Tribune provides its readers, one of the most poignant, unpredictable and fascinating these days is the tale of the newspaper itself.

title: COACHING FRIENDS TAKE NOSTALGIC TRIP
description: A bout two weeks ago, a few days after the game that became the last one for Walt Michaels as the coach of the Jets, he received a telephone call from an old friend. Jack Donaldson and Michaels formed a defensive coaching staff in 1963, the year the Jets were created after the financial ruin of the old Titan franchise.

title: 'Master Harold' to Close
description: '' 'Master Harold...and the Boys,'' written and directed by Athol Fugard, will end its run at the Lyceum Theater on Broadway on Feb. 26. The show begins its national tour March 8 at the Wilbur Theater in Boston.

title: GENERAL WARY OF PLAN TO CURB MILITARY BUDGET RISE
description: David C. Jones, former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today that a $30 billion reduction in proposed military spending recommended by Representative Joseph P. Addabbo ''would be devastating to the defense of our country.''

title: 27 SPOTS RAIDED AFTER AN INQUIRY ON IMMIGRATION
description: The United States Immigration and Naturalization Service last night raided 27 Manhattan restaurants, nightclubs and massages parlors after obtaining warrants for 24 people on charges of attempting to bribe immigration officers, officials said.

title: CUMMINS ENGINE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a pretax foreign currency translation gain of $5,192,000...C-Including an extraordinary credit of $15.2 million and a pretax foreign currency translation gain of $13,285,000

title: CALIFORNIA FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
FORCED TO KILL 11 DOGS, WARDEN FREES LAST 3
description: After killing 11 dogs in one afternoon, the dogcatcher, Dan Barnshaw, says he ''went off the deep end'' and set three condemned mongrels free, an act for which he faces suspension.

title: HOUSE PANEL BACKS REQUEST TO INCREASE JOBLESS TRUST FUND
description: A House subcommittee today approved the Reagan Administration's request to almost double the trust fund that lends money to states to pay their unemployment benefits.

title: VICTORIA BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition of pooled banks; yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 5 percent stock divd payable this month

title: HARTE-HANKS COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
BONRAY DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pershing 2 Is Test-Fired From Cape Canaveral
description: A Pershing 2 missile, the Army's new nuclear medium-range weapon to be deployed later this year in Western Europe, was test-fired today, the second test in a month.

title: ANDERSON CLAYTON & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a net gain of $10.3 million or 83 cents a shr for the qr and 6 mos from the sale of domestic soybean operations; yr-ago results have been restated

title: DURHAM CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
MCI Planning Telex Discounts
description: The MCI Communications Corporation, applying its cut-rate telephone pricing policies to the international telex market, asked the Federal Communications Commission for permission to offer telex customers a volume discount.

title: ERNEST C. MARRINER
description: Ernest C. Marriner, who served Colby College here for 37 years in a variety of roles, including being the college's first dean of men and the first dean of the faculty, died Tuesday. Dean Marriner, who was 91 years old, suffered a stroke in December.

title: Excerpts from address, page B4.
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill asked the General Assembly today to lower Connecticut's sales tax to 7 percent from 7.5 percent, but to expand the tax to cover a wider range of goods and services.

title: IRISH RACE HORSE HELD FOR RANSOM
description: Gunmen forced their way into the Aga Khan's stud farm in Newbridge, Ireland, during the night Tuesday and kidnapped Shergar, one of the world's top thoroughbred racing horses. They demanded a ransom of $2.7 million.

title: BOWL AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: B-Including a gain of $123,000 from the termination of a lease

title: Technology; Computing At Light Speed
description: ELECTRONIC computers that carry out millions of operations a second serve perfectly well to process texts, calculate payrolls and play Pac-Man. But to solve complex problems, such as weather forecasting, more efficiently, the pace of computing must be accelerated to hundreds of billions of operations a second.

title: ROSPATCH CORP reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
CORRECTION
description: The Going Out Guide last Saturday incorrectly gave the date for ''Mean Mothers,'' a film about women in jazz and blues. It is set for 8 and 10 P.M. on Saturday at the Collective for Living Cinema, 52 White Street, between Broadway and Church Street.

title: DEMOCRATS, LOOKING TO 1984, SET FORTH AN AGENDA
description: Still smarting from the perception that they have failed to produce a coherent alternative to the Reagan economic program in the past two years, Democratic Congressional leaders have begun to frame a legislative agenda to give their party a more distinct image and a rough platform for the 1984 elections.

title: E.P.A. DECLARES AIDE'S DISMISSAL WASN'T POLITICAL
description: Anne M. Gorsuch, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said today that the dismissal of Rita M. Lavelle as assistant administrator was a personnel matter that did not involve political favoritism to polluting companies.

title: DESIGNS BUILT IN A WEEK
description: WORKBENCH asked woodworkers from all over the country to design a piece of furniture they could build in a week. The results are on exhibit at the Workbench Gallery.

title: McDermott Taxes
description: McDermott International Inc. will save $220 million in United States taxes over the next five years as a result of its recently completed foreign incorporation under the laws of Panama, James Cunningham, chairman, said. He said at the annual meeting that taxes on earnings of foreign subsidiaries normally were deferred until those earnings were repatriated as dividends to the United States parent.

title: PLACER DEVELOPMENT LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
COLEMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MEDIQ INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After income from discontinued operations of $30,000 for the latest qr and $7,000 for the earlier period

title: EGYPT DECLINES TO COMMENT ON ISRAELI REPORT
description: Egyptian Government leaders declined to comment officially today on the findings of the Israeli inquiry into the deaths of Palestinian civilians in September, saying that the commission's report was an internal matter.

title: Saving Philadelphia
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: The Philadelphia chapter was very pleased to see your article on the Victorian Society (''Victorian Society Celebrates 25th Year,'' Jan. 20).

title: ATLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $1,006,000 for the qr and $1,938,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including a tax credit of $3.4 million

description: B-After extraordinary tax credits of $998,000 for the qr and $3,568,000 for the6 mos...C-Net income; the 1982 figures have been restated to reflect implementation of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 for foreign currency translation

title: A DOG'S LIFE
description: Last year, the Pekingese Ch. St. Aubrey Dragonora of Elsdon was the talk of the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show. Lee Lee, as she is known, will not defend her title Monday and Tuesday at Madison Square Garden, but she is doing quite nicely as a retired champion.

title: 76ers 106, Hawks 93 PHILADELPHIA (AP) - Julius Erving had 27 points, nine assists and nine rebounds to pace the victory. Moses Malone scored 18 points and got 13 rebounds for the 76ers, who never trailed. Dan Roundfield led Atlanta with 20 points.
description: Coach Kevin Loughery of the Hawks was thrown out of the game for getting his second technical foul with 6:26 remaining. He leads the league among coaches, with 18 technicals.

title: MIDWAY AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LILLY, ELI, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bethlehem Mayor in Cairo
description: Mayor Elias M. Freij of Bethlehem in the occupied West Bank of the Jordan met with President Hosni Mubarak today and said the Palestinians should accept President Reagan's peace plan for the Middle East. The Mayor flew to Amman later for talks with King Hussein of Jordan. President Mubarak has been urging the Palestine Liberation Organization to accept the American plan.

title: Closing at Armco
description: Armco Inc. said it would close one of its three coke batteries, idling an unspecified number of workers at the Middletown Works. The works' two other batteries, both newer, will continue. Armco, the nation's seventh-largest steel producer, lost $345 million last year.

title: BANK'S BID FOR AID STIRS OLD, DEEP RESENTMENT
description: Many of the nation's bankers have been trekking to Washington in recent weeks seeking Government assistance in case some of their third world borrowers become effectively bankrupt. In making their appeals, before Congress and Government regulators, the banks find that they are stirring old and deep resentments.

title: EDITOR ON CAMPUS GAINS A REPRIEVE
description: A judge has ordered Howard University to reinstate the editor of its student newspaper, who says she was expelled for defying demands by the administration that she stop publishing articles about a dismissed employee. The university has denied the editor was expelled because of the articles.

title: ST. JOHN'S DEFEATS GEORGETOWN, 75-69
description: In a game with two fights, one ejection of a player and a round of handshakes at the end, St. John's defeated Georgetown, 75-69, at Capital Centre tonight. The victory moved St. John's into first place in the Big East Conference.

title: MONTREAL TRUST CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After $2,040,000 in losses and provisions for losses on mortgage loans and a gain of $719,000 from the sale of investments and the retirement of long-term debt...C-Includes a gain of $1,300,000 from the sale of investments; yr-ago shr earnings are adjusted to account for shr exchange transactions

title: MOSINEE PAPER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WESTMIN RESOURCES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Vancouver stock exchanges

title: ITA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. FARM SUPPORTS: REWARDS FOR BIGNESS
description: To the Editor:

title: WALESA SUMMONED IN A SEDITION CASE
description: Lech Walesa arrived here today from his home in Gdansk for questioning by the military prosecutor about five Solidarity advisers charged with sedition.

title: RATLIFF DRILLING & EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; yr-ago results were restated to reflect an accounting change

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: BALTIMORE (AL) - Signed Sammy S tewart, pitcher, to three-year contract. A lso signed Ken Dixon, pitcher, and John S helby, outfielder.

title: Holocaust Commission Sees Report 2 Years Off
description: An official of the American Jewish Commission on the Holocaust said yesterday that it might take as long as two years before the completion of a full report on the response and attitudes of Jewish groups in this country to Nazi Germany's attempt to annihilate European Jews.

title: CUOMO OFFERS ADVICE TO NATIONAL PARTY
description: Governor Cuomo, in his first major speech on a national platform, said last night that President Reagan ''has widened the gulf between the haves and the have-lesses and the have-nots.''

title: El Salvador Winning, Mrs. Kirkpatrick Says
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief American delegate to the United Nations, said today that the rebels were nearly beaten in El Salvador.

title: Exxon Cuts Prices On Oil and Gasoline
description: The Exxon Corporation, the nation's largest oil company, said yesterday that it was lowering its wholesale gasoline and home heating oil prices by between half a cent and 1 cent a gallon.

title: CABINET IN ISRAEL UNABLE TO DECIDE ON SHARON'S FATE
description: After a day of intensive back-room bargaining, Israel's Cabinet failed again tonight to agree on whether to carry out a state commission's recommendations that Defense Minister Ariel Sharon and three top generals leave their posts.

title: PANEL NOTES REPORTER REFUSED BID TO TESTIFY
description: The state commission that investigated the Beirut killings noted that it had tried, without success, to collect testimony from a correspondent of The New York Times. In a section reporting attempts to call witnesses from outside Israel, the commission declared:

title: Gerber Products Names President and Chairman
description: The Gerber Products Company named a chairman and president yesterday in changes that it termed part of an orderly succession. Carl G. Smith, the company's 62-year-old chief executive, was named to the additional post of chairman.

title: Devils Beaten By Hawks, 5-4
description: Steve Larmer's goal, one of three thirdperiod Chicago scores, lifted the Black Hawks to their sixth straight triumph tonight, a 5-4 decision over the New Jersey Devils.

title: PANEL STUDYING MX GETS EXTRA MONTH
description: President Reagan today granted the Commission on Strategic Forces another month to reach agreement on a basing system for the MX missile and any other proposals for changes in the United States strategic nuclear deterrent.

title: Decision File; Weather Reports, By the Computer
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has a new project. The agency recently announced plans to ''automatically sense the weather'' at 21 airports and to use computer-generated voices to broadcast the reports to pilots.

title: Khoren I Is Dead at 68; Led Armenian Church
description: Catholicos Khoren I, a leader of the Armenian Orthodox Church, died here today, the Beirut radio said. He was 68 years old.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Armadillo at Center Stage

title: KLEINERT'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
CONCERT: SWEDISH ORCHESTRA
description: THERE was hardly an ungracious moment in the performances of the Royal Swedish Chamber Orchestra in Carnegie Hall on Monday night. But the 18 chamber players, who are directed by Mats Liljefors and play under the patronage of the King of Sweden, nearly turned graciousness into mannerism.

title: THE PAINT JOB: HOW TO MAKE IT AS PAINLESS AS POSSIBLE
description: HAVING your apartment or home painted is like having a tooth pulled - very uncomfortable but worth it once it stops hurting. Despite the chaos and disruption it often causes, painting the rooms, if done properly, can be one of the least expensive and most satisfying decorative changes you can make in your home.

title: DIVERSIFIED ENERGIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Bridge: Some Records in the Game Exist Solely in Speculation
description: A few world records relating to bridge can be determined by studying ''The Official Encyclopedia of Bridge,'' which will appear later this year in its fourth edition. But there are many world records, some admittedly quite trivial, about which one can do no more than speculate.

title: BRIEFING
description: Union Summit Meeting

title: Q&A
description: Q. We have a sizable crawl space with a dirt floor that is so shallow that there is no way to spread polyethylene sheets to block dampness from the soil. Is there a spray-on coating, such as a foam-type insulation without formaldehyde, that we can use instead?

title: AVIATION GROUP INC reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $330,000 for the qr and 6 mos...C-Including a tax credit of $276,000

title: G.M. TO RECALL 240,000 X-MODELS FROM '80 TO FIX BRAKES THAT LOCK
description: The General Motors Corporation announced today that it would recall 240,000 of its 1980 X-model automobiles to modify their reportedly defective braking systems.

title: SHULTZ TO PURSUE TALKS ON MIDEAST DESPITE PREOCCUPATION OF ISRAELIS
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the United States was determined ''to keep working away'' at the various Middle East diplomatic problems despite the internal crisis in Israel spawned by the commission of inquiry's criticism of the Begin Government.

title: Stocks End Lower; Dow Falls by 7.91; Technology Issues Off
description: The stock market ended lower yesterday, after a late recovery erased some of the earlier losses. The Dow Jones industrial average, which was down 13.15 points at 2 P.M., closed off 7.91 points, to 1,067.42. Analysts said the late recovery resulted mostly from bargain hunting following the loss of 11.77 points in the key average on Tuesday.

title: DISMISSED E.P.A. AIDE: RITA MARIE LAVELLE
description: To her former colleagues in business and government in California, the difficulties Rita M. Lavelle has experienced in the last week are puzzling. To them she was a hard worker and a team player, not the kind of a person likely to be dismissed suddenly by President Reagan.

title: CUOMO CITES ERROR ON JOBLESS AID
description: Governor Cuomo said today that the refusal of an Assistant Secretary of Labor to consider Trade Adjustment Assistance benefits for unemployed steelworkers in western New York was based on a misunderstanding of available benefits in New York State.

title: SLATER STEEL INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a $612,000 writeoff of equity of idle equipment at Interprovincial steel & Pipe Corp...C-Net income; the company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange

title: PUBLIC AWARENESS OF ASBESTOS HAZARD CREATING NEW JOBS
description: When David Spinazzolo started appearing in office buildings and at other public sites in his disposable suit and rubber respirator, he was sometimes mistaken for a termite inspector.

title: An Assistant Achieves a Goal
description: When Joe Walton is named the Jets' ninth head coach today, he will be taking over a job that only a few weeks ago he was certain belonged to somebody else.

description: Yr-ago results reflect a pooling of interests acquisition

title: Installment Loans Rise by $2.19 Billion
description: Americans took on $2.19 billion more in new installment debt than they paid off in December, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. It marked the second consecutive strong credit-spending month, both paced by auto loans.

title: 2 Muggers Pick on Couple And Make a Chief Mistake
description: A man was walking with his wife on a Flushing, Queens, street last night when two men started to mug him. But the muggers' intended victim was far from an easy mark.

description: * Atlantic Group, Norfolk, Va., has named B. Ralph Sylvia executive vice president in charge of operations.

title: FOR A VICTORIAN SPIRIT, A SERENDIPITOUS COLLECTION
description: LONDON BERNARD NEVILL has been collecting since he was a child, and he has apparently never parted with anything. At first glance, the interior of his Chelsea house looks like one overwhelming hodgepodge. But despite appearances he is a discriminating collector and has never bought anything haphazardly.

ORLOV'S CRIME
description: The letter is not out of Kafka's imagination, or Arthur Koestler's. It was written in Moscow on Jan. 8, 1983. It comes from Orlov's wife. ''Yura's situation is terrible,'' it begins. ''Yura is completely deprived of correspondence rights. The last two letters from him were dated Oct. 18.

Policeman Faces Bank Theft Charge
description: An East Orange police officer was charged today with stealing nearly $10,000 in cash from a Carlstadt bank last week by posing as a courier for a payroll company that is said to hire mostly off-duty or former police officers.

title: 99 High-Rises Get Fire Reinspections
description: Fire Commissioner Joseph E. Spinatto said yesterday that a ''visual reinspection'' of 99 high-rise apartment buildings in Manhattan by uniformed members of the Fire Department had found ''no major hazards.''

title: Dissident Czech Playwright Moved From Jail to Hospital
description: Vaclav Havel, the dissident Czechoslovak playwright, has been moved from jail to a civilian hospital in Prague because he is seriously ill with pneumonia, emigre sources said today.

title: Savings Groups Plan to Merge
description: Two associations representing savings and loans and mutual savings banks announced a tentative agreement today to combine.

title: SCIENTIFIC SOFTWARE CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
CARLISLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CONCERT: STRING QUARTET
description: IF we associate Dvorak as often with America as with his native Czecheslovakia, it is only partly because he visited these shores in the 1890's. Much of his music actually captured a spirit associated with America by Europeans - a spirit of optimism, practicality and freedom from the freight of European culture.

title: GENERAL TESTIFIES AT COURT-MARTIAL
description: Israel's military commander, Lieut. Gen. Rafael Eytan, appeared as a witness in a court-martial here today and defended orders he gave last spring for strong-handed treatment of Palestinian Arabs in the occupied West Bank.

Harvester Finishes Debt Exchange
description: The International Harvester Company said it had successfully completed its debenture exchange offer, with $136 million of existing debentures tendered and accepted out of $140 million authorized.

title: NON-COMMUNIST CAMBODIANS NEED OUR HELP
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: After three days of treatment for a superficial infection of his hands, Bjorn Borg was released from Rhode Island Hospital in Providence. ... The report from Holy Cross Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said that Manager Mike Ferraro of the Cleveland Indians was in satisfactory condition after three hours of surgery to remove his left kidney. ... Carlos Padilla of the Philippines will be the referee in tomorrow night's middleweight title bout between Marvelous Marvin Hagler and Tony Sibson of England. Also scoring the bout will be Tony Perez of New York and Marcelo Bertini of Italy. ... Two metropolitan area players, Melissa Brown of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Jennifer Fuchs of Dix Hills, L.I., were named No.1 in their age groups by the United States Tennis Association, Miss Brown in the girls' 14's and Miss Fuchs in the 16's. ... Nine years after he left the Cincinnati Bengals, the team's former defensive tackle, Mike Reid, is back on the top of the pile. He wrote the lyrics to the No.1 country music song, ''Inside,'' sung by Ronnie Milsap.

title: Little Change In Eurobonds
description: Fixed-interest dollar bonds in the secondary market ended slightly firmer to unchanged today, but dealers said trading remained extremely quiet.

title: Toyota Adds U.S. Parts
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said today that its United States subsidiary, Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. Inc., had bought $32 million worth of American-made parts for new cars and $116 million worth of United States-made replacement parts in 1982. Toyota said the United States subsidiary's latest move to increase use of American-made parts was an agreement to buy Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company replacement parts for Toyota cars in the United States. The United States Congress is considering legislation that would compel non-United States car makers to use a certain percentage of United States-made parts in their cars sold in the United States.

title: Macro Communications Adding Financial World
description: A group of investors headed by Mark J. Meagher, former president of both Penthouse International and the Washington Post Company, has reached an agreement with Macro Communications to purchase Financial World magazine, Robert I. Weingarten, chairman of Macro, announced yesterday.

title: GUARANTEE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
News Analysis

title: BUSH, IN LONDON, CHALLENGED BY NUCLEAR FOE
description: Vice President Bush reached the final stop today in his tour of Western Europe to defend American nuclear arms policy, and he was confronted by a leader of Britain's antinuclear movement.

title: Advertising; Le Jardin's Romance Fragrance
description: ''ROMANCE is back in style,'' said Linda J. Wachner, who is betting a bundle on that judgment. As president and chief operating officer of Norton Simon's Max Factor & Company, she is putting several millions of dollars behind a new fragrance called Le Jardin de Max Factor. Flowery in scent, packaging and advertising, it will get its first network TV support on Sunday, Feb. 27, the start of a five-week, $2.7 million splurge, mostly in prime time.

title: Ellenberger Hired
description: When the co-owners of the Las Vegas Silvers, were unable to agree on how to fund the team and some financial obligations were not met, the Continental Basketball Association stepped in, expelling the owners and transferring the franchise to Albuquerque, N.M. Enter as head coach Norm Ellenberger, the former head coach at the University of New Mexico, who was dismissed at the start of the 1979-80 season in the midst of recruiting and financial irregularities. Ellenberger was convicted in 1980 on 21 of 22 counts of fraud and making false public vouchers.

title: SUPPLIER OF CARS DROPS ITS EFFORT AGAINST M.T.A.
description: The Budd Company, the only United States manufacturer of subway cars, yesterday dropped its six-month effort to penalize the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for its purchase of 825 subway cars from Canada.

title: MAINE PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Figgie Is Still Waiting For Signs of a Recovery
description: Although many economists are saying that a recovery is under way, Harry E. Figgie Jr., chairman and chief executive of Figgie International, does not see one yet in the industrial and consumer sections of his $700 million conglomerate.

title: U.N. Mediator Reports Gains in Afghan Talks
description: A United Nations mediator seeking to negotiate the departure of Soviet troops from Afghanistan said today that he had ''made progress'' in his latest round of talks.

title: MOORE MCCORMACK RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Large I.M.F.  Infusion Urged
description: Finance ministers of developing countries called today for a major infusion of money and credits to bolster their economies and help them repay mounting debts.

title: ACID PITS DUMP SITE LONG IN DISPUTE
description: The Stringfellow Acid Pits, a toxic waste site that has drawn the attention of Federal and state officials and environmental groups, have been a source of contention for more than a decade.

title: Japan's Opposition Urges Tanaka's Ouster as M.P.
description: In a rare display of unity, Japan's opposition parties demanded today that former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka resign from Parliament because of his indictment six years ago in the $2 million Lockheed bribery case.

title: German Bankruptcies
description: West German corporate bankruptcies soared to a postwar record of 11,916 last year, up 40.3 percent from 1981, the Government reported today.

title: RLI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes securities gains of $60,575 for the qr and $77,220 for the yr...C-AFter a securities loss of $40,960 for the qr and a securities gain of $21,465 forthe yr

title: PRODUCT LIABILITY BILL OPPOSED
description: The American Bar Association voted today to oppose Federal legislation on product liability that would set up uniform standards for awarding damages to those injured by unsafe or defective products. It did, however, agree to support more limited Federal legislation to control the thousands of asbestos-related lawsuits that have flooded the courts in recent years.

title: A Takeover Is Rumored Of Psychology Today
description: What would you think of Psychology Today magazine being operated by the American Psychological Association? Well, there is an interesting rumor going about to the effect that the Council of Representatives of that national organization recently voted to take over the 15-year-old magazine.

title: Prosecutor Upheld On Hair Sampling
description: The Appellate Division of New Jersey Superior Court, the state's second-highest court, yesterday upheld an application by District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan that would compel two women who lived with Donald Nash to produce hair and blood samples and finger and palm prints.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Tough Cookie

title: 3 Killed in Assam Protest
description: Three people died today from wounds received when the police opened fire on violent crowds Tuesday in pre-election violence in India's northeastern Assam state, the news agency Press Trust of India reported.

title: ELECTRONIC MODULES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
ABC WINS TWO DUPONT JOURNALISM AWARDS
description: Two ABC News programs - a special on genetic engineering called ''Closeup: The Gene Merchants'' and ''Viewpoint,'' the series with Ted Koppel as anchor - were among top prize winners in the annual Alfred I. duPont-Columbia University Awards for Broadcast Journalism presented at Columbia last night.

title: COLUMBIA GAS SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to meet requirements of a new F.A.S.B. Statement concerning accounting for earnings related to certain intercompany sales
