title: CONTINUUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GRETZKY'S FOUR-GOAL RAMPAGE
description: The Minnesota line of Dino Ciccarelli at right wing, Neil Broten at center and Tom McCarthy at left wing found out in Tuesday night's National Hockey League All-Star Game how difficult it is to upstage Wayne Gretzky.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Company News report in Business Day last Thursday incorrectly reported the dates for a proposed common stock split by the Seagram Company. The shares would be distributed March 28, to shareholders of record March 18.

title: ALFRED WALLENSTEIN, THE CONDUCTOR, DIES AT 84
description: Alfred Wallenstein, the conductor, cellist, classical music pioneer on radio and former music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, died Tuesday while working at his desk in his Manhattan apartment. He was 84 years old.

title: VW - BRAZIL GETS ORDER FROM IRAQ
description: Volkswagen do Brasil, the Brazilian unit of the West German auto maker, has signed a contract to supply Iraq with 50,000 automobiles and spare parts worth the equivalent of $300 million, the parent company announced today.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO BAR DEAL WITH ISRAEL
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has rejected a proposed agreement with Israel under which Israeli forces would have shared military information they gained during the Lebanon conflict, Administration officials said today.

title: UPPER PENINSULA POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ASSAULTS AGAINST BLACKS IN ELMONT UNDER INQUIRY
description: The Nassau County police are increasing patrols and stopping unfamiliar cars in a predominantly black neighborhood here after receiving reports of what they described as a half-dozen racially motivated assaults on blacks in the last month.

title: WALTON WILL TAKE OVER
description: Walt Michaels, who survived when his club was a loser, retired as coach of the Jets today, only 17 days after they had come one victory short of going to the Super Bowl.

title: COMMERCE OFFICES' ELEGANT TOUCH
description: In his eight years as Secretary of Commerce, Herbert Hoover noted in his memoirs, his office was in ''a corner room of a rental apartment building on 19th Street, especially superheated for summer.''

title: VISUAL ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes tax credits of $191,000 for the latest 9 mos and $460,000 for the yr-ago 9 mos

title: Heat Complaints Decline in City
description: The number of New York City residents complaining to the Department of Housing Preservation and Development that their landlord did not provide enough heat fell 30 percent last quarter compared with the same period a year earlier, the Department has announced.

title: VOPLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Gulf Drilling Plan
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation said it had obtained permits needed to drill a well on one of the Beaufort Sea tracts in which it recently acquired a joint interest from Tenneco Inc. Gulf said that the well would be drilled in the Cross Island area, 17 miles northeast of Prudhoe Bay. Its $35 million cost will be shared by the two companies.

title: GALANOS: GLAMOUR OF BYGONE HOLLYWOOD
description: JAMES GALANOS came out of the West yesterday with a high-style collection of clothes for spring and summer that he described as ''slim, slick and contemporary.'' He was quite right, but after 30 years as the head of his own house, making the most expensive readyto-wear in this country, he should know what he is about.

title: OPERETTA: FRIML'S 'FIREFLY'
description: RUDOLF FRIML'S 1912 operetta, ''The Firefly,'' which was presented in a concert version on Sunday evening at Town Hall by the New Amsterdam Theater Company, is a transitional work in which the European comic-opera tradition of plots dealing with Ruritanian royalty and heroes or heroines in disguise was changing to what would become a staple of American musical comedy - high, or somewhat high, society and anybody in disguise.

title: RICHARDSON HELPS NETS WIN
description: In his second game as a member of the New Jersey Nets, Michael Ray Richardson made an impressive homecourt debut at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight and his team scored an impressive 105-90 victory over the Indiana Pacers.

title: Outshooting Stars
description: Richard Gelb was no newcomer to the Bing Crosby Pro-Am golf tournament. In fact, he and his pro partner, Gibby Gilbert, had won the event in 1978.

title: U.S. WAR MATERIAL STARS IN HONDURAS
description: By last weekend, the hypothetical invading legions of ''Corinth'' had been duly repulsed, ending joint maneuvers near the Nicaraguan border involving 4,000 Honduran troops and hundreds of United States soldiers, sailors and airmen.

title: FOOD CHAINS' FRIEND IN THE BATTLE OVER BEER DISTRIBUTION
description: To the Editor:

title: RECITAL: UNUSUAL PROGRAM
description: THE Chamber Music Society's concert at Alice Tully Hall on Monday night offered another of those programs that managed to be highly unusual without ever seeming odd. There were two novelties - a String Trio in C by Dohnanyi and Glazunov's String Quintet in A -to go with the last of Beethoven's 10 Sonatas for Piano and Violin (Op. 96).

description: The Atari Inc. unit of Warner Communications introduced a keyboard that will convert the popular 2600 video game player into a small home computer.

description: The yr-ago results are restated to reflect more appropriately the yr-end adjustments for worker's compensation insurance and capitalized interest

title: Airbus Delivery Change
description: First deliveries of the proposed 150-seat A320 Airbus will not take place until 1988, two years later than first planned, Bernard Lathiere, Airbus Industrie chairman, said today. He told a press conference this was a result of the choice of engine, which is now settled as the CFM-56, developed by the General Electric Company and the French concern Snecma. Air France has placed firm orders for 25 A320's, but Roy Watts, British Airways deputy chairman, said yesterday that the plane would come into service too late for his company's requirements.

title: REXON BUSINESS MACHINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: B-Includes tax credits of $76,000 for the latest qr and $131,000 for the yr-agoqr

title: THE IRISH PARADE TO BACK I.R.A., MARSHALL ASSERTS
description: The newly elected grand marshal of New York City's annual St. Patrick's Day Parade on March 17, an outspoken supporter of the Irish Republican Army, said yesterday amid a furor over his selection that the event would demonstrate support for the I.R.A.

title: ISRAEL AFTER SHARON
description: No crystal ball was needed, months ago, to see that Ariel Sharon would have to bear personal responsibility for the blunder that permitted Lebanese militiamen, their leadership murdered, to wreak vengeance on the Palestinian camps.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Hoist and Derrick Co. shareholder Sol Goldman, a real estate investor, said that he had increased his stake to 6.5 percent of the common stock outstanding and that he would solicit proxies for his nomination as a director.

BRANDT PANEL URGES MEASURES TO AVERT CRASH
description: An international commission led by Willy Brandt, former Chancellor of West Germany, today called upon world governments to take emergency measures in ''a new spirit of solidarity'' to avert an economic collapse that it said could bring global political anarchy.

title: THE SINGING TELEGRAM AT 50
description: When the Postal Telegraph-Cable Company delivered what it claimed was the world's first singing telegram on Feb. 10, 1933, it may have been 50 years or so ahead of its time. The idea was good, but not good enough to save its telegraph business, and the company soon merged with Western Union.

title: KROGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SIMPSON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
China's Bond Complaint
description: China criticized the Reagan Administration today because of a United States District Court ruling that Peking owes $41.3 million to nine Americans for defaulting on railway bonds issued by the imperial Chinese regime in 1911. China argued that it has immunity from foreign courts and that it is not obligated to repay debts of previous governments.

title: Operating Net At Aetna Rises
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company said today that operating earnings rose 3.4 percent in the fourth quarter, as Federal regulators ordered a halt to an accounting practice that had substantially improved results.

title: DREYER'S GRAND ICE CREAM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
HERS
description: ''GIRLS won't do!'' the maitre d'hotel stammered. ''Won't do what?'' my friend the tax lawyer asked. ''I think he means you can't eat here,'' her client, a man, translated, and led her from the grill room of a Wall Street eating club.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: WHICH ISRAEL?
description: The report of the judicial commission on the Beirut massacre puts to Israelis a question far more profound than the political future of Menachem Begin or Ariel Sharon. It asks them to consider what kind of country Israel is going to be: whether it will remain a democracy devoted to law and humanity or will increasingly be swayed by the appeal of authority and military triumphalism.

title: Big Loss Reported By Revere; Lilly Up
description: Revere Copper and Brass Inc. yesterday reported a loss of $115.9 million for the fourth quarter, compared with a deficit of $1.5 million in the period a year earlier. The latest results include the assignment of $99.8 million to reserves.

title: UDALL SAYS HE WILL NOT SEEK PRESIDENTIAL NOMINATION IN 1984
description: Representative Morris K. Udall of Arizona, remarking that he did not want to be a ''spoiler'' who split the progressive vote, said today that he would not seek the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1984.

title: Bristol Brass Sale
description: A crucial $1.5 million loan has been secured for the potential buyers of the Bristol Brass mill, which has been shut down since last Aug. 31. The loan, which was guaranteed by the Connecticut Development Authority for Eastern Rolling Mills of the Bronx, may clear the way for the plant to be reopened by Feb. 21. The 131-year-old mill applied for bankruptcy after several attempts to keep the business going failed, leaving about 125 employees jobless.

THE CITY;
description: A total of $379,105.62 believed to have been stolen from the Sentry Armored Car Courier Company in the Bronx has been recovered, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday.

title: Bank of California
description: The Bank of California announced the sale of three branch offices in the San Bernardino area to American National Bank for a price it did not disclose. In September, American National purchased four branches in the Modesto area. Bank of California said the sale was consistent with its strategy of shifting from local retail banking to serving professional and business customers.

description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, sold $70.3 million of 12 1/2 percent mortgage participation certificates yesterday at an average price of 99 6/32 to yield 12.38 percent. The yield was up slightly from about 12.3 percent a week earlier.

title: Two From Colorado Are Freed by Guatemala
description: A man and a woman from Colorado who were jailed for 28 days in Guatemala on charges of participating in guerrilla attacks were released Tuesday by court order and returned to the United States today

Arguello Plans to Retire
description: Alexis Arguello, who has already won titles in three weight divisions and still hopes to be the first fighter to win in four categories, says he will retire from boxing at the end of the year whether he has attained his goal or not. ''This year will be it - after '83, no more,'' the 30-year-old Arguello told an interviewer in Scottsdale, Ariz., where he is training for a nontitle bout next month.

MENTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

ITEMIZING DEDUCTIONS: GOOD RECORDS ARE VITAL
description: Anyone whose income tax deductions exceed $2,300 - or $3,400 for married couples filing jointly - can save money by itemizing. Because deductions for medical expenses and casualty losses are being tightened up considerably in the 1983 tax year, this is a better time for itemizers than next year will be.

title: TORONTO SUN reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 22
description: Shr earnings for the latest period reflect the issue of 2,045,000 common shrs to Maclean Hunter Ltd

title: The Editorial Notebook; Who Will Pick Up Maureen and Louie?
description: One very cold night last week a blind woman with a Seeing Eye dog got on the Ninth Avenue bus. With the dog curled at her feet, the woman faced the other passengers and asked if anyone was getting off at 12th Street. Could such a person put her in a cab? A young man promised to help. ''She's so brave,'' said the woman at my right. ''We can see, and we walk around frightened, while she goes out like that, with just the dog. It's wonderful.''

title: DURIRON COR reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GHANAIANS WELCOME BACK SONS SEDUCED BY LAGOS
description: For years, the Chief of this poor dusty village has been telling the people they will not improve their lives by moving to a big town like Accra, or another country, like Nigeria.

title: YALE TURNS ON CHARM TO RECRUIT TOP STUDENTS
description: Betty Chen chatted with the concert master of the Yale Symphony. Andrew Siderowf sat in on a Russian history class. Steve Kantrowitz talked baseball with the president of the university.

OIL'S PRICE: THE $34 QUESTION
description: The price of oil, which has been dropping irregularly in world markets since early 1981, is headed still lower in the months ahead, many economists say.

EXHIBITION OF WOOD TURNINGS TO OPEN
description: THE American Craft Museum II, the eight-month-old branch of the American Craft Museum at International Paper Plaza, is a modern, airy space that, beginning tomorrow, will feature an exhibition of ''The Art of Wood Turning: Historical and Contemporary Perspectives.''

AMERICA'S INTEREST IN LEBANON
description: For the moment, stalled negotiations, trivial quarrels with Israeli soldiers and, now, furor over the report of the Israeli inquiry into the Beirut massacres, distracts the United States from thinking about its long-term interests in Lebanon. Do we want a special relationship with Beirut? How can it be maintained? In fact, we stand to gain a very useful ally at relatively little cost.

title: People
description: * Gaston Braun and Elin Jacobson have been elected senior vice presidents of N.W. Ayer Inc.

title: TV: 'FIRED,' ON OUSTED EXECUTIVES
description: FOR the first time since the Depression, business executives are being laid off in significant numbers - tens of thousands each year, says Eric Sevareid, the host of public television's ''Enterprise'' series - and forced to look for new jobs. How they look, or at least how they should look, is the subject of ''Fired,'' the ''Enterprise'' chapter on Channel 13 at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: Accusations Exchanged At East-West Talks
description: Delegates from the Soviet bloc and the West failed to agree today on ways of speeding up the work of a 35-nation conference on detente, delegates said.

title: British Airways' Orders
description: Roy Watts, deputy chairman of British Airways, said today that the state-owned B.A. needs about twenty 150-seat aircraft to replace its remaining Tridents and the most likely contenders were the Boeing Company's 737-200 or 737-300, or the McDonnell Douglas Corporation's DC-9-82. He added that both McDonnell Douglas and Boeing had been asked for a financial package. Mr. Watts said no decision would be made before the last three months of 1983 at the earliest. He added that B.A. will need around 10 more aircraft between 1986 and 1989.

title: An Appraisal
description: Until last week, the struggle over the future of Lever House, the building on Park Avenue between 53d and 54th Streets that was declared an official city landmark last November, has been conducted in something of a vacuum. It was a debate that centered entirely on the merits of the 31-year-old glass tower, and not on the question of what would replace it if it were to be demolished.

title: WAXMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JETS' PERSONNEL SURPRISED AND CURIOUS
description: The Jets who played and coached under Walt Michaels said yesterday that his decision to retire left them shocked, saddened and curious to know more.

title: AMAX INC. POSTS LOSS IN QUARTER
description: Amax Inc., one of the leading metals producers, yesterday announced a loss of $244.5 million in the fourth quarter, compared with net earnings of $14.2 million, or 13 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales fell almost 21 percent, to $540 million, from $681 million.

title: COMPUTER TUTOR IN A JUNIOR HIGH PILOT PROGRM
description: SABRINA MASON carefully studied the video screen displaying a computer program she was working on. ''Some people think computers will take over the world,'' said the eighth grader. ''But I don't think they will, because human beings have to tell them what to do step by step. A computer is dumb - a computer's an 'it.' ''

title: Seven More Dioxin Sites Are Found in Missouri
description: Dioxin has been found at seven more sites near St. Louis, bringing to 22 the number of places in Missouri where the toxic chemical waste has been found.

title: 9th Kenyan Sentenced to Die
description: A court-martial sentenced an air force corporal to death for treason today. He was the ninth man to receive the sentence on charges arising out of last August's attempt to overthrow the Government. More than 900 junior airmen have been sentenced to jail terms of up to 25 years on mutiny charges.

title: TUCKER DRILLING CO reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
Decontrol Gas, Unburden the Poor
description: Just four years ago, Congress thought it had finally settled the tortuous issue of natural gas regulation. Controls were to be relaxed as an incentive to production, yet consumers were to be protected against rapid price increases. But something slipped 'twixt well and burner.

title: THE STEPS TO TAKE WHEN COMPLAINTS BECOME NECESSARY
description: THOSE who yearn for special painting effects should be aware that these can only be done by master artisans. They must also realize that these finishes will cost at least three times the price of ordinary painting and take at least three times as long to do. Marbleizing and wood graining are painted finishes that imitate another material. Strie is a process that gives a three-dimensional striped look using glazes. Glazing is a shiny finish that involves painting a darker color over a lighter one to give a translucent effect. Lacquering is a high-gloss finish achieved by spraying the surface with many coats of colored lacquer, each layer painstakingly rubbed smooth between coats.

title: 81 Jews Left Soviet in Month
description: The Soviet Union allowed 81 Jews to emigrate in January, the lowest monthly total since emigration began in 1971, the Intergovernmental Committee for Migration said today. On their arrival in Vienna, the committee said, 20 were processed to go on to Israel, and the others were transferred to Italy for resettlement elsewhere.

title: NEW YORK RETAILERS SHOW HIGHER SALES
description: New York City's major department stores ended their generally poor fiscal year last month with a flourish, reporting an average sales increase in January of 11.6 percent over a year earlier, according to a spot-check conducted this week. It was the best year-to-year gain for any month since June 1981, when the retailers reported an average increase of 11.7 percent from a year earlier.

title: MCGRAW-EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1982 net includes gain from extinguishment of debt of $400,000 in the qr and $6.7 million for the yr

title: ALASKA OIL EXPORT IDEA IS REVIVED
description: The Reagan Administration has revived a proposal to lift a ban on exports of American crude oil so that oil from Alaska's North Slope could be shipped to Japan, according to sources on Capitol Hill and within the Administration.

title: WASTE MANAGEMENT INC reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
BARTON VALVE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CANCER VICTIMS SEEK CURE ON TRIPS TO ATHENS
description: The telephones seldom stop ringing at the travel agency that is tucked into a small shopping center in this agricultural city in central California. The calls are from people around the country who are dying of cancer and hope to save themselves by taking a trip to Greece.

title: Installation of a New Engine On Shuttle Delayed by a Leak
description: The installation of the space shuttle Challenger's new engine was delayed today when workers at the space center detected a leak, possibly in a shuttle heat exchanger, officials said.

title: Market Place; Pros and Cons Of O-T-C Data
description: ADHERING to the mandate of Congress and the blessing of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the National Association of Securities Dealers has broadly expanded its Nasdaq national market system. The move adds 100 stocks to the 84 already trading in the advanced system.

title: First Charter Bid Lifted by Financial
description: The Financial Corporation of America said it had sweetened its bid to acquire the First Charter Financial Corporation by offering all shareholders stock worth $27 cash for each share.

title: UDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
REAGAN'S WISH IS NO MINIMUM WAGE FOR YOUTHS
description: President Reagan, fondly recalling his own first job as a teen-ager, said today that ''the right thing to do'' for unskilled young people would be to eliminate the Federal requirements that they be paid the minimum wage.

title: NORTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVICE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CONCERT: PETER SERKIN WITH GUARNERI QUARTET
description: MOST concert pianists pay lip service to chamber music, often going on at great length about how they wish they had time for it, and some actually play it on occasion with varying degrees of success. Very few, however, move in and out of it freely and comfortably and, most important of all, enrich it with their virtuosity, understanding and genuine affection.

description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $4,437,000 for the qr and an extraordinary gain of $3,470,000 for the yr...C-Includes extraordinary gains of $10,567,000 forthe qr and $12,360,000 for the yr; the yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the acquisition in Nov 1982 of E.F. title: Insurance In a Bank
description: Borrowing a page from airline terminals, a few banks owned by the Banc One Corporation in Columbus, Ohio, will experiment with insurance desks.

title: Reginald N. Webster, Owner And Breeder of Race Horses
description: Reginald N. Webster, former president of the Standard-Thomson Corporation of Waltham, Mass., who for many years owned and bred thoroughbred race horses, died of heart failure Tuesday at Good Samaritan Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla. He resided in Palm Beach and was 85 years old.

title: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1983; International
description: A plan to end the ban on exports of U.S. oil has been revived with the aim of shipping Alaskan oil to Japan, according to officials. The ban was imposed in 1976 after oil prices rose sharply. Lifting it would help reduce the trade deficit with Japan and make distribution of Alaskan oil more efficient, the officials said. (Page D1.)

title: Trade Deficit For Japan
description: Japan today reported a $1.6 billion trade deficit for January, narrowed from $1.9 billion a year earlier.

title: Rail Line's Delays To Be Reduced
description: The Federal Railroad Administration said yesterday that delays of commuter trains on the New Haven Line of Metro-North were expected to be reduced by five to eight minutes as a result of new procedures for inspecting wheels.

title: HOW ETHNIC CHILDHOODS SHAPED 'BRIDGE' ACTORS
description: Tony Lo Bianco's desire for authentic detail led him to insist on selecting the pattern of linoleum used in the set; he modeled it after the pattern in his boyhood home. Rose Gregorio chose her wardrobe and even her shoes based on her recollections of relatives she knew when she was growing up.

title: FAIR LANES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $10,000 for the qr and income of $492,000 for the 6 mos from discontinued operations...C-After a loss of $40,000 for the qr and income of $218,000 for the 6 mos from discontinued operations

title: JERSEY SENATE PASSES PACKAGE FOR TRAINING IN 'HIGH TECHNOLOGY'
description: The New Jersey Senate today passed a package of bills designed to promote ''high technology'' education and create jobs. It also approved three bills aimed at curbing the scalping of tickets for entertainment and sports events.

title: Chrysler Lessens Its Need for Loans
description: With the Chrysler Corporation starting to pay off $1.2 billion in guaranteed loans this year, the Treasury Department's loan guarantee program will need less money in 1983 and 1984, a Government official said.

title: Another Setback
description: Fred Rensing was never one to hang back. When it came to football, he played hard, hard enough to win a football scholarship to Indiana State.

title: U.S. JEWISH GROUPS PRAISE ISRAELIS FOR 'MORAL DECENCY'
description: The Israeli commission's report on the Beirut killings drew approving comments from American Jewish spokesmen yesterday along with expressions of relief that the findings were detailed and made public immediately.

title: AGENCY TO PURSUE PLAN ON GAS-PRICE CONTROL
description: President Reagan today instructed the Energy Department to pursue a plan that would end price controls on natural gas but would also try to limit price increases for consumers.

title: F.B.I. DELAYS PLAN TO SHARE ITS COMPUTER WITH SECRET SERVICE
description: The Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation ordered a two-month delay today in an arrangement under which the Secret Service would use the bureau's big computer to keep track of people it considered dangerous to those protected by the service.

title: DANCE: PREMIERE BY HARLEM TROUPE
description: ALL three works that the Charlie Vernon Performance Group presented Friday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church had introspective spoken texts, as well as choreography, by Mr. Vernon. The Chicago company's dancing was often strenuous, yet the combination of movement with verbal ruminations helped make physicality symbolize mental activity.

description: The Boeing Company moved yesterday to close the last significant gap in its family of jet airliners by offering a stretched, 254-passenger version of its new twin-jet plane, the 767.

title: G.A.O. Faults Project For Antisatellite Arms
description: Congressional investigators have urged the Pentagon to take a new look at its attempt to develop small space fighters that could destroy enemy satellites, saying the program was more complex than expected and might cost ''tens of billions of dollars.''

title: CHINA'S POLICY ON SIZE OF FAMILIES IS EXTENDED TO INCLUDE MINORITIES
description: China has begun closing a conspicuous loophole in its nationwide birth-control program by restricting the number of children that some of its minorities may have.

title: Japan Unit Cuts Saudi Oil
description: Japan's largest seller of oil products, the Nippon Oil Company, said today that it had decided to cut its purchases of Saudi Arabian crude oil about 30 percent.

title: UNIFLITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Pension Rescue Plan Faulted
description: A national commission's recommendations for restoring financial health to the Social Security System might not keep the system solvent through the decade, a spokesman for a private pension group warned today.

title: SANDINISTS PICK A LOYALIST AS U.S. ENVOY
description: Nicaragua has chosen a longtime member of the Sandinist movement as its next Ambassador to the United States, officials here said today. The previous envoy resigned in December to protest what he said were radical policies of the Government.

description: Following are highlights of Gov. William A. O'Neill's proposed $3.58 billion budget for the 1984 fiscal year: Spending Increases - $25 million for highway repairs and improvements, $31 million in bonds to promote economic development, $49 million in Medicaid, $55 million in grants to municipalities, $13 million in aid to education and money for 412 new prison beds and 48 new state troopers.

title: Filings by Mesta And Cyclotron
description: The Mesta Machine Company of Pittsburgh said it had filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The company, which reported an $18.1 million loss for the first nine months of 1982, said bank lenders had forced the move by declaring its $20 million of secured debt immediately due and by beginning actions to foreclose on assets.

description: Business leaders in Presque Isle, Me., won state approval for a $5.5 million loan guarantee for a proposed $94 million plant in Auburn to supply New England with alcohol to be added to gasoline to increase octane ratings.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Philadelphia 76ers vs. Bulls at Chicago. The Bulls have been beaten by a total of 74 points in their three meetings with the 76ers this season, losing by scores of 145-108, 126-106 and 116-99. (Television - USA 8 P.M.) College: Holy Cross vs. Manhattan and Fordham vs. Notre Dame at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7 P.M. and 9 P.M. (Television - MSG Cable, 7 P.M. live and 1 A.M. tape. Radio - WFUV-FM, 90.7; 9 P.M.). Virginia at North Carolina. The Tar Heels and Cavaliers are one, two in the United Press International poll and one, three in The Associated Press poll, sandwiched around Nevada-Las Vegas. (Television - ESPN, 9 P.M.). St. Bonaventure at Rutgers, Wagner at St. Francis, Manhattanville at City College, Rider at Marist, Rutgers-Newark at St. Thomas Aquinas, Keene State at Southern Connecticut, all at 8 P.M. Women: Monmouth at Rhode Island, 7:30 P.M., Wagner at Adelphi, 8 P.M. Hockey Rangers vs. Minnesota North Stars, at Bloomington, Minn. The Rangers are making the fourth stop of their trip, having gone 0-1-2 over the first three and posting a 1-8-4 record in their last 13 games. They lost the first two meetings with the North Stars this season, 4-2 and 8-5. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M.) Islanders vs. Washington Capitals, at Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L.I., 8:05 P.M. With an 11-6-9 record away from home, the Capitals have the fewest road losses among National Hockey League teams this season. A victory or tie would break a club record for points on the road.

title: HOMEWORK MINIMUM SET FOR SCHOOLS
description: A new policy requiring nightly homework assignments for every pupil in the New York City public schools, ranging from a minimum of 20 minutes for first graders to a minimum of two hours for high school students, was announced yesterday by Frank J. Macchiarola, Chancellor of Schools.

title: IRAQ REPORTS IRAN'S 4TH ATTACK
description: The Iraqi high command said today that a new Iranian attempt to strike into Iraq's Misan Province southeast of Baghdad had been repelled in 10 hours of fighting.

title: Warner-Lambert Co.  Takes Delayed Payment
description: Warner-Lambert Company, a pharmaceutical company based in Morris Plains, N.J., has accepted payment for a $100 million issue of 10 1/4 percent Euronotes due in seven years that was sold through Morgan Stanley International last November at a price of 99 1/2 to yield 10.45 percent.

KOCH VISITS ALBANY TO SPEAK FOR BUDGET PROPOSED BY CUOMO
description: Mayor Koch went to the State Capitol today to defend Governor Cuomo's proposed state budget and to assure critics that it would not spare New York City from painful retrenchment.

title: France Plans Outlays for Nationalized Sector
description: France's Socialist Government today announced a $2.9 billion investment program for the country's nationalized companies, with a sizable share allotted to the ailing steel industry.

description: By Anatole Broyard MOTHER BOUND. By Jill Johnston. Illus- trated. 164 pages. Knopf. $12.95.

New Clipper Charge
description: The former general manager of the San Diego Clippers, Ted Podleski, and the owner of the Clippers, Donald Sterling, have been involved in a court case stemming from a salary dispute.

title: POP: ROBERT KRAFT AT BOTTOM LINE
description: jazz singer, songwriter and pianist, who performed at the Bottom Line on Friday and Saturday, writes moody, touching songs about love in Manhattan. Capturing both the romance and the freneticism of city life among the young middle class, songs such as ''Cafe Society,'' ''Out With My Ex'' and ''Single, Solo'' blend a jaunty, lighthearted humor with a note of wistfulness.

title: P.L.O. ASKS BEIRUT TO GUARD CIVILIANS
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization has asked Lebanon to guarantee the safety of about half a million Palestinian civilians living in the country, according to Arab diplomats here.

title: Hitachi Ltd.  Explains Plea
description: Hitachi Ltd.'s surprise guilty plea to charges of conspiring to transport stolen computer secrets reflects its ''greatest respect'' for the United States legal system and gives the company a ''springboard'' for pursuing expansion of its markets, Hitachi officials said today.

Trump Tower Design
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: While Mr. Donghia's talent and work (''Behind Angelo Donghia's Gray Flannel Success,'' Jan. 20) are most worthy subjects, I would like to set the record straight. The firm of Swanke Hayden Connell Architects is the architect of record for Trump Tower and I am the project architect for Trump Tower since its inception.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
SHIPSHAPE LIGHTING
description: AFRIEND who is an avid sailor and also owns an old house to which he is constantly making additions and improvements has come up with a clever adaptation of a piece of marine hardware for home use. He has used deck lights, which on a boat provide light for dark areas below decks, for the same purpose in a dark, windowless second-floor hallway.

description: W ork hard. And if that's not enough to get the job done, work harder. Walt Michaels lived by that credo. But now he suddenly has decided to stop working, to stop coaching the Jets.

title: BIRD TAKES CHARGE, KNICK STREAK ENDS
description: The Celtics have posted a Dead End sign for winning streaks at the Boston Garden. Last month here, they stopped the New Jersey Nets' string of 11 straight, winning by 25 points; then they ended the Los Angeles Lakers' streak at seven, winning by 15. Tonight they stopped the Knicks' streak at five with a 106-96 triumph.

title: NOTE OFFER BY PAN AM IS OVERSOLD
description: An offering by Pan American World Airways to raise $135 million through the sale of convertible notes secured by some of its aircraft has drawn a surprisingly strong response.

title: Illinois Court Upholds Town's Ban on Pistols
description: The Illinois Appellate Court for the First District today upheld a year-old ban on pistols by the village of Morton Grove.

title: Big Rise in Failures Reported
description: Commercial and industrial business failures surged to 690 last week - the highest number since a record 696 in late August, Dun & Bradstreet Inc. said yesterday.

West German Magazine Says Police Took Its NATO Papers
description: The West German police have seized top-secret NATO documents on nuclear strategy in a raid on the leftist satirical magazine Konkret, a spokesman for the journal said today.

title: Jersey Ethics Unit Continues Inquiry
description: A state ethics panel today rejected a request to delay its inquiry of Reese Palley, chairman of the State Lottery Commission, while the Division of Criminal Justice begins a grand jury investigation of a plan to place video lottery games in taverns.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK ON THE SCHOLARLY TRAIL OF THE NEW REVISIONISTS
description: LITERARY revision appears to be a growing field for scholars these days. It covers an archeological dig into original notes and manuscripts, finding out how they differ from what was actually printed because of imposed editorial changes or typographical gremlins, and then reconstructing the way a book should have appeared in the first place. In the esoteric phrase of one such scholar, the aim is to discover ''authorial intentionality.''

title: CHANGES ENDORSED ON INSANITY PLEAS
description: The American Bar Association today endorsed changes in the insanity defense designed both to narrow its scope and to place greater burdens on those who assert it.

description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $178,000 for the qr and $478,000 for the 6mos...C-Including extraordinary credits of $373,000 for the qr and $400,000 forthe 6 mos and a gain of $1,218,000 for the 6 mos from a change in accounting; results reflects equity in the company's 50 percent owned joint venture, the Cordis Dow Corp; Corids Corp revised some of the figures previously released

title: A FEDERAL ENGINEER NOW QUESTIONS SAFETY AT L.I. NUCLEAR PLANT
description: An engineer for the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has changed his view and now says he has less confidence in the safety of the nuclear plant at Shoreham, L.I., according to an affidavit that became public today.

title: DANCE: HAWKINS PIECE SET TO SCORE BY MAMIYA
description: THE commissioned music featured in the Erick Hawkins Dance Company's season at the Joyce Theater, which ends Sunday, is particularly striking, and this was evident again Wednesday night with the premiere of Mr. Hawkins's ''Summer-Clouds People.''

title: STOCKS SOAR ON RATE HOPES
description: Stock market prices rose sharply yesterday, mostly on renewed expectations that interest rates will decline. Two of the three major market indicators closed at record levels.

title: INNOVATIONS TO UNCLOG COURTS SOUGHT
description: Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman said yesterday that ''a virtual tidal wave'' of cases was swamping the nation's courts and urged that efforts be made to resolve many noncriminal matters outside the courtroom.

title: GOULD INVESTORS TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results include gains from the disposition of rental properties and mortgages of $50,000 or 4 cents a shr for the latest first qr and $9,000 or 1 cent a shr for the yr-ago first qr

title: CONCERT: THE RAPHAEL TRIO
description: THIS year marks the 150th anniversary of the birth of Brahms, and musicians on all fronts seem to be planning to observe it. The Raphael Trio -Charles Castleman, violinist; Susan Salm, cellist; and Daniel Epstein, pianist - hit upon the idea of three concerts devoted to Brahms, Mendelssohn and Dvorak at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: Film 'Parsifal' begins a run at the Guild
description: JURGEN SYBERBERG'S ''Parsifal'' today begins a limited commercial engagement of five weeks at the Guild Theater - if you can use the word commercial when you're talking about an opera by Wagner that runs four hours and 15 minutes.

title: Upstate Support Sought By Cuomo on His Budget
description: Governor Cuomo came to western New York today for the first time since is election campaign, seeking to gather support for his proposed state budget and to rebut charges that both he and the budget favor New York City.

title: EL SALVADOR'S U.S., AND VICE VERSA
description: The American people and the Congress must be aware of the tight web of interdependence between the Reagan Administration and Government of El Salvador. The continuing violation of human rights in El Salvador not only condemns the Salvadoran Government, it also has a devastating effect on the image of the United States in Central America and in the rest of the world.

title: Ailing McEnroe Upset by Tanner
description: John McEnroe, bothered by tendinitis in his left shoulder, lost to Roscoe Tanner, 6-3, 5-7, 6-2, tonight in the second round of the $300,000 United Virginia Bank Classic.

title: Money Supply Plea to Reagan
description: President Reagan was urged by business leaders today to seek a moderate slowdown in the rate at which the Federal Reserve Board is permitting the money supply to grow.

title: PARK CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
FINANCIAL STRESS SEEN AT UNITED AMERICAN
description: The United American Bank empire, run by Jake Butcher, a Tennessean who strongly supported former President Jimmy Carter and lent money to Bert Lance, is apparently under severe financial stress, buffeted by losses from questionable loans and an extensive audit by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation.

title: Fordham Upsets Notre Dame
description: David Maxwell, a senior guard, scored 15 of his 19 points in the second half, including nine of nine free throws, to help Fordham to a 75-69 upset victory tonight over Notre Dame in the second game of a doubleheader at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: WALESA QUESTIONED BY PROSECUTOR IN PROCEEDINGS AGAINST DISSIDENTS
description: Lech Walesa, who was leader of the Solidarity union, today began what could be a long appearance before a military prosecutor.

title: I.M.F. NEAR ACCORD ON QUOTA RISE
description: Financial leaders from around the world neared agreement today on a 50 percent increase in the resources of the International Monetary Fund, the 146-nation organization that lends to countries hard pressed for cash.

title: Ex-Judge Defends Request for Vote
description: On the final day of a misconduct hearing before the State Commission on Judicial Conduct, a former Criminal Court judge testified that he had done no wrong by asking courtroom spectators to vote on which of two men to believe in a harassment case or by telling a defendant in a pickpocket case that he could choose the length of his jail term by accurately predicting the outcome of a coin toss.

description: The United States and Japan have agreed on a program to allow American companies much greater access to the Japanese market for high-technology products, the Commerce Department announced today.
