CONCERT: TODAY'S MUSIC
description: THE exploratory and experimental attitudes of musical composition of recent years were graphically illustrated in the program played by the Group for Contemporary Music Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y; nearly every work was explicitly involved in attempting to create coherence out of contrasting and contradictory musical universes and styles.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about Joe Walton in some copies of Sports Pages yesterday incorrectly listed the teams that recently interviewed him for head coach. The teams were the Kansas City Chiefs, the Atlanta Falcons and the Los Angeles Rams. The Washington Redskins were not among them.

title: SMALL TRUCKERS' LIFE: HARD, GETTING HARDER
description: The following article was written before the Independent Truckers Association announced yesterday that it was calling off its strike.

title: YAMANI HINTS AT A CUT IN OIL PRICES
description: Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, said in an interview to be published today in a Saudi publication that he saw ''no way out of a price reduction'' within the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Counties. The statement was regarded by analysts as a signal that a price cut is imminent.

title: Kean Signs Law On Auto Insurance
description: A complex law changing the way motorists pay for automobile insurance was signed today by Governor Kean. The bill's sponsor, Assemblyman Michael F. Adubato, Democrat of Newark, had seen two previous versions of his bill vetoed by Brendan T. Byrne when he was the Governor.

title: Aoki Tied For Lead
description: Isao Aoki of Japan scored five straight birdies on the way to a 6-under-par 66 and a tie for the first-round lead today in the $325,000 Hawaiian Open.

title: Express Signs Ramsey
description: Tom Ramsey, the U.C.L.A. quarterback, signed a four-year contract with the Los Angeles Express of the United States Football League.

title: Don't Fence Out Lumber
description: American lumber companies suffering hard times want the Commerce Department to protect them against Canadian competition. They may be right in arguing that Canada's Government policy makes it cheaper to harvest forests there. But that's no reason to barricade the American market. Far from it: punitive tariffs against Canada would set a costly precedent for retaliation.

title: Unmarried Couple in Denver Ruled in Violation of Zoning
description: The Denver Board of Adjustment says an unmarried couple are violating city zoning laws by living together in a residential neighborhood and must move out of their house in six months.

title: Dobrynin Departing?  Reports Discounted
description: Unconfirmed reports have been circulating that Anatoly F. Dobrynin, the long-time Soviet Ambassador in Washington, would soon give up his post to return to Moscow, but they were dismissed today by Soviet and American officials.

title: POP: A RIO-STYLE CARNIVAL
description: CONFETTI flew, streamers unfurled and just about everybody at Sounds of Brazil was dancing as the club kicked off its four-night Carnival '83 series Wednesday.

title: Hunt-Wesson Line
description: Hunt-Wesson Foods Inc., a unit of Norton Simon Inc. that makes tomato products and salad and cooking oil, has introduced a line of salt-free foods. As part of a general trend in the food industry to eliminate sugar, caffeine and salt from beverages and processed foods, Hunt-Wesson said it would market such no-salt tomato products as ketchup, tomato paste, spaghetti sauce and tomato juice.

title: SOURCE CAPITAL INC reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Asset figures represent net assets; results for 1982 are after distributions tocommon shrhldrs of $2.68 a shr during the 12 month period and taxes of 54 centsa shr paid on long-term capital gains retained by the company at Dec 31, 1982

title:
COMMODITIES;
Cocoa Price Rise Marks Peak Chocolate Season
description: From Valentine's Day through Easter, more boxed chocolate is sold than at any other time of year. And if cocoa prices keep rising, this already expensive treat will become even more costly in the months to come.

title: TEXAS GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes an extraordinary gain of $8,500,000

title: Aaron the Computer
description: Aaron, a computer with artistic inclinations, can be seen in the fifth-floor West Gallery of the Brooklyn Museum through March 6.

title: PUGET SOUND POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Transactions; BASEBALL
description: METS (NL) - Signed Dan Heep, Gary R ajsich, Marvell Wynne and Billy Beane, o utfielders, to one-year contracts. CLEVELAND (AL) - Signed Bud An- d erson, Jay Baller, Jerry Reed and R amon Romero, pitchers, and Chris B ando, catcher, to one-year contracts.

title: TATI HILARITY LIVES ON IN A FESTIVAL
description: The moment he appears on the screen, audiences start to laugh. Tall and skinny, constantly leaning with an inquisitive nose into a nonexistent wind, he lurches hither and yon, like some spastic bird, in a bouncing, loping stride that rolls from heel to toe.

title: New Jobless Claims Increase
description: First-time claims for unemployment benefits rose significantly in late January, ending a three-week series of declines, the Labor Department reported today.

title: Alain Giletti Hurt In Ski Accident
description: Alain Giletti, a 43-year-old former world figure-skating champion, fell down a crevasse while skiing near here Wednesday and broke both legs and several vertebrae.

title: 3 Priests Implicated In Rome Tax Scandal
description: Three Roman Catholic priests have had their passports withdrawn and were told they face possible legal action in an inquiry into a gasoline-tax-evasion scandal, according to press reports here today.

title: No Headline
description: Green's 34 Pace 21-0 Las Vegas

title: More Philippine Troops Sent In to Fight Rebels
description: The Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos today sent 2,000 more troops into a counteroffensive against Communist rebels in the southern Philippines.

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS SUES OVER SECRETS
description: Texas Instruments Inc. has filed suit in Federal District Court in Houston charging that the Compaq Computer Corporation stole trade secrets and infringed on its patents to develop a portable computer compatible with the International Business Machines Corporation's Personal Computer, it was learned yesterday.

title: Required Reading  An Old 'New' Bill
description: Representative Robert F. Smith, Republican of Oregon, in remarks to the House of Representatives, Feb. 3: Mr. Speaker, I rise before you today to introduce legislation which may qualify as one of the oldest ''new'' bills to come before us in these two years.

title: Foe of Abortion Gets 30 Years in Abduction
description: Don Benny Anderson, the head of an antia@bortion group that called itself the Army of God, was sentenced today to 30 years in prison for attempting to close an abortion clinic by abducting its owner and his wife.

title: Chip Developed
description: The General Instrument Corporation and the Milton Bradley Company said they had developed the first computer chip that can both recognize speech and synthesize words.

title: BARD, C R, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in Nov 1982

title: CONGRESS UNIT SUGGESTS ENDING MX
description: The Congressional Budget Office today gave Congress an analysis of 14 possible reductions in the Reagan Administration's proposed military budget, including the cancellation of the MX missile, the Navy's F/A-18 fighter bomber program and a proposed fleet of 63 Navy destroyers.

title: Dome Mines
description: Dome Mines Ltd. sold its 10.1 percent stake in Denison Mines Ltd. on the Toronto Stock Exchange and will receive about $54.5 million from the sale, a company official said.

title: Ferraro's Tumor Was Malignant
description: A tumorous left kidney removed from Mike Ferraro, the Cleveland Indians' manager, was diagnosed as malignant today. Doctors, however, said they thought they had taken out all of the cancer and expected the 38-year-old Ferraro to make a complete recovery.

title: 'VIETNAM IS NOT OVER,' PARLEY ON WAR LEARNS
description: On the sun-dappled campus of the University of Southern California, the Vietnam War issue was refought this week at an academic conference with some of the anger and confusion that surrounded the war itself.

title: Welcoming in Year of the Boar.
description: EATING the New Year in is one of the more delightful and irresistible of Chinese customs. Anyone who wants to partake of this celebration inexpensively, or considers Chinatown the only place to be Sunday, when the Year of the Boar begins, has some unusual and intriguing choices available. The two restaurants reviewed below are cases in point.

title: FESTIVAL OF OPERA FILMS
description: What is the best substitute for an opera performance? A film of an opera performance, that's what. And so the New York City Opera, which finds itself unable to produce live opera in New York for a sevenmonth period, is filling the gap with a series of six opera films on consecutive Sundays, starting this weekend. The series will take place at the newly renovated Beacon Theater, Broadway at 74th Street, and each film will be shown twice.

title: BACKLASH SEEN ON BANK WITHHOLDING
description: Senator Bob Kasten received 9,000 pieces of mail one day this week. Ninety percent of the letters concerned the same subject: the requirement, beginning July 1, that banks and financial institutions withhold 10 per cent of any income derived from interest or dividends.

title: ART: COSMOPOLITAN MINIATURES BY HELEN WILSON
description: THE evident speciality of Helen Miranda Wilson, whose new paintings can be seen through Feb. 26 at the Monique Knowlton Gallery, 19 East 71st Street, is the small domestic interior. To be more precise, it is the very small domestic interior - the size of a jumbo postcard, a paperback novel or the pocket of a country coat.

title: Dr. Joseph Winn, Psychiatrist And Ex-Head of 2 V.A. Clinics
description: Dr. Joseph A. Winn, who was chief of the Veterans Administration neuro-psychiatric clinics in Manhattan and Brooklyn from 1947 to 1970, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 82 years old.

title: PUBLISHING: COMMERCIAL TIE-IN BOOKS
description: WITH book sales flat and showing little sign of revival, trade book publishers are increasingly looking for commercial tie-ins. In the last 10 months, Bantam Books has sold a major corporation 1.6 million copies of two cookbooks to be used in special promotions.

title: U.S. Gypsum Picks A New Chairman
description: The United States Gypsum Company said yesterday that its board intended to name Edward W. Duffy chairman and chief executive in May. Mr. Duffy, currently vice chairman, would succeed Graham J. Morgan, who plans to retire May 31.

title: 2,000 DECOY BIRDS FLOCK TO SETAUKET
description: They look like black-bellied plovers, curlews, dowitchers and ducks -broadbills, mallards, teals and widgeons - but their feathers are carefully carved wood and delicately applied paint. They are antique decoys - once used by hunters, now hunted by collectors - and this weekend more than 2,000 of them will be on display at one of the largest decoy shows in the Northeast.

title: THOMAS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Reflects increases of $1,600,000 or 23 cents a shr for the latest yr and $450,000 or 6 cents a shr for the 1981 yr resulting from the liquidation of certain inventories valued on the LIFO basis; the results are adjusted for a 5 percent stock divd paid Jan 1

title: TOMORROW'S OPERA STARS MAY BE SINGING TONIGHT
description: WITH Metropolitan Opera tickets going for as much as $60 each and Broadway not far behind, the service performed by New York's small opera companies becomes more precious with each passing year. The variety of material offered is wide, and, this being New York, the singers you hear on a small stage tonight may be the headliners at the Met tomorrow. Ticket prices range from about $4 to $15, and you sometimes get much more than you pay for.

title: Texas Governor Rejected As Juror in a Robbery
description: Gov. Mark White said he was disappointed that he was rejected today as a juror in an armed robbery case.

title: POP JAZZ
description: ADOLPHE SAX invented the saxophone in Brussels in 1841. His original designs called for two families of saxophones, one for orchestral use (in the keys of F and C) and one for the military (in E flat and B flat). Militarism was sweeping Europe in the 1840's, and soon these new horns with the flexibility of reed instruments and the power of brass were part of some of the continent's finest military bands. Symphony orchestras and symphonic composers proved more resistant to the saxophone's charms.

title: EXCERPTS FROM CONGRESSIONAL BUDGET OFFICE REPORT ON REDUCING THE DEFICIT
description: Following are excerpts from the first chapter of a report, ''Reducing the Deficit: Spending and Revenue Options,'' issued today by the Congressional Budget office: Introduction

title: Fund Accord Set For Nuclear Post
description: Consolidated Edison and the State Power Authority have agreed to provide funds for the new Westchester County post of Coordinator of Indian Point Affairs, officials said today.

title: Friday; MAX ROACH AT COOPER UNION
description: Max Roach, the influential jazz percussionist, composer and teacher, who was a father of be-bop, is credited with introducing, among other things, the drum as a melody instrument in jazz and with showing that jazz can work in meters other than 4/4. He will perform solo in a free concert tonight at 8 at Cooper Union's Great Hall, Third Avenue and Seventh Street. Mr. Roach will also talk about himself and his work. Information: 254-6300. 30'S PARIS ON 71ST ST.

title: Opening Doors for the Homeless
description: Granted, the courts had to push New York City to get on with sheltering the homeless. Still, with limited resources Mayor Koch and city officials have done a superb job.

title: Cavaliers 99, Pacers 95
description: INDIANAPOLIS (AP) - World B. Free scored 30 points, and Phil Hubbard hit four free throws in the final 22 seconds as Cleveland extended its longest winning streak of the season to three games.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball College Games: Columbia at Brown (Radio -WKCR-FM, 89.9; 7:25 P.M.); Harvard at Princeton, 8 P.M.; Lehman at John Jay, 4:30 P.M.; Jersey City State at Kean, 8 P.M.; Oneonta State at Merchant Marine Academy, 8 P.M.; New Jersey Tech at New York Maritime, 8 P.M. Boxing Marvelous Marvin Hagler, champion, vs. Tony Sibson, world middleweight title bout, at Worcester, Mass.

title: 2 Doctors in U.S. Agency Back Hepatitis B Vaccine
description: A new hepatitis B vaccine made from blood plasma, which it is feared may contain an agent of the often-deadly acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, is safe and highly effective, two physicians from the Food and Drug Administration say.

title: AUDIOTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Brother Act
description: Ballots are in the mail to the 60 members of the international panel who will vote on this year's candidates for the International Tennis Hall of Fame. This year's candidates for enshrinement (a 75 percent favorable vote is required) are Pancho Segura, Jaroslav Drobny, Lottie Dod, Dorothy Round Little, John Bromwich, Adrian Quist and the Renshaw brothers, Ernest and Willie.

title: SOUTHERN INDIANA GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A HOUSING PLAN FOR ARTISTS LOSES IN BOARD OF ESTIMATE
description: A Koch administration plan for Federally subsidized housing for artists was turned down yesterday by the New York City Board of Estimate.

title: G.M.-TOYOTA PACT HELD NEAR
description: The long-awaited announcement of a General Motors-Toyota Motor agreement for joint production of a subcompact car in the United States is expected on Monday, according to industry sources.

title: Playboy Loses $3.3 Million
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc. said today that it lost $3.3 million in its fiscal second quarter this year, an improvement over a $13.2 million loss in the same period of 1982. It said it lost $5.7 million in the first six months of fiscal year 1983, compared with $7.7 million for the first six months of fiscal year 1982.

title: NATHAN'S FAMOUS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: B-After a charge of $26,000 from reversal of a tax credit...C-After a charge of$32,000 from reversal of a tax credit...D-Including a tax credit of $383,000...E-Including a tax credit of $268,000

title: RYDER SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RETAIL SALES UP JUST 0.1% IN JANUARY
description: Retail sales nationwide rose just onetenth of 1 percent, to $91.58 billion, in January, held down by a second consecutive month of relatively poor auto sales, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: TRUCK OF MONEY IS SURRENDERED IN SENTRY CASE
description: A 100-pound trunk, filled with money believed to have been stolen in the $11 million theft from the Sentry Armored Car Courier Company in the Bronx, was turned over yesterday to the F.B.I. in Albany.

title: THE SQUEAL RULE'
description: I didn't plan to fix the day so indelibly in my mind, but I can pinpoint exactly the first time I went to the doctor to see about birth control.

title: Reunion of Coaches
description: In the 1970's, Bill Parcells and Mike Pope were assistant football coaches on the same college staffs at Florida State and Texas Tech. Parcells, the new head coach of the Giants, has named the 39-yearold Pope as assistant coach of the Giants' special teams. Pope was an assistant coach at the University of Mississippi.

title: Numbers Game
description: The A.C. Nielsen top 30 telecasts for 1982 are out, and 13 sports telecasts, led by Super Bowl XVI, are on the list.

title: BUSH FINDS ALLIES OPEN ON ARMS PACT
description: Vice President Bush said today that allied leaders had told him of their interest in an interim agreement with the Soviet Union that would reduce the number of medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe as a first step toward a total ban.

title: CHURCH OF ENGLAND OPPOSES DISCARDING OF BRITAIN'S ARMS
description: The Church of England called on all nations today to renounce the first use of nuclear arms, but rejected a call for Britain to discard its own bombs.

title: COLD DRIVES RECORD NUMBER TO SHELTERS
description: The temperature plummeted early yesterday to 14 degrees in New York City, driving a record number of homeless people to city shelters, officials said, and a storm watch was issued for the metropolitan area.

title: TENOR AT THE MET 25 SEASONS
description: Charles Kullman, an admired and versatile tenor who sang at the Metropolitan Opera for 25 seasons, died of a heart attack Tuesday at St. Raphael's Hospital in New Haven, Conn. He was 80 years old.

title: A RANGER'S VIEW OF WINTER WONDERS
description: Even in the harshest of seasons, a nature lover's passion knows no chill. ''I please myself with the graces of the winter scenery,'' wrote Emerson. ''Every withered stem and stubble rimmed with frost contribute something to the mute music.''

title: FMI Sets Accord
description: The FMI Financial Corporation said it had agreed in principle to sell its hotel properties and a mortgage loan on one property for $50 million.

title: A Better Report Card for the Police
description: When are the police doing their job? The answers seem obvious: when many are in evidence, when they respond quickly to calls for help, when they catch a lot of crooks and hold down crime.

title: MATAGORDA DRILLING & EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $69,000 for the qr and $156,000 for the 6 mos

title: New Gold Fields Rigs
description: Gold Fields of South Africa Ltd. is prospecting for gold in an area southwest of the Kloof mine in the West Rand, the gold division's executive director, Colin Fenton, said today.

title: Marathon Duel In Search of Site
description: Alberto Salazar and Robert de Castella, the world's two fastest marathoners ever, will compete in a 5,000-meter race tomorrow night in the Vitalis/U.S. Olympic Invitational track meet at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. But where and when they will meet in a marathon for the first time remains uncertain.

title: HISTORY OF STRAUSS'S OPERA
description: The unfinished libretto of ''Arabella,'' the 10th of Richard Strauss's 14 operas, was a legacy to him from Hugo von Hofmannsthal, who died four years before the world premiere at Dresden in 1933. The text was extensively revised by the composer.

title: SHOPSMITH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JERSEY TO START CLEANING UP ITS WORST TOXIC WASTE SITES
description: New Jersey officials today announced a program to clean up major hazardous-waste dumps in the state, which has more than any other.

title: CONCERT: AMRAM WITH 'AMERICANA'
description: piece string section and a jazz quintet, presented a combination concert-seminar on American music entitled ''Americana - From Gershwin to Monk.''

title: DIOXIN FOUND AT DAY-CARE CENTER
description: A church day-care center here has been identified as one of seven additional sites around St. Louis where the soil is contaminated with the toxic chemical dioxin.

title: SIGNS OF CUPID'S DAY
description: That day will soon be upon us, and New Yorkers are scurrying about preparing for it as they do every year by buying heart-shaped greeting cards edged in lace and chocolates in satin heart-shaped boxes.

title: New Sears Centers
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company will begin phasing in its in-store financial network Monday by opening seven financial service centers in six markets. The centers will be in two Sears stores in Atlanta, and in stores at Fort Myers and Tallahassee, Fla.; Bakersfield, Calif.; Lexington, Ky., and Tacoma, Wash., officials said.

title: S.E.C. MAY SHIFT FUND ROLE
description: In an unusual move, the Securities and Exchange Commission suggested yesterday that it turn over much of its responsibility for inspecting the mutual fund industry to the industry itself.

title: RYAN HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a credit of $652,000 or 10 cents a shr from a change in the method of computing depreciation...C-Net loss

title: NO. 1 NORTH CAROLINA TOPS VIRGINIA, 64-63
description: Michael Jordan, a 6-foot-6-inch sophomore who knows all about the pressures of making winning shots in the closing seconds, won another big game that way tonight when his two baskets in the last 64 seconds gave North Carolina a 64-63 victory over Virginia.

title: Barnett Banks Cleared by Fed
description: The Barnett Banks of Florida Inc., of Jacksonville, said the Federal Reserve Board had approved three applications to acquire banks with assets totaling $142 million.

title: Washington Lobbyist Is Rehired by Cuomo
description: Governor Cuomo announced today the reappointment of Brad C. Johnson as director of the state's Office of Federal Affairs.

title: Phillips Oil Statement
description: A gradual drop in oil prices would be beneficial, according to the Phillips Petroleum Company's chairman, William C. Douce. Mr. Douce said a big drop in oil prices would not lead to huge losses in government revenue, a collapse of banks and strains on major oil companies. ''I think it will reduce prices and costs for the consumers,'' he said. ''It will ease the pressures on inflation and hopefully bring interest rates down.''

title: Market Place; Temporary Help Thriving
description: STOCKS of companies that provide temporary help for office work and other assignments have been climbing briskly despite the longest recession since World War II and the nation's highest unemployment rate since 1941.

title: PLAYBOY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,585,000 for the qr and $2,729,000 for the 6 mos...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $12,325,000 for the qr and $5,443,000 for the 6 mos

title: TRANSWAY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FORD AND CARTER TELL OF DIFFICULT COMMUNICATIONS IN GOVERNMENT
description: The most difficult task Jimmy Carter faced in office, the former President said today, was not freeing American hostages in Iran or shaping the Camp David agreement but pushing the treaty that transfered control of the Panama Canal to Panama past 66 recalcitrant United States Senators.

title: ALLEGHENY INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,846,000 for the qr and $3,819,000 for the yr...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $745,000 for the qr and $3,941,000 for the yr

title: Simpson to Be Inducted
description: O.J. Simpson was one of 11 former players named yesterday to the College Football Hall of Fame. Simpson was honored for two outstanding seasons, 1967 and 1968, as a running back for the University of Southern California and was the most recent college player of those selected.

title: DYNATECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated to reflect the pooling of operatons of four previously held companies Dynatech acquired during the third qr

title: Londoner Held in Case Of 3 Bodies in a Sewer
description: A man was arrested today after the dismembered remains of three young men were found in a North London sewer.

title: Spinks Fails to Show
description: Michael Spinks, the World Boxing Association's light-heavyweight champion, failed to appear in Philadelphia Municipal Court to face a weapons charge. When his lawyer told the judge that Spinks was in Florida training for a title fight against Dwight Braxton March 18, the judge set a new trial date, April 4, and issued a bench warrant for the fighter's arrest, a move described as ''a technicality.''

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: BAR GROUP V. MARDI GRAS
description: The name mentioned most frequently at the midwinter meeting of the American Bar Association here wasn't Chief Justice Warren E. Burger or Associate Justice Sandra Day O'Connor or Morris Harrell, president of the organization. It was Robert J. Kutak, who was not here.

title: Jurisdictional Dispute
description: The United States Football League hasn't played its first game yet, but it has already produced a hot rivalry: between competing unions. Ron Baron, a New York lawyer who heads a new group called the United States Football League Players Association, said his representatives had visited seven training camps and come away with authorization cards representing 30 percent of the players on five of the teams.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) * Loss in year earlier quarter.

title: FROM AUSTRALIA, 'WE OF THE NEVER NEVER'
description: ''WE OF THE NEVER NEVER'' is based on a memoir by Jeannie Gunn, who in 1902 accompanied her husband, Aeneas, from Melbourne, Australia, to the remote Northern Territory, where he became the new manager of the Elsey cattle station. The inhabitants of the area were aborigines and white cattlemen, with neither group accustomed to having a white woman in residence. The men, in particular, were suspicious of Jeannie Gunn, thinking she would change their rugged life with her ladylike ways. But Jeannie showed she could be a good sport, and she adapted to the demands of her new life, and everybody loved her.

title: Occidental Income Slides
description: The Occidental Petroleum Company announced yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter plunged 98.9 percent, to $2 million, from $187.1 million, or $1.72 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1981. After provision for preferred dividends, the latest quarter per-share earnings were a loss.

title: Bucks 102, Blazers 92
description: MILWAUKEE (AP) - Milwaukee, led by 28 points by Sidney Moncrief and 20 by Marques Johnson, opened an 11-point lead midway through the fourth quarter to insure a victory.

title: New Plapler Account
description: Plapler & Associates, which recently went into business with People Express as its first client, has just pulled in its second account, a company called 800 Spirits.

title: 76ers OVERCOME BULLS, 116-110
description: Julius Erving scored 24 of his game-high 34 points in the second half tonight and led the Philadelphia 76ers to a 116-110 victory over the Chicago Bulls.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: IT could have been 1947. Stanley held Blanche in his arms. The piano player played ''Come to Me, Bend to M e.'' And Al Hirschfeld sat at a table, wearing a navy blue corduroy b lazer and a pink ascot.

title: U.S. OUTLINES CHEMICAL - ARMS PROPOSAL
description: An outline of a proposed international convention that would provide for a ''complete and verifiable'' ban on chemical weapons was introduced by the United States today at the 40-nation disarmament conference here.

title: HCC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: B-After a loss of $907,000 from discontinued operations

title: Bridge: Neophytes to Join Experts In the Pro-Am Next Week
description: A large number of highly expert players will be playing with an equal number of quite inexperienced partners in New York City next week.

title: DeLorean Parts
description: The national spare parts depot for the DeLorean sports car, an inventory valued at about $50 million retail, will be established in Columbus, according to Sol Shenk, president of Consolidated International Inc. Consolidated is the liquidating company that acquired the parts inventory in bankruptcy proceedings against the DeLorean company in the United States and overseas. Mr. Shenk said Consolidated had appointed another Columbus company, Kapac Inc., to store and distribute parts for the stainless steel sports cars DeLorean had made in Northern Ireland.

title: RIDING THE RAILS TO HIGHER EDUCATION
description: Commuter trains are for dozing and reading, playing bridge and gazing out the window. But for Thalia Sanderson and about 600 other commuters from Connecticut and Long Island over the past decade, the trains are classrooms where corporate executives, bankers and lawyers teach courses like macroeconomic analysis and quantitative methods for management.

title: M.T.A. Escapes Federal Penalty In Rail Car Deal
description: A coalition of national labor unions yesterday dropped an effort to penalize the Metropolitan Transportation Aurthority for purchasing subway cars from Canada. In return, the authority promised that it would not buy additional foreign-made rail cars during the next three years.

title: CHICAGO & NORTH WESTERN TRANSPORTATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec
description: B-Net income; yr-ago figures reflect gains of $1.4 million in the qr and $9.2 million in the yr on the reacquisition of bonds

title: Geers Gross Picks Up $10 Million in Billings
description: Geers Gross Advertising, newly installed in quarters in The Daily News Building, has pulled in about $10 million in additional billings recently from both new and existing clients.

title: NEW YORK COMMERCE DEPARTMENT SET TO DROP HALF OF TOP MANAGERS
description: The State Commerce Commissioner said today that he planned to eliminate half the deputy commissioners and assistant commissioners in his department to cut costs and reduce waste.

title: CAREER'S SAD END
description: Few coaches or managers have ever been dispatched as coolly as Walt Michaels was relegated to history by the New York Jets. There were hardly any kind words about the coach who had come within one game of the Super Bowl.

title: ALCOHOL HELD AID TO SOME MEN
description: Inactive men drinking a moderate amount of alcohol each day raise their level of ''good'' cholesterol, which is associated with a decreased risk of coronary heart disease, researchers said today.

title: CANADA AND U.S. REACH TEST PACT
description: An agreement enabling the United States to test unarmed cruise missiles in northern Alberta later this year was disclosed today in Parliament, a few hours before it was to be signed by the Canadian Ambassador in Washington.

title: Judge Bars Razing Of City Landmark
description: A State Supreme Court justice has temporarily prohibited the owner of the former Mount Neboh Synagogue, a city landmark, from razing the building. The order by Acting Justice Leonard N. Cohen prevents the owner, Alexander Edelman, from demolishing or altering the structure, pending a hearing on Feb. 18.

title: SARASOTA, Fla., Feb. 10 (AP) -Jo Ann Washam took advantage of better weather conditions after a thunderstorm today and led by three strokes in the first round of the $175,000 Sarasota Classic. Miss Washam took charge with a 67 after a rain delay of 2 hours 52 minutes that left the greens soggy on the par-72, 6,128-yard Bent Tree Golf and Racquet Club course.
description: Alice Miller, who played much of her round in a driving rain and stiff wind, shot a 70. Play was suspended because of darkness with 63 players in the field of 133 still on the course. Their rounds will be completed Friday.

title: FOR PAO LEE, FAMILY IS THE FESTIVAL
description: Pao Peter Lee's satisfactory universe, not large, is his family, his restaurant and his community association, all of them circumscribed by the Chinese traditions he has stubbornly kept alive for three generations and defined by four lines from the Tang Dynasty poet Li Po, a poem he says has governed his life. I raise my head up To watch the bright moon, I bow my head down To think of my old home.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Frenzied Finish For Trump Tower Atrium

title: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1983; Markets
description: Stock prices rose sharply as expectations of lower interest rates were revived among investors. The Dow Jones industrial average soared 20.33 points, to 1,087.75, and the Big Board's composite index and the Standard & Poor's index rose to new highs. Turnover expanded to 93.5 million shares. (Page D1.)

title: A MURDERER DESERVES NO 'PEACEFUL DEATH'
description: To the Editor:

title: Investigators in Israel Get Police Protection
description: Police protection has been provided to the three members of the state commission that found ''indirect responsibility'' on the part of Israel for the Lebanese Phalangists' massacre of Palestinians in Beirut, a police spokesman announced today.

title: 6-Year Pact for Stieb
description: The Toronto Blue Jays, last in the American League East, finally found a way to keep their all-star right-hander, Dave Stieb, from straying from the fold. They offered him one of those multiyear, multimillion-dollar contracts that can make even the cellar seem like a palace.

title: Times Co.  4th-Quarter Net Down
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that its earnings fell 29 percent in the fourth quarter as a result of a pretax charge covering termination benefits for 147 composing room employees of The New York Times.

title: WEAN UNITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; the latest yr and yr-ago results reflect the effect of a previously announced consolidation of certain manufacturing operations and the closing of two plants amounting to a charge against income of $2,700,000

title: MACDERMID INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TAMPAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for 1982 reflect the adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 52 for foreign currency translations; the yr-ago results have been restated for a change in reporting certain expenses to more readily conform to industry practices

title: Pass, Jump and Score
description: Only two seconds were left in regulation time, and the Penn basketball team was leading Temple, 51-49. Then, after a timeout, a Temple player passed the ball 75 feet upcourt and a teammate grabbed the ball and sank an off-balance jump shot from 17 feet as the buzzer sounded. Temple went on to win in overtime, 61-53, ending a five-game losing streak.

title: MUNFORD INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest yr include a nonrecurring gain of $1,597,000 from the sale of stock; results for the previous yr include a gain of $1,245,000 from the sale of stock and assets

title: BUDD CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Broker in Playboy Quits
description: Marina E. Verola, a broker who posed seminude for Playboy magazine, has resigned under pressure from E.F. Hutton & Company, her lawyer said today. Thomas Rae, Hutton's chief general counsel in New York, said Mrs. Verola had resigned voluntarily. But her lawyer, Donald A. Wich Jr., said she had been given an ultimatum. Mrs. Verola, who is 29 years old and the mother of two, had worked as an account executive in Hutton's Fort Lauderdale office since August.

title: 'You Can't Take It With You' coming back to New York.
description: IN the beginning, everyone sounded extremely cautious, if not coy. ''We're going to do it four weeks and quit,'' Jason Robards stated firmly. But with a stellar cast that included not only Mr. Robards but also Colleen Dewhurst, George Rose, Elizabeth Wilson and Maureen Anderman, it was inevitable that the revival of ''You Can't Take It With You,'' which opened last month at the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N.J., would find its way to Broadway. And so it has. The production, which closed last Sunday in New Jersey, will reopen Feb. 26 at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington and will arrive in New York in early April.

title: 2 OTHERS MAY LEAVE
description: The frail thread that ties assistant football coaches to their team was snapped once more today when Joe Walton, in one of his first acts as the new head coach of the Jets, dismissed Pete McCulley as the receivers' coach.

title: Imperial Group Profits Climb
description: Despite a worse than predicted performance from its troubled Howard Johnson chain in the United States, Imperial Group P.L.C. reported today that after-tax profits rose 29 percent, to 118.2 million, or about $182 million at current exchange rates, in the year ending Oct. 31 from 91.4 million in the fiscal year 1981.

title: CONGRESS URGED TO CURB DEFICITS IN BUDGET SOON
description: Asserting that ''the American economy faces unprecedented risks'' from large budget deficits, the Congressional Budget Office told Congress today that it should act in far-reaching ways this year to curtail the rise of Federal spending and to raise additional tax revenue.

title: EASTERN UTILITIES ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Revs for the latest periods include approximately $2,435,800 for the qr and $11,723,400 for the yr which has been collected subject to possible refund; yr-ago revs includes approximately $1,222,400 which has been collected subject to possible refund

title: IF DEFENSE-BUDGET FRACTION WENT TO EDUCATION
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN THE POPULAR WILL CHOOSE TO OPPRESS
description: To the Editor:

title: BAR OWNER IS CITED FOR SERVING YOUTH
description: The owner of a bar in Old Brookville, L.I., has been charged with serving beer to an 18-year-old C.W. Post College football player who later that night was killed when the car he was driving while drunk crashed into a tree.

title: INEXCO OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sallie Mae to Market Adjustable-Rate Issue
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association announced plans yesterday to sell $200 million of adjustable-rate preferred stock in the week of Feb. 14 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: ART: WORKS BY LONGO ON VIEW AT 2 GALLERIES
description: OF the current crop of artists who take cues from the readymade visual environment - television, films, theater, advertising, periodicals, even architecture - Robert Longo has certainly been the most striking. Like them or not, you can't ignore the impact of the big, cinematic figures that he (with assistants) renders painstakingly from blown-up photographs, each seen in isolation as it writhes in an unexplained throe - was it struck by a bullet or a blast of punk rock? There's also a certain punch to his deadpan sculptural reliefs, of which the most ambitious example is ''Corporate Wars,'' a Michelangelesque tableau of fisticuffs in the business world, which he did for Documenta, the international art show in Germany last summer.

title: SOVIET JANUARY OUTPUT IS UP IN GET -BACK - TO - WORK DRIVE
description: The Soviet Government said today that labor productivity and output in industry rose substantially in January, the month in which Yuri V. Andropov began a campaign for discipline on the job.

title: A MURDERER DESERVES NO 'PEACEFUL DEATH'
description: To the Editor:

title: Bronzes on the block.
description: Greek gods and goddesses, scenes of romance, heroism and allegory - will be up for sale tomorrow and in later auctions this season at New York's major auction houses. Tomorrow's sale, at 2 P.M. at Sotheby Parke Bernet, York Avenue at 72d Street, is of 45 moderate-price European bronzes, most of which date from the turn of the century and range from $400, for an unidentified figure of Narcissus, to $6,000, for two groups of figures. One of them is a copy of The Rape of the Sabines, a 16th-century marble by Giovanni da Bologna; the other is of the abduction of Hippodamia, a figure in classical mythology, after a French work by Albert-Ernest Carrier-Belleuse.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have no intention to react to the Government's decision, which speaks for itself, and I don't intend to say anything about my future steps.'' - Defense Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel. (A1:6.)

title: Point Semantics
description: Around college basketball these days, statisticians are involved in a new game: semantics. The reason is the distinction between socalled ''real points,'' like 2-point field goals and 1-point foul shots, and the 3-point field goal that has been adopted experimentally this season by 109 teams in 12 Division I conferences.

title: HOME OFFICE DEDUCTION: INTERPRETATION LOOSENED
description: In the last year, taxpayers have won a number of important court rulings broadening the availability of home office deductions. The basic rule on claiming a home office deduction has not changed: To deduct the expenses of running an office in the home, you must be able to prove that you use the area exclusively and regularly for business, and that it is the principal place of your business, or a place where your clients or customers come to see you. As always, when this rule is met, the taxpayer can deduct the taxes, mortgage interest, operating expenses and depreciation attributable to the area of the house used for business.

title: TEMCO SERVICE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes extraordinary credits of $11,900 for the latest qr and $12,960 for the yr-ago qr

title: LED STUDY ON ACTION OF DIGITALIS ON HEART
description: Dr. McKeen Cattell, whose research showed the effect of digitalis drugs on heart muscle, died Tuesday at the Castle Point Veterans Administration Hospital in Beacon, N.Y. He was 91 years old and lived in Cold Spring, N.Y.

title: STANLEY WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a gain of $2,400,000 or 9 cents a shr for the qr from a reduction inLIFO inventories, a gain of $2,057,000 for the yr from the exchange of common stock and cash for debentures and a gain of $3,500,000 or 13 cents a shr for the yr from the sale of the company's drapery hardware division

title: STANDARD COMMERCIAL TOBACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The yr-ago results are restated; the yr-ago shr earnings are adjusted for a 5-for-3 stock split paid in Nov 1982

title: SIGNAL COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'LOOKING AT MUSIC' THROUGH 46 FILMS
description: Imagine! Under one roof, on one night: Arthur Rubinstein, Lili Pons, Jascha Heifetz, Rise Stevens, Ezio Pinza, Gregor Piatagorsky, Jan Peerce and the New York Philharmonic, conducted (but not at once) by Leopold Stokowski, Arthur Rodzinski, Bruno Walter and Fritz Reiner.

title: IRAQI DRIVE AGAINST IRAN OFFENSIVE SAID TO GET OFF TO SUCCESSFUL START
description: Western intelligence sources said yesterday that Iraqi troops, supported by ground attack aircraft and helicopters, had begun what appeared to be an initially successful counterattack against an Iranian drive into the southeastern Iraqi province of Misan.

title: Baby, It's Cold
description: Boxers traditionally wear velvet or satin robes when they enter the ring for a fight. But Hector (Macho) Camacho, the unbeaten junior lightweight, will step into the ring for Saturday's fight against John Montes wearing a black fox fur robe, with the word ''Macho'' stitched on the back in white mink.

title: Saxon Reprieve
description: The Saxon Oil Company said it had received a reprieve from the struggling energy company's principal lender, which had demanded that Saxon repay $89 million in overdue loans.

title: JAZZ BUFFS TO HONOR MAX KAMINSKY
description: band era with the Artie Shaw, Tommy Dorsey and Glenn Miller orchestras, and one of the most dependable, hard-driving exponents of Dixieland of the last three decades, will receive the New Jersey Jazz Society's annual plaque Sunday ''for outstanding services to jazz as a musician.''

title: News Analysis
description: Recent actions by President Reagan and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger have raised the question whether the Administration is tilting toward the Arab moderates and away from Israel.

title: VERNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SEAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Includes tax credits of $31,000 for the qr and $94,000 for the yr...C-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $733,000 for the qr and $2,672,000 for the yr

title: NATIONAL FUEL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OLSTEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
Pan Am Offering
description: The public offering of $150 million of 15 percent convertible notes that was made by Pan American World Airways yesterday was sold out, according to its underwriter, E.F. Hutton & Company.

title: BOSSY GETS 3 AS ISLANDERS ROUT CAPITALS
description: Revenge was what Mike Bossy of the Islanders wanted against Washington, and he got it in the form of a three-goal performance tonight in an 8-3 thrashing of the Capitals at Nassau Coliseum.

title: BLUE CHIP STAMPS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
description: B-Including capital gains of $20,371,000 for the qr and $25,044,000 for the yr...C-Including capital gains of $33,000 for the qr and $6,731,000 for the yr

title: Stanky Resigns Coaching Post
description: The University of South Alabama announced today that Eddie Stanky, the former major league infielder, had decided to resign as baseball coach at the end of the season in May.

title: 'SPEND THE NIGHT,' ROCK BY ROLLING STONES
description: HAL ASHBY'S ''Let's Spend the Night Together'' is probably the handsomest rock-and-roll movie ever made, although few others may have aspired to that distinction. Good looks, at least until recently, were never the point. And no rock film with a claim to authenticity could afford to forfeit its grainy realism. After all, the glamour grew out of roughness and ferocity, not out of wholesome stylishness or sophistication.

title: Vladimov, a Dissident, Getting Soviet Exit Visa
description: Georgi N. Vladimov, a writer who asked permission last month to leave the Soviet Union, was told today to file an application so he can be out of the country by April 1.

title: CURTISS-WRIGHT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $34,131,000 on the disposal of a segment

title: MUSIC: FROM TIN PAN ALLEY
description: THE history of Tin Pan Alley, which is the focus of the ''Lyrics and Lyricists'' series at the 92d Street Y this season, moved last weekend into a period, basically the first two decades of the century, when many of the most lastingly popular songs were written by songwriters whose names are virtually unknown to the public.

title: WALTON TO CALL PLAYS AS JETS' COACH
description: Joe Walton replaced Walt Michaels as head coach of the Jets today and said that he was stunned at the 24-hour upheaval that had changed the leadership of the team.

title: Kansas City Dismisses 13 Building Inspectors
description: The city's Public Works Department today dismissed 13 of the 18 city building inspectors who had been suspended without pay after accusations that they had falsified work reports and cheated on expense accounts.

title: PRATT-READ CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
E.P.A. SAYS IT SHREDDED DUPLICATE DOCUMENTS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it had destroyed ''excess copies'' of documents it had refused to turn over to a House committee that subpoenaed them.

title: SOCIAL WELFARE AGENCIES SURVIVE CUTS IN U.S. AID
description: Almost all of the nonprofit agencies in New York City that provide services in health, welfare and the arts have survived the first year of Federal budget cuts, according to a study by a nonprofit research group.

title: Money Fund Assets Drop
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds dropped $2.4 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to $195 billion, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: CITY TO RECEIVE $49 MILLION TO REPAIR TREATMENT PLANT
description: New York City will receive $49 million from the Federal Government to begin repairing a Brooklyn sewage treatment plant that city officials have said is on the verge of collapse.

title: FINAL SIX HOURS FOR 'WINDS OF WAR'
description: TV's mammoth ''Winds of War'' reaches the final 6 of its 18 hours this weekend, 3 this evening and 3 Sunday, each night beginning at 8 o'clock. As the network anxiously watches the dipping and swelling of the daily ratings, Herman Wouk's story sweeps forward inexorably to the Japanese bombing of Pearl Harbor in December 1941.

title: MARY KAY COSMETICS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Horse's Owners Reject Talks With Abductors
description: Police and owners of the Aga Khan's stolen stallion Shergar today refused to deal with the kidnappers who are demanding a meeting in a Belfast hotel to discuss ransoming the prize racing horse.

title: Advertising; Redbook Rejuggles Its Image
description: APRODUCT'S marketing position is where it lives. If advertising t ells consumers an item is a kitchen cleanser, they won't think to u se it in the bathroom. Similarly, in the case of a magazine, p ositioning defines the audience it appeals to.

title: South Carolina Challenges Law
description: South Carolina is seeking to overturn a 1981 law that requires new tax-exempt bonds sold by state and local governments to be issued in registered form after June 30.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Mayoral Fashion Show

title: THROGS NECK WATERSIDE CONDOMINIUMS
description: The Ruffalo brothers, Peter and George, were born into one of those tightly knit Italian-American families in which the children eventually settle down near their parents.

description: Results for the ry-ago qr and 6 mos reflect an extraordinary gain

title: Lionel Creditors
description: The Lionel Corporation, which with two subsidiaries is in Chapter 11 proceedings under Federal bankruptcy law, said its board had approved a reorganization plan that would provide creditors with cash payments of $70 million and a package of securities including preferred stock and warrants to purchase common stock when the plan is approved. No debt forgiveness is involved, Lionel said, but it would sell its 82 percent stake in Dale Electronics Inc. Its unsecured creditors hold $135 million in debt, the company said. It has no secured debt.

title: BOOTS THAT DO THE JOB
description: It was the end of a quiet summer day in Intervale, N.H., and Francis and Maria Limmer of Peter Limmer & Sons, custom bootmakers, were about to close up

title: EL PASO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income...C-Including an extraordinary gain of $5.9 million...D-AFter a writeoff of $32.4 million for the qr and yr of the company's chemical plant in Bayport, Tex., and from the company's remaining investment in coal leases in Utah and South Dakota

title: PANEL'S FINDINGS,16-1
description: The Prime Minister's office said today that Ariel Sharon had submitted his resignation as Defense Minister in the wake of the Cabinet's vote Thursday night to accept a state commission's recommendations that he and three top army generals leave their posts.

title: UTILITIES AND THE POOR
description: At least two groups are still feeling acutely unhappy about energy: the poor and the public utilities. Their problems are symmetrical. Most energy analysts assume that, short of direct subsidy from the taxpayer, there is no way to help one without hurting the other. Experience contradicts them.

title: SOUTHLAND ROYALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After charges of $7,425,000 from the settlement of a litigation

title: Drone Rams Missile Ship
description: An aerial target drone struck by a missile that had been fired for practice veered off course today and rammed the guided missile frigate ship Antrim, injuring a civilian, the Navy said. A spokesman for the Atlantic Fleet said the ship's drone opened a two-foot hole in the superstructure of the Antrim, which was off the Virginia capes conducting a test of its weapons system.

title: NORTH STARS TOP RANGERS, 7-5
description: The Rangers and the North Stars set a National Hockey League record for the fastest three goals tonight in a wide-open game won by Minnesota, 7-5.

title: Signal Income Down
description: Signal Companies' fourth-quarter net income fell to $27.3 million, or 38 cents a share, from $52.1 million, or 72 cents a share a year ago, Signal announced today. Full year net fell to $113.2 million, or $1.56 a share, from $214 million, or $2.95 a share. The company said its Mack Trucks unit lost $27.5 million for the year, against a $7.8 million profit in 1981.

title: Council Sees Mild Rebound
description: The Business Council forecast today a mild recovery this year, but warned that the outlook for both interest rates and inflation was unclear.

title: CHINA CAUTIONS ON SOVIET TALKS
description: Foreign Minister Wu Xueqian said today that China had a sincere desire to improve and normalize relations with the Soviet Union, but that he did not expect a breakthrough in talks between the two countries next month.

title: LIQUID AIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: IF A DEFENSE BUDGET FRACTION WENT TO EDUCATION
description: To the Editor:

title: HAGLER VS. SIBSON: BATTLE OF WORKMEN
description: In an area that has reduced its unemployment rate from 12.5 to 8.4 percent since 1975, two former blue-collar workers will fight Friday night for more than $1.6 million and the undisputed middleweight boxing championship of the world.

title: Hewlett-Packard
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said it would transfer manufacture of fiber-optic components to Singapore from the United States. It said a company subsidiary, Hewlett-Packard Singapore Ltd., would build a $50 million plant in Singapore to start the fibre-optic operations.

title: Levitt Is Ordered To Pay Foundation
description: William J. Levitt, the builder, has been ordered by a State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan to pay a sum expected to be about $1 million to his own Levitt Foundation.

title: Tourist Rips a Painting
description: A French tourist cut a 17th-century painting out of its frame in the Ducal Palace and ripped it into three pieces when custodians tackled him, the police said Thursday.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Battling Crime Against Homosexuals

title: KENTUCKY CENTRAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CAROL JANELLA BROWN
description: Carol Janella Henning Brown, the first wife of John Steinbeck, died Tuesday at Community Hospital.

title: Search Begins for Distressed Yacht
description: Rescue efforts were under way yesterday to reach Jacques de-Roux, a competitor in the B.O.C. single-handed round-the-world race, who had issued a distress signal in the stormy southern Pacific 1,400 miles west of Chile.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Ceco Corp., Oak Brook, Ill., said it had sold its Lemont, Ill., steel mill to Thomas Steel Corp. for an undisclosed amount as the final step in the divesiture of its steel mill operations.

title: SCHLUMBERGER SLIPS
description: R.J. Reynolds Industries said yesterday that an extraordinary charge caused it to register a 1.1 percent decline in earnings for the fourth quarter, although revenue increased 22.5 percent.

title: A MOVEMENT TO DO SOMETHING ABOUT FILIBUSTERS
description: The rules of the Senate were not chiseled in stone on Mount Sinai. It just sometimes seems that way. Accordingly, it is a matter of some note on Capitol Hill when the Senate contemplates a change in its traditional methods of operation. And right now, a panel of lawmakers is examining ways to limit the use of the filibuster, and accelerate the pace of legislation through what is often called ''the world's greatest deliberative body.''

title: SHARON, THE FORCEFUL GENERAL INTENT ON SECURITY FOR ISRAEL
description: When tanks under the command of Gen. Ariel (Arik) Sharon crossed the Suez Canal in the 1973 Arab-Israeli war, the lead vehicles bore inscriptions in chalk, ''Arik, King of the Jews.'' That campaign was the greatest personal triumph of his military career.

title: SALVADORANS TELL MRS. KIRKPATRICK THEY OPPOSE TALKS TO END WAR
description: The leaders of El Salvador have stressed to Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, that they oppose a negotiated settlement to end the threeyear-old civil war.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1983
description: International Ariel Sharon resigned as Israel's Defense Minister after the Cabinet voted 16 to 1 to accept recommendations of a state commission that he and three senior army generals leave their posts. The vote, with only Mr. Sharon dissenting, came after three days of intense political negotiations and an evening of street violence in Jerusalem over the panel's conclusion that Israeli leaders bore ''indirect responsibility'' for the massacre of Palestinians in Beirut by Lebanese Christian militiamen. (Page A1, Column 6.) The violence in Jerusalem killed one man and wounded nine people, including the son of Interior Minister Yosef Burg. They were casualties of the explosion of a hand grenade in a crowd of anti-Government demonstrators outside the offices of Prime Minister Begin where the Cabinet was debating the commission's report. (A10:1.)

title: 2 TOP DEMOCRATS IN RIFT OVER TAXES
description: A sharp disagreement emerged within the Democratic leadership of the House of Representatives today, highlighting some of the strains and pressures that are afflicting the Democrats as they organize themselves for the new Congress and try to present a coherent alternative to the Reagan Administration.

title: Henry W. Hobson, 91; Ohio Episcopal Bishop
description: The Rev. Henry Wise Hobson, the oldest bishop in the Episcopal Church, died Wednesday at a retirement home in Cincinnati. He was 91 years old and had been bishop of the Diocese of Southern Ohio for the 29 years before his retirement in 1959.

title: MARCHER IS KILLED IN ISRAELI PROTEST
description: A hand grenade exploded in a crowd of anti-Government demonstrators outside Prime Minister Menachem Begin's office Thursday night, killing one man and wounding nine other people, including the son of Interior Minister Yosef Burg.

title: Pension Rescue Plan Backed
description: A national commission's package of tax increases and benefit curbs would keep the Social Security System solvent through the decade but provide ''little margin for error'' in 1985, Congress was told today.

title: UNITED STATES PLAYING CARD CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss; the company acquired the playing card business in Mar 1982 and did not provide a sales figure for 1981

title: OXFORD, '83: AYES FOR QUEEN AND COUNTRY
description: Max Beloff's long journey of conscience ended Wednesday night at the place where it began exactly 50 years ago, in the speaker's well at the Oxford Union.

title: WHEN THE POPULAR WILL CHOOSE TO OPPRESS
description: To the Editor:

title: CITY BALLET: 'UNION JACK'
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE'S ''Union Jack'' is about as close to stage spectacle as anything the New York City Ballet dances. And the company's performance Thursday at the New York State Theater was certainly spectacular.

title: TAX BREAKS THAT LACK A PUBLIC PURPOSE
description: To the Editor:

title: TEXAN WHO BOLTED DEMOCRATS FACES THE VOTERS TOMORROW
description: Sixty-one-year-old Loy Norris concedes that he has been a yellow-dog Democrat for years, the kind of fellow who would rather vote for an old yellow dog than a Republican.

title:
Economic Scene;
Signs of Shift In U.S. Policy
description: BURIED deep in the Reagan Administration's proposed budget for the fiscal year 1984 are signs of a profound change in policy - a change that may say as much about the national political mood as it does about shifting Presidential priorities.

title: DOUGLAS & LOMASON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SCHMIDT WAITS IN WINGS, SHARPENING HIS TONGUE
description: Out of power and out of the limelight, he still ranks in the polls as the most popular politician in West Germany. But Helmut Schmidt, the former Social Democratic Chancellor, is taking it fairly easy in this winter campaign, pacing himself physically and leaving the center stage to his party's candidate for Chancellor, Hans-Jochen Vogel, the underdog.

title: PHILHARMONIC: WAGNER ANNIVERSARY
description: TO surgically excise Wagner's music from its natural place in the world of opera, to lift it in sections and then transplant these sections to the concert stage, may perhaps rob us of the composer's mythic potency. But stripping away the operas' gods and goddesses, their leafy venues, their monsters and their magic can give us something which is valuable in its own right - an unencumbered view of Wagner the pure musician, and, more specifically, of Wagner the master manipulator of orchestral sound.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt TEMPLE. By Robert Greenfield. 411 pages. Summit. $15.95. IGUESS it's amusing that Paulie

title: HOW TO CELEBRATE THREE HOLIDAYS AT ONCE
description: THERE are at least three reasons to celebrate this weekend: Chinese New Year, Brazilian Carnival and an event that transcends nationality - St. Valentine's Day. Fireworks, lion dances and parades will usher in 4681, the Year of the Boar - said to be a good year for businessmen - in Chinatown all day Sunday, starting 15 days of festivity. Elsewhere, costumed samba bands and dancers will evoke the pre-Lenten flamboyance of Rio de Janeiro today and tomorrow. Valentine's Day is, of course, Monday, but some events are planned beforehand to get you in the mood, including a romantic bus tour, origami heart-making and songs of ''love, lust and liquor.''

title: THE STAGE: 'SUMMER,' ADRIATIC RECRIMINATIONS
description: IMAGINE if someone stood up in a crowded theater and shouted ''fire!,'' and the audience responded by shuffling its feet and yawning. That's pretty much what happens at ''Summer,'' the new Edward Bond play that opened last night on the Manhattan Theater Club's main stage. Mr. Bond, the incendiary British author of ''Saved'' and ''Lear,'' has written a work that is meant to frighten and affront a liberal audience. But the drama is so pallid and inept that stupefied theatergoers can hardly even focus on the playwright's shrieking.

title: 11-DAY TRUCKER STRIKE CALLED OFF AMID SIGNS PROTEST HAD COLLAPSED
description: Leaders of the Independent Truckers Association announced today that their 11-day strike was over. They cited assurances from several dozen Congressmen that they would examine the scheduled increases in Federal fuel taxes and user fees.

title: Bruins 7, Penguins 3
description: BOSTON (UPI) - Barry Pederson scored two goals and the goaltender Pete Peeters stretched his unbeaten streak to 30 games (25-0-5) as Boston extended Pittsburgh's streak without a victory to 18 games. The Penguins have lost 11 in a row. Peeters has the second-longest unbeaten streak in league history and is two short of the record held by the Boston coach, Gerry Cheevers.

title: SCHLUMBERGER LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
US SHELTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOVIET PSYCHIATRISTS, FACED WITH CENSURE, LEAVE WORLD GROUP
description: The Soviet Union has quit an international psychiatric group that had been expected to consider whether to expel Moscow on the ground that it was using psychiatry to silence dissidents.

title: MIDLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a gain from discontinued operations of $706,000...C-Afte r income from discontinued operations of $116,000

title: Unwed L.I. Teacher Gives Birth to a Girl
description: Patricia Hope, an unmarried teacher at East Hampton (L.I.) High School whose pregnancy brought demands for her dismissal, gave birth yesterday to a girl at Southampton Hospital.

title: New Leak May Delay Flight of Space Shuttle
description: The discovery of what appears to be another engine leak in the space shuttle Challenger could cause another delay of perhaps two weeks in launching the spaceship on its inaugural mission, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said yesterday.

title: RONYX CORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WESTCOAST TRANSMISSION CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OPERA: METROPOLITAN'S NEW 'ARABELLA'
description: ''ARABELLA'' has traditionally been regarded as a connoisseur item, an opera into which Richard Strauss poured some of his most lyrically tender music as well as a good deal of sentimentality disguised as sophisticated comedy. The Metropolitan Opera introduced the work to America 28 years ago during Rudolf Bing's regime in an English translation and brought it back three times thereafter in an attempt to let it find its public. Last night, however, the Met reverted to the original German, with all the dangers that such a move entails for a work that is exceptionally complex and talky.

title: SMITHSONIAN MUSICIANS VS. MANAGEMENT
description: The Smithsonian Institution and the musicians in its performing arts program are involved in a disagreement over a proposed reorganization that sounds more like a labor-management dispute at a factory than a debate over the future of music at one of the country's most innovative and scholarly institutions.

title: REYNOLDS, R J, INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sentencing Postponed For Teamsters' Chief
description: A Federal judge postponed today the sentencing of Roy L. Williams, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and four co-defendants convicted of trying to bribe Howard W. Cannon, Democrat of Nevada, when he was a senator. Mr. Cannon was not charged.

title: OCCIDENTAL PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a charge of $85 million; results for the latest fourth qr were insufficient to cover preferred divds

title: CONAIR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted for a 9-for-5 stock split distributed on Feb 9,1983

title: AVX CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income of $602,000 from discontinued operations...C-Net loss including income of $74,000 from discontinued operations

title: AMERICAN FILTRONA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a charge of $1 million for the qr and 6 mos for future restructuring

title: CHURCH'S FRIED CHICKEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sculptured Dogs
description: ''Fidoes and Heroes in Bronze,'' 50 sculptures from the fifth century B.C. to the present, will be on exhibit at the Dog Museum of America, 51 Madison Avenue, near 29th Street, through June 3.

title: Heinrich Boll for the Greens
description: Heinrich Boll, the novelist, said today that he would campaign for the Green Party in West Germany's March 6 election.

title: ALCOHOL'S MEAGER TRIBUTE TO THE TREASURY
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESIDENT OFFERS JOB PLAN, STIRRING BIPARTISAN HOPES
description: White House aides gave Democratic leaders proposed emergency job legislation today that House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. said ''goes a long way'' toward meeting the national need.

title: Note and Bond Prices Jump; Rates on Bills Are Down
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose sharply yesterday with traders encouraged by rumors that the Federal Reserve was leaning toward further reductions in short-term interest rates, and by signs that the economy was not recovering as quickly as has been expected.

title: Stockman Plans to Stay On
description: David A. Stockman, who is getting married Saturday, said today that he would go on keeping the Government's budget books for President Reagan but that his wife would keep the family accounts.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Firefighters' Fight T hree firefighters working to revive a small boy are pictured on a poster that Fire Department personnel - protesting proposed cutbacks -began distributing yesterday for shop windows citywide.

title: RUMOR AND BICKERING ON U.S. SALVADOR POLICY
description: Amid signs of increased tensions with Congress over United States policy in El Salvador, the Reagan Administration said today that it sought ''reconciliation'' in the Central American nation while supporting the military campaign against leftist guerrillas.

title: Enemy Of The Good
description: Vice President Bush has been strenuously arguing in Europe for the ideal of ''eliminating from the face of the earth an entire class of new deadly missiles.'' But the ideal is seldom attainable; and the more the Reagan Administration pushes for this one, the more it actually appears to want its own intermediate-range missiles in Europe.

title: JERSEY SENATOR GIVEN SENTENCE FOR CONSPIRACY
description: State Senator John T. Gregorio was sentenced today to two years' probation and fined $10,000 for conspiring to conceal his interest in two go-go bars in Linden, where he is also the Mayor.

title: Fish Makes Him Rich
description: Last Sept. 21, while fishing off Atlantic City, 36-year-old Albert McReynolds hooked a 78 1/2-pound striped bass, the largest such fish ever caught. Today, at the Explorers Club in Manhattan, McReynolds will receive a check for $250,000, the largest prize ever given in a fishing derby. The sponsor, the Abu-Garcia Company, a major tackle manufacturer of Fairfield, N.J., has offered three other $250,000 prizes.

title: DQ Securities Moving, With Partner, to Bache
description: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. moved yesterday to bolster its institutional trading: It bought an entire institutional investment firm and will hire its managing partner.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Monday about fraternities at Trinity College incorrectly described the policy of fraternities at Amherst. All admit both men and women.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Lawyers for Hire for Anything?
description: Forced to choose starkly between models of the lawyer as client's mouthpiece and as caretaker of the law, the American Bar Association has opted for mouthpiece. Indeed, it held so faithfully to the role of hired gun that it left the impression it condones a lawyer's silent acquiescence in fraud.

title: BIG ADVANCE FOR FIBER OPTICS
description: There was no memorable first message, such as ''What hath God wrought,'' or ''Mr. Watson, come here, I want you.'' But a minor milestone in communications nevertheless was reached yesterday.

title: COMMERCE CLEARING HOUSE reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
TV: HAPPY 'NEWS' TALK
description: ''Two on the Town,'' on WCBS-TV at 7:30 tonight, is a permutation of ''happy news.'' Adrienne Meltzer and Lloyd Kramer, the reporters, or hosts, do feature stories. They smile a lot, but because the smiles are not smirks there is an unpretentious quality to ''Two on the Town'' that happy news otherwise lacks. Miss Meltzer and Mr. Kramer also do not get in the way of their stories; they let them happen around them.

title: National Symphony to Tour
description: The National Symphony Orchestra has announced that it will tour the American Southwest next October, its first trip to that area in 15 years. The cities in that area and in California to be visited are Houston, Albuquerque, Las Vegas, San Francisco, Los Angeles, Palm Springs and Pasadena, Calif., and Tempe, Ariz.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: RECITAL

title: Upgraded Walk
description: When Ray Sharp of Colorado State set a world-indoor best for the mile walk in the Millrose Games on Jan. 28, the early arrivals on hand cheered with an enthusiasm usually reserved for running records. Howard Jacobson, a leading race-walk coach, took advantage of the clamor to approach Ray Lumpp, the director of tonight's Vitalis/U.S. Olympic Invitational meet, and say: ''Ray, it's a shame having this event at 6:40.

title: Tammy Grimes Dismissed From Play
description: Tammy Grimes was dismissed yesterday as the co-star of Neil Simon's new play, ''Actors and Actresses,'' which is due to begin a pre-Broadway tryout next week at the Hartman Theater in Stamford, Conn.

title: WILLIAM C. CLEWORTH WEDS MARY BRADY IN CONNECTICUT
description: At the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday Mary E. Brady, daughter of Michael A. Brady of Greenwich and the late Mrs. Brady, was married to William C. Cleworth, son of C. William Cleworth of Winter Park, Fla. and Stockbridge, Mass., and the late Mrs. Cleworth.

title: LOS ANGELES CORONER DEMOTED UNJUSTLY, HEARING REPORT SAYS
description: Dr. Thomas T. Noguchi, ousted last year as the Los Angeles County coroner amid charges of mismanagement, was unjustifiably demoted, according to an interim recommendation made public today.

title: Jury Awards $873,690 For a Police Failure
description: A jury awarded $873,690 today to a 23-year-old widow who said her husband and her baby had been killed because the police did not detain a drunken driver who caused the fatal accident.

title: DANIEL L. ROSS
description: Daniel L. Ross, a research director for the RCA Corporation, died Monday of a heart attack at the Princeton Medical Center in New Jersey. He was 49 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: THOUSANDS ATTEND ISRAELI'S FUNERAL
description: Thousands of Israelis from towns and kibbutzim around the country flocked to the funeral today of Emil Grunzweig, who was killed in Thursday night's grenade attack on anti-Government demonstrators outside the office of Prime Minister Menachem Begin.

title: ISRAEL TRADING INSULTS WITH THE PHALANGISTS ON 'DOUBLE DEALING'
description: The longstanding relationship between Israel and Lebanon's Christian Phalangist militia has sharply deteriorated in recent weeks, with each side accusing the other of breaking promises and double-dealing.

title: Jersey City Schools Facing a Strike
description: Public school teachers in Jersey City, the state's second-largest city, have voted to strike next Thursday unless they are able to agree on a new contract with school administrators.

title: Mina Cravi-Bozza, Soprano; Founded Rehearsal Studios
description: Mina Cravi-Bozza, a lyric soprano who sang with the San Carlo Opera Company and who founded the Guild Rehearsal Studios in the Ansonia Hotel at Broadway and 73d Street, died of cancer Thursday in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 61 years old and lived at the Ansonia.

title: Correction
description: Because of mechanical errors in Weekend yesterday, type was scrambled in a review of art by Helen Wilson and others. The review appears today on page 10.

title: British Inflation Falls
description: Britain's annual inflation rate dropped to a 13-year low in January of 4.9 percent, from 5.4 percent in December, the Government said today.

title: Navy Sled Wins
description: Bill Renton of Virginia Beach, Va., drove his United States Navy sled to a combined track record of 3 minutes 58.99 seconds today to win the North American Four-Man Bobsled Championship at Mount Van Hoevenberg. Renton's team, Mike Gadway of Plattsburgh, N.Y.; Fred Fritsch of Virginia Beach and Carl Flanagan of Deer Lodge, Mont., turned in four sub-minute heats.

title: CORDLESS PHONES RING UP SALES AND RIDDLES
description: As the telephone industry in the United States changes and more people buy their own phones, cordless models that allow users to wander as they speak are capturing the fancy of a growing number of Americans.

title: 2 ROB A STUDENT, 18, TIE HIM IN BUILDING, SET A FIRE AND FLEE
description: An 18-year-old student visiting friends in New York was assaulted and robbed early yesterday by two men who tied him up inside an East Side town house and then started a fire in the building, the police said.

title: Damson Buys Texas Reserves
description: The Damson Oil Corporation announced that it had purchased an interest in certain oil and gas properties from the Petroleum Corporation of Texas for about $159.3 million. Damson, which is based in New York, said the purchase represents proven reserves of about 22.4 million equivalent barrels of hydrocarbons at a purchase price of $7.14 a barrel.

title: HAGLER STOPS SIBSON IN THE 6TH TO RETAIN TITLE
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler, in one of his finest performances, retained his undisputed middleweight title by stopping Tony Sibson at 2:40 of the sixth round tonight.

title: First by a Cap
description: Jockeys in thoroughbred races customarily wear little silk or nylon caps, but the headgear can be more of a handicap than a handy cap. The cap someties shifts and obscures the rider's vision, provides no protection against a head-first spill and exists only to complete the color scheme of a stable's silks.

title: The Talk of Lagos
description: A doctor here likes to tell a story about the women of the white, foreign community who frequent his private practice.

title: Bendix Loses $19.4 Million
description: Citing expenses incurred in its unsuccessful takeover bid for the Martin Marietta Corporation, the Bendix Corporation today reported a loss of $19.4 million for its first fiscal quarter ended Dec. 31, compared with net income of $45.6 million, or $2 a share, a year earlier.

title: A LAW THAT HELPS SAVE HISTORIC FACADES
description: To the Editor:

title: East-West Parley Agrees On 6 Working Groups
description: The East-West conference to review the 1975 Helsinki accords agreed today to establish six working groups to negotiate a final document.

title: Hartford Patches Up and Catches Up
description: Governor O'Neill has long since closed the door - and his mind - to the fundamental tax reform that Connecticut needs. His fiscal 1984 budget, therefore, recommends yet another patchwork of new taxes to cover rising expenditures.

title: Sports of The Times; Exit Miller, Racquet in Hand
