description: T he first thing Marvin Miller did when he retired from baseball last month was to go out and buy a new tennis racquet. The second thing he did was to head for the office, where for 17 years he has been restructuring the major leagues as executive director of the Players Association.

title: TO ELDERLY, JOB IS MORE THAN PAYCHECK
description: There was a graduation of sorts the other day at the World Trade Center offices of Manufacturers Hanover Trust, as another batch of bank tellers completed a two-week training program. There was nothing unusual about it, except that the average age of the new tellers was 60.3 years.

title:
PATENTS;
New Engine Can Use Wide Variety of Fuels
description: A Long Island engineer has invented an engine that he says will run on practically any liquid fuel.

title: Brunswick Stake
description: The Brunswick Corporation said it had been informed by Gulf and Western Industries that it might increase its stake in Brunswick in excess of 25 percent for investment purposes. It said Gulf and Western now held 2.49 million shares, or 21.4 percent of that outstanding, and that any additional purchases would be made on the open market.

title: A.T.& T. Plan On Pensions
description: The Communications Workers union asked a Federal court today to block the American Telephone and Telegraph Company from making changes in its pension program when it divests itself of its Bell System.

title: JUSTICE POWELL HALTS PRAYERS LED BY TEACHERS IN ALABAMA
description: Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. of the Supreme Court today banned Alabama teachers from leading prayers in the classroom pending a lower court's decision on whether the school prayers are unconstitutional.

title: Beth Daniel Up By 2 on a 68-138
description: Beth Daniel, the defending champion, shot a four-under-par 68 today to take a two-stroke lead over four others after two rounds of the $175,000 Sarasota Classic.

title: Performance of 'Evita' To Be Signed for Deaf
description: A sign-interpreted performance of the musical ''Evita'' for deaf audiences will be held Feb. 22 at 8 P.M. in the Broadway Theater under the sponsorship of the nonprofit Theater Development Fund.

title: Phone Service Back in South
description: Long-distance telephone service was restored in seven Southern states about 1 A.M. today after a computer failure knocked out service for more than seven hours.

title: Red Sox, Evans at Odds
description: Contract negotiations between the Boston Red Sox and Dwight Evans, their power-hitting outfielder, went public yesterday when Evans called a news conference to announce that he was demanding to be traded and the Red Sox issued a statement saying that his demand was being turned down. Evans, whose five-year contract has two years to run, said he wanted to leave because offers made by the Red Sox in talks on a three-year extension indicated that the club ''is no longer interested in me.'' The Red Sox said they were very interested in Evans and planned to keep him around for the next two years, whether he liked it or not. Meanwhile, one of the club's three general partners, Buddy LeRoux, belittled a report that he wanted to sell his interest because of differences with the other partners, Jean Yawkey and Haywood Sullivan. The others had no comment on any split, but a spokesman for Mrs. Yawkey sought to create a common front on the Evans matter by denying Evans's contention that Mrs. Yawkey favored giving in to the outfielder's demands. ... The Red Sox did have some success with player relations, however. They signed Dave Stapleton, the versatile player who is scheduled to become the full-time first baseman this season, to a two-year contract. Stapleton had filed for salary arbitration, requesting $285,000 a year; the Red Sox had offered $250,000.

title: Sheriff's Deputy Charged With Attempted Murder
description: A Cook County sheriff's deputy and a man said to be a mob asssociate were charged with attempted murder today in the wounding of a convicted gambler, Ken Eto. Mr. Eto, who was shot in an ambush Thursday, was reported in critical condition.

title: STRATEGY FOR THE HOST IF GUESTS ARE PROBLEM EATERS
description: Few situations are more discouraging for a host or hostess than to prepare a wonderful meal, only to find there is a guest who cannot or will not eat one or several of the dishes prepared.

title: OFFICIALS AT TRADE TALKS PIN HOPES ON RECOVERY
description: Trade ministers of the major industrial countries agreed today that the drift toward protectionism could be checked only if the world economy recovers. They also said it was time to ''consider seriously'' ways to stimulate growth.

title: Kupchak Watches and Waits
description: When Mitch Kupchak goes to watch the Los Angeles Lakers play, he does not sit on the bench or share laughs with his teammates in the dressing room. Kupchak takes a seat at least 20 rows up in The Forum and makes mental notes of the newer players he plans to oppose when his left knee is strong again. Kupchak has found that he dislikes going Laker games as a spectator.

title: Higher Money Target for Quarter
description: The Federal Open Market Committee, which sets Federal Reserve monetary policy, decided at its December meeting to allow money supply growth in the first quarter to exceed the targets set for last year, according to the minutes released today. The decision is aimed at assuring an economic recovery.

title: Article 228936 -- No Title
description: Two masked gunmen slipped in through the open door of a jewelry wholesaler, tied up three workers and stole an estimated 875 pounds of gold valued at up to $9 million in what could be the nation's largest gold theft, officials said today.

title: MELINDA J. ELSON WEDS ANDREW WIMPFHEIMER
description: Melinda Jean Elson, daughter Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Elson of Mishawaka, Ind., and Greenville, S. C., was married yesterday to Andrew Thomas Wimpfheimer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Anthony Wimpfheimer of New York and Greenwich, Conn. Supreme Court Justice Felice Shea of New York State performed the ceremony at the Wimpfheimer home in New York.

title: JOE THOMAS, A NOTED BUILDER OF MIAMI SUPERBOWL TEAMS
description: Joe Thomas the football-talent specialist who in five years built the Miami Dolphins from an expansion franchise into a team that went to the Super Bowl for hte first of three straight seasons, died unexpectedly todayat the age of 61.

title: ALBERTO VARGAS, ARTIST, DEAD AT 87
description: Alberto Vargas, the artist who captured the fantasies of men with his saucy pinup drawings for Esquire and Playboy magazines for more than six decades, has died of a heart attack. He was 87 years old.

title: Reagan Wage Policy Outlined
description: President Reagan, who believes the minimum wage ''never should have been applied to young people,'' will not try to abolish the wage floor although he does hope to lower it for young workers, a White House spokeman said Thursday.

title: Farmers Give Away Fruit In California Protest
description: Thousands of people lined up today to receive free fruit from farmers who were protesting Federal rules requiring them to dump much of their crop to keep prices artificially high.

title: EAST HIT HARD BY WORST STORM OF WINTER
description: The worst storm of the winter struck the mid-Atlantic states and the New York metropolitan area yesterday. Howling winds and deep snows disrupted travel, commerce, entertainment, government and endof-the-week activities for millions of people.

title: TEXT OF I.M.F. APPRAISAL
description: Following is the text of an appraisal of the world economic situation issued today by the International Monetary Fund as part of its communique:

title: U.S. OFFICIALS TELL OF RUSSIAN EMIGRE CRIME GROUP IN BROOKLYN
description: From Tuesday through Saturday, Police Officer Stephen Hrehus spends much of his day on foot patrol along Brighton Beach Avenue, a street that in one respect is unlike most others in Brooklyn. ''That music store there,'' he said, ''it's owned by Russians. Boston Fried Chicken? Russian. Gina Venucci shoes? Russian, too. Gastronom Moscow? Not too Irish.''

title: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 12, 1983; International
description: The I.M.F. agreed to increase its lending pool by $32.5 billion to help debtor nations improve their economies and avoid default. The accord would raise the fund's resources by 47.4 percent, to $98.5 billion. It represents a concession to the Reagan Administration, which is concerned about persuading Congress to approve the U.S. share of the increase, by far the biggest. (Page 1.)

title: Off-Duty Officer Is Shot by Youths
description: An off-duty Transit Authority police officer was shot and seriously wounded in Brooklyn yesterday by three young robbers who attacked him as he was putting tire chains on his car, the police said. At least two of the assailants were armed.

title: Lebanon Chief's Father Says Phalangists Weren't in Camps
description: Pierre Gemayel, leader of the Christian Phalange Party, denied in an interview published today that Phalangist militiamen were responsible for last September's massacre in two Palestinian refugee camps.

title: Heafner Shoots 65 For 3-Shot Lead
description: Vance Heafner finished off a 65 with birdies on four of the last five holes and held a three-stroke lead today following the second round of the $325,000 Hawaiian Open Golf Tournament.

title: Letter: On the Reagan Budget Victimizing the Federal Worker
description: To the Editor:

title: OPERA: METROPOLITAN'S NEW 'ARABELLA'
description: ''Arabella'' has traditionally been regarded as a connoisseur item, an opera into which Richard Strauss poured some of his most lyrically tender music as well as a good deal of sentimentality disguised as sophisticated comedy. The Metropolitan Opera introduced the work to America 28 years ago during Rudolf Bing's regime in an English translation and brought it back three times thereafter in an attempt to let it find its public. Thursday night, however, the Met reverted to the original German, with all the dangers that such a move entails for a work that is exceptionally complex and talky.

title: SOVIET WANTS TO OPEN SOME A-PLANTS TO U.N.
description: In a move that could have a major impact on arms agreements, the Soviet Union has said it wants to start talks this spring on opening some Soviet civilian nuclear plants to United Nations inspectors.

title: WHERE WHISPERS ECHO A NATION'S REVERENCE
description: On a recent night the moon moved behind the clouds and here, in the cold, Abraham Lincoln sat alone. The breeze carried a chill from the river. The buildings of Washington were dark, the boulevards empty. Two visitors, a young couple, stepped hand in hand, from the Lincoln Memorial. They closed their car's doors and drove away.

title: Ambrosiano Case Action
description: Banco Ambrosiano Holding S.A. formally opened legal proceedings today against six former officials of its parent firm, the failed Banco Ambrosiano S.p.A. of Milan; against Banco Ambrosiano itself, and against its successor, Nuovo Banco Ambrosiano, to recoup debts totaling more than $400 million, a Banco Ambrosiano Holding lawyer, Georges Baden, said.

title: U.S. TESTS NUCLEAR WEAPON
description: An underground nuclear weapons test was conducted today at the Nevada Test Site, the first announced test at the site this year.

title: ENVOY OPPOSES CUT IN SALVADOR AID
description: The United States Ambassador to El Salvador said today that a Congressional refusal to approve additional military aid would give ''new heart to the guerrilla movement.''

title: STRIKE AT AMERICAN AIRLINES AVERTED JUST BEFORE DEADLINE
description: Transport Workers Union continued talks today on a new contract in an attempt to avert a strike. A spokesman for the airline, Lowell Duncan, said the airline would operate 75 percent of its flights and maintain service to all destinations in the event of a strike.

title: CHASE IN TALKS TO BUY A DISCOUNT BROKERAGE
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank is negotiating to move directly into the stock brokerage business by acquiring Rose & Company, a discount brokerage firm based in Chicago, according to Steven A. Rautenberg, a Chase vice president.

title: Man Found Slain On Teaneck Path
description: A young man was found stabbed to death this morning on a snowy path atop a wooded knoll about 100 yards north of Teaneck High School.

title: MCI to Increase Its Expenditures
description: The MCI Communications Corporation plans to raise capital expenditures to $1 billion in the fiscal year 1984 from $600 million in the year ending March 31, William McGowan, its chairman, said at a securities analysts meeting here. He said that 1983 revenues could reach $1.2 billion, up from last year's $506.3 million.

title: ART: MINIATURES BY HELEN WILSON
description: The evident speciality of Helen Miranda Wilson, whose new paintings can be seen through Feb. 26 at the Monique Knowlton Gallery, 19 East 71st Street, is the small domestic interior. To be more precise, it is the very small domestic interior - the size of a jumbo postcard, a paperback novel or the pocket of a country coat.

title: The Wayward Bus
description: S he was a good bus driver, but the snow made for slow going for the No. 10 bus down Seventh Avenue. Riders gave her a hard time about keeping them waiting in the cold.

title: 590,000 NEITHER WITH NOR WITHOUT A JOB
description: To the Editor:

title: IN ROOM 832, THEY MAKE WAR ON SNOW
description: At 11 A.M., there were reports of isolated snowflakes on Staten Island. At 12:45, a lonely speck of white, like a piece of lint in search of a sweater, fell past the windows, and someone yelled, ''It's started.'' At 1 P.M., Al O'Leary called his wife, Cathy, and reported to the assembled, ''It's coming down like hell in South Beach.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Holiday in Court Is No Holiday

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title:
PATENTS;
Technique to Recover Gold From Gold Plating
description: A process used in the recovery of gold involved in gold-plating processes was patented this week for Bell Telephone Laboratories of Murray Hill, N.J., by Henry H. Law, a staff chemical engineer.

title: BE STILL, MY HEART
description: Women are waiting longer. In 1970, 90.9 percent of 27-year-olds were married; in 1980, the married --------------------------------------------------------------------- Andrew Hacker is editor of the forthcoming book ''U/S: A Statistical Portrait of the American People.'' group had shrunk to 77.9 percent.

title: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 12, 1983
description: International Ariel Sharon can keep a Cabinet post despite his resignation as Israel's Defense Minister, a spokesman for Prime Minister Menachem Begin said. If he chooses to do so, he could serve as a minister without portfolio, retaining his position in the policymaking inner circle. (Page 1, Col. 6.) Israel's Ambassador to the U.S. has reportedly been asked to replace Ariel Sharon as Defense Minister. Associates of the Israeli diplomat said that Prime Minister Begin had asked him to fill the Cabinet post and that he was inclined to accept. (1:5.)

title: TWO STOCK INDICATORS SET HIGHS
description: Stock prices generally rose yesterday in slower trading. Although the Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.25 points, to 1,086.50, two other leading market indicators closed at record levels for the second consecutive day and advancing issues outpaced decliners by 899 to 665.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Deo Bisnauthsingh, 36 years old and a native of India who lived in Queens with his wife and three children, was found murdered yesterday in a backyard in Jackson Heights. The police said his body had been found behind 37-50 86th Street.

title: OPEC Aid At Record
description: The Organization of Oil Producing Countries granted record financial aid to poorer nations last year from its Fund for International Development despite the organization's first deficit in many years, according to the fund's 1982 report released today.

title: STAHR FINDS FRIENDLY FOE IN RUNNING
description: When Mike Stahr lines up for the 1,000-meter high school run Saturday night in the Vitalis/U.S. Olympic Invitational, he will be alongside Miles Irish. That sight will be familiar to those who saw the Five-Mile Turkey Trot in nearby Yorktown last Thanksgiving. But this time there will be no funny ski caps, no psychedelic T-shirts over thermal underwear and no going AWOL a few yards short of the finish line.

title: SNOWSTORM PUTS OFF EVENTS
description: The New York Arrows were willing, and 10,000 ''Z'' banners were waiting, but Steve Zungul and the Golden Bay Earthquakes couldn't make it through the New York snow yesterday afternoon. As a result, the Major Indoor Soccer League game between the Arrows and the Earthquakes scheduled last night at the Nassau Coliseum had to be postponed until Monday.

title: Your Money; Pros and Cons Of Annuities
description: ANNUITIES, in a variety of sizes and shapes, have become an increasingly popular planning device for individuals. But while they have many advantages as an investment for retirement, they also have disadvantages that should be considered by those planning a purchase.

title: Film Series to Feature Social Documentaries
description: ''The Passaic Textile Strike,'' a film produced in 1926 by International Workers Aid, opens the 12th annual ''What's Happening'' series at the Museum of Modern Art Feb. 22 at 6 P.M.

title: One More Time
description: Once was enough for Home Box Office, but not for Carl King, who manages the heavyweight boxer Michael Dokes. King thinks that Dokes should fight Mike Weaver ''right back to prove the first time was no fluke,'' even if television executives see little interest in a rematch.

title: DANCE: 'ROSSINI QUARTETS,' CITY BALLET
description: Every so often a ballet that seems to hark back to the past is actually something new. It is this kind of happy premiere that Peter Martins created Thursday night at the State Theater for the New York City Ballet in his ''Rossini Quartets.''

title: TO TELL THE TRUTH, WE CAN'T
description: A big debate is going on now in legal circles over whether lawyers should expose clients when they learn that the clients have done or are doing crooked things.

title: CHICAGO COMMUNITIES SEEK FAIR SHARE OF CITY AID
description: Three men struggled to extricate their automobile from the snow and ice that choked a street near California and Ogden Avenues on the city's largely poor West Side, alternately cursing the weather and Mayor Jane M. Byrne each time they lost footing.

title: BREAKTHROUGH SEASON ARRIVES FOR LINDA HUNT
description: In Peter Weir's film ''The Year of Living Dangerously,'' Linda Hunt plays the pivotal role of Billy Kwan, a male Eurasian dwarf. At the American Place Theater, she is now appearing as Joan of Arc in the critically acclaimed ''Little Victories,'' which will run through tomorrow.

title: Bill on N.F.L.  Lost Its Impetus
description: Last August, representatives of the National Football League Players Association testified before the Senate Judiciary Committee that a player strike was inevitable if Congress enacted a bill giving the N.F.L. limited exemption from antitrust laws. By October, nobody was talking about the proposed legislation, but the players were on strike anyway.

title: BRIEFING
description: Tribute to Rickover A dm. Hyman G. Rickover, the strict father of the nuclear Navy who was dry-docked by President Reagan last year after 63 years of service, chose to pass up the usual ceremonial sendoff that is accorded retiring brass.

title: Walesa Is Questioned For a Second Day
description: Lech Walesa, leader of the banned Solidarity union, underwent a second day of questioning by military prosecutors today and was ordered to report back Saturday morning.

title: Cut in Nations' Fuel Use Cited
description: The International Energy Agency has calculated that energy consumption in its 21 member countries fell about 9 percent in the fourth quarter of 1982, to 377 million tons of oil equivalent from 413 million tons in the fourth quarter of 1981, oil industry sources said today.

title: Continental Shift
description: The Continental Air Lines Corporation will move its headquarters and executive offices from Los Angeles to Houston by July 1, officials announced.The company, formed Oct. 31 after the Texas Air Corporation acquired Continental Air Lines and merged it with Texas International Airlines, will retain a base of operations in Los Angeles, its president, Stephen M. Wolf, said.

title:
PATENTS;
Nuclear Fuel Element Extends Life of Barrier
description: A nuclear fuel element designed to operate in nuclear reactors for long periods of time without potential fuel failures was patented this week for the General Electric Company, Schenectady, N.Y. Patent 4,372,817 was obtained by Joseph S. Armijo of Saratoga, Calif., and Louis F. Coffin Jr. of Schnectady.

title: SOVIET PSYCHIATRISTS STUN COLLEAGUES
description: American psychiatrists reacted with surprise and regret yesterday to the sudden decision by Soviet psychiatrists to quit the World Psychiatric Association.

title: No Headline
description: Curren, Teltscher Gain

title: PENALTIES LIFTED FOR TWO UNIONS IN TRANSIT STRIKE
description: A state board announced yesterday that it had restored the right of two transit unions to have the dues of their 34,000 members deducted from their wages by the New York City Transit Authority and paid directly to the locals.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: KEVIN WHITE'S STORY: A LAST HURRAH?
description: If Kevin H. White was the hero of a novel instead of the beleaguered and all-too-real Mayor of Boston, the author would be faulted for having created a stock character.

title: NO HORSING AROUND
description: When visitors from elsewhere start calling New York a sissy town I take them to the corner of Eighth Avenue and 42d Street and point up toward Seventh Avenue and Times Square.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: The Contradictions of Senator Anderson
description: After welcoming Governor Cuomo's budget, the Republican Senate leader, Warren Anderson, has changed his mind and complains it's too generous to New York City. The budget is friendly to the city. And since the city is about as popular upstate as measles, it's easy to see why Mr. Anderson would say too friendly. But in view of his own record, it's hard to see how he can call it that.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE COMPLETE POEMS: 1927-79. By Elizabeth Bishop. 287 pages. Farrar, Straus, Giroux. $17.50.

title: French Skipper Rescued in Pacific
description: Richard Broadhead of England yesterday rescued a fellow competitor in the BOC single-handed round-the-world race from his dismasted and sinking yacht in the blustery southern Pacific.

title: Japan Tops U.S.  In Ice Hockey, 6-4
description: Japan's national ice hockey team defeated the United States, 6-4, today in the first game of the Seiko Super threenation ice hockey series.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Dognapping Mystery

title: TAMPA AMUSED BUT ANGRY AT ARRESTS
description: Thursday morning a week ago, on one of those brilliant clear winter days that have made Florida the new home of so many former residents of the snowbound North, a satirical jingle floated out over radio station WRBQ, rousing laughter in the luminous new glass office towers, the waterfront condominiums, the suburbs that have replaced orange groves rezoned for development. I work for the county, And I can make things go your way. If you want some zoning changes, All you have to do is pay.

title: Index; International
description: In a pell-mell race for wealth, Ni- geria stumbles 2 Israel protests to Vatican over statements by Syrian prelate 3 Envoy to El Salvador warns against aid cut 3 In London, a grim search for vic- tims in a mass murder 3 Basque peace effort ended by killing 4 Around the World 5 Habib sees Gemayel amid re- ports of pullout plan 5 Thousands of Israelis attend fu- neral for marcher 6 Government/Politics Fraud conviction of former Gov. Blanton of Tennessee upset 9 Arrest of commissioners has Tampa amused but indignant 9 New Metropolitan-area Repre- sentatives settle in 26 Offer made to buy city's upstate farm for retired police horses 26 General Around the Nation 8 Los Angeles coroner demoted un- justly, report says 8 Two rob and bind student, then set building on fire 26 LINCOLN'S BIRTHDAY Parking - Alternate-side rules suspended. Other rules in effect. Sanitation - No collections, no street cleaning. Special collection schedule tomorrow. Municipal offices - Closed. Post offices - Regular schedule. Banks - Closed. Transportation - Subways, buses, Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North on regular schedules. Libraries - Closed.

title: Wienerwald Creditor Plan
description: Wienerwald Holding A.G., the Swiss-based holding company for the financially troubled Wienerwald Catering Group, proposed a settlement to its creditors under which it would hand over assets worth about 86.34 million francs for liquidation. The Swiss franc is worth about 49 cents in United States currency.

title: Rangers See Signs Of Hope in Defeat
description: No Ranger could feel pleased about Thursday night's game here, a 7-5 loss to the North Stars. But for a team that has been in a severe offensive slump for the last month, there were a few good signs.

title: BLANTON VERDICT IN TENNESSEE UPSET
description: The convictions of former Gov. Ray Blanton of Tennessee and two aides on chargesgrowing out of the selling of state liquor licenses were overturned today by a Federal appeals court on the ground of faulty jury selection.

title: A GENTLENESS RETURNS TO THE WORLD OF TOYS
description: Amid all the sophisticated beeping, buzzing and blinking of video games, a certain innocence, a gentleness, seems to have descended - for the moment, anyway - upon Toyland. That was the feeling this week when, during the 80th annual American Toy Fair, manufacturers eagerly unwrapped their newest inspirations at the New York Toy Center and several other locations around town.

title: What if the Recession Is Ending?
description: The President's chief economic adviser, Martin Feldstein, drew criticism last week for nudging his slow-growth forecast upward just two days after it was published in the annual Economic Report. Actually, Mr. Feldstein is just one of many economists who have suddenly become more optimistic. The recovery is probably under way, and the start-up may be brisk. If true, it is welcome news. It is not, however, cause to relax.

title: Iran Marks Revolution With Anti-U.S. Rallies
description: Iran celebrated the fourth anniversary of its Islamic revolution today by organizing anti-American rallies in front of the former United States Embassy in Teheran, the Teheran radio said.

title: Bridge: When One Meets Trouble, An Assumption May Work
description: If you have plenty of time for a drive to an airport, a slow but predictable route may be appropriate. But if you are in danger of missing a plane, take the fast highway and pray that you don't run into a traffic jam.

title: 212 FOR THE PEOPLE, 718 FOR THE COMPUTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Feminist Leader Denied Bail in Murder Case
description: A judge refused to release the jailed feminist leader Ginny Foat on bail today as a fight continued over Louisiana's efforts to extradite her on charges of murder and robbery.

title: Soviet Worker at U.N.  Given Asylum by U.S.
description: A Soviet citizen working at the United Nations Secretariat has been granted political asylum in the United States along with his wife, his lawyer said today.

title: Surgery for Governor Hunt
description: Gov. James B. Hunt Jr., who fainted while giving a speech Thursday, had his appendix removed today and was resting comfortably, doctors at Wake Medical Center reported.

title:
Patents;
Inventor Of Year Selected
description: WASHINGTON DR. ROBERT K. JARVIK, the Utah physician who patented the artificial heart now being used by a retired dentist, has been selected as Inventor of the Year for 1982.

title: YIDDISH THEATER
description: "A Celebration: 100 Years of Yiddish Theater in New York," an exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street, has been extended through April 10.

title: ISRAELI'S ENVOY TO U.S. FAVORED FOR SHARON POST
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin has asked Moshe Arens, Israel's Ambassador to the United States, to replace Ariel Sharon as Defense Minister, and Mr. Arens is inclined to accept, associates of the diplomat said today.

title: Stolen Horse Is Dead, Callers in Ulster Assert
description: Anonymous telephone callers said today that Sergar, the champion bay stallion taken from the Aga Khan's stud farm, had been destroyed, but the police said the calls might be a hoax or a ruse to cover the kidnappers' trail.

title: Firkusny Rescheduled
description: Rudolf Firkusny, pianist, who was unable to appear at the 92d Street Y last Saturday evening because of illness, is now scheduled to perform there on March 27 at 3 P.M. Tickets from the postponed concert will be honored on the new date.

title: THREAT POSED BY DIOXIN SUBJECT OF GROWING FEAR
description: Concern is growing among public health officials, environmentalists, scientists and legislators that contamination by dioxin, one of the most toxic substances created by man, may turn out to be a serious national problem for which they are ill-prepared.

title: Marietta Expects A Small Loss
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation said it expected a small loss in the first quarter. It cited effects of the recession, weak operating results for its aluminum sector, increased interest expenses, low operating income for its seasonal businesses and adjustments for certain nonrecurring gains.

title: SHARON IS OFFERED CHANCE TO REMAIN IN BEGIN'S CABINET
description: Ariel Sharon, who resigned this morning as Defense Minister, can remain in the Cabinet as a minister without portfolio, a spokesman for Prime Minister Menachem Begin said today.

title: Auto Makers Raise Output
description: Fewer United States auto workers are on indefinite layoff this week as the major domestic auto makers scheduled an 8.2 percent increase in output from last week, according to industry reports released today.

title: AN EDUCATION SPEEDUP APPROPRIATE FOR SOME
description: To the Editor:

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 16. 1. The purpose would be to ease the work load of the Supreme Court. The proposed court would decide those cases in which any two of the 13 United States Courts of Appeals reached conflicting decisions.

title: Firestone Settles
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company has agreed to settle a $3.2 million stockholder suit accusing the company of concealing defects in its radial tires.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, Feb. 11 (Reuters) - Canada's Energy Mines and Resources Ministry said it had concluded exploration agreements with BP Exploration Canada Ltd. and partners calling for investments of about $260 million for the drilling of six offshore wells covering 5.3 million hectares on the Grand Banks-Labrador Shelf.

title: HABIB SEES GEMAYEL AMID REPORTS OF A PLAN FOR WITHDRAWING TROOPS
description: Philip C. Habib, President Reagan's special envoy to the Middle East, held talks here today with President Amin Gemayel amid speculation in the Lebanese press that he is carrying new proposals for the withdrawal of Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces from Lebanon.

title: Thousands in Naples March Against Mafia
description: Thousands of workers, students, shopkeepers and church officials marched thorugh pouring rain in Naples today in one of the largest protests against organized crime in the Mafia strongholds of southern Italy.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Off-Limits

title: ISRAEL PROTESTS TO VATICAN OVER ACTIVITIES OF PRO-P.L.O. ARCHBISHOP
description: The Israeli Government formally expressed to the Vatican today its displeasure over what it said was continuing anti-Israeli activities by Archbishop Hilarion Capucci, a Syrian prelate who was released from an Israeli prison in 1977 on a papal undertaking that he would not act in a way ''detrimental'' to Israel.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 47.

title: Eritrea Rebels Said to Kill 28
description: Eritrean separatist guerrillas killed 28 Ethiopian Government troops and captured five officers in a battle Thursday, a guerrilla spokesman said today. The spokesman, Osman Abu Bakr of the Eritrean Liberation Front-People's Liberation Front, told the Qatari press agency in Doha that the battle took place west of the city of Barentu in Eritrea, an Ethiopian province.

title: INDIANS BEFORE 1492
description: To the Editor:

title: COSTLY NEWS FOR PHONE USERS
description: The cost of local telephone service could double by 1985 as a result of the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: South Africa Says 112 Died In '82 While in Police Custody
description: One hundred twelve people died in police custody in South Africa in 1982, Minister of Law and Order Louis Le Grange said in Parliament today.

title: CABLE INDUSTRY FIGHTING DISH ANTENNA 'THEFTS'
description: A lot of people who would never dream of stealing a television set think nothing of stealing a television program, the cable industry says, and the industry is out to catch them.

title: TALKS BEGIN ON CONCESSIONS AT FORD STEEL MILL
description: The United Automobile Workers and the Ford Motor Company began negotiations today on concessions the union has been asked to make by a Japanese steel consortium seeking to buy the Rouge Steel Company, a Ford subsidiary.

title: CORRECTION
description: Drawings of exotic fruits in The Living Section on Wednesday misidentified two of them. The papaya was on the right side of the page and the mango was in the bottom left corner.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A year in jail and a $1,000 fine versus faithfully serving the President of the United States? I will continue faithfully serving.'' - Anne Gorsuch, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. (9:1)

title: News Analysis
description: Every day American commerce and industry disgorge the equivalent of a pound of hazardous wastes for every person in the country, and the Environmental Protection Agency estimated a few years ago that only 10 percent of this torrent of poison was being disposed of ''in an environmentally acceptable manner.''

title: Harvester Loss Put Below $150 Million
description: International Harvester will report a first-quarter loss of less than $150 million next week, about half the $299 million loss it had in the comparable period a year earlier, the company said today.

title: 3 USEFUL SPECIALIZED GUIDES; WASHINGTON
description: SOME of the best consumer publications never reach the bookstore. A mong them are ''The Mortgage Money Guide,'' ''Chemical Additives in B ooze'' and ''Reverse the Charges,'' three useful studies distributedb y mail by consumer groups and a Federal agency.

title: NEW VIDEO GAMES FROM OLD
description: What happens when Pac-man loses his punch? To the nation's 14,000 video-game operators, that question - and what to do when a promising new game turns out to be a flop - has assumed vexing proportions.

title: CONGRESSIONAL FRESHMEN SETTLE IN
description: The freshmen representatives have been here for a month, settling into their basement or back-of-the-building offices, furnishing new homes, attending first committee meetings and finding out what it is like to split their lives between the Capitol and their home districts.

title: TRANSPORT FOR AGED, DISABLED
description: New York City has 350,000 handicapped and frail elderly residents who have severe difficulty using public transportation. The needs of most of these people would not be met either by the elevators in subway stations required by a recent New York State Supreme Court decision or by wheelchair lifts in buses. These may provide accessibility in theory but in fact they provide little mobility. What handicapped people need is a convenient and efficient transit system that can carry them door-to-door. --------------------------------------------------------------------- Today, few disabled people make use of the wheelchair lifts installed in 1,300 city buses. The entire fleet of lift-equipped buses has never provided more than 500 rides a month for people in wheelchairs - an average of 17 rides a day. At this rate, with an annual debt service and maintenance bill of $7 million for lift-equipped buses now on the road, each ride is costing more than $1,000. Working against higher ridership are the problems of getting to the bus stop, mechanical difficulties with the lifts and the impatience of drivers and passengers, who often resent the delay incurred in the operation of the lifts. Many riders wind up annoyed, unhappy and angry with themselves for feeling that way. Riding the subways poses greater hazards for the handicapped than does their use of buses. The mandated elevators that, if installed throughout the system, would cost more than $1 billion, hardly offer a solution to the problems encountered by the disabled rider on the platform or in the moving train.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Antares Resources Corp., Great Neck, L.I., said it planned to acquire Crestview Aviation, a New Mexico general partnership, and Altair Corp., a private New Mexico concern that has filed under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Of Crime and Punishment

title: LEDBETTER, JET AIDE, RESIGNS
description: Bob Ledbetter resigned as coach of the Jets' running backs yesterday, apparently spurred as much by Walt Michaels's departure as by the prospect of joining the Giants in a similar position.

title: JUMPER IS SETTING HIS SIGHTS HIGHER
description: Tyke Peacock has this problem. He wants to play in the National Basketball Association, which is unlikely because he is probably not good enough. He wants to be the world's best high jumper, which is possible because he already ranks close to the top.

title: Trucker in Crash May Face Arrest
description: The State Police said they were trying to obtain a warrant for the arrest of a driver from North Carolina whose tractor-trailer slammed into a line of cars at a Connecticut Turnpike toll plaza, killing seven people.

title: Gulfstream Race To Christmas Past
description: Christmas Past took the lead in the stretch and beat Acharmer by five lengths today to win a $25,000 allowance race for fillies and mares at Gulfstream.

title: PRODUCER PRICES FELL 1% IN JANUARY, LED BY DROP IN OIL COSTS
description: The Producer Price Index, led by declines in gasoline and home heating oil prices, fell 1 percent in January, the largest monthly decrease since the index was started in 1947, the Labor Department reported today.

title: INDEPENDENTS' STRIKE
description: The difficult economic times facing the country's independent truckers and the fractionalized nature of the trucking industry were cited by the president of the Independent Truckers Association yesterday as being among the problems that led the organization to call off its strike after 11 days.

title: Article 225603 -- No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: HISTORY OF STRAUSS'S OPERA
description: The unfinished libretto of ''Arabella,'' the 10th of Richard Strauss's 14 operas, was a legacy to him from Hugo von Hofmannsthal, who died four years before the world premiere at Dresden, in 1933. The text was extensively revised by the composer.

title: Columbia Wins
description: Dale Smith, a reserve guard, made four of four shots in the final 27 seconds to lead Columbia to a 63-59 Ivy League victory over Brown tonight. Smith, a sophomore who scored 9 points, made his first two free throws to give the Lions a 60-57 lead. Alex Bynum of Brown (5-13 and 2-4) hit a jump shot with 21 seconds left, but Smith put in two more at the 14-second mark, and Darren Burnett gave the Lions (7-12 and 4-3) their final margin on another pair of free throws with one second remaining.

title:
PATENTS;
Lightweight Robots Used to Teach Others
description: Two Ohio inventors have devised relatively lightweight teaching robots to direct operations of work-performing robots, which may be too large for easy programming. Martin J. Harjar and Jeffrey S. Noss received patent 4,372,721 this week, assigning to it to their employer, the Nordson Corporation of Amherst, Ohio.

title: BASQUE PEACE EFFORT IS ENDED BY KILLING
description: A sudden upsurge in terrorism has upset what many Spaniards viewed as the most promising effort in years to bring peace to the Basque region of northern Spain.

title: BALLET: HARLEM COMPANY
description: Dance Theater of Harlem is an unusual ballet company. It has, among other things, an unfailing, heightened sense of theater, which made for an evening of glowing dance Thursday in the City Center.

title: 2 Loan Companies In Hawaii Close
description: Two loan companies in Hawaii -the Manoa Finance Company and the Great Hawaiian Financial Corporation - were closed and placed in receivership earlier this week, because of severe financial losses and failure to meet statutory requirements.

title: OFFER SUBMITTED FOR HORSE FARM RUN BY THE CITY
description: An investment broker has offered to buy a horse farm in Otisville, N.Y., that is owned by New York City and to keep it open as a home for horses retired from the Police Department's mounted unit and as a veterinary laboratory, principals in the talks said yesterday.

title: GRIM SEARCH FOR LONDON MURDER VICTIMS
description: The police charged a 37-year-old Government employment service worker today with the murder of a young drifter, and searched for the dismembered corpses of other victims.

title: WHAT IT SHOULD COST TO RUN A RED LIGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSE LAWYER SAYS E.P.A. ERRED IN DESTROYING PAPERS
description: A lawyer for the House of Representatives said today that its subpoena for Environmental Protection Agency documents asked for the duplicates the agency has shredded and that their destruction could constitute a crime.

title: Article 228969 -- No Title
description: The International Monetary Fund decided today to increase its lending pool by $32.5 billion so that it can meet the demand for emergency loans from developing countries short of money to pay foreign debts.

title: Lockheed and 2 Fined Millions
description: The United States Customs Service has ordered fines totaling more than $41.3 million against the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and two other companies accused of trying to avoid import duties illegally.

title: TO OBVIATE EXPANSION OF THE REGENTS BOARD
description: To the Editor:

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP IN JANUARY
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday reported that the money supply continued to grow rapidly in January and it announced revisions in what it includes in its measures of money supply.

title: Cascade Captures Yachting Race
description: Cascade, a 38-foot cat-ketch sailed by Russell Long of New York, won the 370-mile St. Petersburg-to-Fort Lauderdale race yesterday.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Major College Games: Syracuse vs. Georgetown, at Landover, Md. (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M. Radio - WNYE-FM, 91.5; 1 P.M.); Maryland at Duke (Television - ESPN, 1 P.M.); Nevada-Las Vegas at Fresno State (Television - Channel 2, 2:30 P.M.); Fordham at Manhattan, 3 P.M. (Radio - WFUV-FM, 90.7; 2:45 P.M.); Notre Dame at North Carolina State (Television - Channel 4, 3 P.M.); Alabama-Birmingham at North Carolina-Charlotte (Television -ESPN, 7 P.M.); Columbia at Yale (Radio - WKCR-FM, 89.9; 7:25 P.M.); Connecticut at St. John's, 8 P.M. (Television - Cablevision, 8 P.M. Radio -WNYE-FM, 91.5; 8 P.M.); Seton Hall at Providence (Television - USA Cable, 8 P.M.); Fairfield at St. Peter's, 8 P.M. (Television - Channels 50 and 58, 8 P.M.); Tennessee at Mississippi State (Television -WTBS, 8 P.M.); Illinois at Iowa (Television - ESPN, 9 P.M.).

title: Big Money for a Big Fish
description: WHEN 36-year-old Albert McReynolds of Atlantic City received a $250,000 check last Friday from the Abu-Garcia Company of Fairfield, N.J., at the Explorers Club in Manhattan, an emotional ordeal ended. For it wasn't until last Thursday that he knew he was going to get the money.

title: LEBANESE PATCH UP THE SCARS OF WAR
description: Five months after the end of the Israeli siege of Beirut, the signs that a war took place here last summer are gradually disappearing.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART The English landscape painter John Linnell - who died 100 years ago this year - is one of those artists who are best known for their association with others. We know that it was he who saved William Blake from virtual destitution in the 1820's, and that it was he who befriended the English visionary painter Samuel Palmer when Palmer was hardly more than a boy. With two such claims to our admiration, Linnell would have a place in the history of art even if he had never in his life sat at an easel.

title: TO MY VALENTINE
description: WHAT do we give each other, my Valentine, at this midcentury celebration? Do we spend endless hours choosing among cardboard-andplastic-hearted passion, who have so long sent each other messages no Hallmark card could compose? Do we send flowers and candies, as we both snuffle in the presence of pollen and suck frantically at sugarless mints and gum that doesn't stick to dentures?

title: Joan H. Baldwin to Wed G.L. Rossano
description: Dr. Helene L'Esperance Baldwin of Cumberland, Md., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Joan Hope Baldwin, to Geoffrey Louis Rossano, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis A. Rossano of Woodbury, L.I.

title: Marriage in June Is Being Planned By Jean S. Padjen
description: Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Padjen of Salem and Topsfield, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jean Seward Padjen, to Oliver Wolcott 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wolcott of Hamilton, Mass. A June wedding is planned.

title: Lesley A. Schultz To Marry in June
description: The Rev. and Mrs. Carl Fearing Schultz Jr. of Glastonbury, Conn., Centerville, Mass., and Lancaster, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lesley Ann Schultz, to Stephen Norman Faber, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Norman Faber of Berkeley Heights, N.J., and Loveladies Harbor, N.J.

title: Upset Follows Hockey's No.1
description: It seems that one of the surest ways to set a team up for a crashing upset defeat in college football and basketball is to name it as the top team in the country in the polls. That now seems to apply to college hockey as well.

title: Madeleine R. James Engaged to Gregory A. Verini
description: Mrs. Norman Hickman and Daniel Willis James, both of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Madeleine Ranson James, to Gregory Alan Verini, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mario Verini, also of New York. The wedding is to be May 14.

title: 6 DIE IN RIOTS AS INDIAN STATE PREPARES TO VOTE
description: At least six people were killed today in clashes between Hindus and Moslems in India's northeastern state of Assam, where pre-election violence has so far taken more than 70 lives.

title: CRIME
description: The British tradition of Dorothy Sayers and P.D. James has a new practitioner in S.T. Haymon, whose RITUAL MURDER (St. Martin's, $10.95) takes the work of her predecessors and makes it into something very much her own. Miss Haymon has been represented up until now by one previous mystery, ''Death and the Pregnant Virgin'' (missed by this department). Her hero in both books is Detective Inspector Benjamin Jurnet, who is a steady, sensitive type rather than the flamboyant investigator represented by Lord Peter Wimsey. But what Miss Haymon has in common with Miss Sayers and more recently Mrs. James is a feeling for British tradition, for the land and what it means, for church and commonwealth, for the sanctity of the law, for the little and big people who make up the country.

title: Teachers in Quebec Vote To Continue a Walkout
description: Teachers in Canada's province of Quebec voted overwhelmingly on Friday to reject the provincial government's latest contract offer and continue their walkout.

title: ARE PROGRAM CUTS LINKED TO INCREASED INFANT DEATHS?
description: As a barometer of the quality of health care, the infant mortality rate is an imprecise gauge. Still, as the nation's infant mortality rate has fallen steadily during the last two decades, Americans have come to look upon this indicator as evidence that health conditions are improving.

title: Rain Interrupts Women's Golf
description: Beth Daniel, the defending champion, who played steady golf in wet weather for the second time in three days, held to a two-stroke lead over JoAnne Carner today when heavy rain stopped play during the third round of the Sarasota Classic.

title: SEEKING CANCER AT THE SOURCE
description: WITH 30,000 new cancer cases a year being reported in New Jersey, health officials are turning their attention to the work environment, hoping to find and get rid of carcinogens at the point of exposure.

title: Hawaii State Senator Accused of Vote Fraud
description: A Hawaii State Senator was indicted Friday along with members of his family and a former political aide on charges stemming from what the authorities say was a vote fraud in an election involving the former aide.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: We've had a taste of snow. And there will be more coming; you can bank on that. Meanwhile we're up to our hocks in picture books that sing of winter's wonders.

title: U.S. HOPES SHARON'S DEPARTURE MAY EASE LEBANON WITHDRAWAL
description: WASHINGTON AFTER months of frustration over failure to achieve significant diplomatic progress in the Middle East, the Reagan Administration was watching the political convolutions in Israel last week with more than usual interest, hoping that the resignation of Ariel Sharon as Defense Minister might provide impetus for ending the negotiating impasse. Frustrations have been openly expressed by Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger and have extended even to failure to agree on sharing the military information gained in last year's fighting in Lebanon.

title: REAGAN SEEKS $200 MILLION TO TRAIN TEACHERS
description: The Reagan Administration proposes to spend $200 million over the next four years to increase the number of mathematics and science teachers in the secondary schools. The proposal is part of an attempt to reverse the nationwide decline in the quality of math and science education.

title: Webb Rallies and Beats Weber in Bowling Final
description: Wayne Webb rebounded from a 27-pin deficit midway through the final game and defeated Pete Weber, 218-201, today in the $110,000 Professional Bowlers Association Greater Miami Sunshine Open.

title: Count Ireland Out
description: Michael Flannery, the grand marshal of this year's St. Patrick's Day parade, is a bit too martial for some. The Irish Republic said last week that it would boycott next month's New York City parade because of Mr. Flannery's outspoken support for the Irish Republican Army. Mr. Flannery is the founder of the Irish Northern Aid Committee, which a Federal judge has ruled an agent of the I.R.A. Last year, he was found not guilty of conspiring to run guns to the Irish guerrillas. After a Catholic laymen's group elected him grand marshal, Mr. Flannery said the traditional event would ''definitely be a pro-I.R.A. parade.''

title: Wedding Planned By Muge Gocek
description: Mr. and Mrs. Muzaffer Gocek of Istanbul and Buyukada, Turkey, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Fatma Muge Gocek, to Charles Rohr Hammerslough 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Charles Hammerslough of Weston, Conn. A May 15 wedding is planned in Weston.

title: STORM BURIES SCHEDULE
description: The near-blizzard that stormed into the Northeast sector of the country on Friday continued yesterday to force postponements and cancellations of athletic events, including the Vitalis/ U.S. Olympic Invitational track-and-field meet at Byrne Meadowlands Arena in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: 107th Westminster Features 2,621 Dogs
description: Westminster, the show of shows, opens a two-day run at Madison Square Garden tomorrow, with 2,621 dogs representing 137 breeds or varieties. They come from 48 states, North Dakota and Wyoming are the exceptions, as well as the District of Columbia, Canada, Puerto Rico, Bermuda and Brazil.

title: Houston 74 Texas Christian 66
description: HOUSTON (AP) - Michael Young scored 21 points and helped rally Houston from a 7-point haltime deficit. Houston now has won 15 straight games, tying its second longest winning streak in history.

title: SAILING ON ICE AND WIND
description: ''THIS has got to be the most frustrating sport in the world,'' declared Bill Doolittle, his arms outstretched and his eyes cast upward as if appealing to the diety that provides the thing that an iceboater cannot do without: wind.

title: Hibernians Out of Step
description: In the Provisional Irish Republican Army, ''to kneecap'' means to cripple a person for life by pumping bullets in both knees. It's a favored punishment for betrayal by fellow Irish Catholics.

title: A Vital Deduction
description: To the Editor:

title: HARD TIMES FOR LOVE?
description: LOVE, it seems, has fallen upon hard times. Modern statistics indicate that the state of love, much like an overused guitar, has broken (heart)strings, an irreparable warp and frets that have been worn down. Can such an instrument be repaired, refurbished, brought back to the life it once knew?

title: Tulane 49, Memphis St. 47
description: NEW ORLEANS (AP) - Daryl Moreau hit a 20-foot jumper at the buzzer to give Tulane the upset victory in a Metro Conference game.

title: WHY SHOULD ANYONE BE A TEACHER?
description: WHEN I was 12 years old, I decided, like my parents and grandparents before me, to become a teacher. When I was 21, I changed my mind. Teaching looked dull and unimportant compared to glamorous opportunities open to an ambitious college student. Nonetheless, tradition ultimately prevailed and I eventually sneaked into the schoolroom, where I found stimulating people and absorbing work.

title: EUBIE BLAKE, RAGTIME COMPOSER, DIES 5 DAYS AFTER 100TH BIRTHDAY
description: Five days after his 100th birthday was celebrated with gala performances of his music, Eubie Blake, the composer and pianist whose career covered a span from the ragtime era in the 19th century to the contemporary Broadway theater a year ago, died yesterday at his home in Brooklyn.

title: A LOST ART: RUSSIAN ENAMELS
description: WHIPPANY SURROUNDED by their Russian enamels and Battersea boxes, Melvin and Barbara Alpren can be found at some of the better antiques shows in the state. Mrs. Alpren inherited a collection of, and a taste for, Russian enamels from her father, who was a doctor.

title: STRUGGLING TO SAVE THE LOCAL MILL
description: FOR decades, this mill town in the West Virginia panhandle was noted in American industry, first because it was one of the biggest company towns in America, then because Ernest T. Weir, the company's founder and a self made industrialist, so fiercely fought unions and the labor policies of Franklin Delano Roosevelt.

title: A SORRY TRIP FOR 'PINAFORE'
description: WHEN Wilford Leach staged his knockabout ''Pirates of Penzance'' for the New York Shakespeare Festival, he set off a spate of imitations. Everywhere, theater owners were putting on their own free-for-all versions of the Gilbert and Sullivan operetta. Inevitably, the bandwagon reaction produced a backlash effect. The more ''Pirates'' one saw, the more traditional they became.

title: D'AMATO: AT HOME IN THE SENATE
description: Tom Goldstein is a writer specializing in legal and political affairs. Day after day, night after night, the debate over legislation to raise the gasoline tax dragged on. Conservatives filibustered against the measure, which was intended to create a public works program. The Administration also disliked the plan, but gradually gave ground as Christmas approached. While larger political and economic issues were being played out around him, Alfonse M. D'Amato, New York's junior Senator, was keeping watch over a more parochial issue - the preservation of operating subsidies for public transportation, a matter of paramount importance to his constituents. This was his issue, the issue he had picked after his election two years before as a means to make his mark in the Senate. Now the Administration was trying to eliminate the subsidies, which helped pay the day-to-day costs of mass transit in New York City and keep the fares down.

title: SIGN ORDINANCE UPSETS BABYLON
description: LEGAL action is in the offing for scores of merchants who are in violation of a comprehensive ordinance designed to regulate commercial signs in the Town of Babylon.

title: H.U.D.'S NEW YORKERS SEEN AS A PLUS FOR CITY
description: Mayor Koch was denouncing the Reagan Administration's housing policies from the front lawn of the White House recently when his Housing Commissioner slipped away from the mayoral entourage to visit the very agency that carries out those policies.

title: FROM ENGLAND TO BROOKLYN TO WEST VIRGINIA
description: THE STORIES OF BREECE D'J PANCAKE Foreword by James Alan McPherson. Afterword by John Casey. 178 pp. Boston: Atlantic/Little, Brown & Co. $13.50.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: An Unusual Theme Marriage between black and white individuals and how children of such unions fare socially are subjects seldom deemed suitable for television. However, Tuesday evening at 9 on Channel 13, the ''American Playhouse'' series will present ''The File on Jill Hatch,'' a three-part drama about an interracial couple and their daughter. The story spans the 40 years from the end of World War II through the American civil rights movement to the recent youth riots in England.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: THEATER After playing several months at the American Place Theater, ''Do Lord Remember Me,'' a heartfelt collage of slaves' memories, has moved to Town Hall, where it will be presented through Feb. 26. Drawing upon oral histories recorded in the late 1930's by the Federal Writers Project, James de Jongh created this compilation of stories, work songs and Gospel music.

title: IT HELPS TO SHARE TWIN EXPERIENCES
description: ''THE first time I was surprised, but the second time I was very shocked,'' said Mila Tegelaar, the mother of two sets of twins, as she recalled her initial reaction to the news, partway through each pregnancy, that she was carrying twins. ''It's a lot of work, that's true,'' she said, describing the task of raising the children, now 2 years and almost 5 years old. ''But now I can say I'm very lucky that I have twins.''

title: TIME FOR A GLOBAL CODE ON MIGRATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Coast Rock Fans Riot In Concert Overbooking
description: Teen-agers spilling out of an oversold rock concert Friday night rampaged over six blocks, throwing stones and bottles and looting some stores where windows were shattered, the police said today.

title: MULTI-TOWN: 'LET IT DIE'
description: TOWN: The very name is a fraud. Way back yonder, when this grandiose, ill-conceived project was being billed as a panacea for the garbage problems of Huntington, Babylon, Islip and Smithtown, someone came up with an ingenious name for its quasi-governmental overseer - the Multi-Town Solid Waste Management Authority. Multi-Town: it had a certain ring to it.

title: VOTE PUTS THE FUTURE OF PACIFIC ISLES IN DOUBT
description: The future of Palau, an island chain in the Western Pacific, was cast into doubt today with the apparent defeat of a nuclear weapons question tied to a proposed political, military and economic alliance with the United States.

title: 'The Breaks'
description: Bit by bit, this talented young novelist, Richard Price, seems to be working his way up out of the violent world of his first two novels, ''The Wanderers'' and ''Bloodbrothers,'' both of which were about the lives of New York's working-class young. In his third novel, ''Ladies' Man,'' Mr. Price took one of these youths at the age of 30 and put him through a lonely week selling household sprays door-to-door by day, and in the evening trying to recapture the gang camaraderie of his adolescence. Now, in his latest novel, ''The Breaks,'' he has taken yet another proletarian youth and given him a serious chance to break out of his class.

title: The Chancellor's Parting Shot
description: Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola's back-to-basics approach has often been credited with helping New York City schools back to respectability. Last week, in what he said would be ''part of my legacy'' of nearly five years in office, the outgoing school chief drove his philosophy home.

title: 29 Food Places Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 29 food establishments last week for violations of the city's health code. In addition, the department named three restaurants that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations, and two that were closed for having failed to do so.

title:
ART;
MAYA TREASURES REVEAL SOPHISTICATION OF AN ANCIENT PEOPLE
description: WHEN it comes to outstanding ancient civilizations, few equal the fascinating Maya peoples of pre-Columbian Central America. Sophisticated and learned - with accomplishments like astronomy, mathematics, holographic writing and an exact calendar - they created a wide range of art objects, including painted ceramic vessels adorned with fluid, linear figures easily rivaling those of early Greece.

title: THE HERO AS LOSER
description: THE BREAKS By Richard Price. 446 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $15.95.

title: HER CAREER HAS BEEN ONE 'LONG, SLOW CRESCENDO'
description: Benita Valente, whose singing has caused critics to pull out adjectives such as ''ravishing,'' ''exquisite'' and even ''awesome,'' to describe it, has never become a mega-star. She says of her career, since she first came to national attention as a winner in the Metropolitan Opera auditions in 1960: ''It's been a long, slow, wonderful crescendo.'' And yet ....

title: More Help Needed To Tutor Children
description: As a recent University of Connecticut graduate, I am proud to read of UConn and Wesleyan students tutoring in Ned Coll's Revitalization Corps (''Beyond Schoolwork,'' Jan. 23).

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: TUESDAY marks the 162d birthday of Susan B. Anthony and, according to Christine Carmody-Ary, the state coordinator of the National Organization for Women, Miss Anthony would be proud of today's women.

title: GERMAN VOTE: THE STUDENTS ARE UNSTIRRED
description: A contradiction seems to be flourishing in this university town of 75,000. Despite a tradition of unorthdoxy and activism, Tubingen and its students seem apathetic in the midst of what many view as one of the most critical parliamentary election campaigns in West Germany's history.

title: No Headline
description: Oregon State Upsets U.C.L.A.

title: IN ROME, A HEAVENLY PLACE TO EAT
description: PAUL HOFMANN, a former correspondent for The Times, lives in Rome.

title: A LETTER TO ANDROPOV
description: Dear Yuri V. Andropov: Are we right in assuming that you are truly serious about slowing down the arms race? Then you might like to consider a step that would not entail the sacrifice of a single Soviet missile but that could have the most profound impact: Tell the truth about your country's defense spending.

title:
ANTIQUES;
APPRAISAL CLINIC FOR PUBLIC
description: MOST collectors know how much money they have in their billfolds and bank accounts, but a surprising number have no real knowledge of the actual market value of family heirlooms or even of antiques purchased only a few years ago.

title: New Evidence Reported In Killing in Salvador
description: A new autopsy on the body of a 21-yearold American killed by Salvadoran soldiers last fall found that he suffered bruises caused by ''blunt force'' before he was shot to death.

title: GUARDING PATIENTS' RIGHTS
description: WHEN a nursing-home resident returned from a hospital stay to find that her beloved books had vanished, she related her anguish to a weekly visitor whose identifying pin read Ombudsman Gloria Schwartz. Mrs. Schwartz approached the housekeeper, who replied that ''the books were removed because they collected dust, which is not good for such a patient with a respiratory problem.''

title: Charles G. Berry, Kathryn McGraw To Marry in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Alexander McGraw of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathyrn McGraw, to Charles Gordon Berry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rynn Berry of New York and Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: OF MARGARET MEAD, HER CRITICS AND UNHELPFUL SENSATIONALISM
description: To the Editor:

title: SOME DEFENSE COMMITTEE MEMBERS WON'T BE FIRING BLANKS
description: Senator John W. Warner, Secretary of the Navy in the Nixon Administration, has consistently been a stalwart voice for increased military spending on the Senate Armed Services Committee.

title: THE JETS' FORMER GIANT
description: IN the years when Joe Walton was the Giants' tight end two decades ago, the progress of the Jets' games would never be posted by the Giants on their Yankee Stadium scoreboard. The Jets were in that ''other league'' then. And the National Football League establishment sneered at the American Football League until the 1966 merger and even after it. But now the ink on the merger treaty has finally dried. Now a former Giant player, Joe Walton, is the Jets' coach.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A music listing today on page 19 of The Guide, section 2A, and a picture and caption, all referring to the musi- cal revue ''On the Air,'' have become outdated. The nightclub Van Buren has closed.

title: Coe's Return a Success As He Captures 1,500
description: Sebastian Coe of Britain made a triumphant return to racing after a six-month layoff by winning the 1,500-meter run at a British-French indoor meet today.

title: FOR HIM, MAGIC IS MORE THAN TRICKS
description: Doug Henning, the magic man, wasn't always the most lovable whiz of a wiz. Once upon a time, he found it intriguing to test the unwary. He'd be sitting at a restaurant counter, and half-dollars would just keep materializing under the plates as the astonished waitress swept them away. He would hand over his money at the cash register and the bills would vanish - to the befuddlement of the cashier. Or the magician would slip into a supermarket, break open a seeded roll, and find a coin inside. He'd smile his gee-wizard grin and say, ''Well look at that!'' prompting onlookers to attack other rolls, hunting for pennies from heaven.

title: DRIVERS SIT THROUGH NIGHT AT CLOGGED LINCOLN TUNNEL
description: Few New Yorkers were as unlucky as those who set out to drive through the Lincoln Tunnel as the snow began to fall Friday. By midday yesterday, many of them had been waiting in their cars and trucks for 18 hours or longer.

title: EFFORTS UNDER WAY TO STEM ILLITERACY
description: WAYNE HELLEIS travels throughout the country as a building appraiser for a Mercer County company. At the age of 30, he owns two homes and earns more than $30,000 a year.

title: DANCE: ERICK HAWKINS AND 'PARSON WEEMS'
description: What do people do in snowstorms like Friday night's? Attend dance concerts by the Erick Hawkins Dance Company, for instance, at the Joyce Theater which was filled with a good crowd of acolytes.

title: Vatican Bank Officials Linked To a Major Financial Scandal
description: Italy's third major financial scandal in a year has touched the Vatican bank.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THY BROTHER'S WIFE. By Andrew M. Greeley. (Warner, $3.95.) In his second novel the author of ''The Cardinal Sins'' artfully intertwines the stories of the Cronin brothers: Paul, an unscrupulous comer in Democratic politics, and Sean, a Catholic bishop who loves Paul's wife but keeps the faith as he fights to make the church more humane. In his review Webster Schott described the book as ''a novel of electrifications'' that leaves the reader with vivid, often sensational images.

title: CATHOLICS ON THE LEFT
description: BREAKING BREAD The Catholic Worker and the Origin of Catholic Radicalism in America. By Mel Piehl. Illustrated. 296 pp. Philadelphia: Temple University Press. $19.95.

title: CUOMO TO ORDER CUT IN AGENCIES' USE OF OUTSIDE CONSULTANTS
description: Governor Cuomo has announced that he is drafting an order to reduce the use of outside consultants by state agencies and authorities. ''There are many occasions for using consultants,'' Mr. Cuomo said in an interview. ''On the other hand, they have been from time to time overused and overpaid.''

title: FLOOD-STRUCK CAMP IS TO REBUILD
description: WHEN the Bushy Hill Dam in Ivoryton broke in the flood last June, it damaged five other dams and 25 homes, and totally drained the mile-long Bushy Hill Lake that was the center of recreation for the nation's second-oldest summer camp as well as a fishing spot for residents of neighboring towns.

title: Miss Beinhorn Marries William P. Dunk in Texas
description: Courtenay Wyche Beinhorn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Beinhorn of San Antonio, was married there yesterday to William Paul Dunk, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Selig Dunk of Scarsdale, N.Y. The ceremony was performed at St. Mark's Episcopal Church by Harold C. Gosnell, retired Bishop of West Texas and the Rev. Sudduth R. Cummings, rector of St. Mark's.

title:
GARDENING;
FAVORITE PLANTS AND THEIR FAMILIES
description: THE rose family contains a diversity of plants, ranging from the garden rose to many commonly grown fruits including the apple, peach, raspberry and strawberry.

title: STYLISH INDIVIDUALISM
description: Norma Kamali, who has been voted the 'outstanding American talent' of 1982, has turned her flair for the dramatic and the daring into a growing business that is achieving both financial and esthetic success. orma Kamali is as individualistic as the designs that have made her a force in the American fashion community. From the time she signaled the dissolution of her partnership with her former husband by starting a company called OMO - for ''On My Own'' - she has been a genuine innovator. Initially, her clothes most appealed to women who favored a high sense of drama in the way they dressed. As personally retiring as her clothes are not, the 37-year-old designer offered daring hip-high swimsuits, jump suits made of parachute cloth, bodysuits in Lycra, broad shoulder pads reminiscent of the 1940's, down coats hinting of sleeping bags. But Miss Kamali has expanded her business to include a noted ready-to-wear line, which gave new panache to sweatshirting, for the Jones Apparel Group Inc., as well as a collection of shoes for Vittorio Ricci and stockings and socks for Camp Hosiery. Thus, she seems to have struck a responsive chord in a growing number of women with a less theatrical bent. All of this, of course, in addition to the children's clothes she designs for Empire Shield.

title: Paris Hotels
description: To the Editor:

title: JAPAN SET TO KEEP LIMITS ON EXPORTS OF ITS CARS TO U.S.
description: Japan's trade minister told President Reagan's trade representative today that he favored a proposal to restrain automobile exports to the United States for a third year.

title: CHICAGO'S PRIMARY DRIVE REFLECTING WEAR AND TEAR ON DEMOCRAT'S MACHINE
description: Chicago's professional politicians relish the story of a major conference of mayors some years ago. Mayor John V. Lindsay of New York eloquently addressed his peers on the important role urban mayors should play in leading a social revolution and creating a new way of life in the nation's troubled cities.

title: A FAMILY AFFAIR IN FAIR LAWN
description: FAIR LAWN NO MATTER how ardent his feminism, it's a man of character who can sandwich himself, professionally speaking, between two women. Wolf Kahn has done just this by taking part in ''A Family in Art'' at the Kornbluth Gallery (7-21 Fair Lawn Avenue), and the women in question are his wife, Emily Mason, and her mother, the late Alice Trumbull Mason.

title: Miss Brody Wed To Alan Levow
description: Renee Jan Brody, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Brody of Short Hills, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla., was married yesterday to Alan Douglas Levow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold A. Levow of Atlanta. Rabbi Barry Friedman performed the ceremony at the Brody home in Short Hills.

title: INTERNATIONAL AMUSEMENTS
SCORSESE'S PAST COLORS HIS NEW FILM
description: When Martin Scorsese first read the script for ''The King of Comedy'' in 1974, he dismissed it as a one-gag film. The story of an ambitious young comic who kidnaps a famous talk-show host in order to get himself on television didn't interest him at all. Years passed, and Mr. Scorsese directed, with much acclaim, such movies as ''Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore,'' ''Taxi Driver,'' ''New York, New York'' and ''Raging Bull.''

title: 14 SEIZED BY POLICE
description: A mob of looters broke through the front door of a Queens warehouse yesterday morning and made off with thousands of dollars of merchandise before police officers could get to the scene, authorities said.

title: Rhode Island Vote Plan Fails
description: Rhode Island's new districts for the State Senate were ordered redrawn Friday by three Federal judges who said the Democrats rigged the boundaries to suit their party. ''There can be no doubt,'' the judges said, ''that a political gerrymander did in fact occur in this case.''

title: CITY UP IN ARMS OVER BRIDGE UP IN AIR
description: VENTNOR THIS barrier-island community whose name is familiar to millions of Monopoly players is about to find itself, like Berlin, a city divided.

title: ABBA LOOKS BACK ON ITS FIRST DECADE
description: ''Abba: The Singles'' (Atlantic 80036-1-G) sums up the first decade in the career of the Swedish pop quartet that claims to have sold more albums worldwide (well over 100 million) than any group since the Beatles. With 23 songs sequenced chronologically, the two-disk set traces the development of Abba's sound from a jingly hard-edged pop toward a grander, texturally more expansive mode of synthesizer pop.

title: CONSUMER RATES
O'NEILL BUCKS CONNECTICUT'S FISCAL TIDES
description: As a political document, the proposed budget that Gov. William A. O'Neill sent to Connecticut's General Assembly last week was fashioned to please everyone. As a practical step toward ending the state's financial crisis, it pleased virtually no one.

title: South African Black, 73, Endures 2-Year Trial
description: Lawyers for a venerable black trade union leader, whose trial here on charges of murder and terrorism is about to enter its third year, did not go through the motions of applying for his release on bail this week after the last potential witness against him recanted an earlier statement.

title: Martha Spong to Wed David Edward Bauer
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. William Belser Spong Jr. of Williamsburg, Va., of the engagement of their daughter, Martha Kingman Spong, to David Edward Bauer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Eugene Bauer of Montclair, N.J.

title: AIR BAGS' DELAYED COST
description: To the Editor:

title: DECLINING PROFITS IMPERIL RECYCLING
description: THE recession that has engulfed the country is threatening to claim another victim -Westchester's municipal recycling programs. During the last six months five municipalities have stopped recycling paper, aluminum and glass, and many others are ready to stop their programs if no way is found to make them pay for themselves.

title: HOW A THEATER STRUGGLES FOR ITS LIFE
description: IN its struggle to secure a foothold in the regional theater firmament, the Hartman Theater in Stamford, Conn., may be reversing a stereotype, and devising a new strategy for survival.

title: Arline Wheat And Lawyer Are Married
description: Arline Cornelia Wheat, daughter of Mrs. McCole Wheat of Alexandria, Va., was married in Manhattan yesterday to Carter Weaver Eltzroth 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eltzroth Jr. of Boston. The Rev. William J. Byron, president of the Catholic University of America in Washington, performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More.

title: PEEKSKILL CENTER OF ALTAR WAFER INDUSTRY
description: MOST laymen call them communion wafers, and the Episcopal and Roman Catholic sisters in Peekskill call them altar bread. By any name, more than 22 million of them are made in Peekskill every year.

title: Paying Taxes In Glen Cove
description: The article ''Glen Cove Mansion Faces Vote on Fate'' (Jan. 30) inadvertently lists the Glengariff Nursing Home among those large parcels that are untaxed by the City of Glen Cove. The Glengariff Nursing Home happens to be one of the largest taxpayers in the City of Glen Cove. KENNETH WINSTON, Administrator, Glengariff Corporation, Glen Cove

title: Bulau Equals Hill Mark In Canadian Ski Jump
description: Horst Bulau, who ranks second in the World Cup, tied the hill record today in taking the 70-meter competition at the Canadian ski-jumping championships.

title: FLORIDA PARKS: OFFBEAT HAVENS
description: HAROLD FABER contributes to The Times from upstate New York.

title: Page Defeats Frazier On Unanimous Decision
description: Greg Page, the World Boxing Council's No.2-ranked heavyweight, used superior quickness to take a unanimous decision over Larry Frazier in a 10-round bout at Public Hall today.

title: TOXIC WASTES ARE A POLITICAL PROBLEM, TOO
description: President Reagan's abrupt dismissal of Rita M. Lavelle, a top official at the Environmental Protection Agency, was officially described early last week as a matter that had more to do with personalities than policies. But before long it became clear that the firing presented Mr. Reagan and his aides with a potentially serious political crisis.

title: 'HOW-TO' HINTS FOR THE DISABLED
description: DURING the last year and a half of Emily Clark's life, she was paralyzed as a result of a debilitating illness. Suzanne Lunt of Great Neck, Mrs. Clark's daughter, helped care for her mother as she grew less able to do things for herself.

title: A SKYSCAPER FIRE IN LAGOS CAUSES PANGS OF CONSCIENCE
description: When Nigeria expelled hundreds of thousands of foreigners recently, many of its people cheered; only a few questioned the effect on the nation's self-image. But another, less publicized event has brought greater self-doubt to black Africa's wealthiest, most populous and least restrained country. It has raised questions about where Nigeria is heading and what kind of society its riches have produced. On Jan. 24, in downtown Lagos, a great conflagration engulfed the 32-story External Telecommunications Building that had been the city's emblem of modernity.

title: Anne Arenstein Married to Dr. Richard S. Sarason
description: Anne Arenstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Arenstein of Cincinnati, was married there yesterday to Dr. Richard Samuel Sarason, son of Cornelia S.
