Sarason of Southfield, Mich., and C. Kenneth Sarason of Laguna Hills, Calif. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Jakob J. Petuchowski and Rabbi Abraham Ingber at the Hillel Jewish Student Center.

title: For Love of Mutts
description: If canines ever get the franchise, Dan Barnshaw could certainly be elected dogcatcher. Mr. Barnshaw, an animal control officer in Rosenberg, Texas, was ordered suspended from his job last week after someone tattled that he had released three dogs he was supposed to kill. Mr. Barnshaw said he had been unable to find homes for the mongrels in the 72 hours permitted under local rules and just couldn't bear to shoot them - he had already destroyed 11 others that day. He said he drove them out of town, opened their cage and said, ''Get out of here.''

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Expensive Satisfaction Guaranteed

title: U.S. OUTLAYS GROW WHILE STATES' DIP
description: Despite President Reagan's efforts to return authority to the states, Federal spending has been increasing rapidly while that of state and local governments has declined, according to a new study by a nonpartisan research group.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: LONG ISLAND was one of the pioneer stops for electronic communications, a jumping-off place for messages that winged their way across the sea from Amagansett, where, for decades, a wireless station served as a vital link in peace and especially in war with foreign lands and ships at sea. Nowadays, the communications industry is more of an internal affair for Long Islanders, whose very lives are dominated by television, radio, automatic telephone answering machines, antennas designed to pluck programs from space and, most recently, the television recorder.

title: 28-38 Years in Working Life
description: The average man can expect to work about 38 years and the average woman 28 years, the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics says. The data, obtained in studies for 1977, reflected a sharp increase in women's work life.

title: FROM ENGLAND TO BROOKLYN TO WEST VIRGINIA
description: NO FOND RETURN OF LOVE By Barbara Pym. 254 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $12.95.

title: Lyrical Novels
description: To the Editor:

title: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 13, 1983
description: International Japan favors continued restraint on its car exports to the United States. The Minister of Trade told President Reagan's trade representative in Tokyo that he favored a proposal to restrain the exports for a third year. At the same time, Japanese trade officials said that they had agreed to limit Japanese exports of videotape recorders to the European Economic Community for three years, and would establish a minimum price system governing the shipments. (Page 1, Col.1.) Israel's opposition leader said that he wanted to meet with Prime Minister Menachem Begin to discuss how to keep the peace between Israel's opposing political and social factions. The proposal by Shimon Peres, head of the Labor Party, followed a hand grenade attack on a group of anti-Government demonstrators outside Mr. Begin's office Thursday night. A man killed in the attack was described by Mr. Peres as ''the first victim on the altar of democracy in Israel.'' (1:2.)

title: Human Rights, Such as They Are
description: On the whole, Assistant Secretary of State Elliott Abrams said last week, Vietnam may be ''the worse country to live in'' for people who value human rights. Some 60,000 Vietnamese are political prisoners, according to the Administration's annual survey of what countries around the world have been doing to the lives and liberties of their citizens.

title: WHEN DISASTER STRIKES, WHO PAYS?
description: RESIDENTS of apartments that have been damaged by fire, burst steam p ipes, water leaks or similar misfortunes must resolve the extent to w hich the building owner is responsible for the damage, and what parto f the repair or replacement cost is their own responsibility.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:On my first visit to Europe several years ago, I became quite interested in the history of World War II. For the first time, the names of cities and battles became real. Unfortunately, most tour books I had access to only briefly mentioned certain points of interest to see in relation to the war. I am planning another trip to Europe this summer and I was wondering if you could direct me to reference material concerning the history and sites of World War II. - R.T.M., Minneapolis, Minn. Answer:Drew Middleton, the military correspondent of The New York Times, suggests that the best overall work on World War II might be Winston Churchill's five volumes entitled ''The Second World War.''

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: ENVIRONMENTAL education has become ''an important priority'' in Jersey City schools, according to Roy Beeler, coordinator of joint activities for the city's Board of Education.

title: HELPING THE LEARNING DISABLED
description: IF football players, their managers and coaches seem to be ardent supporters of the Foundation for Children with Learning Disabilities, it may be because of the persuasive powers of the group's president and founder, Carrie Rozelle. Mrs. Rozelle, who lives in Harrison, is the wife of the Commissioner of the National Football League, Pete Rozelle.

title: Louisville 81, Marquette 73
description: MILWAUKEE (AP) - Lancaster Gordon sank 11 of his first 12 shots and scored 21 of his 27 points in the second half today as Louisville held off a late rally to defeat Marquette.

title: SADAT'S HALF BROTHER IS SENTENCED TO JAIL
description: The half brother of President Anwar el-Sadat and three of the half-brother's sons were sentenced today to one-year prison terms for corruption.

title: CONGRESS'S BUDGET OFFICE PULLS THE DEFICIT ALARM
description: THE President is required by law to send Congress a five-year budget the White House would like to see in place. Ronald Reagan did that two weeks ago. The Congressional Budget Office's mandate is to evaluate economic and fiscal trends and to present -but not recommend - means to set them right. Precisely because it was not a political document, the unvarnished analysis and evenhanded menu for change the office and its founding director, Alice M. Rivlin, offered last week was all the more sobering.

title: FISCAL PROBLEMS IN NASSAU TIED TO INFLATION
description: HOW serious is Nassau County's fiscal problem? ''It's real, no doubt about it,'' said Peter King, the County Comptroller. ''Very severe,'' said Richard M. Kessel, a civic activist. ''I think we're outdoing Abe Beame because we are underplaying the numbers. In December and January the county said there was no deficit. Now they admit it's $36.7 million with a potential for $50 million, and I feel it's closer to $70 million.''

title: Travel Discounts
description: To the Editor:

title: CALIFORNIA ADOPTS A $1 FILL-IN-THE-BLANKS WILL
description: California has become the first state to approve a standard will that allows people with modest assets to plan their estates at a cost of a dollar.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: A Bronx Lamp Shop Bright With Bargains

title: SHE SNARED AGATHA CHRISTIE'S SHORT STORIES FOR TELEVISION
JERSEY CITY VOTING ON FORM OF GOVERNMENT
description: JERSEY CITY VOTERS here will have a chance Tuesday to turn back the clock to the city commission form of government and the era of Frank Hague. Jersey City converted from the five-member city commission to the present form, a mayor and nine councilmen, in 1962, and the current drive to reverse the process appears aimed more at unseating Mayor Gerald McCann than at establishing a more-efficient system of government.

title: CAMPUS GETS HAUTE CUISINE
description: MAYS LANDING THE newest ''classroom'' at Atlantic Community College - a softly lighted, expensive French restaurant - was opened to the public last Wednesday. The restaurant, Careme's, on a wooded, 546-acre parcel of the Pine Barrens near here, is for students of the college's Academy of Culinary Arts.

title: Camacho Knocks Out Montes in First Round
description: Hector (Macho) Camacho put in a strong bid for a title fight with a first-round knockout today of John Montes in a lightweight match.

title: DISKS DISPLAY SIDNEY BECHET'S MELODIES
description: Groups that specialize in traditional jazz tend to draw their repertories from the overworked Dixieland and New Orleans repertories - ''Muskrat Ramble,'' ''That's A Plenty,'' ''Just A Closer Walk With Thee,'' ''Royal Garden Blues'' and ''Panama'' are among the more frequently recorded tunes. Or they borrow material from the recordings of Louis Armstrong and Bix Beiderbecke and Jelly Roll Morton.

title: The Right to a Lease
description: Question: I am a senior citizen and have lived in a rent-stabilized apartment for 15 years. Several months ago, the building was converted to cooperative ownership under a noneviction plan. My lease expired last Sept. 30, and since October I have paid a 10 percent increase. I asked the outsider who bought my apartment to give me a three-year lease, but he refused. A few weeks ago, I received a letter though his lawyer stating that circumstances have drastically altered his need for accommodations for his client and asking if I would move in the foreseeable future. My reply was that I had no intention of moving. Am I entitled to a three-year lease? What should I do? ... L.K., Manhattan Answer: Jane Rosenberg, assistant attorney general, says that you have all the rights of a rent-stabilized tenant, including the right to a lease. The landlord may ask you to move voluntarily, but you do not have to. In addition, Section 352eeee of the General Business Law says a nonpurchasing tenant in a noneviction plan cannot be evicted by an owner who seeks the unit for personal use.

title: WITH SCHILLER, GOETHE AND HEINE
GATT and Taxes
description: To the Business Editor: The pro and con positions on consumption taxes (''Do We Need a 'Consumption' Tax?'' Jan.30) completely overlooked one extremely important concept - that of trade.

title: A DEVELOPER APPRAISES THE MOUNT LAUREL II DECISION
description: TO UNDERSTAND the importance of the Mount Laurel II decision, you must understand four factors that make New Jersey unusual among the states. These factors have restricted development and created the strange anomaly wherein raw-land costs are among the lowest in the nation and finished-lot costs are second only to those in Hawaii.

title: SITUATION COMEDIES IN NEED OF NEW SITUATIONS
description: Assorted sages and analytical researchers have observed that the history of literature can lay claim to about a half-dozen basic story plots. Television's situation comedy, it seems, can get along with even fewer. As the mid-season schedule adjustments get under way, summary descriptions of the new sit-coms can trigger severe deja-vu. Clearly, variations, however slight, are all.

title: Teatime
description: To the Editor: While afternoon tea, as described in Pamela Harlech's article, ''Taking Tea in London Town'' (Travel, Jan. 23) is definitely something to have when visiting there, if only to observe the English relaxing, one should also have tea in a suburban tea shop as is found in Rottingdean, a small town east of Brighton. Here the tea shop is a 17th-century cottage (watch the low beams) where, in the winter, a fire is burning quite briskly.

title: AN ENEMY OF THE CHINESE STATE
description: SON OF THE REVOLUTION By Liang Heng and Judith Shapiro. 301 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.

title: Princeton 54, Dartmouth 44
description: The senior forward Craig Robinson, matching his career game high of 20, and the freshman guard John Smyth combined for 36 points to lead Princeton.

title: Mary M. DeWitt To Marry in May
description: Announcement has been made of the engagement of Mary Marsh DeWitt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Abbott DeWitt of New Canaan, Conn., to Philip Waldo Elmer Faflick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Edward Faflick of Lexington, Mass. A May wedding is planned.

title: TURNING TAP DANCE INTO TOTAL THEATER
MEDAL-WINNING PLAY; NORTH S A K J 4 H A 5 D Q 8 6 4 C A 4 2
description: WEST EAST S 7 5 2 S 9 8 6 H 6 H 9 8 4 3 2 D A K 10 5 2 D J 9 3 C J 9 8 7 C 6 5 SOUTH(D) S Q 10 3 H K Q J 10 7 D 7 C K Q 10 3 North and South were vulnerable. The bidding: South West North East 1 H 2 D 3 D Pass 3 H Pass 4 D Pass 4 H Pass 6 H Pass Pass Pass West led the diamond king.

title: SOVIET EMPLOYEE AT U.N. GETS ASYLUM
description: A Soviet employee of the Secretariat was given political asylum in the United States on Friday, but intends to fight to keep his job at the United Nations, his American lawyer said.

title: ANTIPOLICE SUIT FOCUSES ON A TOWN'S ILLS
description: San Francisco's towers loom through the mist 10 miles southwest across the Bay, but this is a working man's town, not a bedroom suburb. The vote is Democratic, the ethic bluecollar, and the toil, whether in shipbuilding or in the huge refinery, has always needed toughness and brawn.

title: AID GROUPS IN U.S. WORRY OVER FUNDS
description: Leading private aid organizations in the United States are experiencing a time of disquiet over dwindling resources and their changing relationship with the Federal Government.

title: When Steam Trains Rode the Tracks
description: Linda B. Martin's ''Are We on the Right Track?'' (Opinion Page, Jan. 23) brought to mind the Long Island Rail Road I knew so well in the 1930's, growing up next to the railroad in Bay Shore long after the Indians lost their lands to the more sophisticated white man. My grandmother recalled the Indians who lived on the Island during her childhood, the clear, unpolluted water, the abundance of fish and shellfish in the Great South Bay, all slowly disappearing with the advent of burgeoning humanity.

title: FICTION PIECES TO BE OFFERED TO 10 PAPERS
description: The columns of daily newspapers were once a fertile area for aspiring writers of fiction. The National Endowment for the Arts is about to spend $120,000 to see if they could be again.

title: BOTHA'S BID TO CHANGE ALL-WHITE RULE RESISTED
description: A month ago, Prime Minister P.W. Botha appeared to score a remarkable breakthrough when the Labor Party, the largest political grouping among the mixed-race population that is officially classified as colored, decided to seek a place in the new constitutional order that Mr. Botha has been methodically trying to hammer together.

title: LET'S END OUR OWN TRADE BARRIERS FIRST
description: THE United States is in danger of taking the lead in the current r ush toward protectionism. Public policy debates are now dominated byo ne-sided, self-serving views of international trade. Everyone wants o pen markets and free trade overseas. We all know how urgent it is toe liminate ''their'' barriers to our exports. But our barriers in the U nited States to their exports do not generate much interest over h ere.

title: 'Informer' Meter
description: The world may not have been waiting for it, but Jerome H. Lemelson, who is used to building mousetraps that are ahead of their time, believed the hour was propitious for his latest creation: a parking meter that registers the coins inserted and radios the police when the payment runs out.

title: Not Just the Dollar
description: To the Business Editor: Ronald McKinnon suggests in ''How a Strong Dollar Threw the Fed'' (Jan.23), and in ''How to Coordinate Central Bank Policies'' (Jan.30), that the current world recession would not have been as painful had the Federal Reserve made an effort to contain the strength of the dollar in the last two years.

title: THE BLUE-CHIP FIRMS REMAIN MOSTLY WHITE
description: A black executive of a Fortune 500 company recently said that for non-whites, corporate America is now what baseball was before Jackie Robinson. Measured by that metaphor, the status of black and Hispanic and other minority lawyers in the leading corporate law firms is akin to that of Robinson, Larry Doby and the handful of other blacks in the major leagues shortly after the color line was broken: underrepresented, uncomfortable and, in some instances, unwanted.

title: Video Lottery Develops a Blip
description: Noting that recent events had ''cast serious doubts'' on a proposed New Jersey video lottery, Governor Kean last week indefinitely postponed an experiment with the game, to be played on Pac-Man-like machines, while investigators pursue conflict of interest charges involving Lottery Commission officials.

title: THEATER: 'COMEDY OF ERRORS' WITH KARAMAZOVS
description: As virtuosi of the New Vaudeville, the Flying Karamazov Brothers - a team of unrelated young American zanies - juggle everything from tenpins to telephones, from pussycats to pepperoni pizza. At the Goodman Theater, they are proving that they can also juggle Shakespeare. Gregory Mosher, the artistic director of the Goodman, has had the inspiration to match the Karamazovs' breakaway clowning with a classic text, and the result is an irreverent, unbridled assault on ''The Comedy of Errors.''

title: NEW HOMES SHAPED TO A VICTORIAN IMAGE
description: PROSPECTIVE home buyers with a penchant for the architectural styleso f the past often have only two alternatives. They can buy a c enturyold house with poor insulation, outdated living space and r otting exterior woodwork and hope to make it livable. Or they can b uy a new house and decorate it with pictures and furnishings that e voke only a vestige of the atmosphere they want to attain. But therei s another way.

title: OPERATING IN SPACE
description: The high point of all submarine movies for me was always the appendectomy. Everybody knows the scene. The submarine, silent on the sea bottom, is under heavy depth-charge attack with lights flickering on and off, and water leaking through the seams, and the whole crew staring at the sonar phones with the sound of enemy destroyers coming nearer and nearer, and a case of acute appendicitis in the enlisted men's mess.

title: Suspected Mass Killer Is Remanded in London
description: A 37-year-old British civil servant who told the police that he had strangled and dismembered 16 young drifters was remanded in jail today on a single murder charge.

title: PRO BASKETBALL'S EARLY DAYS AND THE HINTS OF THINGS TO COME
description: time sports city, but then, the National Basketball League wasn't big-time, either. So when the Warren Penns entered the National Basketball League in its inaugural season of 1937-38, there was rejoicing among sports fans in the town of 14,000 nestled in the foothills of the Allegheny Mountains, but nary a ripple on the professional sports scene. In those Depression years, major league baseball was king; football was a remote second, and basketball was barely visible on the horizon.

title: TALES OF THE GIANT STORM: CAMARADERIE AND MISERY
description: Side by side on cots in firehouses, in seats on stranded buses or sitting on the floors of hotel lobbies, thousands of strangers far from home spent Friday night and yesterday morning together.

title: CRIME UPDATE
description: INVESTIGATION OF 4 NEW YEAR'S EVE BOMBINGS FOLLOWS SEVERAL TRACKS By LEONARD BUDER

title: Aoki In 3-Way Golf Tie
description: Isao Aoki, seeking to become the first Japanese to win on the PGA Tour, scored a pair of eagles on the way to a seven-under-par 65 that lifted him into a three-way tie for the lead today in the third round of the $325,000 Hawaiian Open.

title: Pioneer Surgery
description: Parkinson's disease, sometimes called ''shaking palsy,'' is a sickness of unknowns. The brain cells do not produce enough dopamine, a substance that plays a key role in muscle control.

title: Busy Night of Boxing
description: There will be 78 scheduled rounds of boxing, featuring world contenders from South America, on the undercard March 18 when Michael Spinks and Dwight Braxton fight for the unified light-heavyweight championship, it was announced yesterday by Butch Lewis, the promoter. The best of the undercard fighters may be Jose Flores, a high-ranking light-heavyweight from Uruguay, who will meet Dave Wigfall, a journeyman from Brockton, Mass., in one of the seven scheduled 10-rounders at Atlantic City's Convention Hall.

title: No Headline
description: To the Business Editor:

title: JUDGE DISMISSES ASSAULT CASE FOR MISSED DEADLINE
description: A State Supreme Court justice has thrown out assault and weapons charges against a defendant in a case stemming from two ganglandstyle slayings and a shootout with a police officer.

title: AMERICAN MUSIC ENLIVENS LONDON
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Nicholas Kenyon is a music critic for The Times of London. LONDON This is an extraordinary season for American music in London. During the past two weeks, the London Sinfonietta, the capital's leading contemporary music ensemble (somewhere between a large-scale Speculum Musicae and a small-scale, permanent American Composers Orchestra) has mounted a pair of Anglo-American concerts in which not only established figures but also lesser known composers like Peter Lieberson and Nick Thorne have been featured. Ten days ago the Sinfonietta appeared in a BBC concert under Gunther Schuller's direction, giving the first British hearings of Donald Martino's Triple Concerto and Gerald Levinson's ''Light Dances: Stones Sing.''

title: Margaret Streeter to Wed D. W. Lauck
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank S. Streeter of New York and Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Montgomery Streeter, to Daniel W. Lauck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bob Lauck of Topeka, Kan. A July wedding is planned.

title: Susan A. Whipple Married To Andrew Wald on Coast
description: Susan Auchincloss Whipple, daughter of Hope A. Whipple of New York and Edgartown, Mass., and George A. Whipple of Middletown, N.J., was married yesterday to Andrew Ross Wald, son of Mrs. Jerry Wald of Beverly Hills, Calif., and the late Mr. Wald.

title: HAS THE GETTY MUSEUM SHAKEN THE ART WORLD?; MALIBU, Calif.
description: When the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif., came into rather more than a billion dollars not so long ago, people talked as if there had been nothing like it since Jupiter presented himself to Danae in the guise of a shower of gold.

title: SOME ROGUISH 60'S ART ACHIEVES MUSEUM STATUS
description: happy, protestprone 1960's was Fluxus, a loose-knit international collection of object-makers, poets, performers, eventists and anti-musicians allergic to the Establishment scene. The prime mover was the late George Maciunas, a Lithuanian-born graphics designer and self-styled ''agitator'' who helped hatch Fluxus in 1962, along with such other undergroundlings as Dick Higgins, Alison Knowles, Yoko Ono, Bob Watts and George Brecht. With roots in Dada and Futurism, Fluxus was described by Maciunas as ''a fusion of Spike Jones, vaudeville, gags, children's games and Duchamp.'' Though the 60's was really its heydey, from 1962 until Maciunas's death in 1978 at the age of 47, Fluxus was a prolific producer of satirical manifestos, jokey multiples, hit-and-run concerts, cheap publications, street events and theater pieces, quixotically devoted to making art ''unlimited, mass-produced, obtainable by all and eventually produced by all.'' And its participants, at one time or another, included Christo, Joseph Beuys, Nam June Paik, Wolf Vostell, Ben Vautier, Kate Millett, Daniel Spoerri, La Monte Young, Emmett Williams, Geoff Hendricks and Joe Jones.

title: STIEGLITZ FELT THE PULL OF TWO CULTURES
description: To understand what Modernism has meant for photography, we inevitably have to take into account the vast and continuing influence of Alfred Stieglitz. In the course of his complex career he functioned as a critic, editor, gallery owner, promoter, enthusiast and nurturer, but he started as a photographer and he remained one throughout his life. It is his photography, then, that is the focus of the excellent exhibition, ''Alfred Stieglitz,'' which opened Feb. 3 at the National Gallery of Art's freshly renovated West Building galleries. Using 171 exquisite examples drawn from a set of 1,600 key Stieglitz prints donated to the Washington museum by the artist Georgia O'Keeffe, guest curators Sarah Greenough and Juan Hamilton have in large measure accomplished their aim of ''demystifying'' this premier American photographer's achievement.

title: Costa Rica
description: To the Editor: For the benefit of readers who would enjoy seeing the exhibition of Costa Rica's ''most spectacular pieces of pre-Columbian art'' mentioned in June Blum's story, ''Between Continents/Between Seas: Pre-Columbian Art of Costa Rica'' (Travel, Jan. 9), I would like to point out that the show will appear at The Detroit Institute of Arts March 9 through May 22.

title: FROM ENGLAND TO BROOKLYN TO WEST VIRGINIA
description: TEMPLE By Robert Greenfield. 411 pp. New York: Summit Books. $15.95.

title: No Headline
description: TOP IRISH DETECTIVE LEADS SEARCH FOR STOLEN HORSE

title: JUDITH LIPSON IS ENGAGED
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Lipson of Newton Centre, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Judith Ann Lipson, to Seth Brauer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Brauer of Eastchester, N.Y. Miss Lipson is a branch coordinator with Bloomingdale's department store in New YOrk. Her fiance is president of his own marketing concern in New York.

title: EXPENSES LANDLORDS PASS ALONG
description: TENANTS say it is unfair. Landlords and city administrators defend i t. Politicians call it a tradeoff. The issue is the rent increases a llowed for major capital improvements in rent-stabilized and r entcontrolled apartment buildings in New York.

title: MINNESOTA HAS A HANDY INDEX TO FISCAL WOES
description: Minnesota has long ranked high among the states for its clean politics, humane public services and progressive tax structure. But of late it has been beset by revenue deficits, cuts in services and regressive taxes, largely as the consequence of the state government trying, in typical Minnesota fashion, to put itself on a more honest footing with its taxpayers.

title: Energy Head Issues Warning On Funds for Reactor Project
description: Energy Secretary Donald P. Hodel has warned that the Clinch River breeder reactor could be scrapped if the nuclear power industry did not provide more private funds for it.

title: 15 BODIES FOUND IN SOUTH LEBANON
description: Fifteen bodies have been found near a Palestinian refugee camp in an area of southern Lebanon where death threats are being directed against Palestinians, the United Nations Relief and Works Agency said today.

title: WILDE'S 'EARNEST,' FUN TO THE LAST PUN
description: year-old Great Neck theater with a star-studded but short-lived stage past - and a more recent history as a movie house - opened last fall. The attractions were a series of two-night stands: an opera, a revue, a ballet, a chamber music recital and a couple of children's shows.

title: Linda Stockton Betrothed
description: Mrs. William Stockton of St. Petersburg, Fla., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Linda Kay Stockton, to Steven J. Siesel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Siesel of Mamaroneck, N.Y. An August wedding is planned. The future bride, daughter also of the late Mr. Stockton, is a nutritionist with the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania. Her fiance is a news photographer at KYW-TV, Philadelphia. fundraising organization in Greenwich. His previous marriage ended in

title: Lynn Henry to Marry Thomas James in June
description: The engagement of Lynn Susan Henry to Thomas N. James has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Leon Henry Jr. of Scarsdale, N.Y., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Guido James of Milford, Conn.

title: 25 DIE IN SINKING OFF VIRGINIA
description: Snowbound and paralyzed by the worst winter storm in 36 years, the mid-Atlantic states and the New York metropolitan area yesterday began digging out of mountainous drifts. Life for millions of people came to a near standstill.

title: CASTING CAN BE A PIVOTAL SKILL
description: Linda Hunt is the tiny, androgynous actress without whom Peter Weir's ''Year of Living Dangerously'' probably never could have been made. It isn't that Miss Hunt, who plays a peculiarly omnipresent male journalist named Billy Kwan, steals the movie from its romantic leads; both Sigourney Weaver and Mel Gibson are as coolly glamorous as their roles require. It's simply that Miss Hunt, in the role of the Eurasian dwarf who seems to orchestrate the story, contributes a sense of strangeness that's essential to the film and that is not otherwise fully provided. Without her transfixing presence, this might be just another love story set in a foreign land; with it, the film develops the genuinely exotic quality that is its most distinctive feature.

title: NORTH WOODS HIDEAWAYS
description: If midwinter cold and snow bring you visions of cross-country skiing and other frosty pastimes rather than of lolling on tropical beaches, then you might find the North Woods of Wisconsin, with its country inns and lodges, just the place for a winter getaway.

title: Nuclear Facility Hires A Drug-Sniffing Dog
description: A dog trained to sniff out narcotics has been brought in to patrol a nuclear power plant near here as part of a stepped-up campaign to prevent drug use at the facility.

title: ADVOCATE'S OFFICE QUITS UTILITY TALKS
description: NEWARK THE state's Public Advocate has pulled out of negotiations seeking an agreement between that office and the Public Service Electric and Gas Company that the utility withdraw until July 1 its request for a $464.5 million increase in gas and electric rates.

title: Data Bank; Feb. 13, 1983
IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: JAZZ Until the death of Cannonball Adderley in 1975, his younger brother, Nat, a cornetist, spent a good part of his career playing in the shadow of the elder Mr. Adderley - literally, since Cannonball was a man of ample proportions and Nat is short and muscularly compact; figuratively, since Cannonball's style on alto saxophone was broad and expansive, in contrast to the lean, incisive staccato phrasing used by his brother. Even the billing of the group, ''The Cannonball Adderley Quintet Featuring Nat Adderley,'' gave the full glow of the spotlight to Cannonball.

title: Eileen Carmody Is a Bride
description: Eileen Carmody, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Barrett Carmody of Danbury, Conn., was married yesterday to James Strother Kreuttner, son of Mrs. Joseph Warwick Kreuttner of Ossining, N.Y., and the late Mr. Kreuttner.

title: New Marrow Made Easier
description: For people with certain types of leukemia, anemia or a severe deficiency in their immune defense system, the problem literally cuts right to the bone. But scientists at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center reported last week that a new bone marrow transplant technique offers to make a hitherto unconventional cure far more available.

title: GOVERNOR SEEKS SUPPORT FOR NEW TAXES
description: HARTFORD THE General Assembly, which had been moving at a leisurely pace since convening Jan. 5, found its agenda sharply altered last week by Governor O'Neill's budget message.

title: Love I: Men For Women to Woo
description: Man-hunting has become a respectable women's sport. Females in search of a date or a mate are willing, even eager, to be the aggressors. What's more, they're interested in buying books about their quarry. With these ideas in mind, several publishing houses are issuing profiles - complete with addresses and photographs - of men who are available and, in many cases, beautiful besides.

title: BOBBY KNIGHT NEVER LEARNS
description: AMERICA'S coach has done it again. Bobby Knight, who is scheduled to coach the American basketball team at the 1984 Olympics, has once again made disparaging remarks toward the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, this time in a speech in Gary, Ind.

title: Temperatures Are Rising On Salvador
description: Among the casualties suffered by El Salvador in three years of guerrilla war, loss of control to decision-makers in Washington must be counted among the most wounding. Life or death decisions - whether aid is to be maintained or increased, and even whether Salvadoran leaders are to be pushed into negotiations with leftists who have been outmaneuvering them - will greatly depend on the actions of a Congress impatient with Salvadoran progress and Administration policy.

title: LOS ANGELES GANGS HEEDING COURT ORDER TO ERASE GRAFFITI
description: On the city's storefronts, billboards, houses and cinderblock fences, there is a new look: the clean wall. Such structures are emerging from the spray paint of gangs' graffiti wars, but neither businessmen nor homeowners did the cleaning up.

title: NEW MARCH OF TOY SOLDIERS
description: Toy buyers from across the country converged on New York last week to wade through acres of dolls, games, popguns, construction kits, swing sets and model cars at the 80th annual American Toy Fair. The buyers' goal: deciding what will be big in 1983. Executives from video-games companies were all smiles at the show. The retail market for video toys nearly doubled last year, reaching about $3.1 billion, and it is expected to climb to $4 billion this year. The folks who make toys that are not electronic had less to be happy about. Their overall

title: WIRETAP SUIT STIRS NEW HAVEN DISPUTE
description: NEW HAVEN THE author John Hersey remembers hearing strange clicks on his telephone in 1970. So when he saw his name on a list published last month of subjects of possible police wiretapping, it was more a confirmation of his suspicions than a surprise.

title: 'KING OF PRUSSIA, ' WITH BERRIGAN BROTHERS
description: Expediency was undoubtedly a factor in determining the plain, rough-edged style of Emile de Antonio's ''In the King of Prussia,'' which has been filmed on videotape for a relatively tiny sum. The film's minimalism is also clearly intentional, as Mr. De Antonio begins with footage of a graffiti artist furtively spray-painting the film's title on a white wall, and continues through a series of crudely staged courtroom scenes depicting the trial of a group calling itself the Plowshares 8.

title: Knicks Obtain Rory Sparrow
description: The Knicks, in need of backcourt help, obtained Rory Sparrow from the Atlanta Hawks tonight on the eve of the National Basketball Association All-Star Game for Scott Hastings and $600,000 in cash.

title: WHAT THE ISRAELI COMMISSION SAID
description: Following are excerpts of key points in the report of the Israeli commission of inquiry: ''Our conclusion is therefore that the direct responsibility for the perpetration of the acts of slaughter rests on the Phalangist forces.'' *

title: PROVINCETOWN LOOKS FOR HELP TO AVERT SEVERE WATER CRISIS
description: With luck and some help from the Cape Cod National Seashore, Provincetown hopes to avert a severe water problem this summer when thousands of tourists and seasonal residents descend on this popular resort town. Without such help, a town official said, Provincetown could face a critical situation.

title: Houston Conflict
description: It seems likely that Houston will get a franchise in the United State Football League in the next couple of years, but it is not so likely that Jerry Argovitz, a sports attorney, will head it, according to a Houston attorney, Don Fisher. Yesterday, Fisher said, ''Argovitz definitely does not have the franchise.

title: AN Opportunity To Make a Deal On Making Jobs
description: In the politics of economics, everybody has his troubles. Last week, the White House's were with President Reagan, and Capitol Hill Democrats' were with each other. Congress and the Administration, however, were getting along just fine. After a private meeting between top White House officials and the House leadership on the touchiest of immediate issues - recession relief for some of the 12 million workers on the official unemployment list - agreement seemed near on a $4.3 billion job package that would have distinct advantages for both sides.

title: A VALENTINE ESPECIALLY FOR THE FORGOTTEN
description: TOMORROW we will be professing our fondest feelings for those special people in our lives. We'll be sharing cards and candy, flowers and other tokens of affection with sweethearts and spouses and a host of folks who, for whatever reasons, hold a spot in our hearts.

title: HIGH DEMAND BUOYS MARKET FOR CO-OPS
description: ALL kinds of housing in all parts of the country have been selling f or less lately - or at least for less than sellers' expectations - a nd New York City co-ops and condominiums have been no exception. Buta fter going through a sluggish period last year, the co-op market h ere has begun a modest recovery, and the prospects for long-term p rice growth in that market are stronger than they are for the s ingle-family homes that dominate the housing market elsewhere in them etropolitan region and in the nation as a whole, according to e conomists and real-estate specialists. The experts also believe, h owever, that the rapid run-ups in co-op prices of the late 1970's a nd early 80's are over.

title: PERES BIDS BEGIN MEET TO DISCUSS ISRAELI VIOLENCE
description: Shimon Peres, head of Israel's opposition Labor Party, said today that he wanted to meet with Prime Minister Menachem Begin to discuss how to keep the peace between opposing political and social factions in Israel.

title: SHOREHAM RADIO ADS: AIRING AN ISSUE
description: For several months the Long Island Lighting Company has been placing ads on Long Island radio stations concerning its Shoreham nuclear power plant. Recently the Shoreham Opponents Coalition, which has been trying to prevent the plant from starting operation, prepared scripts for broadcast, replying to the Lilco ads. The following is a letter sent by Michael R. Patterson, Lilco's director of communications, to Long Island radio stations:

title: REHABILITATION INCENTIVE IS AT A LEGISLATIVE CROSSROADS
description: ON a pleasant residential street called Carlton Avenue in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn stands an e mpty four-story Italianate brownstone that the owner wants to sell. The owner is a 28-year-old Columbia graduate with a master's degreei n anthropology. He does not want his name disclosed or his property i dentified out of concern that this would complicate his sales e ffort.

title: A PLAY THAT FALLS VICTIM TO ITS AUTHOR'S ATTENTIONS
description: In a way, Arthur Miller seems as obsessed with his play ''A View From the Bridge'' as the play's longshoreman hero, Eddie Carbone, is obsessed with desire for the niece he has taken into his home and reared. One feels that ever since ''A View From the Bridge'' was first seen here in 1955, Mr. Miller has stared at it, brooded over it, prodded it and manipulated it and stretched it every which way, unable to put it down until he'd made it grow up. And we know there have been times in the past when this sort of self-critical reworking produced admirable results for one or another playwright. There are also times when it produces a kind of dramatic forgetfulness: the author has tampered with the text so often that he's quite forgotten what's in it and what's not, whereupon he winds up doing some scenes three or four times over and some scenes not at all. In which case the play isn't really rewritten, it's just overwritten. I'm afraid that ''A View From the Bridge'' now belongs to this latter group, victim of the very propinquity that proved so troublesome to Eddie Carbone.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
IN SMALL CLAIMS COURT, THE DECISIONS OF SOLOMON
description: so-dark corners of people's lives; he is intrigued by the sort of dilemmas others call trivial, or dull or at least undramatic.

title: NEIL SIMON PREMIERE
description: A new play by Neil Simon will have its premiere in Stamford Feb. 23 through March 13 at the Hartman Theater on Atlantic Street, with previews scheduled Friday through next Tuesday.

title: Soviet Symptoms Of Withdrawal
description: Many Western observers consider Soviet psychiatry a tool of the state used primarily to punish dissidents who are mentally well rather than to treat patients who are mentally ill. Western psychiatrists have tried pressuring Soviet colleagues into curbing such abuses.

title: GERMANY'S VOLATILE GREENS
description: We want to die so that America may live!'' proclaims the Greens' grim poster, showing a brightly colored Old Glory snapping over the ashen ruins of a nukedout German city. ''Yes to NATO!'' continues the message. ''Yes to rearmament!'' This bit of doomsday humor is one strand in one of the most taut, uncertain - and possibly momentous - election campaigns in the 34-year history of West Germany. Many West Germans think the main issue in the coming March 6 elections ought to be the alarming condition of their once robust economy, dragging under the weight of 2.5 million unemployed, a record 10 percent out of work. But for the Green Party, a mercurial coalition of young environmentalists, antinuclear pacifists, feminists and re-treaded Marxist-Leninists, the main issue is missiles. At almost any price, the Greens want to prevent American cruise and Pershing 2 medium-range missiles from being stationed in West Germany at the end of this year.

title: A THEATER GROUP FINDS SUCCESS IN SUBURBIA
description: In the beginning they were a disparate group of New York actors eking out livings on, off and off-off Broadway on such stages as the New York Free Theater and the Charles Street Playhouse. But they knew each other and shared a common desire for more than just regular work.

title: SUMMER SCHOOL TAKING NEW TURNS
description: MORE and more school districts on the Island will be offering programs this summer designed to challenge accomplished academic students with courses in such subjects as Chinese and computer literacy.

title: Palm Beach
description: To the Editor: The article ''Palm Beach: An Immutable Social Bastion'' by Marylin Bender and the accompanying pieces on that Florida resort (Travel, Jan. 16) neglected to mention an especially delightful outing that we have enjoyed there often. This is to take a walk or a bicycle ride along the Lake Worth Trail, a tree-and gardenlined public footpath lying between Lake Worth and the many beautiful houses that occupy this three-and-a-half-mile stretch north of Royal Poinciana Way.

title: ALL P.L.O. FACTIONS ARE SAID TO SUPPORT STATE TIED TO JORDAN
description: All factions of the Palestine Liberation Organization agreed today that they would endorse the concept of a future Palestinian state confederated with Jordan, the chief P.L.O. spokesman said.

title: DON QUIXOTE RESTORED
description: The following article will appear as the foreword to ''Lectures on 'Don Quixote' '' by Vladimir Nabokov, to be published by Harcourt Brace Jovanovich later this month.

title: TEXAN REGAINS SEAT IN HOUSE
description: Phil Gramm, a former Democratic Representative who resigned from the House last month and switched political parties, won a special election as a Republican tonight, defeating 10 other candidates for the seat he had vacated.

title: FRANK LLYOD WRIGHT VS. THE MACHINE
description: Frank Lloyd Wright's relationship to other early 20th-century designers and to the Arts and Crafts Movement are matters that enthusiasts of the period continue to explore. Even though all of the evidence is not yet in, we can see more clearly some of these issues in ''Frank Lloyd Wright: Art in Design,'' the inaugural exhibition of Hirschl & Adler Modern, 851 Madison Avenue (at 71st Street), and its informative catalogue.

title: MARY KORDES, S.P. HARDY, COLGATE GRADUATES, TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. John L. Kordes of Garden City, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Lee Kordes, to Stephen P. Hardy, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert E. Hardy of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Another Reason For a Quiet Winter
description: ''Winter on East End: Quieter This Year?'' (Jan. 23) was read with joy by my husband and me, as we shared one of our favorite moments: reading the Sunday paper, eating a breakfast of bagels and lox with a fire roaring in the fireplace of our weekend retreat on the East End.

title: EMERGENCY CREWS RISE TO THE SNOWY OCCAISION
description: With some luck and a great deal of exertion, New York City's emergency services began to cope yesterday with the human problems posed by the mountains of snow choking the streets.

title: SONGS: MARY O'HARA, HARPIST
description: Sweetness and light reigned at the Carnegie Hall concert Thursday by the Irish singer and harpist Mary O'Hara, who has been popular in Britain for many years. Accompanied at times by a pianist and a flutist, Miss O'Hara performed songs from the last five centuries in English, Gaelic and Scots Gaelic.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: GETTING INTO TOWN FROM THE AIRPORT
description: W hen Air France introduced its Caravelle jet service from Paris to London Airport 24 years ago it could boast that the flight from capital to capital took less time than the journey from the airport to central London. The same is true today, if you take a taxi in the rush hour. But by taking advantage of the latest extension of the London Underground (subway), the trip can be completed in about 40 minutes, and in relative comfort. (The city-to-city flight takes around 50 minutes.)

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN NEWTOWN
description: WHEN prospective home buyers want to check out the towns of n orthern Fairfield County in Connecticut, Gil Bastos, a real-estate s alesman, makes a special point of driving them down Newtown's Main S treet, past the colonial homes, the old churches and the flag pole.

title: Old State House Not the Oldest
description: Many people, including readers of the Journal in the Connecticut Weekly of Jan. 30, have been misinformed that the Old State House in Hartford is the oldest in the nation. Newport, Boston and Newcastle, Del., have statehouses older than Hartford's.

title: HELP POORER COUNTRIES
description: The Independent Commission on International Development Issues, headed by Willy Brandt, raised a crucial question this week when it called for a large-scale transfusion of funds to thirdworld countries: Are Western politicians and voters beginning to accept the idea that they have, as Mr. Brandt argues, a selfinterest as well as a moral obligation to help poorer countries toward recovery?

title: Arts in Education: A Student's View
description: In response to the article ''Whither Arts-in-Education Programs?'' (Jan. 16): As a senior at Commack H.S. North, I too have recognized a severe deterioration of our monetary resources pertaining in particular to our music department. I perform in three choral groups and have felt the blows we have had to experience because of lack of money.

title: Carol Ann Noer to Wed Mark Rufolo, a Lawyer
description: Dr. and Mrs. H. Rolf Noer 2d of Alexandria, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Ann Noer, to Mark William Rufolo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Rufolo of Florham Park, N.J. A May 29 wedding is planned.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: M.T.A. Will Limit Foreign Purchases
description: Perhaps sensing an escalation in the battle to control the purchase of subway cars and equipment made outside the United States, national labor leaders and Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials last week signed a truce.

title: Elizabeth Prescott Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Rodney W. Preston of Beverly, Mass., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Preston's daughter, Elizabeth Ann Prescott, to Edward Boyd Batchelder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel L. Batchelder of Beverly Farms, Mass.

title: A CLAN CALLED VALENTINE GATHERS FOR THE FIRST TIME
description: It was, everyone agreed between polite and hearty greetings, a Valentine party to end all Valentine parties. Actually, it was more like a beginning, since the host and hostess, plus their 120 or so guests, most with the surname of Valentine, were meeting one another for the first time. They came from as far as Delray Beach, Fla., and as near as a few blocks away, in response to Richard and Nancy Valentines' invitation to their Upper East Side home for a formal dinner and a chance to meet other branches of the Valentine family tree.

title: Boston College 89 Holy Cross, 74
description: Jay Murphy scored 25 points, and John Garris added 24 as Boston College won its fourth straight game. Garris got the first two baskets of the game on assists by Michael Adams, who finished with 18 points, and the Eagles went on to take a 9-0 lead.

title: CORRECTION
description: A society-page article last Sunday on the engagement of Martha Blythe Gerson misidentified her fiance. He is Joseph Charles Francis Lufkin.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
ALL-AMERICAN MUSIC
description: The Great Neck Symphony goes ''native'' today for its third concert of the season - that is, the orchestra, under Herbert Grossman's baton, will perform an ''All-American'' program. On it will be Aaron Copland's ''A Lincoln Portrait,'' narrated by the actor Howard DaSilva; the world premiere of Walter Piston's Concerto for Two Pianos and Orchestra, performed by Joshua Pierce and Dorothy Jonas, duo pianists, and Randall Thompson's Symphony No. 2 in E minor. The concert is at 7:30 P.M. at Great Neck South High School on Lakeville Road. Tickets are $10, or $5 for students.VACATION TREATS

title: Roseanne Galdi to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. Galdi of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, @Roseanne Marie Galdi, to John Frank Guido, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Guido of Scarsdale, N.Y. A September wedding is planned. Prescott, daughter also of the late Gilbert A. Prescott, is

title: FREE JAZZ COMES UNDER FIRE
description: Jazz entered its free-form phase at the beginning of the 1960's, and Charles Mingus, Ornette Coleman and Lennie Tristano were experimenting with free-form improvising as early as 1949-50. But in much jazz literature, free-form jazz is still called ''new jazz'' or ''new music.''

title: E.P.A. Provides Funds For Toxic Dump Listing
description: The Environmental Protection Agency plans to provide nearly $10 million to the 50 states and Puerto Rico to complete their lists of hazardous waste dumps.

title:
GARDENING;
FAVORITE PLANTS AND THEIR FAMILIES
description: THE rose family contains a diversity of plants, ranging from the garden rose to many commonly grown fruits including the apple, peach, raspberry and strawberry.

title: Warburg Honorary Trustee
description: Edward M.M. Warburg, the philanthropist, has been elected an honorary trustee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Mr. Warburg is one of the founders of the museum and served as a staff member, a trustee and organizer of its film library.

title: REAL INCOME OF DOCTORS CALLED LEVEL FOR DECADE
description: The real income of physicians in the United States has stayed flat for hte last decade despite a huge increase in the amount of money spent on doctors' services, according to a study in Friday's issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Texan Linked to Libya Arrested on Tax Charge
description: A man convicted of assaulting a Libyan dissident in Colorado has been arrested by United States marshals in Texas in cases involving Federal tax evasion and the firebombing of a car in Canada.

title: INDOOR AIR POLLUTION FOUND HAZARDOUS
description: NEWARK BECAUSE people spend 80 to 90 percent of their time indoors - at home, at work, shopping and traveling - researchers at the New Jersey Institute of Technology's air-pollution monitoring laboratory here believe that the quality of indoor air is more important to health and well-being than that of the air outdoors.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: IN ITS heyday during the 1930's and early 40's, the towers of the Jersey City Medical Center dominated the city's skyline. The center was a monument to the determination of former Mayor Frank Hague, who spearheaded its construction and viewed the complex as his personal fiefdom. It offered not only the latest in medical care, but also a ready source of patronage jobs.

title: LOW MORALE CALLED A GROWING PROBLEM IN SALVADOR MILITARY
description: There is growing concern among Salvadoran and United States military experts that El Salvador's military is facing a serious morale problem.

title:
ART;
A TOUCH OF THE POET
description: FRANK O'HARA was an original and a major member of the New York School of poetry, a loose confederation of poets beginning in the 1950's who took their cues from the New York School of painting. The Abstract Expressionists, or action painters, sought to embody their moment-by-moment feelings in spontaneous and color-laden gesture; the poets attempted a similar capture in language.

title: CRIMINALS IN MEXICO: HOW MANY ARE POLICEMEN?
description: When the kidnapper and murderer of an 11-year-old Mexico City boy was recently identified as a former policeman who was himself killed while resisting arrest, the outpouring of indignation here was not accompanied by expressions of surprise.

title: KEY TOPIC AT WORLD ORGANIZATION: 'SALIENCE'
description: Salience, meaning emphasis or prominence, has come into vogue at the United Nations as a synonym for relevance, as in ''this scheme must have salience for rural development.'' Some diplomats here have expressed concern over what, accordingly, they call ''the lack of salience'' of the world organization.

title: FOUR GIRLS, FOUR VIEWS
description: HOW do teen-age girls feel about contraception and confidentiality? Four girls, all of whose names have been changed, discuss these issues:

title: Another Hitch For Shoreham
description: The closer the Long Island Lighting Company comes to completing its nuclear power plant at Shoreham, the farther it sometimes seems from getting a license. Last week, for example, James H. Conran, a Nuclear Regulatory Commission engineer who originally testified in favor of the plant, changed his mind.

title: COLLEGE SETS LITERACY GOALS
description: NEWARK OPEN admissions, a philosophical cornerstone of the community college concept, is under fire at Essex County College, and opposing sides are expected to clash at a meeting at the school on Wednesday.

title: A PIANO DEBUT WITH A DIFFERENCE
description: FOR Roberta Rust of Great Neck, the time had come for a New York debut. For 21 years, since the age of 5 in her native Houston, she had been studying the piano, winning competitions, grants and scholarships; winning a scholarship to study at the Peabody Conservatory in Baltimore; graduating summa cum laude from the University of Texas; studying in Europe, and winning a scholarship to the Manhattan School of Music, where she earned a master's degree in 1981.

title: MISHAPS MAY DELAY A TELESCOPE
description: Manufacturing and testing problems are threatening to cause a delay of up to a year in the launching of a $790 million space telescope, an optical instrument that could enable astronomers to see to the edge of the universe.

title: BLUE, GRAY AND BLACK
description: FREEDOM A Documentary History of Emancipation 1861-1867.Selected from the Holdings of the National Archives of the United States. Series II: The Black Military Experience. Edited by Ira Berlin. Joseph P. Reidy and Leslie S. Rowland, associate editors. Illustrated. 852 pp. New York: Cambridge University Press. $37.50.

title: FOR SNACKS, THIS IS TOPS
description: SOME restaurants are for dining and others are better suited to socializing. Brown, Thomson & Company in downtown Hartford belongs in the latter category, though you can easily add another reason for dropping by. The restaurant is located in the stairwell and atrium of a historic building and is a visual treat.

title: A TANK FAILURE
description: It took a little longer than expected last week to demolish Gene Boyle's Restaurant, a Clifton, N.J., dining spot that once was the place to be seen for local business and political figures. Admittedly with an eye toward attracting attention to the 75,000-square-foot office building they will put up on the site, Cali Associates and Dubnoff & Blanda, joint developers, hired a World War II Sherman tank to knock down the old restaurant in what they estimated would be 30 minutes.

title: China Reports Tourism Gains
description: China earned $840 million from tourism last year, a 7.7 percent increase over the $780 million that it earned in 1981, The China Daily reported today.

title:
STAMPS;
NEW ISSUES WELCOME CHINA'S 'YEAR OF THE PIG'
description: This is the Chinese new year, ushering in the Year of the Pig. In the Chinese lunar calendar, used in most of Asia, years have their animal symbols and that animal, according to Asian soothsayers and fortune tellers, influences the events of that year and the character of those born under it. While Japan and Korea officially go by the Gregorian calendar, they still cling to customs and traditions of the past represented in the 12-animal zodiac imported from China centuries ago.

title: FOR TARRYTOWN TEEN-AGERS, A COURT OF PEERS
description: TARRYTOWN teen-agers will have their day in court beginning in May. In fact, they will be the court. The Tarrytown Village Board of Trustees voted unanimously last week to establish a youth court, in which juveniles who commit certain infractions will be judged by their peers.

title: MARDI GRAS (FAT TUESDAY): LIVE IT UP, EAT IT UP
description: TUESDAY is Mardi Gras, the day of revelry and celebration before Lent begins. The term ''Mardi Gras,'' which in French means Fat Tuesday, refers to the centuries-old tradition of using up all the fat in the house before the austere six-week period of Lenten fasting starts. Strictly observed, Lent meant consuming no animal products whatsoever and except in the Mediterranean countries of Europe, where olive oil was produced, animal fats were generally used for frying.

title: INTIMATE RELATIONSHIPS
Wendy Mae Schwartz Is to Wed Thomas Gardner
description: Announcement has been made by Margaret M. Schwartz of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., and William R. Schwartz of Carmel, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Mae Schwartz, to Thomas David Gardner, son of Mr. and Mrs. David J. Gardner of Briarcliff Manor.

title: On the Trail Of Duke's Mixture
description: Referring to William Safire's column ''On the Trail of Duke's Mixture'' (On Language, Jan. 16), his authority, Fred Cassidy, is somewhat in error. Apparently, he was not around in the early 1900's when Duke's, Velvet, Prince Albert, Briggs and various cut plugs were prominent.

title: ROSE WERE A ROSE WERE A ROSE
description: ''I only wish you were as perceptive about politics as you are about grammar,'' writes Senator Edward M. Kennedy, following a piece in this space about the use of the subjunctive mood.

title: IN THE TAKEOVER WARS, THE MAN WHO PLAYS TO WIN
description: WHEN it comes to recognition, the business world has few names that a lmost everybody knows. Among them, surely, are Walter Wriston, H arold Geneen and Harry Gray. Now another increasingly recognizable n ame has been cropping up: Edward L. Hennessy Jr., the man who s tudied under two of the three masters and showed another contender f or the list, William M. Agee, how to play to win.

title: ARABS RUSH TO BLAME JERUSALEM BUT KEEP SILENT ON THE ROLE OF PHALANGIST MILITIA
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon THE Arab world has reacted to the report by the Israeli commission of inquiry into the massacres here with the same apparent indifference toward the Palestinians that it showed when Israel invaded Lebanon.

title: KLAUS BARBIE'S RETURN AWAKENS A BITTER PAST
description: The French criminal justice system last week was struggling to figure out how to give a fair trial to Klaus Barbie, but the unexpected return in handcuffs of the World War II head of the Nazi Gestapo in Lyons launched a much broader process, a trial that involved France itself.

title: Miss Bowling To Be Bride In the Spring
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Chandler Bowling of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Jo Bowling, to Stephen Allyn Gramps, son of Mr. and Mrs. Glenn Allyn Gramps of Stratford, Calif.

title: On a cold day in January 1979, a polygraph machine was perched on a make-shift table in a tiny storage area. An examiner hired by her employer connected electrodes to Sandra Kwasniewski and then began his interrogation of the 28-year-old woman: Had she ever shoplifted anything? Who did she live with? Where did her boyfriend live? What were her dating practices? Did she drink?
description: Mrs. Kwasniewski, the manager of a combination gas station and convenience store in eastern Connecticut, contended that nothing had been stolen or even reported missing from the station. But two days after the polygraph test she was dismissed.

title: HAGLER THE SLUGGER SHOWS HE CAN BOX
description: For hours at a time in the days before the fight, Sugar Ray Leonard would confront Pac-Man, a losing one-onone matchup. At the current exchange rate of four to a dollar, he was probably down to his last 100 million quarters. But if he wanted to replenish his supply, he said, he would not think about coming out of retirement to fight Marvelous Marvin Hagler. Not after Friday night. The former welterweight champion will stick to Pac-Man.

title: John Henry Is Injured; Out of Santa Anita Race
description: John Henry, thoroughbred racing's leading career-money winner, suffered a pulled muscle during a workout today at Santa Anita and will miss the $500,000 Santa Anita Handicap next month.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Deficits for the States

title: Comings and Goings
description: After suffering torn ligaments in his right knee on Thursday in a game against the University of Virginia, Buzz Peterson will be lost to the University of North Carolina for the remainder of the basketball season. Peterson, a sophomore reserve guard, had appeared in 24 Tar Heel games, averaging 7.2 points. ... Jim Skipper, who has been an assistant football coach at the University of Oregon since 1980, has resigned to coach running backs with the Philadelphia Stars of the United States Football League.

title: THE TWO DANGERS
description: There are two emerging dangers in the present nuclear arms debate: first, that the militarists will want too many nuclear weapons, and second, that the pacifists will want too few, or none at all.

title: ESCHEAT FUNDS BRING STATE A BONUS
description: THE escheat department of the State Treasurer's office raised its income from $1.2 million in 1981 to $19.7 million in 1982, an increase of about 1,600 percent.

title: DAYS IN THE COUNTY, NIGHTS AT THE OPERA
description: IT is an icy morning in late January, and four boys, each about 12 years old, are slouched sleepily in chairs in the nurse's office of the Ardsley Middle School. But they are not sick; as they have several other times this week, the boys are awaiting a ride to the Metropolitan Opera House at Lincoln Center in Manhattan, to rehearse their parts as members of the opera company's Children's Chorus.

title: SATELLITE STATION SPURS BROOKLYN DEBATE
description: As construction of the city's first satellite earth station proceeds in the East New York section of Brooklyn, residents of that community are debating whether the facility will automatically trigger needed revitalization of the area or whether its owner should provide direct subsidies for renewal.

title: ETHICS AND THE LAW
description: Significantly absent from the lawyers' deliberations was the question of justice. Loss of income, loyalty to friends, responsibility to a client - yes.

title: AT THE S.E.C., A VISIONARY DREAMS OF RELYING ON COMPUTERS
description: WASHINGTON THESE days, whenever a merger is in the air, there's a palpable tension in the public reference room of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Couriers in sneakers fidget as they wait for copies of new filings, and then race off with them to eager analysts.

title: Scott Ashby Lacy Wed To Susan L. Thorndike
description: Susan Lee Thorndike, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward H. Thorndike of Pittsford and Ithaca, N.Y., was married yesterday to Scott Ashby Lacy, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Lacy of Victor, N.Y. The Rev. James F. Tyrrell performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Victor.

title: GREEK CYPRIOTS, IN VOTING TODAY, TO PICK PRESIDENT
description: After a bitterly contested political campaign, Greek Cypriots are voting on Sunday in presidential elections that are generally expected here to give the incumbent, Spyros Kyprianou, another term.

title: Eileen R. Miller to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Edward Miller Jr. of Rochester have announced the engagement of their daughter, Eileen Refiye Miller, to Glenn William Creutz, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. William Creutz of Commack, L.I. Miss Miller and her fiance are seniors at the State University of New York at Brockport.

title: I.M.F. Agrees to Help the Poor
description: The International Monetary Fund lends money to countries in need of cash. Last week, with the need greater than ever, the I.M.F.'s policy-making Interim Committee gave its approval after hard debate for an increase in the fund's resources by 47.4 percent to $98.5 billion.

title: ALEX HALEY IN NEWARK
description: Alex Haley, who won fame and a Pulitzer Prize for his book ''Roots,'' will lecture at the Newark Museum next Sunday at 2 P.M. The lecture, like the other items in this week's guide, is one of the events in the state marking Black History Month.

title: VOLUNTARY BUSING PLAN BEING STUDIED
description: Renee Gregory sits in the front row at Kirkwood High School, eager for the education she hopes will give her a chance to become a physician.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN THE TOY INDUSTRY;
description: Stamps are still the nation's most popular hobby. But there was a strong suspicion among buyers at the toy fair - although no one appeared to have any hard numbers to back it up - that sometime last year collectible dolls edged out coins for second place.

title: Columbia Names Stein To Theater Post
description: Howard Stein has been named chairman of Columbia University's Oscar Hammerstein 2d Center for Theater Studies. His appointment was announced by Schuyler Chapin, dean of the School of the Arts.

title: Anne Ricks Is Engaged
description: Prof. and Mrs. David Ricks of Cincinnati have made known the engagement of their daughter, Anne Eva Ricks, to Dr. Elliott Sumers, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Sumers of Roslyn, L.I.

title: PARIS HOTELS
description: To the Editor:

title: R & D GETS A BOOST FROM WASHINGTON
description: The Reagan Administration is cutting social programs for the poor and whittling away entitlement programs for the middle class, but it seems determined to pour ever larger amounts of money into scientific research.

title: That Tree In Smithtown
description: Anne Fauvell, who says she is a Smithtown resident, wrote an article entitled ''Shadows in a Season of Lights'' (Opinion Page, Jan. 2). She talked about an enlightened mind and reading Robert Lowell, Wallace Stevens, Plato, Cicero and Petrarch.

title: DIVIDED SUFFOLK CONSERVATIVES URGED TO UNITE BEHIND COHALAN
description: STATE Conservative Party leaders are encouraging feuding Suffolk County Conservatives to get together long enough to endorse the County Executive, Peter F. Cohalan, for re-election this year.

title: ETHICS AND THE LAW
description: It strains credulity to believe that 29 attorneys of moderate competence, handling the personal and business affairs of these convicted felons, might have been oblivious to such wholesale fraud. I submit that readers possessing the analytical powers of reasonable ''men'' might scoff at the supposed ethical ''dilemma'' confronted by these barristers. Could it be that their ethical judgment was attenuated by the $3.2 million dollar per annum fee? Nonsense. JOHN T. MURRAY New York City ------

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: The week's debut recitalists consisted of seven instrumentalists, which attests to the voluminous outpouring of instrumental craftsmen that our conservatories and universities provide today.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE ART PRESENCE By Sanford Schwartz. Illustrated. 246 pp. New York: Horizon Press. $13.95.

title: CONCERTS IN CITY GET WARMUPS IN COUNTY
description: FOR quite a few years now, performers have been using concerts in the county as warmups for New York appearances - the recital equivalent, you might say, of the Broadway show that tries out in New Haven. The procedure, of course, not only gives the artists an opportunity to play through their programs before the scowling city critics can have at them, but allows the rest of us an opportunity to enjoy their work more conveniently, and usually at lower cost.

title: COORDINATED PLANS FOR ROADS SOUGHT
description: FOR 20 years, New Jersey has focused its transportation resources on building and expanding highways designed to connect all parts of the state, and to link them with routes serving an area extending from New England to the Carolinas.

title: The Art Of the Popes
description: In ''The Art of the Popes Comes to America'' (Jan. 16), Stephen S. Hall describes the recently re-restored Apollo Belvedere as ''now regal, seamless and gleaming'' and notes that, ''in the last four centuries, the Apollo has suffered an undignified succession of amputations, incisions, cosmetic surgeries and fanciful prostheses: In 1532, a capricious restorer named Giovanni Angelo Montorsoli supplied it with two hands and a right forearm. The artificial additions lasted until 1924, when everything but the fig leaf was removed.'' I'm sure the latest face lift is an improvement, but it does not follow that we should unequivocally applaud the amputations perpetrated in 1924. What we now have is a well-scrubbed version of the fragmented statue that emerged from the ground at Grottaferrata and entered the Belvedere Courtyard of the Vatican in 1503. What we have lost are the efforts of a gifted sculptor, Fra Giovan' Montorsoli, to reconstruct the original masterpiece. No mere ''capricious restorer,'' Montorsoli served as Michelangelo's trusted assistant in the Medici Chapel in the church of San Lorenzo, Florence. It was he who finished the statue of Giuliano de' Medici, probably worked on the statue of Lorenzo de' Medici and executed the St. Cosmas for the chapel. In all probability he, and not Michelangelo, is the author of most of the drawings recently found on the walls of the cellar beneath the chapel.

title: Falling Out At the E.P.A.
description: With a contempt of Congress citation against its top administrator and at least 12,000 hazardous waste dumps to worry about, the last thing the Environmental Protection Agency needed was a scandal involving charges of political favoritism. But that's what it got last week after President Reagan fired Rita M. Lavelle, the agency's assistant administrator in charge of waste cleanups.

title: SMURFS, SMURFS AND MORE SMURFS
description: Smurfs are troll-like creatures. They are short and blue. And they live deep in the forest. More important to toy makers, they have had a top-rated Saturday morning television show since 1981. Because of that exposure, products stamped with the Smurf image brought in sales of more than $700 million last year. Smurf products dominated this year's toy show. Smurf backers think Smurfs, who were dreamed up by the Belgian artist Peyo 26 years ago, could someday be more of a force in the licensing marketplace than Mickey Mouse.

description: In the already competitive video game industry, things got fiercer last week with the presentation of a slew of new home-video products. Among them:

title: 'Freeze' Prepares For '84 Contests

description: MILLBURN AN ENAMELED orange unpeeling - it resembles a detail by Vermeer - is among the surprises in the National Invitational Jewelry Show at the Sheila Nussbaum Gallery here.

title: A CULTURAL BARGAIN: MUSIC ON CAMPUSES
description: SENDING kids to college is a costly procedure these days, but for music lovers, campus culture is definitely a bargain. Many universities sponsor major concert series, usually at less than the going admission prices, and the proliferation of fascinating - and often free - student and faculty events makes public access to university life even more appealing.

description: AMBROSE LIGHT TOWER AMONG the first things a newly assigned Coast Guardsman here notices is that, in stormy weather, the balls on the pool table seem to come alive, moving about on their own.

title: WHEN A CLASSICAL STATION GOES MODERN
THE WAGNER ENIGMA AND MYSTIQUE LIVE ON
description: On this day 100 years ago, Richard Wagner died after a heart attack in the silk-draped, perfumed study of his 16th-century palazzo on Venice's Grand Canal. By now, you might think, the world would have come to terms with his genius, sorting out the gold from the fool's gold. Not so. This centennial season is certain to demonstrate that ''The Case of Wagner,'' as Nietzsche called it in a famous 1888 essay, is still before the court. I think it should be obvious, after more than a century in which diligent exegetes have churned out millions of words in attempting to explain the man and his works, that Wagner is going to continue to baffle us. And maybe that's a good thing. If the enigma that is Richard Wagner were ever to be cleared up to our general satisfaction, his mystique might die on the spot, like Kundry when Parsifal touches Amfortas's wound with the holy spear.

description: To the Editor:

title: Arctic Pollution
description: After taking measurements, physicists at the University of California's Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory reported last June that the pristine Arctic was being badly tainted with soot.

The repertoire will include a world premiere, as yet untitled, by Sir Frederick Ashton, choreographed for Antoinette Sibley and Anthony Dowell, with sets by David Hockney and a score by William Walton.

He said that all the above would occur if Eddyleon Chocolates Inc. purchased the Fine Arts Building in Hempstead, the home of the Fine Arts Museum of Long Island, and moved its packaging plant there from Garden City.

title: Kate Landon Evarts to Wed

title: Topics; Moneymakers; Tax Bite
description: Governor O'Neill of Connecticut wants to extend the state's sales tax to meals that cost less than a dollar. What? Where can you get a meal for less than a dollar these days? A peanut butter sandwich perhaps, or a couple of doughnuts.

title: Clam Misidentified
description: One of the clam species that could be affected by ocean pollution off Monmouth County was incorrectly identified in an article last Sunday. It is the ocean quahog Artica islandica), which is sold for use in chowder or as canned or minced clams.

title: From England to Brooklyn to West Virginia
description: TWELVE stories, set in an impoverished region of West Virginia, by a young writer of such extraordinary gifts that one is tempted to compare his debut to Hemingway's, when the interrelated stories and prose pieces of ''In Our Time'' were published in 1924: this the good news. The tragic news is that this slender volume is all we will have of Breece D'J Pancake's work, since he committed suicide in 1979, when he was not quite 27 years old. Precisely why he killed himself at the very start of what promised to be a remarkable career is a mystery, though both James Alan McPherson and John Casey, who knew him as a student in the writing program at the Universty of Virginia, set forth a number of clues. Breece Pancake (a typesetter once printed his middle initials as D'J, and he adopted the oddity) ''didn't know how good he was,'' Mr. Casey says in his poignant memoir; ''he didn't know how much he knew; he didn't know that he was a swan instead of an ugly duckling.'' But the stories -tense, elegiac, remorseless in their insistence on the past's dominion over the present - argue for a sensibility so finely honed, so vulnerable to the inexorable passage of time, that it is likely death appeared as a solace. As the stories make powerfully clear, Breece Pancake identified so intensely with the coal-mining and farming area of West Virginia in which he was born that he could not have failed to identify with its slow dying as well.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

In fact, a widely used reference book such as the Dance Encyclopedia (edited by Anatole Chujoy and P.W. Manchester) does not even have a ''Dance in Switzerland'' entry as it does for many other countries.

description: Vice President Bush's public relations may have helped clear the air over nuclear arms policy in Europe, but when he returned home last week Washington seemed as foggy as ever on one of the most vexing issues of all -the MX missile.

title: WHERE TO FIND THE REAL THING
description: 1.The Princess Louise 208 High Holborn. A veritable palace of Victoriana dripping with plaster moldings, full of finely engraved mirrors and polished tile - and offering more than six kinds of real ale, including Greene King's Abbot Ale and Felinfoel's rare Double Dragon. Live music on weekends and very alive people most evenings. An excellent place to begin. 2.The Sun 63 Lamb's Conduit Street. For enthusiasts who don't mind a half-mile detour from High Holborn, follow Red Lion Street north to Lamb's Conduit Street and the Sun where a compact rumbustious bar contrasts with vast vaulted cellars -tours available on request. More than 20 real ales are available. (Try Theakston's Old Peculier and Chudley's Lords Strong Ale.) You may never complete the walk if you tarry too long. 3.The Lamb 94 Lamb's Conduit Street. Close by is this delightfully refined niche popular with film and theater folk and still using 19th-century snob-screens: head-height louvres that can be opened for serving and closed to shield discreet customers from view. The product of one of London's independent breweries, Young's, is featured here. 4.Bung Hole 57 High Holborn. One of a series of newly antiqued pubs complete with beer-barrel tables and sawdust-covered floors. Good food, good real ale (Davey's Old Wallop - actually Courage Director's Bitter) and quite convincing. 5.Holborn Bars High Holborn (closed Sunday).

description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Nancy Hughes Clark is a freelance writer. By NANCY HUGHES CLARK

title: A CHANCE FOR PEACE
description: The drama in Jerusalem, though many have discounted its external significance, does open new possibilities of movement toward peace in the Middle East. It will be a different diplomatic world without Ariel Sharon as Israel's Defense Minister. But the chance of real change depends not only on Israeli politics but on Jordanian and American policies.
