description: Are offshore powerboats unsafe? Rocky Aoki, a driver and sponsor of one of the premier events on the offshore circuit, thinks so and has announced his retirement as a driver.

description: The Westchester Cinema Club begins its third series of film showings at 10:30 A.M. today at the Fine Arts Cinema, in the Archway Shopping Mall, at 365 Central Avenue in Scardale.

title: College 'Sentence'
description: The headline said ''New Mexico Woman Sentenced to College,'' and the story began last Oct. 10: ''A woman convicted of shooting her husband has been sentenced to student life by a judge who said it was cheaper to send a felon to college than to prison.''

title: The Jerusalem Ethic
description: The ethic proclaimed in Jerusalem last week derived from only three days of the long Lebanon war. But it applies to the entire conflict, and more: to Israel's relentless effort to dominate a million Palestinians elsewhere. That is why General Sharon resists the ''mark of Cain'' and why Prime Minister Begin, while obeying the letter of the judgment, maneuvers to defeat its spirit. It is also why other parties, notably Americans, need to find their own lessons in the stern standards set by Israel's inquiry into the Beirut massacre:

title: Questioning of Walesa Is Completed in Warsaw
description: A Polish military prosecutor today ended three days' questioning of Lech Walesa, the leader of the banned Solidarity union, in connection with a case against members of a dissident group associated with the union.

description: SOME commuters apparently make a sharp distinction between increased gasoline taxes at the Federal and state level. Metropool Inc., a Stamford-based nonprofit corporation that helps create ridesharing programs, recently polled the 1,200 commuters who now go to and from work on its 100 vans in Fairfield and Westchester Counties.

description: WASHINGTON ''THE Congressman is the one who really matters,'' Bill Roberts said about his job as administrative assistant to Representative Norman F. Lent, Republican of East Rockaway.

title: LANDMARKS, TOO, OFTEN CHANGE WITH THE TIMES
description: In attempting to save New York City's past, is the Landmarks Preservation Commission impeding its future? That question has been raised repeatedly in recent months, from the Park Avenue congregation of St. Bartholomew's Church, which wants to build a 59-story office tower over its community house, to the theater owners along Broadway, who are fighting the designation of the interiors of some of their buildings, and, it sometimes seems, all the developers in between.

title:
AROUND THE WORLD;
China's Catholic Church Fills High Shanghai Post
description: China's independent Catholic Church has appointed a vicar general of Shanghai to assist the city's bishop without consultations with the Vatican, the New China News Agency said today.

title: NBC's Super Bowl
description: To the Sports Editor: I was genuinely disturbed by Neil Amdur's column (''Coverage Was Worthy Of an Exciting Game,'' The New York Times, Feb. 1) praising NBC's coverage of the Super Bowl. In my view, both the camera work and the announcing were inadequate.

title: A CRAFTSMAN'S LEGACY ON THE MARKET
description: With turn-of-the-century mission oak furniture again in favor, the name and some of the history of one of its makers, Gustav Stickley, have become familiar to collectors.

title: Cooney in Exhibition
description: ''I was rusty, I guess I should have thrown a few more punches,'' said Gerry Cooney after stopping Boone Kirkman in the third round of their exhibition bout on Friday in Eugene, Ore. It was only the Long Island heavyweight's second exhibition appearance in a ring since he suffered a technical knockout last June in a bid to dethrone Larry Holmes, the World Boxing Council champion.

title: INCINERATOR FACES TEST IN GLEN COVE
description: BESIDES being the first public garbage- and sludge-burning facility in the state, Glen Cove's new incinerator might take first place in another category.

title: PRODUCER PRICES DROP 1% IN JANUARY
description: Producer prices plummeted in January in the biggest monthly decline since the introduction of the index in 1947. Natural gas, home heating oil and gasoline prices all slumped. The producer price index fell a full 1 percent - a 12 percent decline on an annual basis.

title: THE RECORD BOOK
description: Add the name of Peter Schram to your Guinness Book of World Records. Peter Who? Peter Schram was a singer who appears in no standard encyclopedia of musicians. But in the narrow circle of collectors of vocal records he suddenly has achieved fame, thanks to a recently discovered cylinder that he made in 1889. Schram was born in 1819 and thus is the earliest-known singer in terms of date of birth ever to make a recording that has survived.

title: Daylight Saving Bill Is Filed
description: Two House members have reintroduced legislation to extend daylight saving time by two months to save an estimated 100,000 barrels of oil a day. Under the bill introduced Thursday by Representatives Richard L. Ottinger, Democrat of Westchester, and Carlos J. Moorhead, Republican of California, daylight saving time would begin on the first Sunday in March rather than the last Sunday in April. The House passed an identical bill last year but the Senate did not act on it.

title: Ethics And the Law
description: Regarding ''Ethics and the Law: A Case History'' (by Stuart Taylor Jr., Jan. 9), it is hard to distinguish the so-called ''ethical conduct'' advised by Henry Putzel from a deliberate plan designed to protect Singer Hutner's reputation. The real picture painted by this article is not one of attorneys wrestling with legitimate ethical dilemmas, such as tainted criminal evidence or vague alibis. Instead, it depicts businessmen who, by employing their special status as attorneys, sought to prolong an increasingly questionable relationship with a high-paying client, while also attempting to keep their own hands clean. PETER B. ACKERMAN, New York City

title: Pilgrim State And Housing for Aged
description: As a long-time advocate of housing to meet the needs of the Nassau population, I am pleased to note that Mr. Purcell has at least given de jure recognition of the problem by supporting a proposal to create a 1,600 unit project for the senior citizens of the bi-county area at Pilgrim State.

title: TURNOUT AT SHOW ENCOURAGING SIGN
description: IF it is anything, Detroit is a repository of enthusiasm. It is a city with a salesman's smile, and the traditional predictions tend to be glowing.

title: Letters; Historical Focus
description: To the Editor:

title: THE VERDICT
description: JERUSALEM ISRAEL stood last week at the conjunction of honor and tragedy. At the same moment in the same place, the powerful, self-corrective force of healthy democracy crossed with dangerous intolerance. In the Cabinet room, Prime Minister Menachem Begin and all but one of his 16 ministers bowed to the findings of a state commission that Israel bore ''indirect responsibility'' for the massacre of Palestinians last September by Lebanese Christian Phalangists in Beirut, and that Defense Minister Ariel Sharon and three top generals should leave their posts. Outside the office building, a hand grenade exploded in a group of anti-Government demonstrators who had been heckled and assaulted repeatedly by young toughs singing ''Begin, King of Israel!'' and shouting that it was too bad Hitler hadn't got all the European Jews, too bad they weren't in the Beirut refugee camps where the Phalangists could have finished them off. The youths themselves finished off one protestor with a grenade thrown among the demonstrators that also wounded nine people.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
DO METAL PRICES AFFECT VALUE OF RARE COINS?
description: In theory the value of rare coins should have little or no connection with the price of precious metals. Still, it is apparent that the variations in rare coin prices have closely paralleled those of precious metals in recent years - and some observers think this is no coincidence.

title: THE DIFFICULTY OF TREATING THE DRUG-ABUSING ATHLETE
description: BUCK WILLIAMS of the New Jersey Nets estimated last week that 20 to 30 percent of professional basketball players take drugs. These athletes, like those in other sports, are now being offered help with their problems. In the National Football League, for example, players and owners have agreed that drug abuse is an illness and that players should be offered treatment. The N.F.L. as a whole, the other professional leagues and several individual teams now offer various forms of help to the drug-abusing athlete.

title: Bar Association Favors Stricter Confidentiality
description: The American Bar Association last week changed a proposed ethics code to prohibit lawyers from blowing the whistle on the people they represent. The new rules mean that if a lawyer knows that the directors of a client corporation intend to issue a false financial report, he would not be allowed to report this to the Securities Exchange Commission or to prospective victims of the fraud.

title: WHEN ISLANDS ARE PARTNERS
description: known organization that is reaching out to Latin America and the Caribbean.

title: Unorthodox Portfolio
description: When an E.F. Hutton broker poses, people look - to the consternation of the firm's executives.

title: THE A B C'S OF TRIMMING TILES TO FIT AGAINST CURVED EDGES
description: WHEN putting down new floor tiles, or installing ceramic or plastic tiles on walls, counter tops and other surfaces, the do-it-yourselfer is often faced with the task of trimming the tiles in the last row (around the border) so they will fit neatly against a curved or irregularly shaped surface.

title: IN SEARCH OF A NEW PURPOSE FOR A CITY STREET
description: There is something about a Manhattan street that is not like a street anywhere else. It is essentially like Manhattan itself - a place of distinct styles thrown together, a place of clashing forces, of struggling for position. The activity on the street means more in New York, surely, than it does in any other city - crowded sidewalks are a sign of urban health here, and so are shopfronts. It is no accident that in Manhattan there has been no wholesale abandonment of old-fashioned storefronts by retailers in favor of indoor malls and atriums. In New York the street itself is a destination - not just a means of getting from one place to another.

title: THE PHILIDOR LEGACY
description: Were Francois Andre Danican Philidor (1726-1795) among us today, he would be delighted and proud of the course that the strategy of the game has taken. In his own time, his famous precept, ''The pawns are the soul of chess,'' went entirely ignored by a public that was not ready for it. But now almost everyone is a Philidorian.

title: CARD DESIGNERS TAKE HEART IN THEIR NO. 2 DAY
description: BARRIE WYMAN has left her heart in San Francisco, as well as in most other major American cities and a few foreign countries. But it is an affair destined to end, at least temporarily, tomorrow.

title: NEGOTIATORS MEET IN PHILADELPHIA RAIL DISPUTE
description: Negotiators facing a Monday morning strike deadline for the city's commuter rail system met for about six hours today, then continued discussions in a series of telephone calls, a city councilman seeking to avoid a passenger train shutdown said.

title: All-Star Selection Savored by Lucas
description: There was a huge grin on Maurice Lucas's face, which appeared to spell out vindication as the former Knick forward explained his feelings today about being a starter on the West team in Sunday's 33d annual National Basketball Association All-Star Game at the Forum.

title: UP, UP AND AWAY-THEN BACK TO EARTH
description: IFOLLOW sports. I go to a few baseball games at Yankee Stadium and I see the football Giants play in the Meadowlands. I get the games on TV and I also play a little golf.

description: IRAQ SAYS IT ATTACKED OIL PORT

title: COPENHAGEN: BEYOND TIVOLI
description: FLETCHER KNEBEL is the author of ''Crossing in Berlin'' and other books; his latest, ''Poker Game,'' a novel about computer espionage, is forthcoming from Doubleday.

title: Tripe: The Homage Vice Pays to Virtue
description: Calvados, the apple brandy, is a key ingredient in tripes a la mode de Caen. here are some quotations about food that are so exquisitely related to a subject at hand we find them irresistible. This is certainly true of a few lines pertaining to tripe that we discovered years ago in the Wise Encyclopedia of Cookery.

title: BURGER'S OPENING ARGUMENT FOR A NEW APPELLATE COURT
description: Ever since he ascended to the United States Supreme Court 14 years ago, Chief Justice Warren E. Burger has complained about the Court's workload. In a speech before the American Bar Association last week, he got around to asking the Congress to do something specific about it.

title: PRIVATE GROUP HELPS RUNAWAYS
description: AN organization devoted to helping young runaways was begun in Connecticut when Frank Barnaba found a young woman crying in a latenight restaurant.

title: Headliners; No Horse-Trading
description: The gunmen who abducted the race horse Shergar from a stud farm in Ireland last week certainly picked a winner, but they may nevertheless have wound up in a losing proposition. The Aga Khan and other members of the syndicate that paid more than $13 million for the Irish Derby champion in 1981 flatly refused to pay a $2.7 million ransom. Even when the horsenappers scaled their demand down to $52,000 - about half Shergar's stud fee - the Aga Khan, who is the spiritual leader of the world's 15 million Ismaili Moslems, remained firm in his refusal to deal with them.

title: WALT MICHAELS: PRESSURES CLOUDED THE FINEST SEASON
description: HE is a man of such diverse facets that those around Walt Michaels v iew him in completely different ways. And each may be right. To Dr. Calvin Nicholas, the New York Jets' almost-gentle physician,M ichaels was a friend of 20 years' standing - ''a man much deeper t han most people give him credit for.''

title: Iran Trying to Recruit Doctors From Europe
description: Iran is sending teams of specialists to Western Europe to recruit doctors to replace those who have left the country since the 1979 revolution.

title: W. Virginia's Top Judge Asks Inquiry on Himself
description: West Virginia's Chief Justice feels he may have violated judicial ethics by starting a charity food fund, so he has filed a complaint against himself.

title: TALL, THIN SPACE TO LET
description: In keeping with the current waste-not, want-not trend in government, the National Parks Service has decided not to let a 125-year-old lighthouse on Fire Island sit idle. The 164-foot lighthouse, which is about 1,000 feet away from the easternmost parking lot of Robert Moses State Park, used to mark the entrance to New York Harbor and warn of a treacherous shoal offshore.

title: TRuckers On The Road Again
description: Leaders of the nation's 100,000 independent truckers last month vowed not to drive their rigs until Washington repealed new increases in fuel taxes and road-use fees. But like their idle vehicles they didn't get very far, so last week those that called the strike called it off.

title: ILLUSTRATOR FINDS 76 WAYS YO SAY 'I LOVE YOU'
description: THE world of Sandra Boynton is inhabited by fractious felines, petulant pigs, toothy monsters, lovesick hippos and a flock of halfwitted turkeys. It is a world where disgruntled beavers mutter ''dam, dam, dam,'' furry, horned creatures apologize for being ''beastly,'' and a platoon of rabbits delivers a ''21-bun salute.''

title: THE LONELINESS OF THE LONG-DISTANCE WRITER
description: IN San Francisco a shadow hangs over the literary life. The shadow can be described in two dreaded words: New, York. A lot of writers in Manhattan also wonder how to break through the barriers of opportunity and luck, so that they too may be taken to lunch at the Algonquin and dinner at Elaine's, but in San Francisco the grief and paranoia are almost as much a part of the atmosphere as the friendly fog, the yellow and gray light, the coffee shops and the affinity groups. ''New York said about my book. ...'' an angry novelist began.

title: Mixing Business And Knowledge
description: When industrial sponsorship of university research began to rise, so did worry about conflict of interest. The fear is that professors with hefty financial ties to corporations, particularly in bioengineering and electronics, might steer their work primarily in the direction of private profits, not human knowledge.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''By the time we got to New York, the train was like a big snowball.'' -M.P. Fagan, engineer, Metro North. (35:6.)

title: AIRLIFT IS KEEPING STRANDED NAVAJO FAMILIES ALIVE
description: After three weeks of storms, about 2,000 Navajo families remained stranded today on the nation's largest Indian reservation, marooned by snow with drifts up to the roofs. Mud clogged the unpaved roads.

title: A Bombing in South Africa
description: A bomb damaged Government offices Friday night in a black residential area near Pietermaritzburg in Natal Province, the South African radio reported today. There were no injuries in the blast, which occurred on a lawn outside the building, shattering windows and damaging the roof. No one claimed responsibility.

title:
ART;
CRYPTIC TITLES HINT AT ARTISTS' THEMES
description: ''IDON'T like titles that are too obvious - they're boring,'' said Tom de Gruyl, an artist whose charcoal and pastel drawings bear names taken from ancient languages and legends.

title: RANGERS WIN, 3-2, END 7-GAME SLUMP
description: Hanging on through a hazardous final few minutes of the game, the Rangers defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 3-2, tonight for their first victory in seven games.

title:
HOW TO TIGHTEN THE FLOW OF TECHNOLOGY;
CLOSER COORDINATION WITH OUR ALLIES
description: THE next weeks are likely to see renewed controversy over the P resident's authority to invoke economic sanctions in peacetime as a f oreign policy weapon when Congress takes up extension of the Export A dministration Act of 1979.

title: HEAD IS CHOSEN FOR GREATER NEW YORK FUND
description: Horace W. Morris, former executive director of the New York Urban League, has been named executive director of the Greater New York Fund/ United Way.

title: NEWPORT IN WINTER
description: Newport is a city of winter brilliance. In December as the sun swings low, sunshine slants across harbor and ocean, floods the streets, pours through moire Colonial panes and motel thermal windows, through doorways, along tablecloths, into wineglasses hanging over bars. There are no skyscrapers to create canyons, and no mountains to gnaw at the horizon. The town pokes out into the water, and if there is light anywhere, Newport captures it like a jewel.

title: Bradley Razook, Mary Jo D'Agostino Are Married in Manhattanville Chapel
description: The marriage of Mary Josephine D'Agostino, the special-events assistant at People magazine, to Bradley George Razook, vice president and general counsel of Brean Murray, Fosters Securities Inc., took place yesterday in Purchase, N.Y. The Rev. Michael Trainor performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the Manhattanville College Chapel.

title: 'LATCHKEY' PROGRAMS EXPAND IN COUNTY
description: THE growing numbers of working mothers in the county, both in single-parent and two-parent families, have drawn attention not only to the needs for day care for the younger child but also to the needs of older children who often go to empty homes after school. Camille Murphy, director of the Westchester County Office for Women, recently estimated that 58 percent of working-age women in the county are in the work force. Of those, she said, 16,000 have children under 6 years old and 43,000 have children 6 to 17.

title: TV Deregulation And the Island
description: ''Making the 'Airway Robbery' Worse'' by Abby Kenigsberg (Opinion Page, Jan. 9) was inconsistent.

title: SOCIAL SCIENCES ESCAPE WASHINGTON HIT LIST
description: WHEN the Reagan Administration released its first budget two years ago, researchers in the social and behavioral sciences felt a particularly heavy crunch. But outcry from scientists and opposition in Congress have helped to renew some of the most severely affected categories.

title: Miss Hepburn Weds James Greenhalgh
description: Cheryl Lou Hepburn, daughter of Mrs. LeRoy J. Hepburn of Ewing Township, N.J., and the late Mr. Hepburn, was married yesterday to James Dieter Greenhalgh, son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. Greenhalgh of Baraboo, Wis. The Rev. J. Courtney Hayward and the Rev. George E. Morris performed the ceremony at Trinity United Methodist Church in Ewing Township.

title: The Garbage Next Time
description: Mount Everest is not the ''there'' it once was. Instead it is a high-altitude dump, strewn with the detritus of its climbers: tents, oxygen bottles, tinned food, cooking gas, pots and plates and plastic bags.

title: NEW OPERA DISKS: A MIXED BLESSING
description: Doomsayers to the contrary, the standard opera repertory lives on. For all the supposed decline in vocal skills and for all the restless exhumations of operatic exotica, we still have singers who sing these parts, decently or better; we still have conductors who are eager to imprint their conceptions for posterity, we still have opera companies and audiences eager to encounter these works, and we still have record companies willing to risk new recordings - especially now that they have a new technology, in the digital process, to play with.

title:
DINING OUT;
MEXICAN FARE UNDER VILLA'S EYES
description: IT is a pity that in its East Coast translation, Mexican cuisine appears to have lost many of its zippy nuances and subtleties. We lament New Rochelle's short-lived Maria Bonita Restaurant that served if not the genuine article then something very close to it. Its menu abounded with pork (one of Mexico's most popular meats) and various fish as well as chicken and beef dishes, gracefully and complexly spiced.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
WITH SONG, STORY AND 'YINGLISH'
description: THE routine has a familiar ring to it; it's a heated, yet jocular, exchange about ''who's on first.'' But Abbott and Costello might not recognize their baseball classic, since Helen and Meyer Zaremba romp through it in Yiddish, transforming the hilarious piece into the engaging cornerstone of ''The Jewish Experience Through Song and Story,'' which the couple will perform today at 2:30 P.M. at the Shelter Rock Public Library in Albertson.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: FIRST there were the Republicans, meeting at the Rye Town Hilton with a $150-a-plate dinner and preparing for what they hoped would be victory next November. Then there were the Democrats, meeting at the Yonkers Raceway for a $20-a-person brunch, and celebrating last November's election victories.

title: U.S. FINDS IT COSTLY TO GIVE FOOD SURPLUSES TO POOR
description: The Agriculture Department, in its latest efforts to reduce huge grain and dairy surpluses, has found it is neither cheap nor easy to give them away.

title: Carolyn R. Kohn Wed in Brewster
description: Carolyn Root Kohn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Root Kohn of Cornwall, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Francis Eckstein 3d, son of Mrs. Eckstein Jr. of Lake Hiawatha, N.J., and the late Mr. Eckstein. The Rev. Lawrence Larson performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Brewster, N.Y.

title: INDIAN POINT OPERATORS: ZONE OF RISK IS FOUR MILES
description: CONSULTANTS for the operators of the two Indian Point nuclear power plants testified last week that the 10-mile emergency planning zone, a take-cover or evacuation area around the facilities, could be reduced to four miles because virtually all of the early risks following an accident were contained within the smaller area.

title: And Bear in Mind Other recent books that in the opinion of the Book Review staff are of particular literary, topical or scholarly interest:
description: volume biography, this one covering the years 1805-36. THE AFRICANS, by David Lamb. (Random House, $17.95.) A study of the c ontinent today. ANGER, by Carol Tavris. (Simon & Schuster, $14.95.) A non-Freudian s tudy of the emotion.

title: Pamela S. Deely Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. James S. Deely of New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Sayre Deely, to John William Van De Loo, son of Mrs. Robert Van De Loo of Albany and the late Mr. Van De Loo. A July wedding is planned.

title: HOW TO GET 'LOCK STEP' INTO AMERICA'S SCHOOLS
description: To the Editor:

title: GOVERNOR FOLLOWS STYLE OF REAGAN
description: The face that looked out from television screens on a special statewide broadcast this week belonged to California's new Governor, George Deukmejian. But, as he assailed a ''small handful'' of what he depicted as profligate Democratic legislators and urged Californians to bring pressure on them to avoid a tax increase, he sounded very much like Ronald Reagan.

title: Dr. Costa Is Engaged
description: Dr. Antoinette Geraldine Costa and Dr. Douglas Herbert Zaeh, residents in internal medicine at University Hospital, Newark, and affiliated hospitals, plan to marry May 1. The future bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Costa of Jersey City, who have announced her engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert F. Zaeh of Murray Hill, N.J.

title: PROPER BRITISH ALE: A PRIMER
description: DAVID YEADON is the author of ''Hidden Corners of Britain'' (W.W. Norton).

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;
THE HANDMADE BASKETS OF CHARLESTON
description: SKIP ROZIN has completed a book on Daley Thompson, the Olympic decathlon champion, due in May from Hutchinson, London.

title: Turkey
description: To the Editor:

title: THE TROUBLE AT THE TOP
description: LIFE AND DEATH ON THE CORPORATE BATTLEFIELD How Companies Win, Lose, Survive. By Paul Solman and Thomas Friedman. 248 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $13.95.

title: OFFICIAL DISMISSED IN E.P.A. RIFT SEES 'NOTHING TO HIDE'
description: Rita M. Lavelle, who was dismissed by President Reagan as an assistant administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said in an interview that she did not know why she was ousted and declared, ''I can defend every action I have taken.''

title: COALITION SEEKING MORE AID FOR PUERTO RICANS
description: Although the income of more than 40 percent of Puerto Rican families is below the poverty level and unemployment among the 5.2 million Puerto Ricans in the continental United States and in Puerto Rico is twice the national average, these families have received little attention or help from philanthropic organizations.

title: ISRAEL'S DEEPENING WOUND
description: The report of the inquiry into the massacre in Sabra and Shatila fell like an ax upon a deep division in the Israeli body politic, further deepening the wound. In the aftermath of its publication, the confrontation between Menachem Begin's conservative, nationalist bloc and the moderate, liberal opposition erupted in open violence. The report drew attention to one ingredient of this conflict - Ariel Sharon's responsibility - but the inquiry may now be overwhelmed by the division itself.

title: Mailbox; An Attempt to Set Ivy Record Straight
description: To the Sports Editor: I feel compelled to respond to certain aspects of the column ''The Example Perkins Set'' by Murray Chass (The New York Times, Feb. 7). In general I agree with the concepts expressed.

title: A TIME TO BE WARY OF TRACTOR STOCKS
description: TRUE to form, investors were among the first to pick up the scent ofr ecovery in cyclically depressed industries like autos, housing and s teel. Now, based on movements in share prices of major farm and c onstruction equipment companies, the stock market seems to think t hat agriculture, one of the recession's most prominent victims, is o n the verge of a sharp recovery. Analysts suggested, however, that s uch optimism might be slightly premature.

title: RUMANIA'S EMIGRANT TAX IMPERILS TIES TO U.S.
description: The United States has reiterated a warning to Rumania that trade relations between the two countries may be cut back sharply if the Rumanian Government puts into effect a law that would restrict emigration, the State Department said last week.

title: New Weather Advisory For Drivers
description: Winter driving may not be among the great joys of travel, but the American Automobile Association is doing its part to make it a bit easier and safer.

title: A MATTER OF PAYING ATTENTION
description: PORTERHOUSE II in Lynbrook is the sequel to Porterhouse of Valley Stream, having been in the new location for about two years. It should be a better restaurant and, if more attention were paid to certain details, it could be.

title: This Week
description: When the temperature is above 40 degrees for a day, reapply antidesiccants to rhododendrons, hollies, evergreen azaleas, dwarf conifers or other valued evergreens subject to winter sun and windburn. Valentine's Day

title: BIGGER AND BETTER LEEKS NEED AN EARLY START
description: It is time to think leeks. Since this distinguished member of the onion family is a slow grower, starting should not be delayed. We have already planted our first leek seeds indoors, but will continue to plant seed this month and next so we can have leeks as thick as our wrists by midsummer continuing into November.

title: PLAYERS OF FUTURE ARE PROMINENT AMONG ALL-STARS
description: LOS ANGELES WHEN one buys a program at such gatherings as today's 33d National Basketball Association All-Star Game at the Forum in nearby Inglewood, it is hardly necessary to look past the line of first names that dot the lineup to comprehend the magnitude of the affair. Listed are Kareem and Moses, who are basketball's finest centers; Julius and Artis, players with illustrious pasts who still dominate the present, and Buck and Isiah, the stars of the future.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
SPRING ROLLS ARE LIKE EGG ROLLS, BUT GLORIFIED
description: FEI LO, the author of ''The Dim Sum Book: Classic Recipes from the Chinese Teahouse'' (Crown), teaches regional Chinese cooking at the China Institute in America in New York.

title: TEATIME
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed Pamela Harlech's mouth-watering article on teatime in London but was surprised that she did not mention the Dorchester Hotel, where a delicious and bountiful tea is served every afternoon in the elegant lobby.

title:
DINING OUT;
TRUFFLES WHERE A TREE USED TO BE
description: SEVERAL years ago, the tiny Morris County town of Meyersville was put on the map, so far as food people were concerned, when the Foy brothers opened the original Tarragon Tree restaurant. After the brothers moved on to open individual restaurants - John at Le Delice in Whippany and Denis at The Tarragan Tree in Chatham - there was a void that several restaurants tried unsuccessfully to fill.

title: CLINICS OPPOSING BIRTH-CONTROL RULE
description: TAPED to the window of the waiting room in the Planned Parenthood clinic in Hackensack is a note printed in felt marker: ''Planned Parenthood of Bergen County Absolutely Will Not notify parents of minors receiving services.''

title: Yugoslav Winner
description: Bojan Krizaj of Yugoslavia posted his first World Cup victory of the season today with a slalom performance that he said surprised him.

title: NEW RULES SET ON SUSPENSIONS OF CITY HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS
description: New procedures governing suspensions of students in New York City's high schools have been formulated by the Schools Chancellor, Frank J. Macchiarola.

title: NASSAU'S NEW NEIGHBOR
description: Some may call it grumbling, but James Harvie, vice president of the Collins Development Corporation, says Princetonians are simply asking questions about the kiosk going up at the entrance to Palmer Square, across the street from Princeton University. Collins bought this hub of the town's commercial district from the university in 1980 for $17 million and announced plans for an expansion of the Nassau Inn and the creation of new office, retail and residential space.

title: VALUE OF THE PLACEBO BEING ARGUED ON ETHICAL GROUNDS
description: A woman who is a frequent patient at the Shands Teaching Hospital in Gainesville, Fla., recently returned to the emergency room and asked for drugs to alleviate chronic pain in her hip. Because doctors thought she was ''hooked on the needle,'' sometimes claiming relief even before the hypodermic was withdrawn, the attending physician ordered a nurse to give her a placebo.

title: CANADA USING A SOVIET SATELLITE TO AID IN RESCUES
description: Canada, in cooperation with the United States, the Soviet Union and France, has begun a program that uses satellites to help locate people in distress.

title: FEAR OF CRIME: THE DEBATE INTENSIFIES
description: SOMEHOW, no matter where the Roslyn Estates Village Trustees started, almost every item on their agenda the other night kept coming back to crime.

title:
CAMERA;
SHOPPING POINTERS FOR SLR CAMERA BUYERS
THE NEW VIETNAM SCHOLARSHIP
description: Ten years ago today, I stood on the floodlit tarmac of Tan Son Nhut air base and watched as a group of 27 American prisoners of war were delivered to freedom by United States Army helicopters. The men had been picked up from a Communistcontrolled rubber plantation near the Cambodian border, and their arrival was the first tangible benefit for Americans of the Paris peace accords, signed in late January.

title: Elliott Has Pole at Daytona
description: Bill Elliott, the pole-sitter, already was looking over his shoulder 24 hours before the start of the $220,000 Busch Clash.

title: Rabbi and Mrs. Samuel Freilich of Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Hadassah Freilich Tucker, to Joseph I. Lieberman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Lieberman, of Stamford, Conn.
description: The wedding is planned for March 20.

title: THE PROBLEMS OF PREGNANCY
description: The pregnant woman faces unique beauty challenges. The metabolic changes that occur during pregnancy can dramatically affect both her appearance and her state of mind. As hormone levels rise, particularly from about the 10th week on, many women feel a positive change in their moods, some experts say. The radiant glow commonly associated with pregnancy may, in fact, be related to mental as well as physical alterations.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE
description: Marques Johnson, a forward with the Milwaukee Bucks, will not only play in the National Basketball Association All-Star game in Los Angeles today, he will also serve as the host for an 11-year-old boy who calls Johnson his favorite player. Maltese Williams, a burn victim from Milwaukee, has been flown with his uncle to Inglewood, Calif., where Johnson will make them his guests at a hotel, a $100-aplate banquet and the All-Star game.

title: MAN'S BEST FRIEND? NOT WITH A 'DOG BELL'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paula Elise Roland to Marry Paul Charles Marcus
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Roland of Teaneck, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Paula Elise Roland, to Paul Charles Marcus, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Marcus of Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: KARL MALDEN IN 'TWILIGHT TIME'
description: ''Twilight Time'' is a halfway foreign film, which means that it's set in a distant land (Yugoslavia) and populated by some local extras but chiefly written and directed in a conventionally mawkish style that is universal. It's a curious hybrid, and at unexpected moments a gentle and touching one, particularly whenever Yugoslav-born Karl Malden has an opportunity to make the most of his role.

title: NEEDIEST CASES FUND IS AIDED BY THE GIFTS OF RELIGIOUS LEADERS
description: Church leaders and other representatives of religious faiths, recognizing a charitable obligation beyond their own parishes or neighborhoods, often contribute to the broader commmunity embraced by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title:
HOW TO TIGHTEN THE FLOW OF TECHNOLOGY;
SET UP A SPECIAL, HIGH LEVEL AGENCY
description: TRADE with the Soviet Union is in our national interest. In additiont o increased jobs and enhanced earnings to be reinvested in research a nd development, trade ties with the Soviet bloc countries can have a n important, though limited, effect toward moderating Soviet b ehavior.

title: TOWNS TAKE STEPS TO CONSOLIDATE
description: BEFORE the year ends, residents in Putnam, both the town and the city, a small municipality within the borders of the northeastern town, will have to decide whether the boundaries they erected nearly 100 years ago should be pulled down.

title: HEALTH PLANS AND MATERNITY BENEFITS
description: MARY is a sales manager in a large company. Her husband Joe recently had his appendix removed and the c ompany's health insurance plan paid all $2,000 of his medical costs.T im works with Mary, and his wife recently had a baby. The health p lan paid only $500 of the couple's $2,000 maternity bill.

title: Yale Chips In For New Haven
description: Yale may be considered one of New Haven's great resources, but the feeling hasn't exactly been mutual. It probably didn't change much last week, but at least the university finally gave the city some credit.

title: Reagan, in Radio Talk, Defends Social Policies
description: President Reagan said today that the nation's troubled economy was recovering and suggested that critics who described his programs as unfair to the poor were guilty of slander.

title: ETHICS AND THE LAW
description: As a practicing lawyer for over 25 years, I have a deep commitment to the very strong public policy supporting the lawyer's obligation to keep clients' secrets and confidences sacred.

title: THE REAL NICOLE AND DICK
description: SARA & GERALD Villa America and After. By Honoria Murphy Donnelly with Richard N. Billings. Foreword by William M. Donnelly. Illustrated. 254 pp. New York: Times Books. $17.95.

title: Researching History In Great Neck
description: We in the Great Neck public schools have been researching the history of our peninsula since last summer. We received a grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities to develop a historical instructional kit for fourth-grade teachers.

title: MONEYMAKERS; Paid Access
description: New Jersey's State Republican Committee wants to form a ''Governor's Club'' that would offer members access to Governor Kean, his Cabinet and legislators in exchange for a minimum annual gift of $1,000. Michael Horn, Chairman of the State Ethics

title: FAIRFIELD PLAN WINS APPROVAL
description: A NEW regional plan for lower Fairfield County, which had been the center of disagreement between Darien and Stamford, won unanimous approval last Monday night.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: MUSIC Modern symphony orchestras are frequently chastised for the predictable sameness of their programming: typically a safe short novelty followed by a concerto followed by a warhorse symphony. So, the fact that this week's New York Philharmonic program includes Schubert's ''Unfinished'' Symphony might seem little cause for comment.

title: Giving Advice On Nutrition
description: In the article "How Nutrition Became a Life Style" (Jan. 9), Betty Kamen is described as a nutritionist. While "nutritionist" can be a genuine job title, it is a term that anyone can adopt.

title: THE DIGITAL ERA GIVES RISE TO THE 'TONMEISTER'
description: Easy-does-it often brings better results than a gung-ho try. Most craftsmen already know this, but they're just learning it in the record business, where almost everyone has been trying a little too hard lately. For a while it seemed that engineers let themselves be lured by the new digital techniques into attempting ''ultrafidelity'' recording that allows technical braggadocio to prevail over musical considerations. Instead of capturing the natural sound of music as it might be heard from a good seat in a good hall, engineers were tempted to show off their tricks in a more drastic fashion. Aiming for ''spectacular'' sound, they moved their microphones close to the performers, thereby exaggerating sonic detail out of its natural proportion so that detail overwhelmed the aggregate and - so to speak - the sound upstaged the music. No doubt the result was riveting. Some listeners were mesmerized by the sound. Others thought it crass.

title: HOSPITALS ENGAGED IN 'BUILDING BOOM'
description: The amount of money spent to build and renovate hospitals has increased dramatically in many states since the Reagan Administration started trying two years ago to abolish the Federal health planning program designed to prevent excessive spending.

title: LIFE: THE BIG SELL
description: IUSED the word ''esoteric'' in a class recently and then paused to s ee if anyone knew what it meant. The answer was quick to follow: ' 'Isn't that a skin cream that old people use to remove spots on t heir hands?''

title: WHO BUYS THE EXPENSIVE CO-OPS?
description: Manhattan is an island separated from the rest of the United States by, among other things, wealth. The Corcoran Group, a New York real-estate company, recently developed a statistical profile of the buyers in the 180 Manhattan co-op and condominium transactions it handled in 1982.

title: SChool Prayer Banned Again
description: Advocates of prayer in the schools took heart at President Reagan's proclamation two weeks ago that 1983 is ''the year of the Bible.'' They got little cheer last week from Supreme Court Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr.

title: Polish Police Disperse Pro-Solidarity Throng
description: Several hundred policemen, firing tear-gas grenades and wielding rubber batons, dispersed more than 2,000 people demonstrating for the outlawed Solidarity labor union tonight.

title: No Headline
description: HALEY RETAINS HIS TITLE

title: ...WRONG? SILENCE IS RIGHT
description: ''Before you say anything more, it is my duty to warn you that anything you say may be used against you. Specifically, I may be required, or may decide on my own, to reveal what you tell me to a judge, a jury, the person who is suing you, the Internal Revenue Service, or the public prosecutor.''

title: Hanlon, Rangers Regain Confidence
description: Glen Hanlon voiced a question Saturday night that has been bothering the Rangers lately. ''Who knows why you lose confidence?'' he asked, sounding convinced that no answer existed. ''One day you have it, and then, just when you feel like you've got things under control, bang!, you lose it.''

title: Cabby Hurt in Canal Plunge
description: A 37-year-old taxicab driver was seriously injured last night when his car went off an opened drawbridge on the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn, the police said. The driver, who was unidentified, drove over the side of the Hamilton Avenue Bridge at 9:45 P.M. after the barriers failed to descend. The police said the cabby, who had been alone in the cab, was taken to Long Island College Hospital in serious condition.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball College: Georgetown at Connecticut (Television -ESPN, 8 P.M.); Fordham at Siena (Radio - WFUV-FM, 90.7; 7:45 P.M.); Southern California at Oregon State (Television -USA, 11 P.M.) Dog Show Westminster Kennel Club, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 9 A.M. A total of 2,621 dogs from 137 breeds and varieties are entered. Breeds to be benched and judged today are in the working, herding, terrier and non-sporting groups.

title: Advertising; Vanity Fair's Rebirth
description: AFTER almost half a century in the tomb, Conde Nast's Vanity Fair magazine is coming back to life with explosive vigor. Its first issue in March, due on the stands the first of that month, will carry a mind-boggling 168 pages of advertising.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the judging schedule for the Westminster Dog Show in the Sports section yesterday, the captions with photographs of Ch.

title: Washington Watch; Starting Point For Decontrol
description: TIMERS in the lawmaking process here say that a bill has a better chance of survival if a lot of people like it a little, than if a few people dislike it a great deal.

title: Grapple and Tackle
description: Steve Williams is his real name. On the professional wrestling circuit in the states of Arkansas, Louisiana, Mississippi and Oklahoma he is known as Doctor Death. Williams likes that name, and he is fervent about pro wrestling.

title: Val Adams, Radio-TV Reporter For Daily News and The Times
description: Val Adams, who covered radio and television for New York City newspapers for 30 years, died Saturday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J., where he had recently undergone surgery for lung cancer. He was 66 years old and lived in Glen Rock, N.J.

title: No Headline
description: Bruins Keep Rolling

title: ERVING PROVIDES A SPECTACULAR SHOW
description: With all of the save-it-for-the-highlight-film plays made by Julius Erving at the Forum today, it just didn't seem appropriate that the 33d annual All-Star Game would end on a play he failed to make.

title: Star Pastures, Sangue Triumph
description: Star Pastures and Sangue, a pair of foreign-bred 5-year-old mares, won the two divisions of the Santa Maria Handicap at Santa Anita today.

title: Curry Wins Championship
description: Donald Curry, surviving the first knockdown of his professional career, captured the World Boxing Association welterweight title tonight with a unanimous 15-round decision over Jun Sok Hwang of South Korea.

title: Salvador Weighs Freeing Prisoners for Pope
description: The Constituent Assembly will review cases of hundreds of political prisoners for possible release during Pope John Paul II's visit to El Salvador next month, two Government officials said today.

title: Crash Tied to Epilepsy Is Ruled as a Homicide
description: The Cook County medical examiner has ruled the deaths of a family of four to be ''homicide'' as the result of a two-car collision Jan. 30 that involved an epileptic driver.

title: Carrington Viyella
description: Carrington Viyella P.L.C. said today that James Spooner, chairman of the Vantona Group P.L.C., had been appointed chairman of its board. The outgoing Carrington Viyella chairman, William Fieldhouse, has relinquished his duties, the company added. Vantona last week succeeded in taking over Carrington Viyella.

title: Vietnam Assails China Over U.S. Oil Companies
description: Vietnam accused China today of violating Vietnamese sovereignty by allowing American oil companies to operate in the Tonkin Gulf, off northern Vietnam and southwestern China.

title: Executive Selected At Castle & Cooke
description: Castle & Cooke, producer and marketer of such brands as Dole pineapples and bananas and Bumble Bee tuna, has tapped a former Coca-Cola officer to be president and chief executive.

title: OPERA: MET STAGES STRAUSS'S 'ARABELLA' IN GERMAN
description: ''ARABELLA'' has traditionally been regarded as a connoisseur item, an opera into which Richard Strauss poured some of his most lyrically tender music as well as a good deal of sentimentality disguised as sophisticated comedy. The Metropolitan Opera introduced the work to the United States in an English translation 28 years ago, during Rudolf Bing's regime, and brought it back three times thereafter in an attempt to let it find its public. Last Thursday night, however, the Met reverted to the original German, with all the dangers that such a move entails for a work that is exceptionally complex and talky.

title: Doctor's License Lifted In Abortion on Girl, 12
description: The state Board of Medical Examiners has unanimously revoked the license of a physician accused of performing an illegal third-trimester abortion that nearly killed a 12-year-old.

title: 2 U.S. Marshals Killed In Shootout With 3 Men
description: Two United States marshals were killed and three other officers were wounded today when a gunfight broke out as the authorities tried to arrest a probation violator, the highway patrol said. One of those wounded, another marshal, was reported in critical condition.

title: Girl, 16, Shot to Death While Car Is Stranded
description: A 16-year-old girl was shot to death Saturday night in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn by one of two men who had become embroiled in an argument with her father. Prior to the argument, the men refused the father's pleas for assistance in freeing the family's stalled car.

title: No Headline
description: VILAS TOPS DENTON IN RICHMOND FINAL

title: DANCE: HARLEM TROUPE OFFERS 'WINGBORNE' AND 'BANDA'
description: DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM is an unusual ballet company. It has, among other things, an unfailing, heightened sense of theater, which made for an evening of glowing dance last Thursday at City Center.

title: RED LOBSTER LOOKING ABROAD
description: In the 15 years since the first Red Lobster opened its doors, the seafood restaurant chain has become one of the largest in the nation, with 350 establishments in 36 states. And now, with the opening of a restaurant in Japan, it is going international.

title: OPERA: 'TURN OF THE SCREW,' BY CHAMBER THEATER
description: THE Chamber Opera Theater of New York's reputation for highly professional presentations of important operas for smaller-thanconventional forces is sustained in its current, mostly admirable production of Benjamin Britten's entirely admirable operatic setting of ''The Turn of the Screw.'' This writer and a few other determined enthusiasts saw the second performance last Friday night, at the height of the blizzard of '83. The last three of the six scheduled performances will take place at the Marymount Manhattan Theater tomorrow, Thursday and Saturday at 8 P.M.

title: U.S. NAVAL STRATEGY IS READY, BUT IS THE NAVY?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hearts and Minds
description: Is there more than the usual amount of social hugging and kissing going on these days? So it seemed to us, and we wondered: Is it seasonal, peaking with Valentine's Day? Or is it cyclical - people huddling closer together against the recession's adversities?

title: Commodities; Fed's Role In Setting Margins
description: SHOULD the Federal Reserve regulate margins in the market for futures and options on financial instruments and stock indexes? Or should this power remain with the individual exchange? Needless to say, the industry views outside control over margins as a threat to free markets.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Advertising column in Business Day Thursday, data on the revenues of the magazine Psychology Today were incorrectly stated. A corrective item appears in the Advertising column on page D9.

title: LAWYER'S SILENCE: WRONG...
description: What kind of people would agree to keep silent even after learning that those they were trying to help were secretly using that help to lie, steal, destroy property or cause physical harm to others? Lawyers.

title: ART: HELEN WILSON'S COSMOPOLITAN MINIATURES
description: THE evident speciality of Helen Miranda Wilson, whose new paintings can be seen through Feb. 26 at the Monique Knowlton Gallery, 19 East 71st Street, is the small domestic interior. To be more precise, it is the very small domestic interior - the size of a jumbo postcard, a paperback novel or the pocket of a country coat.

title: VILLANOVA UPSETS N. CAROLINA
description: Villanova, which had voted to make the trip through a snowstorm rather than cancel the game, took an early lead today and held on at the end to upset top-ranked North Carolina, 56-53.

title: ISLANDERS SLUMPING AT HOME
description: The Islanders, who last Thursday looked impressive in an 8-3 rout of the Washington Capitals, played listlessly on Saturday night and lost at home to a Hartford Whaler team that had not won in its last 13 games on the road.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Thursday about the Alfred I. duPont-Columbia University Awards for Broadcast Journalism omitted one winner. It was ''CBS Reports: People Like Us,'' with Bill Moyers.

title: TV: ANN-MARGRET PLAYS A DYING MOTHER OF 10
description: IF restaurants can get stars, certain kinds of movies deserve handkerchiefs. Those are the ones blatantly aimed at the tear ducts. Who can forget Margaret Sullavan in ''No Sad Songs for Me'' or Olivia de Havilland in ''To Each His Own''? Those were four-handkerchief productions, no doubt about it. Tonight on Channel 7 at 9, Ann-Margret is starring in a television movie called ''Who Will Love My Children?'' Let's give this one three, or maybe even three-and-ahalf handkerchiefs. Ann-Margret, the glamorous entertainer, who has already demonstrated her impressive acting talents in a few theatrical-release films, does a memorable turn.

title: Patlex Director Moves Into Chairman's Seat
description: Richard I. Samuel has been named chairman and president of the Patlex Corporation, which is involved basically in the business of patent enforcement.

title: 12-Year-Old Is Shot in Chicago In Reported Holdup Attempt
description: A 12-year-old boy was hospitalized in critical condition Saturday after he was shot while trying to hold up a grocery store with a toy gun, the police said.

title: LEAK OF RADIOACTIVE WATER CAUSES A SHUTDOWN OF INDIAN PT. 2 PLANT
description: The Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant was shut down yesterday after radioactive water leaked from a cooling system, Consolidated Edison said. The plant, in Buchanan, N.Y., was being restarted when the leak developed.

title: COMPRESSED SCHOOLING NEEDS AN INCENTIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: Film Series at Modern Focuses on Social Issues
description: ''The Passaic Textile Strike,'' a film produced in 1926 by International Workers Aid, opens the 12th annual ''What's Happening'' series at the Museum of Modern Art on Feb. 22 at 6 P.M.

title: FATIGUE SAPS SPIRIT OF RECORD VAULTER
description: BECOMING the first 19-foot pole-vaulter in indoor-track history has exhausted Billy Olson. He says he is ''mentally tired and physically worse.''

title: Rain Postpones Daytona Trials
description: Heavy rains today washed out the pole-position qualifying for next week's $1 million Daytona 500, as well as the $300,000 Busch Clash and an America Racing Club Association 200 stock car race.

title: U.S. EASING CONTROL OVER WESTERN RANGELAND
description: Western cattle ranchers stand to gain a large measure of control over land and water resources on 170 million acres of Federal land under policy changes initiated by the Reagan Administration.

title: IN PARIS, CELEBRITIES TALK OF ARTS AND THE ECONOMY
description: A dazzling array of novelists, movie stars, directors and intellectuals gathered here this weekend at the invitation of the French Government to explore the role of culture in resolving the world's world's economic crisis.

title: KNICKS ACQUIRE SPARROW
description: Rory Sparrow became the newest Knick Saturday in a trade that illustrated just how much his value has increased since the New Jersey Nets cut him in training camp in 1980.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: OUTDOORS: FUN FOR THE OLDER SKIER
description: IN many walks of life, older people complain about lack of respect for their generation. Fred Kerpen, a 72-year-old New York City resident, hasn't found that to be the case in skiing.

title: BARTER THE MX
description: The future of arms control for strategic weapons in this decade may be decided in the next few weeks. The Commission on Strategic Forces, under the chairmanship of Gen. Brent Scowcroft, is now due to report to President Reagan in mid-March with recommendations for basing the new MX missile - or some alternative plan for dealing with the perennial issue of the vulnerability of land-based missiles.

title: BONJOR CLARK KENT CHOSEN BEST OF PUGS
description: Although specialty shows caused the principal excitement in the dog show world yesterday, they were only a prelude to the main event, the 107th edition of the Westminster Kennel Club Show, which gets under way at Madison Square Garden this morning and ends tomorrow night.

title: I.M.F. PLAN HELPS EASE DEBT CRISIS
description: Last week the International Monetary Fund took a large step toward easing the world's latest financial crisis. Delegates meeting in Washington agreed to expand the I.M.F.'s lendable resources by $32.5 billion, or 47.4 percent. It is the largest increase in the organization's history, and the United States will have to contribute $5.8 billion of it.

title: Woman Held as Leader Of Cocaine Ring
description: Narcotics agents moved in on a baby shower and arrested a woman suspected of being the matriarch of a 70-member cocaine ring.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Fire in a Garret Gets Out of Hand

title: INFORMATION ABOUT TRANSIT
description: New York City - For subway and bus information, the Transit Authority, 330-1234; Big Apple Report on travel conditions, 976-2323.

title: HORACE DWIGHT TAFT, PHYSICS PROFESSOR AT YALE
description: Horace Dwight Taft, professor of physics at Yale University and former dean of Yale College, died of a heart attack Saturday while working in his office at the Josiah Willard Gibbs Laboratories on the Yale campus. He was 57 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: IN JERSEY, IT WAS DIG AND DIG AGAIN
description: The homeowner finally is free. After two days of digging, the suburbs are honeycombed with channels and trenches leading from front doors through the snow to the streets. It has, everyone says, been a test of will, patience and endurance.

title: Israelis Pressing Inquiry About Grenade Attack
description: The Israeli police have questioned ''many people'' in connection with a hand-grenade attack last Thursday at an anti-Government demonstration here, but no suspects have been detained, Meir Gilboa, a police spokesman, said today.

title: REVUE: 'BETTER WITH A BAND'
description: DAVID ZIPPEL'S lyrics are not yet as familiar as those of such celebrated contributors to American popular songs as Lorenz Hart, Ira Gershwin, E.Y. Harburg, Dorothy Fields or Johnny Mercer. But the cabaret revue called ''It's Better With a Band'' at Don't Tell Mama, 343 West 46th Street, indicates that they may be on their way.

title: DUTIES UNCERTAIN
description: Ariel Sharon, who submitted his resignation as Israel's Defense Minister on Friday, said today that he would accept Prime Minister Menachem Begin's offer to remain in the Cabinet as a minister without portfolio. The Cabinet accepted the arrangement.

title: Oil Slick in Kentucky Shuts City Water Plants
description: A 50-mile-long oil slick from a blownout oil well moved down the south fork of the Kentucky River today, causing the water-pumping plants of three communities to be shut down as crews tried to clean up the spill.

title: STAGE: ART AND POLEMICS IN ARRABAL'S 'INQUISITION'
description: THE plays of Fernando Arrabal are fierce tragicomic rituals that wrestle with the polarities of sacrifice and vengeance, saintliness and criminality. The work of this Spaniard living in Paris has always been grounded in his political consciousness; through his plays, he proclaims his anarchism and his outrage at injustice. The result, in his new play, ''Inquisition,'' at the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, is an uneasy amalgam of art and polemics, but because the author is Arrabal, the evening arrests our attention.

title: BEIRUT SEEKS AN END TO HARASSMENT OF PALESTINIANS
description: Lebanon has asked the United States to intervene with Israel to halt a campaign of intimidation against Palestinians in southern Lebanon by Christian militiamen.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I would like to make it clear that I have no intention of resigning from the Cabinet and I will continue to serve in it as minister.'' - Ariel Sharon. (A6:5.)

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Valentines

title: Irish Police Official Says Race Horse May Be Dead
description: A high-ranking police official involved in the search for the Aga Khan's stolen $13 million race horse said today that ''I must now take seriously the possibility that Shergar is dead.''

title: MX'S FOR ADMIRALS AND GENERALS TO SHARE
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinese Usher In Year of the Pig
description: China welcomed the Year of the Pig today with firecrackers, mass weddings, calls for frugality and reminders not to forget family planning.

title: OLD LOYALISTS IN SPAIN BATTLE FOR VETERANS' RIGHTS
description: Now, more than four decades later, Fernando Medina Martinez can laugh at the words with which he was sentenced to death in August 1939. The prose was so bureaucratic yet so passionate.

title: REAGAN CALLS FOR HIRING AND L.I. GROUP ANSWERS
description: When President Reagan suggested that much of the unemployment problem could be solved if every business hired one more person, the Long Island Association of Commerce and Industry responded.

title: SOUTH AFRICA 'COLOREDS' FIGHT PARTY DEAL
description: The largest political party among the mixedrace people officially designated as coloreds is running into resistance in the region around Cape Town, where most coloreds live, as a result of its decision to accept the constitutional deal being offered by Prime Minister P.W. Botha.

title: GOING BACK TO BASICS
description: THE great pitcher Bob Feller once said he had developed his fastball as a child by carrying pails of water from the Raccoon River to his family's farmhouse in Van Meter, Iowa.

title: THE WHYS OF EARLY CAMPAIGN GIVING
description: When money talks at this stage of a Presidential campaign, it neither pleads nor demands. It murmurs, and the motives of the contributors seem more innocent than cynics might imagine.

title: CHEMICAL CONNECTIONS: PATHWAYS OF LOVE
description: To be in love is merely to be in a state of perceptual anesthesia. - H.L. Mencken, 1927.

title: TEXAN RETURNS TO HOUSE WITHOUT RENEGADE TAG
description: Representative-elect Phil Gramm returns to his job in Washington this week and to his old seat on the House Budget Committee -but as a loyal Republican, not a renegade Democrat.

title: RESPONSE OF CICERO, ILL., TO A BIAS SUIT IS CLOUDED OVER BY THE CITY'S RECORD
description: Trouble began almost immediately when Ronnie L. Stackhouse moved into a Cicero apartment building a year ago. The tires of his 1972 Cadillac were shot or slashed and the windows were repeatedly broken. There were threatening phone calls and jeers on the street. His apartment was invaded by burglars.

title: CONSERVATIVES GATHER IN CITY TO DEFEND THEIR PRINCIPLES
description: A conservative attack - and a conservative lament - were part of a gathering this weekend in New York, as more than 200 writers and scholars met to explore what some termed an assault on ''good, oldfashioned American patriotism.''

title: BANKS AND OIL PRICING OUTOOK
description: A sharp decline in world oil prices could hurt the nation's banks more because of their loan exposure to the energy industry than because of their loans to oil-producing countries.

title: Wisconsin Democrats Give Up Primary Fight
description: Wisconsin Democrats, tired of an 11-year fight against the National Committee over their cherished open Presidential primary, voted Saturday to seek a change in state election law.

title: BASED ON HOFFMANSTHAL STORY
description: The unfinished libretto of ''Arabella,'' the 10th of Richard Strauss's 14 operas, was a legacy to him from Hugo von Hofmannsthal, who died four years before the world premiere at Dresden in 1933. The text was extensively revised by the composer.

title: Coin-Toss Suspense
description: At 6 P.M. last Thursday, Ray Patterson, the president and general manager of the Houston Rockets, left the lobby of the Century Plaza Hotel in Los Angeles, where general managers, coaches and owners were gathered for yesterday's National Basketball Association All-Star Game.

title: EAST WINS ALL-STAR GAME
description: There was little need for the 24-second clock. A 10-second clock might have been more appropriate today for the National Basketball Association All-Star Game, in which the East defeated the West, 132-123.

title: France's Bossard Hires Head of U.S. Operations
description: Bossard Consultants, France's largest management consulting firm, plans an expansion in the United States and has hired Frank D. Rich for the new job of president of United States operations.

title: Arrows Rally For 6-4 Victory
description: Paul Kitson scored two short-handed goals in the final period as the Arrows rallied for a 6-4 Major Indoor Soccer League victory over the Pittsburgh Spirit today.

title: TV: 'FRONTLINE' LOOKS INTO ITALIAN BANKER'S DEATH
description: WHEN Roberto Calvi, president of the largest private bank in Italy, was found hanged beneath London's Blackfriars Bridge last June, the shock of the death was heightened by the revelation that followed: Mr. Calvi, with the support of the Vatican, had made $1.4 billion in unsecured loans to shadowy companies in Panama. It was a scandal of international proportions.

title: Credit Suisse Volume
description: Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd. of London more than doubled its underwriting volume in 1982 on the Euromarkets from the previous year, its holding company, Financiere Credit Suisse First Boston, said. It was lead manager on or co-managed 254 issues, totaling $29.6 billion, the Swiss-based holding company said in a statement accompanying its results.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Civic Honors

title: FIREWORKS AND ICE FOR CHINATOWN'S YEAR OF THE PIG
description: ''One should rise before the cock's crow and explode firecrackers in the courtyard to ward off demons.'' So wrote Zong Lin of the New Year in the fourth-century text ''Records of Annual Festivals in Central China.''

title: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 14, 1983; Companies
description: Loan losses at United American Bank in Knoxville, Tenn., may prove to be much higher than the $2.3 million reported by the bank. Industry and state sources, involved in emergency meetings on the fate of the bank, say auditors believe the losses could total $50 million or more, with another $50 million classified as ''doubtful'' or ''substandard'' loans. (Page D1.)

title: Over Budget - and Under Strength
description: How much is enough for defense? It's the question of the hour but it may well be the wrong question. A new internal Air Force study suggests that the costs of its new planes and missiles are seriously underestimated: hence the President's budget will fail to buy the extra weapons he wants, even if approved in full.

title: U.N. Chief Arrives in Uganda
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations arrived in Uganda today on the final leg of an eight-nation African tour. The Secretary General has discussed talks on the independence of South-West Africa with officials in Angola, Zambia, Mozambique, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Tanzania and Kenya.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: ADESTE FIDO

title: No Headline
description: SEARCH IS HALTED FOR 9 CREWMEN OF STRICKEN SHIP

title: PRIVATE INVESTORS SELLING WIND POWER TO UTILITIES
description: In the last two years a forest of windmills has sprouted on the bare hills of Altamont Pass, 50 miles east of here, as private investors have tried to cash in on windgenerated electric power.

title: CARIBBEAN RECOVERY AWAITED
description: After a disappointing Christmas tourism season, the countries of the Caribbean are hopeful that a revived United States economy will help them ease their own economic problems.

title: PHIL MAHRE 4TH
description: On an icy, hazardous course, Ingemar Stenmark turned in a strong second run today and scored his first World Cup giant-slalom victory of the season.

title: Boston Goes After Scofflaws
description: The city will begin a crackdown Monday on 50,000 parking scofflaws who owe up to $15 million on about a million tickets, Boston's traffic commissioner says.

title: ASPIRING ROMANCE NOVELISTS SEEK WAYS TO BREATHE PASSION INTO THEIR PROSE
description: On the weekend before Valentine's Day, 298 aspiring romance novelists, mostly women, attended a convention here to learn how to write sensuous love scenes and other passionate passages.

title: TAXING CAPITAL GAINS: CHANGE HELPS INVESTORS
description: One of President Reagan's major changes in the tax field has been a lowering of the rate of taxation on capital gains: the maximum tax on long-term capital gains realized in 1982 is only 20 percent. As a result, it is more attractive than ever to invest in property that is expected to increase in value, be it over-the-counter stock, gold coins or a new home.

title: Anxiety at Cortland
description: There is a hand-painted sign tacked up outside the Bessiel Park Athletic Center at Cortland (N.Y.) State. ''Ice Rink For Sale,'' it reads, ''Contact Mario Cuomo.''

title: PLEADING INSANITY IS HERE TO STAY, INSANITY PLEA OR NOT
description: To the Editor:

title: Trial Set for Four On Fixing Charges
description: The trial of four men accused of fixing six races at the Yonkers and Roosevelt harness racing tracks in 1978 was scheduled to begin Monday at United States District Court here.

title: AFTER THE STORM: A DAY OF SHOVELING, REVELING AND RECOVERING
description: With stores, theaters and restaurants snowbound by the weekend storm, New York began to count the damage yesterday to the city's commerce and entertainment industry.

title: TRAVEL LIMPING TOWARD NORMAL AFTER SNOWSTORM
description: Snowplows cleared major arteries, airports were reopened and rail lines and subways resumed near-normal operations yesterday as residents of the New York metropolitan area continued to dig out from the worst winter storm in decades. For commuters today there were words of caution and hope.

title: FORECASTERS' MINOR MISTAKES CAN PRODUCE MAJOR SURPRISES
description: The paralyzing nature of the snowstorm that hit much of the East Coast in recent days caught New York and New England by surprise, showing once again that a small meteorological error can make an enormous practical difference.

title: CYPRIOT PRESIDENT WINS SECOND TERM
description: The President of Cyprus, Spyros Kyprianou, won election to a second five-year term Sunday with the support of the powerful Communist Party.

title: CITY BALLET: PETER MARTIN'S 'ROSSINI QUARTETS'
description: EVERY so often a ballet that seems to hark back to the past is actually something new. It is this kind of happy premiere that Peter Martins created last Thursday night at the New York State Theater for the New York City Ballet in his ''Rossini Quartets.''

title: TV: 'PERSEPHONE,' BALLET
description: ONE of the most ambitious undertakings of the New York City Ballet's 1982 Stravinsky festival was ''Persephone,'' which will be seen tonight on Channel 13 in ''Balanchine Celebrates Stravinsky,'' in the ''Great Performances'' ''Dance in America'' series. Created by Igor Stravinsky in 1933, ''Persephone'' is a blend of dance, music and declamation that has seldom been presented in anything but concert form. To tell the ancient myth of the abduction of Persephone by Pluto, ruler of the underworld, and of her subsequent return to earth as the personification of spring, the work requires a tenor, mixed chorus, boys' choir, dancers and orchestra. It also demands a performer who can move and recite verse.

title: Vatican Study Questioned
description: The Vatican was ''at best misleading'' in its description of its connections with two companies that played a part in the collapse of Italy's Banco Ambrosiano, according to a report in today's Sunday Times of London. The companies are said to be Manic, a Luxembourg holding company, and the United Trading Corporation of Panama.

title: POLICE AND FIRE DEPARTMENTS BEING MERGED IN KALAMAZOO
description: There will be no firefighters or police officers to serve this city's 80,000 people in five years, yet officials hope police and fire protection will be better than ever, at less cost.

title: U.C.L.A. MAY HAVE LOST THE MOST IN WEEKEND OF BIG UPSETS
description: U.C.L.A. may have lost its 7-foot-2-inch center, Stuart Gray, for the remainder of the season because of a knee injury he suffered when the Bruins were beaten by Oregon State, 69-65, Saturday at Corvallis, Ore.

title: DESPITE EFFORTS, TRAFFIC PROBLEMS SEEN FOR TUNNEL
description: A squadron of tow trucks worked through the day yesterday to clear many of the vehicles abandoned in the snow on the eastbound lanes of Route 3 at the New Jersey side of the Lincoln Tunnel. But officials warned that there would be serious traffic problems during this morning's rush hour.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Human Bus

title: A WAY TO TRACE LOST GEMS
description: A laser technique for inscribing identification names or numbers on gemstones has been developed by GIA Gem Trade Laboratory Inc., a subsidiary of the Gemological Institute of America. Thus, owners or purchasers of diamonds, rubies or other stones can have their possessions marked both to personalize them and to aid in identifying lost or stolen gems.

title: 5 Are Found Slain in Detroit
description: The bodies of two men and two children were found today in a house on the city's southwest side about six blocks from a motel where the body of the children's mother was discovered later, the police said.

title: IN WAKE OF GIANT SNOWFALL, A TIME TO FALL IN THE SNOW
description: In front of his home at 72d Street and Riverside Drive, Steve Osborne was digging his car out. It was in the parking space he always tries to get, but the spot is a poor choice when it snows. The city's plows had turned the corner there many times, and it was going to take some time before anyone would be able to recognize the car.

title: Dreams Died Early
description: When Ralph Sampson was a high school senior, he was making his own choice of where he would go to college and play his basketball.

title: Israeli Woman, Hit by a Rock Thrown by an Arab, Is Dead
description: An army spokesman said today that an Israeli civilian died Saturday of a head injury received two weeks ago when she was hit by a rock thrown at her by an Arab near the Israelioccupied West Bank town of Hebron.

title: Ziff Confirms Deal For Psychology Today
description: The Ziff Corporation, parent of Ziff-Davis Publishing, confirmed Friday that it had reached an agreement with the American Psychological Association in Washington to sell it the ailing Psychology Today magazine. The possibility of such a deal was reported here last Thursday.

title: SHORT-TERM RATES UNCERTAIN
description: Economists on Wall Street never seem to be at a loss to explain the latest wiggle in interest rates, although they concede that nobody has perfected a way for accurately predicting rates.

title: U.S. CALLED READY TO CONSIDER SHIFT ON MISSILE PLAN
description: President Reagan has agreed to consider recommendations from key allied leaders that he propose a compromise plan to the Soviet Union on reducing the number of medium-range missiles in Europe, White House officials said today.

title: CHAPLINS: ARE THEY CONSTITUTIONAL?
description: Standing in a nearly deserted Senate chamber, the Rev. Richard C. Halverson, a Presbyterian, began praying: ''God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, God and Father of us all ... ''

title: Philadelphia Commuters Are Spared a Rail Strike
description: Union leaders voted unanimously tonight to indefinitely postpone a strike that would have shut down commuter rail service for 50,000 commuters.

title: No Headline
description: AOKI'S EAGLE WINS IN HAWAII

title: FAIR OF GERMAN BOOKS COMING TO NEW YORK
description: For each of the last 35 years, American book publishers, editors and agents have attended the Frankfurt Book Fair, which is now the largest gathering of book people in the world. But next month more than 500 German-language publishers and booksellers will journey to New York for this city's first German Book Fair, which will simultaneously be celebrated by cultural events at Goethe House, the Deutsches Haus at New York University and the New School.

title: Market Place; Escalation in Stock Indexes
description: JUST when brokerage firms seemed to agree that phase one of the bull market in stocks was over, a strange thing happened: Several broad market indicators moved higher last week to finish at record levels.

title: BRIEFING
description: Tidewater Revisited

title: 'Butcher of Lyons' Says He Did His Duty
description: Klaus Barbie, the former Gestapo leader who was extradited to France eight days ago from Bolivia, said in a television interview today that he had forgotten his past and that the rest of the world should forget it as well.

title: U.S. DELAYS BUYING MORPHINE TO AVOID WAR-READY IMAGE
description: The Reagan Administration, in part out of concern about public fears that the United States might be prepared to wage a limited nuclear war, has decided to defer purchasing large quantities of a pain-killing drug stored to treat victims of wars and other national emergencies, according to Government officials.

title: Concealing the Boss's Pay
description: Full disclosure was the heart of the New Deal legislation that established regulation of securities and their markets. Let the markets rise and fall, but let no pertinent information be hidden from the investor. It has proved its worth over 50 years, yet this concept would now be whittled down by a proposal from the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, FEBRUARY 14, 1983
description: International Recommendations from key allies that President Reagan propose a compromise plan to the Soviet Union on reducing the number of mediumrange missiles in Europe will be considered by Mr. Reagan, White House officials said. He has been insisting on the complete elimination of such missiles. (Page A1, Column 6.) Ariel Sharon said he would accept Prime Minister Menachem Begin's offer to remain in the Cabinet as a minister without portfolio. He announced his decision in a formal letter notifying Mr. Begin of his resignation as Defense Minister, and the Cabinet accepted the new arrangement. Mr. Begin will act as Defense Minister until a new one is appointed. (A1:4.)

title: News Analysis
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin's willingness to retain Ariel Sharon in his Cabinet, even after insisting that he resign as Defense Minister, appears to have grown out of both political calculation and personal sentiments, officials here say.

title: HINCKLEY ON A HOSPITAL RESPIRATOR AFTER APPARENT SUICIDE ATTEMPT
description: John W. Hinckley Jr., found innocent by reason of insanity of shooting President Reagan, was in serious condition today after he apparently tried to kill himself, the authorities said.

title: Look Who's Not Bashing Japan
description: The big news in last week's report from Martin Feldstein, President Reagan's economic adviser, was the shift in Administration style: Tell It Like It Is has replaced the Joy of Free Lunch. No more predictions of a supply-side Phoenix rising from the ashes of Big Government.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: On a kickoff in a professional football game, a member of the receiving team is hit by the ball, which is then picked up by a player on the kicking team. Can he run for a touchdown? What is the ruling if the player does not take possession of the ball until it rolls into the end zone?

title: TREASURY SET TO AUCTION 2-YEAR NOTES IN WEEK
description: Treasury financing this week is confined to issues due in three months to two years - a range that dealers say is easier to distribute than longer-term securities.
