title: Margeotes and Others Capture New Accounts
description: Margeotes/Fertitta & Weiss has beaten a field of high-class talent and has won the Remy Martin Cognac account. And it wasn't the only agency ending the week in a blaze of glory.

title: MUSIC: MINNESOTANS PLAY AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: GIVEN the snowy weather, the Minnesota Orchestra's concert last Friday evening was not badly attended. Still, it is a pity that all the windy howling outdoors seemed to have kept so many people away from the civilized sounds emanating from the stage of Carnegie Hall.

title: RELATIONSHIPS
description: ONCE they agreed about money; now the joint checking account has b ecome a battlefield. Once the household chores were rotated; now shed oes the cooking and he pays the bills. Once they had a satisfying s ex life; now something is missing.

title: Pirates Criticized On Sale of Stock
description: A Pittsburgh city councilman has called for a public hearing on the recent sale of 48 percent of the Pittsburgh Pirates' stock to Warner Communications Inc.

title: MAYOR BYRNE PLAYS DOWN HER SEX IN CHICAGO RE-ELECTION CAMPAIGN
description: The Mayor of Carl Sandburg's ''City of the Big Shoulders'' recently confessed to a crowd of a thousand ''Women for Jane Byrne'' of fears she had when taking office three and a half years ago.

title: ECONOMIC THEORIES ALLERGIC TO PRACTICE
description: To the Editor:

title: AUTO DEALERS URGE MORE INCENTIVES
description: While generally optimistic about the auto industry's outlook for 1983, most dealers attending the National Automobile Dealers Association convention here this weekend said they consider the recent improvement in auto sales to be fragile and able to be choked off by any abrupt end to incentives.

title: News Analysis
description: The American Bar Association's meeting here this week sent a clear message: It is more important for lawyers to preserve confidential relationships with their clients than to prevent themselves from being used as shields for ongoing crime and fraud.

title: TENNESSEE BANK TALKS ACCELERATE
description: In a swirl of meetings this weekend in Atlanta and Knoxville, Tenn., to determine the fate of the United American Bank of Knoxville, industry and State Government sources said auditors had turned up loan losses much greater than the $2.3 million the bank has disclosed. They said the loan losses could total $50 million or more, with another $50 million categorized as ''doubtful'' or ''substandard'' loans.

title: NATHAN KLINE, DEVELOPER OF ANTIDEPRESSANTS, DIES
description: Dr. Nathan S. Kline, whose work in psychopharmacology helped revolutionize the treatment of mental illnesses, died Friday during a heart operation at University Hospital in New York. He was 66 years old and a longtime resident of Manhattan.

title: JAGGER, 39, SHOWS NO SIGN OF QUITTING
description: In the middle of the new Rolling Stones movie, ''Let's Spend the Night Together,'' Mick Jagger breaks into the old hit ''Time Is on My Side,'' and resonant images from the band's past flash across the screen: the Stones, dressed like schoolboys, making it as England's hottest new pop stars; the Stones playing ''Midnight Rambler'' in the late 60's as Mick Jagger cavorts on stage, a demonic figure cloaked in black and red, and the Stones, on their latest tour, mature professionals performing good, hard, driving rock-and-roll to an audience of more than 2 million.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Adams Resources and Energy Inc., Houston, has elected W.M. Kennedy and Jeff J. Wood vice presidents.

title: RECITAL: RENATA SCOTTO, MET SOPRANO
description: THE first of Petrarch's sonnets set by Liszt celebrates the paradoxes of love. ''I care for nobody, and could embrace the world,'' the translation reads. ''What binds me neither frees nor ties me down.'' And that is how Renata Scotto sang these settings in recital at the Metropolitan Opera on Sunday afternoon.

title: WALTON'S COACHING CAREER TAKES A SURPRISING TURN
description: JOE WALTON got the bad news in Hawaii a week or so ago. The Atlanta Falcons had not picked him to replace Leeman Bennett as head coach. The Kansas City Chiefs also had not picked him to replace Marv Levy. Now he was 0 for 2 in the National Football League's job market.

title: A Trustee Is Elected At Ford Foundation
description: William G. Milliken, former Governor of Michigan, has been elected to the Ford Foundation's 18-member board of trustees. Mr. Milliken retired last December from the governorship after serving 14 years, longer than any governor in the state's history.

title: Joan Snyder, Investment Banker, Weds
description: Joan Lynn Snyder, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Snyder of Manhattan and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Richard Lewisohn 3d, son of Richard Lewisohn and Mrs. Richard A. Feldon, both of Manhattan. Rabbi Ronald E. Sobel, senior rabbi of Temple Emanu-El, performed the ceremony at the couple's home in Manhattan.

title: Burger King Layoffs
description: The Burger King Corporation, a unit of the Pillsbury Company, said it had laid off 57 workers from its corporate staff in a move intended to cut overhead and streamline operations. The workers ranged from ''senior-level executives to filing clerks,'' said Jerry Ruenheck, Burger King president.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 14, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Non-Use of Force - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: On Looking For a Horse
description: IN the glow of the bluegrass twilight near Lexington, Ky., on June 25, 1977, the Claiborne Farm manager, John Sosby, was about to enjoy a quiet Saturday evening. Suddenly, on his walkie-talkie, he heard the crackling voice of his night security chief, Dexter Campbell.

title: VALENTINE HUMBUG
description: St. Valentine's Day may be a dandy time for a gangland massacre, but it's not my idea of a national holiday. On this day, across the nation, from every living heart and hearthstone, comes an outpouring of simpering sentiment and commercialized affection that is enough to wring the heart of every true lover. St. Valentine's Day is giving ''sweetheart'' a bad name.

title: Japan's Seko Wins Tokyo Marathon
description: Running in dry, bright weather, Toshihiko Seko ran the fourth-fastest marathon in history here today, winning the Tokyo Marathon through the streets of this city with a time of 2 hours 8 minutes 38 seconds.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE WATCHER. By Charles Maclean. 343 pages. Simon & Schuster. $14.95.

title: Toni Ellis Wexler and Thomas W. Mahr Are Wed
description: Toni Ellis Wexler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert I. Wexler of New York and Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to Thomas W. Mahr, son of Barbara Taylor and Michael M. Mahr, both of Baltimore. Rabbi Jacob Lantz performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: Bridge: Culbertson's 'Asking Bids' Did Not Catch On at First
description: Half a century ago Ely Culbertson had cornered the market in bridge books. Millions of players regarded him as the great authority, and awaited his pronouncements with eager interest. But in 1936 he tried to sell them a highly technical concept, and later said he was wrong to try. It was called the ''asking bids.''

title: HELLO, OUTSIDE WORLD
description: ONE advantage of a portable computer is being able to transmit data between wherever you are and the office. But personal-computer communication obviously goes beyond business use, and more people are using a computer at home to contact information services such as CompuServe, the Dow Jones News/Retrieval Service and The Source for catalog shopping, stock market data and educational and message services.

title: AMERICAN PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange

title: But Who Knows Wins
description: Not all winter dreams of the Kentucky Derby blossom in Florida and California. Some are forged amid the snow banks of Ozone Park, like the dream that began yesterday at Aqueduct for a gelding named But Who Knows.

title: CYPRUS PRESIDENT IS SWORN IN WITH COMMUNIST AT HIS SIDE
description: The Greek Cypriot head of state was proclaimed President of the republic today for another five-year term after a strong electoral victory in which he had the backing of the Communists.

title: Phillips Tests Well
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company said it had completed tests of an exploratory well in block B-1 off the Ivory Coast.

title: DI GIORGIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE DEPRESSION ARMY
description: News Item (yesterday) - ''The city Human Resources Administration reported that 4,869 men and women sought refuge Saturday night at 13 shelters. The figure is about average for this time of year.''

title: SOUTHWEST LEASING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a sale of tax attributes of $203,000 for the qr and $269,000 for the9 mos

title: JEFFERSON-PILOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Foreman Is Cut In Comeback Bid
description: Chuck Foreman got the bad news yesterday in the camp of the Los Angeles Express of the United States Football League: At the age of 33, attempting a comeback after two years on the sidelines, he was cut from the squad.

title: REFLECTONE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes gains on the sale of real estate of $1,847,254 for the qr and 9 mos

title: METROMEDIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After income from discontinued operations of $2,609,000 for the qr and $20.6 million for the yr and a gain of $202,388,000 on dispositions for the qr and yr...C-After income of $5.5 million from discontinued operations...D-After income of $21,294,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $479,000 on dispositions; the 1982 net from continuing operations includes $50,045,000 or $13.45 a shr relating to gains on disposition and retirement of debt

title: MAGICIAN'S EFFORT TO DEBUNK SCIENTISTS RAISES ETHICAL ISSUES
description: ACONTROVERSY is rippling through the borderlands of science over how best to aid the quest for truth in the marshy backwater of psychic research.

title: BRIEFING
description: Treading Lightly

title: Galiffa Makes the Hall
description: Arnie Galiffa, the Army quarterback, was named to the National Football Foundation's College Hall of Fame.

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss)

title: Frank Sabasteanski, Coach Of Track Team at Bowdoin
description: Frank F. Sabasteanski, the track coach at Bowdoin College here for the last 28 years, died of cancer Sunday at the age of 62.

title: BRAEWOOD DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After establishment of a reserve of $2,001,659 for the qr and 6 mos for loss on investment in Tradewood partnership...C-Net income

title: BEI and 2 Owners On Trial in Theft
description: Two men and the corporation they owned went on trial today on charges of conspiring to steal computer equipment valued at up to $7 million from the Nixdorf Computer Corporation of Burlington, Mass.

title: ASTRO DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; Yr-ago revs have been reclassified to eliminate the tax effect ofthe sale of a drilling rig

title: AMDISCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $15,000 for the latest firstqr and $27,000 for the yr-ago first qr

title: 96 BOOKS ARE NOMINATED FOR AWARDS
description: Books by such well-known writers as Eudora Welty, Dumas Malone, Russell Baker, Judy Blume and Paul Theroux have been nominated for the fourth annual American Book Awards, along with those of first novelists Gail Albert, John M. Del Vecchio, Susanna Moore, Gloria Naylor and David Small.

title: Military Analysis
description: The continuing controversy over the basing of the MX intercontinental ballistic missile, which is delaying the production of the missile itself, has provoked debate in the military establishment, raising questions about the soundness of the present division of responsibility for United States strategic nuclear forces.

title: AIR WISCONSIN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
News Summary; TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 15, 1983
description: International Israel's new Defense Minister is to be Moshe Arens, the Ambassador to the United States, who, like the outgoing Defense Minister, Ariel Sharon, holds hard-line views on key aspects of Israeli policy. Mr. Arens's appointment, announced by Prime Minister Menachem Begin's office, is expected to be approved by the Cabinet and Parliament. (Page A1, Column 6.) The small Persian Gulf states are increasingly concerned over falling oil prices. For the first time since the big price spurt in 1974, the conservative, pro-Western rulers of Kuwait and the other vulnerable oil-producing countries are learning that they can no longer count on constantly rising revenue to buy domestic peace. (A1:5-6.)

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 15, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Outer Space Scientific and Techni- cal Subcommittee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Ferraro Is Released
description: The Cleveland Indians' manager Mike Ferraro, who had a cancerous kidney removed last week, was released from Holy Cross Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.,yesterday.

title: GREAT DANE GAINS WESTMINSTER FINAL
description: The top-winning dog in America last year, Ch. C & B's Special-K Gribbin, became the first finalist in the 107th Westminster Kennel Club show, which opened a two-day run at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

title: TYMSHARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Top Jersey Court Rules on Alimony
description: The State Supreme Court ruled today that divorced spouses do not necessarily lose their alimony when they begin cohabiting with another person.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: From Slush to Romance For 250 Lucky Readers

title: WHITE HOUSE OFFER ON E.P.A.'S PAPERS IS STILL UNDER STUDY
description: A decision will made in the next few days on the Reagan Administration's offer of a compromise to give Congress access to documents from the Environmental Protection Agency, a spokesman for Representative Elliot M. Levitas, Democrat of Georgia, indicated today.

title: Quake Deaths Fall
description: Earthquake deaths fell substantially last year, although there were more significant quakes, according to the United States Geological Survey.

title: SENIOR MEMBER IS RENOMINATED TO UTILITY PANEL
description: Governor Cuomo, who has promised to restructure the state's Public Service Commission, announced today that he was renominating the commission's senior member, Edward P. Larkin, to another six-year term.

title: Midgetman
description: There's an irony in the arms race: Sometimes the weapons that most threaten American security are those invented by the United States. A case in point is the MIRV missile, the multiple independently targeted re-entry vehicle that America started deploying in the mid-1960's. It was the Soviet Union's deployment of its own MIRV's that has made America's 1,000 fixed, land-based Minutemen theoretically vulnerable and created the pressure to find alternatives, like the huge, 10-warhead MX.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Internal developments in Israel do not have - and will not have - any impact on the process of peace in the Middle East.'' - Menachem Begin. (A8:1.)

title: XOIL ENERGY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
Market Place; Big Changes At Rowe Price
description: WHEN the T. Rowe Price Growth Stock Fund was started in 1950, its first investment was in International Business Machines. Today, I.B.M. ranks as the largest single holding and accounts for 7.2 percent of the mutual fund's net assets, which exceeded $1 billion at the end of 1982.

title: New HBO President Named by Time Inc.
description: Time Inc. said yesterday that it had named a new president and chief executive of Home Box Office Inc. and promoted the current HBO head to a newly created post of deputy group vice president for video in the Time organization.

title: OWNERSHIP OF A HOME: WISE PLANNING PAYS OFF
description: Some homeowners may be hit with an unexpected tax liability this year. When interest rates were rising, many banks offered to buy back low-interest mortgages from their customers at a substantial discount. The difference between the outstanding mortgage and the amount paid to cancel the debt could be considerable - and it is taxable income. ''When the banks came around and said, 'You have outstanding a $60,000 mortagage at 5 percent, but if you give me $40,000, I'll consider it paid off,' most people didn't realize they would be taxed on the difference,'' said Gail Winawer of Oppenheim, Appel, Dixon & Company, an accounting firm. ''But that's $20,000 of taxable ordinary income.''

title: DAKOTA 'FANATIC' HUNTED IN SLAYING OF 2 MARSHALS
description: Federal and state officers searched a foggy prairie today for a 63-year-old ''fanatic'' tax protester after two Federal marshals who tried to arrest him were shot to death.

title: TIME-DC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary loss of $25,000...C-Includes a loss of $2,612,000 for the qr from discontinued operations, an extraordinary loss of $1,116,000 for theqr, a loss of $3,118,000 for the 6 mos from discontinued operations, and an extraordinary credit of $2,084,000 for the 6 mos...D-Net loss

title: ANACOMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Parker Pen Prices
description: The Parker Pen Company said it had cut prices up to 33.8 percent on two of its four principal lines of writing products in the United States. The company attributed the reductions to reduced manufacturing costs and a more competitive marketing policy.

title: Mrs. Hauptmann Loses Court Bid
description: Anna Hauptmann, whose husband, Bruno Richard Hauptmann, was executed in 1936 for the kidnapping and murder of the baby son of Charles Lindbergh, lost another round today in her $100 million wrongful-death suit.

title: A SOCIAL SECURITY PROPOSAL FOR DOUBLE
description: To the Editor:

title: NATIONAL GALLERY OF ART A HIGH POINT OF CULTURE
description: The lights were low and David Smith's sculpture stood witness in the courtyard of the National Gallery's East Building as several hundred dinner guests in black tie and taffeta gathered for cocktails and canapes.

title: DRESSER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PALESTINE COUNCIL OPENS WITH A VICTORY FOR ARAFAT
description: The Palestine National Council opened its 16th session today with Yasir Arafat beating back attempts by radical factions to reject President Reagan's Middle East peace plan, senior conference officials said.

title: TRUS JOIST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOLING A WEDGE AT 18 TO WIN
description: O n the television screen, Isao Aoki's wedge shot floated up from the rough 128 yards away. The ball soared over a bunker toward the flagstick on the 18th green, bounced once and hopped into the cup. ''One hop, down,'' he would say later. And with that startling shot for an eagle 3 on the final hole, the slender Japanese touring pro suddenly had won the Hawaiian Open by one stroke.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: EVEN at midblizzard midnight, at that exact moment when last week b ecame the weekend, the windows at Tiffany were quietly bright. The C rown Building, across the street, was quiet too, the gaudiness of i ts lights softened by snow. Inside the Trump Tower, the blowers g lowed and roared but no other noise disturbed the Atrium, New York'sn ewest vertical shopping mall.

title: NOT A 'BROKEN MAN,' SHARON SAYS TO STAFF IN A FAREWELL SPEECH
description: Ariel Sharon stepped down as Defense Minister today, saying in a farewell speech to his staff that he was not ''leaving office a broken man.''

title: Transactions; AUTO RACING
description: Announced that An- d rea De Cesaris and Mauro Baldi would d rive its race cars in Formula I competi- t ion this season. BASEBALL METS (NL) - Signed three pitchers, R ick Ownbey, Walt Terrell and Scott Dye t o one-year contracts. BOSTON (AL) - Signed eight players, i ncluding three who had filed for arbitra- t ion: John Tudor and Steve Crawford, p itchers, and Glenn Hoffman, shortstop. O thers signed were Brian Denman and B rian Kingman, pitchers, Julio Valez and J ackie Guiterrez, shortstops, and Gus B urgess, outfielder. CHICAGO (NL) - Signed Lee Smith, r ight-handed relief pitcher, to one-year c ontract. MINNESOTA (AL) - Ron Davis, relief p itcher formerly with Yankees, won arbi- t ration case and an increase of $175,000 to $ 475,000; Bobby Castillo, pitcher, sought $ 360,000 and lost to Twins' offer of $185,000.MONTREAL (NL) - Signed Jeff Rear- d on, right-handed relief pitcher, to one- y ear contract. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Lonnie Smith, out- f ielder, lost in arbitration and will receive $ 500,000 for the 1983 season. Smith had b een seeking $580,000.

title: Dioxin Found at Illinois Sites
description: Investigators have found dioxin contamination at two dump sites in Southern Illinois, the Envionmental Protection Agency said today. The two sites, near Cahokia and Sauget, were known to have been used by a waste-oil hauler, Russell Bliss, whose spraying of dusty sites in Missouri several years ago has been blamed for contamination there. The E.P.A. said further tests would be necessary to determine the extent of the contamination.

title: THE U.S.  MISSILES BONN NEVER ASKED FOR
description: To the Editor:

title: HEART PATIENT, NOW 'FAIR,' GETS PRIVATE ROOM
description: Dr. Barney B. Clark's condition was upgraded to fair today, and he was moved out of his hospital's intensive care unit into a private room.

title: PHOTON SOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DANCE: FRED BENJAMIN OFFERS 'PARELLEL LINES'
description: FOR the most part, the Fred Benjamin Dance Company was out to entertain when it appeared Friday night at Symphony Space as part of the Harlem Cultural Council's Dancemobile Winter Series. Mr. Benjamin was not afraid to be boisterous in his choreography, and his troupe danced up a merry storm while a real storm raged outside. But the dancers' warmth made Symphony Space a cozy place to be.

title: Bridge: Negative Redouble Gives Point to a Nursery Rhyme
description: Some bridge players would do well to study the story of Simple Simon, who doggedly set out to catch a whale in his mother's pail. The moral, of course, is that if the enterprise you are considering is hopeless, something not quite hopeless should be attempted instead.

title: THOMSON TO BUY AMERICAN BANKER
description: The International Thomson Organization, the Canadian-based energy, travel and communications company, announced yesterday that it would acquire American Banker and The Bond Buyer, the daily newspapers for the banking industry and the tax-exempt bond sector.

title: SOUTHMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes tax credits of $3,741,000 for the qr and $5,564,000 for the 6 mos...C-Includes tax credits of $5,485,000 for the qr and $11,535,000 for the 6 mos

title: GENSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
YARBOROUGH SETS MARK, THEN CRASHES
description: Cale Yarborough set a Grand National speed record of more than 200 miles per hour on the first of his two qualifying laps today, then sent his car crashing into a retaining wall on the second lap and was forced to withdraw it from next Sunday's Daytona 500.

title: Kraft to Modify La Creme Claim
description: When Kraft takes on General Foods' Cool Whip topping with its La Creme product and the advertising keeps repeating ''real cream'' and ''cream'' and ''real cream taste'' over and over, a consumer could get the idea that the Kraft product is predominantly cream. At least that is what the National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus said after a complaint from General Foods.

title: BROWN, TOM, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REAGAN JOBS BILL GAINS MOMENTUM WITH DEMOCRATS
description: Congressional Democrats said today that they would accept a $4.3 billion emergency jobs bill proposed by the White House as a starting point in dealing with unemployment. But they said they would try to add about $1 billion to the measure.

title: New Delay for Shuttle
description: The launching of the space shuttle Challenger has been delayed until at least the mid-March because of a leak in the inlet a replacement engine, the National Aeronautics and Space Adminstration said today.

title: AN E.P.A. VICTORY OVER HAZARDOUS WASTE
description: To the Editor:

title: WASHINGTON POWER'S PROBLEM
description: There seems little doubt now that the Washington Public Power Supply System will be unable to meet a $15.7 million monthly interest payment to the Chemical Bank on March 31, credit market analysts agree. At that point, the nation's largest issuer of tax-exempt bonds would lapse into technical default on $7 billion of principal and interest on bonds issued for two abandoned nuclear power plants.

title: SIPPICAN OCEAN SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split declared Jan 5, 1983

title: Delora L. Gans Is Wed To Dr. Frederick Hyde
description: Delora Louise Gans and Dr. Frederick Herbert Hyde were married yesterday in the chapel of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York by the Rev. Beatrice Blair.

title: PLAIN-SPOKEN HARD-LINER FOR ISRAEL
description: Shortly before the announcement today that Moshe Arens, the Israeli Ambassador to the United States, was to return home and become Defense Minister, he was fending off telephone calls asking him if he was Prime Minister Menachem Begin's choice to replace Ariel Sharon.

title: Problem Seen For Bell Units
description: The 22 Bell System companies could have a rough time raising money after they are set free by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, according to a report by the Federal Communications Commission staff that became available today.

title: BASIC EARTH SCIENCE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
I.B.M. Sees Rise In 1983 Shipments
description: The International Business Machines Corporation expects shipments of its large processors to increase in 1983, according to the company's 1982 annual report.

title: Litton's Itek Offer
description: Litton Industries said 4,018,587 common shares of the Itek Corporation, as well as $18,494,000 of debentures, were tendered as of Feb. 11 under a Litton unit's tender offer.

title: Regan: Fed Supervision Of Lending
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan told a Senate banking subcommittee today that the Federal Reserve Board and other bank regulators should exercise greater supervision over bank lending overseas.

title: E.P.A. AND AIDE REACH SETTLEMENT AVERTING HEARING ON HARASSMENT
description: The Environmental Protection Agency reached a negotiated settlement today with an official whose charges that the agency was mismanaging its toxic waste programs brought on several Congressional investigations.

title: Mush, to the Ring
description: It's not that dogs are necessarily hardier than people, but most of the dogs made it to the Garden for the 107th Westminster Kennel Club show, despite the snowstorm that struck the Northeast. Not only that, but all 36 judges made it from 18 states and Canada, except for one who was sick.

title: MARION PRESTON WED IN BOSTON
description: Dr. Marion Mason Preston, daughter of Mrs. Charles Drury Preston of Lake Forest, Ill., and the late Mr. Preston, was married yesterday to Dr. Russell Nicholas Ake Cecil, son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell C. Cecil of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Edward Miller, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the bride's home in Boston.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Other Suriname
description: Only on fugitive occasions does the spotlight touch Suriname, until 1975 a Dutch colony in South America spelled without the final ''e.'' Now, alas, Suriname is getting five minutes of fame for a dismal reason: it has succumbed to a tyrant named Bouterse, who in one bloody swoop killed nearly every rival of importance in Paramaribo, the capital.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Police Enable Doctor To Beat the Storm

title: EX-STATE SENATOR FACES VOTE CHARGE
description: Former State Senator Vander L. Beatty of Brooklyn was indicted yesterday on forgery and other charges stemming from his unsuccessful attempt to win a 1982 Congressional primary.

title: GERMANS GETTING TO KNOW KOHL'S HARD-RUNNING FOE
description: Hans-Jochen Vogel, the Social Democratic candidate for Chancellor, is running hard despite the handicaps of a party short on funds and opinion polls that put his opponent five or six points in the lead.

title: QUEENS MAN FACES I.R.A. GUN CHARGE
description: A 47-year-old Queens man, who was a fugitive in Ireland until he voluntarily returned to the United States and surrendered over the weekend was arraigned in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of conspiring to smuggle firearms and explosives to the Provisional Irish Republican Army.

title: 'Danton's Death' Opens
description: Georg Buchner's ''Danton's Death,'' a play about Robespierre's Reign of Terror during the French Revolution, will open March 17 at the CSC Repertory, 136 East 13th Street. The play, which completes the repertory for the season, will run through March 31.

title: Tribute to Strasberg At Fund-Raising Event
description: A fund-raising tribute to Lee Strasberg, the late head of the Actors' Studio, will be held at Avery Fisher Hall on May 23. The ''With Heartfelt Thanks'' benefit, with tickets from $25 to $1,000, is aimed at raising $1 million for the Children of the World Program of the Deborah Heart and Lung Center of Browns Mills, N.J.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CHANNEL OF BEAUTY

title: CITY COUNCIL HEARS DISPUTE ON FIRE DEPT. MANNING CUTS
description: Fire officials and union leaders yesterday brought before the City Council their dispute over a proposal to reduce the number of firefighters riding on pumper trucks.

title: BBDO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results reflect foreign currency translation losses of $92,000 and $322,000 forthe latest qr and yr, respectively, and $34,000 and $108,000 for the yr-ago qr and yr respectively; shr earnings have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in Jan 1983

title: BARDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
Sonny Dove, St. John's Star In 1960's, Dies in Car Plunge
description: Lloyd (Sonny) Dove, a basketball star at St. John's University in the 1960's who later played professionally for the Detroit Pistons and the New York Nets, died early yesterday of injuries he suffered when a taxicab he was driving plunged into the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn.

title: NLI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The yr-ago qr and 6 mos figures were restated for change in method of accounting for company investments

title: OTHER MARKETS HELP CORN SHOW STRENGTH
description: Futures prices of corn, the nation's most important crop, continued to advance yesterday despite record supplies of the grain. In fact, the prices of the 1983 crop, which has not yet been planted, closed at or near contract highs. The demand spilled over into the wheat and soybean markets, where price gains were even larger.

title: SOVIET SHIPS CAME CLOSE, NAVY SAYS
description: Two Soviet warships recently sailed within 50 miles of the Gulf Coast, United States Navy officers said today. The officers said it was the closest that Soviet warships had come to the United States since they periodically began deploying to the Caribbean in 1969. Soviet trawlers gathering intelligence on United States missile tests have long lingered just off the coast of Florida, and Soviet submarines may have penetrated within 50 miles before.

title: Talking Business with Graham of Jones & Laughlin; Upturn in Steel Looks Weak
description: The steel industry has just completed one of its worst years. Shipments of steel in 1982 totaled a meager 59.8 million tons, the lowest level since 1949. Some large producers, such as the United States Steel Corporation and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, have closed major plants. And as bargaining for a new contract begins, the United Steelworkers Union of America is being asked for wage and benefit concessions. With local union leaders showing little willingness to grant them, the possibility of a strike looms. Thomas C. Graham, the president and chief executive of the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation, a subsidiary of the LTV Corporation that is the nation's third-largest steel company, discusses the industry's outlook for the year.

title: PACIFIC SCIENTIFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the 1982 yr include an increase of $6,000,000 from acquisitions made by the company during Sept 1981

title: AS OIL REVENUE FALLS, KUWAIT TIGHTENS ITS BELT AND WORRIES
description: Falling world oil prices are sending tremors of apprehension through this tiny state at the head of the Persian Gulf. Kuwait's alarm is shared to varying degrees by all the other small oil exporters along the Gulf, from Bahrain down through Qatar and the United Arab Emirates to Oman.

title: HEALTH CARE IN CANADA: POPULAR SYSTEM NOW ROCKED BY CRITICISM
description: TORONTO WHEN Tommy Douglas was a boy, a Winnipeg doctor told him that he was suffering from a bone disease called osteomyelitis and that his leg would have to be cut off. Only because a brilliant young orthopedic surgeon decided to use the young charity patient for a teaching demonstration was he lucky enough to avoid the amputation. ''Had I been a rich man's son,'' Mr. Douglas says, ''the services of the finest surgeons would have been available. As an iron molder's boy, I almost had my leg amputated before chance intervened and a specialist cured me without thought of a fee.'' Mr. Douglas grew up to become the Premier of Saskatchewan, head of one of the first socialist governments in North America. In 1962, his party established a comprehensive medical insurance system, providing, in his words, ''complete medical care without a price tag.'' By 1971, such a system, administered by individual provinces and financed partly by the Federal Government, had been extended to cover every Canadian.

title: CONTROLLING ARMS AND THE MEN
description: Following Vice President Bush's recent trip to Europe, the Administration has expressed some willingness to consider compromise on cutting medium-range missiles in Europe. But even if the President decides he wants an arms control agreement, can his Government - as presently constituted -deliver one in time?

title: Business Loans And Savings Up
description: Loans to businesses at major banks across the country rose $2.1 billion, to $218.55 billion, in the week ended Feb.2, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said yesterday. The announcement was delayed from last Friday because of bad weather.

title: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 15, 1983; International
description: G.M. and Toyota have agreed to produce a subcompact car jointly in the U.S. For G.M., seeking help from an outside manufacturer marks a turning point. Analysts viewed the agreement as a concession to Japan's reputation for superior quality and low-cost production. (Page A1.) For innovative Toyota, the joint venture is a relatively low-cost, low-risk way to start producing in the U.S. (D5.)

title: Tiger Halts Some Loan Payments
description: Tiger International Inc. said today that it had ''temporarily'' stopped payments on certain bank and institutional loans ''as a cash conservation measure.''

title: MUSIC: U.S. COMPOSERS
description: THERE is such a thing as well-written bad music, as a French critic once said about the works of Saint-Saens. In fact, at any time in history there is more of it than of anything else, except poorly written bad music. But, of the two basic types, well-written bad music is more depressing to hear simply because it is not so easily dismissed. There were several varieties of such music on the program last night at Alice Tully Hall, where the American Composers Orchestra explored new or neglected works under the direction of Charles Wuorinen.

Square D said it had acquired 42.5 percent of Topaz's common stock for 714,915 of its own shares. The remaining 57.5 percent was converted into the right to receive $14.40 a share, or a total of $31.9 million, it said.

title: TREATMENT OF EAR INFECTION
description: A NEW study sponsored by the National Institute of Neurological and Communicative Disorders and Stroke, has shown that a medicine commonly used to treat middle ear infections in young children is no more effective than a placebo.

The Ladies' Professional Golf Association's Chrysler-Plymouth Classic will return to New Jersey this year, according to Peter Busatti, the tournament director.

U.S. Authorities Change Description of Suspect
description: A woman who was arrested by Federal drug agents Saturday and described as the nation's No. 1 female fugitive is not the matriarch of a 70-member cocaine ring, as the authorities at first described her, the Government said today in court.

title: CORRECTION

title: Judge Blocks Execution
description: A Federal district judge today blocked the execution of Dennis W. Smith, who had been condemned to die Tuesday for killing a man he robbed of $6 and a wrist watch. District Judge W. Terrell Hodges said he could not study the constitutional claims in Mr. Smith's appeal without more records of the case.

title: Judge in St. Louis Delays Desegregation Trial
description: A Federal district judge delayed today's scheduled beginning of the city's school desegregation trial, giving lawyers 24 hours to seek a settlement in the 11-year-old case.

description: Traffic on New Jersey's highways and movement on public transportation systems were approaching normal today, the first workday after the storm that covered much of the state with 18 to 24 inches of snow.

title: FOR BIG CLEANUP: HAVE SNOW SHOVEL, WILL TRAVEL
description: For Charles Deering, every time it snows, it snows pennies from heaven. ''I've been working snowstorms since 1947,'' Mr. Deering said yesterday as he prepared to dump a truckload of Chinatown snow into the East River. ''I've worked most of the big ones: Chicago, Buffalo, you name it. In '61, I worked three storms here in the city. It ain't a bad way to earn a few bucks, especially nowadays when things are so rough.''

title: FOR WINTER, THINK WARM
description: Even if Friday's blizzard did drop 17.6 inches of snow in Manhattan, that didn't stop New Yorkers from looking fashionable in the aftermath. For many, it was simply a chance to wear the furs that had been hanging in their closets all winter. Some chose fur hats, others jackets made of fur and wool, and some thought nothing looked better, or felt warmer, than a fur coat trimmed with fur.

title: SEIS PROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Petro-Canada Proposal
description: Petro-Canada's chairman and chief executive officer, William Hopper, said today that he would likely approach the federal Government about a step-by-step decontrol of Canadian oil prices. In a speech to the Canadian Club, Mr. Hopper said that he favors allowing oil prices to rise to world levels, instead of to 75 percent of those levels as at present.

title: CANADIAN UTILITIES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Building to Rise In Saugatuck River
description: A 40,000-square-foot office building can be constructed on a spit of land in the Saugatuck River in Westport, Conn., according to an out-of-court settlement yesterday of a three-year-old lawsuit.

title: THE NIGERIAN EXODUS: AN AFRICAN GENESIS?
description: Nigeria's sudden expulsion of illegal aliens could be a worrisome forerunner of what could happen in other African countries as global recession results in deep economic stagnation, and more and more countries victimize foreigners in their midst in a search for scapegoats or for real solutions. There are many Ugandans in Kenya, a varied immigrant population in the Ivory Coast, Eritreans in the Sudan, masses of Guinean exiles in neighboring countries and, not least, many Nigerians all over Africa.

title: JUDGE BARS FEDERAL BIRTH-CONTROL RULE FOR MINORS

description: Alcoa Australia Ltd. has signed a contract valued at $4 billion to $5 billion with the West Australian State Energy Commission for natural gas from the northwest shelf, according to the state's minister for resources development, Peter Jones. He said the contract is for 20 years.

title: REAGAN MISSTATEMENTS GETTING LESS ATTENTION
description: President Reagan's aides used to become visibly alarmed at suggestions that he had given mangled and perhaps misleading accounts of his policies or of current events in general. That doesn't seem to happen as much anymore.

title: Charlotte Curtis; The Presidential Hopefuls Hit the Party Trail
description: CALIFORNIA'S former Governor Jerry Brown said he was in town ''on sabbatical, gathering material and doing research,'' yet when several persons asked to what purpose, he turned coy. ''I'm not going to elaborate,'' he said. Though he saw some people and went to some parties, there's less here than meets the eye. The 1984 election is nearly two years away, the state primary 13 months, and already it's the season for presidential aspirants to see and be seen in the city. The pilgrimage has begun.

description: For all the creativity and imagination so often displayed in professional basketball, the object of the game remains simple - to put the ball in the basket any way possible. On Sunday some of the National Basketball Association's most creative players participated in the 33d All-Star Game at the Forum in Inglewood, Calif., and it turned out to be one of the most entertaining of the annual confrontations.

title: ON L.I., ALL SET FOR COMMUTERS
description: With a whole weekend to clean up, officials had the Long Island Expressway and all the parkways ready today for the morning push. Only the breakdown lanes were blocked with snow and abandoned cars; only the entrance ramps provided more trouble than usual.

title: NATION SEEN AS READY FOR BETTER SCHOOLS
description: AGROUP of about 50 high-level figures in American politics, business, labor, education and science met earlier this month at the Carnegie Corporation in the conviction that the American people are far ahead of their own leaders in their readiness to raise the place of education higher on the national agenda. Among them were the governors of five states, the presidents of the Ford Foundation and the Carnegie Corporation itself, and a United States Senator with a bill in his briefcase (only one of many initiatives under consideration) that could revolutionize Federal support for education with a commitment as sweeping in some ways as the Morrill Act of 1862 that created the land-grant colleges.

title: AMENITIES, AND HOPE, FOR JOBLESS EXECUTIVE
description: Dwight Ives gets up early, grabs his briefcase and drives through rush-hour traffic from the suburbs to the downtown Chicago office of the Executive Assets Corporation, where during the day he anxiously checks his messages, dictates letters and makes phone calls. He often wanders by John J. Doherty's well-appointed office.

title: FOR SPRING, THE FASHION OPTIONS ARE OPEN
description: There have been seasons when fashion hewed to such a straight and narrow line it took considerable courage to stray from it. This is not one of those seasons.

title: NEW GENERATION OF WARHEADS JUST AROUND THE BEND
description: WASHINGTON THE United States is about to enter a new age of missile technology in which nuclear warheads will be designed to maneuver in flight, either to dodge enemy defenses or to home in on a target with unparalleled accuracy.

title: 4 REFINERS TO PAY $1 LESS FOR OIL
description: One major oil company and several smaller ones yesterday announced dollar-a-barrel reductions in the prices they will pay for domestic crude. Analysts said other major refiners could join the move within a week, in the second round of price cuts in less than a month.

title: Teamsters President Retains Policy Post
description: Roy L. Williams and six other top officials of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters were re-elected today to the union's policy committee by delegates to the group's Central Conference meeting, which began here today.

title: Kaiser Aluminum
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said it had withdrawn its published prices for primary aluminum ingot and would price and sell the product on a transaction basis until further notice. Kaiser said it had taken the action because ''aluminum ingot is currently being traded like a commodity, making the published price for ingot a fiction.'' Kaiser's current transaction price for 99.7 primary aluminum ingot in the United States is 60 cents a pound; its published price for the product was 76 cents domestically and 82.6 cents internationally.

title: SELF-SABATOGE IN CAREERS A COMMON TRAP
description: THE conflict is this: A powerful desire to achieve success is often thwarted by an even stronger fear of it. That debilitating fear of being successful, which some regarded in the 1970's as particularly prevalent among career-minded women, increasingly appears to be an abiding problem for members of both sexes. Indeed, at times, it seems to afflict almost everyone.

title: Two Poles Get Prison Terms In Munich in Airline Hijacking
description: Two Poles were sentenced to jail terms of four and a half years each today for hijacking a Polish airliner to Munich last year with a fake bomb.

title: Wieboldt Lease
description: Wieboldt Stores Inc., the Chicago department store chain, said it had signed a long-term lease with the First National Bank of Chicago to rent 295,000 square feet, or about one-third, of the space in the Wieboldt flagship store on State Street in Chicago. The bank plans to move its administrative operations into the space this year. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Dublin Police Link 3 To Horse Kidnapping
description: The police issued descriptions today of three men they said had kidnapped Shergar, the Aga Khan's $13 million race horse, and they stepped up farm searches and set up checkpoints throughout the western county of Galway.

title: NATO Rejects Soviet's Plan For Cutting Nuclear Missiles
description: The NATO allies rejected as inadequate today a Soviet proposal to reduce its medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe to 162, matching the total held by France and Britain.

title: The Light
description: Long after we've forgotten the long journey home, the shoulder sprained while shoveling, the ignominious slide on the ice, we're going to remember the light. How it bounced off birds and branches and buildings and magnified all of them.

title: IN CONNECTICUT, SKIERS FROLIC
description: The ski area operators and even the state officials who had to keep the roads open had some kind words today about the storm that dumped up to two feet of snow on Connecticut Friday and Saturday.

title: ISRAEL'S U.S. ENVOY IS BEGIN'S CHOICE AS DEFENSE CHIEF
description: Moshe Arens, Israel's Ambassador to the United States, has been appointed to succeed Ariel Sharon as Defense Minister, Prime Minister Menachem Begin's office announced today.

title: TV: A THREE-PART DRAMA OF INTERNATIONAL MARRIAGE
description: TONIGHT at 9 o'clock, public television's ''American Playhouse'' begins a three-part series called ''The File on Jill Hatch,'' a coproduction of the BBC and WNET-TV. The subject is race relationships between blacks and whites, and it has rarely been explored dramatically with more candor and more raw power.

title: Boris F. Podtserob, 72; Envoy Attended Yalta
description: Boris F. Podtserob, a Soviet delegate to the Yalta conference in February 1945 and a former Ambassador to Austria and Turkey, has died, the Government newspaper Izvestia announced today. He was 72 years old.

title: MISSILES THAT COUNT
description: If President Reagan, as Vice President Bush suggests, is now ready to consider an ''interim solution'' to the problem of intermediaterange missiles in Europe, one thorny problem obviously concerns the independent French and British nuclear forces.
