description: B-After a reduction of $135,000 resulting from the restoration of LIFO inventory quantities that were reduced in the latest third qr

title: SCOPE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes extraordinary credits of $18,000,000 for the qr and $24,100,000 for the 6 mos from the sale of holdings in Avnet Inc...C-Includes an extraordinary credit of $1,800,000 from the sale of holdings in Manufacturers Bank

title: UNIVERSAL VOLTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes tax credits of $57,000 for the qr and $65,000 for the 6 mos...C-Net loss

title: Race-Fix Trial Gets Under Way
description: Two men bribed a groom to help them drug horses in an effort to fix harness races, a prosecutor said today at the opening of a race-fixing trial in United States District Court here.

title: Coast Guard Prepares For Hearing on Sinking
description: The Coast Guard said today that a public inquiry would begin this week into the sinking of the Marine Electric, an old cargo ship that capsized in a storm off the Virginia coast Saturday, at a cost of at least 24 lives.

title: CONCERN GROWING OVER UNCLEAR THREAT OF DIOXIN
description: Concern is growing among public health officials, environmentalists, scientists, and legislators that contamination by dioxin, one of the most toxic substances created by man, may turn out to be a serious national problem for which they are ill-prepared.

title: Coca-Cola Net Climbs 14.2%
description: The Coca-Cola Company yesterday reported a 14.2 percent rise in fourth-quarter net income, largely because of stronger soft-drink sales.

title: SOVIET PSYCHIATRISTS STUN COLLEAGUES
description: American psychiatrists have reacted with surprise and regret to the sudden decision by Soviet psychiatrists to quit the World Psychiatric Association.

title: Nigeria Says 1.2 Million Have Been Expelled
description: About 1.2 million West Africans have left Nigeria since the Government ordered the expulsion of foreign workers four weeks ago, Internal Affairs Minister Ali Baba said today.

title: Zungul Scores 3 Against Arrows
description: Steve Zungul returned to Nassau Coliseum against his former team, the New York Arrows, and scored three goals, including the game-winner, to lead the Golden Bay Earthquakes to a 6-5 victory tonight.

title: TRI-CHEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EASTMAN KODAK CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THERMO ELECTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NATIONAL WHAT MONTH?
description: The current session of Congress was still in its infancy when the business of designating special days, weeks, months or even years began all over again.

title: G.M. AND TOYOTA PRODUCE CARS IN JOINT VENTURE AT PLANT ON COAST
description: The General Motors Corporation announced an agreement today to produce a subcompact car in the United States jointly with the Toyota Motor Corporation of Japan.

title: TOYOTA: INNNOVATIVE AND CONSERVATIVE
description: For the Toyota Motor Corporation, the joint venture with the General Motors Corporation is a comparatively lowcost, low-risk way to begin producing cars in the United States.

title: Recent Issues Up in Price
description: Interest rates were mixed in uneventful trading yesterday. Short-term rates rose slightly while long-term bond yields declined.

title: RTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Columbia Chairman Decides Not to Go
description: Frank Price will not be leaving as chairman and chief executive of Columbia Pictures after all. Mr. Price, who joined Columbia in 1978 and led the studio to profitability with several successful films, said last week that he planned to quit in June to become an independent producer. Yesterday, Mr. Price said he had reconsidered and over the weekend reached a decision to stay where he was.

title: Low U.S. Car Stocks
description: American auto makers reported record low inventories at the end of January, an industry journal said today. The inventory of 1.18 million cars - a 71-day supply - was the lowest for Jan.31 since 1965, Ward's Automotive Reports said. Meanwhile, the inventory of new imported cars held relatively steady at a 52-day supply on Jan.31, Ward's said.

title: MAUI LAND & PINEAPPLE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After gain of $1,901,000 from cumulative effect of accounting change

title: CANADIAN PACIFIC LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
People
description: * Gavin Scotti appointed executive vice president, director of client services at Klemtner Advertising.

title: CONVERGENT TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BALLY MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest yr include operations of Six Flaggs Corp, acquired in Jan 1982

title: Airline to Link L.I.  With Philadelphia
description: A new commuter airline said it would begin service Tuesday between Republic Airport here and Philadelphia.

title: MORRISON-KNUDSEN CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TESORO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The yr ago results are restated to reflect an accounting change

title: FROZEN FOOD EXPRESS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
COMBUSTION ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Advertising; Expansion, By Baileys On Coast
description: UNLIKE most states, freedom-loving California does not allow marketers to sample new liquor products, according to Alvin J. Ferro, president of the Paddington Corporation.

title: 'WINDS' EXPECTED TO SET TV PATTERN
description: ''The Winds of War,'' ABC's 18-hour saga about World War II that ended its run Sunday night, apparently is second only to the 1977 ''Roots'' as the most-watched mini-series to be aired on American television. As a result of its success, many television executives believe it will exert a profound influence on network programming in the future.

title: Reardon Decides to Sign
description: Jeff Reardon, the right-handed relief pitcher, signed his contract yesterday with the Montreal Expos. The 27-year-old former Met was scheduled for an arbitration hearing yesterday.

title: AN ARRIVAL AND DEPARTURES AT A RESTLESS CITY HALL
description: Help wanted: a fire commissioner, a cultural affairs commissioner, a buildings commissioner and a Washington lobbyist. Unemployment is high in New York City, but don't tell that to the Koch administration. It is accepting applications and conducting interviews for at least four top jobs, which pay from $55,000 to $72,000 a year. In addition, more positions may be opening, because several other mayoral aides have let it be known that they, too, are restless.

title: COMPUTER FACTORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DOW SOARS TO 1,097.10, A RECORD
description: The stock market advanced to record-breaking levels yesterday, led by technology issues, with small investors increasing their participation.

title: Postponed, Snow
description: Storm or no storm, how do you postpone a track meet with nearly 600 athletes for two weeks? What do you do with the 30 or 40 athletes who have already showed up, with the others stranded in airports around the country?

title: Useful 'Trouble' on Human Rights
description: ''Human rights is at the core of American foreign policy because it is central to America's conception of itself.'' So says the State Department's annual survey of human rights, in tones that finally express the American consensus. In that sense the Reagan Administration atones for its initial cynicism in using human rights only as a weapon against the Soviet empire. But it does not yet make up for the President's own selective declarations.

title: Ledbetter Goes to Giants
description: Bob Ledbetter, who resigned as coach of the Jets' running backs after last week's departure of the head coach, Walt Michaels, was hired by the Giants today. He will replace Bob Lord, the running-back coach the last four seasons, who, the Giants said, has resigned.

title: POINTS OF ACCORD ON LEBANON PUT IN WRITING
description: Israeli, Lebanese and American negotiators have begun trying to put into writing points of agreement reached so far in talks on a withdrawal of Israeli troops from Lebanon and future relations between the two countries.

title: REAGAN URGES DRIVE FOR HIGH-TECHNOLOGY INDUSTRY
description: President Reagan today defended his military budget against a ''constant drumbeat'' of criticism and urged the country's corporate leaders to join him in ''a new economic era'' rooted in high-technology industries.

title: Service for Eubie Blake Set
description: A memorial service will be held Friday for Eubie Blake, the jazz pianist, composer and conductor who died Saturday, five days after his 100th birthday. The service is scheduled for 1 P.M. at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, at 54th Street and Lexington Avenue, where a 24-hour celebration was held on Mr. Blake's birthday.

title: Eurobonds Down Slightly
description: Fixed-interest Eurobonds, denominated in dollars, closed slightly lower today in quiet trading.

title: Eugene Reilly 3d Dead at 58; Founded Marketing Concern
description: Eugene L. Reilly 3d, founder and chairman of the Gene Reilly Group, a market-research concern in Darien, Conn., died of cancer yesterday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital.

title: Chrysler's Plan
description: The Chrysler Corporation said holders of more than 80 percent of its 1981 preferred stock series had tentatively approved the company's recapitalization plan, which includes the exchange of preference stock for common stock. Chrysler said shareholder approval of two-thirds of the issue was one of the conditions of the plan.

title: Russian and Italian Are Arrested for Spying
description: An official of the Soviet airline, Aeroflot, and an Italian businessman were arrested today on suspicion of espionage, the carabinieri announced.

title: DRESSER POSTS LOSS
description: The Eastman Kodak Company yesterday reported net earnings for the fourth quarter rose 15.5 percent, to $428.9 million, or $2.61 a share, from $371.4 million, or $2.28 a share, for the comparable period a year earlier.

title: New Chief At Phoenix Mutual Life
description: The Phoenix Mutual Life Insurance Company of Hartford changed its top management yesterday, in a scheduled move. John Gummere, 55, was named chief executive, suceeding Robert T. Jackson, 65, who is retiring after 43 years with the company. Mr. Gummere is no newcomer either.

title: COCA-COLA BOTTLING CO CONSOLIDATED reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'CANDIDE' CANCELLATION A LOSS FOR CITY OPERA
description: Because of the cancellation of plans to revive the City Opera's acclaimed production of Leonard Bernstein's ''Candide'' at Lincoln Center in late February, the City Opera Campany now expects a financial loss if the New York State Theater remains dark, as expected, for nine weeks. The company had expected to earn a modest profit from the revival.

title: SAUL, B F, REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a gain of $3,871,000 or 64 cents a shr on property sales and a tax credit of $1,237,000 or 20 cents a shr...C-Net loss after a gain of $623,000 or 10 cents a shr on property sales and a tax credit of $87,000 or 2 cents a shr

title: CHIEFTAIN DEVELOPMENT CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a special gain of $3,284,000

title: ETHNIC HATRED BOILS OVER IN AN INDIAN BORDER STATE
description: The people of Assam, one of India's most remote and troubled states, are being asked over the next seven days to choose a new State Legislature and 12 members of the national Parliament. But violence born of ethnic fears and hatreds is keeping both voters and candidates away from the polls.

title: INVENTORIES SHRANK 0.6% AS DECEMBER SALES FELL
description: American businesses reduced their inventories of unsold goods six-tenths of 1 percent in December, despite weak sales, by holding down production, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: OPERA EBONY: BLACK HISTORY
description: OPERA EBONY and the American Symphony Orchestra celebrated Black History Month Sunday with a program of black singers and black composers in Carnegie Hall. Everett Lee conducted, and there was music ranging from the Classical era to the present; but this was really an afternoon for sopranos.

title: Georgia Revenue Issue Also Backed by Taxes
description: The Municipal Electric Authority of Georgia, a consortium of 46 cities and one county, is selling $100 million of electric revenue bonds this week.

title: Interpace Ratings
description: The Interpace Corporation's senior debt and industrial revenue bond ratings were lowered to BBB+, from A, by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, which also removed Interpace from its Creditwatch list and affirmed its commercial paper rating at A-2. S.& P. said the rating change reflects the weak construction market and the company's loss of electric utility insulator market share overseas because of the strength of the dollar.

title: Suits Against Phillips Dismissed
description: A Federal judge has ruled in favor of the Phillips Petroleum Company, dismissing lawsuits totaling $2 billion in the 1980 collapse of a North Sea oil rig operated by a company subsidiary.

title: AMERICAN CITY BANK (LOS ANGELES, CALIF) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mrs. Gorsuch Pollutes the E.P.A.
description: On becoming head of the Environmental Protection Agency, Anne Gorsuch inherited one of the most efficient and capable agencies of government. She has turned it into an Augean stable, reeking of cynicism, mismanagement and decay.

title: Tame the White Panthers
description: Once the White Panthers in San Francisco were peace marchers. Now a group of 20 have turned to wild ideas and predatory politics.

title: MUSIC: LYNN CHANG VIOLINIST
description: LYNN CHANG is a first-rate young violinist who combines startling dramatic intensity with an easy lyricism. Mr. Chang's recital at the 92d Street Y Wednesday night, produced under the auspices of the Young Concert Artists Series, teamed him with the pianist Christopher O'Riley, and the result was memorable.

title: DR. JOSHUA FINKEL
description: Dr. Joshua Finkel, professor emeritus of Semitic languages and literature at the Bernard Revel Graduate School of Yeshiva University, died last Saturday at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn.

title: No Headline
description: THE Coca-Cola Bottling Company of New York is not satisfied with the 30 percent share of the soft-drink sales it has here in the country's largest market. One way it could grow would be to have a line of mixers to offer retailers. This is, after all, the country's largest market for mixers.

title: APL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DANCE: TWO PROGRAMS
description: ERICK HAWKINS is given to dreaming. He dreams of a form of modern dance in which bodies flow in a natural, unforced way, of a world of ordered objects. In ''Greek Dreams, With Flute,'' performed by the Erick Hawkins Dance Company on Saturday afternoon at the Joyce Theater, Mr. Hawkins looks back without nostalgia or irony to ancient Greece.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: ERIC CLAPTON, who will be making his first appearance in the New York area in several years next Tuesday, at the Brendan Byrne Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., was the reluctant guitar hero of 1960's rock. His stints with the Yardbirds, the Bluesbreakers, Cream, Blind Faith and his own Derek and the Dominos won him the admiration of his fellow musicians as well as a huge popular following.

title: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 16, 1983; The Economy
description: Banks are keeping interest rates high in part to protect themselves from losses on problem loans, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan told a Senate panel. The banking industry denied Mr. Regan's assertion. The Secretary also cited uncertainty in the financial community about Federal Reserve policies and about projected Treasury borrowings to meet large budget deficits. (Page A1.)

title: Arnold Bernhard Picks Daughter of Founder
description: Arnold Bernhard & Company, a mutual fund manager and publisher of the Value Line Investment Survey, has named Jean Bernhard Buttner as vice chairman.

title: SCOLIOSIS TREATMENT
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I read with growing dismay Jane Brody's article on scoliosis. Why was chiropratic treatment never mentioned in the article? To suggest that the scoliosis sufferer's only recourse is to seek treatment from an orthopedic physican is unfair to both the consumer and the chiropractor.

title: IMM ENERGY SERVICES & TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago 6 mos results reflect nonrecurring business combination expenses of $1,396,000 relating to the acquisition of International Moorings & Marine Inc

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: South Africa Rate Cut
description: South African banks today cut the prime lending rate by one percentage point, to 16 percent, as money market interest rates continued to decline following the Government's abolition of exchange controls on foreigners last week.

title: Eastern Jet Lands on Its Belly
description: An airliner carrying 67 passengers and seven crew members made a successful emergency belly landing on a runway tonight after its landing gear failed to retract fully after takeoff.

title: Houston Romps, Runs Streak to 16
description: Clyde Drexler scored 21 points tonight to keep Houston's winning streak, the nation's second longest, intact with a 106-63 Southwest Conference victory over Texas.

title: WOOD-STOVE COOKS, 19TH-CENTURY STYLE
description: WASHINGTON IRVING, a bachelor who once described the fair sex as ''those arch innovators upon the tranquility,'' would have been apoplectic to witness the commotion in the kitchen of his homestead here last week.

title: WALDECK ROCHET, COMMUNIST, DEAD
description: Waldeck Rochet, the French Communist leader from 1964 to 1972 and the architect of a policy of greater independence from the Soviet Union, died yesterday after a long illness, according to party officials. He was 77 years old.

title: AT THE HEART OF AMERICA'S TRADE DEFICITS
description: To the Editor:

title: Elway Rejects Offer
description: The Oakland Invaders made a game effort, and their offer must have been tempting, but John Elway, the Stanford quarterback, has said no to the United States Football League. According to those familiar with the complex offer, it included a series of lifetime payments that could have brought Elway more than $6 million. In rejecting it, Elway, an economics major, told the Invaders he wanted to be graduated with his class in June and thought he would not if he was playing with the Invaders.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Anatole Broyard THE MOONS OF JUPITER. By Alice Munro. 233 pages. Knopf. $12.95.

title: VIGILANTISM STRESSED BY GROUP LINKED TO SUSPECT
description: The Posse Comitatus, to which Gordon Kahl, the suspect in the slayings of two Federal marshals in North Dakota, has been linked, is a 14-year-old, loosely knit string of ultraconservative groups that insist on their right to carry guns, act as vigilantes and oppose most government authority above the county level.

title: Military Analysis
description: Iran's latest attempt to invade Iraq appears to have been halted, according to reports from Western military experts who have visited the front.

title: CONTEMPT SENTENCING IN INSIDER CASE
description: An accountant was found guilty today in Seattle of criminal contempt for disobeying a court order arising from charges that he had profited illegally by trading on insider information in the stock of the Santa Fe International Corporation. He was sentenced to six months in prison.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: AWHILE ago in this space, I reported my discovery of a form of found humor I called the Mobius Mot. First cousin to the pun, the Mobius Mot is absurdly or obnoxiously self-referential, but its chief characteristic is its inadvertence. People don't make these things up, they just go ahead and say them, unconsciously, while their minds are short-circuiting.

title: DEFENDING RESEARCH
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: In response to Bessie H. Gruber's letter, may I say that I, too, work, as do most older women in this country. My work performance, however, would undoubtedly improve were I not awakened every night by flashes and sweats that often last until the dawn.

title: Rebound Record
description: Deborah Temple of Delta State set a women's national collegiate record Monday night by grabbing 40 rebounds in an 83-79 overtime victory over Alabama-Birmingham. Miss Temple, a 5-foot-10-inch forward, had entered the game as the nation's No. 6 female rebounder, with an average of 14.6. Her 40 rebounds broke the previous record, set by Gail Koziara of Dartmouth Jan. 9, 1982, by 10.

title: News Analysis
description: The pre-eminence of Japanese companies as the world's masters at making small cars was emphasized this week as never before by the decision of the General Motors Corporation to seek assistance from the Toyota Motor Corporation in producing a new subcompact.

title: FILM: 'NUIT DE VARENNES,' SPOT OF FRENCH HISTORY
description: THE great historical pageant that is Ettore Scola's ''La Nuit de Varennes'' unfolds with supreme ease. It begins with a series of casual coincidences and weaves them brilliantly into a vision of one of the most important moments in French history, a vision not the least bit limited by the specifics of its place and time.

title: No Headline
description: ASHLAND, MARATHON TO PAY LESS FOR OIL

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: WHILE honeymooning in New England, my husband and I visited the centuries-old graveyards of several churches. The tombstones spoke of repeated tragedy: families in which three, four and sometimes as many as 10 children succumbed. ''How did those parents survive it?'' I wondered. ''I'd never recover from the death of a child.'' And my husband replied, ''Neither would I.''

title: New Sunlight Power Plant
description: A new California power plant that uses 20 acres of silicon cells to convert sunlight directly to electricity has displaced a Saudi facility as the largest of its kind in the world, officials said.

title: WEATHER HELPS IN CITY SNOW CLEANUP
description: Warmer weather yesterday helped New York City's storm cleanup, and the runoff from the snow was expected to raise the city's reservoir levels.

title: Mariners Dispute '82 Yankee Trade
description: The Seattle Mariners say they are considering asking Commissioner Bowie Kuhn to intercede in a winterlong dispute with the Yankees over a trade the two teams made last year. The Mariners contend the Yankees reneged on their promise to deliver Otis Nixon, a highly regarded minor league second baseman as part of the trade.

title: BARCO OF CALIFORNIA (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
CORRECTION
description: A Business People item in Business Day Monday gave an incorrect first name for the new president of Bossard Consultants. He is John D. Rich.

title: TEACHING BREAST EXAMINATION
description: Breast self-examination is the key to early detection of breast cancer, and researchers find that the women most likely to check themselves are those who have been taught by health professionals.

title: Fix Witness Tells Of a Drugging
description: The Government's key witness at the trial of four men accused of fixing six harness races at Roosevelt and Yonkers Raceway testified today that he had helped one defendant drug a horse.

title: Topics; There's a Better Way; Uncovered
description: Of New Jersey's three million drivers, one in five disregards the law that all must be insured. A new state law will punish them with larger fines and jail sentences.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption yesterday accompanying a dispatch from Gauhati, India, incorrectly identified the leader of the opposition Bharatiya Janata Party. He is Atal Bihari Vajpayee.

title: DUPLICITY CHARGES TRADED BY ISRAELIS AND PHALANGISTS
description: The longstanding relationship between Israel and Lebanon's Christian Phalangist militia has sharply deteriorated in recent weeks, with each side accusing the other of breaking promises and ''double-dealing.''

title: WATT'S ECONOMIC FOLLY
description: Take your most valuable personal property - your home, life savings or business. If you placed this property under a trustee's protection, you would demand that he manage it conservatively and sensibly, to preserve its long-term value for your children. If the trustee suddenly started liquidating your most valuable assets for only a fraction of their market value, you would fire him immediately.

title: 'Simple Enjoyment'
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 16, 1983; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets at 3:30 P.M. about the occu- pied Arab territories. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: FLOW GENERAL INC reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $1,150,000 for the qr and 6 mos from the settlement of stockholder litigation...C-Net income

title: Powell a Winner
description: Doug Powell of Chappaqua, N.Y., continuing his comeback from a serious ankle injury suffered last season, raced to a narrow downhill victory today in the North American Ski Trophy series. Powell was timed in 1 minute 54.09 seconds, three one-hundredths of a second faster than the secondplace finisher, Bill Johnson. The race was a preview of the United States Alpine championships, which begin here Wednesday.

title: ROYAL CROWN COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
CONCERT: GREGG SMITH SINGERS
description: THE concert by the Gregg Smith Singers at St. Peter's Church Saturday evening alternated between finely made Romanticism and a penitent, often medieval, sense of piety. Except for Billings's setting of Psalm 42, however, none of this music was older than Brahms.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Activision Inc., Mountain View, Calif., has appointed Harvey Gillis vice president-finance and chief financial officer.

title: PIANO RECITAL: SEYMOUR LIPKIN
description: SEYMOUR LIPKIN has divided his career between the piano and conducting, and Sunday night at the 92d Street Y he returned to the keyboard with Bach's French Suite in G, the Brahms Variations on a Theme by Schumann and Beethoven's ''Hammerklavier'' Sonata.

title: REGAN SAYS GAP IN CITY'S BUDGET IS 'MANAGEABLE'
description: New York City is in better shape than usual at this stage of its budget-building - assuming Mayor Koch goes through with his contingency program of layoffs, service cuts and tax increases -State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said yesterday.

title: U.N. CHIEF SAYS THREAT OF NUCLEAR WAR GROWS
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar warned today that new and more accurate nuclear missiles had increased the prospects of nuclear war.

title: ELECTRO-NUCLEONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest and yr-ago 6 mos periods include extraordinary gains of $161,000

title: Allison Wrecks Car a 2d Time
description: Bobby Allison, last year's winner, was involved in a wreck for the second time in the last 24 hours as preparations continued today for Sunday's Daytona 500 race.

title: Chicago Mass Murderer Is Stabbed by Inmate
description: John Wayne Gacy, the mass murderer, and another inmate were stabbed today by a third man in the death row unit at the Menard Correctional Center.

title: HERSHEY FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
4 Flee in Holdup; Suspect Is Seized
description: Four gunmen wearing ski masks robbed a savings and loan association in Cranford, N.J., today and shot at police officers during a car chase that ended in Newark, authorities said. The thieves crashed their stolen auto into a snowbank and fled into a residential neighborhood, the police said.

title: NORTHROP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WEST COAST CHEF'S BIG DAY IN THE SUN
description: MARCH 3 promises to be the high point in Norbert Brandt's 15-year career. It is the day when the 29-year-old executive chef at the St. Francis Hotel in San Francisco will cook dinner for the President of the United States, the Queen of England and 250 guests selected from California's elite and powerful.

title: Arguello Gives Up Title
description: Alexis Arguello relinquished his lightweight championship in a telegram to the World Boxing Council last Friday, saying he would be ''too weak'' to fight at the 135-pound limit. Arguello, only the sixth man to win world boxing titles in three weight classes, has thus become the first to give up three titles without a loss.

title: Scoliosis Treatment
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: I was quoted by Jane E. Brody, in an article on scoliosis in the ''Personal Health'' column printed on Jan. 26.

title: Caterpillar Sets Indonesia Venture
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company announced that it had won approval from the Indonesian Government to form a joint venture company with its dealer P.T. Trakindo Utama. The companies plan to build a manufacturing plant in Indonesia.

title: LEAR PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Comparable figures for 1981 yr were not available because the company changedto a calendar yr from a fiscal yr ended Sept 30

title: PERKIN-ELMER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest qr include a writeoff in connection with the final settlement of a computer contract for a telecommunications system as well as unusual costs associated with moving the company's equipment business from California toConnecticut

title: LANCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
Crowd Control
description: Coach John Thompson of Georgetown took his basketball team off the court at Providence last month when a sign appeared in the crowd denigrating the scholastic ability of Patrick Ewing, Georgetown's 7-foot sophomore center and leading player. The Hoyas did not return until the sign was removed.

title: MANNY WARMAN
description: Manny Warman, Columbia University's official photographer for 37 years, died of a heart attack on Saturday at his home in Rego Park, Queens. He was 67 years old.

title: Built-In Watch
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: In reponse to Enid Nemy's article (New Yorkers,etc., Jan. 26) about New Yorkers who don't wear watches, I'd like to mention a point overlooked in her otherwise excellent and entertaining piece.

title: Italy Reports Crime Link To American Gangs
description: Proof of links between Italian gang bosses and associates in the United States and France has been uncovered by a nationwide police drive against organized crime, Italian Justice Ministry officials said today.

title: EASTERN CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
HOME BENEFICIAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After securities losses of $27,519 for the latest yr and $12,990 for the previous yr

title: REAGAN HOPES TO KEEP BREEDER REACTOR PLAN ALIVE
description: The Reagan Administration, confronted by mounting Congressional opposition to the Clinch River Breeder Reactor, is considering a wide range of Federal guarantee proposals to keep the project alive, according to Energy Department officials and industry representatives.

title: NEW CLERGY GROUP ASSAILS CHURCH AID TO LEFTISTS
description: An unusual group made up of clergy who are angry with their churches' positions on world affairs and political activists with little past involvement in religion has become a major critic of American denominations.

title: Coast Man Is Sentenced To Die for 6 Slayings
description: Douglas Clark, who asked for the death sentence after being convicted of murdering six young women, was sentenced today to die in the gas chamber.

title: Israelis Kill 3 Palestinians
description: Israeli soldiers today killed three Palestinian guerrillas who attacked an Israeli roadblock with light weapons two miles east of Beirut, an army spokesman said. There were no Israeli casualties, the spokesman added.

title: Lehman Brothers Signs With Albert Frank
description: After an eight-year stay uptown with Doyle Dane Bernbach, Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. has decided to return to the Wall Street area and that financial area fixture, Albert Frank-Guenther Law.

title: GROUPS ASSAIL PLAN FOR BELL DIVESTITURE
description: State regulators and consumer-interest groups told the Federal District Court here today that terms of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's divestiture agreement would weaken local phone companies across the country and hit consumers with higher phone bills.

title: SOVIET SAID TO TEST NEW TYPE OF ICBM
description: The Soviet Union has carried out a test-firing of a new intercontinental ballistic missile, United States intelligence sources said today.

title: Careers; Colleges' Housing Managers
description: JOHN C. SMALLEY fondly recalls the white tablecloths and attentive waiters from the days when he was a Purdue University student. Gracious dining was common at many colleges 35 or 40 years ago.

title: REPUBLICAN LEADERS WARN NEW DEMANDS MAY IMPERIL JOB BILL
description: Republican Congressional leaders conferred with President Reagan today on emergency job legislation and then cautioned that adding provisions beyond those endorsed by the Administration could doom the measure.

title: SAUDIS DELAYING AID TO LEBANON, SHULTZ DECLARES
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that Saudi Arabia and other Arab countries were holding off giving large-scale reconstruction aid to Lebanon until they were certain that Israeli and other foreign forces had withdrawn from that country.

title: KROEHLER MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Economic Scene; Lambsdorff's Observations
description: WITH the West German election scheduled for March 6, Otto Lambsdorff, the Minister of Economic Affairs, was in New York this week, arguing against the use of stimulative fiscal and monetary policies in his own country or elsewhere for the sake of getting rid of unemployment at a time of a continuing inflationary threat.

title: MANY CONCERNS GIVE MATCHING DONATIONS TO FUND FOR NEEDIEST
description: Although the traditional season of gift-giving is past, The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund continues to receive gifts both from individuals and from corporations and small businesses that match the donations of their employees.

title: CALIFORNIA, IN DEFICIT STANDOFF, TO GIVE I.O.U.'s
description: California, whose Democratic Legislature and new Republican Governor have been at a standoff for weeks over how to close a $1.5 billion budget deficit, is all but certain to have to pay some bills with i.o.u's next week.

title: HAWAIIAN ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a nonrecurring gain of $12.7 million from an accounting change

title: ARTS IN NEW YORK SAID TO GENERATE $5 BILLION A YEAR
description: From the Broadway theater to the New York Botanical Garden, the arts and cultural activities of the New York metropolitan area pump $5.6 billion a year into the economy and generate 117,000 jobs, according to a study released yesterday.

title: AFGHAN WESTMINSTER BEST IN SHOW
description: The clock was turned back 26 years in Madison Square Garden last night, when a black and tan Afghan, Ch. Kabik's The Challenger, owned by Chris and Marguerite Terrell of Anacortes, Wash., was named best of 2,621 dogs at the 107th Westminster Kennel Club show.

title: DOW EDGES ABOVE 1,100 BUT THEN ENDS DOWN 4
description: The stock market finished slightly lower yesterday, as selling pressure increased after the Dow Jones industrial average edged above the 1,100 level for only the second time.

title: Indian Election Violence Claims Life of Candidate
description: An assassin killed one of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's candidates today and a bomb wounded 13 people in the latest election violence in the northeastern state of Assam.

title: Italian Police Rule Out Arson In Theater Fire That Killed 64
description: The police said today that they ruled out arson as a possible cause of Sunday's movie theater fire that killed 64 people.

title: CRUISERWEIGHT CHAMPION NEEDS IMAGE
description: ''If only one fan showed up, I would consider it a success, because then at least one person was interested.'' When a promoter talks like that, it is clear that attendance records are not about to be broken. Don King, the promoter, is not expecting crowd-control problems at Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight, when a world boxing champion who is even less well known than the title he holds will make his first defense in comparative isolation.

title: FRUEHAUF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COLLEGES SEEK STATUS GAINS BY RUBBING SHOULDER PADS WITH 'RIGHT' SCHOOLS
description: Trinity University in San Antonio has 2,500 undergraduates and an endowment above $110 million and aspires to become one of the better liberal arts colleges in the country.

title: 'NUIT DE VARENNES,' SPOT OF FRENCH HISTORY
description: THE great historical pageant that is Ettore Scola's ''La Nuit de Varennes'' unfolds with supreme ease. It begins with a series of casual coincidences and weaves them brilliantly into a vision of one of the most important moments in French history, a vision not the least bit limited by the specifics of its place and time.

title: WINE TALK
description: EARLY on, we learn to submit to the tyranny of vintages. Was 1980 a good year in Bordeaux? What about the '81 Beaujolais? In sunny California is every vintage the same? If the 1977's are at their peak, how can the 1975's still be too young? Were the 1972's good in Burgundy and poor in Bordeaux, or was it the other way around? Can a simple bottle of wine be worth $1,000 because it was made in 1945?

title: When Less Is Just Less
description: Although ''today's busy world'' has become one of our time's most commonplace excuses for incompetence, I hadn't realized how busy it really is until ''One-Minute Bedtime Stories'' came along. Here we have 20 popular children's stories condensed - according to the advertising copy - ''so they can be read by a busy parent in only one minute.''

title: CONCERT: WAGNER, MAHLER AND STRAUSS
description: THE Brooklyn Philharmonic celebrated the centennial of Wagner's death this weekend with a program titled ''Wagner and His Legacy.'' But on Saturday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, as conducted by Lukas Foss, the legacy was subtle and effective, while Wagner himself seemed overly insistent.

title: Jerry Della Femina Marries Judy Licht
description: Judy Licht, co-host of ''Good Morning New York'' on WABC-TV, was married yesterday to Jerry Della Femina, chairman of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners, the advertising agency. Civil Court Judge Shirley Fingerhood performed the ceremony at Club 30 in Manhattan.

title: U.S. TO PENALIZE HEART RESEARCHER ON FRAUDULENT PROJECT AT HARVARD
description: The National Institutes of Health moved yesterday to bar a former Harvard Medical School scientist who admitted committing a fraud in heart research from receiving Federal funds for a decade. It also asked the hospital where he worked to pay back to the Government $122,371 for one project on which he falsified data.

title: CONTROL OF MISSILES STIRS GROWING DEBATE IN BRITAIN
description: The controversy over the installation of American cruise missiles in Britain continues unabated, despite the efforts of Vice President Bush last week to calm it.

title: U.S. TO INVESTIGATE INCIDENTS AT E.P.A.
description: The Justice Department will investigate whether Environmental Protection Agency employees destroyed subpoenaed documents and whether the agency's former assistant administrator, Rita M. Lavelle, violated laws on conflict of interest, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Of Tweaks and Friendships

title: Michael Cefola, Helped Develop Atomic Bomb
description: Michael Cefola, one of the original members of the Manhattan Project team that developed the atomic bomb, died Saturday at the Rosary Hill Home in Hawthorne, N.Y. He was 74 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: CBI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Griffith Sounds Off
description: When a baseball player wins in salary arbitration, he gets the money. The club owner gets to sound off. After his top relief pitcher, Ron Davis, had been awarded a salary of $475,000, Calvin Griffith, the owner of the Minnesota Twins, got his turn. ''He's no more entitled to that kind of salary,'' Griffith said, ''than I am being President of the United States.'' The owner was so upset that he raised the possibility of trading Davis, saying, ''I know deep down in my heart that I would die a slow death if I had to pay him that much money for the whole year.'' But he said he would probably be stuck with Davis, who made $300,000 last year, because ''now that he's making that kind of money, I don't know of anybody who would want him; he certainly isn't worth that kind of money.'' As he complained, Griffith, the last of the major league owners who makes his living strictly from baseball, received some surprising support from Davis. ''I'm on Calvin's side,'' said the pitcher, who sought a fiveyear contract before the case went to arbitration. ''I really do feel sorry for Calvin because we know he can't afford it.'' Davis lost in salary arbitration last year, when he sought $575,000 from the Yankees. ... The Los Angeles Dodgers have won their arbitration case with Pedro Guerrero, the outfielder who hit .304 last season, with 32 home runs and 100 runs batted.

title: SHINN TO LEAVE FIRST BOSTON
description: George L. Shinn surprised Wall Street yesterday with the announcement that he planned to resign in April from his posts at the First Boston Corporation at the age of 60.

description: The Broten brothers from Roseau, Minn., rivals tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, each scored a goal, but the older brother's was the more important one, sending the Minnesota North Stars to a 3-2 victory over the Devils.

description: City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said yesterday that an audit by his office showed that the Transit Authority had been bilked out of at least $1.1 million through rigged bidding, large overpayments and the purchase of inferior materials.

description: Dr. Seymour Fiske, a cardiologist in Manhattan for 60 years, died of pneumonia last Friday at Dobbs Ferry (N.Y.) Hospital.

SHCHARANSKY SAYS HE HAS ENDED FAST
description: The mother of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the imprisoned dissident, said today that she had received a letter from him confirming that he had abandoned a hunger strike after four months.

title: HOUSE PANEL VOICES DISCORD ON NAMIBIA
description: The State Department official in charge of African policy met some strong Congressional criticism today while defending Reagan Administration policy on southern Africa.

title: Alekseyev to Get Lifting Honor
description: Vasily Alekseyev of the Soviet Union is now 40 years old. Though he has been retired since 1980, he reportedly has lost few of the 347 pounds he weighed when he was the world's leading weight lifter.

title: BANKS KEEPING LOAN RATES HIGH TO PROTECT EARNINGS, REGAN SAYS
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that the banking industry was keeping interest rates high in part to protect itself from losses on problem loans.

description: Amnesty International issued a report yesterday that said Egyptians suspected of opposing their Government faced years of imprisonment and repeated trials.

title: STAGE: 'BLOOD RELATIONS,' THE LIZZIE BORDEN CASE
description: IT isn't easy to write an absolutely bloodless drama about the Lizzie Borden case, but that's what Sharon Pollock has done in ''Blood Relations,'' her new play at the Hudson Guild. Not only does Miss Pollock shroud her story's murderous payoff in a blackout, but she also precedes it with two hours of exceedingly anemic and repetitive talk. A blue pencil wouldn't be enough to edit this script - it's a job that cries out for an ax.

title: ELSCINT LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BIGGER CREDIT ALLOWED ON COSTS OF CHILD CARE
description: Many families will qualify for lower tax bills this year not only because the overall rates have dropped but also because the Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981 reduced the so-called marriage penalty and increased the child-care credit. Starting with this year's returns, two-earner married couples will be allowed a deduction from their gross income of 5 percent of the first $30,000 of the lower-earning spouse's income, up to a maximum deduction of $1,500. For the 1983 tax year that will double to 10 percent, for a maximum deduction of $3,000.

title: Market Place; Tax Preparers And Flat Tax
description: THE flat tax, or a uniform Federal income tax rate for all individuals, is a concept whose time may or may not have arrived. But it stirs the rhetoric of Congressmen and occasionally receives comment from President Reagan himself.

title: 1. Jewelry From China
description: The Noble Trading Company started importing antique jewelry from China in 1977. Now the partners - Baba Groom and Leslie Schweitzer - are designing contemporary jewelry and having it made in Peking. There are bracelets, necklaces and earrings of brass with colorful enamelwork. Prices for the collection, currently in the street-floor jewelry department at Lord & Taylor on Fifth Avenue, range from $30 to $238. The bracelets shown are, from the left, a blue enamel cuff, $150; an angled cuff in dark tones, $88, and a hexagon in pastel shades, $45.

description: The Big Three auto makers reported today that sales in the first 10 days of February were off 5.1 percent from the same period last year. It was the first time since mid-October that the companies reported a year-to-year decline.

title: THE YEAR OF THE BIBLE
description: President Reagan, by what earthly or heavenly authority is not clear, declared the other day that 1983 should be ''The Year of the Bible,'' and recommended that all of us read it as a moral and even fiscal guide to the future. The hope here is that he will take his own advice, for it says some relevant things.

title: Tiger in Talks On Repayment

title: FORD'S LEFTOVER IDEA
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge: Who Should Get the Blame If Bidding Meets Disaster?
description: In a home game, not infrequently, the players will suffer a major bidding catastrophe, playing perhaps, in a part-score when game was easy and a slam possible. They probably think that this does not happen to the experts, but it does - though not so frequently.

title: PAUL B. ROBINSON
description: Paul B. Robinson, who retired in 1969 as a director of the medical marketing division of Johnson & Johnson, died Monday at his home in Englewood, N.J. He was 77 years old.

title: THE CITY
description: Two youths were struck and killed yesterday by a Long Island Rail Road train in Corona, Queens. The youths, identified as Jorge Rodriguez, 20 years old, and Priamo Genao, 16, had climbed a fence at an overpass at 111th Street and 44th Avenue in the Corona section and had descended to the tracks of the railroad's Port Washington branch, the police said.

title: COAL SHIP THAT SANK WAS GRANTED DELAY IN INSPECTION OF HULL
description: A 605-ton coal ship that sank in a storm over the weekend, apparently killing 31 crewmen, was scheduled to have its hull inspected this month but was granted a postponement at her owner's request, the Coast Guard said today.

title: RAID FAILS TO FIND MURDER SUSPECT
description: About 100 police officers, using a National Guard armored personnel carrier and firing tear gas, stormed a farmhouse today in a futile search for a ''fanatic'' tax protester suspected of killing two Federal marshals.

title: 'Bama Gets a Shula
description: For three years in the 1960's, Don Shula coached Ray Perkins with the Baltimore Colts.

title: Nikolai P. Firyubin, 74; A Top Soviet Diplomat
description: Nikolai P. Firyubin, a Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister who was also secretary general of the Warsaw Pact's political consultative committee, has died at the age of 74, the press agency Tass said today.

title: 'WINDS' SET MARK FOR VIEWERS
description: With the final compilation of statistics, ABC's 18-hour series, ''The Winds of War,'' turned out to be the most-watched program in television history. According to the network, 140 million people saw at least some of the seven-part saga of World War II.

title: President Becomes Oppenheimer Chief
description: Stephen Robert has been named chairman and chief executive of Oppenheimer & Company, the investment firm that since last August has been a unit of Mercantile House Holdings of London.

title: CORDLESS PHONES CATCHING ON
description: AS the telephone industry in the United States changes and more people buy their own phones, cordless models that allow users to wander as they speak are capturing the fancy of a growing number of Americans. Asked about the trend - 2.4 million cordless sets may be sold in 1983, according to one industry estimate - consumers, distributors and manufacturers tell tales of both electronic wizardry and electronic woe.

title: JEAN S. TUFTS
description: Jean S. Tufts, Assistant Secretary of Education for Special Education and Rehabilitative Services, died Sunday at George Washington University Hospital here after a long illness.

title: IN PROVENCE, A BOUNTIFUL HARVEST OF PRIZED OVERRIPE OLIVES
description: EARLY each New Year, the craggy slopes of the Prealpes behind the Cote d'Azur are suddenly spread with strange colorations: dirty white, rust red and Astroturf green. Close inspection shows the colors come from acre upon acre of plastic sheets, primitively pinned to the ground with stones and closely fitted around the trunks of the olive trees that stud these hills.

He properly found the ''squeal rule,'' requiring notice to parents, a denial of Congress's intent and called the defense of it ''mere sophistry.''

Corcoran, vice president for government relations of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, to succeed Albert B. Lewis, a former State Senator who has run the department since 1978.

title: SHULTZ WARNS OF FIGHT WITH EUROPE ON FOOD
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz warned today that the Atlantic allies risk fighting a food trade war of ''devastating impact'' unless the Europeans ''take seriously'' Washington's efforts to negotiate an end to export subsidies.

title: PORTABLE FOOD CHOPPERS
description: FOR all their technological advances and beefed-up power, food processors still have one big drawback: You can bring foods to the machine, but you can't bring the machine to the foods. For example, if one wants to prepare a pureed vegetable soup, it's necessary to remove the vegetables from the cooking pot, place them in the processor bowl, puree them and then return the mixture to the pot.

title: Nazi Hunter Raises New Charges on Barbie
description: French officials knew Klaus Barbie, the convicted war criminal, was in Bolivia working for the Central Intelligence Agency and West German intelligence for at least eight years before they tried to get him expelled, Serge Klarsfeld, the Nazi hunter, said today.

title: Eurobonds Up Slightly in Price
description: Fixed-interest dollar Eurobonds rose slightly today. Prices gained 1/4 to 1/2 point this morning on the renewed belief that United States interest rates may be headed lower, although dealers felt the upward trend mainly represented short covering by professional traders.

CLEVELAND (AL) - Traded Sandy W ihtol, right-handed pitcher, to the Chi- c ago Cubs for an undisclosed amount of m oney. LOS ANGELES (NL) - Announced that a n arbitrator has ruled in favor of the club i n its arbitration case with Pedro Guerre- r o. The third baseman made $295,000 last s eason and reportedly was asking more t han $800,000 this year. Amount of the c lub's counter-offer was not disclosed. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Lost arbitration c ase with Tony Pena and now must pay the t hird-year catcher $365,000 on a one-year c ontract this season. The team had report- e dly offered about $300,000. title: COUPLES WITH DIFFERENT SHIFTS
description: Many working couples with children have only one spouse employed during regular day hours, and a tenth of these couples work different shifts with no overlapping hours, sociologists say.

WORKING PROFILE: Rep. Thomas S. Foley; DEMOCRATIC WHIP A KEY TO JOB BILL
description: On Monday afternoon, Representative Thomas S. Foley sat down at the huge desk normally occupied by the Speaker of the House and called James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff. The subject of the conversation was emergency job legislation, and Mr. Foley was reporting the reactions of Congressional Democrats to a proposal advanced last week by the Reagan Administration.

title: Japan Extends Curbs on Cars
description: Japan today formally announced that it would continue its program of restraining automobile exports to the United States for a third year, beginning in April, and said it would reduce its export ceiling for exports to Canada for the first six months of this year.

title: 3 Suspects Indicted In Sentry Robbery
description: Three suspects were indicted in Manhattan yesterday on a Federal bank larceny charge concerning the theft of $11 million from a Bronx @armored-car company on the night of Dec. 12.

title: MISSISSIPPI VALLEY GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
200 Seized in West Bank
description: About 200 Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza have been arrested in two days, Arab sources said today. Most were youths, rounded up after Israeli cars were stoned in the West Bank and an Israeli man was shot Monday in Gaza during demonstrations in support of the Palestine National Council.

title: INTERPUBLIC GROUP OF COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LEVESQUE PROMOTING 'RIGOROUS' MEASURES ON TEACHERS'STRIKE
description: In an attempt to force an end to a 14-day strike by 77,000 Quebec schoolteachers, the Government of Premier Rene Levesque submitted legislation today that calls for the dismissal of teachers who do not report for work on Thursday.

title: Foreign Money Futures Are Moderately Higher
description: Foreign exchange currency futures prices closed moderately higher yesterday, despite some late selling. Brokers said that most of the selling was caused by an unexpectedly small rally in the dollar's value among interbank foreign exchange dealers.

title: 2 More Aides Leave Jets
description: Bob Fry and Dan Sekanovich today signed as assistants with the Atlanta Falcons, becoming the third and fourth coaches to leave the Jets since Walt Michaels retired as head coach last week.

title: GOLDEN NUGGET INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: PART of the pleasure of working with food and writing about it is tracking down the origin of food names. On a recent occasion I made my own version of a jambalaya, one of the best-known of all Creole dishes. I had a fine frame of reference for the dish, for I was present when Paul Prudhomme, generally considered to be the finest Cajun and Creole cook in America, came into my kitchen to make it.

title: A.T.& T. ENDS RENT PLAN AT ITS TAX-AIDED BUILDING
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has changed its mind again and will not rent out space in its new Madison Avenue headquarters building, which is nearing completion.

title: ARREST ORDERED IN CRASH FATAL TO 7
description: Warrants were issued yesterday for the arrest of a North Carolina truck driver whose tractor-trailer struck a line of cars at the Stratford toll plaza on the Connecticut Turnpike Jan. 19, resulting in the deaths of seven people.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Time and Again on the IRT

title: GREEK CYPRIOT APPEALS TO U.S. FOR TURKISH PULLOUT
description: President Spyros Kyprianou called on the United States today to exert its influence on Turkey to withdraw its troops from the northern part of Cyprus.

title: Topics; There's a Better Way; The Future Fruit
description: Frantic attempts to improve the image of the prune - ''the black diamond of the fruits,'' it was gushingly called - came to naught back in the 1950's. And we bet the new drive, by the California Prune Board, will be equally fruitless.

title: IPM TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $30,000 for the qr and $54,000 for the 6 mos

title: AT NEW ROCHELLE, A POWER EMERGES
description: National ranking notwithstanding, Coach Lou Kern of the College of New Rochelle said that the most accurate measure of his team's emergence as a National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III women's basketball power was an 86-60 victory over Manhattanville College Feb.1.

title: SALVADOR'S STALEMATE - A TIME TO NEGOTIATE
description: The Reagan Administration wants to increase military assistance to El Salvador to $86.3 million and add even more advisers to the 35 or so now vainly trying to influence Salvadoran military actions. The problem is that the Salvadoran military accepts our equipment but not our military advice. And it is doubtful that more money and advisers can force the military to change from the wrongheaded tactics it has stubbornly followed in a war that may eventually become a losing effort.

title: 3 Die in North Carolina Fire
description: Three people were killed and at least 13 others were injured tonight in a fire on the top floor of an 11-story apartment building where many elderly people live, the police said.

title: Patterson Urges Federal Boxing Control
description: The former heavyweight champion Floyd Patterson and the television commentator Howard Cosell urged Congress today to create a Federal commission that would control what Mr. Cosell termed the ''desperately sick sport'' of professional boxing.

title: NORTHROP'S NET IS OFF
description: The Northrop Corporation, citing lower results from its services businesses, and reduced interest income, reported yesterday that its earnings in the fourth quarter of 1982 dropped 25.1 percent, while sales rose 25.7 percent.

title: K.F. TRIMINGHAM, YACHTSMAN AND BERMUDA BUSINESSMAN
description: Kenneth Fenton Trimingham, an international yachtsman and businessman who helped develop Bermuda into a leading tourist area, died Feb. 2 at his home in Bermuda after a long illness. He would have been 97 years old last Sunday.

title: Satellite-Home TV Ruling
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has rejected an attempt to delay construction of a satellite-to-home television system by a Comsat affiliate.

title: TEAMSTER PRESENTENCING CASE TO CHANGE FOCUS TO WILLIAMS
description: Federal prosecutors at the presentencing hearing for Roy L. Williams plan to try to link the teamsters' union president to top leaders of the Mafia in Kansas City, Mo., his home town and political base in the union.

title: SOVIET PREMIER TO VISIT GREECE
description: The Soviet Prime Minister will visit here later this month, it was announced today. The visit will be the first to Greece by a senior Soviet official.

title: LEADERS IN CONGRESS ACT TO SPEED SOCIAL SECURITY RESCUE BILL
description: Congressional leaders are still working to produce a bill by Easter to deal with the Social Security System's problems despite reservations of several groups toward elements of a national commission's financing plan for it.

title: GNC ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TV Networks to Cover News Session Tonight
description: President Reagan will hold a news conference tonight that will be covered live beginning at 8 o'clock, Eastern standard time, on the ABC, CBS and NBC television networks, on CNN, the Cable News Network, and SNC, the Satellite News Channel.

title: Bill Sale Tuesday
description: The Treasury announced yesterday that next week's auctions of new three- and six-month bills would be held on Tuesday, because Monday, the regular auction day, is the Washington's Birthday holiday. The two auctions will total $12.4 billion, the same as last week, and raise $1.25 billion of new cash after maturing bills are paid off.

title: GENERAL PHYSICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ISLANDERS LOSE, 4-1
description: The Islanders confronted the Stastny brothers and a sharp Nordiques team here tonight and lost, 4-1, before a sellout crowd of 15,240 at the Colisee.

title: AIR FORCE SAID TO MOVE UP PRODUCTION ON MISSILE TO SNEAK BY RADAR
description: The Air Force, finding that technology has developed faster than anticipated, plans to stop producing its current cruise missiles and begin making a version more capable of evading radar, Air Force officers said today.

title: Missing Answers
description: Akila Brutus Shokai is a 6-foot-8-inch freshman at Fairleigh Dickinson, a member of Sudan's national basketball team. Don Feeley, Fairleigh's basketball coach, helped coach the Sudanese team last summer and recruited Shokai, but he is not yet playing for Fairleigh.

title: CONSOLIDATED NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $15,492,000 or 39 cents a shr from the sale of Canadian properties; yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in May 1982

title: Books of The Times
description: he pain of human contact. The fascinating pain; the humiliating necessity.'' This is what Alice Munro writes about in ''The Moons of Jupiter.'' Some of her stories deal with women in that ambiguous period between youth and middle age, a time when one either surrenders a part of the self in exchange for peace and the company of a man or decides to remain whole at the risk of loneliness and the eccentricity of the single mind. <TD WIDTH=2

title: TV REVIEWS BASED ON EARLY TAPES
description: PUBLIC television showed ''God's Banker,'' part of its ''Frontline'' documentary series, Monday night. This critic's review of ''God's Banker,'' based on a tape cassette supplied by the producer, appeared in The New York Times on Monday morning. The practice of reviewing tapes supplied in advance is in accordance with the usual custom, permitting critics to publish reviews on the same day that a program is shown. In this case, the review said that ''God's Banker'' was ''a mess.'' The program, as it appeared, was indeed ramshackle, although not so ramshackle as this critic had said. In fact, a viewer who watched ''God's Banker'' on Channel 13 might reasonbly have concluded that this critic had reviewed a different program. In a way, the viewer would have been right.

title: Howard Rusk Is Given Award By Pope John Paul II Center
description: Dr. Howard A. Rusk, a prominent leader in the field of rehabilitative medicine, has received the first Pacem in Terris award of the Pope John Paul II Center of Prayer and Study for Peace.

title: Yugoslavia Imprisons 23 Ethnic Albanians
description: Twenty-three ethnic Albanians were sentenced to jail terms of one to 14 years today for plotting to form a separate Albanian Republic from parts of Yugoslavia.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jersey Joe Walcott, the New Jersey State Athletic Commissioner, is in Cooper Hospital-University Medical Center in Camden. The 69-yearold former heavyweight champion was listed in satisfactory condition. ... Cecil Cooper, the Milwaukee Brewers' first baseman, won the Roberto Clemente Award for ''best exemplifying the game on andoff the field.''

title: INTEREST RATES RISE MODESTLY
description: Interest rates rose modestly yesterday as investors and speculators waited for Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, to testify before Congress today.

title: BALDOR ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bobbie Brooks
description: Bobbie Brooks Inc., said that its plan of reorganization had been confirmed by the Bankruptcy Court and that it was out of Chapter 11.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Major College Games: Manhattan at Army, 7:30 P.M.; Fairleigh Dickinson at L.I.U., 7:30 P.M.; Fordham at Fairfield, 8 P.M. (Radio WFUV-FM, 90.7; 8 P.M.); Maryland-Eastern Shore at Brooklyn College, 8 P.M.; Hofstra at Wagner, 8 P.M.; Marist at St. Francis, 8 P.M.; Iona at St. Peter's, 8 P.M. (Television - MSG Cable, 10:30 P.M., tape. Radio - WFAS-FM, 103.9; 8 P.M.) Temple at Rutgers, 8:05 P.M.; (Television - WTBS, 8 P.M.); Villanova at Providence (Television - USA Cable, 8 P.M.); Seton Hall at Syracuse (Radio - WNYE-FM, 91.5; 8 P.M.); North Carolina at Maryland (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.); Iowa at Indiana (Television - ESPN, 10 P.M., tape); Notre Dame at Pittsburgh (Television - ESPN, 12:30 A.M. Thursday, tape). Additional Local Games: Dowling at Pace, 7:30 P.M.; John Jay at Staten Island, 8 P.M. (Radio - WSIA-FM, 88.9; 8 P.M.); Hunter at Lehman, 8 P.M.; New York Maritime at Manhattanville, 8 P.M.; Southampton at Pratt, 8 P.M.; Kentucky at Rutgers, women's game, 5:45 P.M.; Army at Manhattan, women's game, 7:30 P.M. Boxing S.T. Gordon, champion, vs. Jesse Burnett, World Boxing Council's cruiserweight title bout, 12 rounds, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J.; first preliminary, 7 P.M. Gordon, from Las Vegas, Nev., is making his first defense since winning the title from Carlos de Leon last June.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 16, 1983
description: International Lebanese troops regained East Beirut without incident from the Phalangist militias that had ruled the predominantly Christian sector since the civil war of 1975-76. (Page A1, Column 6.) No reconstruction aid for Lebanon is being provided by Saudi Arabia and other Arab states because of the continued presence of Israeli and other foreign troops, according to Secretary of State George P. Shultz. In Senate testimony, he in effect acknowledged that the Administration's hopes of securing large-scale Saudi aid now seemed contingent on the success of the American-led mediation effort to get the Israeli, Syrian and Palestinian forces to leave. (A1:5.)

title: COURT RULES NEW YORK CAN ENFORCE JEWISH MARRIAGE CONTRACT
description: Jewish marriage contracts that require spouses to obtain divorces from special religious panels may be enforced by state courts, the New York State Court of Appeals ruled yesterday.

title: STATE PANEL ACCUSES BEATTY OF WRONGLY TAKING $76,000
description: The State Commission of Investigation said yesterday that former State Senator Vander L. Beatty had ''pocketed'' at least $76,000 in state funds from a Brooklyn community rehabilitation program.

title: Required Reading; A Question on Marines
description: Representative Ike Skelton, Democrat of Missouri, in a statement before the House of Representatives. Jan. 25, 1983: More than four months have passed since the President committed U.S. troops to Lebanon. A letter I received lately from the State Department offers no indications of when we might expect our troops to come home. In light of this week's news reports of U.S. Marines being involved in a volatile situation, I feel that we must begin to question the President's intentions for the 1,200 young American military men in Lebanon.

title: A Ziegfeld Girl Keeps Running
description: T he way Lina Basquette sees it, her life is somewhere between the gossip magazines and the television commercials. At the age of 75, she says, she has done most of the things they write about in The National Enquirer, but she doesn't have any of the old-age ailments they feature in the television commercials.

title: ATLANTIC RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE PIZZA IN AMERICA: UPWARD AND ONWARD
description: PIZZA is taking on a whole new look - and taste - these days. Green vegetables are replacing tomatoes, goat and Swiss cheese are now alternatives to mozzarella and crusts are being made with wholewheat flour. Some pizzas are even being topped with fruit. And not only is it being prepared with a vastly wider range of ingredients, pizza is also being served in finer restaurants and specialty food shops, and can even be found in other than its familiar flat, round shape.

title: CTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: Sales for the latest yr include results of CTS Fabri-Tek unit and Intra-Fab, acquired in 1982, and CTS Printex, acquired in the fourth qr of 1981

title: NETWORK SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TELEVISION'S ROLE AT THE WHITE HOUSE
description: Most days, Larry M. Speakes, President Reagan's spokesman, walks into the White House press room with a folder filled with prepared responses for the daily news briefing. But more often than not, he is asked to comment on only one issue.

title: SNOW REMOVAL LETS GARBAGE GROW
description: Against the brownstones and high rises, alongside the grocery stores, the restaurants and cafes, the bags had been stacked like fortifications against an imminent flood.

title: FROM OFF BROADWAY TO MICHIGAN WILDS
description: TWO actors, Justin Rashid and Kate Marshall, abandoned careers in the New York theater to become suppliers of morels, cattail shoots, buffalo meat and other exotic ingredients to a handful of restaurants, a move they have found surprisingly easy and profitable and philosophically satisfying as well.

title: AMERFORD INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Inquiry on Thrift Units
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board says it has started a formal investigation into stock purchases in two savings and loan associations by a hotel owner, Severyn Ashkenazy, and five associates - Marshall Goldblatt, Gary Nielsen, Alexis Eliopulos, Harold Brown and Fred Roven. The issue is whether purchases in Beverly Hills Savings and Loan and Financial Federation Inc. violated Federal law.

title: Corkscrews; TO THE LIVING SECTION
description: I read with interest the article on sparkling wines (''The Right Technique in Opening Champagne,'' Dec. 29). My only comment is about the last paragraph: using a corkscrew.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think that banks, faced with a lot of problem loans, both domestic and international, are doing their utmost to keep their earnings by keeping their interest rates up.'' - Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan. (A1:3.)

title: Defending Research
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION: In answer to Bessie H. Gruber (Letters, Jan. 26), who spoke against the research for the hot flashes, I wish to disagree with her.

title: FROM CANINE WORKS OF ART TO DOG FOOD
description: THOSE who went to the 107th annual Westminster Kennel Club show at Madison Square Garden over the last two days spent some time looking at the dogs up close or in their cages (not infrequently decorated with photographs of the occupant, an occasional Snoopy poster or, in consideration of the time of year, red paper hearts). But many of these dog fanciers also went to spend money at the countless exhibits and stands that circled the dogs' abodes.

title: Jersey City Voters Keep Government
description: Voters here overwhelmingly chose today to retain their present form of city government in a referendum.

title: ARMY OF LEBANON EXTENDS CONTROL TO ALL OF BEIRUT
description: The Lebanese Army, without incident, took control of East Beirut today from the Lebanese Christian militiamen who had ruled there since the civil war of 1975-76.

title: COMPANIES ARE BUYING PREFERRED STOCK HEAVILY
description: The credit market is faced with a flurry of adjustable rate preferred stock financings, more than $900 million of which have come to market in the last three days, while $550 million more was announced yesterday.

title: FAB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: Results for the latest periods include pretax income of $1,725,000 for the qr and $777,000 for the yr from the reduction of LIFO inventory reserves; yr-ago results reflect charges of $346,000 for the qr and $656,000 for the yr from the increment of LIFO reserves; yr-ago results for the qr and yr include a gain of $1,680,000 on the sale of real estate and a net nonrecurring gain of $673,000 from the writedown of an investment in leveraged leases

title: LIGHT OPERA: GILBERT AND SULLIVAN 'GONDOLIERS'
description: THE Light Opera of Manhattan is offering Gilbert and Sullivan's ''Gondoliers'' through most of this month, and last Saturday afternoon's performance at the Eastside Playhouse showed a production that was modestly staged, well prepared and, for the most part, sung with style.

title: FPA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HARD TO HEAR

title: 8 MASTER PAINTINGS GIVEN TO THE MODERN BY WHITNEY ESTATE
description: A group of major modern paintings, largely unknown to the public, has been given to the Museum of Modern Art by the estate of John Hay Whitney. The artists are Georges Seurat, Theo van Rysselberghe, Edouard Vuillard, Pablo Picasso, Maurice Utrillo, Rufino Tamayo and Balthus.

title: SPECIAL ANTIBODIES HALT BOY'S REACTION TO HIS TRANSFUSION
description: Doctors in Boston have used special antibodies to halt a potentially fatal reaction to a blood transfusion in a baby born with a severe immunological deficiency. Dr. Fred S. Rosen of Children's Hospital Medical Centersaid the baby would almost certainly have died without the treatment.

title: AT C.W. POST, WOMEN HOPE FOR RECOGNITION
description: Every time Kathy Solano, the coach of the C.W. Post women's basketball team, met with the players for a timeout in a recent game against Sacred Heart, a television camera was on her. Every time Post's star forward, Sue Salg, pulled down a rebound, a camera was there to get the action. There were interviews at halftime and after the game. Popcorn and refreshments were plentiful, and in the bleachers, there were squads of cheerleaders and brass bands.

title: Texas Airliner Hijacked And Forced to Mexico
description: An Iranian immigrant who said he was upset over United States policy toward his homeland hijacked a commuter airliner carrying 21 other people over Texas today, ordered it to a Mexican border town, where he freed all his hostages, and flew here unarmed on a Mexican Government jet, the officials said.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: LEGISLATIVE CHIEFS RESERVING JUDGMENT ON BUDGET
description: Governor Cuomo's $31.5 billion budget has so far been spared many of the angry disputes that have dominated the adoption of a state budget during the last few years.

title: HI-G INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-After charges of $44,000 for the qr and $324,000 for the 9 mos representing writedowns of an investment in a subsidiary...C-Including gains of $11,000 for the qr and $69,000 for the 9 mos on the repurchase of debentures...D-Net income

title: BOSTON COLLEGE ROUTS ST. JOHN'S
description: Boston College continued its mastery over St. John's last night as the Eagles beat the highly favored Redmen for the second time in a month, trouncing them, 92-75, at Alumni Hall.

title: DEREGULATION CAN CURE OUR TAXI PROBLEMS
description: To the Editor:

title: Deere Layoffs
description: Deere & Company plans to reduce its salaried work force by 485 employees on March 1, the company announced.

description: To the Editor:
