description: To the Editor:

title: Clearing the Mind
description: Sam Freeman, a Manhattan lawyer, has an unusual way to solve business problems. ''When I run at night,'' he said, ''there are no distractions.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I like to use freshly grated cinnamon in apple pies and other desserts but can't find a convenient way to grate it fine enough. Do you have any suggestions?

title: News Analysis
description: New York State once had plans for the construction of 16 nuclear plants; six made it into operation, a seventh is nearing completion, and eight more were scratched as impractical, because of high cost and low demand for electricity.

title: LA MAUR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NATIONAL PATENT DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes tax credits of $1.2 million for the qr and $6.3 million for the yr...C-Includes tax credits of $152,000 for the qr and $1.2 million for the yr

title: CAUTION RULES BASS BREWERY
description: Like the fellow whose idea of experimenting is trying a different type of lager in his neighborhood pub, Bass P.L.C., the largest British brewer, is careful about new ventures.

title: RCA Helps Sell Its Stock, Which Is Owned by Allied
description: The RCA Corporation is helping to sell a 7.2 percent block of its stock owned by the Allied Corporation, Edward L. Hennessy Jr., chairman of Allied, said last night.

title: LAS VEGAS DENIED NO. 1 IN COACH POLL
description: Nevada-Las Vegas, the only remaining undefeated basketball team among major colleges, lost out on the No.1 position in United Press International's weekly poll yesterday, largely because four of the 42 coaches who make up the news agency's panel of selectors kept the school off their ballots entirely. Instead, the Rebels attained only the No.2 spot, as Indiana leapfrogged ahead of them to the top.

title: LAWMAKER MAY SEEK TO CUT ARMS INCREASE BY HALF
description: Representative James R. Jones, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, would like to cut, by half or more, President Reagan's proposed 10 percent increase in the military budget for 1984, aides to the Oklahoma Democrat said today.

title: MAN WHO RESTRUCTURED NL PLANS TO STEP DOWN
description: Ray C. Adam, who restructured NL Industries in the 1970's from a metal fabricator into a major oil-services company, plans to step down on April 30, NL's board said yesterday.

title: Government Destroys Cape Town Shanties
description: Government demolition crews guarded by armored cars knocked down about 500 squatters' shacks today, wrecking a black shantytown, witnesses said.

title: KOLLMORGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TEAMSTER LEADER'S SENTENCING DELAYED AS JUDGE EXCUSES A LAWYER
description: The sentencing of Roy L. Williams, the teamsters' union president who was convicted last December of attempted bribery, was postponed again today for at least another week because of courtroom arguments and schedule conflicts among lawyers and witnesses.

title: IN WELL-MANNERED CITY APARTMENTS
description: ARLINE FEINBERG learned to bide her time. For 23 years she lived in Westchester with her husband and their two children and waited for the time she would be able to move into Manhattan. While she waited she visited show houses and studied decorating magazines -always looking for the designer who would create the ''perfect'' penthouse for her family's needs.

title: JAMES RIVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 23
description: The results for the latest qr and 9 mos include contribution of Dixie Northern acquired from American Can Co in July

title: Turkey to Cut Straits' Fees
description: Transit charges for ships using the Bosphoprus and the Dardanelles will soon be reduced, a Turkish Government official said today. They were raised tenfold in November. Soviet ships, the heaviest foreign users of the straits, refused to pay the higher fees starting in mid-December and ran up a debt that shipping agents in Istanbul say now exceeds $7 million.

title: Indiana, North Carolina Upset
description: Indiana, ranked No.1 this week in the United Press International poll of coaches and No.2 in The Associated Press poll of writers and broadcasters, and North Carolina, ranked No.3 in both polls, were upset last night.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: EATON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $100,383,000 for the qr and $118,672,000 for the yr...C-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $7,438,000 for the qr and $45,305,000 for the yr

title: No Headline
description: SALVADOR REBELS ISOLATE KEY TOWN A SECOND TIME

title: ECONOMIC STRAINS ON NIGERIA
description: The Nigerian economy is in deep trouble. When the Government laid out its current five-year development plan, the forecast for 1983 was that production of high-priced oil, at two million barrels a day, would earn the nation $30 billion.

title: Losing a Home
description: In the 1920's and 1930's, Izzy Grove fought many featherweight and lightweight main events in the old Madison Square Garden. Later he became part of the Garden boxing scene and distributed posters around town advertising future fight cards.

title: Adverse Reaction
description: The first couple of times he took bee pollen as an energy supplement, according to Pat Cummings, nothing much happened.

title: Dr. Eugene Hevesi, 87, A Jewish Leader, Dies
description: Dr. Eugene Hevesi, who had served as foreign affairs secretary for the American Jewish Committee, died of lung cancer Tuesday at Long Island Jewish Hospital. He lived in Forest Hills, Queens, and was 87 years old.

title: POLE-VAULTER HAS AN UNUSUAL TECHNIQUE
description: J oe Dial, a sophomore at Oklahoma State, did not receive any medals in recognition of his recent record pole-vault performance. Years from now, track and field historians will pay little attention to a figure of 18 feet 2 1/4 inches. They might pay attention had they been there to watch. ''I call it the indoor barn world record,'' Dial said.

title: Indictment Is Returned In Miami Shooting Case
description: The Dade County grand jury issued a sealed indictment late last night in connection with the fatal police shooting here of a 21-year-old man on Dec. 28 at an electronic games arcade.

title: A SENATE GROUP REFUSES TO BACK REAPPOINTMENT
description: The Energy Committee of the State Senate, deadlocked 6 to 6, has refused to endorse the reappointment of Edward P. Larkin, a Republican, to the Public Service Commission.

title: Nationwide Advertising Plans General Ad Unit
description: The Nationwide Advertising Service, based in Cleveland but operating worldwide, is pulling a switch on the business.

title: LEBANESE TROOPS TRY BUT FAIL TO HALT ISRAELI PATROL
description: Lebanese troops tried and failed today to keep an Israeli patrol from going through their checkpoint on the outskirts of the city in a confrontation that lasted about 20 minutes.

title: CHAPARRAL RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
News Analysis
description: Tales of paper shredders, charges of mismanagement and corruption, refusal by a President to turn over certain documents. These and other elements give the current dispute over the Environmental Protection Agency a familiar ring to followers of scandals in Washington. But the ingredients of the controversy over the environmental agency are as bewildering as they are familiar. Even those involved in the matter acknowledge that many of the charges are based on supposition.

title: Court Rejects 2d Shift In Brink's Case Trial
description: A state appeals court yesterday refused to change its December ruling tranferring from Rockland County to Orange County the trial of six defendants in the 1981 Brink's armored car robbery in Rockland.

title: Market Place; Advantages Of Stock Splits
description: NO ONE knows how high the stock market will climb in 1983, but one thing already seems clear. Rising prices for individual issues promise a bounty of stock splits this year.

title: PETER S. LOFT
description: Peter S. Loft, chairman of the Loft's Seed Company of Bound Brook, N.J., died of cancer Monday at his home in Westfield, N.J. He was 51 years old.

title: BUTLER NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including a gain of $450,000 for the qr and 9 mos on the sale of the company's distance measuring equipment engineering documents

title: Sale of Pargas
description: Pargas Inc. said that it had agreed in principle to be acquired by Forstmann Little & Company, a New York investment firm, in a leveraged buyout for about $175 million in cash, and that some of its senior management would participate as equity investors. They are to pay $42.25 a share for just over 4.1 million shares outstanding, subject to regulatory and other approvals. Pargas, of Waldorf, Md., is in the liquefied petroleum gas distribution business.

title: QUARTET: THE GALIMIR
description: MUCH of the audience left the 92d Street Y Tuesday night during intermission, before the Galimir String Quartet played Arnold Schoenberg's remarkable String Quartet No. 2 in F-sharp minor (Op. 10). The composer's name apparently scared listeners off, despite the fact that Felix Galimir, the first violinist of the quartet, had direct contact with the composer and others of his circle; at that time the original Galimir Quartet included Mr. Galimir's three sisters.

title: CULLINET SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Yr-ago shr earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 split paid Jan 10, 1983; the company changed its name from Cullinane Database on Feb 1

title: ANAEROBIC ENERGY SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Georgia Utility

title: Paul A. Lobel, 83, Is Dead; Leading Industrial Designer
description: Paul A. Lobel, a Rumanian-born American who was a strong contributor to the development of modern design in the United States, died in New York City last Friday.

title: CONCERT: SPANISH MUSIC
description: Federico Mompou may not be a composer whose name rings a bell with many American music followers, but his songs and piano music have a charm and distinction all their own and he is one of Spain's most cherished musical figures. His 90th birthday is fast approaching (he was born on April 10, 1893) and in anticipation of that anniversary a concert honoring Mompou was given at Alice Tully Hall last night.

title: WARNER'S PROFIT FALLS BY 56.5%
description: Warner Communications Inc., citing its troubled Atari video-game division, reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit fell 56.5 percent, to $33 million, or 50 cents a share, from $75.8 million, or $1.17 a share, a year ago. Revenues rose 3 percent, to $1.12 billion, from $1.09 billion.

title: CALIFORNIA LEGISLATURE FINALLY REACHES AGREEMENT ON BUDGET DEFICIT
description: After weeks of rancorous debate, the California Legislature reached agreement tonight on a plan to close a projected $1.5 billion budget deficit. State officials said it was unclear whether the agreement came in time to halt the scheduled issuance by the state next week of i.o.u.'s to pay some of its bills.

title: FACTORY OUTPUT UP 0.9%, INDICATING END TO SLUMP
description: Factory production in America jumped nine-tenths of 1 percent last month, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Many analysts believe this sharp improvement means the end of the recession.

description: It was plain to see what last night' game 5-4 victory over Washington meant to the Rangers simply by looking at their faces after each goal they scored.

title: Chairman to Retire At Marine Midland
description: In an unexpected move, Edward W. Duffy, the chairman of Marine Midland Banks Inc. and its holding company, Marine Midland Bank N.A., said yesterday that he will retire on June 30. Midland, in which the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation acquired a 51 percent interest in 1981, said the 56-year-old Mr. Duffy would be succeeded by John R. Petty, 52, currently president of the bank and its holding company.

title: Wife of Hunted Militant Begs Him to Surrender
description: The wife of an ultraconservative militant hunted in the slayings of two United States marshals went on television today and begged her husband to surrender.

title: N.Y.U. Back on Court
description: New York University, which once fielded basketball teams that were among the nation's strongest, plans to announce today that it is returning to varsity competition next season. But the Violets will be competing at the National Collegiate Athletic Association's weakest level, Division III.

title: STATE PANEL BACKS CITY'S BUDGET PLAN
description: The staff of the State Financial Control Board cited ''sound grounds for optimism about the city's future'' yesterday and recommended that Mayor Koch's preliminary budget be approved.

title: HOUSING STARTS IN JANUARY UP 35.9%
description: Housing starts soared a record 35.9 percent in January to an annual rate of 1.72 million units, the highest since September 1979, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Ogden Mills Phipps, who recently resigned as head of the New York Racing Association, has been elected chairman of The Jockey Club. He replaces the ailing August Belmont, who remains a steward. ... John Stearns, the Met catcher who missed the last part of the 1982 season because of tendinitis in his right elbow, reported early to training camp at St. Petersburg, Fla., to test his arm. After throwing softly yesterday for 15 minutes at distances up to 90 feet, he said he felt no pain or discomfort. ... John Ferchill, a real estate developer, said he was close to buying the Cleveland Cavaliers from Ted Stepien, who said he wanted to sell before the end of the N.B.A. season. ... A group headed by Michael Shapiro, a California-based former native of Kansas City, Mo., failed to prove it had assets to buy 49 percent of the Kansas City Royals by yesterday afternoon's deadline, imposed by the club's owner, Ewing Kauffman, who reportedly mandated that potential minority buyers show that they had $25 million in assets.

title: LENOX HILL'S NURSES POSTPONE DEADLINE 22 HOURS FOR STRIKE
description: Nurses at Lenox Hill Hospital yesterday voted to postpone by 22 hours a strike that was threatened to begin this morning, a spokesman for the nurses' union said.

title: VIDEO GAMES: DIVERSION OR A DANGER?
description: ''IDON'T think I ever wanted something as bad,'' said Benjamin Fischler, a Manhattan 11-year-old whose parents gave him a home video game for Christmas. ''But I never had to work harder for a present before. I guess parents are afraid the games will interfere with schoolwork.'' He paused in thought. ''Maybe they think that kids will spend too much time at the joy stick rather than at the pencil.''

title: 'LOCAL HERO,' HOUSTON-TO-SCOTLAND ODYSSEY
description: GENUINE fairy tales are rare; so is film-making that is thoroughly original in an unobtrusive way. Bill Forsyth's quirky disarming ''Local Hero'' is both, and it's also proof that Mr. Forsyth's other feature film released here, ''Gregory's Girl,'' was more than a happy accident. The Glasgow-born Mr. Forsyth has put Scottish comedy on the map, for whatever that's worth. He has also developed a dryly whimsical style, very close to a deadpan at times, that allows the strangest events or personages to glide by almost unnoticed. ''Local Hero'' contains a mermaid, an enchanted village and a possibly magical rabbit. No undue fuss is made about any one of them.

THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 17, 1983; The Economy
description: Paul A. Volcker told a Senate panel that for the rest of the year, the Fed wants to promote recovery while containing inflation. The chairman of the Federal Reserve indicated that it would continue to rely more on its own judgement in setting overall monetary policy than on targets it sets for growth in the money supply. Thus, he left the exact outlines of Fed policy unclear. (Page D1.) A standing-roomonly crowd gathered to hear Mr. Volcker's testimony. (D6.)

title: ISRAEL STEINBERG, PHYSICAN, IS DEAD
description: Dr. Israel Steinberg, one of the developers of an important technique in the diagnosis of heart disease in adults, died Tuesday after a stroke at St. Joseph's Hospital in Phoenix. He was 80 years old and had lived in Phoenix for the last three years after moving from Stony Brook, L.I.

title: Frank Doyle, Press Secretary Under Mayor Wagner, Is Dead
description: Frank D. Doyle, who had served as press secretary for the Police, Fire and Sanitation Departments and for former Mayor Robert F. Wagner, died of cancer Tuesday night at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn. Mr. Doyle, a resident of Jamaica Estates, Queens, was 74 years old.

description: A 17-year-old amateur boxer died Tuesday without having regained consciousness since lapsing into a coma Feb.6. Michael Pitzer had become comatose soon after withdrawing in the second round of a Golden Gloves fight that day.

description: The Board of Education voted last night to confirm its award for typewriter purchases to a West German company, Olympia International. The vote was 6 to 1, with James F. Regan, the Staten Island member, dissenting.

title: INDOOR PLANT PESTS CAN BE OUTWITTED
description: INSECTS that do dreadful things to house plants have early-warning systems, so close examination during watering can keep them at bay. Here is what to do about five common insects found on indoor plants. Fungus gnats. These tiny gray gnats are attracted to soil mixes containing a lot of peat moss, compost or humus. The gnats, which hover, are not as troublesome as their larvae, which bore into roots and cause a loss of vitality. In high populations, tiny wormlike larvae float to the surface.

title: BUSH AND BAKER NECK AND NECK IN GALLUP POLL
description: If President Reagan chooses not to run for re-election in 1984, the early indication from the Gallup Poll is that Republicans are about evenly split between Vice President Bush and Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate majority leader.

description: Even as he uttered the words suggesting that he favors abolishing the corporate income tax, President Reagan realized he was inviting being labeled anew as a defender of the rich and powerful. He needn't have risked that, because Congress already has fulfilled much of his wish for him.

title: STRAIGHT STORY (II)
description: Michael Straight, by his own account, is a man who was a member of a secret Communist cell in Cambridge in the 1930's; who accepted an assignment to return to the U.S. to insinuate himself into a position of influence; who, while working in the Roosevelt Administration, prepared five ''political analyses'' and handed them to a Soviet secret agent; and who, knowing that an old Cambridge classmate and cellmate was spying on the U.S. during the Korean War, kept that information to himself.

title: CORRECTION
description: The ''At the Movies'' column Friday incorrectly identified Winifred Wagner. She was Richard Wagner's daughter-in-law.

title: Chase May Add Rose
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, parent company of the Chase Manhattan Bank, said yesterday that its directors had approved plans to acquire Rose & Company, a discount brokerage firm based in Chicago. The acquisition of Rose, the nation's fourth-largest discount broker, is subject to approval by the Federal Reserve Board. It would mark the first acquisition by a New York commercial bank of a discount brokerage firm and place Chase in a position to compete directly for certain services on a nationwide basis with Merrill Lynch and other brokerage houses.

title: REAGAN TO WEINBERGER: UNITED FRONT
description: For a stretch from mid-December to early February, nothing seemed to be going right for Caspar W. Weinberger. The Secretary of Defense was assailed in the press by unnamed senior White House officials for his refusal to trim military spending. When the military budget was presented to Congress, Republicans and Democrats alike tore into it. The Joint Chiefs of Staff disagreed with their boss publicly over basing MX missiles and holding down pay in the armed forces. Leaders of Jewish organizations excoriated Mr. Weinberger for espousing what they considered to be anti-Israeli policies. Editorials accused him of preaching ''hogwash,'' lacking ''discernment'' and acting like ''Cap the Mule.''

title: KELLY JOHNSTON ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated and do not give effect to a nonrecurring gainfrom an accounting change; shr earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2stock split to be effected Feb 28

title: NEW BOLIVIA UNSUITED FOR A KLAUS BARBIE
description: To the Editor:

title: Audrey Boyers Walz, Author Of Novels and Canada Study
description: Audrey Boyers Walz, an author of mysteries and historical novels, died of cancer Monday at the Franklin Nursing Home in Greenfield, Mass. She was 76 years old and lived in Greenfield.

title: MUSIC: MISS ALLISON, SOPRANO
description: A listener could not develop much affection for Glorietta Allison's soprano voice in Merkin Hall on Monday night. It was thin-bodied, a trifle piercing on top and lacking warm support underneath.

title: 20 Injured as Boat Capsizes
description: A fishing boat carrying junior high school students to watch migrating whales overturned in heavy seas today, throwing 32 people into the sea near the mouth of Morro Bay off southwestern California. All were rescued, but officials said 12 children and eight adults were injured.

title: The G.M.-Toyota Compact
description: Toyota and General Motors plan to build cars together in California: what a common-sense solution, people say, to international trade problems. They're probably wrong. The joint venture may well serve the interests of the two companies, and it will certainly provide jobs for 3,000 unemployed Californians. But it's not at all clear that the arrangement will serve broader American or Japanese economic interests. It's better than cruder protectionism, but not much better.

title: DANCE: FOOD SUITE BY BLONDELL CUMMINGS
description: EDIBLES and the act of eating were the subjects when Blondell Cummings and dancers performed a suite of works called ''Food for Thought'' on Tuesday at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater. What the evening was really all about, however, was the extraordinary performing of Miss Cummings.

title: PERINI CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Hearing Is Closed In Murder Case
description: TRENTON Feb. 16 - The public and the press should be excluded from a bail-reduction hearing for a Morristown man accused of stabbing a waitress to death last December, the New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today.

title: SILVER UP 5 AN OUNCE; GOLD FUTURES PRICES SLIP
description: Silver futures traders waited in vain again yesterday for either the price to break through the $15-an-ounce level or for the threemonth advance to end in huge profit taking. Instead, the active near March contract closed up 5 cents an ounce at $14.75, after ranging between $14.89 and $14.67 on New York's Commodity Exchange.

title: UGI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Iraq Says It Beat Back A New Iranian Thrust
description: Iraq said today that its troops had repulsed a new Iranian attack along the border east of the Iraqi town of Amara.

title: CITY BALLET: CHANGES IN CASTS
description: THE New York City Ballet's weekend at the New York State Theater featured some interesting cast changes. Saturday night's bill included Jerome Robbins's ''Interplay,'' a repeat performance of Peter Martins's new ''Rossini Quartets'' and George Balanchine's ''Stravinsky Violin Concerto,'' in which, partnered by Ib Andersen, Heather Watts made her debut in the first pas de deux. Miss Watts's strength and determination suited this tense duet, and her encounters with Mr. Andersen became real contests of wills.

title: CONCERT: RACHMANINOFF TRIO PERFORMS BAKSA
description: THE Rachmaninoff Trio has had a checkered history. The violinist, Tatiana Feigin and her brother, Eugene Feigin, the pianist, were part of a flourishing ensemble in Moscow known as the Chamber Music Trio.

title: BRIEFING
description: Speeches and Secrets

title: ARAB BANK BOYCOTT OF DATA LINKS
description: Arab banks in the oil countries of the Persian Gulf are boycotting the leading international system for transferring money around the world because 10 Israeli banks have become members, according to banking and business sources here.

title: Doomed Ship's Crewman Tells An Inquiry of Holes in Hatches
description: A crewman who was pulled to safety after a coal carrier overturned and sank told investigators today that deck hatches designed to keep out the elements were warped and one had holes in it.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A music listing in The Guide on Sunday gave the location incorrectly for a concert by Jim Theobald on Saturday at 2 P.M. It is at the Washburn Gallery downtown, 113 Greene Street.

title: F.A.S.B. Issues Peso Bulletin
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board yesterday issued a technical bulletin to provide guidance on how Mexican subsidiaries of United States companies should translate pesos into dollars for consolidation into the parent's financial statements.

title: 5 CONVICTED OF CONTEMPT IN AN INQUIRY ON F.A.L.N.
description: Five advocates of Puerto Rican independence were found guilty yesterday of criminal contempt of court for refusing to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating bombings that the F.A.L.N., the group seeking independence for Puerto Rico, has claimed responsibility for.

title: LEE PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income including an extraordinary credit of $40,000 or 2 cents a shr

title: NORTHWESTERN STEEL & WIRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
U.S. Discussing Currency Goals
description: The United States trade representative, Bill Brock, said today that the Reagan Administration did not object to currency ''targets'' that would encourage greater stability in exchange rates, but that it still opposed market intervention to bring this about.

title: THE VOLCKER SHOW PLAYS ROOM SD 538
description: Paul A. Volcker made his way through the corridors of the Dirksen Senate Office Building, without an entourage but nevertheless noticeable. Who else in Washington, after all, is 6 feet 7 inches tall and carries Antony y Cleopatra cigars that match his blue-suited frame? Who else but Mr. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, a man who is often called the second most powerful man in the country.

title: PENGO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $1,661,000 from discontinued operations...C-Ne t income which includes income of $3,400,000 from discontinued operations; the yr-ago results are restated

title: PHOTOGRAPHIC SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a nonrecurring charge to operations of $773,000 resulting from the formal receivership proceedings entered into Jan 17 by the company's United Kingdom subsidiaries

title: STRAUSS JUMPS OFF ON CAMPAIGN TRAIL
description: Franz Josef Strauss opened the electoral campaign of his Bavarian conservatives here today, saying that victory next month by the opposition Social Democrats could lead to ''the de facto neutralization'' of Western Europe.

title: COWLES BROADCASTING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FUCHSBERG REPORTEDLY PLANS TO LEAVE COURT OF APPEALS
description: Judge Jacob D. Fuchsberg reportedly told Governor Cuomo today that he plans to step down from the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, before the official end of his term on Dec. 31.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $50 million from costs associated with the withdrawal of Tylenol capsules; the company adopted late in 1981 F.A.S.B. No 52 which replaced F.A.S.B. No 8 in accounting for foreign currency translation and that quarterly results for 1981 were restated to reflect this change

title: DYCO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DECIDING ON TAX STATUS: THE 5 BASIC CATEGORIES
description: Death may be certain, but taxes are not. In fact, many people do not have to file a tax return. Most American citizens and resident aliens need not file if their gross income is below a certain level: $3,300 for single taxpayers under 65, and $4,300 for 65 or older. Self-employed taxpayers, however, must file a tax return if their net income from self-employment is $400 or more. And those claimed as a dependent on someone else's return must file if they have $1,000 or more in unearned income, such as interest or dividends. In most cases, married taxpayers need not file a return if their gross income is $5,400 or less. That threshold rises by $1,000 for each spouse 65 or over.

title: TECHNICOM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Comparable figures for 1981 are unavailable as the company was formed in Aug 1981; shr earnings are adjusted for a 50 percent stock divd in Oct 1982 and a 100 percent stock divd in Dec 1982

title: Books Of The Times
description: THERE ARE ALLIGATORS IN OUR SEWERS. And Other American Credos. By Paul Dickson and Joseph C. Goul- den. 172 pages. Illustrated by R.J. Shay. Delacorte. $11.95.

title: PAUL LIPPINCOTT OBRE
description: Paul Lippincott Obre, a former senior vice president of Avrett, Free & Ginsberg, a New York City advertising agency, died Monday of cardiac arrest at Stamford University Hospital in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 45 years old and a resident of Southampton, L.I.

title: RISING CONCERN ON CONSUMER ISSUES IS FOUND IN HARRIS POLL
description: In the seven years since Congress last passed a major piece of consumer protection legislation, the public has grown more concerned about such consumer issues as defective and dangerous products and shoddy repair services, according to a national poll taken last fall and released today by Louis Harris & Associates.

title: Marian Nixon, 78, Actress; Tracy's First Leading Lady
description: Marian Nixon, who was Spencer Tracy's first leading lady and the wife of the late director William Seiter, died two days after undergoing open heart surgery. A spokesman for the actress said Tuesday that she died Sunday night in Cedars-Sinai Medical Center.

title: IRWIN SHAW, NEAR 70, ADDS IT UP AND FEELS 'RIGHT'
description: When he was still in his early 20's and newly famous for his 1936 antiwar play, ''Bury the Dead,'' Irwin Shaw was offered steady work and some fatherly advice by the head of the RKO studio in Hollywood: ''Come out here, get married, get a house with a swimming pool. By the time you're 30, you'll lose your ideals - and then you'll be happy.''

title: John S. Dickerson Jr., A Leading Yachtsman
description: John Stiles Dickerson Jr., a prominent yachtsman who was the chairman of the New York Yacht Club's racing committee from 1955 through 1958, died of congestive heart failure last Sunday at a hospital near his home in Southport, Me. He was 77 years old.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: THE popularity of wood stoves for supplementary heating -in some cases they may be a primary heat source - has led to an increasing number of fires resulting from improper installation.

title: Lawyer Sentenced For Embezzlement
description: The former president of the Passaic County Bar Association was sentenced today to 10 years in prison for embezzling more than $1 million from 18 clients.

title: Old Guns Returned As 3 Are Arrested
description: Three stolen guns from the 16th century that were appraised at $100,000 each were recovered with the arrest of three men near here Tuesday night.

title: LEISURE & TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income...C-After extraordinary credit of $234,000

title: A Tribute to Violinist
description: Manuscripts, letters and annotated scores of three concertos belonging to Joseph Szigeti, the Hungarian violinist who died 10 years ago, will go on exhibition Saturday in the Amsterdam Gallery of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center, at 111 Amsterdam Avenue, near 65th Street. Mr. Szigeti's Guarnerius violin, programs and a manuscript autographed and dedicated to him by Bela Bartok are also part of the display, ''Joseph Szigeti Remembered,'' organized by Frank Campbell, chief of the library's music division, as a tribute.

title: BEGIN'S BLOC WINS PARLIAMENT TEST
description: The Government of Prime Minister Menachem Begin defeated motions of no confidence today in Parliament. They were the first such motions since the state commission's report on Israel's ''indirect responsibility'' for the Beirut massacre.

title: Jane Chambers Dead; Won Awards for Plays
description: Jane Chambers, author of the ''Last Summer at Bluefish Cove,'' which ran at the Actor's Playhouse in 1980, and playwright in residence for the Glines production company, died of a brain tumor Tuesday at her home in Greenport, L.I. She was 45 years old.

title: PEETERS'S UNBEATEN STEAK ENDED AT 31
description: The unbeaten streak of Pete Peeters of the Bruins ended at 31 games, one game short of the league record, when the Buffalo Sabres beat Boston, 3-1, tonight.

title: No Headline
Interpublic Earnings Gain 11.8% in Quarter
description: Thanks to an increase in operating income, a change in accounting practices and last March's acquisition of the remaining 51 percent of SSC& B: Lintas, the Interpublic Group of Companies had a better financial report to make Tuesday than it did a year earlier.

title: CONCERT: ROBERT BLACK AND NEW MUSIC GROUP
description: ROBERT BLACK'S New York New Music Ensemble has proved itself one of our best contemporary music groups, and indeed the performances Tuesday at Carnegie Recital Hall were again first-rate. But the concert was a little misleading if you took the ensemble's title literally.

title: U.N. Unit Asks Soviet Pullout And Afghan Political Solution
description: The United Nations Human Rights Commission called today for an immediate withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan as part of a political settlement that would include the right of refugees to return safely.

title: RAIN SEVERELY DAMAGES SOUTH FLORIDA CROPS
description: Heavy rains in southern Dade County have ruined as much as 60 percent of the nation's largest midwinter vegetable crop, county officials said Tuesday.

title: BENGUET CONSOLIDATED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results have been translated at the rate of 9.17 Philippine pesos equal $1 for the latest periods and 8.20 Philippine pesos equal $1 for the yr-ago periods

title: HOUSE UNIT TO GET SUBPOENAED DATA
description: The Justice Department today backed off from its claim of executive privilege and offered a House subcommittee access to the documents of the Environmental Protection Agency that the Administration has been withholding, according to sources involved in the dispute.

title: ALASKA INDIANS HIT BY FISCAL REALITY
description: In the wake of losses exceeding $25 million last year, the throb of drums and the towering mystical beauty of totem poles have lost their glamor for the Haida and Tlinglit Indians who own the Sealaska Corporation.

title: YEAR DELAY IS URGED FOR WORKERS JOINING SOCIAL SECURITY PLAN
description: Representative Claude Pepper, in a bid to win union support for the Social Security rescue package, today proposed a one-year delay in bringing new Federal workers into the system.

title: Mortgage Unit Cites Earnings
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation reported today that it had record earnings last year and was making changes to broaden its activities in the future.

title: FERRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GENERAL HOST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $1.4 million for the qr and yr...C-Includingan extraordinary gain of $2,330,000 for the qr and yr

title: Technology; The Buzzword Is Buzzwords
description: IN the fast-paced business of personal computers, it seems, one cannot mark a trend without a buzzword. Last year's was ''userfriendly'': Every hardware and software manufacturer was trying to make products easy to master and nonintimidating for the novice user.

title: SCOUTING
description: The fastest mile of the indoor track season, and perhaps the fastest indoor mile ever, might be run tomorrow night when Eamonn Coghlan, Steve Scott, Thomas Wessinghage and others meet in San Diego. Then on Saturday afternoon, Coghlan, Scott, John Walker, Ray Flynn and Sydney Maree will run in Cleveland in a mile to be televised live on ABC's ''Wide World of Sports.''

title: MORE PREFERRED PLANNED WITH AJUSTABLE RATES
description: The market for adjustable-rate preferred stock remains active, with several such issues announced yesterday. The Columbia Gas System became the first utility to indicate that it would sell adjustable-rate preferred.

title: Q & A
description: Q. The brick around our fireplace was covered with white enamel by a previous owner. I have tried all kinds of removers but none seem to do the job. Is there any way to remove the paint?

title: I.B.M. Discussing Matsushita Venture
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and the Matsushita Electrical Industrial Company are discussing a joint venture to make small computers and office automation equipment, the companies said yesterday.

description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $1,175,000 from the settlement of a lawsuit

description: B-There are no comparable yr-ago results because the company began operations in Nov 1981

title: South African Offers Neighbors Some Choices
description: Prime Minister P.W. Botha says his Government would consider requests for aid from anti-Communist guerrilla forces in southern Africa. He also says he stands ready to enter into nonaggression pacts with any neighbor, regardless of its political system.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Avon Products Inc. said that it would seek to add 150,000 sales representatives to its current force of 440,000, and that the recruiting drive would be backed up with a multimillion-dollar advertising campaign.

description: B-After a loss of $928,969 from discontinued operations...C-Afte r a loss of $399,439 from discontinued operations...D-Net income after a loss of $1,182,884 from discontinued operations

title: GERMAN, NOT U.S. ISSUES
description: In stressing that the question of American missiles is central to America's relations with West Germany, the Administration has needlessly exposed this country and its prestige among Europeans. The outcome of the West German elections will be widely interpreted as a referendum on the deployment of our intermediate-range missiles, but the elections are more likely to pivot on social and economic issues.

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON HAS 10.5% NET DROP
description: Johnson & Johnson, reflecting the effects of the Tylenol recall and its attempt to return the product to the market, reported yesterday that its net income in the fourth fiscal quarter dropped 10.5 percent.

title: Soviet Airline Official Formally Charged in Italy
description: Viktor Pronin, a Soviet airline official, was formally charged today with political and military espionage, the Italian news agency Ansa said.

title: Changes at Hyster
description: The Hyster Company of the United States, a manufacturer of forklift trucks, will invest more than $61.7 million to upgrade production at Hyster Europe Ltd.'s Irvine, Scotland, plant as part of a worldwide restructuring of Hyster's operations, William Kilkenny, chairman, said.

title: MUSEUMS BLOSSOMING IN LOS ANGLES
description: THESE travel notes come to you from your friendly neighborhood grasshopper, who loves a trip but hopes not to leave town again for quite some while.

title: BACARDI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Sales figures exclude excise taxes

title: Democrats Cautioned On Presidential Race
description: Governor Cuomo and Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, in letters to fellow Democratic leaders made public yesterday, urged them to keep the New York party uncommitted in the Presidential campaign.

title: A Mass for Sonny Dove
description: A mass for Lloyd (Sonny) Dove, the former St. John's University basketball star who died earlier this week, will be offered at 9:30 A.M. Saturday at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church, 118-22 Riverton Street, St. Albans, Queens. Mr. Dove died when the taxi he was driving skidded into the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn. The body will be on view at the Gilmore Funeral Home, 191-02 Linden Boulevard, St. Albans, from 7 to 9 P.M. today and from 2 to 5 P.M. and 7 to 9 P.M. tomorrow.

title: REAGAN ENDS FIGHT TO WITHHOLD DATA IN DISPUTE ON E.P.A.
description: President Reagan, retreating from the earlier Administration position, said at a news conference tonight that he would no longer withhold Environmental Protection Agency documents from Congress because he would never invoke executive privilege to conceal possible wrongdoing.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Crimp in Some Gala Plans Brings Brooklyn Fireworks

title: TANDY BRANDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BALLET: 'NORWEGIAN MOODS'
description: TWO mercurial presences took over the stage of the New York State Theater on Friday, when the New York City Ballet presented Lew Christensen's ''Norwegian Moods.''

title: VOLCKER OUTLINES DUAL GOALS
description: The Federal Reserve Board chairman, Paul A. Volcker, said today that for the rest of this year the Fed wants to try to assist the economy's recovery. But he said its efforts would be tempered by a parallel commitment to holding down inflation.

title: DUCOMMUN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $96,000 for the qr and $253,000 for the yr...C-After a loss of $288,000 for the qr and a gain of $1,302,000 for the yr from discontinued operations and a gain of $5,640,000 for the qr and yr on the disposition of discontinued operations

title: Ambrosiano Plans Sale
description: Ambrosiano Holding of Luxembourg is offering for sale a majority stake in Banca del Gottardo, Fernando Garzoni, the bank's chairman, said today. He said Ambrosiano, which has a 45 percent stake in the bank, may also hold indirectly another 5 percent or more. Ambrosiano Holding, a unit of Banco Ambrosiano of Milan, Italy, has been seeking a buyer of its stake since July, when Banco Ambrosiano went into liquidation because of the burden of hundreds of million dollars in bad loans.

title: ATLANTIC AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pope Is Suffering From Flu
description: Pope John Paul II, suffering from a slight case of flu, ushered in Lent today at a mass in a fifth-century church in Rome. In his Ash Wednesday message, he urged Roman Catholics to help the needy, the exiled and those deprived of freedom in their own countries.

title: STAGE: 'LUMIERE,' LIFE AND TIMES OF FRERES MANET
description: EDDIE and Beth love each other desperately, but there's a hitch: Eddie will never leave his wife. Gene, who is Eddie's kindly but nebbishy brother, also loves Beth, but she likes him only as a friend. Will Beth, if she can't have the dashing Eddie, settle for less by marrying Gene? Will Eddie leave his wife after all and come to Beth's rescue? Such are the timeless questions raised by ''Lumiere,'' the new play by Donald Marcus at the Ark Theater Company in SoHo.

title: Kirby to Amend S.E.C. Statement
description: The Kirby Exploration Company said its registration statement covering shares to be issued in its merger with the General Energy Corporation had not become effective with the Securities and Exchange Commission in time to permit use of unaudited interim financial statements in the prospectus and a joint proxy statement included in the registration document.

title: HEART PATIENT GOES BACK TO INTENSIVE CARE UNIT
description: After spending almost two days in a private room, Dr. Barney B. Clark, the artificial heart recipient, has returned to a surgical intensive care unit because of lung and kidney problems.

title: DELTAK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FEWER ARTISTS AT WORK
description: Employment in the arts declined in 1982 for the first time since the Government started gathering statistics 12 years ago, the National Endowment for the Arts reported today.

title: NASSAU REQUESTS 1 RISE IN SALES TAX
description: Francis T. Purcell, the Nassau County Executive, asked state legislators today to approve a one-cent increase in the county's three-cent sales tax.

title: OLD DOMINION REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec
description: B-Including gains of $480,763 for the qr and $1,330,918 for the yr on the sale of property...C-Including a gain of $212,439 on the sale of property

title: CORRECTION
description: The Jose Clemente Orozco mural used to illustrate Gabriel Garcia Marquez's Nobel lecture, ''The Solitude of Latin America,'' on Feb. 6 is in the Baker Library at Dartmouth College, Hanover, N.H.

title: Eurobonds Rise Slightly
description: Fixed-interest dollar Eurobonds rose slightly as New York bonds moved higher following testimony by Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, to Congress, but the market remained very quiet, dealers said.

title: Citicorp Seems to Halt Advertising in Fortune
description: Fortune magazine confirmed yesterday that Citicorp, which ran 22 pages of advertising worth about $750,000 in the magazine in 1982, has stopped advertising in it. That has happened since the Jan. 10 issue and the article on David Edwards, who caused Citibank its storm of woes overseas.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: In a Midtown Line, Time for Introspection

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of mechanical errors, Tuesday's Mutual Funds table was repeated in Business Day yesterday in place of the correct table. Readers wishing a copy of the Wednesday table may write to Production Quality Control, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036.

title: REAGAN SEES EARLY COMPROMISE ON JOBS BILL
description: President Reagan said tonight that he hoped to reach agreement with Congress on an emergency jobs bill ''in the next several days.'' The legislation, he said, could reach his desk by next month.

title: Mickey Rooney Slated For an Honorary Oscar
description: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences said Tuesday that Mickey Rooney would receive an honorary Oscar for ''50 years of versatility in a variety of memorable film performances'' at the April 11 presentations. The actor, who appeared in 124 films, was nominated four times for an Oscar but never won.

title: J. E. Brooks, Author, Rare Books Authority
description: Jerome E. Brooks, an author and authority on rare books, died Tuesday at Mt. Sinai Hospital. He was 88. Mr. Brooks, a native of New York, wrote a number of books, including one about the Americas Cup races.

title: Missouri Senators Urge U.S. Buy Dioxin Sites
description: Missouri's two United States Senators are urging Federal officials to buy out residents of Times Beach, Mo., charging that the Government responded in a ''leisurely'' manner to dioxin contamination in the town.

title: WTC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OPERA: A CHANGE IN 'ARABELLA'
description: NEARLY everyone at the second performance Monday night of the Metropolitan Opera's fine new ''Arabella'' production was in better voice except for Kiri Te Kanawa in the title role, who was in no voice at all. Miss Te Kanawa, who reportedly had been under the weather at last week's opening night, withdrew from Monday's repeat with the flu.

title: THE SOCIAL RESEARCHER AS PART OF HIS SUBJECT
description: To the Editor:

title: '74 KILLING BAFFLES TOUGH POLICE CHIEF
description: In 12 years as head of the Provincetown Police, Chief James J. Meads has gained a reputation for being tough, stubborn and tenacious, particularly for his efforts to solve a case known locally as ''the Body in the Dunes.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Of Truants and Tales

title: Johnson Takes Downhill Race
description: Bill Johnson solidified his claim to being America's best downhill skier when he won that event today at the start of the national Alpine championships.

title: HERS
description: WHENEVER I see a baglady, I see myself slipping past the edge of time and space into an abandoned doorway. ''We are all bagladies in our souls,'' says a friend who has certainly had her successes. She tells me of riding a bus recently when a baglady climbed on, heaving herself and her possesions through the door and up the steps. Some sense of pride or purpose, or both, pushed her past the seats reserved for the handicapped and elderly, down the aisle to the back where one long, overheated seat served as an inspection table for the contents of her bags.

title: ANTITRUST'S QUESTIONABLE TRIUMPH OVER A.T.& T.
description: To the Editor:

title: Transit Betrayed
description: Betrayal is not too strong a word for the Reagan Administration's refusal to honor the compromises it struck to win passage of the higher gasoline tax last year. It had agreed to divide the proceeds between highways and mass transit and to allow localities to judge what transit help they need most: new equipment or more operating and maintenance money.

title: HOME BEAT
description: THOUGH the cocktail party seemed just like a college reunion, the 60 people at the Seventh Regiment Armory last week were past and present members of Bloomingdale's interior-design department. ''Since the 1940's Bloomingdale's designers have been influencing taste in homes and offices across the country,'' said Richard Knapple, vice president for interior design, who is pictured at far right.

title: F.D.I.C. Cites Bank Actions
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation tried at least twice to stop the failed United American Bank of Knoxville from engaging in unsound lending practices, court records show.

title: ENERGY CONVERSION DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RELIGIOUS STRIFE DEEPENING AS GUATEMALA AWAITS POPE
description: Preparations for the visit of Pope John Paul II to Guatemala are being accompanied by recriminations and insults between the country's Roman Catholics and followers of fast-growing Protestant fundamentalist sects.

title: DANCE: ERIE BARSNESS TROUPE
description: TEACHERS of creative writing often warn students that, even though their subject matter might be boredom, they should take care to prevent their stories and poems from being literally boring. It's good advice that can be applied to creations in other arts than literature.

title: WHERE CHARITY BEGINS
description: If President Reagan has his way, Federal workers will no longer be able to make about $4 million in payroll pledges to nonprofit groups advocating such things as women's rights, civil rights and environmental issues.

title: Soviet Output Up in January
description: Soviet industrial and agricultural production in January rose considerably over January of last year but failed to reach the 1981 level in several key sectors, according to data published today by the Economic Gazette.

title: MOHASCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SCHOOL PLAN GAINS IN ST. LOUIS TALKS
description: Faced with the possibility of mandatory busing, lawyers for 20 of St. Louis County's 23 school districts agreed today to a voluntary plan to desegregate city-county schools.

title: ENERGY MANAGEMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a pretax gain of $1.7 million on the sale of assets

title: Houston Charge
description: Houston Industries said it took a $168 million after-tax charge against fourth-quarter earnings after the Texas Public Utility Commission disallowed the recovery of certain costs associated with the Allens Creek Nuclear Project, which was canceled last August. Including the charge, Houston Industries reported a fourth-quarter loss of $115.1 million, compared with a profit of $39.8 million, or 56 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: 3 SCHOOL BOARDS SEEKING AN END TO SUSPENSIONS
description: Leaders of three suspended community school boards in Queens moved yesterday to get the suspensions lifted and strongly criticized Schools Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola for having suspended them. The Chancellor acted after the boards had canceled or threatened to cancel classes because of the snow.

title: 24-HOUR RADIO HUMOR BRIGHTENS CAPITAL LIFE
description: It's 5 P.M. and you're stuck in traffic on the 14th Street Bridge. You can sit and stew, you can lean on the horn. Or, you can tune your radio to 1150 AM and hear Henny Youngman say, ''Take my wife. Please.''

title: A THRONG FOR MONTANA
description: YOU had to be a little crazy to go out into the cold Tuesday night and stand on a damp sidewalk for half an hour to see the Claude Montana fashion show at the Seventh Regiment Armory. ''Or you had to really need some inspiration,'' said Antonio Lopez, the fashion illustrator.

title: POWER CORP OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a special charge of $1,545,000 for the qr and a special gain of $4,103,000 for the yr...C-After a special charge of $4,674,000 for the qr and a specialgain of $10,894,000 for the yr

title: AS LENT BEGINS, BISHOP MOORE TALKS OF THE HUNGRY
description: As the season of Lent began yesterday, the Episcopal Bishop of New York linked the traditional themes of repentance and renewal with concern for the poor and oppressed.

DESIGN NOTEBOOK;
UNKNOWN FURNITURE DESIGNS OF BUGATTI

description: * Baldor Electric Co., Fort Smith, Ark., has elected William T. Kirkpatrick president and chief operating officer.

Evidence Verified In Race-Fix Case
description: James Veno, a former groom at Roosevelt Raceway, authenticated prosecution tape recordings today at a race-fixing trial in its third day.

title: FINANCING DELAYED, MEXICO SEEKS A BRIDGE LOAN
description: Mexico will seek a $400 million to $500 million bridge loan from a group of leading Western banks because of delays in the completion of a planned $5 billion financing package, Finance Ministry officials said here today.

title: K-TEL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
2 Islanders Are Sidelined
description: The Islanders, after losing on Tuesday night for the third time in four games, saw their frustrations grow yesterday when they learned that two of their defensemen, Mike McEwen and Gord Lane, would miss tonight's game against the Penguins.

title: TV: SOME UNUSUAL MOMENTS
description: AGATHA CHRISTIE without a detective, the Speaker of the House of Representatives pulling a stool up to a bar in a situation comedy - television entertainment can still come up with its unusual moments.

title: LEGISLATOR SAYS HE REPORTED TRANSIT BID RIGGING IN 1981
description: A State Assemblyman from the Bronx said yesterday that he had reported allegations of corruption in the Transit Authority's purchasing department more than a year before an audit released Tuesday found bid rigging and other abuses.

title: HOFSTRA WINS IN 2 OVERTIMES
description: David Taylor scored 23 points and grabbed 15 rebounds tonight to lead Hofstra to an 83-80 double-overtime victory at Wagner.

title: QUESTIONS FOLLOW RICHARDSON'S PATH
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. J udging by the National Basketball Association's media guides, Michael Ray Richardson does not exist. Shortly before the season began, he was traded by the Knicks in time for his biography and career statistics to be expunged from their guide just as it went to press. By the time he joined the Golden State Warriors, their guide had been printed. Now he's with the New Jersey Nets, much too late, of course, for him to be included in their guide. But as the Nets await tonight's game against the Denver Nuggets, their man without a media guide is not without a reputation.

title: SOME CLEVER SOLUTIONS BY APARTMENT DWELLERS
description: BURNING fireplaces are enough of a luxury in city apartments so that New Yorkers who have them don't seem to mind the problems they can cause. One, for example, is where to store the firewood.

title: Opel Reports A Profit for '82
description: Adam Opel A.G., the West German unit of the General Motors Corporation, released preliminary figures today indicating it made a profit equivalent to $37.1 million in 1982, following two consecutive years of heavy losses.

title: Queen Elizabeth in Caymans
description: Queen Elizabeth II today began her first visit to the Cayman Islands, one of Britain's few remaining Caribbean colonies. The Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh flew here from Jamaica, where they spent three days. The welcoming crowd was estimated at 5,000.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: JONATHAN LOGAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes loss of $1,000 in the latest qr of equity in results of affiliated companies compared with income of $475,000 for the yr-ago period...C-Net loss reflects a charge of about $17 million, net of tax benefits, relating to the closing of the company's textile manufacturing operations in Spartansburg, S.C.

title: TALKING ABOUT TALKING ABOUT SEX
description: ''Personally, do you believe in premarital sex?'' the student in English 213 asked the visitor. ''What do you mean by premarital sex?'' the visitor responded. ''Well, intercourse,'' said the student. ''Ahhhhhhh,'' said Dr. Mary S. Calderone. ''Say it then. Intercourse.'' This kind of conversation has been going on all week at Vassar College - in classrooms, in student lounges, over lunch with staff counselors, at tea with faculty members, at dinner with administrators and up and down the pathways of this stark and snowy campus.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: BOOKISH

title: U.N. Reports Millions Are Executed Unlawfully
description: At least two million people have been put to death over the last 15 years without due process, according to a United Nations report issued today. Due process includes a fair trial, a right to a lawyer of choice or the right to appeal,

title: Long Pact for Molitor
description: The Milwaukee Brewers signed their star third baseman, Paul Molitor, to a five-year contract that guarantees him an average of $1 million a year and could bring him an additional $140,000 annually in bonus payments. ... In the biggest arbitration award so far this year and the second largest ever, Mario Soto, the Cincinnnati Reds' pitcher, won $625,000. The club had offered $450,000. The award has been exceeded only by the $700,000 won by Bruce Sutter of the St. Louis Cardinals in 1980.

title: Stratas Met Roles Canceled
description: The soprano Teresa Stratas has canceled all her appearances this season as Mimi in the Metropolitan Opera's ''La Boheme,'' because of an illness in her family. In place of Miss Stratas will be Linda Zoghby, who made her debut in the role last season.

title: DROP IN OIL PRICES SPURS FUEL CO-OPS
description: THE winter of 1982-83 has turned out to be a boom season for fuel oil cooperatives, the organizations of consumers in the metropolitan area who have banded together to get lower prices from suppliers.

title: SOURCES OF SUPPLY: LOGS AND KINDLING
description: The following is a sampling of sources that sell firewood: A.A. Armator & Son, 1701 Second Avenue (88th Street), 212-737- 1742.

title: COLECO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss; the 1982 qr and yr results have been adjusted to reflect a 100 percent stock divd paid in Jan 1983

title: Let's Define the Quango
description: One of the Reagan Administration's better ideas was to enlarge subsidies to foreign democrats and to take the operation out of the secret cupboard. It has already taken steps in that direction. But the project needs a less pedestrian name than Democracy Program and a clearer charter of purpose.

title: SHULTZ DENOUNCES SALVADOR'S REBELS AS 'CREATING HELL'
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the Salvadoran insurgents were ''creating hell'' with Soviet-supplied weapons and that the United States would never support negotiations allowing them to ''shoot their way'' into the Government.

title: A COOKIE WHOSE TIME KEEPS COMING
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: NORTH KOREA LEAFLET PAINTS U.S. DEFECTOR IN 'A CONTENTED LIFE'

description: Simply entitled ''February Exhibition,'' the current show at the Departure Gallery features the work of three divergent artists whose pieces complement each other handsomely.

SOUTHLAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in Jan 1983

title: U.S. Plans to Appeal Ruling On Teen-Ager Birth Control
description: The Reagan Administration plans to appeal a Federal court ruling that blocks a requirement that parents be told when young women receive prescription contraceptives at federally subsidized clinics.

title: PEOPLES DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 15
Pirates Pick Starter
description: Spring training doesn't begin until Saturday, and the start of the baseball season is two months away, but Chuck Tanner, manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates, is convinced that he has already clinched an opening-day record.

title: ISLANDERS EYE TOP TEEN-AGE PROSPECT
description: Brian Lawton, a 17-year-old center who is a senior at Mount St. Charles Academy in Woonsocket, R.I., could be the next teen-ager to move from a United States high school to the National Hockey League.

title: THE U.S. IN AFRICA
description: Dr. Nthato Motlana, an important spokesman for urban blacks in South Africa, was invited last year to speak at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York. He accepted - subject to his getting a passport. The South African Government often takes the position now that blacks are citizens of a ''homeland'' and must go there for passports.

title: MCI Bolstering Communications
description: The MCI Communications Corporation announced plans to invest $1 billion in its communications network during the fiscal year that begins April 1, up from $600 million in the current year.

title: A Good Fight
description: In the aftermath of Marvelous Marvin Hagler's marvelous performance last Friday night in stopping Tony Sibson of England in six rounds, it seemed the only opponents left for the universally recognized middlweight champion were those from history. No one around today, except perhaps Thomas Hearns and Wilfred Benitez, seems capable of giving Hagler a tough evening.

title: CASTLE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. GRANTS AID TO HELP REPAIR BROOKLYN BRIDGE
description: The Federal Government awarded $5.4 million yesterday to New York State to repair the Brooklyn Bridge, and officials expected more money for the project to be made available.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
SHOWER HEADS ON ONE HOSE
description: held shower heads with snap couplings so that various heads can easily be used on one hose.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 17, 1983
description: International Trouble for a Presidential nominee was indicated as the Senate Foreign Relations Committee put off a scheduled vote on the appointment of Kenneth L. Adelman as the chief American arms control official. The action came after Senator Charles McC. Mathias, the Maryland Republican considered a swing vote, indicated he would oppose the nomination after new questions were raised about Mr. Adelman's commitment to arms negotiations. (Page A1, Columns 1-2.) Reports of Libyan-Sudanese tension were cited by President Reagan as he disclosed at a news conference that Air Force Awacs reconnaissance planes had been sent to Egypt for ''training exercises.'' Administration officials said that Libya had recently moved some Soviet-built fighter planes closer to its border with the Sudan, probably in Chad. (A1:4-5.)

title: SEALED POWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a gain of $5,339,000 from the sale of a 57 percent interest in the company's Mexican operation

description: B-Net income including a tax credit of $2,755,000

description: B-Net income...C-Including a gain of $4.9 million on the sale of oil and gas properties...D-Net loss

title: Gerstle Mack, 88, Author; Biographer and Historian
description: Gerstle Mack, the author of a history of the Panama Canal and a biography of Paul Cezanne, died Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 88 years old.

title: ROCK: AEROSMITH IN JERSEY
description: AEROSMITH, one of the most popular rock bands of the 1970's, played its first engagement in the New York City metropolitan area in several years Sunday in the Brendan Byrne Arena, in East Rutherford, N.J. The band's absence from the concert scene, the result of a motorcycle injury suffered by its lead singer, Steven Tyler, had not appreciably diminished its largely teen-aged audience.

title: Loan for Colombia
description: Colombia is seeking an $80 million, eight-year loan from private banks, according to banking sources. Colombia will probably have to pay at least 1 1/4 percentage points over the London rate, compared with 5/8 to 3/4 point in the second half of 1982, they added.

title: THE SOCIAL RESEARCHER AS PART OF HIS SUBJECT
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Murder Suspect Arraigned
description: A civil servant charged with murdering a young drifter was ordered held without bail today in a case that the police say may involve 14 other slayings. Dennis Andrew Nilsen, 37 years old, was jailed until a further hearing Friday.

title: ERNST, E C, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income including a tax credit of $2,755,000

title: Decision Deferred
description: She's a 17-year-old high school senior, people always told her that college had been the best years of their lives, and so she planned to follow in her sister's footsteps and enter Stanford next fall. That's the kind of thinking that can make a father proud, but in this case the prospective student was Andrea Jaeger, the professional tennis star.

title: ILLINOIS TOOL WORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results reflect special gains equal to 9 cents a shr for the latest fourth qr and 5 cents a shr for the yr-ago fourth qr

title: ASBESTOS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges

title: CONNECTICUT HEARS PLEAS TO CURB DRUNKEN DRIVING
description: One at a time, from all parts of the state, they have come forward to speak before the Governor's task force on drunken driving: Constance Aikens lost a husband, Donna Maynard a sister, Betty Spicer a daughter, Frank Sutton a brother.

title: Miss von Stade Drops Chamber Society Dates
description: The mezzo-soprano Frederica von Stade will not appear with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center for three concerts, because of a death in her family.

title: BEATRICE FOODS IN SHIFT
description: Beatrice Foods, a highly diversified conglomerate, announced a sweeping reorganization plan that will include after-tax charges of $280 million, including a big write-off on Tropicana, and result in a sizable loss in the fourth quarter of the 1983 fiscal year.

title: MIDLAND CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for As of Dec 31
Dow Retreats 5.67, to 1,087.43; Other Major Indicators Off
description: Despite some encouraging economic news, the stock market yesterday ended moderately lower in slower trading as investors cashed in some of their recent gains.

title: Poles Attack Rally Coverage
description: Poland's official press agency attacked Western news outlets today for their reports on a pro-Solidarity demonstration here Sunday night. It said the confrontation was a ''flimsy brawl'' distorted to ''create an impression in the West that everything is falling to pieces in Warsaw.''

title: French Lithographs
description: A group of 150 French lithographs by Delacroix, Gericault, Daumier, Manet, Pissarro and other French 19th-century artists will be on view at Associated American Artists, 663 Fifth Avenue, near 53d Street, through March 4. Hours are Monday to Saturday, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission is free. Information: PL 5-4211.

title: ROCK: DREAM SYNDICATE BAND
description: JUST about every new-wave band shows the influence of the Velvet Underground. But the Dream Syndicate, which played Monday at the Mudd Club, is utterly, single-mindedly devoted to the Velvets for both sound and sense.

title: POP-SOUL: HOUSTON DUO
description: soul singer, and her 19-year-old daughter, Whitney, have been performing together informally in small clubs and in churches for the last four years. Tuesday, they made their ''official'' club debut as a duo, opening a four-night engagement at Sweetwaters. Because of their firm gospel orientation, they share many stylistic similarities.

title: GODFATHER'S PIZZ reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A 'Start' at N.Y.U.
description: Dr. John Brademas, the president of New York University, said yesterday that the school, which announced that it would again field a basketball team, had no plans to move up to Division II or Division I. It will compete in Division III of the National Collegiate Athletic Association but may play some of its games against teams in higher divisions.

title: Phelps Reopening
description: The Phelps Dodge Corporation said it would resume operations at its Ajo mine on Feb. 28, recalling 600 workers, because of increased demand for copper. The smelter will remain closed, the company said. Resumption of work at Ajo will mean that the company will be operating at 75 percent of normal capacity, said A.J. Kinnenberg, senior vice president.

title: Delay for Manville
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge in New York has granted the Manville Corporation a 45-day extension for filing its formal reorganization plan, the company said. A Manville spokesman said Judge Berton Lifland in New York approved the extension, beginning Feb. 22, the judge's original deadline.

title: FUQUA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including extraodinary income of $370,000 for the qr and $2,970,000 for the yr...C-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $5,605,000 for theqr and $11,618,000 for the yr, an extraordinary loss of $501,000 for the qr andextraordinary income of $301,000 for the yr; yr-ago results have been restated

title: Harvester Outlays
description: The International Harvester Company plans to spend $125 million on product development in 1983, down from $182 million last year, Donald Lennox, the company's president, told shareholders at the annual meeting.He said he expects truck sales to rise 6 to 8 percent this year, but cautioned that sales could be hurt by the higher gasoline tax.

title: Two Fishing Vessels Missing in Bering Sea
description: A Coast Guard search for two vishing vessels with 14 people aboard ended unsuccessfully today, but officials said it would be resumed at first light Friday.

title: Polaroid Corporation
description: The Polaroid Corporation today reported that fourth-quarter earnings surged to $9.6 million, or 31 cents a share, from $1.7 million, or 6 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: SOVIET PROPOSES TALKS ON ITS PLAN FOR TREATY BANNING NUCLEAR TESTS
description: The Soviet Union called on the 40-nation disarmament conference today to start detailed talks on a treaty outlawing all nuclear weapons tests without mandatory on-site inspection to verify compliance.

title: Friendly Advice Saves a Pitcher
description: At this time two years ago, many baseball people thought Scott Holman's career was over. When the Mets open their early camp today in St. Petersburg, Fla., Holman will try to become a starting pitcher.

title: Brooklyn Bridge Walk
description: On May 24, the Brooklyn Bridge will be 100 years old.

title: PITCHING BIG PROBLEM
description: The Mets began to gather today for their early spring-training camp with one clear and urgent mission: to overhaul a pitching staff that led the team's collapse into last place in the National League's Eastern Division.

title: MONARCH CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
69 REPORTED DEAD AND 1,000 HURT
description: Brush fires, driven by high winds, raged today for a second day through parts of two southern Australian states, raising the death toll to at least 69. Officials said at least 7 people were missing and about 1,000 injured.

title: BOSSY LEADS ISLANDERS OVER PENGUINS
description: Although they were outplayed in the last period, the Islanders played well enough in the first two periods to defeat the Pittsurgh Penguins, 4-1, tonight at Nassau Coliseum, ending a two-game losing streak.

title: 2 Accounting Firms Sued
description: Five former customers of the closed Toledo brokerage firm of Bell & Beckwith have filed a $100 million lawsuit against the company's former managing partner and two accounting firms yesterday in Lucas County Common Pleas Court.

title: SUSQUEHANNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes income of $805,000 from discontinued operations for the qr and yr and an extraordinary credit of $532,000 for the yr

title: News Analysis
description: Congress can cut military spending, as a chorus of voices is asking, but it has few tools to reduce the constantly growing costs of buying and operating a military force and that may be the only way to achieve real control of the Defense Department budget.

title: Nassau County Bonds, Insured, Sell Quickly
description: Nassau County's $57 million of new general obligation and sewer bonds were offered yesterday with yields ranging from 4.5 percent for bonds due in 1984 to 7.5 percent in 1993 and 9 percent for bonds due in 2003-13 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch.

title: No Headline
description: AROUND THE WORLD; Tass Denounces Arrest Of Aeroflot Man in Italy

title: AMERICAN SOLAR KING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid on Jan 13

title: EDDIE FISHER SINGS IN TOWN FIRST TIME SINCE '67
description: ''THEY call me 'the comeback kid.' I hate the word 'comeback,' but sure, it's a challenge to be playing New York after all this time,'' Eddie Fisher said the other day.

title: U.S. Fish Exports Fall
description: United States fish exports declined last year, the National Marine Fisheries Service reported today.

title: U.S. REVOKES CURB ON WATER CONTROL
description: The Interior Department today revoked an earlier legal opinion that had limited the authority of states to control some scarce water supplies in the West.

title: Tests for Kunkel
description: Bill Kunkel, an American League umpire who had one cancerous rectal tumor removed, said today that a second one was detected last week and that he would enter New York University Hospital for tests. Kunkel, a 46-year-old resident of this central New Jersey community, returned to umpiring last year after missing most of the previous season and then undergoing two operations in the autumn of 1981 for removal of the first tumor. He said that he would be readmitted to the hospital Friday or Saturday and would undergo tests next week to determine whether the newly detected cancer had spread.

title: M.T.A. Offering Sells Out in a Day
description: Strong investor demand enabled underwriters to offer an issue of Metropolitan Transportation Authority revenue bonds this week rather than next week. ''We wanted to take advantage of market conditions,'' an official at Dillon, Read & Company, the lead underwriter, said.

title: Mobil Germany Reports Loss
description: The Mobil Corporation's West German subsidiary today announced its worst annual loss since World War II.

title: FIRESTONE TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $1 million for the latest first qr and $900,000 for the yr-ago first qr

title: WOLOHAN LUMBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FORD MOTOR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GOVERNOR REJECTS EVACUATION PLANS FOR ATOMIC PLANT
description: Governor Cuomo yesterday ordered the state not to approve emergency evacuation plans for the area around the Shoreham nuclear power plant in Suffolk County.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: I nominate Yasir Arafat for the ''Chutzpah of the Year'' award for his proposal of a Nuremberg-type tribunal to judge the complicity of Israel and the U.S. in war crimes against civilians. If an unbiased tribunal were convened, the first defendants would be Arafat and his P.L.O. colleagues for their systematic killing of civilians over more than a decade. Would Arafat submit to the jurisdiction of such a tribunal? ALAN M. DERSHOWITZ Cambridge, Mass., Feb. 10, 1983

(Television - MSG Cable, 7:30 P.M., live, and 1 A.M. Saturday, tape.)

title: Tribune Co. Net Up 69%
description: The Tribune Company said fourth-quarter net rose 69 percent, to $50.5 million, from $29.9 million a year earlier, on revenue of $390.9 million.

title: COMBINED INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'Lost' Tissot and Turner.
description: TWO 19th-century art works whose whereabouts were for many years uncertain by art scholars - a painting by James Jacques Tissot and a watercolor by J.M.W. Turner - will be offered in sales of 19thcentury European paintings, drawings and watercolors next week at Sotheby Parke Bernet, York Avenue and 72d Street, and at Christie's, Park Avenue and 59th Street.

title: Marchal Landgren, Historian And Author of 'Years of Art'
description: Marchal E. Landgren, an art historian and author, died of cancer last Sunday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington.

title: Caught in the Act
description: For a time, Frank Wills was a hero. It was he, working as a guard in the Watergate in Washington, who discovered tape on the stairway door lock that night in June 1972.

description: B-Net income; Results for 1982 include a special writeoff of $3,369,000 resulting from a change in direction for the company's microcomputer manufacturing subsidiary

title: DOLE URGES TAX INCREASE FOR BANKS
description: Senator Bob Dole, chairman of the tax-writing Senate Finance Committee, said today that Congress should pass selective tax increases this year, particularly for commercial banks and thrift institutions and possibly for insurance companies.

title: Draft Registration Is Pressed
description: The Justice Department, with a new list of 5,154 names, said today it intended to pursue prosecution of men who had failed to register for a possible draft, despite court rulings against the law.

title: REAGAN CHOICE FOR ARMS POST SAYS HE'LL FIGHT
description: Kenneth L. Adelman, President Reagan's choice to be the nation's chief arms control official, said today that he would fight to win confirmation in the Senate, where his nomination has been under criticism.

title: ROPER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: B-Net loss after income of $43,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $1,424,000 from the disposal of discontinued operations

title: ROCKWELL K. DuMOULIN
