description: Rockwell King DuMoulin, an architect who taught and practiced in Providence, R.I., died Saturday at the age of 77. Mr. DuMoulin, who lived in Matunuck, R.I., administered and taught in the architecture division of the Rhode Island School of Design for six years before retiring in 1978.

title: THE POTENTIAL OF A SUB-SUPREME COURT
description: To the Editor:

title: RADICAL URGES P.L.O. TO REJECT 'DISGRACEFUL' REAGAN PEACE PROPOSAL
description: Dr. George Habash, the leader of the radical wing of the Palestine Liberation Organization, urged the 350 members of the P.L.O.'s parliament today to deliver a ''clear and categoric'' rejection of the ''disgraceful'' Reagan peace plan.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS SAY LIBYAN THREAT LED TO AWACS DISPATCH
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that Awacs surveillance planes had been sent to Egypt because of concern over possible Libyan military moves against the Sudan. They said they expected the planes to remain only a few days unless Libya launched an attack.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in the Executive Changes column in Business Day on Feb. 10 incorrectly identified the company that promoted Denis F. Mullane. It was the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company.

title: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1983; Companies
description: G.M. and Toyota have apparently decided to bypass the U.A.W. in hiring workers for their joint production of subcompact cars at a G.M. plant in Fremont, Calif. Executives of both companies said the new venture will not be bound by the General Motors contract with the union. But the union said G.M. had promised it would represent the workers at the plant. The divergence appeared to set the stage for a confrontation. (Page A1.) Executives who were asked about the G.M.- Toyota venture noted that it contained some new twists and a few unfavorable aspects. (D3.)

title: REAGAN LAND SALE POLICY STALLED IN RHODE ISLAND
description: Under increasing fire in Congress and in the courts, President Reagan's policy of selling off Federal lands to reduce the national debt ran aground this week on a shoal of its own selection: a beautiful little rocky peninsula on the New England coast, in Narragansett Bay.

title: FORMER U.S. DIPLOMAT WAS 64
description: Barbara M. Watson, the first black and the first woman named an Assistant Secretary of State, died at a hospital here today, it was announced. She was 64 years old.

title: HARVARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $205,000

title: U.S. JURY CLEARS BRITON IN AN ARMS SMUGGLING CASE
description: A British international arms dealer has been found not guilty of charges he conspired to smuggle weapons to Iran and Iraq, which are at war with each other.

title: GILLETTE CO reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
Fan Dies in Fall
description: A man fell 47 feet to his death from a ramp at the Kingdome while leaving the Seattle SuperSonics game Wednesday night.

title: POP JAZZ
description: TEN years ago, on Feb. 5, 1973, a 36-year-old Assistant Attorney General for the State of New York who had never produced a concert of any kind, booked the tiny Theater De Lys on Christopher Street for a jazz concert. But not just a jazz concert. He booked it for two nights, a month apart, and thereby implied a series.

title: FLICKINGER, S M, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
AFFILIATED HOSPITAL PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TENDING THE INDIAN AFFAIRS TINDERBOX
description: When Kenneth L. Smith, Assistant Secretary of the Interior for Indian Affairs, was asked why his people were still so suspicious of the agency he heads, he produced a letter that had been dispatched to all Indian tribes in 1923 by one of his predecessors.

title: Suriname's Rulers Lift Their Ban on Meetings
description: Suriname's military Government has lifted restrictions imposed on the country last December when it said it crushed at least two attempted coups, the official Suriname press agency said Wednesday.

title: PHILHARMONIC: SCHOENBERG ESSAY
description: IN building his program for last night's New York Philharmonic concert, Zubin Mehta must have thought he had done everything possible to insure that no one would be offended. He placed Schoenberg's ''Erwartung,'' a 1909 essay in atonal opera, at the end of an otherwise lightweight program, where it could easily be avoided by the more militant members of the Philharmonic's notoriously conservative audience. No luck. Throughout the performance, people headed for the exits with shocked and insulted looks on their faces, showing their backs to Hildegard Behrens, the soprano who was singing the only role in this dramatically and vocally difficult monodrama.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues.

title: EDWARD M. DOUGLAS
description: Edward M. Douglas, retired vice president and former director of the International Business Machines Corporation, died Tuesday of a cardiac illness at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. Mr. Douglas, a resident of Vineyard Haven on Martha's Vineyard, Mass., was 79 years old.

title: KLEZMER MUSIC MAKES LEAP TO CARNEGIE HALL
description: IT is music whose time has come, even though its time is long gone. It is the music of the klezmorim, those itinerant musicians who trooped through Yiddish-speaking Eastern Europe, playing melodies of strident, compelling joy and pulsating rhythm, designed to raise spirits that were often dashed by the grim politics of the region.

title: ELIZABETHTOWN WATER CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
BBDO Earnings Up 1%; Foote, Cone Off 20.9%
description: BBDO International and Foote, Cone & Belding Communications have issued their fourth-quarter and year-end financial statements, but neither is worth writing home about.

title: CAMPBELL SOUP CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
King of Morocco To Buy Estate
description: GLADSTONE, N.J., Feb. 17 (UPI) - King Hassan II of Morocco intends to buy a 490-acre estate in Somerset County to use as his personal residence when he visits the United States, the Moroccan consul general in New York said today.

title: MICC INVESTMENTS LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After a special loss of $8,427,000...C-Net income

title: TASTY BAKING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss after a loss of $1,810,717 from discontinued operations

title: RACE MAY SET A COST RECORD
description: The three-way race for the Democratic mayoral nomination in Chicago may be the most expensive race ever for a city job anywhere in the nation.

title: NEW YORK IS A GALLERY OF THE BEST BY LIVING ARTISTS
description: UPTOWN galleries come in many shapes and sizes, but most of them are fundamentally domestic in scale. Even if they have a storefront directly on the street, we are likely to find ourselves in companionable spaces once we get inside. If they are upstairs, in bits of brownstones or grand houses cut into 11 pieces, we have an even stronger impression of having walked into a rather large living room in which one or two things are for sale and a uniformed parlormaid is about to come in with tea and cookies. Five such places are considered here.

title: Japan Recorder Exports Higher
description: Japan's production and exports of videotape recorders rose again in 1982, but the increases were well below those of the previous two years, the Electronic Industries Association of Japan said today.

title: STRIKING TEACHERS IN QUEBEC DEFY TOUGH LAW
description: Teachers in Quebec maintained their strike today in defiance of a stringent law enacted overnight empowering the provincial government to dismiss, fine, curtail seniority and deny the right of appeal under civil rights laws to absent teachers.

title: PROGRAMS UNLIMITED reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEW YORK IS A GALLERY OF THE BEST BY LIVING ARTISTS
description: SOHO is the place where the garrets are the largest and plushest and are more likely to be inhabited by galleries than artists. On balance, exhibitions in SoHo go to greater extremes of style and scale than do their counterparts uptown, and it's in this neighborhood, accordingly, that the newest, hottest tickets stage their commercial breakthroughs.

title: Rain Halts Hawaii Fire
description: Firefighters doused a few smoldering spots today after rain helped stop a brush fire that burned more than 3,000 acres of drought-stricken land, threatened homes and forced evacuations on the Big Island of Hawaii. The rain began late Wednesday and continued until 3 A.M. The area had had only about an inch of rain so far this year, far below ususal levels.

title: APACHE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $177,000 from discontinued operations...C-Afte r a loss of $175,000 for the qr and a gain of $200,000 for the yr from discontinued operations

title: Goodyear-Toyota
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company has agreed to supply $500,000 worth of replacement V-belts for Toyota Motor vehicles, Goodyear officials said. They said Goodyear becomes the first United States supplier to provide mechanical replacement parts to the Japanese auto maker. Goodyear said it may recall a few of its 300 laid-off workers here.

title: Autumn Synod in Rome
description: The sixth world synod of Roman Catholic bishops will begin here Sept. 29 and its discussions will focus on the church's role as a force for reconciliation in a divided world, the Vatican said today. The synod, the theme of which has been officially defined as ''reconciliation and penance in the mission of the church,'' will be attended by at least 200 bishops and is expected to last about a month.

title: Jets Name 3 Aides
description: Jim Ringo, the former star lineman, was among three assistant coaches hired by the Jets yesterday to help fill vacanies created by the departure of four assistants in the last week.

title: Market Place; Explorer Fund In Sharp Rise
description: WHEN Frank V. Wisneski played basketball for Yale in 1968, he made the All-Ivy League's second team. But now he's definitely firststring when it comes to picking little-known, high-technology companies in the stock market.

title: Defensive Tactics Give Rangers Lift
description: The emotional currents of a hockey game sometimes influence the play as much as the physical moves of the players. In Wednesday night's game between the Rangers and the Washington Capitals at Madison Square Garden, the emotional tide reversed itself in a fourminute span of the third period, sweeping the Rangers on to a 5-4 victory.

title: SPLIT BY VICTORY IN ZIMBABWE, EX-ALLIES WAGE A BITTER WAR
description: Since mid-January, Zimbabwe's western province of Matabeleland has been the center of a harsh campaign against members of the Ndebele tribe by troops drawn from the Shona tribe of Prime Minister Robert Mugabe.

title: Solidarity Broadcaster Sentenced in Poland
description: The head of the clandestine radio station operated by supporters of Solidarity during martial law was sentenced to four and a half years in jail today by a military court for ''broadcasting false information.'' The broadcaster, Zbigniew Romaszewski, who is a longtime dissident and one of the best-known Solidarity activists, and eight associates have been on trial here for three weeks in closed session before a military court.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Blair Video Enterprises has appointed Lennart Ringquist to the newly created post of executive vice president, creative affairs.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I believe the American people want what the President wants, which is real arms reductions which increase security.

title: Nurses and Lenox Hill Reach Tentative Pact
description: Lenox Hill Hospital and its nurses reached tentative agreement yesterday on a new contract. A spokesman for the Manhattan hospital said the agreement was expected to avert a strike threatened for today.

title: Common Market Studying Hyster
description: The Common Market's Executive Commission said it was investigating reports that the Hyster Company, an American concern that makes forklift trucks and construction equipment, had been promised aid from Britain to increase output there, while cutting back in Belgium and the Netherlands.

title: Robert Goodwin, Dramatist; An Early Black Writer for TV
description: Robert L. Goodwin, an innovative dramatist and one of the first blacks to write for national television, died of cancer Sunday at the University of California at Los Angeles Medical Center.

title: HOLMES TO FIGHT WITHERSPOON
description: Larry Holmes, saying that he would fight ''until I lose the desire,'' will fight undefeated Tim Witherspoon as part of a heavyweight title doubleheader May 20 that could be boxing's version of ''All in the Family.''

title: HOLIDAY INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income of $861,000 for the qr and a loss of $21,239,000 for the yr from discontinued operations...C-Includin g income from discontinued operations of $7,835,000 for the qr and $38,652,000 for the yr; yr-ago results have been restated

title: Two-woman play about suicide is coming in March.
description: character play is moving to New York intact from the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., where it received excellent reviews.

title: RPS PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Claims for Jobless Aid Decline
description: Some 510,000 Americans applied for firsttime unemployment benefits in the first week of February, a decline of 7,000 from the previous week, the Labor Department reported today.

title: DUDLEY MORRE RETURNS IN 'LOVESICK'
description: FORGET ''Six Weeks.'' Dudley Moore, incomparable in ''10'' and ''Arthur,'' is back doing what he does best in ''Lovesick,'' Marshall Brickman's sweetly wacky romantic comedy about a successful psychiatrist who betrays his profession by falling wildly in love with one of his patients. The film, which opens today at the National and other theaters, may be the most indigenously New York comedy since Woody Allen's ''Manhattan.''

title: Smoldering Fuses in the Subway
description: When New York's Transit Authority purchases $34 million in hardware in less than two years, as it did recently, no system for preventing fraud can be completely foolproof. But subway officials are obliged at least to try to defend the public's money. If a recent audit is correct about losses on fuses and pipe nipples, the agency hasn't even made the attempt.

title: NEW MEXICO & ARIZONA LAND CO reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
description: B-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $4,320,000 for the qrand $3.6 million for the yr

title: CIRCLE K CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
FOOTE CONE & BELDING COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results include gains equal to 9 cents a shr for the latest fourth qr and 30 cents a shr for the yr-ago fourth qr from the purchase of tax credits

title: Advertising; Time Inc.  Challenges TV Guide
description: TIME INC.'s latest magazine venture is very much a creature of the electronic age. Without cable television there would be no need to publish it. And without the computer it would be impossible to publish.

title: CIGNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results are pro forma earnings of Connecticut General Corp and INA Corp which merged to form Cigna Corp in 1982

title: BUILDER IN PRINCETON AREA SEES BIG HOUSING GROWTH
description: One could say that Robert and Bruce Toll, brothers who are president and chief financial officer, respectively, of Toll Brothers, developers of Horsham, Pa., are bullish on the Princeton area - and that would be an understatement.

title: E.P.A. Staff Reversed On Opinion, Aides Say
description: A top Environmental Protection Agency official last month reversed staff recommendations and ordered speedy issuance of a permit for ocean disposal of toxic wastes to a concern whose lawyer is a former adviser to the agency's administrator, Anne M. Gorsuch, agency officials said today.

title: OMNI EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; the company went public on Nov 7, 1981; yr-ago results are for the period from Nov 7 through Dec 31, 1981

title: 'TABLE,' A FATHER AND HIS KIDS
description: THE complex, troubled, nonnuclear modern American family would be one of the movies' most important topics today, if only anyone in post-''Kramer vs. Kramer'' Hollywood knew what to do with it. ''Table for Five'' certainly tackles the subject. However, that's not the same thing as casting any light on it.

title: Soviet Journalist Is Visiting Peking
description: A Soviet political commentator is visiting Peking, and foreign diplomats here say he may be involved in an effort to evaluate the recent trip to China of Secretary of State George P. Shultz and sound out Chinese intentions for the next round of Chinese-Soviet talks scheduled for early March in Moscow.

title: Spivey a Candidate
description: Bill Spivey, a 7-footer who led the University of Kentucky to a national basketball championship in 1951 before he was accused of taking money to hold down scores, is running for the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Governor of Kentucky.

title: FINNIGAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including gains of $2,706,000 for the qr and $3,113,000 for the yr from discontinued operations...C-Net loss including a gain of $190,000 from discontinued operations...D-Including a gain of $541,000 from discontinued operations

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 18, 1983
description: International Awacs planes were sent to Egypt because of concern over possible Libyan military strikes against the Sudan, according to Administration officials. They said they expected the four surveillance planes to remain in Egypt only a few days unless Libya launched an attack. (Page A1, Column 4.) Israeli-supplied Lebanese militias set up three new garrisons in southern Lebanon this week, and they say they control the entire area 28 miles north of the Israeli border. The advances have aroused the concern of Lebanon's Government, whose sovereignty is limited to the Beirut area. (A7:1-3.)

title: Economic Scene; Will Volcker Keep His Post?
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN, in his news conference this week, expressed his confidence in Anne M. Gorsuch's management of the Environmental Protection Agency, which he said had compiled a splendid record that had been overlooked amid a ''flurry of accusations.'' And he defended his nomination of Kenneth Adelman as head of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, saying that ''the young man'' was very intelligent and had had ''experience with Jeane Kirkpatrick at the United Nations and all.''

title: MEETING ON CITY'S BUDGET BECOMES DEBATE OVER GOVERNOR'S BUDGET
description: What was scheduled as a routine meeting yesterday to approve New York City's preliminary budget turned into a dispute between Governor Cuomo and State Comptroller Edward V. Regan over the health of the state's budget.

title: RODDAM'S 'LORDS OF DISCIPLINE'
description: FRANC RODDAM'S crisp, suspenseful ''The Lords of Discipline'' gives an old-fashioned tale of military-school life some brutal new twists. The customs at Carolina Military Academy, where Pat Conroy's novel (which has been adapted by Thomas Pope and Lloyd Fonvielle) was set, involve a lot more sadism than it takes to build character. The film details the viciousness with which new cadets are hazed and the particular savagery of their racism, all the while telling of how one upperclassman discovers his own courage and rises above all this ugliness. It's a well-crafted story told in extremely nasty terms.

title: 'STING II'
description: A STING: that's a trick, a swindle, a con. ''The Sting II'' sounds as if it ought to be one, what with Mac Davis and Jackie Gleason in the Robert Redford and Paul Newman roles. However, the casting of these two accomplishes at least one thing for the sequel: it lowers the audience's expectations that this will be anything on a par with the original. So on that basis, and on that basis alone, ''The Sting II'' is better than might have been anticipated.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption Tuesday incorrectly identified a Vietnam veteran's friend who died in the war.

title: 11 States Work on Plan For Radioactive Waste
description: A committee of the Coalition of Northeastern Governors gathered here today to try to agree on legislation to provide for a regional solution to disposing of low-level radioactive waste.

title: OFFICER INDICTED IN MIAMI SHOOTING
description: For the third time in three months, a Miami police officer has been indicted in the fatal shooting of a black. A Dade County grand jury last night returned a manslaughter charge against Officer Luis Alvarez, a two-year veteran of the force, whose Dec. 28 shooting of Nevell Johnson Jr., 21 years old, brought on nearly two days of sporadic violence in the city's Overtown section.

title: Bank Board Nomination
description: President Reagan announced yesterday that he would nominate Edwin J. Gray, senior vice president of the Great American Federal Savings and Loan Association of San Diego, to be a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, the chief regulatory agency for the savings and loan business. Willilam B. O'Connell, president of the United States League of Savings Institutions called Mr. Gray ''extremely well equipped for the job.''

title: SCOT LAD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: B-After tax credits of $66,000 for the qr and $104,000 for the 9 mos

title: HADDAD MILITIA CLAIMS A SWATH OF SOUTH LEBANON
description: Israeli-supplied Lebanese militiamen have set up three new garrisons in southern Lebanon this week and have announced that they now control the entire area 28 miles north of the Israeli border. The move has aroused concern in the Lebanese Government, whose sovereignty is currently limited to the Beirut area.

title: LOWENSTEIN, M, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The yr-earlier qr results include gain of $492,000 from a lower 1981 effective tax rate than estimates used in the first three qtrs and the adoption in this qrof LIFO and the F.A.S.B. rules for foreign currency translations; the 1981 yr results are after a net reduction of $1,498,000 from the adoption of LIFO and F.A.S.B. rules for foreign currency translations

title: GREGORY HARRISON IN 'THE FIGHTER'
description: GREGORY HARRISON, star of the series ''Trapper John, M.D.,'' occasionally ventures out into a television movie. Last time, it was ''For Ladies Only,'' in which he played a male stripper in a nightclub that caters to cheering and whistling female customers. Now, tomorrow night at 9 on CBS-TV, Mr. Harrison is going the wellworn route of the struggling boxer in a film titled, directly enough, ''The Fighter.'' As usual with this intense actor, he ends up being more impressive than might be anticipated of a poster-pinup figure.

title: BILL TO FORCE LAWYERS TO TELL OF CLIENTS' FRAUD INTRODUCED
description: Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, has proposed legislation to make it a Federal crime for a lawyer to fail to tell the Federal authorities about crimes or frauds in which his services have been used.

title: FOR THE CHIEF OF PROTOCOL, 'CHARMED' AND BUSY LIFE
description: There will be five official representatives of the United States Government accompanying Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip on their nine-day visit to the West Coast, which begins tomorrow. In the party will be Michael K. Deaver, the deputy chief of staff, and his wife, Carolyn; John J. Louis Jr., the United States Ambassador to the Court of St. James's, and his wife, Josephine, and a meticulously groomed woman whose job it is to make sure that all the diplomatic niceties are unobtrusively observed. The woman's name is Selwa Roosevelt and the sign over the door of her office at the State Department reads ''Chief of Protocol.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * Grumman Aerospace Corp. said it had been awarded $185 million in Navy contracts for F-14 fighter planes and A-6E light bombers.

title: Golf Alternative
description: For the affluent, the important and the influential, few things are more exciting than playing with superstar golfers in a pro-amateur golf tournament. But what of the poor souls who don't play golf?

title: INTERCONTINENTAL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TV 'DISH' MAKERS FIGHT THEIR OWN 'STAR WARS'
description: Their critics call them pirates and want to wipe them out, but the people who make those backyard satellite antennas that pluck television programs out of the air are moving uptown. They are donning three-piece suits, forming their own political action committee and gearing up to match Jack Valenti, Hollywood and Home Box Office, lobbyist for lobbyist, to preserve their gains.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Down-to-Earth Advice From an Astronaut A lbert Thompson Jr., aged 8, took an astronaut to school yesterday. Maj. Charles F. Bolden Jr. visited the St. Ignatius school, on East 84th Street. Then he went to Harlem to the St. Charles school, on West 143d Street and Intermediate School 136, on West 136th.

title: MARTIN PLANS SWITCHES
description: Across the tops of the lockers at the far end of the Yankees' clubhouse, nine names were crammed into a space made for six. Thus, not all of the taped names and numbers were visible: ''Lombardi 61 Espino 65 Hernaiz 81 Wehrmeister Nixon 39 Winters 7 Dayett 60ontenotHoll.'' The ''F'' in Fontenot was covered over by Dayett's number, and the rest of Holland's name and his number were somewhere around the corner of the last locker.

title: BRIEFING
description: By Their Colors ...

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Upward Mobility

title: Profits Scoreboard
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss)* Loss in year earlier quarter.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 18, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Outer Space Scientific and Techni- cal subcommittee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: VIOLENCE SEEMS TO GROW IN INDIA'S TROUBLED STATE
description: Violence appeared to be spreading rapidly today in the countryside of Assam, this northeastern state where elections now under way have been marred by ethnic and religious fighting.

title: HOWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
OF WATER WARS, TAX CUTBACKS, FORECLOSURES AND THE PROBLEM OF BALMY WEATHER
description: It is water, or more precisely, the lack of it, that is at the heart of most matters in the arid states west of the 100th meridian.

title: Executive Shifts Are Set for Alcoa
description: After eight years as chairman and chief executive of the Aluminum Company of America, W. H. Krome George will step down March 31, four days after his 65th birthday, thus ending a 41-year career with the world's largest aluminum producer.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Moynihan Won't March

title: More Funds Asked For Waste Cases
description: Connecticut's chief prosecutor urged today that the legislature put more money into prosecuting hazardous-waste cases than Gov. William A. O'Neill proposed.

title: In the Village, Creole charm.
description: OPENED almost exactly one year ago, Texarkana, the stylish Cajun-Louisiana restaurant on 10th Street in Greenwich Village, has already become something of an institution. Regulars know they must wait until 9 or 9:30 if they want meaty, flavorful suckling pig that turns on a spit in the big open fireplace, and a young-spirited, attractively costumed crowd gathers every night at the handsome wood bar that was crafted by George Nakashima. And whether dressed in expensive, fashionable sweaters or in more gussied-up supper-club outfits, regulars have in common a taste for high-style Gulf Coast specialties prepared under the direction of Abe de la Houssaye, who oversees the kitchen at Texarkana, just as he does at his East Side restaurant, La Louisiana. A Cajun by birth, he has given chic and innovative touches to his native fare, occasionally with a loss of character, but generally with delicious results.

title: LEAGUE SENDS CUOMO DATA IT CHALLENGED
description: The League of New York Theaters and Producers has sent Governor Cuomo a two-page letter asking him to reconsider his proposed 8.25 percent state tax on theater tickets.

title: Bailing Out the World
description: Though it saw no great problem only months ago, the Reagan Administration now urges Congress quickly to authorize a large increase in America's subscription to the International Monetary Fund. This change of heart has led to accusations that the measure is just a bailout for big banks that lent recklessly.

title: MORTGAGE GROWTH INVESTORS reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
description: B-Includes gains from sale of real estate of $364,000 for latest yr and $1,773,000 for 1981

title: Ham of Steelers Retires
description: Jack Ham, the outside linebacker who helped the Pittsburgh Steelers win four Super Bowls and who was selected to the all-pro team nine times, announced his retirement yesterday. ''Twelve years is a long time to play pro football,'' said Ham.

title: NATIONAL CAN CORP reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
Elsa Thompson, Made Radio Documentaries
description: Elsa Knight Thompson, a pioneer of radio news documentaries, died Saturday at Merritt Hospital in Oakland. She was 76 years old.

title: REAGAN ASSERTING CLAIM OF PRIVILEGE ON FILES OF E.P.A.
description: The White House said today that President Reagan was still pressing the claim of executive privilege that led to his battle with the House of Representatives over Environmental Protection Agency documents.

title: STAGE: 'DIFFERENT MOON' IS ABOUT WOMEN ALONE
description: THE setting of Ara Watson's ''A Different Moon,'' at the WPA Theater, is a drab household in a sleepy, sullen Arkansas town of 1951. It's a place that might seem entirely dead were it not for the presence of the play's one male character, Tyler Biars.

title: Connors Moves To Quarterfinals
description: Top-seeded Jimmy Connors defeated Raul Ramirez of Mexico, 6-3, 6-3, tonight to advance to the quarterfinals of the $315,000 United States National Indoor tennis championships.

title: BAYLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 22
ADDENDA TO THE INQUIRY OF THE BEIRUT MASSACRE
description: To the Editor:

title: German Prices Stable
description: Producer prices in Germany were unchanged in January after a decline of two-tenths of 1 percent in December, the Federal Statistics Office said today. The index, based on prices in 1976, remained at 134.5 in January, up 2.3 percent from a year earlier.

title: TORO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WOMETCO ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results for 1982 include gains of $952,000 and $175,000 from the sale of real estate while the yr-ago results include a gain of $776,000 for the qr and $2,956,000 for the yr

title: 2,000 Israelis Mourn A Slain Demonstrator
description: More than 2,000 anti-Government demonstrators gathered today in front of Prime Minister Menachem Begin's office today to mark the end of the seven-day mourning period for the protester killed in a grenade attack here last week. There was a heavy police presence.

title: BOLD STEPS ARE WEIGHED TO MEET DROP IN PRIESTS
description: Forecasts of a continuing sharp drop in the number of priests in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York over the next 20 years have prompted a candid discussion among church leaders that they say could bring about striking changes in the life of the ordinary parish.

title: Sentence Modified
description: Mike Strachan, the former New Orleans Saints running back who had been sentenced to a minimum of 22 months in prison for selling cocaine to his teammates, won a sentence modification that could free him on parole in as little as a year. But the Federal judge who ordered the modifcation, turned down Strachan's plea for immediate release on the ground that his imprisonment was a hardship to his family.

title: Bank Agrees to Access In Time-Deposit Plan
description: The Metropolitan Savings Bank has agreed to give 200 depositors access without penalty to money in time deposits that had been denied to them since the bank acquired the Greenwich Savings Bank in the fall of 1981.

title: POLAROID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PUBLISHING: CENSORSHIP CAN TAKE INDIRECT FORMS
description: ON April 1, 1950, Macmillan published Immanuel Velikovsky's ''Worlds in Collision,'' a book that attempted to explain the origins of the universe by references to the Old Testament, world literature and ancient mythology. Widely condemned by the scientific community, the book nevertheless soared onto The New York Times best-seller list, where it remained for 31 weeks. Yet two months after publication, at the height of its popularity, Macmillan literally gave the lucrative Velikovsky title to Doubleday without cost and dismissed the editor who had signed up the book. Moreover, Gordon A. Atwater, who wrote an article praising the author's approach, even while disagreeing with many of his conclusions, was summarily dismissed as chairman of the astronomy department of the American Museum of Natural History and as curator of the Hayden Planetarium.

title: HANDY & HARMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including net income of $1,181,000 or 8 cents a shr from the reduction in quantities of silver inventories valued under the LIFO method and net income of $510,000 or 4 cents a shr, related to LIFO accounting for gold inventories

title: BIW CABLE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ROBERT GARVEY
description: Robert Garvey, author of ''Good Shabbos, Everybody!'' and other children's books on Jewish themes, died Wednesday at Metropolitan Hospital following a heart attack.

title: STATE SEEKS CURB ON DOCTORS' BUYING OF EQUIPMENT
description: The New York State Health Commissioner said yesterday that he would ask the Legislature to make it more difficult for doctors in private practice to acquire expensive new medical equipment.

title: Sweetening the Pot
description: Jerry Tarkanian, the basketball coach at The University of Nevada-Las Vegas, saw his team receive a boost to the No. 1 ranking in a wire-service poll this week. But it may be nothing compared with the lift the school's booster club has given him in the last three years.

title: OPERA: MET 'BALLO' WITH NEW VOICES
description: THE Metropolitan Opera's current production of Verdi's ''Un Ballo in Maschera'' is built on the compellingly lyrical singing of Carlo Bergonzi, the sprightly charm of Roberta Peters, and the forthright conducting of Anton Guadagno.

title: Mailers and Times Reach Agreement
description: Mailers Local No. 6 and The New York Times reached agreement yesterday on a three-year contract extension providing $110 a week in wage increases and an additional pay incentive for early acceptance of the offer made by The Times, according to George McDonald, the president of the union.

title: Unusual Kidnapping
description: IT would be difficult to describe Martin Scorsese's fine new film, ''The King of Comedy,'' as an absolute joy. It's very funny, and it ends on a high note that was, for me, both a total surprise and completely satisfying. Yet it's also bristly, sometimes manic to the edge of lunacy and, along the way, terrifying. It's not an absolute joy by a long shot but, in the way of a film that uses all of its talents to their fullest, it's exhilarating.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ONE MAN'S MEDICINE. By Morris Gib- son, M.D. Foreword by James Herriott. 218 pages. Beaufort Books. $12.95.

title: Sharing Profits
description: Bobby Joe Young, a world-ranking welterweight boxer from Steubenville, Ohio, still carries a union card from Local 1190 of the United Steelworkers. And he has not forgotten his former co-workers around the blast furnaces.

title: GRAPHIC SCANNING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Friday; DEBUT FOR FRIEL PLAY
description: ''Living Quarters'' by Brian Friel, the Irish writer whose plays include ''Philadelphia, Here I Come,'' makes its American debut at the Vineyard Theater, 309 East 26th Street, starting with previews tonight at 8. In this work, a general returning home as a hero learns that his young wife has had an affair with his son by an earlier marriage. The consequences are shattering -but the family gets a chance to relive the preceding events in hope of bringing about a different ending. The director is Susan Einhorn. Tickets are $8 ($7 for students and over-65's). Reservations: 683-0696. TAP THEATER IN CHELSEA

title: TRANSAMERICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including extraordinary income of $1,204,000 for the qr and $5,454,000 for the yr...C-After an extraordinary loss of $94,000...D-Including a gain of $140 million on the sale of an entertainement subsidiary, a loss of $121,871,000 on the planned sales of certain bonds, a loss of $18,129,000 from discontinued operations and an extraordinary gain of $2,634,000

title: Explosion Rocks Offices Of Aeroflot in Capital
description: Several blocks in downtown Washington were closed off tonight after an explosion outside the building housing offices of Aeroflot, the Soviet airline. There was no report of injuries or serious damage to the building in northwest Washington.

title: CARTWRIGHT GETS 25 AS KNICKS WIN
description: Bill Cartwright, Len (Truck) Robinson and Paul Westphal flourished for the Knicks in the 14-game absence of Bernard King. Last night they flourished in King's return as they paced the Knicks to a 108-92 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers at Madison Square Garden.

title: Matsushita's Harvard Gift
description: A Japanese industrialist has donated $1 million to the Harvard Business School to fund a professor of leadership, aimed at distinguishing between managers who ''act to limit choices'' and leaders who ''develop fresh approaches.''

title: Gain by Losing Mr. Adelman
description: With a stubbornness that often serves him well, President Reagan bids the Senate to suppress its misgivings and confirm Kenneth Adelman as head of the arms control agency. With apparent innocence the President declines the invitation to reconsider, which came when the Foreign Relations Committee delayed rejection of the nominee:

title: HART ENTERS PRESIDENTIAL RACE, STRESSING NEW IDEAS
description: Senator Gary Hart of Colorado today announced his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination, saying he represented a new political generation that sought to ''break the deadlock of old systems and old doctrines.''

title: Bomb Blast in Scotland
description: A letter bomb went off in Glasgow civic offices today and an extreme nationalist group said it was a protest against a visit by the Princess of Wales, the police said. The device caught fire when it was opened by a secretary at Glasgow Council chambers, but it was quickly extinguished and no one was hurt.

title: No More Tennis
description: When Alicia O'Connell was growing up in Brooklyn, she learned to play tennis at age 9 or 10 and started playing at the Heights Casino when she was 12. When the tennis courts there became crowded, she decided to try the empty squash racquets courts.

title: ICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RESEARCH-COTTRELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Includes an after-tax gain of $1,462,000 from the sale of the company's remaining interest in Biphase, a joint venture with Transamerica Delaval...C-Includesan after-tax gain of $778,000 from the sale of the company's interest in Altran, a technological venture in energy loan management

title: DEUKMEJIAN SIGNS BILL TO EASE CALIFORNIA $1.5 BILLION DEFICIT
description: Gov. George Deukmejian signed a compromise bill to ease California's $1.5 billion deficit today, saying he was sure ''it is not going to be necessary to raise taxes.'' But the state's top finance officials said the action came too late to avoid issuing i.o.u.'s next week for the first time since the Depression.

title: Labor Relations Chief Appointed by Cuomo
description: Thomas Hartnett was today appointed the state's chief labor negotiator by Governor Cuomo. Mr. Cuomo announced Mr. Hartnett would become director of the State Office of Employee Relations. Mr. Hartnett, 37 years old, has been deputy director of contract negotiations and administration in the office since 1979.

title: William T. Sweigert; A U.S. Judge Since '59
description: Federal District Judge William T. Sweigert, who ruled the Vietnam War unconstitutional in 1970, died Wednesday at his home after a short illness. Judge Sweigert, who was partly retired, was 82 years old.

title: EQUITABLE LIFE TO BUILD 7TH AVE. TOWER
description: The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States announced yesterday that it would build a 54-story skyscraper on Seventh Avenue between 51st and 52d Streets. It will be the company's headquarters when it is finished, in 1985.

title: Required Reading; An Overreaction?
description: Representative Thomas N. Kindness, Republican of Ohio, in a press release dated Jan. 24, 1983: On Oct. 21, 1981, during House consideration of a four-year farm bill, an amendment was approved to empower fraud investigators in the Agriculture Department inspector general's office to carry firearms and issue arrest warrants for food stamp law violations. At the time I told my colleagues: ''If this amendment is adopted, then other departments are going to be in here and we are going to have all the inspector general personnel in all the departments running around with shoulder holsters while green eyeshades might be more appropriate.''

title: Judge to Evaluate Owners of Bulls
description: A Federal judge on Wednesday ordered Arthur Wirtz, the principal owner of the Chicago Bulls, his son and the team's two co-owners to prepare statements of their net worth in preparation for a hearing next week.

title: TELECONCEPTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split effective Jan 14

title: Retired People's Group Rejects Moynihan Plea
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan cautioned the nation's largest group of retired people today that its opposition to the Social Security rescue plan could hamper efforts to repair the system.

title: US HEALTH CARE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings reflect the effect of a 2-for-1 stock split paid in Mar 1982 the 50 percent common stock divd declared in Dec 1982, and the exchange of 400,000 shrs of preferred stock on a 1-for-3 basis for common shrs on Feb 9, 1983 which isterated by the company as having taken place in 1982

title: ADDENDA TO THE INQUIRY OF THE BEIRUT MASSACRE
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 ISRAELI SOLDIERS GUILTY IN HEBRON HARASSMENT
description: A military tribunal said today that the former military commander of the occupied West Bank had issued illegal orders to harass Arabs in the Hebron area last spring.

title: OXOCO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $385,000; sales include gains on the sale of interest in oil and gas properties of $3,318,000 for the latest fourth qr and $4,844,000 for the yr-ago fourth qr

title: ROLE FOR THE U.A.W. LEFT IN DOUBT
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Corporation have apparently decided to bypass the United Automobile Workers in hiring workers when the two companies begin joint production of cars at a G.M. plant here in 1984.

title: XONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary loss of $263,000; the yr-ago results are restated to include the results of Radiograhic Development Corp which was acquired in May 1982 and Diagnostic Information Inc which was acquired in Aug 1982; the shrs outstndg figures for the latest qr and 9 mos reflect the Feb 1982 issuance of 4,900,000 common shrs to cover the conversion of preferred stock series B, C, and D.; the figures also reflect the issuance of 2,200,000 common shrs for acquisitions

title: Queen Bids Farewell To the Cayman Isles
description: Queen Elizabeth II left the tranquillity of the Cayman Islands today for the hustle and bustle of Acapulco, Mexico, concluding the Caribbean leg of her winter tour with a speech to the 15-member assembly of this tiny British colony.

title: AN ASPREY'S IN NEW YORK
description: Asprey & Company, purveyors of such items as 18-karat gold beard combs, mother-of-pearl caviar spreaders and handmade leather cases for polo boots, will bring such necessities, and many more, from London to its new shop that opened Monday in Trump Tower.

title: CORROON & BLACK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for a pooling of interests

title: IN AMMAN, 3 VIEWS OF HUSSEIN'S OPTIONS
description: In the Kingdom of Jordan, men have to be persuaded that powers from afar and other Arabs and Palestinians asking them to take on the burden of Palestine are not inviting them to participate in their own ruin.

title: GROMYKO ATTACKS AMERICAN POLICIES
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko attacked American arms control proposals today and accused the United States of ''imperial ambitions'' and favoring ''international brigandage.''

title: PHIBRO-SALOMON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest qr include an after-tax charge of $30,000,000, half of which relates to a nonrecurring writeoff of a 30 percent interest in a New Mexicocopper property

title: HALEY INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TELETEXT IS READY FOR DEBUT
description: After several years of experimentation, a number of major broadcasters and publishers are gearing up to offer a new electronic information service known as teletext.

title: A 'Die-In' Held in Geneva
description: Antinuclear demonstrators splashed with their own blood staged a symbolic ''die-in'' in front of the Soviet Mission today to protest the nuclear arms race. Five of the 15 protesters laid down in front of the mission gate, the blood falling on their faces and clothes through tubes attached to plastic hospital blood bags. The blood was collected Wednesday night by a medical student in the group.

title: NEW YORK'S BUS DRIVERS TAUGHT TO GRIN AND BEAR IT
description: Some people waiting for buses will swear drivers aim for the slush puddles as they pull into a stop. Or that they like to close doors on old people trying to catch a bus. Or prefer to keep their bus's destination a secret from people seeking directions.

title: MEI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a gain from disposal of discontinued operations of $593,000 for the qr and yr; the latest yr net includes $335,000 reductions of income tax reserve; the 1981 yr net from continuing operations includes a gain of $553,000 from sale of nonoperating assets

title: OF ROE VS. WADE AND THE LINE BETWEEN JUSTICE AND LIBERTY
description: To the Editor:

title: EFFECTIVE TAX PLANNING: KEEP RECORDS CURRENT
description: In terms of long-range financial thinking, filing a tax return may be far less significant than the tax planning that should go on at the same time. ''Tax returns should be a simple mechanical function if the taxpayer has been keeping the right records throughout the year,'' said Herbert Paul, who recently left Touche Ross & Company, the accounting firm, to found his own tax law firm.

title: Ruling Favoring I.B.M. Is Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld a ruling that the International Business Machines Corporation did not violate antitrust law, as the Transamerica Corporation had contended in a lawsuit.

title: WHITE CONSOLIDATED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The shr earnings are fully diluted

title: NATION MAGAZINE LOSES SUIT ON FORD'S MEMOIRS
description: The Nation magazine violated Federal copyright laws by printing un-@authorized excerpts from the memoirs of President Gerald R. Ford before they were officially published, a Federal judge ruled yesterday.

title: Surprises and luck tell story of 'Betrayal.'
description: THERE are no producers like Sam Spiegel any more. And there never were many. Alexander Korda and Gabriel Pascal, two who might have been mentioned in the same breath with him, are gone now, but Mr. Spiegel, who will be 80 years old next November, is still working, and ''Betrayal,'' his latest effort, opens Sunday at Cinema II.

title: SWIFT INDEPENDENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: B-Includes a nonrecurring gain of $1,344,000 from the sale of a broiler business

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL AFFILIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $239,700 for the qr and $471,000 for the 6mos

title: SANDERS ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
WALBRO CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
PLANT USE REVERSES LONG SLIDE
description: Factory use in the United States rose last month for the first time in nearly a year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: S.E.C. Settles Auditing Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today accused a California accountant of numerous deficiencies in reporting on the financial condition of Olympic Gas and Oil Inc., a Dallasbased energy company.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: COLLEEN DEWHURST couldn't make the party given the other night to m ark the Circle in the Square's 10th anniversary as a Broadway t heater.''She's snowed in up in Syracuse,'' said Theodore Mann, a rtistic director of the theater.

title: Chaffee Cards 65, Leads by a Stroke
description: Jon Chaffee, faced with the possibility of losing a spot on the PGA Tour, shot a seven-under-par 65 today for a one-stroke lead after the opening round of the Isuzu-Andy Williams San Diego Open.

title: BTK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
CONFERENCE IS AWAITED ON U.S.-PALAU ISLANDS LINK
description: How to get around the mixed outcome of a recent plebiscite in the Palau Islands of the Western Pacific is to be taken up shortly at a conference of island leaders with United States officials.

title: SEA GALLEY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a charge of $432,000 from an accounting change...C-Net income

title: MILTON ROY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The shr earnings figures reflect a 3-for-2 stock split payable Mar 18; the latest yr earnings were lowered by 15 cents a shr as a result of a nonrecurring losson the sale of a unit

title: TECHNOLOGY ISSUES GAIN
description: With technology issues posting some of the best gains in a day of slower trading, the stock market closed yesterday with few major price changes.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: At One Street Corner, Issue Is 'Life and Death

title: SCORSESE'S 'KING OF COMEDY'
description: IT would be difficult to describe Martin Scorsese's fine new film, ''The King of Comedy,'' as an absolute joy. It's very funny, and it ends on a high note that was, for me, both a total surprise and completely satisfying. Yet it's also bristly, sometimes manic to the edge of lunacy and, along the way, terrifying. It's not an absolute joy by a long shot but, in the way of a film that uses all of its talents to their fullest, it's exhilarating.

title: ALBERTA ENERGY CO LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $21 million on oil sands agreement...C-Aft er a writedown of $12.7 million of the Petalta project

title: TIE COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Nuggets Recover To Top Nets, 117-108
description: The erratic Denver Nuggets, the National Basketball Association's most potent offensive team with a 122-point scoring average, recovered from an uncharacteristic slump in the first period to surge to a 117-108 victory over the Nets tonight at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: WESTERN CARROTS WASTED ON MOSCOW
description: To the Editor:

title: FORD MOTOR CO OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SANITATIONMEN GET TENTATIVE ACCORD
description: The city and the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association announced a tentative agreement yesterday on a two-year contract that provides for a total pay increase of 16 percent and establishes a schedule for use of two-man crews on certain trucks.

title: KUWAIT'S MARKET BAILOUT
description: An eerie silence fills the empty lobby under a midtown parking garage. Here is where the Magnificent Nine once operated. They were the inner ring of billionaire dealers on Kuwait's notorious Souk al-Manakh - an unregulated stock market that collapsed last summer.

title: TO TAKE THE GUESSING OUT OF U.S. PUBLIC WORKS
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S.-Mexico Farm Accord
description: The United States Agriculture Secretary, John R. Block, signed a $1.7 billion agricultural loan package today intended to help recession-plagued Mexico buy American grains and other foodstuffs on easy terms. The agreement was negotiated in August, but was increased by $700 million last week.

title: ROUSE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Win Some, Lose Some
description: Hours before their salary dispute was to go before arbitration, the Cleveland Indians announced they had signed Rick Sutcliffe to a new contract. Sutcliffe, a right-hander, led the American League with a 2.96 earned run average last season and had a 14-8 record.

title: ESTERLINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Leave-Taking, Take 2

title: House Panel Votes to Expand Reagan's Jobless Relief Bill
description: In its first chance at President Reagan's $7.3 billion unemployment relief package, a Democraticcontrolled House subcommittee voted today to extend more unemployment benefits than the President requested.

title: African arts in Jamaica.
description: THE Jamaica Arts Center, at 161-04 Jamaica Avenue in Queens, is marking its 10th anniversary. Founded by the Greater Jamaica Development Corporation, the center is playing an increasing role in the development of a deprived area of southeast Queens. ''You name it, they don't have it,'' F. Carlisle Towery, executive director of the development corporation, said.

title: MGM Hotels
description: MGM Grand Hotels Inc. said it had agreed to sell its 14 1/2-acre Atlantic City property to Golden Nugget Inc., for $25 million.

title: MID-CONTINENT TELEPHONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Homeless Women Get New Shelter
description: The city opened a new shelter for homeless women last night in a state-owned armory on Lexington Avenue at 26th Street. Kathryn Ruby, a spokesman for the Human Resources Administration, said that the new facility would immediately house 50 women, but that the city had not determined its ultimate capacity.

title: MORE STRESS ON PAROLE ASKED TO EASE CROWDING AT PRISONS
description: A newly organized citizens' group said yesterday that prison overcrowding in New York State would be better solved by an emphasis on parole, probation and alternative punishments, such as required community service, than by building more cells.

title: HARWOOD COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $180,000 for the qr and $288,000 for the yr...C-Net loss after an extraordinary loss of $59,000...D-Including an extraordinary credit of $35,000

title: Bridge: Messages to Yourself Cost More Than They're Worth
description: Trying to telephone oneself is not a productive undertaking, but it does not add to the phone bill. However, the bridge player who sends a message to himself may have to pay a heavy price. West did just this on the diagramed deal and has been regretting it ever since. It was played at the Mayfair Club, in the Gramercy Park Hotel at 2 Lexington Avenue, and was noted by Al Roth, who owns and manages the club.

title: SCREEN: SCORSESE'S 'KING OF COMEDY'
description: IT would be difficult to describe Martin Scorsese's fine new film, ''The King of Comedy,'' as an absolute joy. It's very funny, and it ends on a high note that was, for me, both a total surprise and completely satisfying. Yet it's also bristly, sometimes manic to the edge of lunacy and, along the way, terrifying. It's not an absolute joy by a long shot but, in the way of a film that uses all of its talents to their fullest, it's exhilarating.

title: Slalom to Shaw; Phil Mahre Is 2d
description: Tiger Shaw held off Phil Mahre on the second run to win the giant slalom today in the United States Alpine ski championships.

title: OWNER DARES UNION TO STRIKE
description: Sam Schulman, the owner of the Seattle SuperSonics, said yesterday that he would relish a strike by the National Basketball Players Association because it ''would enable us to return to normalcy.''

title: EL SALVADOR AIRLIFTS MORE SOLDIERS TO CITY UNDER SIEGE BY GUERRILLAS
description: The Government rushed reinforcements today to Suchitoto, under guerrilla siege for a week, in an effort to prevent rebels from capturing the northeastern city.

title: IRAN SAYS IRAQ STILL HOLDS LAND
description: Iraq is holding 350 square miles of Iranian territory despite Baghdad's assertion that all Iraqi troops have left Iranian land, the Iranian press agency said today.

title: NORTHWEST AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes pretax gains of $6,865,000 for the qr and $12,425,000 for the yr from the disposal of property...C-Include s pretax gains of $2,975,000 for the qr and $16,975,000 for the yr from the disposal of property

title: Trainers Testify In Race-Fix Case
description: The trainers of three horses testified today that they had noticed symptoms that led them to believe their horses had been tranquilized before some races in 1978 at Yonkers and Roosevelt raceways.

title: No Headline
description: Missouri Defeats Kansas by 74-69

title: JOSLYN MANUFACTURING & SUPPLY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ART GIVEN A ROLE IN TINA HOWE'S PLAY
description: ''Every time I stepped out of the house,'' Tina Howe said the other day, ''the Metropolitan Museum was the first thing I saw. From the time I could walk, it was a refuge. I remember my brother and I toddling in to see the armor and the van Goghs, and all the Roman dead people in the tubs.''

title: ESQUIRE RADIO & ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DRIVERS CHARGED IN A FATAL CRASH
description: The drivers of a Greyhound bus and a tractor-trailer that crashed on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway last month killing three people have both been charged with reckless driving, the state police said yesterday.

title: F.A.A. FINES QUEENS AIRLINE AND OUSTS CHIEF
description: The Federal Aviation Administration collected a $50,000 fine yesterday from Guy-America Airways and forced the resignation of the airline's president for what it called violations of safety rules in jet service to Guyana and the Caribbean Island of St. Maarten.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption with a photograph of Pete Peeters, the Boston Bruin goaltender, in some copies yesterday incorrectly identified the player who scored against him in the first period Wednesday night. He was Gilbert Perreault.

title: 'STATE OF THINGS'
description: WIM WENDERS'S ''State of Things,'' which was named the best film at last year's Venice Film Festival, is a movie with a very romantic, very European sensibility, not about life, but about films and the people who make them. I feel that I must choose my words carefully here because, although it left me absolutely cold - frigid, really - I know it's the kind of work that will be infinitely fascinating to film aficionados whose priorities I do not share.

title: UNITED MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Proposal On Dome Debt
description: A syndicate led by Citibank has put together a counterproposal for a package to refinance Dome Petroleum Ltd.'s debt, banking sources said.

title: Chief Financial Officer Is Appointed at Chase
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that it had named Anthony P. Terracciano as chief financial officer to succeed William S. Ogden, who has announced plans to resign.

title: SCHOOLS USING 'ROBOTS' AGAINST ABSENTEEISM
description: The parents of many pupils who skip school without permission here, in New York and in California no longer get the news from a visit by a truant officer but by a call from a ''robot.''

title: SECURITIES OPERATIONS LIFT PHIBRO-SALOMON 21%
description: Phibro-Salomon Inc. reported yesterday that strong gains by its securities operations lifted earnings in the fourth quarter of 1982 by 21 percent while revenues advanced 27 percent.

title: Vandals With Snowplow Create Havoc at Airport
description: Vandals took a snowplow and turned a small private airport into an airplane junkyard today, causing more than $500,000 damage, the authorities said.

title: SUPERIOR ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOOVER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOTEL COULD BE HELD LIABLE FOR THEFT LOSSES, COURT SAYS
description: The Court of Appeals ruled today that a luxury hotel in Manhattan might be liable for millions of dollars in losses to guests in a 1979 robbery despite a state law limiting the hotel's liability to $500 a guest.

title: G.M.-TOYOTA ACCORD NOT SEEN AS TREND
description: Joint ventures involving American and Japanese companies are not new, but a couple of new twists are seen in the agreement reached this week by the General Motors Corporation and the Toyota Motor Corporation.

title: Jersey Lobbyists Spent $3.4 Million
description: Reports filed with the state show lobbyists spent $3.4 million last year to influence the Legislature.

title: NORTHGATE EXPLORATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ALMOST 25% OF HOMICIDES IN CITY IN '81 TIED TO DRUGS
description: A new Police Department study released yesterday shows that nearly a fourth of the record 1,832 homicides recorded in 1981 were drugrelated.

title: VENTREX LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EX-OFFICER IS CHARGED A 2D TIME FOR MURDER
description: A former policeman who killed his first wife but was acquitted by reason of insanity today faced charges that he shot his second wife to death.

title: NEW YORK IS A GALLERY OF THE BEST BY LIVING ARTISTS
description: THE glamorous street prosaically known as 57th is the city's main drag for art. From the Avenue of the Americas to Park Avenue, more galleries line 57th Street and its bordering areas than can be found in the rest of the United States. And the big new buildings going up in the neighborhood are bound to increase the audience for them. The atmosphere is tonier and more formal than in SoHo, and the gallery space is less expansive, but the outlook is international, and the art shown along this crosstown boulevard is some of the world's very best.

title: SOVIET DESERTERS, ON TV, SAY THEY JOINED AFGHAN REBELS
description: Six men described as Soviet deserters from their military units in Afghanistan said in a television interview last night that they were disillusioned with the Soviet military intervention.

title: SOVIET CITY PUTS BREZHNEV ON THE MAP
description: The news that their city had been renamed came as a total surprise to the people here. Nadezhda S. Akepsimova, a Deputy Mayor, learned about it from the evening television news. Even Gennadi S. Bashtanyuk, a 33-year-old truck plant foreman who is a candidate member of the Communist Party's Central Commitee and was at the meeting in Moscow where the decision was taken, did not know in advance.

title: Transactions; BASEBALL
description: CHICAGO (AL) - Won an arbitration c ase brought by Tony Bernazard, second b aseman. CLEVELAND (AL) - Signed Rick Sut- c liffe, pitcher, to a 1983 contract. Won an a rbitration case brought by Len Barker, p itcher, who will be paid the team's salary o ffer of $475,000 for the 1983 season. KANSAS CITY (AL) - Granted Larry G ura, pitcher, a three-year contract ex- t ension. LOS ANGELES (NL) - Signed Rick R odas, pitcher, to a one-year contract. MINNEAPOLIS (AL) - Signed Lenny F aedo, shortstop, and Randy Bush, desig- n ated hitter, to one-year contracts. NEW YORK (NL) - Signed Tim Leary, D oug Sisk, Brent Gaff and Carlos Diaz, p itchers, and Rusty Tilldan, outfielder. SEATTLE (AL) - Sold Gary Gray, first b aseman, to the California Angels. TORONTO (AL) - Won an arbitration c ase brought by Roy Lee Jackson, pitcher, w ho reportedly had been seeking a one- y ear contract of $225,000.

title: Thrift Unit Gets New Capital
description: C.H. Butcher Jr. announced today that he had obtained a $20 million in capital to bolster his Southern Industrial Banking Corporation after $6 million was withdrawn in two days. Southern Industrial is a state-chartered savings and loan company; deposits are not insured.

title: Dissecting An Election
description: Mayor Tom Bradley of Los Angeles, who was defeated last year for governor of California, may be well out of a deficit problem so severe that officials say the state will have to meet some of its obligations with i.o.u.'s.

title: TELECO OILFIELD SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a tax benefit of $1,445,000 from the utilization of operating loss carryforwards

title: Driver Critically Injured
description: Bruce Jacobi was critically spectacular cart-wheeling crashes that marred the 125-mile qualifying races for the Daytona 500.

title: North Dakota Raid Fails to Find Suspect
description: A convoy of law-enforcement officers swooped into this prairie town of 1,200 people today, sealed off the highways and searched several houses in a futile attempt to capture an antitax militant accused of killing two United States marshals.

title: Interest Rates Fall Modestly; Pressure on Yields Is Seen
description: Short- and long-term interest rates declined modestly yesterday. All of the declines came in afternoon trading. Prices had been mostly lower and rates higher in quiet morning trading. But dealers said activity picked up after Martin S. Feldstein, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said that long-term bond yields could fall sharply when market participants see that progress is being made in reducing future budget deficits of the Federal Government.

title: Greyhound Corp.
description: The Greyhound Corporation's Armour Food subsidiary said it had agreed to sell three pork slaughterhouses - in Huron, S.D.; Worthington, Minn., and St. Joseph, Mo.

title: Money Fund Assets Drop
description: Assets of the money market funds dropped $2.6 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to $192.3 billion, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: LEASEWAY TRANSPORTATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KOCH APPOINTS SPINNATO CITY FIRE COMMISSIONER
description: Joseph E. Spinnato, temporary commissioner of the Fire Department since last October, was given a permanent appointment yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: THREE FILMS LEAD OSCAR RACE
description: A venerated Indian leader, a man pretending to be a woman, and a lonesome visitor from outer space have taken the lion's share of the 1982 Academy Award nominations. As expected, ''Gandhi'' (11 nominations), ''Tootsie'' (10 nominations) and ''E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial'' (nine nominations) will be competing for most of the major awards, including best picture, best director, cinematography, film editing and best original screenplay.

title: Landmarks Chief Stepping Down
description: Kent L. Barwick submitted his resignation yesterday as chairman of the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission to become president of the private Municipal Art Society. Mr. Barwick, who has been head of the commission since March 1978, expects to leave in late spring or early summer.

title: Texas Commerce Bank Fills Chairman's Post
description: Charles C. Beall, president of the Texas Commerce Bank in Houston, has been named the bank's chairman. The bank is the flagship of Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc., a fast-growing bank-holding company with assets of $18.2 billion and 59 banks in Texas and offices in Denver, New Orleans, New York and overseas.

title: Building Plans Set In New Brunswick
description: Plans to construct $90 million worth of new and renovated office space, retail stores and middle-income housing were announced today by officials of the New Brunswick Development Corporation.

title: FOR AMSTERDAM NEWS, WALKOUT ACCENTS WOES
description: The strike against The New York Amsterdam News, which began Feb. 1, comes against a setting of internal disputes among the owners of the black weekly and persistent financial problems that threaten its survival, according to interviews with current and former employees.

title: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA WATER CO reports earnings for Yr to Feb 1
TRY AN MZ MISSILE
description: There is a little-discusses reason why some people in the Administration, the Air Force and Congress continue to press for the MX missile: Our existing Minuteman missiles can't be launched quickly enough to escape a Soviet first strike.Unfortunately, neither can the proposed MX, which is why the many MX basing schemes have been dreamed up. If the problem of missile launching were discussed openly, it would be possible to dismiss costly MX or mobile-missile basing schemes as unnecessary, and build a cheaper, less ominous new weapon to modernize the United States missile force.

title: Sirens to Be Tested Near Indian Point
description: Residents of Westchester County will probably be hearing plenty of noise Saturday morning as 75 warning sirens around the Indian Point Unit 2 nuclear power plant will be tested.

title: Debt Issues
description: * The European Investment Bank is issuing 200 million marks of Eurobonds due in 1993 with 7 3/4 percent coupons, priced at par through Deutsche Bank A.G.

title: ODETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RANGERS A ROARING SUCCESS
description: T he noise was pure New York, like the roar of a subway train. It wasn't like a Montreal subway, with the hum of rubber wheels, or the space-age murmur of the Washington subway.

title: FORD HAD NARROWER 1982 LOSSES
description: The Ford Motor Company yesterday reported lower losses for the fourth quarter of 1982 and the full year partly because of lower operating costs and partly because of a more favorable method of reporting losses from foreign currency translations.

title: EX-F.B.I. AGENT LINKS TEAMSTERS' CHIEF TO CRIMES
description: A Government witness today linked Roy L. Williams, the teamsters' union president convicted of bribery conspiracy, with a series of extortions of union funds and with the shooting in 1959 of a union dissident in Kansas City.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Giorgio Chinaglia, the most prolific scorer in the North American Soccer League, has decided to forgo a business career for the present and play again for the Cosmos this season. ... The New Jersey Generals of the U.S.F.L. obtained a linebacker, Sammy Green, from the Tampa Bay Bandits for a draft choice. ... Jerry Rhome, the former offensive coordinator for the Seattle Seahawks, is the new quarterback coach for the Washington Redskins, replacing Dan Henning, the new head coach of the Atlanta Falcons.

title: HUDSON GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $226,000 for the qr and $200,000 for the 6 mos...C-Including income from discontinued operations of $585,000for the qr and $1,291,000 for the 6 mos

title: WASHINGTON CELEBRATED
description: An opportunity to celebrate the birthday of George Washington where George Washington celebrated his 51st birthday is being offered this weekend at Washington's headquarters in Newburgh, N.Y.

title: U.S. Indicates Fighting Over Namibia Is Easing
description: A State Department spokesman, responding to questions about the status of talks between Angola and South Africa, said today that no formal cease-fire had been worked out, but suggested there had been some reduction in the level of fighting in the region.

title: UNITED INDUSTRIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a nonrecurring gain of $494,000 or 10 cents a shr from the sale of investment less the writedown of the value of leveraged leases

title: DR. SUSAN A. DERI
description: Dr. Susan A. Deri, a New York psychoanalyst who taught at the Institute for Psychoanalytic Training and Research and the National Psychological Association for Psychoanalysis, died Wednesday at her home in Manhattan.

title: NEGOTIATOR SEES ACCORD NEAR IN DISPUTE OVER E.P.A. DATA
description: Deputy Attorney General Edward C. Schmults, the Reagan Administration's negotiator in the battle with Congress over access to documents on pending Environmental Protection Agency cases, said today that he believed an agreement was imminent.

title: Police in Central Park To Use Dogs on Patrol
description: Beginning this summer, police dogs will patrol Central Park as part of an experimental Police Department project, officials said yesterday.

title: ST. JOHN'S TRIUMPHS BY 98-78
description: St. John's recorded its highest score in more than four seasons last night for a 98-78 victory over Connecticut in a Big East Conference game before 6,177 fans at Alumni Hall.

title: MYERS, L E, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a gain of $427,000 from the sale of plant and equipment...C-Net loss

title: SHEPHERD PRODUCTS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a special gain of $121,171

title: LANGLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
N.L.R.B. Nominee Confirmed
description: Donald L. Dotson, Assistant Secretary of Labor for labor-management relations, was confirmed today for membership on the National Labor Relations Board by a voice vote of the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee. Before joining the Labor Department, Mr. Dotson, a Pennsylvanian nominated for the labor relations agency by President Reagan, was a labor counsel for several corporations and for the National Labor Relations Board.

title: INFOTRON SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
More Refiners Cut Price for Crude Oil
description: The downward pressure on oil prices intensified yesterday as six American refiners announced $1-a-barrel reductions in the price they will pay for crude oil. Also, the British Government confirmed that the British National Oil Corporation would announce a reduced price on its North Sea crude today. The move had been reported by industry sources.

title: FEDERAL OFFICIALS TO MONITOR MAYORAL VOTE IN CHICAGO TUESDAY
description: Scores of Federal officials will monitor voting in Chicago's mayoral primary Tuesday in an attempt to deter the widespread voting fraud that they say disrupted the November election.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 15. 1. Using a laser technique, the diamond has been inscribed on its girdle, or widest part, with letters and/or numerals that identify it.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Advanced Patent Technology Inc. said the William Morris Group will not purchase its Colorado Belle Casino in Laughlin, Nev.

title: F.B.I. to Study Bank Failure
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation will look into whether Jake Butcher's United American Bank of Knoxville committed any crimes by lending bank directors and relatives $54.8 million in 1982, a spokesman for the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: Under this heading, The Times amplifies articles or rectifies what the editors consider significant lapses of fairness, balance or perspective. Corrections, also on this page, continue to deal with factual errors.

title: TEACHING WON'T DO WITHOUT LESSON PLAN
description: To the Editor:

title: ACCORD IS REACHED FOR HOUSE ACCESS TO FILES OF E.P.A.
description: The Reagan Administration and a key House subcommittee chairman reached agreement tonight on procedures to allow subcommittee members to see subpoenaed Environmental Protection Agency documents.

title: DANCE: POOH KAYE OFFERS SOME 'ECCENTRIC MOTIONS'
description: They chewed on wood, threw bricks and showed speeded-up movies on Thursday at the Kitchen, in Pooh Kaye's ''Eccentric Motions.'' It was eccentric, all right, but it also was an evening of vivid theater.

title: O.A.U. Panel Suggests A Meeting in Ethiopia
description: A 12-nation panel recommended today that the Organization of African Unity move its 19th meeting of heads of government from Libya, where it collapsed twice last year, to the O.A.U.'s headquarters in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.

title: STATE LISTS 100 DUMP SITES FOR HAZARDOUS WASTE TESTS
description: The State Department of Environmental Conservation has released a list of a hundred known or suspected hazardouswaste disposal sites to be tested under a new Superfund program.

title: JARVIK EXPLAINS MOVIE ON U.S. JEWS' WARTIME ROLE
description: Near the end of Laurence Jarvik's documentary film ''Who Shall Live and Who Shall Die,'' to be broadcast for the first time on television on Channel 13 tonight, a witness to the events of World War II declares that American Jewry bears a heavy burden of guilt for failing to come to the aid the European victims of the Holocaust.

title: SOVIET ANNOUNCES OFFER ON TROOP CUTS
description: Soviet officials held a news conference here today to announce a proposal presented Thursday at the talks on limiting conventional forces in Central Europe.

title: Outcome of Palau Vote On Home Rule Barred
description: An Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of this Western Pacific territory has barred certification of the results of last week's voting on home rule until a lawsuit charging voting irregularities is heard.

title: GOLDEN GLOVES SHIFTS TALENT FROM THE RING TO THE SCREEN
description: The seats were blue and in the upper reaches of Madison Square Garden. Below, the figures in the ring looked more like dots painted on the canvas than boxers fighting for a title. But Mark Breland could still make out the Ali shuffle and the Frazier hook, and he said he knew then, even as a 7-year-old, that he belonged inside the ropes.

title: CORRECTION
description: Six words were omitted yesterday from a news analysis article on military spending. The second sentence of the third paragraph, referring to weapons and equipment, should have read, ''These purchases account for 34 percent of President Reagan's military budget request for the 1984 fiscal year.''

title: SPORTS PEOPLE
description: Comings and Goings His team had the best regular-season record in the American Football Conference, and now Tom Flores of the Los Angeles Raiders has been named A.F.C. Coach of the Year. In the poll of 56 sportswriters conducted by United Press International, Flores got 24 votes, Don Shula of the Miami Dolphins got 16, and Walt Michaels, the former coach of the New York Jets, got 10. ... Ken Linseman of the Edmonton Oilers and Dean Kennedy of the Los Angeles Kings have been given four-day suspensions because of a fight in Edmonton, Alberta, Feb. 3. ... Damaso Garcia, Toronto's second baseman, won $400,000 in arbitration.

title: 2,000 Polish Youths Protest in Cracow
description: About 2,000 young people staged an anti-Government protest Thursday night in the southern city of Cracow, official and eyewitness accounts said today. The demonstration was the fourth reported in Poland in the last week.
