title: Driver Is 'Stable'
description: Bruce Jacobi, the stock car driver injured in an accident during a Daytona 500 qualifying race Thursday, was in critical but stable condition today. The 46-yearold Jacobi suffered an injury to the brain stem, said Jean Hartgrove, a spokesman for Halifax Hospital.

title: INTEREST RATES FALL SHARPLY
description: Interest rates declined sharply throughout the day yesterday because of investor optimism that Federal Reserve policy would encourage lower interest rates despite increasing growth in the nation's basic money supply.

title: 76 BLACKS WOUNDED IN SOUTH AFRICAN BOMB BLAST
description: A bomb exploded today in a provincial government building containing work permit offices, wounding 76 blacks, 18 of them seriously, the police reported. They said they believed the blast was set off by the outlawed African National Congress as a part of its increasing fight against white minority rule in South Africa.

title: BIRTH-CONTROL RULE IS BLOCKED
description: In a rebuff to the Reagan Administration, a second Federal district judge today blocked regulations that would have required federally supported family planning clinics to notify parents when minors received prescription contraceptives.

title: CO-OP CITY TOUR SHOWS CONSTRUCTION PROBLEMS
description: Twenty-five state and city officials, along with local residents, toured the 300-acre Co-op City housing complex in the northeast Bronx yesterday to examine some of the numerous construction problems at the state-supported development.

title: Labor Secretary Urges Lower Pay for Youths
description: Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan, appealing for passage of President Reagan's proposed subminimum wage for young people, said today that the lower rate would not cost adults their jobs.

title: Women's Hockey A Free Night Out
description: For most people, the big hockey game at the Nassau Coliseum today sends the Islanders against the Montreal Canadiens at 5:05 P.M. For Janet Charak and a few others, the big game is the one that follows, the Green Machine Eagles against the Newark Ironbound Recreation Center in the Mid-Atlantic Conference for women.

title: IN A SEESAW WAR, SALVADORANS HOLD THEIR PEACE
description: The civil war in El Salvador, now three years old, is being waged in cycles. Each begins with an announcement on the clandestine rebel radio station that a new offensive is imminent. Guerrillas, followed by Government troops, then sweep through the countryside and, in a matter of weeks, return to base camps and barracks, leaving behind burned-out buildings and fresh graves.

title: Kite Leads by 3
description: Tom Kite had nine birdies for a seven-under-par 65 to take a three-stroke lead today in the second round of the Isuzu-Andy Williams San Diego Open.

title: GOVERNOR TRYING TO END IMPASSE ON TAX BREAKS
description: Governor Cuomo will try next week to break a deadlock over the future of New York City's most important taxincentive program, which provides property tax abatements and exemptions to encourage developers to rehabilitate rundown buildings.

title: NewsAnalysis
description: Not surprisingly, the suggestion that banks are keeping interest rates high to shore up their profit margins has drawn a spirited riposte from bankers and others who follow the financial world.

title: HOLD THE MOLOCH
description: On ''Saturday Night Live'' not long ago they were stopping people on the streets and asking them, ''What do you hate?'' and not a soul said, ''Possession movies,'' which is what I would have said.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Denver Nuggets, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M. (Television - MSG Cable, 7:30 P.M., live, and 1 A.M. Sunday, tape. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 7:30 P.M.) Major College Games: Duke at Wake Forest (Television - ESPN, 12:30 P.M.); Connecticut vs. Villanova, at the Hartford Civic Center, 1 P.M.; St. Peter's at Army, 1 P.M.; Iona at Fordham, 2 P.M. (Radio - WFUV-FM, 90.7; WFAS-FM, 103.9; 2 P.M.); Louisville at Memphis State (Television - Channel 2, 2 P.M.); North Carolina at North Carolina State (Television -ESPN, 2:30 P.M.); Fairfield at Manhattan, 3 P.M.; Georgetown at Pittsburgh (Television - Channel 4, 3 P.M.); Clemson at Maryland (Television - ESPN, 4:30 P.M.); Virginia Tech at Florida State (Television - USA Cable, 5:30 P.M., tape); Columbia at Dartmouth (Radio - WKCR-FM, 89.9; 7:25 P.M.); L.I.U. at Wagner, 8 P.M.; Boston College at Syracuse (Television - USA Cable, 8 P.M. Radio - WNYE-FM, 91.5; 8 P.M.); Wisconsin at Minnesota (Television - ESPN, 9 P.M.); Stanford at Southern California (Television -USA Cable, 11 P.M.) Other College Games: C.W. Post at Rutgers, 3:30 P.M. (Television - Channels 23, 50, 52 and 58, 9 P.M., tape. Radio - WRSU-FM, 88.7; 3:30 P.M.); Sacred Heart at Bridgeport, 7:30 P.M.; Staten Island at Adelphi, 8 P.M.; City College at Lehman, 8 P.M.; Queens at John Jay, 8 P.M.; North Adams State at the Merchant Marine Academy, 8 P.M.; Dowling at Monmouth, 8 P.M.; Central Connecticut at Southern Connecticut, 8 P.M.; Mount St. Vincent at Yeshiva, 8:30 P.M.; Fairfield at Manhattan, women's game, 1 P.M.; Penn State at Rutgers, women's game, 1 P.M. Harlem Globetrotters Exhibition, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 2 P.M., and at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7:30 P.M. Boxing Johnny Bumphus vs.

title: Survivors Get $10 Million In Tennessee Mine Blast
description: Owners of a coal mine where 13 men were killed in a methane gas explosion in 1981 agreed today to pay 10 widows and their children about $10 million in damages over their lifetimes.

title:
PATENTS;
A Seismic Monitor To Detect Tunneling
description: A seismic monitor has been invented to track prisoners or others who are digging their way out underground.

title: Ex-Boston Aide Is Sentenced For Lying in Inquiry of Mayor
description: A former city official was sentenced today to two years in prison for lying to a Federal grand jury investigating suspected corruption in the administration of Mayor Kevin H. White.

title: Bruins, Peeters Fall to Jets, 6-5
description: Two glaring mistakes by Pete Peeters, the Bruins goatender, resulted in goals as the Winnipeg Jets opened a 4-0 lead en route to a 6-5 victory over Boston tonight.

title: Kyle May Retire
description: It's not definite yet, and he's not going to make any rash decisions, but Aaron Kyle, the Denver Broncos' cornerback and the team's union representative during last fall's players' strike, said that ''it's a pretty good possibility'' that he won't be playing next year. With two years to go on what he called ''a good contract,'' Kyle insisted that his retirement talk wasn't a negotiating ploy.

title: RECYCLING INDUSTRY V. AKRON
description: No news is bad news. So it is in Akron, Ohio, where the nation's $1 billion-a-year paper recycling industry has mounted a drive to preserve its sources of supply -largely newspapers - against threatened inroads from government.

title: Museum Gets $60,000 For Volume on Critiques
description: The New Museum has been awarded a grant of $60,000 by the Henry Luce Foundation to finance a volume of critical essays on art devoted to contemporary art and ideas.

title: ROBERT T. BUCK TO HEAD THE BROOKLYN MUSEUM
description: Robert Treat Buck, director of the Albright-Knox Gallery in Buffalo, was named director of the Brooklyn Museum yesterday and outlined an ambitious program to increase membership, intensify corporate support and establish a new identity for the museum.

title: UNDERSTATED SOCIAL SECURITY CONTRIBUTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Australian Is Charged With Setting Brush Fire
description: An unemployed 19-year-old youth was charged today with setting one of the fires that ravaged southeast Australia, and firefighters in Victoria State battled two blazes still burning out of control.

title: Louisianian Gets Six Months Over Hoax Calls on Cyanide
description: Gregory Larks, accused of making false assertions that the water of Gonzales was poisoned with cyanide, has been sentenced to six months in jail and fined $500.

title: THE AMERICAN DREAM AT ITS IRREDUCIBLE MINIMUM
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 ARRESTED IN MILAN AFTER AUDIT OF RIZZOLI EDITORE
description: Angelo and Alberto Rizzoli and the managing director of the ailing Italian publishing dynasty founded by their grandfather were arrested today on fraud charges that court sources said stemmed from the disappearance of nearly $20 million of company funds.

title: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1983
description: International A $3-a-barrel cut in North Sea oil was proposed by the state-owned British National Oil Corporation, whose move was long-awaited by oil analysts. Norway quickly followed suit. Traders said Nigeria was preparing to break ranks with the rest of OPEC and cut its prices by up to $5.50 a barrel. The North Sea cuts were at the modest end of the market predictions and followed reductions by the Soviet Union, Egypt and others. (Page 1, Column 4.) 76 South African blacks were injured by a bomb explosion in a provincial Government building in Johannesburg where work permits are issued. The police said they believed the bomb was placed by the outlawed African National Congress as part of its increasing fight against white minority rule in South Africa. (1:5.) Two Libyan planes were chased away from the carrier Nimitz by the ship's F-14's as it was moving in the eastern Mediterranean near Libya this week, Administration officials said. The announcement was made as a delegation of Pentagon officials arrived in Cairo amid continued tensions in the region over Libya's military activities. (1:2.)

title: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 19, 1983; International
description: British National Oil proposed a $3-a-barrel cut in the price of its North Sea crude. The reduction was promptly matched by Norway, and rumors spread that individual members of OPEC were ready to follow suit. Other producers have already cut their oil prices, but analysts were looking to Britain to pose a major test of OPEC's ability to keep the price decline from accelerating into a plunge. (Page 1.) American executives said they plan to approach any new contracts for British oil with caution as they wait for other producers to lower their prices. (39.)

title: Debt Issues
description: * The Farm Credit Banks said it would offer on Feb. 24 three bond issues totaling $3.41 billion made up of $1.73 billion of bonds due Sept. 1, $1.06 billion of bonds due Dec. 1 and $615 million of bonds due Sept. 1, 1987. Interest rates will be set Feb. 23.

title: LeRoux Not Leaving
description: Buddy LeRoux, one of the three principal owners of the Boston Red Sox, has denied reports that he plans to sell his shares in the club because of a feud with the two other general partners, Haywood Sullivan and Jean Yawkey, the widow of the club's longtime owner, Tom Yawkey. Indeed, to hear LeRoux tell it, it's precisely because of the feud that he plans to hold his shares.

title: AUTHORITY OVER A-PLANT PLANS SUDDENLY CONFUSED
description: To the many questions about preparing for a nuclear accident, a new one was added this week: What happens when officials of a county where a nuclear power plant is situated say that no emergency evacuation plan will make the plant safe enough to operate?

title: Manville Purchase
description: The Manville Corporation, which is in bankruptcy proceedings, said its Forest Productions subsidiary had purchased a plywood and sawmill facility in Joyce, La., from the Crown Zellerbach Corporation for an undisclosed amount. Manville said the plant, which employs 372 workers, has a current annual production capacity of 200 million square feet of plywood and 85 million board feet of lumber and studs.

title: Connecticut Shows Home-Start Rise
description: Housing starts in Connecticut rose 9.4 percent last year over 1981, the State Housing Department reported today.

title: The Wrong Time
description: As president of the New York Road Runners Club, Fred Lebow is the person most responsible for making the annual New York City Marathon an international sports event and a local happening.

title:
PATENTS;
Supplemental System For Gasoline Engines
description: James W. Welsh, an engineer in Summit, N.J., was granted Patent 4,373,493 this week for apparatus to add a supplementary gaseous fuel to the gasoline in an car engine.

title: NKOMO FIGHTING FOR HIS POLITICAL LIFE
description: Joshua Nkomo, Zimbabwe's opposition leader, still receives visitors and petitioners in the manner of a benevolent monarch, as if the years have blurred and fused his identity with that of his party and people.

title: DANCE: SCIENCE FICTION BY GAIL CONRAD THEATER
description: Like many other choreographers, Gail Conrad tells stories in dance. But what makes her unusual is her desire to tell stories through tap dancing, a form that is usually associated either with purely decorative extravaganzas or with solo expressions of moods and feelings.

title: THE AWFUL BAR EXAM
description: To most people, July and February are opposites. They do, however, share one thing in common: They are the times when the legal profession's ritual of fire, the bar examination, is administered. The bar exam is the last obstacle that law school graduates must overcome in order to win their wings as fledgling attorneys. As veterans of the Washington, D.C. exam, we protest against the grueling nature of this exercise.

title: Dumping the Disabled
description: Uncle Sam provides payments to people too disabled to work. After the Reagan Administration stepped up a campaign to crack down on malingerers, social agencies began reporting nightmarish tales of hopelessly crippled people denied payments because they had been suddenly judged ''able to work.'' Now the state and city of New York are suing Washington to protect the most defenseless of the disabled, the mentally handicapped. For fiscal as well as moral reasons, the issue is well worth a fight.

title: JANET BRAGUIN
description: Janet Braguin, a former fashion and promotion director of Vanity Fair Mills Inc. of Manhattan, died last Saturday after a stroke at her home in Essex, Conn. She was 75 years old.

title: WALKER TO REMAIN AT GEORGIA
description: Herschel Walker, responding to reports that he was ready to leave college for an offer of as much as $16.5 million from the New Jersey Generals, said yesterday that he would remain at Georgia for his senior year.

title: WRONG PARADE MARSHAL
description: To the Editor:

title: F-14'S FROM CARRIER NIMITZ CHASED 2 LIBYAN JETS, U.S. OFFICIALS SAY
description: Two Libyan MIG-23 fighter planes were chased away from the carrier Nimitz this week by the ship's F-14's, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: No Headline
description: MARINES EXPANDING PATROL ROUTES TO HELP LEBANESE ARMY IN BEIRUT

title: AT WHAT AGE SCHOOL?
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS;
Engine Cooling System
description: A new system for cooling engines and heating passengers has been patented for the General Motors Corporation.

title: DOW UP 3.91, to 1,092.82
description: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday in heavier trading, buoyed by the growing conviction that interest rates will decline. The Dow Jones industrial average, which lost more than 8 points in the previous three sessions, rose 3.91 points, to 1,092.82. For the week, the key average was ahead 6.32 points mainly because of its advance of 10.60 points on Monday, when it closed at a record 1,097.10.

title: TEAMSTERS' REBUFF ON PACT REPORTED
description: The teamsters' union has rejected a request by a trucking industry group that it make contract concessions, industry sources said yesterday.

title: Las Vegas (23-0) Tops San Jose St.
description: Larry Anderson of Nevada-Las Vegas scored 28 points, including 18 in the second half tonight as the Rebels remained the only unbeaten major college team by downing San Jose State, 84-81, in a Pacific Coast Athletic Association game.

title: OFFICERS GET CHOICE: POUNDS OR DOLLARS
description: For good luck, Patrolman Seth Hubbard wore a T-shirt today that announces, in purple spangles, ''I'm Not Fat, I'm Short for My Weight.'' Then he made a mandatory visit to the man of medicine known as the Fat Doctor.

title: NEW I.B.M. GALLERY FOR MAJOR EXHIBITS WILL OPEN NEXT FALL
description: A gallery substantially larger than the biggest floor of the Whitney Museum of American Art will open next fall in the new International Business Machines Corporation headquarters at Madison Avenue and 57th Street.

title: Pate Quits Tourney
description: Citing the same shoulder injury that forced him out of the British Open, Jerry Pate, a former United States Open champion, withdrew from the Australian Masters golf tournament yesterday and said he did not know when he might play again.

title: TOUCH OF RANCIDITY CAN SPOIL THE FEAST
description: As much as one might allow for a wide variety of individual preferences in flavors (some like it sweet, others like it sour), it is hard to believe that anyone would deliberately choose food because it is rancid. Yet such spoilage is all too common, not only with food served in restaurants, but also in retail groceries, health food stores, candy shops and bakeries, and even in samples offered at fancy food trade shows. One might conclude that there are, in fact, people who list ''rancid'' among their favorite flavors; more probably, many simply do not recognize it and assume that the flavor is typical of the food being eaten.

title: SOME FARMERS THRIVING AS OTHERS GO UNDER
description: Around the country a cloud of gloom hangs over the general agricultural economy, but a close examination reveals a picture with many bright spots among the shadows and many shades of gray.

title: Letter: On Subsidizing Industry; Canadian Lumber's Unfair Advantage
description: To the Editor:

title: A Reagan Seeks Record
description: Last summer, he set a powerboat speed record from New Orleans to St. Louis.

title: JUROR'S DUTY IS A LONG WAIT TO DO DUTY
description: The operative word is ''waiting'' - waiting in line to check in with a clerk in the mornings, waiting to be sent to a courtroom where they must wait to be questioned about their suitability for a particular case, waiting to learn whether they have been chosen or must return to the assembly room, waiting for attorneys or judges or defendants to arrive, and waiting, finally, to be set free.

title: Zenith Records a Loss; Colgate Declines 21.6%
description: The Zenith Radio Corporation reported a loss today of $17.2 million for the fourth quarter, compared with net income of $1.5 million, or 8 cents a share, in the corresponding period of 1981.

title: M.T.A. Bonds Sold At 9.5% Interest
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority sold $125 million worth of bonds yesterday to finance the rehabilitation of its commuter rail lines and bus and subway systems.

title: Czech Hijacking Fails
description: The security police shot and killed a man today who had tried to hijack a domestic flight carrying 34 passengers. The official Czech press agency said the man, Marian Pesko, 26 years old, attacked a female flight attendant on the TU-134 aircraft, tried to enter the cockpit and threatened to blow up the plane.

title: No Headline
description: Kings Turn Back Lakers by 124-118

title: BONN SAYS ARRESTED RUSSIAN IS PROBABLY HEAD OF SPY RING
description: A Soviet trade official who was arrested Thursday is thought to be the head of the K.G.B. spy network in West Germany, the authorities said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PROMISES, PROMISES

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 48.

title: If War's Hell, What's the Alternative?
description: Though he meant to sound tough and steady, Secretary of State Shultz sounded testy in telling Congress why he opposed negotiations to end El Salvador's civil war. He accused the guerrillas of ''creating hell,'' trying to ''shoot their way'' into power and causing the violence. Buzzwords aside, that's a pretty good definition of a civil war.

title: Time-Life Books Reducing Its Staff
description: Time-Life Books Inc., reeling from a plunge in income from $21 million in 1981 to $1.6 million last year, will reduce its editorial staff at its headquarters by 26 percent, a company official said.

title: Nurses Vote Pact
description: Nurses ratified a contract early yesterday morning with Lenox Hill Hospital, averting a strike, officials said. The registered nurses at the 690-bed hospital at 100 East 77th Street in Manhattan approved 192 to 119 a contract similar to those approved recently at other hospitals, said Michael Ruggiero, a hospital spokesman.

title: Bishop James V. Pardy, Maryknoll Missionary
description: Bishop James V. Pardy, a longtime Maryknoll missionary in South Korea, died Tuesday at El Camino Hospital in Mountain View, Calif. He was 84 years old.

title: Paterson Man Charged In Slaying of a Student
description: A 34-year-old man has been formally charged with the murder of a college student whose body was found here in a shallow grave Feb. 5.

title: O'NEILL ASSAILS REAGAN'S POLICIES AND PROMISES A FIGHT ON JOB BILL
description: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. assailed the Reagan Administration's economic policies today, asserting that ''tight money, trickle-down tax cuts and cruel budget cuts have brought the economy of the greatest nation in the world to its knees.''

title: THE REDSKINS FROM PRINCETON
description: WASHINGTON I t has been three weeks since his team won the Super Bowl, and yet the Redskin quarterback has received no offers for endorsements, for commercials, for personal appearances.

title: PRESIDENT HINTS HE MAY RUN AGAIN
description: President Reagan offered a ringing reavowal tonight of the most conservative parts of his agenda, teasing a conference of his supporters with a re-election hint that his Administration ''will need more than two years'' to complete its goal of reforming the Federal Government.

title: Cyanamid to Close Facility in Jersey
description: The American Cyanamid Company announced that its Shulton Inc. U.S.A. subsidiary would phase out operations at its Mays Landing, N.J., manufacturing and distribution facility over the next several months, then close the plant entirely.

title: Bridge: A Winter Sectional Begins As Quiet Revival Goes On
description: The high cost of hotel space has in recent years virtually eliminated sectional tournaments from the New York calendar. But a modest revival is taking place, and local enthusiasts can enjoy two in quick succession, both at the New York Hilton. One begins today, and another will follow at the end of March.

title: 3 CHICAGO FOES SEE MINORITIES AS KEY TO CITY HALL
description: After forcefully criticizing her two opponents in next Tuesday's Democratic mayoral primary, Mayor Jane M. Byrne softened her voice and spoke to the forum of Hispanic women as if confiding in an old friend.

title: News Analysis
description: After winning a dangerous personal gamble with his prestige and political strength, Gov. George Deukmejian, a Republican, has made the Democrats do it his way in order to resolve California's fiscal crisis.

title: A.T.&T WILL PROVIDE MOBILE PHONES IN CITY
description: The Federal Communications Commission today approved plans by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to build a cellular radio system in New York City and the metropolitan area that would be the largest advanced mobile telephone service in the nation.

title: KOCH SAYS HE'LL DEFY U.S. ON ROUTE INTO LEBANON
description: Mayor Koch, who is going to Israel next week, said yesterday that he was ready to defy a State Department policy prohibiting travelers who come into southern Lebanon from Israel from meeting with United States marines stationed in Beirut.

title: BRITAIN PROPOSING $3-A-BARREL CUT FOR NORTH SEA OIL
description: The state-owned British National Oil Corporation today proposed to its customers a $3-a-barrel cut in the price of North Sea crude oil. Norway quickly matched the cut, and rumors swirled that some OPEC producers were poised for similar actions.

title: Tribute for Basilio
description: He held world titles in the welterweight and middleweight divisions in the same year, and he is a member of the World Boxing Hall of Fame, but the folks in his hometown of Canastota, N.Y., are afraid that Carmen Basilio might be forgotten unless they do something about it. They plan to raise $30,000 to build a memorial to the fighter right off Exit 34 of the New York State Thruway.

title: THREE ROLES FOR GRIFFEY IN ONE DAY
description: ''Hey, Yogi,'' Ken Griffey yelled to Yogi Berra, ''maybe you can help me. Where am I going to be this year?''

title: Buses in Harbor Being Retrieved
description: The Transit Authority began efforts yesterday to retrieve two city buses that had fallen into New York Harbor when a pier at an authority depot on Staten Island collapsed.

title: Irish Concerts Booked At Folk City, in 'Village'
description: Four concerts of traditional Irish music will be presented at Folk City in the Irish Festival '83, a celebration of the season of St. Patrick, opening with a performance next Friday by James Keane, an accordionist; Robbie O'Connell, a singer, and Mick Moloney, a banjo and mandolin player.

title: Golf to Horses
description: The Fox Run Country Club, a golf club along Route 25A in Muttontown, L.I., has been closed down since Dec.31. Now Bruce Williams, who is a plant engineer, and his wife, Michelle, hope to buy it and turn it into an equestrian center, with profits going to the United States Equestrian Team.

title: REAGAN BID REOPENS RIFT WITH RIGHT
description: With his modest jobs proposal, President Reagan has reopened a rift with right-wing loyalists who grow uneasy each time he goes for bipartisan compromise. But his strategists calculate that these tactical accommodations are worth the cost to bolster his image with the majority of voters.

title: INSPECTOR FAULTS E.P.A. RECORDS OF '82 SPENDING
description: The Inspector General of the Environmental Protection Agency has said he was unable to show whether almost one third of the $180 million committed to cleaning up the nation's toxic waste dumps last year was spent correctly.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Singing the Praises Of an Unsung President

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A listing in Weekend yesterday gave an incorrect date for a concert by the Classical Quartet at Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st Street. It is at 3 P.M. on Feb. 27.

title: PERSONAL INCOME WAS FLAT IN JANUARY
description: Personal income, depressed by a plunge in farm earnings, grew at a rate of less than one-tenth of 1 percent in January, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Keith Winter, Playwright, 76; Wrote 'The Rats of Norway'
description: Keith Winter, a playwright who wrote ''The Rats of Norway,'' first produced on Broadway in 1933, died Thursday at the County Manor Nursing Home in Englewood, N.J. He was 76 years old and had lived in the Actors Fund retirement home in Englewood since 1978.

title: BIOTECHNOLOGY RETRENCHMENT
description: When Genentech, a biotechnology company laden with scientific talent, went public in October 1980, the price of its shares soared to $89 each from $35 in a matter of hours.

title: Patents
description: WASHINGTON AMEDICATION infusion system to be implanted in the body, so that a physician can ''prescribe'' the release of the correct dosage by phone directly to the device, has been patented by Robert E. Fischell, a staff physicist at the Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory in Laurel, Md.

title: POLICE CHIEFS' ENDEAVOR
description: To the Editor:

title: Nationwide Hunt Is On For Ex-Florida Justice
description: The Federal authorities have begun a nationwide search for former Justice David L. McCain of the Florida Supreme Court, who failed to appear last month for arraignment on drug smuggling charges in Lake Charles, La.

title: GEORGE'S NEW YORK DAYS
description: New Yorkers have as much right to take the lead in celebrating George Washington's 251st birthday on Monday as citizens of the nation's capital do. George did more than simply sleep in the Big Apple for a night. He spent some of the most significant months of his life in the city, both as a general and President of the United States.

title: C.I.A. REPORTS TO SENATE PANEL ON SHOOTING OF POPE
description: The Central Intelligence Agency reported to a Senate committee today about the shooting of Pope John Paul II. There has been concern among members of Congress that the Reagan Administration has not shown adequate interest in determining whether Bulgaria and the Soviet Union played a role in the 1981 assassination attempt.

title: Governor Cuomo's determination to maintain a balance between state support of public and private higher education in a time of financial crisis, affirmed in introducing his proposed budget for the 1983-84 fiscal year, obliges the two sectors to accommodate their differences and join together in seeking maximum support for all the state's colleges and universities.
description: Higher education would be harmed by continued dissension and competition of the sort now in evidence. This dissension - bubbling beneath the surface - regularly erupts at budget time. But this year's ''survival budget'' may produce higher education's Mount St. Helens.

title: PRESIDENT IS NAMED BY AVIS
description: Norton Simon Inc.'s Avis division, the nation's second-largest car rental company, said yesterday that it had named Joseph V. Vittoria as president and chief operating officer, to succeed Howard C. Miller Jr. It said Mr. Miller is resigning at age 56 ''to pursue personal business interests.''

title: Berle Play Postponed
description: ''Goodnight, Grandpa,'' the new play by Walter Landau starring Milton Berle, has postponed its opening to March 2 at the Entermedia Theater. The schedule of preview performances also has been revised.

title: Spanish Official Says Treaty On U.S. Bases Will Be Ratified
description: Spain will ratify a treaty giving the United States military installations in the country before a May 21 deadline, Foreign Minister Fernando Moran said today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Snow in Queens May Melt, But It Won't Go Away

title: EX-HEAD OF SENTRY INDICTED IN THEFTS
description: The former head of the Sentry Armored Car Courier Company in the Bronx was indicted yesterday on charges of stealing more than $346,000 from clients' accounts and misappropriating $29 million in a scheme to obtain illegal bank-interest payments.

title: TOLL IN INDIA'S ELECTION VIOLENCE IS SAID TO HIT 170
description: Tension and fear are reported from all parts of this northeastern area of India as the final day of a threepart election nears.

title: Arts Academy-Institute Elects 13 Members
description: The American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters has elected two composers, five writers, five artists and an architect to the organization's 250-member Institute.

title: A FIX-IT-YOURSELF TREND FOR APPLIANCES
description: Frustrated with appliances that break down and repairmen who miss appointments or leave exorbitant bills, a growing number of consumers have begun making their own repairs in the last five years. Now appliance manufacturers are responding to the do-it-yourself movement, and they see it as a way to improve customer relations and make money at the same time.

title: Ex-Agent Gets 17 Years In Explosives Smuggling
description: Edwin P. Wilson was sentenced to 17 years in prison today for smuggling plastic explosives to Libya, but the court denied a request by prosecutors to declare him a ''dangerous, special offender,'' which could have meant eight more years.

title: THE GRAY AREAS
description: Bolivia's recent extradition to France of its leading resident Nazi, Klaus Barbie, causes one to remember the compelling urge to forget.

title: BASEBALL
description: BALTIMORE (AL) - Agreed to con- t ract terms with Gary Roenicke, outfield- e r, who will reportedly receive $300,000 t his season. CHICAGO (AL) - Won an arbitration c ase brought by Dennis Lamp, pitcher, w ho will be paid the $312,500 offered by the t eam. CINCINNATI (NL) - Joe Price, pitch- e r, won a salary arbitration case against t he team and will receive $210,000 this sea- s on. Signed Ted Powers and Bill Dawley, p itchers, to one-year contracts. CLEVELAND (AL) - Signed Lary S orensen, pitcher. NEW YORK (NL) - Signed Jesse O rosco and Tom Gorman, both pitchers, a nd Ron Gardenhire, infielder, to 1983 con- t racts. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Invited eight nonros- t er players to their spring training camp, i ncluding Steve Braun, outfielder; Or- l ando Sanchez, Jim Hunt and Tom Nieto, c atchers, and Jerry Garvin, Todd Worrell, T om Thurberg and David Van Oblen, p itchers. TORONTO (AL) - Damaso Garcia, s econd baseman, won his salary arbitra- t ion case and will receive $400,000.

title: DePaul's Randolph Finds Life Harder
description: CHICAGO L ife was so much less complicated when Bernard Randolph was younger, and the basketball team at DePaul University was built around the talents of his friends. He had come from Westinghouse High School in Chicago, the same public school that sent Mark Aguirre and Skip Dillard to DePaul.

title: ABC Rejected Request To Delay Awacs Report
description: ABC News rejected a White House request Wednesday that it delay for 24 hours an exclusive report on the deployment of Awacs surveillance planes and the carrier Nimitz in the eastern Mediterranean last weekend to counter what were regarded as aggressive moves by Libya.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: To March or Not to March

title: BRIEFING
description: Nevada Target: Burger

title: DANCE: HARLEM THEATER'S 'OTHELLO'
description: The Dance Theater of Harlem, which has one more week at the City Center, presented its newest bill Thursday night - the company premiere of John Butler's ''Othello'' and the season's first performances of ''Frankie and Johnny'' and ''Troy Game.''

title: TV: '2 ON THE TOWN' TALKING
description: ''Two on The Town'' is not so happy that it is silly and not so newsy that it is burdensome to even the smallest degree. Its reporters, or hosts, are Adrienne Meltzer and Lloyd Kramer. They smile a good deal of the time, but there is more ingenuousness than calculation in their smiling, and their evident self-satisfaction is never smug. Moreover, they do not intrude on the people they interview.

title: KLEIN II'S VERSATILITY PARES PRICE
description: The discussions at the introduction of the Anne Klein II collection this week centered on whether the tailored double-breasted jacket made of sweat-shirt material or the knitted wool single-breasted jacket would be the success of the season. The sweat-shirt jacket may have had the edge. It can be worn over swimsuits this summer as well as with leather skirts next fall, thus ranking high on any versatility scale.

title: U.S. BUYERS AWAIT OTHER PRICE CUTS
description: American oil executives, whose companies comprise the largest foreign buyers for oil sold by the British National Oil Corporation, said yesterday they would not rush to sign new contracts for North Sea crude pending expected price cuts from other producers.

title: U.S. Restricting Visas Of North Koreans at U.N.
description: The United States is restricting the re-entry visas it issues to North Korea's United Nations diplomats in retaliation for the harboring by North Korea's United Nations Mission of a North Korean official wanted on a charge of sexual abuse, diplomats from both countries said today.

title: BONN SEIZES 3 IN BOMBINGS OF U.S. BASES
description: Three men were arrested this week on suspicion of having bombed American military installations in West Germany, officials said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Thursday misstated the exchange rate to be used by companies in translating the accounts of their Mexican subsidiaries from pesos into dollars. A proposal by the Financial Accounting Standards Board would require the use of the current ''market'' rate of about 150 to the dollar, unless a company is assured access to the ''preference'' rate of 100 to the dollar.

title: Brazil Adjusts Cruzeiro Rate
description: Brazil announced today it was devaluing the cruzeiro, which is pegged to the dollar, by 30 percent.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ANGER: The Misunderstood Emotion. By Carol Tavris. 302 pages. Simon and Schuster. $14.95.

title: LOUISIANA LAND MAY BUY BELCO
description: The Louisiana Land and Exploration Company is holding merger talks with the Belco Petroleum Corporation, Wall Street sources disclosed yesterday.

title: Allied to Sell Klippan Units
description: The Allied Corporation said it agreed to sell three of the five operations of its Klippan European seat-belt unit and its two-thirds interest in a fourth operation to Nike Finanziaria S.p.A.

title: CONSUMER SATURDAY
description: WHEN a car engine pings, pongs, stalls, bucks or otherwise m isbehaves, it may mean that it is time for a tuneup. But what you g et when you ask for a tuneup varies from repair shop to repair shop,a nd the cost depends as much on where you take your car as on the p roblems under the hood, according to a survey by the New York State C onsumer Protection Board.

title: JUDGE APPROVES PSA PLAN FOR BRANIFF
description: A Federal judge approved a plan today to return some of Braniff International's planes to the air and some of its former employees to work as part of Pacific Southwest Airlines.

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: Balked in the hunt for a militant survivalist wanted in the slayings of two United States marshals, investigators today checked out telephone tips by citizens. A $25,000 reward has been posted for the suspect.

title: NEIGHBORS JOIN TO ASSIST SHELTER ON THE EAST SIDE
description: Amid opposition in other neighborhoods where city-run shelters for homeless people have opened, men staying at a shelter on Park Avenue have found good will and French pastries.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We will make additions to his bill, but we are not looking to make political points by provoking a veto.

title: T.T. WANG, INFLUENTIAL MASTER OF CHINESE KITCHEN, DIES AT 55
description: Tsung Ting Wang, a chef who was influential in introducing fine, authentic Chinese cooking to New York, died of cancer last Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 55 years old.

title: Wickes Completes Sale of Division
description: The Wickes Companies have completed the sale of the Maxwell Furniture division to the group's previous owner, Maxwell Brothers Inc., for about $10 million in cash, Wickes officials said.

title: Canada Inflation Ebbs
description: Inflation fell one percentage point in Canada last month, to 8.3 percent, the lowest level in more than three years, the Government reported today.

title: California to Extradite Feminist in Murder Case
description: Ginny Foat, the California feminist leader accused of the 1965 killing of a South American businessman near New Orleans, was ordered today to be extradited to Louisiana to stand trial.

title: Man Denies Guilt in Rampage That Left 23 Planes as Scrap
description: A former mental patient pleaded not guilty today to charges that he used a four-ton airport snowplow to destroy or seriously damage 23 single-engine airplanes.

title: BL Gearbox Orders
description: BL P.L.C., the British auto maker, said it is buying 500 gearboxes a week from France and may switch further orders abroad to save on costs. BL switched the order for automatic gearboxes from the Borg-Warner Corporation's factory in Wales to the General Motors Corporation in Strasbourg because of the considerably lower price, said a spokesman for Austin-Rover, BL's volume and executive car division.

title: City Federal Ends Bid for Suburban
description: The City Federal Savings and Loan Association of Elizabeth, N.J., said that it had withdrawn its proposal for the acquisition of Suburban Savings and Loan Association of Wayne, N.J., and its mortgage banking unit, the Suburban Coastal Corporation, because changes in the market and continued losses at Suburban had made the merger proposal ''outdated.''

title: Bucks 121, Pacers 94
description: MILWAUKEE (AP) - Milwaukee, led by Marques Johnson with 20 points and Junior Bridgeman with 16, broke to a 16-point lead in the first quarter and went on to rout Indiana.

title: KOCH'S TALL ORDER FOR EMERGENCY SHELTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Corco Says Sale To Apex Is Off
description: The Commonwealth Oil and Refining Company, of San Antonio, announced yesterday that its agreement to sell substantially all its refining and petrochemical plants to a subsidiary of the Apex Oil Company had been terminated. But the company also disclosed that it had a new proposal from a Sun Company unit.

title: Why John Hinckley Had a Gun
description: Surely many have wanted to ask the same question of President Reagan since the attempt on his life nearly two years ago: ''Don't you think that things might have been different if Hinckley had had more difficulty in being able to get a gun?''

title: Your Money; Giving Power Of Attorney
description: ESTATE planning encompasses planning for an individual's life, as well as for his assets after death. And a valuable document for lifetime planning is a power of attorney.

title: EX-F.B.I. OFFICIAL CLEARED BY JURY
description: A Federal jury has acquitted H. Edward Tickel Jr., a former supervisor for the Federal Bureau of Investigation who was charged with attempted larceny after a janitor found him after office hours in the bureau's credit union.

title: Briggs Approval
description: The Justice Department's antitrust division approved a proposed joint venture between the Briggs & Stratton Corporation and an Italian firm, Lombardini F.I.M. S.p.A., for the manufacture of small diesel engines in the United States. Briggs & Stratton, of Wauwatosa, Wis., and Lombardini requested a ruling under the division's business review procedures for their 50-50 venture. The two companies would manufacture diesel engines of 60 horsepower or less in the United States for sale here and abroad.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Woman Shoots And Kills Burglar
description: A 64-year-old woman shot to death a burglar who broke into her apartment while she was playing cards with two friends, the police said.

title:
PATENTS;
Eliminating TV Ghosts
description: A system for eliminating reflected television signals - ghosts - was patented this week for the RCA Corporation by David D. Holmes, director of the Consumer Electronics Research Laboratory in Princeton, N.J. The system, Patent 4,374,400, is designed to operate automatically so that when a ghost signal is detected, a control circuit produces a pseudo-ghost signal. This is used with other means to produce what the patent terms a ''deghosted'' video signal.

title: POISONED HAMLET FRETS AMID DELAY
description: With each passing week, life in Times Beach deteriorates a little more, according to the 100 or so families that have returned despite a warning by Federal officials that the hamlet may be seriously contaminated with highly toxic dioxin.

title: D'Amato Announces Separation From Wife
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, and his wife, Penelope, have signed legal papers for a temporary separation, the Senator's office said today.

title: Ann M. Jacobs Is Wed To Frederick J. Bruce
description: The marriage of Ann Marshall Jacobs to Frederick J. Bruce took place yesterday at the Ferry Bank, a restaurant in Brooklyn Heights. State Supreme Court Justice Nicholas J. Clemente performed the ceremony.

title: Miss Ashford Sets 50-Yard Mark
description: Evelyn Ashford broke her own world indoor best in the 50-yard dash tonight at the San Diego Indoor Games with a time of 5.74 seconds.

title: American Among 3 Reporters Who Are Missing in Salvador
description: The American Embassy has asked the Salvadoran armed forces to cooperate in finding an American freelance writer and two Swedish journalists who left the capital Monday morning.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Stacking the Deck On a New Area Code

title: Prosecution Rests In Harness Trial
description: The prosecution rested today at the trial of four men accused of bribing a groom, James Veno, to gain access to the stable areas at Yonkers and Roosevelt race tracks in 1978 so they could drug horses and then bet heavily on other horses in the race.

title: SLOW START FOR SEAVER IN A DRILL
description: On his first day in spring training with the Mets in six years, Tom Seaver strained his right calf muscle today and was forced to stop running.

title: A COMPANY FINDS A NICHE FOR ITSELF
description: It's not true that the Dance Theater of Harlem can dance anything, which its rather wide repertory is suggesting during the current season at the City Center. But it is true that the company is carving out an unexpected niche for itself as an outstanding producer of Americana ballets and as an adventurous explorer of revivals from the international repertory.

title: THE REDECORATING OF MORVEN
description: style structure served over the years not only as the first official residence of Elias Boudinot, the head of the newly formed republic of the United States of America, but also as the state's Executive Mansion. It was recently given to the Newark-based New Jersey Historical Society, which is redecorating Morven's front two rooms.

title: EL SALVADOR: THE STATE OF SIEGE CONTINUES
description: In a conference room behind the high gray walls, heavy steel latticework and thick bulletproof glass of the United States Embassy in San Salvador, one of the highest-ranking members of the diplomatic mission is offering his view of the facts of life to a group of American visitors. The delegation, which includes a Congressman, two entertainers active in human-rights causes and several others concerned about American policy, is angry; they have seen and spoken to political prisoners who say they've been tortured, Salvadoran officials who say they are doing their best and refugees who say little but suffer a lot. The diplomat is tired. This is the 17th delegation the embassy has shepherded through the Salvadoran labyrinth during the past few weeks. ''The semiannual precertification flying circus and hootenanny,'' another embassy official calls it.

title: Future Events; Performing for Charity
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Loving Tribute Feb. 24 - The AMAS Repertory Theater, a nonprofit company that has spawned such Broadway productions as ''Bubblin' Brown Sugar,'' may have another winner on its hands in ''Miss Waters, to You.'' The gala opening performance of the dramatization of the life of the late Ethel Waters will be followed by a reception at the theater, 1 East 104th Street. Wine and open-faced sandwiches will be offered, along with a chance to hobnob with the cast including Mary Louise, who plays the title role and belts out ''Harlem on My Mind,'' ''Stormy Weather,'' ''Am I Blue'' and other favorites from the Waters repertory. Tickets, $25. Proceeds will go to the Eubie Blake Children's Theater, which is an AMAS program, and the search for a new permanent home to be named for the late jazz musician.

title: Data Bank; Feb. 20. 1983
ECONOMIC PRESSURES IN HONDURAS TESTING YEAR-OLD DEMOCRACY
description: Economic pressures are posing a severe test for this Central American country's year-old democracy. While the administration of President Roberto Suazo Cordova has taken steps, at the urging of international financial institutions, to reduce spending and otherwise shore up his Government's fiscal affairs, the dismal state of the Honduran economy remains a seemingly insurmountable challenge. In the Western Hemisphere, only Haiti is poorer.

title: Florida Keys
description: To the Editor: Walter Logan's article, ''Across 42 Bridges Through Florida's Keys'' (Travel, Jan. 30) was a pleasant surprise.

title: CUTTING THE STATE WORK FORCE MAY GIVE CUOMO A BIG BOOST
description: ALBANY NEW YORK STATE'S 225,000 employees are still waiting for word on who will lose jobs under Governor Cuomo's proposed $31.5 billion budget. But if experience is a guide, they may not have much to worry about. Though governors have frequently proposed work force freezes and reductions, the state bureaucracy, propelled by new mandates and programs, has continued to increase. In fact, it grew by the equivalent of more than 20,000 jobs during the eight-year rule of Hugh L. Carey.

title: STATE FIRE CODE DRAWING CRITICISM
description: A600-PAGE proposal for the first statewide Uniform Fire Prevention a nd Building Code is stirring vigorous controversy among officials, e nvironmentalists and private groups as it is discussed at public h earings throughout the state.

title: OHIO GROUP SETS UP A FOOD LINE FOR PETS OF JOBLESS OF NEEDY
description: While soup kitchens feed hundreds of unemployed and needy people in the Youngstown area, Animal Charity of Ohio runs a bread line to serve their pets.

title: MYRIAD ACTIVITIES FOR VACATIONING SCHOOLCHILDREN
description: WITH many of the county's schools closed for vacation this week, parents may be looking for activities to engage their children's interest and energy. The following events range from pure entertainment to outings that offer esthetic and educational value. Many are planned specifically for children, but others have the potential to interest the whole family.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART If you've missed appearances of the Japanese Kabuki and Noh theaters in New York - and even if you haven't -both can be enjoyably experienced in a show at the Queens Museum in the New York City Building, Corona Park in Flushing - ''The World of Japanese Theater'' (through April 17). This lively presentation of costumes, masks, prints and musical instruments from the late 17th century to the present (including a full-sized replica of a Japanese Noh stage), traces the history of both types of theater; the slow-moving, highly stylized Noh oriented to the upper classes; the more popular Kabuki with its love themes, family sagas and historical subjects geared to the lower and middle classes.

title: SEEING THE BRIGHT SIDE
description: THESE days it demands stern stuff to commute by rail from Connecticut to New York. Not altogether because of the muchpublicized wheel inspections. Delays caused by them have been shorter, and therefore less annoying, than expected.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN WASHINGTON
description: DAVID SHRIBMAN is a correspondent in the Washington bureau of The New York Times.

title: CREWMEN TESTIFY ABOUT SURVIVING SHIP'S SINKING
description: Two of the three surviving crewmen of the Marine Electric have given investigative officers dramatic, sometimes emotional, accounts of the hours and minutes before the coal ship capsized and sank in stormy seas, taking 31 lives.

title: The Bottom Line Is Graduation
description: To the Sports Editor: Congratulations to Robert Klit gaard! He has hit the nail on the head regarding the problem of academics and the scholarship athlete (''Make Graduation Rate the Bottom Line,'' The New York Times, Feb. 6).

title: Virginia and Missouri to Play in Jersey
description: Ralph Sampson has played at his best in nationally televised games for two reasons, according to Virginia's coach, Terry Holland:

title: CLAUDIO ARRAU AT 80-THE YEARS HAVE DEEPENED HIS ART
description: Claudio Arrau's piano recital at Avery Fisher Hall this afternoon will celebrate his 80th birthday and, at the same time, bestow a twofold gift on his listeners. For every so often, nature produces a musician who achieves great age without relinquishing his powers of communication, and events like today's not only compress 70-odd years of practical performing experience into two hours of music; they tell us in fascinating ways how age can transform how we think and how we hear.

title: HOPING FOR A HAPPY SEASON ON BILLY AND GEORGE SHOW field
description: ticket brochure proclaims, ''Billy's back!'' Bumper stickers shout, ''Billy's back!'' Billboards blare, ''Billy's back!''

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: BECAUSE tercentenary celebrations are not milestones to be taken lightly, Suffolk County is throwing an ambitious 300th birthday party for itself. The hoopla will begin March 9 in Riverhead with a parade and the raising of a tercentenary banner and will end next November with a history conference.

title: THE UNEXPECTED CONSEQUENCES OF AUTHORSHIP
description: MY FIRST novel, ''Footfalls,'' was published last October by Atheneum/ Margaret K. McElderry. Recommended for readers 12 years old and up, my book tells the story of 14-year-old Stevie Farr, a girl whose father is dying of cancer.

title: PLAYWRIGHT EYES A NEW GIANT STEP
description: WHEN it comes to jobs that offer unusual fringe benefits, Lou Peterson, the playwright whose ''Take a Giant Step'' found its way to the lists of the ''10 Best Plays, 1953-1954,'' is the first to admit that his post in the theater arts department of the State University at Stony Brook can't be topped.

title: Miss Stanton And Banker Are Married
description: Cynthia Sutherlin Stanton, daughter of Mrs. Alden Oliver Stanton of New York and the late Mr. Stanton, was married yesterday to Thomas Allen Richards, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Baker Richards of New York. The ceremony was performed at St. Bartholomew's Church by the Rev. Bruce W. Forbes, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Irving S. Pollard.

title: AT 25, THE GRAMMYS EXTOL POP'S MAINSTREAM
description: This Wednesday, the Grammy Awards will celebrate their 25th anniversary in a live three-hour telecast on CBS from the Shrine Auditorium in Los Angeles. While the Grammys, the record industry's answer to the Oscars, have yet to seize the public imagination the way its movie counterparts have done, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences (NARAS), which presents the awards, has steadily grown in stature since it was formed in 1957.

title: City Council to Hold 7 Meetings This Week
description: The City Council and its committees have scheduled seven meetings this week. They are: TUESDAY - The Committee on General Welfare considers a bill to prohibit discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation, City Hall, 9 A.M.

title: THE RATTLERS ARE MISSING
description: SCENES IN AMERICA DESERTA By Reyner Banham. Illustrated. 228 pp. Salt Lake City: A Peregrine Smith Book/Gibbs M. Smith. $14.95.

title: Former Coach Sues
description: Jim Carlen, the former football coach and athletic director at South Carolina, has filed a suit against the university charging that his dismissal ''seriously and permanently damaged'' his reputation. Carlen, who now lives in Cookeville, Tenn., charged in a complaint filed in United States District Court that he was ''wrongfully relieved and terminated'' and that his dismissal had left him unable to find a similar job at another college. Paul Ward, attorney for the university, acknowledged the suit Friday but said he would not comment on it.

title: Arthur Rubinstein
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 AUTHORS DECRY 'CENSORSHIP'
description: QUESTIONS of censorship -real or imagined, imposed or self-imposed - have arisen about three recent books by New Jersey authors. In one case, a bookstore has declined to stock a novel and a booksigning by its author was canceled; in another, a talk by the author was canceled; in the third, the author said she regretted having listened to her editor's advice in leaving out material that could ''offend libraries.''

title: HINTS ON USING ACRYLIC PLASTIC AS A REPLACEMENT FOR GLASS
description: CLEAR sheets of acrylic plastic have been become increasingly popular for use as a glazing material in storm doors, basement windows, garage doors and other hazardous locations around the home where the safety features of a break-resistant plastic are desired to eliminate the potential dangers posed by the use of conventional window glass. (Plexiglas and Lucite are two of the most widely sold brands, but they are not the only ones.)

title: 20-Year Fire to Be Monitored
description: A computerized gas-monitoring system will be installed in homes to detect carbon monoxide from an underground fire that has smoldered 20 years, the Department of Environmental Resources has reported.

title: New York Times Magazine February 20, 1983
description: William Safire 9 On Language Chickening In Russell Baker 17 Sunday Observer Perchance to Dream John A. Jenkins 20 A Candid Talk With Justice Blackmun Peter Miller 30 Speed Skiing The record to break is over 126 m.p.h. At this speed, the racer is more a projectile than a skier. Richard J. Meislin 34 El Salvador: The State of Siege Continues Despite conditions attached to U.S. aid, human-rights abuses continue in El Salvador. Carrie Donovan 46 Fashion View A Renewed Vitality for Couture Craig Claiborne 50 Food with Pierre Franey A Mix That Matches Terry Robards 52 Wine A Look After the Leap 58 Puzzles Answers, Page 54 78 Letters Cover: Photograph by Michael O'Neill. Copyright 1980, The New York Times

title:
DINING OUT;
SOME LIKE IT HEARTY
description: FOR the last six years, La Villetta has attracted a devoted neighborhood clientele who come for the unstinting portions of hearty food, some of it very good, indeed. Paul Torre, the owner and chef, cooks with a sure but occasionally heavy hand, especially with sauces that sometimes flood the plate. However, when Mr. Torre is good he is very very good, and his appetizers for the most part proved commendable on our four visits, dishes we would go back for.

title: THE C.I.A.'S COVERT OPERATIONS
description: Philip Taubman incorrectly reported that the ''C.I.A., with assistance from the Turkish Government, has provided millions of dollars' worth of arms and weapons to two Iranian paramilitary groups in eastern Turkey that oppose the Khomeini Government in Teheran.''

title: FARWELL ADDRESS: A LESSON FROM 1976
description: WASHINGTON'S Farewell Address, a perceptive document written by a sober, sensible American patriot, has influenced government leaders for several generations. A reading of this historic address easily persuades one that Washington was strongly convinced that the Constitution of the United States was a visionary instrument of government that heralded a new horizon in self-government.

title: ARTS UNIT ADDS 13 MEMBERS
description: The American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters has elected two composers, five writers, five artists and an architect to the organization's 250-member Institute.

title: Former Ruling Party In Spain Is Dissolved
description: The political party that guided Spain from dictatorship to democracy before suffering a crushing defeat at the polls last October has announced it is disbanding.

title: WHO GETS APARTMENT IN DIVORCE?
description: WITH divorce so common and New York City apartments so hard to find, the question of who keeps thea partment when a couple breaks up has taken on new importance. An additional element is added to the situation when there is a p rospect of a conversion to a cooperative. Whoever gets the a partment may be able to buy it at a bargain insider price in a c onversion. There are many other questions involving real estate thatp arting couples may quarrel over, usually when property is owned. Butr ental situations offer special complications.

title: BACKYARD BIRDING IN BERGEN COUNTY
description: RAPTORS are like canaries in a mine shaft. If the environment is too polluted, too poisonous, hawks and owls are the first to go. That's why I like having raptors for neighbors.

title: SPORTS TODAY
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Philadelphia 76ers, at the Spectrum, Philadelphia, 1:05 P.M. The 76ers have won six straight games against New York. (Television - Channel 9, 1 P.M.) Nets vs. Bucks, at Milwaukee. The Nets have beaten the Bucks in both games between the clubs this season. The Nets are 14-13 on the road, one of five teams in the N.B.A. with a winning road record. (Television - Sports@Channel, 2:30 P.M. Radio - WVNJ, 620 AM; 2:30 P.M.) Bulls vs. Dallas Mavericks, at Chicago (Television -ESPN, 8 P.M.) Trail Blazers vs. Washington Bullets, at Portland (Television - ESPN, 10:30 P.M.) Exhibition: Harlem Globetrotters at Nassau Coliseum, Uniondale, L.I. 2 P.M. College: St. John's vs. DePaul, at Madison Square Garden, 33d Street and Eighth Avenue, 1 P.M. This is the first time the schools have met since the 1949-50 season. (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M. Radio - WGBB, 1240; and WNYE-FM, 91.5; 12:55 P.M.). Missouri vs. Virginia, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 3:45 P.M. Ralph Sampson's only appearance in the New York area this season. (Television - Channel 2, 3:45 P.M.). North Carolina-Charlotte at Jacksonville (Television - ESPN, 5 P.M.). New Paltz at Stony Brook, 2 P.M. Hunter at Lehman, 3 P.M. Women: Rutgers vs. Virginia at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J. (Radio - WRSU-FM, 88.7; 1:15 P.M.).

title: D. H. LAWRENCE ON CHARLIE BROWN
description: This week Applewood Books will publish ''The Brand-X Anthology of Fiction'' (cloth, $17.95; paper, $11.95), a follow-up to Applewood's 1981 ''Brand-X Anthology of Poetry'' - both edited by William Zaranka. The new volume contains parodies of English and American fiction, starting with Daniel Defoe and Jonathan Swift and ending with Ian McEwan and Ann Beattie. (''Henry and Joyce sat by the edge of the pool. Shirley sat on the chaise longue and Bill stretched out on the hot tile that had been put around the edge of the pool by Shirley's father.'') Some of the fun is classic, like E.B. White's Hemingway parody, ''Across the Street and Into the Grill,'' and some of it, like the selections below, will be new to most American readers.

title: ATLANTIC CITY NIPS AT VEGAS'S HEELS
description: ATLANTIC CITY SINCE the opening of its first hotel-casino in 1978, this resort often has been called Las Vegas East. But if the swift growth here continues, Las Vegas may become Atlantic City West.

title: 13 SLAIN AT CLUB IN SEATTLE'S CHINATOWN
description: Twelve men and a woman were shot dead Friday night in a Chinatown gambling club, apparently in a robbery attempt, the police said today.

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Outings for a Winter Respite
description: IF a craving to escape the rigors of winter has begun to possess you, a splendid and relatively inexpensive way to respond to this would be to take part in one of Wilderness Southeast's ''learning expeditions.''

title: Live-In Help For Auto Maker
description: What's good for Toyota may be even better for General Motors. Under an agreement signed last week, the two manufacturers are to begin turning out 200,000 small cars a year at a currently idle California plant in 1984.

title: Durango
description: To the Editor: The item on the Purgatory ski resort in southwestern Colorado included in the Special Ski Issue (Travel, Nov. 7) said: ''The mountain is 25 miles north of Durango, a cowpoke town. Most people stay in the handful of lodges at the base.''

title: Technology, Luck Save a Life
description: Satellites and navigational computers combined with old-fashioned luck helped save the life of Jacques de Roux, the French solo sailor. De Roux was rescued from his dismasted and sinking yacht in the blustery Southern Pacific Ocean by Richard Broadhead of England, a fellow competitor in the B.O.C. single-handed round-the-world race. The details were put together Friday in Newport, R.I., by the race committee, which coordinated the rescue, after radio contact with Broadhead last week.

title: After-Burn Of a Hot Race
description: The rewards of politics are many and varied. In the case of Vander L. Beatty, officials charged last week, they were also illegal.

title: Howard Berman Is Married to Jill R. Oppenheimer
description: Jill Robin Oppenheimer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Oppenheimer of Rockville Centre, L.I., was married there last evening to Howard Berman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Berman of Whitestone, Queens. Rabbi Paul Joseph performed the ceremony at the Central Synagogue of Nassau County.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: ANEW corporation that wants to establish a 35-acre plant in Perth Amboy to store and treat hazardous waste for disposal at sea has retained former Gov. Brendan T. Byrne as counsel and a leading public relations agency.

title: IONA RALLIES TO BEAT FORDHAM BY 68-60
description: Iona improved its hold on first place in the Metro Atlantic Conference yesterday by rallying from a 10-point first-half deficit and defeating Fordham, 68-60, at the Rams' gym on Rose Hill in the Bronx.

title: A CANDID TALK WITH JUSTICE BLACKMUN
description: John A. Jenkins lives in Washington and writes on legal matters.

title: CUOMO SUBMITS BILLS FOR CRIMINAL-JUSTICE CHANGES
description: Maximum sentences for most repeat felony offenders would be extended to 50 years under a five-bill package of criminal-justice reforms Governor Cuomo submitted to the Legislature this week.

title: No Headline
description: COGHLAN BEATS SCOTT IN MILE

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: Juvenile books dealing with the immigrant experience invariably used to celebrate the ideal of the American melting pot. Todays' authors are much more likely to treat this theme with a certain ambivalence. Children who may be several generations removed from contact with their immigrant forebears hardly need to be told about the rewards of assimilation, but they do need to be reminded of what is unique to their particular heritage. This shift in emphasis is apparent in three otherwise very different books on the theme of Jewish immigration to America.

title: OFFICE BOOM OUTSTRIPPING HOTEL CAPACITY
description: LIKE many other segments of the support-services industry, the hotela nd motel trade is trying to catch up with the corporate h eadquarters and white-collar businesses that have moved into New J ersey suburbs in the last decade.

title: BATTLING OVER BANK INTEREST RATES
description: IT was shocking last week to hear Donald T. Regan, a conservative Treasury Secretary, attack the nation's b anks for charging too much interest. ''Banks are doing their utmost t o keep interest rates up,'' he told a Congressional committee.

title: 10 Injured as Protesters Disrupt a Klan Rally
description: At least 10 people were injured here today when the police clashed with hecklers from a crowd of about 1,500 people who were protesting a rally by about 50 Ku Klux Klansmen.

title: ON THE HIGH ROAD TO TAOS
description: metropolitan division of WNET 13.

title: BRILLIANCE-OR LUCK?
description: Does it matter whether the game is won by a brilliant improvisation to escape a cul-de-sac or by a profound conception worked out from the beginning?

title: LEARNING TO THINK IN A MANOR
description: OVERLOOKING Lloyd Harbor, perched on the side of a hill, sits an uninhabited house beckoning to children to come explore, dream and learn about the 18th century.

title: IN DEFENSE OF LIBERTY AGAINST THE MACHINE
description: To the Editor:

title: A WIDOW'S TALE
description: PRAISESONG FOR THE WIDOW By Paule Marshall. 256 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $13.95.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Whatever the young Uruguayan pianist Enrique Graf chooses to play is invariably played well; his Saturday afternoon Carnegie Recital Hall debut was, in all respects, a triumph.

title: SEX AND RESPONSIBILITY
description: To the Editor:

title: ARENS SAYS STRAINS IN U.S.-ISRAELI TIES ARE AT HIGH POINT
description: Moshe Arens, who is replacing Ariel Sharon as Israel's Defense Minister, says that Israeli-American relations have worsened in recent months partly because of the Reagan Administration's attitude toward talks on Lebanon.

title: A BLIND SPOT SHOWS IN THE JEWISH STATE
description: In all the soul-searching provoked by the war in Lebanon, the Beirut massacre and the state inquiry commission, the foundations of one Israeli attitude have gone relatively untouched. That is the national consensus on the illegitimacy of Palestinian nationalism.

title: MALTA TAKES ON THE WORLD IN DIPLOMATIC WAR
description: For more than a month the Government of Malta has been waging diplomatic warfare with the rest of the world. A truce has been reached, but members of the United States Embassy, along with all of the other diplomatic missions in this island republic of 320,000 people, remain under threat of being expelled as persona non grata.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: The Business Is Child's Play

title: CAUCUS DRAWS A TAX PLAN
description: HARTFORD FOR the first time in its history, the state legislature's Black and Hispanic Caucus has prepared its own tax plan, one that is substantially different from that proposed by Governor O'Neill.

title: COFFIN 'HOTEL': CHINESE WAIT TO GO HOME
description: In a collection of old buildings on the western side of Hong Kong Island, away from the skyscrapers that dominate the skyline, there is a compound containing more than 300 coffins awaiting transportation to China for burial. Some have been there for decades.

title: DIGGING DOWN TO IRISH ROOTS
description: DESMOND RUSHE is a critic and columnist for The Irish Independent in Dublin.

title: The Wages of Zealotry
description: The President's firing of Rita Lavelle has thrown the Environmental Protection Agency into crisis. But the cause of the crisis goes far beyond the current turmoil. It dates to the decision two years ago to appoint James Watt Secretary of the Interior and Anne Gorsuch as head of the E.P.A.: Mr. Reagan thereby entrusted stewardship of the nation's environment to two people fundamentally opposed to the legal missions of their agencies.

title: CONCERT: THE KING'S SINGERS
description: The King's Singers, a six-member male vocal ensemble from Britain, covered almost every imaginable style in Carnegie Hall Thursday night and managed all with unfailing grace. There were English madrigals - including four newer ones by Thea Musgrave - Spanish songs, a Magnificat by Victoria, Zulu songs from modern South Africa, Lithuanian folk settings by Dvorak and some sappy but ingratiating popular items at the end.

title: TRAVEL AGENTS SEE CLOUDY FUTURE
description: WASHINGTON THE Civil Aeronautics Board's recent deregulation of the travel agent industry, which eliminated travel agents' exclusive rights to sell airline tickets, threatens to disrupt the industry, according to the owners of some of Connecticut's largest travel agencies.

title: REPUBLICANS ON THE BRINK OF A NEW ERA
description: HARTFORD CONNECTICUT Republicans, the minority party in the state since the 1950's, will make a change at the top this week in a shift that could reshape the party's future.

title: Molly Schueler Is Married to Omar F. Elder 3d
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Chestnut Hill, Mass., Mary Parsons Schueler was married yesterday to Omar Franklin Elder 3d. The Rev. Donald Bitzburger performed the ceremony.

title: A LOOK AFTER THE LEAP
description: According to a legend told in the California wine country since the turn of the century, hunters were pursuing a mighty stag through the rugged hills that rim the eastern side of the Napa Valley. It was the onset of winter, the stag was large and strong, and its meat would feed many people during the cold months ahead, so the pursuit was intense and lasted several days.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: SEARINGTOWN SINCE sending Ellen out into the world, I have Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday and Sunday nights free. Ellen, 17 years old, has a driver's license. So, for the last seven weeks, she has driven herself to jazz band on Mondays. Or picked up Michael after Hebrew school. Or taken Mark to visit his friend who invents computer games.

title:
CAMERA;
LEARN FROM THE MASTERS
ANOTHER NAME FOR MADNESS
description: Marion Roach's article is enormously helpful in its medical information about Alzheimer's disease, but what I shall not forget is the personal anguish: the cats being destroyed at the vet's, the burglar alarm's mangled wires, her mother's writing ''Merry Christmas'' in the doctor's office and - because I, too, am the mother of two redheads - the end of the game called ''another redhead.'' SUSAN H. TUCK Bloomington, Ind.

title: FROM CAPITOL HILL TO L.I. DISTRICTS
description: THERE was a time when members of the House of Representatives commuted from their Long Island homes to Washington every week. Now, with Congressional sessions running virtually year-round, some members of the Long Island delegation commute from their Washington homes to their Long Island districts.

title: PRACTICAL MATTERS FOR VISITORS
description: CHRISTINE LUND is a writer who lives in Santa Fe.

title: T.J.C. Smyth Jr.  Becomes Fiance Of Miss Marshall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Allerton Delano Marshall of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Katharine Delano Marshall, to Thomas James Campbell Smyth Jr., son of Mrs. Smyth of Greensboro, N.C., and the late Rev. Thomas James Campbell Smyth.

title: Mailbox; Buck and Stram Get High Marks
description: To the Sports Editor: I am addressing this letter to The Times largely because I enjoy so much reading the braille version of The New York Times Large Type Weekly.

title: Heidi Michalis Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Fahnestock Michalis of Locust Valley, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cora Candler Michalis, to Douglas McMillan Thomas, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter A. Thomas of Greenwich, Conn., and Naples, Fla.

title: CAMPUSES WOO CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON UNLIKE Harvard and Princeton, Yale University does not maintain a Washington lobbyist or a large on-campus staff of Federal relations experts. It says it gets along fine without them.

title: ETTORE SCOLA'S HISTORIC BACKDROP
description: ROME In ''A Special Day,'' the 1977 film that brought him international recognition, the Italian director Ettore Scola placed the tender and fleeting mutual recognition - perhaps love - between a worn-out and exploited wife of a domineering Fascist and a homosexual equally victimized by Mussolini's brutal regime against the background of a major event in history.

title: CURRY LUNCH: RICH COLORS, AROMATICS AND PUNGENCIES
description: THE curry lunch is not an institution familiar to many Americans. It is an Anglo-Indian tradition that became immensely popular among many British people, especially those posted abroad. For years, it was a favorite way to entertain on Sundays. The afternoon began with drinks, gin and tonic or a concoction called Pimms No. 1. There are few buffet spreads I remember being as colorful as this one.

title: JAZZ-POP: BOBBY COLE, PIANO
description: By force of his circumstances, Bobby Cole should probably be categorized as a cocktail pianist and singer. His circumstances are that he plays piano and sings in the cocktail lounge of the Versailles, on East 50th Street.

title: Scripps Dance Award Will Go to Paul Taylor
description: Paul Taylor will receive the 1983 Samuel H. Scripps/American Dance Festival Award. Created in 1981 to honor American modern dance choreographers for their lifetime contributions to the field, the $25,000 award is the largest annual award in the performing arts.

title: U.N. GIVEN CONSENT TO MEET AFGHAN REFUGEES
description: A United Nations mediator has won approval from Afghanistan and Pakistan to consult Afghan refugees about the refugees' conditions for a safe return home, Western diplomats said today.

title: Amy Klein to Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Klein of Fort Lee, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Beth Klein, to Brian Lefsky, son of Murray Lefsky of Freeport, L.I., and the late Frieda Lefsky. The wedding is planned in May. The future bride is an associate real estate manager in the real estate investment office of the Prudential Insurance Company in Boston. Mr. Lefsky is an engineer with Prime Computer Inc., a computer manufacturer in Framingham, Mass.

title: High Tea
description: To the Editor:

title: Bumphus Wins in 8th; Last Fight for Shields
description: The undefeated junior welterweight Johnny Bumphus of Clementon, N.J., raised his record to 18-0 today by stopping Randy Shields 1 minute 15 seconds into the eighth round.

title: WALKER DENIES SIGNING CONTRACT WITH GENERALS
description: Herschel Walker, the Heisman Trophy-winning tailback, said tonight that he had not signed a contract with the New Jersey Generals, and that he was confident he would be back at the University of Georgia for his senior year.

title: A NEW INDIA CLOSES IN ON OLD LEADERS
description: NEW DELHI Abrief but tumultuous phase in Indian politics has come to an apparent end with the impressive victory in this month's Delhi municipal elections by Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's weakened and embattled Congress Party.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: THAIS HESITATE TO WRECK OPIUM FIELDS OF TRIBES
description: The Thai Government, which has outlawed the cultivation of opium poppies, has nonetheless declined for now to destroy thousands of acres of poppy fields, according to senior Thai and Western drug enforcement officials.

title: E.D. Frank 2d Weds Dr. Susan C. Day
description: Dr. Susan C. Day, daughter of Mrs. William L. Day of Philadelphia and the late Mr. Day, was married yesterday to Edward D. Frank 2d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Howard A. Frank of Brookline, Mass. The Rev. Richard Hess performed the ceremony at Old St. David's Episcopal Church in Wayne, Pa.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE One of the jewels of New York dance in the 1960's was Manhattan Festival Ballet, an adventurous little chamber company that is remembered with special affection by anyone who went to dance in the city in those days. Ronald Sequoio and James De Bolt, two Manhattan Festival veterans, will return to the New York stage with their new Dance Compass company on Saturday, next Sunday and March 5 and 6 at the Emanu-El Midtown Y, in a joint concert with Marvin Gordon's Ballet Concepts.

title: Elly Ameling to Teach
description: Elly Ameling, the Dutch soprano, will give her first New York master class on Feb. 26 at 2 P.M. at the Greenwich House Music School, 27 Barrow Street. The class is open to the public at a cost of $5, and the number for information is 242-4770.

title: China Rejects Complaint Of Vietnam on Oil Hunt
