description: China today rejected Vietnamese charges that it was violating Vietnamese sovereignty by allowing foreign companies to search for offshore oil in the disputed Tonkin Gulf off northern Vietnam and southeastern China.

title: Marcy L. Wachtel Will Wed in April
description: June Rosner of New York and Fire Island has announced the engagement of her daughter, Marcy Lynn Wachtel, to Gary Ian Horowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Horowitz of Spring Valley, N.Y. An April wedding is planned.

title: Ann Bosso Is Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. A. Raymond Bosso of Indianapolis of the engagement of her daughter, Ann Bosso, to Christopher C. Quick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leslie C. Quick Jr. of Laurel Hollow, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla. An April wedding is planned.

title: Garcia Seeks Trade
description: On Friday, he won the $400,000 annual salary he had been seeking in arbitration. Nevertheless, Damaso Garcia has asked to be traded from the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: PRACTICAL GARDEN PLANNING FEEDS THE HUNGRIEST FAMILY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Nancy Bubel has written many books on vegetable gardening. BY NANCY BUBEL

title: LIMITED PARTNERS
description: WASHINGTON WHENEVER a President and his Congressional rivals work together in the spirit of bipartisan cooperation for the good of the nation, an inevitable question arises. Which side is going to be able to use the products of their compromise to advantage in the next election?

title: ANOTHER NAME FOR MADNESS
description: Marion Roach refers to the discouraging state of medical research on Alzheimer's disease.

title: DRAFT-LOAN TIE ROILS COLLEGES
description: WASHINGTON THE vote by Congress to deny Federal loans to students who failed to register for a draft will most likely result in an increase in paperwork for schools and students, including women.

title: MUST SYMPHONY CONCERTS AND TELEVISION BE INCOMPATIBLE?
description: There are things you might suspect but never really know unless you opened your mail. For instance, many people still watch televised orchestral concerts in hopes of enjoying a musical experience as well as a visual one. Such trust is touching, but the truth is that the concert experience translates to the living room - or isn't it called the media room nowadays? - about as successfully as a souffle would survive an ocean crossing in a hydroplane.

title: 'DISCOVERY IN DANCE IS INEXHAUSTIBLE'
description: In some ways, Mary Overlie is a very up-to-date choreographer, for she seeks to carry on and develop some of the kinetic explorations begun by the pioneering Judson Dance Theater two decades ago. She has also been associated with two innovative theater companies, the San Francisco Mime Troupe and the Mabou Mines. She is currently on the faculty of New York University's Experimental Theater Wing and is one of the founders of the School for Movement Research, an organization devoted to the investigation of new dance forms.

title: Florio Says Landfill Operator Kept Different Sets of Books
description: An Environmental Protection Agency inspection report shows that a landfill operator represented by a former adviser to Anne M. Gorsuch, the agency administrator, kept two sets of books to conceal leaking at a Colorado landfill, Representative James J. Florio, Democrat of New Jersey, asserted today.

title: THE SCHISGAL TOUCH EXTENDS TO FILM
description: center style of absurdist humor, it seems that Murray Schisgal has entered what could be called phase two of success. With ''Tootsie,'' which he co-wrote, currently the country's highestgrossing film, and the continued run of his pair of two-character plays, ''Twice Around the Park'' -his first Broadway show in nine years - Mr. Schisgal's career is newly in ascent.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: TOMORROW is a government holiday, but there will be activity at the County Office Building in White Plains. On its outside steps, an hourlong demonstration is scheduled for noon. It will be held by Power, People Outraged With Energy Rates, to protest against Con Edison's request for a 12 percent rate increase, which is under deliberation by the state's Public Service Commission.

title: CONCERT: MARVIS MARTIN AND CHAMBER SOCIETY
description: If there are few vividly dramatic voices among today's women singers, we can at least be grateful for smaller, more subtle, blessings. Three of these understated talents - all Americans - figured in the music of this past week.

title: Of Big Betting And Pro Football
description: To the Sports Editor: That was an interesting supposition in Dave Anderson's Jan. 20 column (''What's Under the N.F.L. Rugs?'') critiquing the PBS program ''The Unauthorized History of the N.F.L.'' by quoting bookmakers and odds-setters that their point spreads ''actually police pro football gambling.'' Big bets are supposed to show up with the subsequent fluctuations of the point spread to warn National Football League security chiefs.

title: LOSING THE SALARY GAME
description: Proposition: Men and women with Columbia M.B.A.'s and similar undergraduate education, economic backgrounds and marital and social status will rise equally in the business world.

title: DEER POPULATION: A GROWING CONCERN
description: ALTHOUGH no one is able to determine how many deer roam the county, conservation and wildlife officials report a growing number of complaints - some from as far south as New Rochelle - that the animals are feeding on crops and shrubbery. The deer, which because of hunting restrictions and a lack of natural predators are older and larger than elsewhere in the state, are also increasingly cited as a hazard to motorists.

title: CHANGES RUFFLE STONY BROOK
description: IN 1940, Ward Melville, a philanthropist who built a financial empire in the shoe business, stood on a grassy stretch in the sleepy village of Stony Brook and watched his dream of rebuilding a village start to become a reality. A hodgepodge of shoddy structures built in the early 1900's shattered as easily as plastic toys, and in their place, new stores, all adhering to an Early American motif, took shape -one next to the other, complete with whitewash and green shutters, in a semicircle.

title: 2 Children Found Smothered In a Refrigerator in Brooklyn
description: Two children died yesterday after apparently becoming trapped in a refrigerator in the basement of their home in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: BIG BUSINESS TIGHTENS ITS ARTS BUDGET
description: This season, the complete ''Ring'' cycle is being shown on public television's ''Great Performances,'' courtesy of the Exxon Corporation. The Vatican show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art was sponsored in large part by Philip Morris. And in Minneapolis, there is a new production of ''Peer Gynt'' at the Guthrie Theater - thanks to a grant from the Dayton-Hudson Corporation, a leading retailer headquartered there.

title: First Strike On Adelman
description: President Reagan's strategy for filling the top spot at the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency was in danger of becoming another zero-zero option last week. A recalcitrant Senate Foreign Relations Committee put off a vote on the nomination of Kenneth L. Adelman when it became apparent that the result would go against him. But the President stuck by him and prepared for a fight that one Republican supporter predicted would be ''a debilitating, demeaning experience for Ken.''

title: Correction
description: The publication date of ''Lectures on Don Quixote'' by Vladimir Nabokov, from which The Book Review excerpted the foreword in last Sunday's issue, has been changed.

title: Kew Gardens
description: To the Editor:

title: A.J. TESSITORE, A C.P.A., TO WED MARIA CANALE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Canale of Fairfield, Conn. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maria Christin Canale, to Aristide Joseph Tessitore, son of Mr.a nd Mrs. Joseph C. Tessitore of Newtown, Conn.

title: NKOMO IS HELD BY ZIMBABWE TO BLOCK TRIP
description: Zimbabwe's opposition leader, Joshua Nkomo, was detained by the police for eight hours today after he tried to board an airliner for a trip to Czechoslovakia.

title: COLLEGE PUTS BUSINESS TO WORK FOR STUDENTS
description: John D'Elia is an investment, of sorts. A large insurance company has put $5,000 into his mind, or, more precisely, into paying for part of the college education that will enhance his mind.

title: 10 Children Injured in Crash
description: Ten children suffered minor injuries this afternoon when a Salvation Army van overturned on an Antelope Valley road, the police said. Officer Bob Kanyr of the California Highway Patrol said the accident occurred just before 5 P.M. about a half-mile south of the California Aqueduct.

title: Death Toll Now 71 In Australian Fires
description: Another victim of southeast Australia's fires was found today, and the police set up patrols to guard abandoned homes from looters.

title: A Nuclear Albatross for Suffolk County?
description: The Shoreham nuclear power plant on Long Island is 10 years late, 10 times over budget and, because of action in Albany last week, perhaps indefinitely on hold. In an unexpected move, Governor Cuomo ordered the state not to approve an emergency evacuation plan for the 10-mile area surrounding the facility. Mr. Cuomo said he ''would not be a party to any effort to impose an independently developed state plan upon Suffolk County.''

title: TRUDEAU AND 16 CARIBBEAN LEADERS HOLD TALKS
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliot Trudeau flew to the island of St. Lucia today to meet leaders of 16 Caribbean governments. According to aides, Mr. Trudeau will reaffirm Canada's commitment to double aid to the region in the next five years.

title: AN AMERICAN FAMILY
description: DESCENT FROM GLORY Four Generations of the John Adams Family. By Paul C. Nagel. Illustrated. 400 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $25.

title: BONN CANDIDATE WRITES REAGAN ON ARMS
description: The West German opposition candidate for Chancellor, Hans-Jochen Vogel, has written a letter to President Reagan calling on the United States and the Soviet Union to ''abandon their respective starting positions'' in the Geneva talks on the reduction of medium-range missiles.

title: WHY MAKE THE AUDIENCE DO ALL THE WORK?
description: In the course of ''Merlin,'' which magician Doug Henning has caused to appear at the Hellinger, a number of very tricky tricks are offered for our astonished inspection between musical-comedy songs, dances and - God save the mark - jokes. The illusion you've probably heard most about involves Mr. Henning, as the Merlin who's gone vagabonding along the byways of ancient England, mounting his white horse, entering a slatted crate and riding upward therein, and, as the crate suddenly collapses with a great empty clatter, appearing astride the same horse in a gypsy caravan half a stage away. That one's nifty, all right.

title: DANCE: GREG REYNOLDS, A WASHINGTON TROUPE
description: The Greg Reynolds Dance Quintet from Washington is not your ordinary modern-dance company. On the basis of its concert Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, it seems that much of Mr. Reynolds's choreography falls into the liturgical-dance category and even when it does not, the dances are tied to a strong expression of ethical values in the program notes.

title: Correction
description: The Practical Traveler column on airport departure taxes (Travel, Jan. 30) incorrectly described the situation in two countries. Australia levies a departure tax of 20 Australian dollars a person (about $19.30 American, based on recent exchange rates), and Kenya charges 80 shillings (about $6).

title: STUDENTS SUE OVER AID TO PUBLIC-INTEREST LAWYERS
description: Eight students from various campuses of the State University of New York have charged that the mandatory diversion of funds for student activities to a public-interest law firm is unconstitutional. They have sued to halt further collections.

title: Kathryn Altman Betrothed
description: Ashley J. Altman of Lower Merion, Pa., and Loveladies, N.J., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Kathryn Jo Altman, to Craig Andrew Fertel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Fertel of Bala Cynwyd, Pa. Miss Altman is a daughter also of the late Sandra K. Altman. The wedding is to be in October.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
OFFICIAL REAGAN MEDAL IS FINALLY AVAILABLE
description: After much delay the United States Mint has finally unveiled its official Mint medal of President Ronald Reagan. Special gold-plated and silver-plated versions of the medal were presented to Mr. Reagan on Feb. 3 at the White House, and the regular bronze version is now on public sale.

title: A HUNTINGTON SPLIT
description: Andrew Varipapa, the 93-year-old legendary bowling champion, goes there three or four times a week ''to keep fit,'' he says. Century's Huntington Lanes on Long Island are usually busy with both league players and occasional bowlers seeking just one of those high games that came so easily to Mr. Varipapa.

title: The Fugate Graphs
description: Caril Ann Fugate spent 18 years in prison because a jury didn't believe she was Charles Starkweather's unwilling companion during a 1958 murder spree that left 10 people dead in Nebraska and Wyoming.

title: UTILITY DISTRIBUTES ENERGY-CONSERVATION KITS
description: The first of 5,000 home weatherization kits for low-income families were distributed here today to help homeowners and apartment dwellers conserve energy.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOIOCES
description: NEW MUSIC Although Laurie Anderson's ''United States I-IV'' has finished its run, it's by no means the season's last interdisciplinary performance.

title: VALENZUELA GRANTED $1 MILLION
description: Fernando Valenzuela, who in only two years has become a folk hero in Los Angeles, made baseball history yesterday when he became the first player to win a $1 million salary in arbitration.

title: E.P.A. OFFICIALS SAY INQUIRY DATA HAVE BEEN ERASED OR ARE MISSING
description: Computer disks containing information relevant to a Congressional investigation of the Environmental Protection Agency have been erased or are missing, according to two agency officials.

title: BIRTHDAY GIFT FOR PEDIATRICIAN'S PATIENTS
description: SEVERAL times lately, women have come up to Dr. Gerald L. Schwartz, stared knowingly into his eyes and told him, ''This is the month.'' They and their husbands are trying to conceive now so they won't have to pay later. If they have a baby on Nov. 16 - Dr. Schwartz's birthday, about nine months hence - and choose him as their pediatrician, the doctor will give the child free medical care until he or she is 22 years old.

title: Transit Authority Taken for a Ride
description: If the New York City Transit Authority isn't giving bus and subway riders their money's worth, one reason could be that the agency isn't getting its money's worth. An audit by City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin found that through bid-rigging, overpayments and the purchase of inferior hardware, plumbing and electrical supplies, the authority had been bilked out of $1.1 million on just $1.6 million of contracts.

title: ROCKETTES SELL NEW YORK IN PARIS
description: After 46 years, the Rockettes finally made it back to Paris. But it wasn't quite the same on the night of Feb. 11 as it was in 1937. The Radio City Music Hall stars' last trip here was for the world championship in precision dancing, held during the Paris Exposition.

title: Prospectus Miscue
description: Question: My wife and I have lived in a rent-controlled apartment on Central Park West for 17 years. About six years ago, our building was converted to cooperative ownership. On the prospectus, our apartment was listed as the superintendent's apartment. At the time, we could not afford to buy, so we did not protest. Do we still have a right to purchase our apartment at the original price? ... T.P., Manhattan. Answer: According to a spokesman for the State Attorney General's Office, if you wanted to buy, you should have protested the misrepresentation six years ago. Based on the facts in your letter, the spokesman said, it appears that you have no claim to buy now.

title: THE ART OF STORYTELLING REVIVED IN HISTORIC INN
description: GEORGE WASHINGTON didn't sleep there. But the Marquis de La Fayette, accompanied by his aide, Rochambeau, did - on a night in 1824. The French general is depicted on a sign that hangs outside the spot - the Vernon Stiles Inn, an early 19th-century tavern in the northeastern Connecticut border town of Thompson.

title: NEW BUMPER RULE IS SAID TO BRING COSTLIER REPAIRS
description: Weaker automobile bumpers permitted last year by the Government resulted in sharply higher automobile repair costs and no apparent saving to car buyers, an insurance industry organization has reported.

title: ORCHESTRA CONDUCTING WAS WHAT SHE ALWAYS WANTED
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Heidi Waleson writes frequently about music and musicians. BY HEIDI WALESON

title: THE NEW ENVIRONMENTALISTS
description: THE environmental movement in New Jersey has expanded considerably in the last two years, adding new organizations, new members and a greater diversity of people.

title: WILL CONGRESS PASS THE BUCK ON CAMPAIGN FINANCING?
description: WASHINGTON CONCERN about the role of money in the 1982 elections has triggered alarm bells all over Washington. The dependence of prominent members of the House on political action committees, the steady increase in the price of a seat in Congress (five House candidates, a record, spent over $1 million in 1982), and last-minute floods of slick and sometimes sleazy direct mail have all raised questions about how campaigns are financed and conducted.

title: SCHOOL IN GRAND TETON HELPS STUDENTS TO DISCOVER NATURE
description: The little school beside the big mountains does not teach the three R's. Its mandate is to help people learn what the land was like before there were big cities, turnpikes and garbage dumps.

title: PORTRAIT OF THE ARTIST AS A YOUNG COMPUTER
description: Given what we've seen of it to date, it's small wonder that when we hear the term ''computer art'' our attention begins to wander. By now, we've developed an understandable resistance to the boring optical shenanigans that result when computers are programmed to make drawings by technicians who lack the imagination of artists. And so the announcement of a show at the Brooklyn Museum devoted to AARON, an ''intelligent computer program'' that can produce up to 12 ''unique, original drawings'' every hour might seem - to put it mildly -one of the season's less compelling events.

title: MISS JEWETT PLANS JUNE 19 WEDDING
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Jewett of Louisville, KY., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Jewett, to Evan S. Marshall, son of Maxine D. Marshall of Sharon, Mass., and Ronald Marshall of Randolph, Mass.

title: FLORIDA INMATES WORK ON CHAIN GANGS WITHOUT CHAINS
description: A car whizzes past, heading down the highway toward Key West. A man working along the roadside stretches, wipes sweat from his brow, leans on his shovel and gazes after the travelers.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: REPRESENTATIVES of government, academia and industry got together for a few hours last week in Bridgeport to discuss what all agreed was the need to coordinate policies to produce quality-trained personnel for high-technology industries. The speakers did not present a rosy picture of efforts to date or future prospects of Connecticut or the nation in meeting foreign competition.

title: Ellen E. O'Hare Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. James J. O'Hare of Hanover, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ellen E. O'Hare, to Robert H. Rogers Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Rogers of Fairfield, Conn. The wedding is planned for April.

title: AN AMERICAN LIFE
description: Lewis H. Lapham, a former editor of Harper's Magazine, is writing a book on the pathologies of wealth in America.AFTER LONG SILENCE By Michael Straight. Illustrated. 351 pp. New York: W.W.Norton & Co. $17.50.

title: FOR MOROCCO, SAHARAN WAR APPEARS OVER
description: In 1975 Ahmed Douiri was 21 years old, living in the central Moroccan town of Sidi Kacem, with a chance to get a university education. But being ''an adventurer,'' he said, he took part in November of that year in the Green March of about 350,000 Moroccans charged with walking into this barren territory to put pressure on Spain to give it up.

title: Shultz Derails Two-Track Policy
description: Salvadoran guerrillas continued last week to demonstrate their ability to operate in the field, but Secretary of State George P. Shultz refused to yield political ground to them. He ruled out negotiations that would allow them to ''shoot their way'' into the Government.

title: HOSPITALS CUTTING BACK ON ROUTINE TESTS
description: Patients at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center of New York no longer routinely undergo a battery of tests when they are admitted, or any other tests later unless ordered by a physician, according to hospital officials.

title: THEATER: 'HANNAH,' HEROSIM IN WAR
description: ''Hannah'' is a new play with music and dance about a courageous young Jewish girl in World War II. It opened Wednesday night at the Harold Clurman Theater but it is so caught up in its stagecraft that it misses its chances to seize the emotions and catch the heart.

title: Strikers in Philadelphia Reject Compromise Offer
description: Striking blue-collar workers in the Philadelphia School District overwhelmingly rejected a compromise offer tonight from a Common Pleas Court judge to get them back to work.

title: Miss Coleman Marries Michael L. Owen in Florida
description: Christina Peabody Coleman, daughter of Mrs. James A.D. Pollock of Darien, Conn., and Townsend P. Coleman Jr. of Jupiter, Fla., was married yesterday to Michael Leon Owen, son of Mrs. George A. Lawson of Jupiter and Gary F. Owen of Plymouth, Mass. The Rev. Dr. Seymour St. John, former headmaster of the Choate School, performed the Episcopal ceremony at Christ Memorial Chapel at Jupiter Island, Fla.

title: PLATFORM TENNIS DROPS IN POPULARITY
description: LESS than a decade ago Dick Squires, an authority on platform tennis, predicted that the game was ''a mere single serve away from becoming America's next major participation sport.''

title: JURY GETS CASE OF BOY, 16, WHO KILLED FATHER
description: A 16-year-old boy was found guilty tonight of voluntary manslaughter in the shotgun slaying of his father, who he said had abused him for years.

title: LEOPOLD GODOWSKY 2D, 82, SHARED IN INVENTING KODACHROME PROCESS
description: Leopold Godowsky 2d, who developed the Kodachrome color photography process with a boyhood friend, died of a heart attack Friday outside his home on the Upper East Side. He was 82 years old.

title: Recital Is Canceled
description: The soprano Judith Raskin's recital at the 92d Street Y, scheduled for Feb. 27, has been canceled. Ticket refunds may be obtained at the Y box office, 1395 Lexington Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10028.

title: Kristen Kidwell to Wed C.L. Miller Jr.
description: Doris B. Kidwell of Basking Ridge, N.J., and Dr. Allyn P. Kidwell of Ridgewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kristen Emilie Kidwell, to Charles Lockett Miller Jr., son of Commander Miller, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Miller of Annapolis, Md. The wedding is to be April 16.

title: BLACK HISTORY IN ART MUSEUMS
description: BLACK HISTORY MONTH is getting so much attention in New Jersey art galleries this year that there is scarecely space enough to report on it.

title: Opthalmologist Defines Role of Optometrist
description: In the Jan. 30 Opinion Page article entitled ''A Plea To Ease Eye-Care Rules,'' we see, from the very outset, the progress of mediocrity as it is being proposed to the detriment of the public.

title: A NEW COMEDY THAT IS TOO HEAVY
description: LUBA is looking for love - the kind with ''the sun and moon and stars and fireworks in between.'' She has lost count of all the men she has had. The ones she has really loved - and who have loved her - add up to three, which is not such a sad tally.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: PHOTOGRAPHYTo some eyes Ellen Brooks's contrived tableau photographs of middleclass dolls in middle-class doll house environments have seemed too stagey, too theatrical, to function as an effective satire. But social criticism is not exactly what Miss Brooks has in mind.

title: Cunningham Anniversary
description: The Merce Cunningham Dance Company will celebrate its 30th anniversary with a two week-season at City Center, from March 15 to 27. Highlights of the season will be the American premiere of ''Quartet'' and the world premiere of a staging of a new video dance, as yet untitled. The company will revive ''Runes,'' a 1959 work by Mr. Cunningham, with new decor by Mark Lancaster, and will perform two evenings of ''events.''

title: Wendy Sue Natelson Plans To Marry Michael P. Nolan
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alvin L. Natelson of Wantagh, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Sue Natelson, to Michael Patrick Nolan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Nolan of Wantagh and Sarasota, Fla.

title: Copyright or Free Speech?
description: A soon-to-be-published Presidential memoir may be a hot property but it's not necessarily news, ''hot or otherwise,'' a Federal judge ruled last week. Thus copyright laws, not constitutional guarantees of free speech, may govern its publication.

title: CONSUMER RATE
PLANS TO EXPLORE PLANETS REVIVED
description: After years of steady decline, the nation's planetary exploration program appears to have been rescued from extinction by the Reagan Administration and is now shaping a long-range survival strategy involving a number of lower-cost missions.

title: VALUED VOICES; Frail Newspaper
description: The Amsterdam News has been in continuous weekly publication for 75 years, longer than any other American newspaper for blacks. With deficits rising, its run was threatened two weeks ago by a strike to protest a cut in the paid work week from five days to four.

title:
ART;
SUCCESSES AT COLLAGE EXHIBIT
description: ON-HUDSON ALOT has happened since the early years of this century when Picasso turned collage into one of the quintessentially modern ways of making art. Perhaps the dominant impression one gets from ''Collage-Assemblage'' at the Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson (through Feb. 27) is that collage has lost its radical role as a method of bringing ordinary life into pictures.

title: SALISBURY CHERISHES A SKI LEGACY
description: SEATED in the rustic, wood-framed judges' booth atop the 60-meter hill, Birger Torrissen scores the performances of young ski jumpers and recalls an earlier time when he and teammates from Norway and Sweden introduced their native sport to fellow Americans.

title: WINTER HAVENS IN PORTUGAL
description: Nazare, for better and for worse, is a postcard. Its whitewashed houses - like shells flung at the foot of the tallest cliff on the Portuguese coast - and its barefoot fishermen in bright tartans and tasseled caps rowing out to sea, as they have for 300 years, make Nazare one of the most photographed villages in Europe.

title: JEWELRY BY SEASON
description: Karen Sebiri is a jewelry designer with a highly personal point of view. Although she works with semiprecious stones, she does not consider her works to be collectibles.

title: MARINES IN LEBANON START NEW PATROL ROUTINE
description: United States marines today started twice-a-day patrols that will eventually take them into East Beirut regularly.

title: Maine Backs District Rights
description: Maine has became the 11th state to ratify a proposed amendment to the Constitution that would give the District of Columbia full voting rights in Congress.

title: Miss Rockefeller Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Gray Rockefeller to Douglas Parker Currier has been announced by Mrs. John P. Fisher of Edmundston, New Brunswick, and Andrew C. Rockefeller of Greenwich, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert M. Currier Jr. of Aurora, Ohio.

title: SPEED SKIING
description: From the basin floor, the skiers looked like flakes of mica in the snow of the couloir.

title: LIGHT ON A DARK SUBJECT
description: SECRETS On the Ethics of Concealment and Revelation. By Sissela Bok. 332 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $16.95.

title: 55 for Boys & Girls Star
description: Dwayne Washington, the basketball star at Boys & Girls High School in Brooklyn who will attend Syracuse University next fall, demonstrated his court prowress on Friday by scoring 55 points in an 85-74 P.S.A.L. playoff victory over Tilden. The 6-foot 2-inch senior guard hit 21 of 28 field-goal attempts and 13 of 18 free throws, and had 14 rebounds and 10 assists.

title: Swift Currents, Muddy Waters Off Libya
description: Libya's Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, who is under permanent suspicion in Washington of being up to no good, appeared last week to have justified such nasty expectations, causing considerable confusion in the process.

title: Subway Numbers
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert S. Garrick Weds Laurie L. Volk
description: Laurie Louise Volk, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Quinton Volk Jr. of San Marino, Calif., was married yesterday to Robert S. Garrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. B. John Garrick of Santa Ana, Calif. The Rev. Dennis Denning performed the ceremony at the Community Church.

title: Morris Accusations
description: Reports filed by inmates and guards at the Dade County Jail accuse Eugene (Mercury) Morris of roughing up a juvenile inmate and having unauthorized contact with a female visitor, according to The Miami Herald, which says it obtained a copy of the reports. Ronald Strauss, an attorney for Morris, the former Miami Dolphin running back who is serving a minimum prison term of 15 years for trafficking in cocaine, said the reports were generally ''fallacious.''

title: Summer Jobs Program Registering Youngsters
description: The New York City Partnership, a group of business and civic leaders, will begin registering economically disadvantaged young people tomorrow for its summer jobs program. Forms may be filled out until March 25 at high schools and community centers and on the campuses of the City University.

title: Susan A. Sanders Wed to S.J. Fier
description: Susan Andrea Sanders, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Robert Sanders Jr. of Short Hills, N.J., and Steven J. Fier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Fier of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Stratton, Vt., were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed in the Tower Suite by the Rev. Robert Nunn, a Presbyterian minister, and Rabbi Bert A. Siegel.

title: EVIDENCE ON OSSINING MAY GO TO GRAND JURY IN WESTCHESTER
description: A grand jury investigation of last month's uprising at the State Correctional Facility at Ossining could lead to kidnapping and other charges against some inmates, the Westchester County District Attorney said yesterday.

title: GOSPEL SALUTE
description: Cissy Houston, the gospel singer, will present a ''Salute to Black Women'' at Essex County College in Newark Wednesday evening. The performance, like the other items in this week's guide, is one of the events in the state marking Black History Month.

title: NEW FINDINGS ABOUT CANCER RAISING HOPE
description: Scientists believe they are closing in fast on the secrets of cancer, a disease that has mystified them for centuries.

title: RECENT DISKS CELEBRATE CHAMBER MUSIC'S RICHES
description: Goethe once likened the playing of chamber music to a ''discourse between reasonable individuals.'' If so, it's a discourse with a lot of outside interest. The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center habitually fills Alice Tully Hall for its weekend concerts, while less celebrated groups proliferate throughout the city. Since the chamber repertory is so large - Haydn alone wrote 60-odd string quartets, as well as over 200 compositions for the obsolete baryton - there is much rich material left to discover, and always more on the way. Several recent recordings offer involving new music, as well as the opportunity to re-evaluate lesser known works of composers past.

title: MISSOURI DIOXIN CLEANUP: A DECADE OF LITTLE ACTION
description: The long and unhappy story of dioxin contamination that is unfolding across Missouri began one day in late 1971 when Judy Piatt got into her bronze-colored Buick sedan, determined to find out what was killing her beloved appaloosas and quarter horses.

title: FOR SALE
description: New York City keeps trying to get out of the landlord business. Not only does it try every other month to auction off some of its 15,000 properties, but it also resorts to special promotions to interest developers in buying and developing unusual properties.

title: October Wedding For Carolyn Rider
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Decker Rider of New Canaan, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Carolyn Decker Rider, to Michael Timothy Martin, son of Mrs. Robert David Martin of Guilderland, N.Y., and the late Mr. Martin. An October wedding is planned.

title: 13 Slain in Seattle Club
description: Twelve men and a woman were shot and killed at a Chinatown gambling club, apparently in an attempted robbery. Page 26.

title: RETRAIN EXECUTIVES AND BUREAUCRATS
description: AFEW years ago energy experts were being asked when oil prices wouldr each $60 a barrel. Today, the question is how far prices will fall a nd whether $20-a-barrel oil is good or bad. This debate, like those b efore it, focuses on the wrong question: Its concern with $20 oil i mplies a predictability about oil prices that simply does not exist.

title: NEW CORRECTIONS CHIEF IS SWORN IN
description: WHITE PLAINS AT some time during his nine years on the State Board of Parole, the county's new Corrections Commissioner earned the nickname ''Maximum John.''

title: JERSEY'S NEW CANCER CENTER GETS A DIRECTOR
description: Dr. David M. Goldenberg, an internationally known cancer researcher at the University of Kentucky, has signed a letter of intent to head the new cancer research and treatment center at the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey, Governor Kean announced today.

title: SHORTER IS BETTER
description: The short story is the last refuge of the imagination. That, of course, is the kind of zealous overstatement you might expect from a recent convert. For years I have existed on a steady diet of novels, and for years I have shared the common presumption that short stories are literary snacks, to be consumed before or between novels. But on the basis of six months' voracious reading of stories, I'm ready to declare that there's more variety, energy, idiosyncrasy and innovation in American fiction than most novel readers will ever suspect.

title: No Headline
description: Louisville Tops Memphis St.

title: ITALIAN DRAWINGS TESTIFY TO A CURATOR'S TASTE
description: One of the stranger facts about the Metropolitan Museum is that not until December 1960, when its first centenary was already in sight, did it get itself an independent department of drawings. It was, in fact, a visiting English scholar, Philip Pouncey, who made it clear to the trustees of the Met in the late 50's that the establishment of such a department was long overdue.

title: Catherine Draney Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Draney of Hicksville, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catherine M. Draney, to Edward F. Mead Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Mead of Plainview, L.I.

title: Navy Astronaut Will Be First To Fly Space Shuttle 3 Times
description: Capt. Robert L. Crippen of the Navy, who piloted the first flight of the space shuttle Columbia, has been named as commander of the 13th shuttle flight, making him the first astronaut to take a shuttle into space three times.

title: Madolyn Nagley Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth F. Nagley of Birmingham, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Madolyn Sue Nagley, to Harald Gerhard Greve, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Greve of Princeton, N.J. An April 9 wedding is planned. Miss Nagley is a vice president of sales for Jonathan Bennett Neckwear in New York. Mr. Greve is a project engineer with Feld, Kaminetsky & Cohen, New York consulting engineers.

title:
DINING OUT;
OPEN KITCHEN: PLUSES AND MINUSES
description: LE BISTRO, an intimate little restaurant in the Delaware River hamlet of Stockton, was given two stars in 1978. It changed hands a couple of years ago, and the current chef, John Case, has kept to the same format, that of an appealing, eclectic menu of French, American and Italian dishes that he finishes in the open kitchen at the center of the dining room.

title:
GARDENING;
MORE ABOUT THE BUTTERCUP FAMILY
description: THE buttercup family, Ranunculaceae, was the focus of last week's column. Several genera including Aconitum, the monkshoods; Adonis; Anemone and Aquilegia, the columbines, were noted as being desirable garden subjects. We now continue with additional worthwhile members of this plant family.

title: JUDGE IS OVERRULED IN MIDWIFE CASE
description: PRINCETON THE state's Board of Medical Examiners has unanimously reprimanded Lonnie Holtzman Morris, a prominent New Jersey nurse-midwife, and placed her license on one year's probation, despite the recommendation of an Administrative Law Judge that all charges against her be dismissed.

title: Trying Again, Losing Again
description: Opponents of Jersey City Mayor Gerald McCann failed to throw him out of office with a recall drive, and now they have failed to throw out his office. By a better than 3-to-1 margin, voters last week chose to retain the present form of government - and Mr. McCann - rather than return to the city commission that was abandoned in 1961.

title: NEW PLAN FOR A TROUBLED VILLAGE
description: FOR years, Hempstead Village on Long Island has been fighting problems that are more often found in i nner cities than in the suburbs. In the mid-1960's, many poor blacksm oved in and many middle-class whites moved out. Property values b egan to decline and crime began to rise.

title: Madrid
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
MORE ABOUT THE BUTTERCUP FAMILY
description: THE buttercup family, Ranunculaceae, was the focus of last week's column. Several genera including Aconitum, the monkshoods; Adonis; Anemone and Aquilegia, the columbines, were noted as being desirable garden subjects. We now continue with additional worthwhile members of this plant family.

title: Mailbox Battle
description: After stuffing residents' mailboxes with fliers for years, civic groups in Greenburgh, N.Y., came a cropper in 1976. The postmaster in Westchester County warned one, the Saw Mill Civic Association, that it was violating a 1934 law and subject to a $300 fine for each offense.

title: FORECAST FOR E.P.A. WAS STORMY FROM THE START
description: WASHINGTON THE storm now breaking over the Environmental Protection Agency was clearly presaged, to anyone with a weather eye for political crises, by a series of lightning flashes that began almost simultaneously with the advent of the Reagan Administration.

title: RANDI C. FEINBERG AND DR. PAUL NEUSTEIN ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Feinberg of Short Hills, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Randi Cara Feinberg, to Dr. PUAL Neustein, son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Neustein of Linden, N.J. A March wedding is planned.

title: ANOTHER NAME FOR MADNESS
description: If Alzheimer's disease is detected early, patients may be helped by memory training, which can be taught by any speech therapist. Although this does not reverse the process of the disease itself, it may slow down the progress of memory loss and help patients to cope better. HESKEL M. HADDAD, M.D. New York City ------

title: The New York Times Book Review February 20, 1983
description: NONFICTION AFTER LONG SILENCE. By Michael Straight. 1 ALEXANDER OF RUSSIA: Napoleon's Conqueror. By Henri Troyat. 8 BRECHT IN EXILE. By Bruce Cook. 14 DESCENT FROM GLORY: Four Generations of the John Adams Family.

title: Trainer Suspended
description: Maryland's racing stewards have suspended a trainer, King T. Leatherbury, for 15 days because the drug theobromine was found in the post-race tests of a winning horse at Laurel last December. State Steward J. Fred Colwell said that testimony in several private hearings revealed that Leatherbury had bought a vitamin supplement with cocoa flavoring that included the prohibited substance. The drug was found in tests of the gelding Flush N Diamonds, who won a Dec. 21 race.

title: ABOUT WESTCHESTER
description: SCARSDALE BASKETBALL is not a chic sport. It doesn't have the trendy cachet of racquetball or tennis or squash, or the old-guard allure of golf. Men don't learn to play basketball in order to meet business contacts.

title: EVOLUTION OF A SWAMP
description: THE muscles of the pond across the road from our house barely move under their skin of thin, transparent ice. The ice is so new and delicate that it has water's reflecting qualities. It mirrors the tops of trees and holds to itself the image of winter clouds.

title: P.L.O. WINS MAINLY CONSOLATION PRIZES
description: ALGIERS AN air of unreality hung over last week's deliberations of the Palestine National Council, an overriding sense that the Palestinians still had not adjusted to the events of last summer in Lebanon or found a relevant new strategy to guide them through their post-Beirut phase.

title: KNICKS GET ASSIST FROM BENCH TO WIN
description: Sly Williams and Louis Orr, who substituted when Len (Truck) Robinson and Bernard King got into early foul trouble, led the Knicks to a 124-115 victory over the Denver Nuggets last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: SCHEVENINGEN, NORTH SEA SPA FOR ALL SEASONS
description: MARYLIN BENDER is the author, with Selig Altschul, of ''The Chosen Instrument: Juan Trippe and Pan Am, The Rise and Fall of An American Entrepreneur'' (Simon & Schuster).

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Double Exposure The tragic life of Frances Farmer, the Hollywood actress of the 1930's and 40's, is getting much attention. There is the feature film ''Frances,'' currently playing around the country; and now a new TV movie, ''Will There Really be a Morning?'' The CBS-television version, based on Miss Farmer's autobiography, will be broadcast Tuesday from 8 to 11 P.M. Susan Blakely, one of the starring trio of ''Rich Man, Poor Man,'' will portray the ill-fated star, the role for which Jessica Lange has earned critical acclaim in the feature film.

title: LEADING THE DEMOCRATS ON WASHINGTON'S BUDGET BATTLEFIELD
description: WASHINGTON DURING his 12 years in the Florida legislature, Lawton Chiles sometimes styled himself as a ''progressive conservative,'' a label that suggests one leg on each side of the fence.

title: Mary Strong Brooks Wed to Richard Tilghman Jr.
description: At St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan, Conn., yesterday Mary Strong Brooks, daughter of Mrs. John W. Brooks of Bedford, N.Y., and Harold C. Strong Jr. of New York, was married to Richard A. Tilghman Jr., son of State Senator and Mrs. Tilghman of Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. Frank C. Strasburger performed the ceremony.

title: Campaneris Gets Chance
description: Bert Campaneris, who helped the Oakland A's win three straight World Series in the early 1970's, will get a chance to win a job as a utility infielder with the Yankees.

title: Turks Go Home Is Still the Cry
description: Spyros Kyprianou was re-elected President of two-thirds of Cyprus last week, and immediately renewed his efforts to claim the rest of it.

title: Bowler Strikes Out
description: Joe Salvemini rolled three strikes in the 10th frame today to beat Johnny Petraglia, 206-200, in the final of the $125,000 St. Louis stop of the professional bowling tour. Salvemini, a 27-year-old left-hander from Reno, had previously finished no higher than 33d in a pro tournament. He earned $20,000 today.

title: ISLANDERS ROUT CANADIENS, 5-0, AND FLYERS DEFEAT RANGERS, 8-5 & Ryan Walter
description: The Islanders, displaying strong forechecking and crisp and accurate passing, dominated the Montreal Canadiens and won, 5-0, at Nassau Coliseum today.

title: A June Wedding Is Being Planned By Miss McCune
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Foster McCune of Bethesda, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Rebecca McCune, to Thomas Sanford Jewett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Freeborn Garrettson Jewett Jr. of McLean, Va.

title: Kitzbuhel
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: N. CAROLINA LOSES 3D IN A ROW Carolina's Brad Daugherty

title: Court to Hear Dispute on Bulls
description: On Tuesday, eight days of hearings begin in United States District Court here that could shift ownership of the Chicago Bulls of the National Basketball Association to Marvin Fishman, the Milwaukee realtor who helped to organize the Milwaukee Bucks.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
VERDI'S 'REQUIEM'
description: Although originally composed in 1874 as a mass to honor the 19thcentury poet-novelist Alessandro Manzoni, Verdi's ''Requiem'' has survived in spectacular nonsecular fashion; it's known as much for its passionate theatricality as for its religious underpinnings. Today, the Concert Orchestra of Long Island will tackle all aspects of what has been called one of the greatest works of that century when it offers the ''Requiem'' at the C.W. Post Center's Concert Theater in Brookville.

title: THE SOLDIER'S GENERAL
description: A GENERAL'S LIFE An Autobiography. By Omar N. Bradley and Clay Blair. Illustrated. 752 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: BALLET TO TOUR THE STATE WITH 'CARMINA'
description: NEW BRUNSWICK ABALLET as demanding as ''Carmina Burana'' is a challenge for any dance company. And Caroline Clark, executive director of the New Jersey Ballet, is the first to admit that presenting a statewide tour of Carl Orff's scenic cantata of medieval verse is something of a major accomplishment.

title: 2 REVIVED THEATERS SEARCH FOR NICHE
description: CAN professional theater find happiness - and financial viability - on Long Island? That's the question under consideration as revivals are presented in refurbished old theater buildings in two North Shore communities. In Great Neck, the Long Island Playhouse offers the touring New Globe Theater's production of Oscar Wilde's ''Importance of Being Earnest.'' It opened to generally favorable reviews last week.

title: Defense Budget: The Uncuttables
description: As it did last year, the Defense Department told Congress last week that any cuts in its budget request would mean the elimination of badly needed weapons. And as they did last year, key legislators vowed to trim the request.

title: A BRIGHT FUTURE FOR AMERICAN FURNITURE
description: Following two highly successful American furniture auctions held in New York at Christie's and Sotheby Parke Bernet late last month, the question arose whether these sales are an accurate barometer of the market, or are exceptions to it.

title: BRINGING THE WORLD INTO THE CLASSROOM
description: When John C. Burton became dean of the Columbia Business School last July, one of his first administrative decisions was to eliminate the school's international business division. But it proved to be the beginning of a series of steps to strengthen the international focus at Columbia.

title: DECISION DUE ON NEW NAVY FIGHTER-BOMBER
description: Sitting on the desks of Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger and his new deputy, Paul W. Thayer, are papers that will determine the future of a large segment of naval aviation and affect the fortunes of five large military contractors.

title: EX-WALLFLOWER NOW BLOSSOMS
description: When Anne Beatts looks back on her high school years in Somers, N. Y., in the early 1960's, she recalls how no one would dance with her at the freshman dance. ''I went home and cried,'' she says. She also has memories of how classmates called her ''Four Eyes'' because of her thick glasses, or ''String Bean Beatts'' because she was so thin and flat-chested.

title: The Jeu de Paume
description: To the Editor: In the Letters column (Travel, Dec. 19) a correspondent says he visited the ultimate tourist spot, the Jeu de Pomme. The correct name of the museum in Paris with the Impressionist paintings referred to is the Musee du Jeu de Paume, named for a court where the old form of tennis was played, with the palm (paume).

title: MOLIERE A LOSER ON GEORGE ST.
description: NEW BRUNSWICK THE George Street Playhouse announces its rambunctious staging of ''The Doctor in Spite of Himself'' ''with apologies to Moliere and almost everyone else.''

title: THE AGING OF JAPAN'S AUTO INDUSTRY
description: NOT long ago, seated in a bar in Tokyo's Ginza District, a Japanese auto executive offered the kind of personal view of his industry that seems fairly common here these days. He made no mention of profit projections or engine specifications or miles per gallon.

title: Two Climbers Die in Wales
description: Two climbers fell to their deaths from a peak in the Snowdon range and six others were hospitalized. A 16-year-old boy ran nearly five miles to a farmhouse to report that his companions in a party of seven boys and two teachers from a London school had fallen Friday while climbing the 3,000-foot Craig-yr-Ysfa ridge.

title: Protestations
description: To the Business Editor:

title: PATH MARKS DIAMOND JUBILEE
description: FIVE years ago this Friday -at 3:40 P.M. on Feb. 25, 1908 - President Theodore Roosevelt pressed a button in the White House that sent a train on a ceremonial first trip between Jersey City and Lower Manhattan.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Bali
description: To the Editor:

title: Catherine Sibbitts Is Wed To John Miller, Engineer
description: Catherine Sibbitts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert LaVack of Gouverneur, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Sault Miller, son of Dr. and Mrs. Harry Miller of Manhasset, L.I. Cantor Richard Berman performed the ceremony at the Miller home.

title: INDIAN PORTRAITS BY KIHN EXHIBITED
description: HIS home state is finally according W. Langdon Kihn, an artist noted for his portraits of North American Indians, the recognition his admirers feel is his due. ''Portraits of Native Americans,'' an exhibition of crayon and pastel drawings done on field trips to the West and Canada from 1920 to 1937, can be seen at the Davison Art Center Gallery at Wesleyan University in Middletown through March 10.

title: 'THE KING OF COMEDY' DELIVERS A PASSIONLESS STING
description: Rupert Pupkin: That's the name of the main character in Martin Scorsese's ''King of Comedy,'' though people sometimes call him Mr. Pipkin or Mr. Pumpkin by mistake. On the basis of his name alone, Rupert inspires a mild disdain; in the flesh, he has much the same effect. He's a pesty, obsessive autograph hound who lives for show business and show business alone, and ''The King of Comedy'' is his story. But why?

title: U.S. Reactor on Coast Has Radioactive Leak
description: Up to 200,000 gallons of radioactive water a day may be leaking from a basin holding spent fuel rods from a reactor at the Government's Hanford nuclear reservation.

title: 'Samaritan' Story
description: Abraham Newman, then 83 years old, was walking on the boardwalk at Brighton Beach in Brooklyn in 1980 when he saw a young man assaulting a woman. Mr. Newman tried to help the woman, but the assailant grabbed his cane, beat him and broke his hip.

title: ANOTHER NAME FOR MADNESS
description: In response to the article on Alzheimer's disease, in which I was quoted, I feel I have to make my position clear.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
A CASE FOR HOLDING MILITARY PORTION OF TAX FROM I.R.S.
description: PRESIDENT REAGAN will sacrifice food, jobs and medical care, but he will not consider reductions in the war budget. Last month, an article in the Westchester Weekly section celebrated $150 million of military expenditures in the county, giving glowing reviews to the local business it generates.

title: IT'S A BIG SACRIFICE FOR JUNK-FOOD JOBS
description: FOR minimum-wage workers, purchasing power has been substantially e roded by inflation in recent years. The minimum wage would need to b e $4.14 an hour today to equal the buying power of the $2.65-an-hourm inimum wage in effect in 1978, the last time Congress changed the l aw. This loss of purchasing power greatly injures America's l owestpaid families, making them even more dependent upon Government s upport.

title: FINISHING ANOTHER SCHUBERT SYMPHONY
description: The word ''unfinished'' is generally used to define just one Schubert Symphony -the ''Unfinished'' Symphony No. 8, of course. But there is another Schubert unfinished symphony - No. 7 in E, which the composer sketched in orchestral score in 1821 and never got around to completing.

title: MUSIC: BENITA VALENTE, LYRIC SOPRANO
description: Benita Valente has had a curious career. It has not been an unsuccessful one - her voluminous program biography easily refutes that notion. The curiosity lies in the discrepancy between her prodigious gifts and her relative lack of renown.

title: AN EYE FOR RELATED SHAPES
description: STIEGLITZ A Memoir/Biography. By Sue Davidson Lowe. Illustrated. 456 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $25.50.

title: CORPORATE BARTER ON THE UPSWING
description: DIVERSIFIED PRODUCTS INC., a manufacturer of sporting goods, last y ear had excess inventory $4.4 million worth of racquetball r acquets, gloves, bags and covers, and various other pieces of s porting equipment.

title: Gretzky Gets 50th Goal As Oilers Win by 10-7
description: Wayne Gretzky scored two goals, including his 50th of the season in the third period, to lead the Edmonton Oilers to a 10-7 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight.

title: 'PLAYING OUR SONG' FULL OF FALSE NOTES
description: ELMSFORD ''THEY'RE PLAYING OUR SONG'' is a semiautobiographical minimusical. It contains two characters. In Charles Repole's staging at An Evening Dinner Theater, one of them is just right.

title: NEW ROCHELLE'S LONG BLACK HISTORY
description: NEW ROCHELLE ONE of the country's first communities of free blacks existed in New Rochelle before the Revolutionary War. Black residents fought in both the Revolutionary and Civil Wars. A house on Long Island Sound with secret tunnels and attic passages is believed to have been a stop on the Underground Railroad. And in 1698, of a population of a few hundred, 14 percent was black, while today, of 73,000 people in the city, the figure is about 18 percent black.

title: CABARET: MISS DE LAURENTIS
description: A performer who attempts to be both funny and serious runs the risk that one approach will obscure the other. But Semina De Laurentis, who was at Don't Tell Mama, 343 West 46th Street, last week and will be back starting Wednesday, is a brilliant comedian and an exquisite singer who combines her talents so skillfully that they give her performance a remarkable scope.

title: CUOMO STANCE SHARPENS FIGHT OVER SHOREHAM
description: WHEN Governor Cuomo interceded last week in the debate over the evacuation plans for the Shoreham nuclear power plant, his action crystallized the consensus that had been building among Suffolk County officials.

title: BLIZZARD BRINGS JOY TO RESORTS
description: CONNECTICUT was transformed into a winter wonderland this past week following last weekend's blizzard which dumped more than two feet of snow over most of the state.

title: FOLLOWING U.S., EUROPE AWAKENS TO THE DANGERS OF TOXIC WASTES
description: The following article was written by Paul Lewis of The New York Times Paris bureau, based on his reporting and that of Times bureaus in Bonn, London and Rome. GOUDERAK, HOLLAND

title: TYPICAL RUNNERS NEED NOT FEAR ANOREXIA
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSTON FEARS A BOND RATING SLIP AS BOOM ECONOMY FALTERS
description: Boom-town Houston, long the envy of financially troubled cities in much of the rest of country for its robust fiscal health, is beginning to wheeze a bit, and this has city officials fearing that its bond credit rating may slip a notch from its rare and long-held triple-A rating.

title: INFLATION FEARS AND THE ADVANCE OF GOLD
description: THE price of gold has been hovering around the $500 an ounce mark in recent weeks after rising sharply from $298 l ast June, its lowest point since the wild speculation of 1979-80. B ut many traders now believe gold, after a round of profit taking, w ill go much higher.

title: LABOR DEALS WITH HARD TIMES, NEW TECHNOLOGY
description: WASHINGTON UNION leaders representing more than 3.6 million workers have prepared their negotiators for new contract talks this year that labor and management both believe will end in few, if any, givebacks. But these negotiations may establish new patterns in collective bargaining, with increased emphasis on such non-wage issues as retraining and job security that will affect both sides for many years.

title: SPRING TRAINING: A FAN'S NOTES
description: IRA BERKOW is a sports columnist for The New York Times.

title: SOUTHOLD SEEKS HORSE LIMIT
description: HORSES are leaping through loopholes in Southold Town, where an oversight in the town code allows them to graze in unlimited numbers in residential areas.

title: A COZY CORNER FOR CAROLINA'S FURNITURE CRAFTSMEN
description: DURHAM, N.C. ''A few years ago, people would purchase furniture on impulse,'' said Charles Greene, president of Classic Gallery Inc. in High Point, N.C. ''But not any more. Now they buy more carefully, more like an automobile purchase. The American love affair used to be with the car; now it is with the home.''

title: HANDLING DEAFNESS IN A MODERN WAY
description: AT the office for the Disabled in White Plains, September Polk, a staff interpreter, answers the phone. A light attached to the console indicates that the call requires the use of special equipment. She places the receiver in a cradle extension, and types on the phone keyboard: ''Office for the Disabled. This is September Polk. May I help you? - GA (Go Ahead).''

title: STATE TERMS FAKE DOCTORS GROWING PERIL
description: Walter Ian Fischman has published dozens of books for the home handyman and hobbyist. Among the titles are ''101 Projects for Bottle Cutters'' and ''How to Finish Off Your Basement or Attic.''

title: LIBERAL CZAR
description: ALEXANDER OF RUSSIA Napoleon's Conqueror. By Henri Troyat. Translated by Joan Pinkham. Illustrated. 335 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $17.95.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: BRECHT IN EXILE By Bruce Cook. 237 pp. New York: A New Republic Book/ Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $17.95.

title: Q&A
description: Question:Several months ago I read an article that mentioned two restaurants in Israel well known for their preparation of vegetables. As I am planning a trip there in April, I would like to know their names and locations. - G.K., Houston, Tex. Answer:Stuffed vegetables, also called mahshi, are staple dishes in the Middle East and the specialty of several restaurants in Jerusalem and Tel Aviv.

title: OFTEN SOLO, OFTEN DUO
description: ONE day a couple of years ago, Melvin Berger of Great Neck was giving a viola recital at Lincoln Center in New York City. In the audience, one woman said to another: ''Do you want to hear something strange? I have a number of science books in my library written by somebody with the exact same name as the violist.''

title: 'PIRATES' BROUGHT FROM STAGE TO SCREEN
description: ''The Pirates of Penzance'' has been made into a cheerful movie, but it isn't nearly as deft or distinctive here as it was on stage. The principal cast is still on hand, and still a delight, with the felicitous addition of Angela Lansbury to a group already including Kevin Kline, Rex Smith, George Rose, Linda Ronstadt and Tony Azito. The same director, Wilford Leach, is also here, and he has moved from the stage to the screen less successfully than the players. Mr. Leach's stage production was buoyant and charming. But in adapting it for film, he has too infrequently seen fit to leave well enough alone.

title: POLICE IN TRENTON KILL ARMED MAN
description: A man who threatened two plainclothes police officers with a 12-inch knife was shot dead and one officer was hospitalized with a bullet wound Friday after a fight outside a bar, the police said.

title: THE HOUSE WHERE JENNY WAS KISSED
description: PYKE JOHNSON Jr. retired managing editor of Doubleday, lives in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: Knight Explains
description: Bobby Knight, the Indiana University basketball coach, says he was only speaking humorously when he made a remark in December that caused the governor of Puerto Rico to ask for Knight's removal as coach of the United States Olympic basketball team in 1984. At a dinner in Gary, Ind., Knight said that when he left Puerto Rico after the 1979 Pan American Games, he dropped his pants ''because that's the last thing I wanted those people to see of me.''

title: KITE WIDENS LEAD TO 4 STROKES AT 201
description: Tom Kite turned back several challenges with a four-under-par 68 today and took a four-stroke lead at 201 after three rounds of the $300,000 San Diego Open.

title: AGENCY FOR ELDERLY IN DISPUTE ON FUNDS
description: SINCE February last year, 62-year-old Ann Marie Citron, a lively and articulate woman, has been living in a ranch-style house in East Northport. She has a private bedroom and shares the use of a living room and kitchen. Although these may seem like modest accommodations, she speaks of them with pride and gratitude.

title: AN ISRAELI SCHOLAR STIRS A-ARMS TOPIC
description: In the debate that Israelis constantly conduct on their country's military and political policies, the subject of nuclear weaponry commands only silence. But an Israeli political scientist has now stepped into this void of debate with what is apparently the first book-length examination by an Israeli of Israeli nuclear strategy.

title: Speed Limit
description: To the Editor:

title: Reagan's Sources
description: To the Business Editor:

title: LIBYA ACCUSES U.S. SHIPS AND PLANES OF JAMMING
description: The Libyan Government of Col. Muammar el-Q@addafi charged today that United States espionage planes and warships were jamming Libyan communications. It said the Gulf of Sidra would become a bay of ''blood and fire'' if the carrier Nimitz from the Sixth Fleet entered its waters.

title: ADDICTION FICTION
description: THE WASHINGTON SQUARE ENSEMBLE By Madison Smartt Bell. 342 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $15.75.THE TRANSFER By Thomas Palmer. 402 pp. New Haven and New York: Ticknor & Fields. $14.95.

title: Dr. Cynthia A. Swann To Marry a Physician
description: Dr. and Mrs. Raymond O. Swann of Kalamazoo, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Cynthia Ann Swann, to Dr. W. Lawrence Greif, son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Greif of Potomac, Md. A May 28 wedding is planned in Kalamazoo.

title: PINTER'S 'BETRAYAL,' DIRECTED BY DAVID JONES
description: Harold Pinter, the justifiably celebrated English playwright, has done a lot of film work, sometimes adapting his own plays (''The Caretaker,'' ''The Birthday Party'') and sometimes adapting the works of others (''The Servant,'' ''Accident,'' ''The French Lieutenant's Woman,'' among others).

title: Nonwhite South Africa Group Is Split on Government Plan
description: South Africa's major nonwhite political grouping today suspended the membership of the Labor Party for agreeing to take part in the Government's proposed constitutional revisions.

title: POP: MORGANA KING, SINGER, AT TUESDAY'S
description: Morgana King's mannered pop singing, with its stealthy phrasing, foggy timbre and other-worldly high notes, isn't a style suited to the broadest spectrum of pop music. But given well chosen ballads and sensitive instrumental support, Miss King can weave an intoxicating spell.

title: Ann R. Cox, Teacher, Is Married to John E. Taylor
description: Ann Rebecca Cox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Cox of New York, was married yesterday to John Ellis Taylor, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John E. Taylor of Boonton, N.J. The Rev. Frederick Fenton performed the ceremony at St. Augustine-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Santa Monica, Calif.

title: Boston
description: To the Editor:

title: BRAZIL'S CURRENCY IS DEVALUED 30%
description: Brazil has announced a 30 percent devaluation of its currency in a move that dramatizes its continuing difficulty in ending its economic crisis.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The information we have leads us to believe that some material that was on computer tapes may have been destroyed.'' - Stanley M. Brand, general counsel to the Clerk of the House, speaking of E.P.A. documents. (1:2.)

title: Botha's Cards On the Table
description: South Africa's Prime Minister P.W. Botha last week offered to stop harassing his neighbors, if and when they show they tacitly accept his system of white rule and help insulate it from the ''Communists'' he says are bent on its destruction.

title: REDISTRICTING TO ADDRESS ISSUE OF MINORITY VOTERS
description: LAST year, when county legislators had their yearly breakfast with members of the Westchester County Association, a questioner posed this challenge when the subject turned to redistricting, or redrawing the county legislative lines: ''What do you intend to do about minority representation?''

title: BREAKS WITH OPEC; NORTH SEA CRUDE SET PACE; West African Producer's Move Seen by Analysts as Step to Further Reductions
description: Nigeria announced Saturday night that it would cut the price of its crude oil by $5.50 a barrel to match the price of North Sea oil after price cuts Friday by Britain and Norway.

title: Ford Pays Man $12.4 Million
description: The Ford Motor Company has ended a 13-year legal battle by paying $12.4 million to James Hasson, 32 years old, of Sherman Oaks, who was disabled by brain injuries he suffered in an automobile accident in 1970 when the brakes of his father's Lincoln Continental failed.

title: Miss McKinney Takes Giant Slalom for 2d Title
description: Tamara McKinney won her second national title in two days by winning the giant slalom today in the United States Alpine skiing championships.

title: JEWISH ODYSSEY
description: To the Editor: In an otherwise commendable article, Margaret Croyden perhaps inadvertently makes light of what is a very significant and painful matter.

title:
GARDENING;
MORE ABOUT THE BUTTERCUP FAMILY
description: THE buttercup family, Ranunculaceae, was the focus of last week's column. Several genera including Aconitum, the monkshoods; Adonis; Anemone and Aquilegia, the columbines, were noted as being desirable garden subjects. We now continue with additional worthwhile members of this plant family.

title: JEWISH ART OBJECTS STOLEN FROM 92D ST. Y EXHIBIT
description: Thieves stole about 18 religious objects Friday night or Saturday morning from an exhibition and sale of ceremonial Jewish art at the 92d Street Y, the police said.

title: Quality in Quantity
description: ''Dinner at the Homesick Restaurant,'' Anne Tyler's ninth critically acclaimed novel, was the first of her books to become a best seller, and it's about to be launched in paperback with the bigbook treatment usually reserved for work critics dismiss as ''commercial.''

title: OPERA: MOZART AND PURCELL
description: The hapless Opera Ensemble of New York unveiled John J.D. Sheehan's new production of Mozart's ''Bastien and Bastienne'' and Henry Purcell's ''Dido and Aeneas'' during the Feb. 11 storm. But those who fought their way through the snow to the Lillie Blake School Theater were rewarded by an uneven but enjoyable production, which will run through next Sunday at the Lillie Blake School Theater, at 45 East 81st Street.

title:
WEEK IN BUSINESS;
FOR FED WATCHERS, YET ANOTHER CLUE
description: Vintage Volcker. In last week's standing-room-only appearance before the Senate Banking Committee, Fed chairman Paul A. Volcker (right) took the oath again to encourage both recovery and lower inflation. Precisely how remains the question. But the chairman gave Fed watchers a new clue to future central bank behavior. They should keep one eye on the M's and the other eye on a new statistic: total borrowings by nonfinancial businesses, households and governments. The market's response to Mr. Volcker's recital: rates up, down, flat.

title: 3 HOUSE PANELS UNHAPPY AT PLAN FOR E.P.A. PAPERS
description: Two House subcommittee chairmen said today that despite a compromise allowing House investigators access to subpoenaed Environmental Protection Agency documents, they would continue to press for full control of the material.

title: Summer Wedding For Lori Howard
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry S. Howard Jr. of Carefree, Ariz., and Ripon, Quebec, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lori Elizabeth Howard, to Peter Gerard Thomas, son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Thomas Jr. of Montvale, N.J.

title: Mary Ellen Darcy to Wed Harry Austin 3d in the Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph T. Darcy of East Hanover, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Ellen Darcy, to Harry G. Austin 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Austin Jr., of Gibsonia, Pa.

title: JOEY WAITS HIS TURN TO BE THE MEYER CALLED 'COACH'
description: CHICAGO JOEY MEYER moves serenely, dribbling under the basket, lightly flipping the ball over his shoulder toward the hoop. Practice for the DePaul University basketball team will soon begin, and Meyer, an assistant coach and son of the head coach, Ray Meyer, shoots baskets with the players, joking with one, teasing another and moving effortlessly with the ball.

title:
ART;
O'KEEFFE AND NEVELSON WORKS IN RARE JUXTAPOSITON
description: OF all the American artists who have come to prominence in this century, the painter Georgia O'Keeffe (born in 1887) and the sculptor Louise Nevelson (born in 1899) are among the most renowned. Their achievements have been acknowledged in retrospective exhibitions, biographies, film portraits and glossy art books, and their works are eagerly sought by museums and private collectors around the world.

title: RADIOLOGIST AT N.Y.U.
description: Dr. Milton Friedman, a cancer specialist and professor of radiology at the New York University School of Medicine from 1956 until his retirement in 1970, died after a stroke Feb. 12 at his home in Greenville, S.C. He was 79 years old.

title: CONTRIBUTORS TO NEEDIEST CITE HOMELESS
description: The plight of the city's homeless men and women during the colder months continues to encourage gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Soviet Disciplines 3 In Embezzlement Case
description: Two officials, including a Deputy Minister of the Soviet aviation industry, have been dismissed and another ministry official has been sentenced to 15 years in connection with an $84,000 embezzlement case, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda said today.

title: THERE'S NO THERE THERE
description: The United States is conducting a remarkable experiment in modern government. It is testing the effects on a great democracy of a vacuum at the center: of a Chief Executive who is scarcely informed on the substance of issues and shows no interest in being informed.

title: NEW STUDY WEIGHS FUTURE OF SPOFFORD CENTER
description: Ellen Schall, who was appointed the city's Commissioner of Juvenile Justice six weeks ago, has begun a study to determine the future of the aging and decrepit Spofford Youth Center in the Bronx.

title: RECENT SALES
description: Cliffside Park $135,000 *2*300 Winston Drive, 2-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*7-year-old condominium; high-rise *2*tower atop Palisades; taxes $2,200. Marlboro $112,000 *2*22 Quebec Road, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath; *2*11-year-old colonial; pool, basement, *2*fireplace; taxes $2,439. Montclair $150,000 *2*156 Highland Avnue, 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, *2*57-year-old Tudor; wood staircase, Manhattan *2*skyline view; taxes $4,735. Oakland $88,000 *2*58 Powhattan Path, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*23-year-old colonial; optional fourth bedroom, *2*wooded lot, heated driveway; taxes $2,280. South Orange $108,000 *2*357 Lenox Avenue, 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*50-year-old colonial; basement, redwood deck; *2*; taxes $2,850. Washington Township $91,600 *2*213 Beacon Hill Road, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2 bath, *2*28-year-old ranch; fireplace, garden *2*shed; taxes $1,976. OTHER AREAS Bay Shore, L.I. $125,000 *2*67 West Lane 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*26-year-old high ranch; fireplace in *2*living room, eat-in kitchen, deck, *2*2-car garage; taxes $5,000. Pound Ridge, NY $495,000 *2*Bamegat Road, 6-bedroom, 4 1/2-bath converted barn; *2*maid's room, wine cellar, pool, cathedral *2*ceilings, patio, 2 acres; taxes $6,309. Morris, Conn. $34,000 *2*East Shore Road 3-bedroom, 1-bath, lakefront *2*cottage, new kitchen, leased land on 1/2 acre, *2*cathedral ceiling, 2-car garage; taxes $1,100.

title: Jewish Odyssey
description: To the Editor: Like Margaret Croyden in her article, ''Jewish Odyssey is Recalled in Tel Aviv'' (Travel, Jan. 2), we, too, were impressed by Beth Hatefutsoth, the Nahum Goldmann Museum of the Jewish Diaspora.

title: HALF WORK DONE ON WESTWAY CALLED USABLE ON ALTERNATES
description: At least half of the more than $75 million that has been spent on the Westway project over the past decade could be applied to an alternate roadway if the embattled superhighway is never built, according to the project's director, Michael J. Cuddy.

title: Millstone A-Plant Shut Down
description: A faulty circuit breaker automatically shut down the Millstone II nuclear power plant this morning, the plant's operator reported. Small amounts of nonradioactive steam were released after the 4:05 A.M. shutdown, said Clifford Hill, a spokesman for Northeast Utilities, which operates the plant.

title: HOW YANKEE-HATING BECAME A FINE ART
description: THE first Yankee-haters were New Yorkers. They were fans of the New York Giants, who preceded the Yankees in town and earned the devotion of local baseball fans. Giant fans had reason to look down on the rest of baseball, and they viewed the Yankees with contempt. Under Manager John McGraw, the Giants won six pennants while the Yankees were still floundering after their first.

title: DEPRESSION IN AGED TERMED REVERSIBLE
description: ALTHOUGH the graying of the county's population is welldocumented, many symptoms commonly thought inevitable in the aging process are actually treatable and reversible symptoms of depression, say researchers at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKIG OF LIVING IN: SCARSDALE
description: SEVERAL years ago, a New Yorker cartoon showed a middle-aged couple w ith suitcases walking down a road marked Scarsdale. They had r ejected two other routes, one to Sodom and the other to Gomorrah. ' 'Let's hope,'' the man was saying to his wife, ''that our decision h asn't been too hasty.''

title: Allison Feigin Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Allen Feigin of Merrick, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Allison Witt Feigin, to Michael DiCandilo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas DiCandilo of Rosemont, Pa. Miss Feigin is a unit manager at the New York Guardian Mortgagee Corporation in Hempstead, L.I. Her fiance is a staff accountant for Ernst & Whinney in Philadelphia.

title: READY TO ACT IN CASE OF A PERSIAN GULF CRISIS
description: To the Editor:

title: A MASTER POTTER-ARTIST IS HONORED
description: QUAKERTOWN ''YOU WORK hard and do the best you can,'' Toshiko Takaezu said recently in reference to her 30 years as a potter. Miss Takaezu's ''best'' has proved excellent enough to bring her international recognition as a master craftsman and academic respect as a faculty member at Princeton University, where 16 years ago she introduced studio ceramics to the curriculum.

title: VALUED VOICES; Mr. Moynihan's Nay
description: It took pluck and principle for Senator Moynihan to decide (''with sorrow but without regret'') to stay away from the St. Patrick's Day parade.

title: Headliners; Death Wishes
description: When Edwin P. Wilson set out to obstruct justice last year he meant to get firmly in its way, according to a Federal indictment handed down in Manhattan last week.

title: Pope Sees Japanese Envoy
description: Ambassador Masami Ota of Japan, who converted from Shinto and Buddhism to Roman Catholicism last month, had a private audience with Pope John Paul II today, the Vatican announced. His term as Ambassador is ending.

title: Tentative Accord in Belgium
description: Belgium's 890,000 public-sector workers have reached preliminary agreement with the Government to take a pay cut to help ease record unemployment. Prime Minister Wilfried Martens said Friday night that the accord was for a 2.5 percent cut in real wages and a one-hour reduction in the working week, to 37 hours, in exchange for the creation of 10,000 new posts.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Golden Anniversary

title: AFTER 7 YEARS, COAST DEATH IS RULED MURDER
description: John T. Langlos was found dead in his blood-spattered office seven years ago. A gash was in his head and his wallet was missing. The Los Angeles County coroner, Thomas T. Noguchi, called it an accident. The wife, Ruth Langlos, called it murder.

title: BABIES WITHOUT RIGHT TO BE A SURPRISE
description: To the Editor:

title: Spain-Morocco Talks Open
description: Spain and Morocco opened talks here today on resolving their longtime disagreements over Spanish fishing boats that work in Moroccan waters and over transporting Moroccan oranges across Spain to reach other European countries.

title: STORY TELLERS
description: EVENING OUT By David Walton. 197 pp. Athens: The University of Georgia Press. $12.95. PASTORALE By Susan Engberg. 161 pp. Urbana: University of Illinois Press. Cloth, $11.95. Paper, $4.95. BABARU By B. Wongar. 102 pp. Urbana: University of Illinois Press. Cloth, $11.95. Paper, $4.95.

title: Warm Water Draws Odd Fish to the Coast
description: Unusually warm Pacific waters off the coast of southern California are drawing varieties of marine life that do not normally winter here, scientists say.

title: ANOTHER NAME FOR MADNESS
description: In the late 1960's, my husband was the recipient of the American Society of Civil Engineers' award for outstanding achievement. He had designed the Kennedy Center, in Washington.

title: SPELLBOUND IN SANTA FE
description: NORMAN ZOLLINGER, a novelist who lives in Albuquerque, is the author of ''Corey Lane'' and ''Riders to Cibola.''

title: KIENAST QUINTUPLETS ENTERING TEENHOOD
description: LIBERTY CORNERS WHEN they were born on Feb. 24, 1970, their arrival was so extraordinary that they made headlines around the world: A young woman from New Jersey had given birth to quintuplets - three girls and two boys - over a 10-minute span at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in New York City.

title: Cairo Conspiracy Trial Resumes After a Recess
description: The trial of 300 Moslem fundamentalists accused of conspiring to overthrow the Egyptian Government after the assassination of President Anwar el-Sadat resumed today after a recess of six weeks.

title: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 20, 1983
