description: International Nigeria cut its oil price by $5.50 a barrel to match the lowered price of North Sea oil after price reductions announced Friday by Britain and Norway. Nigeria's is the first break in the posted pricing structure of the OPEC cartel. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: Jean Aubeck Macy Marries Edward White on Tortola
description: Jean Aubeck Macy and Edward Williams White, managing director of Whyte's Merchant Bank Ltd. and Island Enterprises in Road Town, Tortola, British Virgin Islands, were married there yesterday.

title: POLS AND OTHER PERPETRATORS
description: Chicago, which likes to think of itself as the city primeval, has burst into sensational flower this winter. Tuesday's Democratic mayoral primary has produced some strange growths, and simultaneously the underworld, volcanically disturbed by pressure from the Federal Government, has erupted spectacularly. Not long ago, Allen Dorfman of the teamsters' pension fund was gunned down in a parking lot. Now plea-bargaining witnesses are talking freely about Joey (The Clown) Lombardo, convicted with Dorfman and Roy Williams, the teamsters' union president, of conspiring to bribe Senator Howard W. Cannon of Nevada. Politics are politics, crime is crime, but in Chicago they occasionally overlap. The line between virtue and vice meanders madly - effective government on one side, connections on the other.

title: WASHINGTON WAS HERE
description: The Van Cortlandt Mansion in the Bronx, where Generals Washington and Rochambeau are said to have planned some of the final strategy of the Revolutionary War, will be the site of a concert commemorating our first President's birthday at 2 P.M. today.

title: NEW NEED REPORTED FOR TOXICOLOGISTS
description: THE Tylenol poisonings, food additives and environmental pollution are only a few of the areas of public concern that have led in recent years to legislation controlling toxic substances, creating a ''sudden, dramatic need for scientists who are qualified to assess the harmful effects of chemicals on living organisms.''

title: PROSPECTS
description: A Little Joy at Tax Time

title: ANGER
description: To the Editor:

title:
STAMPS;
A NEW PRESIDENTIAL SERIES ANNOUNCED FOR '86
description: A preview of a major philatelic event, the issuing of a new series for all the Presidents of the United States, has been presented by the postal Service with the unveiling of one of the forthcoming issues in that series. The stamp is for Martin Van Buren, the eighth President of this nation and the first born under the American flag.

title: Iran Rebels Say They Killed 5
description: An Iranian leftist opposition group, the People's Mujahedeen, said today that guerrillas had recently killed five members of Iran's paramilitary corps in three separate clashes.

title: Burglar, 17, Is Jailed Till He Gets Diploma
description: A 17-year-old has been sentenced to the state penitentiary and told he will remain there until he earns his high school diploma.

title: ONE MINUTE TO THINK
description: If a kibitzer sits down to watch a game in which the players are unknown to him, he can sometimes, without looking at a card or hearing a bid, gain a useful clue to the standard of play. If when the dummy appears the declarer plays very quickly, he is probably a weak player. If he takes his time and exerts himself to count his tricks and plan the play, he is very likely quite experienced.

title: MEMORIES OF THE BIGGEST TIMES IN N.Y.U. BASKETBALL loss
description: IN the spring of 1948, N.Y.U. basketball was at its zenith. The team had a great season, capped with a chance to play in the National Invitation Tournament and an invitation to a tournament that would choose that year's Olympic team.

title: FELICITOUS SETTIG IN A HOTEL
description: CHARDONNAYS in the Long Island Marriott Hotel in Uniondale could probably be the envy of many restaurateurs. Here is a new 120-seat restaurant in a new hotel built smack in the middle of the Nassau Coliseum parking lot. The restaurant is filled every night of the week, regardless of whether there is a hockey game.

title: PLAN FOR 2D FERRY IRKS PORT JEFFERSON
description: THE Bridgeport and Port Jefferson Steamboat Company recently raised some hackles among officials in the Town of Brookhaven and the Village of Port Jefferson when it announced plans to add a second ferry this summer.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
MINOR WHITE-THE LAST OF THE ROMANTICS?
description: The photographs taken by the late Minor White from the 1930's to the 60's, though distinctly modern, have a decidedly different look from the work being done by many younger photographers today. They are not in color. They are not torn, pasted, tinted or scribbled on. They do not make jokey little references to the work of commercial photographers in the mass media. And though it is often impossible to say what they mean, it always seems that they do mean something.

title: Signs of Spring, Notes of Caution In the Economy
description: President Reagan has always been quick to share encouraging news from the economic front. So, at the start of a news conference last week, he said that ''the recovery is beginning to flex its muscles,'' thanks to his Administration's programs.

title: AND BEAR IN MIND
description: And Bear in Mind Other recent books that in the opinion of the Book Review staff are of particular literary, topical or scholarly interest: AARON BURR, by Milton Lomask. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.50.) The second volume of a two-volume biography, this one covering the years 1805-36.

title: 15 Food Establishments Cited For Violations of Health Code
description: The New York City Department of Health has released the names of 15 food establishments it said had violated the Health Code. The department also released the names of two establishments that were allowed to reopen after correcting earlier violations and four that were closed for failing to do so.

title: DIP IN NAKASONE BACKING TIED TO ARMS STAND
description: Aides to Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone say they are concerned by what they fear is a drop in popular support because of his policies on increased arms spending and military cooperation with the United States.

title: Joblessness Rates
description: To the Business Editor:

title: A RENEWED VITALITY FOR COUTURE
description: Couture has mellowed into a drowsy dinosaur, a lovely relic of what was once fashion's heart and soul. In the old days - before the ready-to-wear designers and manufac-turers, not only of Paris but of Milan, New York and even Tokyo, took over as the trend setters - the Paris couturier collections were the fountainhead of creativity in clothing. These days, the famous couture houses continue to exist, but usually with substantial deficits that they offset by using their prestigious reputations as marketing devices for their ready-to-wear lines, their perfumes and cosmetics, and all manner of other licensees.

title: Modern Dance Caucus Has Been Established
description: The American Modern Dance Caucus has been established to represent the estimated 4,000 to 5,000 modern dance companies in the United States.

title: Nuclear Plants Are Fined
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has proposed $120,000 in fines for violations of maintenance and parts quality standards at Commonwealth Edison's Dresden and Quad Cities nuclear power plants. The utility does not deny that the violations took place, but says there was no danger to the public.

title: NORTHEAST WASTE DUMP PANEL APPROVES PLAN
description: An 11-state regional group has approved a preliminary compact that is the first step toward establishing a lowlevel nuclear waste dump somewhere in the Northeast.

title: A MAN OF MANY FACETS ADDS BELLINI
description: When the Juilliard American Opera Center decided to mount the first fully staged production in New York in over 130 years of Vincenzo Bellini's two-act opera ''I Capuleti e I Montecchi,'' it engaged an expert on the Berne Copyright Convention as its conductor. To rehearse the orchestra for the performances, which take place this week in the Juilliard Theater on Wednesday and Friday evenings and next Sunday afternoon, it turned to a student of acoustical phenomena with half a dozen technical papers to his credit. The job of coaching the singers was given to a noted authority on the manuscripts of Giuseppe Verdi. The surprising thing about this seemingly chaotic arrangement - which grows less surprising as one gets to know him - is that Denis Vaughan is all of these people.

title: CLEANING UP THE MARKET
description: THE TRANSFORMATION OF WALL STREET A History of the Securities and Exchange Commission and Modern Corporate Finance. By Joel Seligman. 701 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Co. $27.50.

title: A BIT OF FORGOTTEN THESPIANA
description: The Lincoln Theater, a 59-year-old, 275-seat theater in New Haven, has been used to show motion pictures for as long as most local people can remember. Modest in looks, this seemingly inconsequential structure, on part of a three-acre site known as the Audubon Arts Complex, was scheduled for demolition last summer to make way for luxury housing sponsored by the Arts Council of Greater New Haven.

title: CRIME UPDATE
description: POLICE BELIEVE 2 PAINTINGS STOLEN FROM VAN WILL BE OFFERED FOR SALE By LEONARD BUDER

title: WORK, LUCK AND LITTLE DEBT PRODUCE THE GOOD LIFE FOR COUPLE ON IOWA FARM
description: Sally Puttmann doesn't consider herself unusual, but most farmers around here apparently do. Two years ago they elected her the first female president of the Woodbury County Farm Bureau, the local chapter of the country's largest agricultural organization.

title: SOUTH AFRICA SAYS IT KILLED 96 NAMIBIA REBELS
description: West Africa, Feb. 19 (AP) - South African military authorities said tonight that their troops had killed 96 black nationalist guerrillas in the last few days in South-West Africa. They said the rebels had sought to begin a new offensive in the territory.

title: Cheating Children
description: One way to gauge the social and economic health of a nation is by the physical health of its children. By that measure, the United States is pretty healthy: our infant mortality rate has been declining for two decades and now stands at 11.7 deaths per 1,000 births. But during 1981, eight states and 36 local areas - most of which also have increased unemployment rates - reported sharp increases.

title: WEST GERMAN COURT PONDERS IMMUNITY FOR KHOMEINI AIDE
description: A court ruled Friday that a close aide of the Iranian leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, might be entitled to diplomatic immunity against drug smuggling charges, and it adjourned a hearing until Wednesday to give his defense lawyers time to prove it.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: STRINDBERG AND THE POETRY OF MYTH By Harry G. Carlson. 240 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $22.50.

title: G.I. DRESS CUTBACK ASSAILED
description: VINELAND WHAT appears to be a routine cost-saving decision by the military could lead to the demise of the clothing-manufacturing industry in South Jersey, say union officials and manufacturers.

title: F.A.A. Says Dallas-Fort Worth Tops Airports in Guns Seized
description: The Dallas-Fort Worth Regional Airport leads the nation in the number of weapons confiscated from passengers, according to the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: GETTING YOUR CAR TO FLORIDA
description: Florida in winter remains a strong lure for travelers from the Northeast, and the prospect of having one's own car to drive while there continues to appeal to many motorists. But the thought of driving 1,000 miles or more just to get the car there can be a major deterrent. Even though the most direct route is now practically all Interstate highways, pockets of congestion remain, toll plazas and road repairs impede progress, and miles of fa-tiguing monotony cannot be avoided.

title: The House May Get A Look at E.P.A. Records
description: One of the several shadows over the Environmental Protection Agency appeared to have lightened last week when the Reagan Administration agreed to give House committee members access to documents they had subpoenaed. But it was unclear if the move would be the final chapter in a battle that began when President Reagan ordered E.P.A. Administrator Anne M. Gorsuch to withhold the records, leading Congress to cite her for contempt.

title: BALI
description: To the Editor: May I add a small footnote to the romantic, delightful and casual discussion of Bali.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: MARY CHESNUT'S CIVIL WAR. Edited by C. Vann Woodward. (Yale University Press, $14.95.) Mary Chesnut kept a journal in the 1860's that she rewrote in the 1880's, and the reworked version was excerpted for publication as a diary years after her death in 1886. C. Vann Woodward's rendering of her later portrait of a society at war, which restores selected passages from the original journal, won the the 1982 Pulitzer Prize in history. Our reviewer, Kenneth S. Lynn, thinks Mrs. Chesnut should be labeled the perpetrator of an audacious literary fraud, but he characterized this edition of her much-praised work as the fullest and most careful to date.

title: Valued Voices; 'Old No. 3'
description: The Supreme Court's softest-talking justice is speaking out. Justice Harry Blackmun is telling the world that the highest court is a tough, challenging place to be.

title: A.D. Whittemore Jr.  Marries Miss Gonzales
description: Kimberly Ann Gonzales, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Conrad Gonzales of Pittsburgh, Centerville, Mass., and Marco Island, Fla., was married yesterday to Alexander Douglas Whittemore Jr., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Whittemore of Madison, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Robert W. Golledge performed the ceremony at Old North Episcopal Church in Boston.

title: CHARLES G. BLUHDORN, THE HEAD OF GULF AND WESTERN, DIES AT 56
description: Charles G. Bluhdorn, who built a small Michigan auto-parts company into Gulf and Western Industries, the multibillion-dollar conglomerate, died yesterday while flying home to New York from a business trip in the Dominican Republic. He was 56 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: LAWYERS GRAPPLING WITH DISCIPLINE
description: WHILE the American Bar Association hammered out a new code of ethics at its midyear convention in New Orleans earlier this month, New Jersey's legal community faced changes in the way ethics violations are dealt with.

title: A CONSERVATIVE SHOWS HIS LIBERAL BENT
description: WASHINGTON SENATOR Dan Quayle is an unorthodox conservative. The youthful Indiana Republican, who says that Government can be ''brutal and ruinous'' has taken the lead in championing the cause of the structurally unemployed - those who have been eliminated from the job market by a lack of training or education. He says that Government has no alternative but to help provide jobs for minority-group members, women and youths.

title: VERMONT PROTEST TO WIDENING OF SKI AREA WINS CONCESSION
description: A plan to expand a large ski area on Federal land has drawn strong local opposition, and the United States Forest Service is reconsidering its tentative approval of the proposal.

title: INDIAN ARMY ORDERED OUT TO QUELL RIOTS IN ASSAM
description: Indian Army troops were called out today in parts of Assam to combat mounting violence in the northeastern state, where more than 250 people are believed to have died in the last two weeks. Today the 48-hour death toll in two areas alone was reported to have been about 120.

title: THE C.I.A.'S COVERT OPERATIONS
description: What troubles me most are covert operations. Mr. Taubman writes: ''The Reagan Administration considers covert operations a routine instrument for foreign policy,'' and notes, ''Casey's enthusiasm for covert operations.''

title: QUIET L.I. COMMUNITY MAKES POLICE CHIEF'S JOB PART TIME
description: This tiny island's police blotter shows that 11 crimes were committed here last year - two burglaries and nine larcenies. No one is calling that a crime wave, but when the fulltime police chief asked for a raise in his salary, the island's trustees decided to abolish his job.

title: SKIING FROM A HELICOPTER
description: TERENCE SMITH is the Washington Talk editor of The Times, in Washington.

title: 450-TON OBSERVATORY IN OHIO MAY BE AIRLIFTED TO NEW SITE
description: Because of plans to convert the site of an Ohio radio astronomy observatory into a golf course, the observatory's giant twin antennas may take to the air, in sections.

title: U.S. MAY PUT A 13,000-ACRE HAVEN UP FOR GRABS
description: In the 1930's, the Federal Government bailed out Depression-stricken farmers and bought the farmland near this tiny hamlet in the Finger Lakes region.

title: GUIDE TO THE GRAPEFRUIT LEAGUE
description: For two months every winter when the great American sports stadiums lay dormant under snowy blankets, South Florida quietly takes its place as the baseball capital of the universe. A geographic diamond that reaches from Orlando on the north, Sarasota on the west, Miami on the south and West Palm Beach on the east, links 18 major-league clubs that migrate to winter sunshine to prepare for the summer season.

title: THANK YOU, OLD BUDDIES
description: HAS anybody considered that Jerry Tarkanian's four coaching friends did him a service by omitting his University of Nevada-Las Vegas team from their United Press International ballots last week?

title: THE BRITISH FINALLY TAME THE THAMES
description: A $700 million expenditure and years of hard slogging by thousands of engineers and workmen paid off one stormy night this month when the new Thames Flood Barrier held back the waters of the North Sea surging up the river toward the capital.

title: Another Name For Madness
description: Marion Roach captures the nightmarish quality of life peculiar to Alzheimer's disease victims and their families (''Another Name for Madness,'' Jan. 16). Ironically, the ability to diagnose Alzheimer's disease, to understand it in a limited sense and to predict its course has apparently not removed the stigma often associated with misunderstood mental disorders.

title: 'Anger'
description: To the Editor:

title: A NEW HAVEN RENEWAL PLAN MOVES AHEAD
description: NEW HAVEN AS one multimillion-dollar project stood still, another moved ahead in downtown New Haven last week: a $28.7 million overhaul of the Chapel Square Mall.

title: WHO IS THE SEA FLOOR'S LANDLORD?
description: THE hotly disputed controversy over who legitimately owns the land beneath the sea goes well beyond the international Law of the Sea treaty. Ownership of the outer continental shelf is currently the subject of intense concern for New Jersey, California, New England, Virginia, New York, North Carolina and Alaska, among others.

title: RETREATING FROM THE RULES
description: FROM the beginning, the policy of America's latest springtime d iversion, the United States Football League, has been to ignore p layers with college eligibility remaining. Commissioner Chet Simmonsh as stated repeatedly that, ''We won't touch anybody who has not c ompleted his eligibility'' or anyone whose class has not graduated. A nd the New Jersey Generals' commander, Chuck Fairbanks, has also b een opposed to raiding the colleges.

title: BOOKS
description: ANEW attitude toward the business world - jungle that it is - might help your finances and draw some laughs as well, advises Arthur Hecht of Ridgewood, the author with Byron Stevens of ''The Business Beastiary'' (Stein & Day, Scarborough House, Briarcliff Manor, N.Y. 10510, $14.95; $7.95, paper).

title: D.E.P. FACES MAJOR CHALLENGE
description: THE Department of Environmental Protection, perhaps more than any other state agency, faces the Herculean task of trying to mend New Jersey's deteriorating infrastructure. At a time when Federal funds are drying up, it must find ways to increase the state's dwindling water supply and decrease unacceptably high pollution levels that are making that water potentially hazardous.

title: FLORIDA'S TOURISM SHIFTS FROM SOUTH
description: Tourists visiting central Florida without hotel reservations are hard pressed to find a vacancy this weekend. There is hardly a room available within 50 miles of Orlando, the hub city of the region's growing tourist and recreation industry, a situation that is becoming common there.

title: Reopen 27th Street
description: To the Editor:

title: Friends and Deeds
description: As a law enforcement officer under indictment for taking bribes from mobsters, Sheriff James A. Traficant Jr. of Mahoning County, Ohio, may not have been a pillar of his community.

title: The C.I.A.'s Covert Operations
description: Philip Taubman's article ''Casey and His C.I.A. on the Rebound'' (Jan. 16) seems to assume that covert operations abroad by the United States Government are inherently evil. Some covert actions may be stupid, ineffective and even immoral, but those designed to protect the security of the United States and its allies can be wise, effective and morally justifiable. C.I.A. covert activity should be assessed by the three principal criteria of the classic Christian just-war doctrine: (1) Is the end just? (2) Are the means just and proportionate? (3) If the action succeeds, will the chances for justice and freedom be enhanced?

title: THE SHOVEL LIVES!
description: To the Editor:

title: Navy and Marines Fail to Find Ships Lost in Mediterranean
description: United States Marine helicopters and a Navy ship searched for two ships in distress in a Mediterranean storm today but did not find them, a Marine spokesman said.

title: MCCANN ELATED AT VOTE
description: JERSEY CITY MAYOR Gerald McCann breathed a sigh of relief last week after voters overwhemingly defeated a move to change Jersey City's form of government from its present Mayor-Council setup to a City Commission.

title:
ART;
FOCUS ON CORPORATE COLLECTORS
description: SOMETIMES a knowledge of local conditions is as necessary for the complete understanding of an exhibition as a knowledge of art history. For instance, one might wonder about the preponderance of bold and brassy abstract painting in the current members' exhibition at the Katonah Gallery, a place known for its receptiveness to a variety of styles. It all becomes clear when one realizes that ''Art for the Collector'' is pitched especially at the corporate collector.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
WHEN 4 PLUS 5 DOES NOT EQUAL 9
description: CONTRARY to public opinion, turning 35 is not as traumatic as it used to be. Because of the miracles of modern science, life expectancy has risen and many years arrive as golden ones.

title: 'WHY ARE DOCUMENTARIES SO DULL?'
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Richard Lacayo is a freelance writer. By RICHARD LACAYO

title:
GARDENING;
MORE ABOUT THE BUTTERCUP FAMILY
description: THE buttercup family, Ranunculaceae, was the focus of last week's column. Several genera including Aconitum, the monkshoods; Adonis; Anemone and Aquilegia, the columbines, were noted as being desirable garden subjects. We now continue with additional worthwhile members of this plant family.

title: Courts Block Federal Rule on Contraceptives
description: The Reagan Administration's stated goal of fostering closer ties between parent and child may have been well-meant, but two Federal courts last week said the means -regulations requiring federally funded clinics to notify parents if teen-agers receive contraceptives -were unlawful.

title: Margaret Donohue Married to George Dornbusch
description: Margaret D. Donohue, daughter of Mrs. Cyril T. McDermott of North Tarrytown, N.Y., and the late Robert Luce Donohue, was married at the Roman Catholic Church of the Transfiguration in Tarrytown, N.Y., yesterday to George W. Dornbusch, son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Dornbusch of Bennington, Vt., formerly of Rye, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Normand J. Godin, assisted by the Rev Donald W. Poole, a Presbyterian minister.

title: OF I.R.A.'S MUTUAL FUNDS AND TRUSTS
description: Below are answers to some recent questions from readers of the Personal Finance Column. Q.I'd like to set up an I.R.A., but I think that I may need to draw on the money before I reach age 59 1/2. If I face a 10 percent penalty for premature withdrawal, does it make sense for me to open one? A.It depends on how long you leave the money in and the interest rate it bears. But in many cases, investing in an I.R.A. can be preferable to another, fully taxable investment, even if the funds are left there for as little as five years, says the accounting firm of Arthur Young & Company. The reason is twofold: You get a dollar-for-dollar tax deduction for the money you contribute to the I.R.A. and that money compounds tax-free until you withdraw it.

title: THE NEW KHOMEINI
description: Iran's revolutionary leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, is at long last moving to curb the excesses and brutalities of the country's Revolutionary Guards and committees, the revolutionary courts and prisons. Ironically, these overdue measures pose a grave risk to the stability of the regime.

title: Mercedes M. Cue To Marry in April
description: Mercedes Gispert de Cue of Mexico City has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mercedes Montserrat Cue, to Jean-Francois Noel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Guy Noel of Brussels.

title: YALE STUDENTS LEARNING PRACTICAL POLITICS
description: First, Janet Stearns studied politics the Yale way, with tomes by Hobbes and lectures on St. Thomas Aquinas. Then she became a ward committeeman in this city and discovered the importance of attending wakes.

title: Big Japan Trade Group Plans Trip to Moscow
description: A 250-member group of Japanese business executives is to fly to Moscow on Tuesday on a trade promotion trip that Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone's Government has done nothing to encourage.

title: SCHOOL CLUB SAVES ENERGY
description: CURRENT events usually influence what goes on in classrooms across the country, and the Mark T. Sheehan High School in Wallingford is no exception.

title: ROYAL HAWAIIAN: WAIKIKI AS IT WAS
description: ROBERT TRUMBULL, formerly a Times correspondent, lives in Hawaii.

title: FICTION
description: 1 2 15 MISTRAL'S DAUGHTER, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $15.95.) The art world of the 20's and the fashion industry of the 80's. 2 4 25 MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $15.95.) The hidden truth behind a woman business tycoon's rise to power. 3 1 21 SPACE, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) The story of the American space program told through fiction. 4 3 15 2010: ODYSSEY TWO, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) A continuation of the tale begun in ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' 5 5 25 THE VALLEY OF HORSES, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $15.95.) A continuation of the saga of human survival at the dawn of civilization begun in ''The Clan of the Cave Bear.'' 6 6 19 FOUNDATION'S EDGE, by Isaac Asimov. (Doubleday, $14.95.) The struggle to keep civilization alive in a crumbling empire: science fiction. 7 14 2 FLOATING DRAGON, by Peter Straub. (Coward, McCann & Geoghegan, $15.95.) An unspeakable horror invades a suburban commuter town. 8 8 16 LIFE, THE UNIVERSE AND EVERYTHING, by Douglas Adams.

title: CABARET: PAT COOK AT MARTY'S
description: Jacques Brel's bitter and bawdy ''Port of Amsterdam,'' with its vivid imagery and highly emotional climax, is not the kind of song one expects to hear a cocktail pianist singing. Nor is the poignant cry of a young soldier dying alone in the woods during the revolution, ''Momma Look Sharp,'' from the musical ''1776,'' which is as moving in its quiet way as ''Amsterdam'' is in its violence.

title: Bradford Landers Engaged to Wed Miss Burchenal
description: Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Holland Burchenal of Noroton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Fahys Burchenal, to Bradford Worth Landers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Worth Landers of Worcester, Mass.

title: THE LAW AS SERVANT OF THE PUBLIC
description: THIS is Washington's Birthday week and those students who are not on vacation are likely hearing stories of our first President's exploits in the Revolutionary War. But it is important to remember that the struggle for independence was not just a military battle.

title: SPAIN GIVES A LOUD OLE! TO COCHINILLO
description: ROBERT PACKARD is a professor of the humanities at Stevens Institute of Technology.

title: Small Step to Lebanese Unity
description: In the crazy quilt of conflicting forces that is Lebanon, any move toward achieving national integrity is important. Last week, after months of hovering on the edges of East Beirut, the Lebanese army moved in and took control from private Christian militiamen in the name of the Government. These forces shifted to the hills northeast of the capital, a still intact and ever formidable threat to President Amin Gemayel, their nominal ally.

title: STUDENTS PERFORM IN O'NEILL'S COTTAGE
description: WITH the camera focused on them and a microphone boom swung in front of them, two student actors played a scene from Eugene O'Neill's ''Long Day's Journey Into Night.''

title: A number of international treaties bind Europe's closely clustered states to eliminate or curb the dumping of toxic substances in the seas and rivers they share. The most recent, the United Nations Regional Convention on the Mediterranean, was signed in 1979 by all countries bordering the sea, including Israel and several Arab states. It is a framework agreement committing these countries to work out more detailed pacts for cleaning up the badly polluted Mediterranean. So far four action protocols have been signed.
description: The first, already in force, establishes a ''black list'' of substances that may not be dumped in the sea from boats or aircraft, and a ''gray list'' of less hazardous wastes for which a special government dumping license is required. A more ambitious protocol, expected to come into force in 1984, seeks to control the discharge of dangerous wastes into the Mediterranean from the land. Currently 80 percent of Mediterranean pollution is believed to be ''landbased.''

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: KURT WEILL An Illustrated Biography. By Douglas Jarman.160 pp. Bloomington: Indiana University Press. $20.

title: LEBANON: IF ISRAEL WITHDREW IN HASTE
description: To the Editor:

title: Deborah Ann Derleth Marries Stephen K. Meahl
description: Deborah Ann Derleth, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald William Derleth of Riverside, Conn., was married yesterday to Stephen Kendrick Meahl, son of Mr. and Mrs. William K. Meahl of Winchester, Mass. The Rev. Leo J. Gorman performed the ceremony at St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: ANOTHER NAME FOR MADNESS
description: The adult day-care center is an alternative to institutionalization for people who are no longer able to live independently.

title: No Headline
description: CONNORS TO MEET MAYER IN INDOOR FINAL

title: Headliners; Use Next Window
description: The head of the United American Bank of Knoxville, Jake Butcher, apparently gave a lot of credit where it wasn't due.

title: WHY REPAIRS COST SO MUCH
description: Reporting the news in the hyperactive field of audio often leaves too little time to deal with the ordinary household problems of keeping a sound system in good trim or to do an occasional brush-up on basic concepts. These are things that come to the surface when dipping into the mail arriving at this desk, and here are a few queries and answers along with a reminder that we can respond only to questions of general interest and cannot provide personal consultation.

title: WORD PLAY
description: VISITING RITES By Phyllis Janowitz. 83 pp. New Jersey: Princeton University Press. Cloth, $10.95. Paper, $5.95. CROSSING COCYTUS By Paul Mariani. 94 pp. New York: Grove Press. Cloth, $12.50. Paper, $5.95. PM/AM By Linda Pastan. 112 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Co. Cloth, $12.95. Paper, $5.95.

title: REAGAN IN 1984?
description: The most popular game in the capital of the United States these days is ''Will He or Won't He'' run for a second term in the White House. It's popular because it takes everybody's mind off more important problems. You don't have to think much about it, and couldn't do anything about it if you did, and the best player in this political game is the President himself.

title: ADMINISTRATION REOPENS DRIVE FOR NERVE GAS
description: Rebuffed by Congress last year, the Reagan Administration is opening a fresh drive to win approval for production of a new generation of nerve gas weapons.

title: THE OFFBEAT ADDS SPICE TO THE CALENDAR
description: THE Westchester cultural calendar continues to be crowded with musical events, and over the next couple of weeks it will be enlivened by such offbeat offerings as a barbershop chorus, a double-bass concerto and an antinuclear dance.

title: COMPARATIVE PRICING HELPS IN RELOCATION
description: SUPPOSE, said Ann Abbruzzese, that a new career was forcing a familyi n Salt Lake City to move to the New York metropolitan area. And s uppose the family had a house it had to sell in Salt Lake and wantedt o use the proceeds to buy another in the New York area, but knew n othing about values or neighborhoods in New York. Where to turn?

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: VALENTINE'S DAY poems are common this time of year, but one prizewinner was a bit unusual: It was a love poem to a Siberian tiger. The poem was written by 7-year-old Allison Radecki of Montclair, one of the winners in a children's poetry contest co-sponsored by the Turtle Back Zoo in West Orange and Urban Voices, an Essex County group that promotes art and literature.

title: AMTRAK CHIEF SAYS RAILWAY IS COMING OF AGE
description: Amtrak, the national passenger railroad, has improved its financial footing and will rely less on Federal financial aid in the coming years, according to W.Graham Clator Jr., chairman and chief executive of the railroad.

title: CHICKENING IN
description: ''If you want a fresher chicken,'' goes an advertisement from Holly Farms, ''you'll have to grow your own.'' ''If you grew chickens,'' counters Perdue Farms, ''they'd be golden yellow, too.'' What's this about growing chickens? I always thought you raised chickens, bred horses and cultured bacteria, but reserved growing for vegetables.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: COMMUTERS PLEAD THEIR CASE IN COURT
description: NEW ROCHELLE THE courtroom was as crowded as the 7:44 out of Scarsdale, and the commuters were hoping to persuade the judge to render a fine against Conrail for alleged offenses.

title: Miami Officer Indicted in Killing
description: In a move that seemed likely to at least temporarily reduce tensions in Miami's black community but increase them among police officers, a grand jury last week indicted yet another patrolman in a fatal shooting of a black.

title: Miss Schoene Leading In World Speed Skating
description: MARX-STADT, East Germany, Feb. 19 (AP) - Andrea Schoene, a 22-year-old East German, led at the halfway point of the women's fourdistance world speedskating championship today with her strongest event, the 5,000-meter race, to come Sunday. The 1,500-meter race was also scheduled for Sunday.

title: A 'Good Times' Chief of Parks
description: In more ways than one, Henry J. Stern is assured of finding that the grass is greener on the other side. The at-large City Council member from Manhattan last week was named Commissioner of Parks and Recreation, replacing Gordon Davis, who resigned last month.

title: Parthenia Ross to Wed C.W. Kiersted
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edmund Burke Ross of Basking Ridge, N.J., and Edgartown, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Parthenia Ross, to Christopher William Kiersted of Edgartown, son of Mrs. William Cole Miller Jr. of Tucson, Ariz., and the late Lieut. Comdr. Wynkoop Kiersted 3d, U.S.N. An April wedding is planned.

title: Pilgrimages To the Shrines Of Rock Stars
description: Pilgrimages at home and abroad to pay homage to the great idols of rock and roll are on the schedule for the coming spring and summer. ''Rock On'' to Graceland, for example, will provide fans of Elvis Presley with the opportunity to fly to Memphis at the end of April for a visit to the Elvis Presley Mansion; then, in June, July and August, there will be a total of 16 departures for England from New York and Atlanta on a series of tours built around visits to the Beatles' birthplace - Liverpool.

title: 10-Year Penalty For Researcher
description: When a Harvard cardiologist committed research fraud in 1981, there was no rule book on how to handle such matters. But there were rules of thumb - action should be swift and should involve an independent investigation - and other institutions, such as Memorial Sloan-Kettering, had observed them. Harvard Medical School did not, according to Federal investigators examining the case of Dr. John R. Darsee.

title:
TV VIEW;
WHEN THE PACKAGE ITSELF OUTWEIGHS THE PRODUCT
description: Sidney Sheldon's ''Rage of Angels,'' a best-selling novel, has been made into a four-hour television movie that can be seen on NBC this evening and tomorrow, each night beginning at 9 o'clock. It is a big production, put together skillfully by a staff of TV veterans. It is a glamorous production, starring Jaclyn Smith and filmed, in a picture-postcard manner, on location in New York, Paris and Acapulco. It is, in short, the very stuff of current popular-entertainment packaging, as effective on the weekly book lists as it in the movies.

title: GOOD VALUE IN LIVELY SETTING
description: WHEN you look at the crowds of happy diners that flock to Poor Richard's restaurant in Waterford, you suspect there is a certain irony in the name. With business so good, Richard should be anything but poor.

title: A Hard Setback For Barney Clark
description: Barney B. Clark's determination to get well got him as far as a private room at the University of Utah Medical Center last week, but it was a brief victory. The artificial heart recipient soon developed breathing trouble and, after less than two days, was sent back to intensive care and hooked to a mechanical respirator.

title: Bradley, DeBusschere Join Hall of Fame
description: Teammates. Roommates. And now, fittingly, Bill Bradley and Dave DeBusschere have been cast together again. The two former Knicks were named yesterday to the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame.

title: WALL ST. RESTORATION
description: The 1918 neo-Georgian building at 30 Wall Street has been the headquarters of the Seamen's Bank for Savings since 1954. But with the bank vacating more than three of its 12 floors for another location and the building sold to investors, the old Federal Office of the Assay - once the place to go to make deposits of gold in forms as varied as eyeglasses or teeth -is in for a facelift.

title: Begin & Co. Tough It Out
description: Israeli Prime Minister Menachem Begin last week handed his critics another lesson in playing to win. Pulling together his often unruly coalition, he rode out the storm raised by a commission's finding that Israel was indirectly responsible for the massacre of Palestinians in Beirut.

title: A SOUTHERN SKI WEEKEND
description: MARTIN TOLCHIN is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The Times.

title: PERCHANCE TO DREAM
description: When I said I never dreamed, sleep authorities laughed. Everyone dreams, they said. It is scientifically established: Where there is sleep, there must be dreams. ''You are refusing for some reason to remember your dreams,'' I was told by a woman who had been seven years in the hands of psychiatrists and dreamed incessantly. ''Perhaps you are so ashamed of them that your conscious mind refuses to recognize them.''

title: MUSIC CENTERS, IN TROUBLE, SEEK WIDER AUDIENCE
description: THE current building boom that has dotted the American landscape with new performing arts centers, all lavishly planned and financed, is a nagging reminder that not only does New Jersey lack a new allpurpose hall but also that what it does have is inadequate.

title: Lauri F. Stark to Marry
description: Dr. and Mrs. Eli H. Stark of North Bellmore, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lauri Felisa Stark, to Eric Craig Last, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Last of Valley Stream, L.I. A September wedding is planned. The couple are students at the New York College of Osteopathic Medicine in Old Westbury, L.I.

title: Applications at Brown U. Top Ivy League for the First Time
description: Brown University, for the first time in its 219-year history, has topped its seven Ivy League rivals in applications.

title: ILLEGAL MIGRANT WORKERS KEEP BORDER PATROL IN FLORIDA BUSY
description: The United States Border Patrol says that arrests of illegal aliens have risen sharply in the Orlando area.

title: Control Board Hugs City Budget
description: The ''worst case'' budget proposal Mayor Koch unveiled last month might not be so bad after all. The State Financial Control Board last week approved the preliminary $16.5 billion spending plan for the fiscal year beginning in July after its staff predicted that the city would even end up with a $65 million surplus.

title: No Headline
description: Syracuse Triumphs by 108-88

title: REVAMPING M.T.A.: REGIONAL BOARDS COULD BE ITS 'RIGHT ARM'
description: THE special Albany legislative session held in December resulted in another round of tax increases for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. During the debate, the issue of reorganizing this enormous authority was raised by both Democrats and Republicans. Reorganizing the M.T.A. deserves study as suggested by Governor Cuomo, but the Legislature should not go home without passing a bill to make the M.T.A. more responsive and responsible.

title: IN THE TRENCHES FOR THE BATTLE OF THE BREAK
description: HONESTLY, Abe, if only you had experienced February vacation with Robert, Tad and Willie romping around the White House, you would have had the good sense to celebrate your birthday in the summer. The same goes for you, George. If you had been the Mother of Our Country, I wouldn't even have to mention it.

title: Miss Martin Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Mott Martin of Rowayton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Read Martin, to Sandon Mark Herzlich, son of Valori Herzlich of Bronxville, N.Y., and Eric Joseph Herzlich of West Hartford, Conn.

title: ENTREPRENEURS IN TRAINING
description: Despite a high failure rate among young companies, Columbia's ''Managing New Ventures'' course has become one of the most popular electives in the curriculum. And this spring it carries an even greater-than-usual appeal: Columbia will provide seed money for at least one of the most promising business plans devised by the students.

title: LONDON'S THEATER SHARES MANY OF BROADWAY'S WOES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Benedict Nightingale writes frequently on theater in London. BY BENEDICT NIGHTINGALE LONDON American playgoers, lately accustomed to one doleful bulletin after another emanating from Broadway, are sometimes inclined to regard the London theater as a sort of bustling gymnasium for the hale and hearty: cheap seats, an abundance of fine work, smiling managers whose only problem is whether to cast Gielgud or Olivier in the new Stoppard, Ayckbourn or Simon Gray.

title: Top Avenger Is Winner In the Sporting Plate
description: Top Avenger, running third at the head of the stretch, made a late rush yesterday to win by a head in the $54,000 Sporting Plate Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: FACING the gaping shells of two abandoned 12-story buildings at Scudder Homes, a public-housing project in Newark, is one bright spot: the Newark Police Housing Unit. A year ago last fall, several first-floor apartments of a still-occupied building in the complex were converted into a police substation through a combination of tenant pressure, $1.5 million in Housing and Urban Development funds and the initiative of Lieut. Joseph J. Santiago.

title: THE JOY OF SAVING ENERGY
description: ''ALTERNATIVE energy source'' is a phrase that seems to burn with national economic and social implications, but lately I have been taking it very personally.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: Here's hearty fare for children as well as for their parents - a set of eight volumes subtitled ''Easy Menu Ethnic Cookbooks'' (Lerner, $7.95 each). Beginning alphabetically with COOKING THE CHINESE WAY, they cover English, French, Italian, Japanese, Mexican, Norwegian and Spanish cuisines. Each book has been written by an expert.

title: TOWN QUANDARY: 20 ACRES, RIV VU
description: THE 2,400 villagers of Piermont - a faded mill town nestled beneath t he Palisades about a mile and a half from the Tappan Zee Bridge - a re preparing to confront their future.

title: A MIX THAT MATCHES
description: There are some falvors in foods that may seem illogical in theory although they are admirable in practice. These include sweet and sour combinations, dishes other than desserts containing chocolate (the best-kown of which is Mexico's mole poblano) and main courses consisting of a blend of meat or poultry with seafood.

title: Trieste
description: To the Editor:

title:
ANTIQUES;
33 EXHIBITORS AT GUILFORD
description: THERE may be other states where dealers and collectors suffer from cabin fever during the harsh weeks of winter, but no one can claim Connecticut does less than its best to keep antiques trading active throughout every month no matter how dire the weather forecast.

title: PLAYING BY RIGID RULES FOR ABSENT AUDIENCES
description: WASHINGTON WHEN the American arms control negotiators returned to Geneva a few weeks ago, strobe lights flashed and reporters gathered almost as if the negotiators had the power to work out agreements with the Russians. Actually, the two sets of talks - one on strategic weapons and intercontinental-range forces, the other dealing with mediumrange nuclear forces on the Eurasian land mass - are staged, grueling and rather dull. The men at the tables are more messengers than negotiators. The real business takes place in Moscow and Washington.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
THE NICE THINGS ABOUT SNOW
description: SNOW. To many, it is the most detestable four-letter word in the English language. Thousands of people tremble at the thought of it. Weathermen avoid forecasting it, and when they must, they invariably throw in a ''changing over to rain'' clause to calm the jittery nerves of their viewers.

title: 9 YEARS AQUILTING
description: Every Monday at noon, half a dozen women of the Old Greenwich First Congregational Church arrive in the quilting room, put the kettle on to boil, eat their brown-bag lunches and go to work.

title: Artist vs. City
description: Like many modern artists, Christo does not convince all spectators that what he does is art. There is, however, wide agreement on one point: He does things big.

title: COLLEGES GRAPPLING WITH AID AND DRAFT
description: WASHINGTON ANEW LAW denying Federal loans to students who do not register for the draft has raised questions at American colleges and universities. In New Jersey, educators are far from certain of the answers.

title: WINTER BRING SURPRISES
description: ALTHOUGH Long Islanders have just weathered one of the worst snowstorms of the last 35 years, it has been a relatively mild winter, holding out the prospect of a warm spring and early summer.

title: IN SALVADOR, THE TALE OF DENNIS, 21 MONTHS OLD
description: The story of Dennis Orlando Gallardo Quintanilla, a 21-month-old American citizen, is a peculiarly Salvadoran tale.

title: TRAILING WILLA CATHER
description: HERBERT MITGANG is a cultural correspondent for The New York Times.

title: Plated Pennies
description: Reacting in 1974 to soaring copper prices, Congress authorized the Treasury Department to remake the one-cent coin - from 95 percent copper and 5 percent zinc to 2.4 percent copper and 97.6 percent zinc.

title: NOTRE DAME ALONE IN DROPPING HOCKEY
description: When Notre Dame announced recently that it was ending its National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I hockey program, followers of the sport feared that other schools might eliminate the sport as well. Hockey, after all, is an expensive sport to administer on a major level.

title: PETTYS RACING IN DAYTONA 500
description: Richard Petty was a lanky 22-year-old when Bill France first opened the gates to the new Daytona International Speedway in 1959. The son of Lee Petty, one of the sport's early stars, Richard was just starting his second year of racing when practice began for the first Daytona 500. But no one had ever raced stock cars before at a track like Daytona's - 2 1/2 miles around, with imposing 31-degree banks and long straightaways.

title: No Headline
description: Pitt Upsets Georgetown, 65-63

title: STEARNS' INJURED ARMS SHOWS SOME SIGNS OF IMPROVEMENT
description: The most important sore arm on the Mets this spring does not belong to a pitcher, but to a catcher: John Stearns, who suspects that he may not return to full-time catching until May or June.

title: LONG ISLAND IS WINNING A PROFITABLE PAPER CHASE
description: LONG ISLAND'S success in job development was underlined last week when the State Department of Labor released statistics showing that the area had gained some 13,000 jobs in 1982. An important element in the growth has been the increasing number of firms that have moved their ''back office'' operations from high rent districts in Manhattan.

title: LEANING TOWER OF PISA IS LEANING A BIT MORE
description: The Leaning Tower of Pisa leaned another five one-hundredths of an inch last year, and city officials say it is doomed to collapse unless a way is found to halt the ever-increasing tilt.

title: Susan Haldenstein Wed
description: Susan Gail Haldenstein, daughter of Caren Haldenstein of Larchmont, N.Y., and Austin K. Haldenstein of Manhattan, was married yesterday to Gregory Thomas Federspiel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Federspiel of Gilford, N.J. Justice of the Peace Gene Waggaman of Greenwich, Conn., performed the ceremony at the Silvermine Tavern in Norwalk, Conn. The bride, who has retained her name, is director of the Early Childhood Resource Project in Henniker, N.H. Mr. Federspiel is director of public relations with the Rural Education Center in Wilton, N.H.

title: ISLANDERS ROUT CANADIENS, 5-0, AND FLYERS DEFEAT RANGERS, 8-5
description: The Philadelphia Flyers have used excellent defense as a foundation for constructing one of the three best records in the league this season. But their offense had to bail out the defense this afternoon as they defeated the Rangers, 8-5, at the Spectrum.

title: A BREAK FOR YOUTH COULD BE COSTLY
description: THE Administration's proposal to establish a special $2.50 an hour s ub-minimum wage for teenagers seeking after-school and summer jobs i s a high-risk proposal. The likely gain of a youth sub-minimum is t he creation of a substantial number of new jobs for youth. The d ownside risk, however, is that many adult workers from low-income f amilies may find themselves out of jobs. Unfortunately, no one r eally knows how likely it is that this will happen.

title: Index; International
description: Thai tribe being priced out of its own religion A2 Twice in six years, a Nkomo sup- porter flees A3 Indian plant producing weapons- grade plutonium A4 Around the World A5 Libya's parliament calls for formation of suicide squads A6 Ex-Irgun commander is named Ambassador to Britain A8 Tribal groups make up 10 percent of Assam's population A10 Washington Talk Congress: The trend toward packaging legislation B6 Link seen between good eco- nomic news and news confer- ences B6 The Calendar B6 Required Reading B6 Briefing B6 SportsMonday Auto Racing: Yarborough, driv- ing backup car, wins Daytona 500 C7 Baseball: An unusual rookie tries for spot on Mets C2

title: MUSIC: ARRAU MARKS 80TH BIRTHDAY WITH A RECITAL
description: CLAUDIO ARRAU celebrated his 80th birthday at Avery Fisher Hall yesterday afternoon with a piano recital that affirmed his position as a 20th-century virtuoso. He studied with Martin Krause, a student of Liszt, but his own approach to music is serious rather than theatrical, scrupulous rather than improvisatory. Compared with an earier generation, Mr. Arrau is more controlled than Arthur Schnabel, more disciplined than Alfred Cortot, less a colorist than Walter Gieseking.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Colleges: Connecticut at Boston College (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M.; Channel 11, 11:30 P.M., tape); Massachusetts at St. Peter's, 8 P.M. (Television - Channel 50, 8 P.M.); L.I.U. at Fordham, 8 P.M. (Radio -WFUV-FM, 90.7; 7:45 P.M.); City University of New York Tournament, qualifying round, City College vs. Medgar Evers, at Nat Holman Gymnasium, Convent Avenue and West 138th Street, 4 P.M. (Radio -WNYE-FM, 91.5; 4 P.M.); Rutgers of Newark at Bloomfield, 7:30 P.M.; Fairleigh Dickinson-Teaneck at Wagner; New Jersey Tech at Drew; New York Poly at Yeshiva; New York State Maritime at Pratt; Southampton at Adelphi, and William Paterson at Glassboro State, all 8 P.M. Exhibition: Harlem Globetrotters, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 2 and 6 P.M. Hockey Devils vs.

title: STATE AFFIRMATIVE-ACTION PROGRAM FOR JOBS IS ANNOUNCED BY CUOMO
description: Governor Cuomo announced tonight the appointment of three black and five Hispanic officials and a three-part program to strengthen the state's minority hiring.

title: NEW MEXICO GOVENOR PICKED AS LEADER OF HISPANIC LOBBY
description: A loosely structured coalition of Hispanic leaders from around the country today chose Gov. Toney Anaya of New Mexico to lead a new political lobbying group that hopes to influence candidates for the Democratic Party's 1984 Presidential nomination.

title: BRANDT II: AS POOR AS BRANDT I
description: Bemoaning the lack of attention paid to its 1980 report, Willy Brandt's Independent Commission on International Development Issues has produced a sequel, this time insisting that its recommendations be implemented to avert worldwide ''anarchy.'' While it is true that economic conditions have worsened in the intervening years, the commission's pronouncements make no more sense in 1983 than they did in 1980.

title: BRIEFING
description: Money's Warm Glow

title: Claims to O. Henry
description: In New York, where there are 16,209 restaurants, according to the latest count of the city's Health Department, proprietors are always looking for a way to stand out from the crowd. Take Pete's Tavern on Irving Place, where a sign beside the first wooden booth on the right declares that O. Henry (the pseudonym of William Sydney Porter) wrote his famous Christmas short story, ''The Gift of the Magi,'' in two hours at that very table back in 1905.

title: SIX-MONTH WAITING PERIOD FOR BETROTHED CATHOLICS
description: The Diocese of Providence, seeking to halt the rise in broken marriages, will soon require Roman Catholic couples to wait six months before they may marry.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * New Jersey Resources Corporation, Asbury Park, N.J., has elected Jack V. Richards Jr. executive vice president, Thomas B. Toohey executive vice president and chief financial officer and Philip H. Reardon senior vice president.

title: U.S. APPEALS COURT RESTRICTS USE OF OPINIONS BY LAWYERS
description: The Federal Court of Appeals in New York, complaining of a heavy workload, has been restricting the use of its written decisions over the last decade by lawyers who want to cite them in arguing related cases.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Brooklyn Jumps the Gun On Honoring Its Women

title: A P.L.O. MODERATE RESIGNS IN PROTEST
description: One of the leading Palestinian advocates of recognizing Israel resigned in protest from the Palestine National Council today after Yasir Arafat prevented him from addressing the group.

title: HARVARD FILLS MATSUSHITA'S PROFESSORSHIP
description: Abraham Zaleznik has been appointed Konosuke Matsushita Professor of Leadership at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration. He is a psychoanalyst who specializes in the social psychology of management.

title: QUAKER OATS PICKS EXECUTIVE FOR TOYS
description: The Quaker Oats Company, apparently dissatisfied with the performance of its Fisher-Price Toys division, has installed a Quaker Oats executive there with a reputation as a strong manager but with no experience in the toy industry.

title: CLUB WHERE 13 WERE SLAIN IS LIKE MANY IN COAST CHINATOWNS
description: The Wah Mee gambling club, where 13 people were tied, robbed and shot dead Friday night, has been a fixture of Seattle's International District for half a century.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Style page Friday incorrectly gave the West Coast ar- rival date for Queen Elizabeth and Prince Philip. Their visit begins next Saturday.

title: Giant Killer
description: The University of Virginia was the No.1-ranked college basketball team in the nation on Dec. 23 when the Cavaliers stopped off on a trip back from Japan to play Chaminade University of Honolulu. The almost unknown Silverswords pulled one of the greatest upsets in college history by toppling Virginia, 77-72.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Threatened Landmark

title: Ethiopia and Armenia At Alternative Museum
description: The Alternative Museum presented two kinds of music rarely heard in New York last weekend - Ethiopian folk songs Friday and Armenian music Saturday.

title: IN THE FACE OF CONTROVERSY, PACKAGING
description: It was a meeting of the House Democratic leaders about Social Security legislation, and Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts was unhappy about some aspects of the bill. He especially objected to the proposed deferring of cost-of-living increases.

title: Salvador Sends Bones For U.S. Identity Check
description: Bones believed to be the remains of an American freelance writer who disappeared more than two years ago in El Salvador were sent to the United States this weekend.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Tows Return From the Snows

title: CABINET IN ISRAEL RETAINING SHARON ON 2 KEY PANELS
description: The Israeli Cabinet voted today to retain former Defense Minister Ariel Sharon on two important Government bodies, the steering committee for the negotiations with Lebanon and the larger of two ministerial panels on defense.

title: Mafia's Help Reported In the Rescue of Dozier
description: American and Italian intelligence officials turned to the Mafia for help in locating Brig, Gen. James L. Dozier after his kidnapping in Italy and rescued him the day after a Mafia leader revealed where the general was being held, Time magazine reports in its current issue.

title: YARBOROUGH, IN BACKUP CAR, CAPTURES DAYTONA 500
description: Cale Yarborough, who sent his car crashing into a retaining wall during practice last week, drove his backup car past Buddy Baker on the backstretch of the last lap today to win the $1 million Daytona 500 stock car race.

title: Speed Skating To Miss Schoene
description: MARX-STADT, East Germany, Feb. 20 (AP) - Andrea Schoene of East Germany won the 1983 women's four-distance world speedskating championship today, after capturing three of the four races in the two-day meet.

title: Celebrating 10 Years For 'Highlights of Jazz'
description: To celebrate the 10th anniversary of the ''Highlights in Jazz'' series, its founder, Jack Kleinsinger, brought together on Saturday at New York University's Loeb Auditorium as many of the participants in the original program of a decade ago as were available in New York for the occasion.

title: Panamanian Commander Warns U.S. Ambassador
description: The commander of Panama's national guard has accused the United States Ambassador of activities that ''affect our national security'' and warned the Ambassador that he might be asked to leave.

title: Tryout Delayed For Campaneris
description: Bert Campaneris, the 40-year-old former major league shortstop who is trying for a comeback with the Yankees, had hoped to begin working out with the team today.

title: BEST TOTAL SINCE '81
description: Doug Soetaert had one of those nights when everything goes wrong, and the Rangers had one of those nights when everything goes right. As a result, it seemed that almost everything went into the net.

title: DOCTORS AND INSURERS PRESS FOR LIMITS ON MALPRACTICE AWARDS
description: With jury awards in medical malpractice suits soaring into the millions of dollars in recent years, cries of alarm from the medical profession have stirred a debate about New York State's malpractice insurance system and the quality of health care.

title: Required Reading; Assessing Andropov
description: Lawrence S. Eagleburger, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs, in an address to the governing board of the World Jewish Congress. Washington, Feb. 1, 1983:

title: COSTLY VICTORY FOR CLUBS
description: The final scorecard reads clubs 17, players 13, but the clubs know theirs was a Pyrrhic victory. Even the 17 players who had lost in salary arbitration won, gaining a collective 54 percent increase over their 1982 salaries. By comparison, the average salary for all major leaguers rose 30 percent last year.

title: Strike Up the Band
description: When an 11-piece group from the Yale University band provided music for the USA/Mobil Indoor Track and Field Championships at Madison Square Garden last year, reactions were surprising. Meet officials had been apprehensive that having a band at a Garden meet for the first time in 15 years might prove distracting to the athletes and too loud for the public-address system's announcements to be heard.

title: U.S.F.L. WOULD NOT BACK PACT ON WALKER
description: If Herschel Walker, the all-America running back and Heisman Trophy winner from the University of Georgia, had signed a contract with the New Jersey Generals of the United States Football League, it would not have been approved by the league, according to a U.S.F.L. official.

title: Yugoslav Looting Reported
description: Stores were looted in the southwestern town of Titograd two days ago when detergent went on sale for the first time in a month, Belgrade newspapers reported today.

title: OUTDOORS: THE CITY AS WILDERNESS
description: LURCHING head-down along Manhattan's Seventh Avenue in the great blizzard of 1983, I yearned for my down coat, my Sorel boots with thick felt liners, a good pair of wool mittens, and something better than the Irish tweed hat that won't stay on my head when the wind is gusting over 30 miles an hour - an experienced outdoorsman caught unprepared in the wilderness of man-made canyons, blaring horns and gale-driven snow.

title: TAKING JUST ONE SHOT TO MAKE A MILLION
description: ALBANY UNNOTICED at first, an armored security truck containing $1 million quietly backed into the Washington Avenue Armory here Saturday night and stopped just a few feet from the baseline of the basketball court while a game was in progress.

title: Parts of New Mexico And Colorado Snowed In
description: By The Associated Press A blizzard building snowdrifts taller than a trucker's rig shut down a corner of New Mexico and part of Colorado yesterday, stranding travelers in schools and wayside homes.

title: Hardy Violettes
description: The other New York University basketball coach was a remarkably good sport last week about all the hoopla being made over ''the return of basketball'' to N.Y.U.

title: TWICE IN 6 YEARS, NKOMO BACKER FLEES
description: A 28-year-old Ndebele-speaking villager returned to this city as a refugee today for the second time in six years.

title: Diane L. Cherr Bride Of Richard Bachman
description: Diane Leslie Cherr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Cherr of Westfield, N.J., was married yesterday in New York to Richard Arthur Bachman, son of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Bachman of New York and Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi Charles A. Kroloff of Temple Emanu-El in Westfield, N.J., performed the ceremony at the American Stanhope Hotel.

title: POLICE LACKING SUSPECT IN THEFT AT THE 92ND ST. Y
description: The theft over the weekend of religious objects from an exhibition and sale at the 92d Street Y may have been carried out by thieves who hid themselves in the building Friday evening, the police said yesterday.

title: THE BID TO RESHAPE U.S. STEEL
description: For decades, the sprawling Homestead Works in Pittsburgh was the quintessence of the United States Steel Corporation and, perhaps, of the steel industry itself.

title: MIDEAST CAMPAIGN ORATORY
description: Jack Wells, my late mentor in Republican politics, used to come to campaign headquarters on the day after election sporting a large button on his lapel that read: ''Great job, kid - now get lost.''

title: Ann Wimpfheimer Marries Professor
description: Ann Frieda Wimpfheimer, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Seymour Wimpfheimer, was married yesterday to Dr. Baruch Micah Bokser, son of Rabbi and Mrs. Ben Zion Bokser. The bridegroom's father performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue.

title: Oklahoma Coach Is Struck by Car
description: Billy Tubbs, 47-year-old basketball coach at the University of Oklahoma, suffered a fractured skull today when he was hit by a car while jogging near his home in Norman.

title: AN OIL-IMPORT FEE IS GOOD FOR THE U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Commodities; Detached Investors Try Pools
description: WHERE'S the action in the commodity futures market? For a growing number of investors in futures, the response would be that they don't know and, quite likely, couldn't care less.

title: WOMEN BALANCE POLICE WORK AND HOME
description: On a recent Saturday afternoon, Frances Magliolo, wife, mother and an investigator in the Brooklyn South Narcotics Unit, took her 14-year-old daughter shopping in a large Brooklyn department store. They had been there only minutes when Officer Magliolo was approached and upbraided by a woman whose son she had recently arrested. The officer did not mind the confrontation - ''It's part of the job,'' she said - but it frightened her daughter.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, FEBRUARY 21, 1983
description: International Hindu tribesmen killed 600 people in an eight-hour attack on Moslem settlements in a rural area of Assam, a state in northeastern India, according to a senior state official. Witnesses said that the Moslem settlements were attacked by thousands of tribal people armed with homemade guns, machetes and spears. The figures, if confirmed, would bring the number of dead in three weeks of sectarian and ethnic violence in the state to about 1,000. (Page A1, Column 6.) Ariel Sharon will remain on two important Government bodies, the steering committee for the negotiations with Lebanon and the larger of the two ministerial panels on defense. The decision by the Israeli Cabinet, made at Prime Minister Menachem Begin's request, appeared to mean that Mr. Sharon, the former Defense Minister, would continue to have a major role in shaping Israel's positions in the talks with Lebanon, officials said. (A1:4.)

title: BALLET: NEW PENNSYLVANIA REPERTORY
description: This month, the Pennyslvania Ballet has been offering its first repertory programs since last summer, when its board named Robert Weiss, formerly a principal with the New York City Ballet, as new artistic director and Peter Martins as artistic advisor.

title: CULTURE MEETING IN PARIS SETS OFF DEBATES
description: The conference of artistic and intellectual celebrities sponsored by the French Socialist Government here a week ago has set off a series of polemics. The debate has raised anew the question: just what did President Francois Mitterrand and his Minister of Culture, Jack Lang, have in mind when they invited 300 French and foreign artists and intellectuals to ponder the relation between art and the economy? Other matters avidly discussed were the state of France's artistic life and whether there is such a thing as ''American cultural imperialism.''

title: SURVEY FINDS HIGH FEAR OF CRIME
description: Fear of crime continues to pervade American society, especially in urban areas, where 76 percent of women fear walking alone at night in their neighborhoods, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: MUSIC: CLEVELAND COMPOSERS
description: NEW YORK chauvinists often divide music of our time into two arbitrary categories: ''uptown'' and ''downtown.'' At Symphony Space on Saturday night, David Stock, conductor of the Pittsburgh New Music Ensemble, made a plea for what he called ''out-of-town'' music, and devoted an entire program to works by members of the Cleveland Guild of Composers.

title: 76ERS ROUT KNICKS, 104-89
description: The Knicks, who had won 10 of their last 12 games, were jolted back into the real world of pro basketball today. As they were being routed, 104-89, by the Philadelphia 76ers at the Spectrum, the Knicks got a quick lesson that the National Basketball Association was divided between an elite class and a lower class, each having several teams, with a lot of mediocrity in between. Against the 76ers, whose 46-7 mark is the best in the league, the Knicks performed like the 14-26 team they were last Jan. 21, rather than the 24-29 team they are.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Taste of the Apple, Transplanted to Frankfurt

title: OF DOCTORS, LAWYERS, ETHICS AND DOLLARS
description: To the Editor:

title: 16 TRIBAL GROUPS CONSTITUTE 10% OF POPULATION IN ASSAM
description: Assam, India's remote northeastern state where at least 600 civilians were reported yesterday to have been killed by Hindu tribesmen, has a population of nearly 15 million. Among these, there are at least 16 tribal groups that make up perhaps 10 percent of the state's population.

title: PROPER WASHINGTON SUPPORT FOR COSTA RICAN DEMOCRACY
description: To the Editor:

title: FLYERS' FROESE (12-0-1) STOPS DEVILS, 3-0
description: Bob Froese, the rookie goalie of the Philadelphia Flyers, turned in his third shutout tonight with a 3-0 victory over the Devils. He faced only 16 shots and extended his unbeaten record to 13 games (12-0-1) since he was brought up from the Maine Mariners of the American Hockey League last Jan. 7. The National Hockey League record for an unbeaten rookie is 14 games (11-0-3), set by Bill Burnan of the Montreal Canadiens in 1943-44.

title: Museum Gets $60,000 For Volume of Criticism
description: The New Museum has been awarded a grant of $60,000 by the Henry Luce Foundation to finance a volume of critical essays on art devoted to 20th-century art and ideas. The volume is intended to be a general reference guide to source material.

title: Money Supply Fraud Case
description: A Federal judge has imposed a sentence of one year's probation on a former Federal Reserve System employee who illegally retrieved sensitive information from the Fed's computer after he left the agency.

title: AFTER 'M*A*S*H' COMES 'AFTERMASH'
description: Larry Gelbart, the writer who shaped ''M*A*S*H'' into a prime-time television institution 11 years ago, is creating its successor, a new series for CBS next fall called ''Aftermash'' (''One word, no asterisks,'' he says).

title: Villanova Takes 2 Big East Titles
description: John Marshall set a Big East record of 1 minute 51.9 seconds in the 800-meter run today and paced Villanova to the conference's indoor track championship in the Carrier Dome.

title: TEACHING PARENTS TO DISCIPLINE
description: A letter arrived in the mail notifying the parents that their 16-year-old son had failed three subjects and cut class on at least 21 different occasions. Should the parents (a) take away privileges in order to improve performance, (b) suggest the school was at fault for not notifying them soon enough to take remedial action or (c) take no action themselves but let the youngster face the stigma of not graduating with his peers?

title: Time to Turn the Illegal Tide
description: Mr. Immigration, they call him in Washington and for good reason. Repeatedly, Peter Rodino, Chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, has been a man ahead of his time. He was instrumental in enacting the 1965 law undoing the odious national origins quota system. In the early 70's, he recognized, long before others, that further reform depended on making it illegal for employers to hire illegal immigrants. Twice, he managed to get the House to enact such sanctions.

title: RELATIONSHIPS
description: YOU think you are an expert. But then so does everyone else. F riends and relatives keep saying that after giving birth to one c hild - and coaxing him or her through the first year - you are e minently prepared to handle a second. By comparison, they observe a nd you believe, the second time around will be a breeze.

title: GOOD NEWS OFTEN BRINGS MORE NEWS
description: WASHINGTON Feb. 20 - There hasn't been much good economic news in recent months. But when there has been, President Reagan has often managed to take full advantage of it, to the point that a pattern seems to be emerging.

title: Reagan Hints More Aid To Greece for Bases Pact
description: The Greek Government has made public a letter from President Reagan to Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou suggesting that Washington would increase aid to Greece in return for an agreement on United States military bases here.

title: SIGN THE SEA-LAW TREATY
description: ''Ten thousand fleets sweep over thee in vain,'' Byron wrote admiringly of the ocean. ''Man marks the earth with ruin - his control stops with the shore.''

title: YALE MAN TRIES FOR METS' SPOT
description: Besides his name, Ron Darling may have more personal distinctions than anybody else in the training camp of the Mets.

title: FUTURE QUESTIONABLE BUT HIS OUTLOOK IS BRIGHT
description: LEXINGTON, Ky. A CUMBERSOME plaster of Paris cast has become a part of Sam Bowie's uniform the last two years. There have been times when it felt so normal to be wearing it that Bowie might have been persuaded to paint the cast in Kentucky blue, inscribe his number 31 and resume his playing career. His thin legs always gave the impression that he was walking on stilts, so a cast would only help make him look more formidable.

title: ODYSSEY ENDS IN BRAZIL FOR CUBAN CIGAR MAKER
description: A search by one of Cuba's great cigar-making clans for a place with the characteristics suitable for re-creating their aromatic old Havanas has led to this small farming community in the backlands of Brazil's state of Bahia.

title: STUDY OF JOB-LINKED BRAIN CANCER PLANNED FOR TEXAS AND LOUISIANA
description: A new study by medical scientists in Texas and Louisiana will try to determine if occupational exposure in the chemical and petrochemical industries increases the risk of brain cancer.

title: Hijacked Libyan Plane Held at Malta Airport
description: A Libyan airliner carrying about 160 passengers was hijacked in midflight today and landed at a Malta airport ringed by policemen and soldiers, the Maltese police reported.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It was every person for himself, and our women, the old men and the children could not run fast enough,'' - Abdul Matalib, a survivor of a massacre in Assam, India. (A11:4.)

title: MARTYRDOM AND TRADE
description: To the Editor:

title: Folk City Irish Concerts For St. Patrick's Season
description: Four concerts of traditional Irish music will be presented at Folk City in the Irish Festival '83, a celebration of the season of St. Patrick, opening with a performance next Friday by James Keane, an accordionist; Robbie O'Connell, a singer, and Mick Moloney, a banjo and mandolin player.

title: SHULTZ ASSERTS LIBYAN THREAT HAS 'RECEDED'
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that what the Reagan Administration believed last week was a military threat by Libya against the Sudan had now ''receded.''

title: FOR YOUNG PEOPLE OF THE PENNSYLVANIA STEEL COUNTRY, A DIM FUTURE IS SEEN
description: Youth is supposed to be a golden time. But in the towns of western Pennsylvania, for a hundred years the gritty center of American industrial production, the bounty that the steel mills bought is ebbing, and so, in many cases, are the spirits of the young.

title: BANKER IN TENNESSEE ASSAILS FEDERAL INQUIRY
description: Outside, the late winter light was fading behind the golden Sunsphere, the symbol of the 1982 World's Fair. Inside, in a nearby condominium apartment he had refurbished and stocked with fine wines for dignitaries visiting his extravaganza, Jake F. Butcher, the banker-politician who brought the fair to Tennessee, mulled in disbelief the demise of his flagship United American Bank and rubbed his eyes wearily.

title: BASKETBALL'S ROAD TO ALBUQUERQUE
description: OUT on the basketball court at Madison Square Garden yesterday, the cheerleaders in red and white unfurled a banner that proclaimed, ''St. John's Is For Real.'' Written on it in a Rockaway scrawl was a personal message from a St. John's alumnus at courtside with an NBC microphone.

title: THOUSANDS RALLY FOR EMBATTLED NKOMO
description: Singing songs of praise, thousands of Zimbabweans gathered outside the home of the opposition leader Joshua Nkomo today in a demonstration of support after his detention by the police Saturday.

title: THAI TRIBE IS BEING PRICED OUT OF ITS OWN RELIGION
description: Lao Lu, a high priest of the hill people known as the Yao, seemed the soul of trust as he talked with a visitor to his village northwest of here. He is 62 years old and his real name is Lei Tsan Kuei, but everyone calls him Lao Lu - ''sixth eldest'' among his brothers.

title: INDIAN PLANT NOW PRODUCING WEAPONS-GRADE PLUTONIUM
description: India has begun producing weapons-grade plutonium at a nuclear reprocessing plant near Bombay, but the operation is being monitored by international inspectors instructed to warn if the plutonium is diverted to military use, United States Government officials said today.

title: Bridge: Fishermen Are Not Alone In Coloring the Facts a Bit
description: Fishermen boast about the one that got away without considering that failure might be regarded as a reflection on their skill. Bridge players, however, are more sensitive and find different ways to distort the truth.

title: Venture in U.S.  For Nippondenso
description: The Nippondenso Company, one-fifth owned by the Toyota Motor Corporation, said it planned to produce auto parts in the United States for the joint venture between Toyota and the General Motors Corporation.

title: A NEW DISPUTE BLOCKING ACCORD IN TOKEN BATTLE
description: The four-month effort to figure out what to do about the Connecticut Turnpike tokens that fit New York City subway turnstiles has hit yet another snag, officials said yesterday.

title: STATE CONFRONTS BACKLOG IN DISCIPLINING DOCTORS
description: More than 1,400 complaints of abuse and improper practices against New York State physicians are sitting in the files of a State Health Department office, a backlog the head of the agency said was ''not justifiable.''

title: JURY SAID TO HAVE SPARED BOY 'DRIVEN' TO KILL
description: The attorney for a 16-year-old boy convicted of manslaughter in the shooting death of his father says the jurors rejected a greater charge of murder apparently because they decided the youth ''was driven to a certain state of mind that caused him to act the way he did.''

title: OIL PRICING STIRS FEAR OF IMPACT
