description: The reduction in oil prices announced Saturday by Nigeria has raised broad international concern about growing price competition that could lower the price of crude oil so sharply that economic dislocations could result.

title: 3 Die in Pit Collapse
description: Firefighters and passers-by clawed at dirt with picks, shovels and bare hands in a vain attempt to save three workers buried when the wall of a pit collapsed.

title: Bomb Attack in Brussels
description: A gasoline bomb was thrown against the Congo Embassy in Brussels early today, breaking a window and causing minor damage inside, the police reported. No group claimed reponsibility for the attack. Congo is a former French colony.

title: Swiss Capture Bobsled Crown
description: Ralph Pichler, who had to qualify for his Swiss national team to participate in the world two-man bobsled championship, won the title today at Mount Van Hoevenberg.

title: Hallberg Triumphs On 18th-Hole Birdie
description: Gary Hallberg, playing with a relic of a putter, used it to sink an eight-foot birdie putt on the 18th hole and defeat Tom Kite by a stroke in the Isuzu-Andy Williams San Diego Open today.

title: Louisiana Mall in Uproar After Shooting in Cafe
description: A 24-year-old man opened fire in a crowded mall restaurant, wounding one woman, before he was talked into surrendering by a Secret Service agent and a trooper who had been shopping nearby, officials said today. The suspect, Karl Acosta, was booked Sunday on charges of attempted murder in the shooting Saturday night of Cindy Quebedeaux, who was listed in stable condition with a gunshot wound.

title: Lloyds Profits Off 18.1% in '82
description: Lloyds Bank, one of Britain's four major clearing banks, reported an 18.1 percent drop in 1982 pretax profits, to 315.9 million ($486.5 million), from 385.6 million ($593.8 million) the previous year.

title: TV: 'RESEARCH FOR THE SOUL'
description: THE problem with ''Research for the Soul,'' the documentary on Channel 13 at 10:30 tonight, is that it doesn't tell you enough about the Schomburg Collection or the man who founded it. But it probably didn't intend to.

title: PRESIDENT OF AMHERST COLLEGE
description: Julian H. Gibbs, the president of Amherst College since 1979 and a leading figure in the field of physical chemistry, died of a heart attack yesterday at Bay State Medical Center in Springfield, Mass. He was 58 years old.

title: Richard Maquire, Close Aide To President Kennedy, Dies
description: Richard Maguire, an aide to President Kennedy and a former treasurer of the Democratic National Committee, died Friday at his home here after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 21, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Council for Namibia - 3:30 P.M.

title: Margaret Corwin, 93, Once Dean at Rutgers
description: Margaret Trumbull Corwin, dean for 21 years of Rutgers University's New Jersey College for Women, now known as Douglass College, died Saturday at Yale-New Haven Hospital. Miss Corwin, a resident of Guilford, Conn, was 93 years old.

title: Market Place; Interest Rates Still Call Tune
description: THAT frequently predicted crack in stock prices has yet to appear. Last week, key indicators for the New York Stock Exchange, the American Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market all set new records.

title: LITTLE TOWNS ARE CUT OFF IN U.S. BUS DEREGULATION
description: It's been years since any passenger trains stopped here. Kerman never was big enough for airline service. And soon, the Greyhound buses that come to a stop at Kerman Junction twice a day with a hiss of their brakes will be gone.

title:
CALLING FOR PEACE IN SOVIET;
The following questions and answers were written by Sergei Batovrin, the 26-year-old spokesman of a small, unsanctioned Soviet peace group. They were received in New York City and translated by Catherine A. Fitzpatrick at Helsinki Watch. Last September, she visited Mr. Batovrin at the psychiatric hospital in Moscow where he was interned for his peace activities. Soon afterward, he was released, but severe harassment of the group continues.
description: Q. Does the movement exist? Or, as some in the West suppose, is it paralyzed by harassment?

title: No Headline
description: Pope Hopes for Truce In Lands He Is to Visit

title: FRANCE GETS TOUGH WITH 'LE HOT DOG'
description: Hopeful French actors may be dismayed to learn that they will no longer be able to turn up at ''le casting'' in search of a job.

title: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 21, 1983; Energy
description: OPEC members are conferring urgently to avoid a price war that Persian Gulf oil exporters fear may result from Nigeria's slashing of its posted price by $5.50 a barrel, to $30. Non-OPEC North Sea producers cut their prices Friday. (Page A1.) Nigeria's move put its prices below Britain's for comparable quality crude, increasing concern about the stability of the existing oil-pricing structure. (D1.)

title: THE LIMITS OF FED POWER TO CURE THE ECONOMY
description: To the Editor:

title: Szigeti Is Remembered At Carnegie Hall
description: It was fitting perhaps, that the most moving part of the tribute to the Joseph Szigeti in Carnegie Hall on Saturday night was one of the Hungarian violinist's own recordings. The event, planned by Edith Jonas Levy, a friend of the violinist, gathered his family and distinguished musical company to honor the 10th anniversary of his death.

title: School Strike Leaders Accept Third-Party Plan
description: Leaders of blue-collar workers striking the Philadelphia school district accepted a contract proposal presented by two City Council members tonight at a meeting that was boycotted by school officials.

title: PROPOSED HALT TO DAILY BUS RUNS ALARMS DEPENDENT PEOPLE UPSTATE
description: The proposal by the Greyhound Bus Company to cancel its remaining two runs a day to this village on the Susquehanna River has aroused the protests of dozens of elderly people.

title: TV MOVIE: GRACE KELLY
description: ''GRACE KELLY,'' tonight's television movie on Channel 7 at 9, maintains that Princess Grace of Monaco assisted in the preproduction of the film for several weeks before her death last year. The extent of that ''assistance'' is not easy to pinpoint, but it may have something to do with the sense of stately awe and suffocating propriety that seeps through the project. ''Grace Kelly'' will offend nobody. Unfortunately, it's not likely to interest too many people, either.

title: Layoffs by Timex
description: Citing ''excessive inventories,'' officials of the Timex Corporation said they would temporarily lay off 200 employees at the company's electric clock division here. A Timex spokesman, Robert Hehn, said the layoffs would begin around the end of the month. No estimate was made on how long they would last. Mr. Hehn also said the company had reached an agreement to sell the company's Telechron facility.

title: 38 People Die and 79 Are Hurt In a Train Collision in Mexico
description: At least 38 people were killed and 79 injured in a collision between a passenger train and a freight train in northwestern Mexico, the police said today.

title: GAMECOCKS' COACH BACK AFTER ILLNESS
description: When Bill Foster, the basketball coach at the University of South Carolina, walked onto the court in the Carolina Coliseum at Columbia, S.C., Saturday, he received a standing ovation from the crowd of 8,873. And the opposing coach, George Blaney of Holy Cross, made a point of shaking Foster's hand, wishing him well and remarking how good it was to see him back.

title: A Law to Cure Blindness
description: A quirk in state law keeps some New Yorkers blind when they could be cured by the implantation of corneal tissue from a dead donor. There's no easier way to cure some people's blindness than to amend the law.

title: Correction
description: The Finance/New Issues column in Business Day on Tuesday misidentified Alan P. Richman. He is a municipal bond analyst at Shearson/American Express.

title: Ex-Irgun Man Named Ambassador to Britain
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin has decided to appoint Israel's Ambassador to South Africa as the new envoy to Britain, succeeding Shlomo Argov, who was severely wounded in a terrorist attack in London last June.

title: TAX MAIL ANNOYS LAWMAKERS
description: The battle over whether to repeal the 10 percent withholding tax on dividends and interest payments is being fought not only in the lobbies and committee rooms of Capitol Hill.It is also being fought in the mailroom.

title: Gwen Brodkin, Illustrator, Is Wed to Chester Zaslow
description: Gwen Brodkin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sid Brodkin of Tucson, Ariz., was married there yesterday to Chester Zaslow, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Zaslow of Hartford.

title: NEW YORK'S SPREADING EDUCATIONAL EXCELLENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: E.P.A. ADMINISTRATOR SAID TO ASK INQUIRY ON MISS LAVELLE'S ACTIONS
description: The administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency has asked the Justice Department to determine whether a former subordinate, Rita M. Lavelle, had acted improperly, according to high agency officials.

title: Topics; Animal, Vegetable; The Surly Test
description: Telephone surliness is increasing, says a firm called Sindlinger & Co., which proves that times are really bad. The company observes that previous surges of surliness occurred during the recession of 1957, just after the inflationary uncertainty of 1971 and during the great oil embargo of 1974.

title: 'CHOKING' DEATH IS LATER TERMED ROBBERY MURDER
description: The manager of two West Side health clubs, at first believed to have choked to death on a piece of meat, was found yesterday to have been killed by a gunshot to the head.

title: LIBYAN CONGRESS ANNOUNCES 'SUICIDE SQUADS'
description: Libya has announced that it will remain on the offensive against both Israel and those ''symbols of treason'' in the Arab world that are aligned with the United States.

title: FOR L.I. SKATERS, SPEED'S THE THING
description: Three-year-old Mary Battaglini had competed in a few local speed-skating races before, but those always started with a friendly man saying, ''On your mark, get set, go.''

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: With a man on first, the batter bunts down the first-base line. The first baseman charges the ball and, while straddling the baseline, wheels and attempts to throw to second. The batter, running on the foul side of the line, bumps into the first baseman, who drops the ball. What is the ruling?

title: Dressed for Success
description: The task of outfitting more than 700 athletes who will compete for the United States in the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles will be handled by Levi Strauss. In addition, the apparel company will take care of the uniform clothing needs of approximately 20,000 people working for the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee.

title: BY 1989, MEDICARE WILL USE UP FUND, 2 U.S. REPORTS SAY
description: Medicare, the health insurance program for 26 million elderly Americans, is facing huge financial problems that have been exacerbated by the withdrawal of $12.4 billion from the Medicare trust fund to rescue the old-age benefits trust fund of the Social Security system.

title: POTHOLE CREWS ERASING LEGACY OF THE BIG SNOW
description: Throughout the city, 330 workers -about three-quarters of the city's pothole repair staff - are spending the holiday weekend trying to undo some of the damage caused by last weekend's snowstorm.

title: NIGERIAN OIL PRICE CUT SPURS URGENT TALKS WITHIN OPEC
description: Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf countries are engaged in urgent consultations with other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries seeking to prevent an oil price war that could break up OPEC.

title: TRADE WAR FEARED OVER FOOD EXPORT ISSUE
description: Almost against the will of the participants, the competition for a share of world food markets has escalated to the point where it threatens to ignite a trade war among the industrialized nations.

title: LIBBY, MCNEILL & LIBBY CHOOSES NEW PRESIDENT
description: Libby, McNeill & Libby Inc., a subsidiary of Nestle Enterprises Inc., has been changing its product mix for the last year, and now it has changed presidents.

title: PRIME TIME FOR A WALK
description: ONE of the most exciting races of this indoor track season, or any other season, was held at the decidedly-not-prime time of 6:40 P.M. last Jan. 28. The race was the one-mile walk, an event that sometimes draws titters from casual observers who have no idea how hard it is to keep one foot or the other on the ground at all times, vigorously churn the arms and upper body for power, and grind out times faster than six minutes per mile.

title: Barbara Abrams Is Married
description: Barbara B. Abrams, widow of Joseph L. Abrams, was married at her home in Manhattan yesterday to Milton S. Harrison, a lawyer practicing in White Plains. Rabbi Maurice Davis of White Plains performed the ceremony, which was attended by the bride's children, Ellen Abrams of New York and Peter J. Abrams of Hollywood, Calif., and the bridegroom's son, Dr. Joseph Harrison of White Plains. Mr.Harrison has another son, Dr. Michael Harrison of Tel Aviv, also from his first marriage to the late Joan Kant Harrison. His second wife, Margery Malsin Harrison, also died.

title: WAUKEGAN WEARY OF LONG POLLUTION FIGHT
description: For seven years since high concentrations of PCB's were found in its inner harbor on Lake Michigan, Waukegan has been frustrated by legal and scientific wrangling over the cleanup of the toxic wastes.

title: Early Music Ensemble Journeys to 17th Century
description: The Ensemble for Early Music's evening at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday night dwelled mainly in the 17th century and mostly on the voice. Peter Becker, Mark Bleeke, Wilbur Pauley and Carol Wilson combined their voices in madrigals by Monteverdi and others, but most of the burden fell on Sally Sanford, who, accompanied by the lutes and guitars of Robert and Catherine Liddell Strizich, sang music of Alessandro Grandi, Pietro Berti, Giovanni Stefani, Biagio Marini, Carlo Milanuzzi, Sigismondo d'India and again Monteverdi.

title: No Headline
description: INDOOR TITLE TO CONNORS

title: DEMOCRATS WEIGH ARMS BUDGET CUTS
description: The House Budget Committee has been holding extensive hearings on President Reagan's proposed military budget for 1984. But in the end, Representative Les Aspin said, the Democratic majority will decide how much money to allocate not by finely honed calculations about money and weapons but ''by a state of feel.''

title: 70'S TOXIC WASTE DISPOSAL OPENS QUESTIONS ON DIOXIN
description: The mishandling of toxic wastes by a Louisiana disposal company 12 years ago has raised questions about what happened to dioxin shipped to it around the same time by a Missouri chemical plant.

title: Cuomo Tells Aides To Study Charges
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that he had asked two advisers to look into recent accusations of corruption in the Transit Authority's purchasing department.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ROBERT BROWNING: A LIFE WITHIN LIFE. By Donald Thomas. 334 pages. Viking Press. $18.75.

title: No Headline
description: LaPorte Keeps W.B.C. Title

title: Topics; Animal, Vegetable; Hybrids
description: Scientists at Kansas State University have crossed tomatoes with potatoes to produce the pomato: a small, yellow fruit that smells like a tomato but resists blight.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HAPPY BIRTHDAY

title: The Calendar
description: Monday

title: Texas Judge in Divorce Linked to Murder Dies
description: State District Judge Joseph Harvey Eidson Jr., who once faked his own death to assist a Federal investigation of a Texas millionaire, died Saturday at the age of 64.

title: Down to the Sea in Cartels
description: Most ocean cargo liner companies would welcome the maritime ''reform'' now being debated in the Senate. So would most foreign governments. So would most of the industry's customers, the importers and exporters who pay $15 billion a year to ship everything from ketchup to crayons. Why, then, do observers of the industry find the reform proposal offensive? The answer lies in the word ''cartel.''

title: Arrows Lose, 7-6
description: The Buffalo Stallions scored three goals in the third period to edge the New York Arrows, 7-6, today before a crowd of 9,569 at Memorial Auditorium. The score was tied at 4-4 at halftime, but Jim Sinclair, Germain Iglesias and Mike Lashchev scored to give the Stallions a 7-4 lead.

title: 3 CHARGED IN MURDER AND ROBBERIES IN QUEENS
description: Two teen-age brothers and a friend were arrested yesterday and charged with last month's murder of a Queens store manager and the shooting of three people during a three-week-long robbery spree, the police said.

title: SEABED? NO, BED OF NAILS
description: The Law of the Sea Treaty failed to achieve international consensus at Jamaica's Montego Bay. The United States and 46 other nations, together accounting for more than half the global gross domestic product, withheld their signatures. Twenty-two abstained, and 24 did not attend. Thus, the way is cleared to develop more promising arrangements.

title: No Headline
description: WOODSON GETS 48, HITTING 15 IN A ROW

title: Washington Watch; Money Funds And Their Ads
description: WASHINGTON THE Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to add a new weapon this week to the arsenal of money market mutual funds in their fierce battle with banks for consumer deposits.

title: EXPERIMENTAL LIST OFFERS CLUES ON LIKELY DERBY CONTENDERS
description: It sounds too good to be true: a list of 15 horses - available four months before the Kentucky Derby - which has included the Derby winner for 11 years in a row. But such a list exists, and it is neither a tout's scam nor an insider's expensive secret.

title: THE LAPSE IN GERMAN INVESTMENT
description: Despite mildly optimistic forecasts from Government officials and central bankers in Frankfurt, West German business investment is locked in a holding pattern that economists and bankers say could retard early economic recovery.

title: Two Pitt Players Arrested in Fracas
description: Two University of Pittsburgh football players were arraigned today on charges of creating a street disturbance and then attacking the arresting officers, according to the police.

title: DAVID C. McCLUNG
description: David C. McClung, a former president of the Hawaii state Senate and chairman of Hawaii's Democratic Party, died Saturday in Honolulu.

title: Son Accused of Trying To Kill Dying Mother
description: The distraught son of a terminally ill woman has been charged with the attempted mercy killing of his mother by disconnecting her life-support system, the police said today.

title: 600 REPORTED DEAD AFTER HINDU RAIDS ON INDIAN VILLAGES
description: At least 600 men, women and children were killed Friday in an eight-hour attack by Hindu tribespeople on Moslem settlements in this rural area of Assam, a senior state official said today.

title: VIRGINIA ROLLS
description: St. John's took a tentative step forward yesterday, and DePaul continued to go backward. At a point in the basketball season when a team's direction becomes most important, the 64-52 victory by St. John's at Madison Square Garden was a reminder that the teams appear to be headed in opposite directions.

title: Up to 50 Peruvian Rebels Are Reported Slain
description: The police and peasants killed 30 to 50 left-wing rebels in the last three days, news reports said today.

title: EUROPE'S FARM POLICIES CLASH WITH AMERICAN EXPORT GOALS
description: A cause of America's growing agricultural trade tension with Europe is well illustrated on Rene and Nicole Barbot's tiny, muddy farm in Normandy. This young French couple, both in their mid-thirties, are trying to build a life for themselves and their three children on just 20 acres of land in the village of Conde-sur-Vire. They share the property, bought eight years ago on a 25-year mortgage, with 19 cows, 150 calves, a shed full of rabbits and a goat.

title: GERULAITIS CASE: PUBLICITY AND SECRECY
description: Vitas Gerulaitis, one of the world's top tennis players, received some unwanted attention six months ago when his name was mentioned in a trial involving a conspiracy to buy cocaine.

title: MANY SEE JOBS PROPOSAL AS MERELY A FIRST STEP
description: As Congress starts drafting an emergency jobs bill this week, many lawmakers in both parties are grumbling that the legislation will make only a superficial impact on the nation's persistent unemployment problem.

title: Books Of The Times
description: SECRETS: On the Ethics of Concealment and Revelation. By Sissela Bok. 332 pages. Pantheon Books. $16.95

title: The Mondale Line for '84
description: AWEEK before former Vice President Walter F. Mondale officially announced the obvious yesterday, that he would seek the presidency, he was guest of honor at Alice Mason's elegant dinner, charming scores of the 60 rich, powerful and mostly Democratic guests in his warm outgoing way. Mrs. Mason is big in real estate and he sat at her right, next to Barbara Walters and across from the editors of Time and Newsweek, but he didn't allow a table heavily freighted with news people to become a news conference nor to pin him down on the specifics. Yet he left indelible tracks.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Academy Award nominations in Weekend on Friday incorrectly cited the number of previous dual-nomination winners.

title: No Headline
description: Nevada-Las Vegas No. 1

title: SHORTCUT TO LIGHTENING THE HIGH COURT'S LOAD
description: To the Editor:

title: CONFIDENCE ON RATE OUTLOOK
description: The credit markets appear to have shaken off fears that interest rates might rise. Rates on Treasury bills fell last week, by about a quarter of a percentage point, to 7.96 percent for three-month bills and 8.15 percent for six-month bills. At the same time the Treasury's 10 3/8 percent bonds due in 2012 rose about two points. They were offered late Friday at 97 1/8 to yield 10.7 percent, compared with 10.94 percent a few days earlier.

title: Tinto Officer in Talks On British Steel Post
description: Sir Alistair Frame, deputy chairman and chief executive of the Rio Tinto-Zinc Corporation, the mining and manufacturing conglomerate, is reportedly poised to become head of the beleaguered British Steel Corporation. He would replace Ian MacGregor, a former New York investment banker, who is in line to take charge of the National Coal Board this summer.

title: ILL-ADVISED U.S. CONCILIATION OF PRETORIA
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1983
description: International The Middle East peace plan proposed by President Reagan is an unacceptable basis for solving the Palestinian problem, the Palestine Liberation Organization has decided. A P.L.O. spokesman also said the organization would not give Jordan a mandate to negotiate with Washington on its behalf. (Page A1, Column 6.) Features of distant galaxies have been revealed in infrared images received from a new United States telescope that has begun orbiting the Earth. The telescope has also revealed cosmic ''maternity wards'' where clouds of interstellar gas and dust appear to be in various stages of giving birth to stars. (A1:2-4.)

title: Herman & Rosner
description: Herman & Rosner Enterprises has become agency for the 53-outlet Dutch Pantry Family Restaurant chain based in Camp Hill, Pa. The chain had been doing most of its advertising in-house. The budget is about $1.5 million.

title: CHICAGO PRIMARY MARKED BY CANDIDATES AS DIVERSE AS THE CITY
description: As the most expensive municipal election campaign in American history draws to a close here today, Chicago's voters for once face a choice of candidates as diverse as the giant city that spawned them.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Jan. 17 on graduate-program ratings by four national academic organizations omitted a department from the ''top 10'' listing in microbiology, ranked by faculty reputation. The department, at the University of Washington, ranked third, after the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Rockefeller University.

title: 1 Dead, 4 Hurt in Blast
description: A steam cooker for drying paperboard pulp blew up today at the California Paperboard Corporation, killing one man and injuring four people. The explosion tore a hole in the roof and scattered parts of the large cooker as far as 30 yards away in an industrial area of Santa Clara. Officials speculated that the blast might have resulted from failure of a pressure relief valve.

title: HELP FOR SCIENCE MAY BE ON WAY
description: PUBLIC concern over the quality of science and mathematics teaching has risen in recent years to a pitch recalling the frenzy of reform that followed the Soviet Union's launching of Sputnik 1, 25 years ago. Though there is yet no consensus on what exactly should be done, a great many public officials at all levels now agree that some kind of action is required, and soon.

title: SPOT OIL PRICES DIP IN LONDON
description: Prices quoted for most crude oil fell nearly $1 a barrel today on London's spot market. Activity was light, as traders waited for Saudi Arabia and other oil producers on the Persian Gulf to respond to price cuts by Nigeria, Britain and Norway.

title: DEVILS ARE TIES WITH 0:10 LEFT
description: Paul Cyr of Buffalo scored a goal with 10 seconds left against a harried Glenn (Chico) Resch tonight to give the Sabres a 4-4 tie with the Devils at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: VARIED LIST OF TAX-FREE ISSURES IS SET
description: Investment bankers have scheduled a wide variety of tax-exempt issues for sale this week, including an issue of New York City bonds. Few corporate offerings are planned.

title: NEW DRIVE UNDER WAY IN CONGRESS TO REVAMP U.S. IMMIGRATION LAW
description: Congressional efforts to rewrite the nation's basic immigration law have resumed, with Senator Alan K. Simpson and Representative Romano L. Mazzoli introducing legislative proposals.

title: PUBLISHED MORE THAN 100 BOOKS
description: Robert Payne, the author of more than 100 books, most of them reflecting his interest in the marriage of Eastern and Western cultures, died while on vacation in Bermuda Friday of complications from a stroke and heart attack. The 71-year-old writer had entered King Edward VII Hospital Feb. 6.

title: EX-OFFICIAL'S OBSESSION WITH VIETNAM WAR
description: Fourteen years ago Ralph W. McGehee sat in a sparsely furnished Saigon apartment contemplating the disintegration of his small corner of the American Dream. He thought about hanging a banner out his window that said ''THE C.I.A. LIES'' and then shooting himself with the rifle he kept in his bedroom.

title: Gray Gets Support Of Savings Industry
description: Edward J. Gray, who was nominated last week as a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, has garnered unusually strong support from the beleaguered savings and loan industry not only because of his experience as an executive of a major savings institution, but also because of his close and potentially useful ties to the White House.

title: Washington Address Gets Sparse Audience
description: The Senate, continuing a tradition begun in 1896, convened today on Washington's birthday to hear a reading of the first President's farewell address.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Theatrical Hive

title: MORE RULES FOR BANKS PROPOSED
description: Banks may have to report more often and in greater detail on their foreign lending, set up larger reserves against ''problem'' foreign loans and alter the way they handle fees under proposals that could become law this year, Congressional analysts say.

title: AN F.C.C. CHIEF IN AN ERA OF BROADCASTING CHANGE
description: Since assuming the chairmanship of the Federal Communications Commission nearly two years ago, Mark S. Fowler has beaten the drums for broadcast deregulation more insistently than any of his predecessors. But so far he appears to have scored more points for rhetoric than results.

title: U.S. Aide Sees Oil Price Drop
description: A top Energy Department official told a Congressional hearing today that oil prices, already tumbling because of a worldwide oversupply caused by the recession, are likely to drop further.

title: News Analysis
description: That the Toyota Motor Corporation and General Motors Corporation say they may bypass the United Automobile Workers in the California plant they plan to operate demonstrates the difficulties foreign companies face as they enter the United States.

title: YARBOROUGH MANEUVERS TO VICTORY
description: The move that won the Daytona 500 for Cale Yarborough was not his 200-mile-an-hour, last-lap passing of Buddy Baker, who was driving a faster car.

title: CURRENCY SALE HALTED BY CARACAS
description: The Venezuelan Government ordered all sales of foreign exchange suspended today and Tuesday. The Government took the action Sunday night to slow the flight of capital out of the country. Bankers and financial analysts predicted that the Government will supplement the measure within days with formal rules. Government officials were not available to comment on their plans.

title: EARNINGS STILL WEAK IN QUARTER
description: Company earnings continued to fall on a year-to-year basis in the fourth quarter, although profits have been moving higher from one quarter to the next.

title: Accounts
description: * Berje Inc., Long Island City, to Plapler & Associates.

title: JAPAN VIDEO ACCORD LEAVES EUROPEANS WARY BUT HOPEFUL
description: Japan's plan to limit exports of videotape recorders to the European Economic Community appears to be easing trade tensions. But two European companies that had filed complaints against Japanese trade practices say they are not yet prepared to withdraw them.

title: The Nostalgic Holmes
description: Ten years after he earned $63 for his first professional fight, Larry Holmes wants to return to Scranton, Pa., to defend his world heavyweight title against Lucien Rodriguez of France, the European champion.

title: MRS. GANDHI, ON A TOUR OF ASSAM, BLAMES 'AGITATORS' FOR MASSACRE
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi toured the northeastern state of Assam by helicopter and car today and comforted weeping Moslem survivors of mass attacks by Hindu tribespeople. She said student-led opponents of state elections were responsible for the attacks last Friday in which about 600 Moslems were killed.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Knicks vs. Dallas Mavericks, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue and 33d Street, 7:35 P.M. After being routed Sunday at Philadelphia, the Knicks resume play against a team closer to their level.

title: Marcos Calls Premier Most Likely Successor
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos today described Prime Minister Cesar Virata as his most likely successor. Mr. Marcos, 65 years old, said in an interview that if he were to die or be disabled before his term ended in 1987, the Prime Minister would have the support of the Cabinet, the military and the First Lady, Imelda Marcos. In such a case, a 10-member executive committee headed by the Prime Minister takes over the presidency until an election can be held.

title: ORBITING TELESCOPE GLIMPSES 'BIRTH' IN SPACE
description: In its first days of operation, a new telescope orbiting the earth has returned infrared images showing previousy unobserved features of distant galaxies and revealing cosmic ''maternity wards'' where clouds of interstellar gas and dust appear to be in various stages of giving birth to stars.

title: Addenda
description: * Bio/Technology, a new monthly trade magazine to be published by Nature Publishing Company, beginning in March.

title: THE ROOTS OF VIOLENCE: REFUGEES AND RESENTMENTS
description: The violence in Assam, touched off by a student-led campaign to boycott and disrupt last week's state elections, has its roots in religious, political, ethnic and economic resentments.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: In 1950, Eiji Toyoda decided that if Japan was to have an automobile industry, his company had better learn how to make them properly. To do that, he naturally went to the United States, where he spent a month or so touring American auto plants, observing the latest machines and manufacturing methods in action, taking notes all the while.

title: CHAMBER: WUORINEN
description: TWO early works by active composers provided the most interesting moments on Sunday's International Chamber Artists program at Town Hall. Charles Wuorinen's Trio Concertante for Violin, Oboe and Piano dates from 1958, when the composer was in his early 20's.

title: BAT CASE MAY EASE U.S.-JAPAN FRICTION
description: When he greeted Japan's trade minister in Tokyo recently, United States Trade Representative Bill Brock gave his Japanese counterpart, Sadanori Yamanaka, a present: an American-made metal baseball bat.

title: F.B.I. INQUIRY ON AFTER-HOURS CLUBS STRAINS LINKS WITH POLICE
description: At 4 A.M., the ground floor of the warehouse was transformed into a cave of fantastic shadows: an all-night crowd spurred on by flashing lights, music, liquor and a little cocaine.

title: Costa Rica Debt Upheld
description: A Geneva Court has rejected efforts to have Costa Rica formally declared in default on a loan, a spokesman for Costa Rica's lawyers said today.

title: A C.L.U. MOVES TO FIND PURPOSE OF SILENT MINUTE
description: The American Civil Liberties Union is seeking to question 54 present and former New Jersey legislators about their reasons for voting on a law that requires schools to begin each day with a moment of silence.

title: New Theater Ticket Booth
description: Beginning today, half-price tickets for theater performances will be available at the new location of the Lower Manhattan Theater Center in the mezzanine of No. 2 World Trade Center. The tickets booth, operated by the Theater Development Fund, was formerly situated at 100 William Street. Hours are Monday through Friday, 11:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M., and Saturday, 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. Information: 354-5800.

title: TV: BIOGRAPHY OF FRANCES FARMER
description: Suddenly, it seems, it's Frances Farmer time. The late actress, whose life disintegrated into a pathetic public spectacle, is now the subject of two film biographies. Already released in theaters across the country, ''Frances'' stars Jessica Lange, whose performance has been nominated for an Academy Award as best actress. Now, tonight on CBS-TV, there is the television movie ''Will There Really Be a Morning?'', with Susan Blakely playing the severely troubled woman.

title: Maidenform Reviewing Creamer Relationship
description: Maidenform, the lingerie maker, is reviewing its relationship with Creamer Inc., the agency that got its business in the summer of 1981.

title: CITY BALLET: IB ANDERSON
description: THE New York City Ballet ended what could only be called one of its most splendidly danced seasons on Sunday night at the State Theater. But even at the close the company came up with some new faces in repertory roles.

title: West Virginia Workers Curbed Over Damages
description: Workers injured on the job in West Virginia will no longer be able to collect punitive damages from their employers, under a bill signed today by Gov. John D. Rockefeller 4th.

title: Bankruptcy's Interim Rules
description: ALTHOUGH it has been eight months since the United States Supreme Court declared the nation's bankruptcy system unconstitutional, there is less certainty than ever about how the system will be changed to solve the constitutional problem.

title: Losing Pounds for Pay
description: There's nothing like the promise of a little cabbage to curb an appetite.

title: MARINES HELP OUT IN LEBANON BLIZZARD
description: United States helicopters joined operations today to rescue hundreds of people stranded by a blizzard along the Beirut-Damascus highway in the hills east of here.

title: Aspirin Impairs Defenses
description: For all its undisputed benefits as a reliever of pain, inflammation, fever and even anxiety, aspirin still has a fair share of detracting side effects. Among the best known is its ability to cause gastrointestinal irritation and bleeding; less well known are the powers of aspirin to increase spread of virus by people with infections and to interfere indirectly with the immunological response to infection.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: ''W E have to reinvent ourselves every day,'' said Gloria Vanderbilt at a dinner Thursday night. In the candlelight she looked brand new in a black dress and wing-shaped diamond earrings, her black hair a small black wing. ''If we don't reinvent, we don't create anything new, if we don't create anything new, we're lost.''

title: Raymond Vitte, 33, an Actor, Dies After Scuffle With Police
description: The actor Raymond Anthony Vitte, costar of the recently canceled ABC-TV series ''The Quest,'' died in the back of a patrol car Sunday night after scuffling with the police, the authorities said today.

title: Inquiry Set in Violence Over Texas Klan Rally
description: Mayor Carole McClellan has ordered an investigation into whether the police used excessive force Saturday in subduing protesters at a Ku Klux Klan march on the state Capitol. Police Chief Frank Dyson said he would not comment until he had reviewed a videotape.

title: THE CONSULTING GAME
description: What with entire professions and skills falling daily into obsolescence before the juggernaut of what is called the new technology, kids these days are more confused than ever about what they ought to be when they grow up.

title: Crime Said to Drop In Jersey's Cities
description: Preliminary figures show that crime in New Jersey's largest cities decreased for the first nine months of 1982, the state police said today.

title: Weekend Inserts Found Tops in Coupons
description: During 1982, weekend - mostly Sunday - newspaper inserts became the dominant form of manufacturers' cents-off coupon distribution, according to a report from the Nielsen Clearing House.

title: Sullivan Vote To Mrs. Tabb
description: Mary Decker Tabb, the distance runner who broke seven world marks and 10 American standards last year, received the Sullivan Award tonight as the top amateur athlete of 1982.

title: 5 in Row at Bowie
description: Donald Miller Jr. rode five straight winners today at Bowie Race Course, including Noble Home, who captured the $57,800 W.P. Burch Purse. Miller, the leading jockey at Bowie, won the fifth through ninth races.

title: RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.53 An index of yields for long-term A-rated general obligation bonds compiled weekly by The Bond Buyer. Aa Utility Bonds*12.62 Salomon Brothers' estimate for new long-term issues.

title: Italian Refiners Post Big Loss
description: Italian oil refiners lost 2,000 billion lire in 1982 after losing 2,300 billion in 1981, according to Achille Albonetti, president of the oil industry's trade association. Last year's loss is equivalent to $1.45 billion at current exchange rates.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Putting a Rumor to Rest

title: Rose President Ready For Link With Chase
description: John L. Rose said he began playing the stock market as a Navy lieutenant in the mid-1960's, and found he was good at it. When his hitch ended in 1967, he left the sea for the trading floor.

title: Kuwait Airbus Order
description: The Kuwait Airways Corporation has placed orders for 11 A300 European Airbus jets valued at $1 billion, chief executive Ahmed al-Mishari said today at a press conference. The first of the aircraft will be delivered in September, he said, and the airline will lease another Airbus during the summer to meet an expected upsurge in demand.

title: 2 'MAGNET SCHOOLS' STRIVE TO STAY THE BEST IN CITY
description: They are unlikely spots for excellence - two junior high schools situated on blocks surrounded by burned-out tenements and abandoned lots. One sits in the shadow of the parachute jump at Coney Island, the other in a neighborhood that has become synonomous with urban blight, the Bushwick section of Brooklyn.

title: Turkey and U.S. Sign Accord
description: Turkey and the United States signed an agreement today under which the two Governments will exchange scientists and scholars and set up joint projects in the fields of health, energy, agriculture and industry, Turkish officials said.

title: Defense Dept. Contract Data
description: The General Dynamics Corporation received $5.9 billion worth of defense contracts in 1982, heading the list of 18 companies that each did more than $1 billion in business with the Defense Department, according to Pentagon data.

title: Stricter Audits Urged For Medicare-Medicaid
description: Medicare and Medicaid could save millions of dollars if officials did stricter audits of unneeded medical care and cut off doctors who repeatedly overcharged, according to a study by the General Accounting Office.

title: ON HEAT AND LIGHT
description: During his last news conference, President Reagan was asked why he did not withdraw the nomination of Kenneth Adelman to head the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, since the Senate Foreign Relations Committee otherwise would reject the nomination.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN RIGHTIST RIVALS SQUARE OFF
description: Prime Minister P.W. Botha's most important right-wing challenger resigned his seat in Parliament today in order to set up by-elections that could be a crucial test of sentiment among white voters on plans to give nonwhites a subordinate role in the national Government.

title: Nuclear Ban Backed in Iowa
description: The Iowa Legislature today formally ratified a proposal for a nuclear weapons freeze by adopting a resolution to be sent to President Reagan. The State Senate approved the measure, 41 to 7, following earlier approval by the House.

title: Frank Farrell, 71, a Columnist For Three Papers in New York
description: Frank Farrell, a public relations executive and former New York newspaper columnist, died in his sleep last Thursday at his apartment in Manhattan. He was 71 years old.

title: Canada Urges Cut In Sulfur Emission
description: Environment Minister John Roberts, citing a two-year acid rain study by United States and Canadian scientists, today asked for a 50 percent cut in sulfur emissions.

title: Article 247711 -- No Title
description: The American Motors Corporation lost $2.9 million in the fourth quarter of 1982, its 11th-straight quarterly deficit, bringing its losses for the year to $153.5 million, the auto maker said today.

title: German Steel Plan
description: The West German Government made clear today that it was not bound by an independent report that called for regrouping the country's steel industry into two giant units, and would not dictate any such restructuring plan to the industry. The report foresees the two biggest steel companies, Thyssen and Krupp, linking to form a ''Rhine Group,'' with Hoesch, Kloeckner and Salzgitter.

title: CATCHER SITUATION INTRIGUES YANKEES
description: At one point last season, Butch Wynegar said he would demand a trade if Rick Cerone stayed with the Yankees, and Cerone said he would become a free agent if Wynegar stayed. They did not dislike each other, but each wanted to be an everyday catcher.

title: CONCERT: LEPPARD LEADS Y MUSICIANS
description: GOOD marriages grow often from an attraction between opposites. Sunday's concert at the 92d Street Y, for example, subjected the Y Chamber Symphony - an ensemble noted for tense, driven virtuosity - to the softening influence of its guest conductor, Raymond Leppard. The Leppard style was not one of flowing phrases or easy grace, but it calmed and smoothed this orchestra's hard-edged string sound admirably.

title: A Friend Returns
description: In the early 1950's, the roller derby was so popular that it was on television three nights a week. That overexposure almost killed it.

title: HOSPITAL PATIENTS CAN SUFFER TWICE WHEN STAFF ADDS INSULT TO INJURIES
description: THE feeling has come over almost everyone at one time or another: a sense of deep embarrassment in a doctor's office or in a hospital room. It's a kind of humiliation that seems to grow out of vulnerability, nakedness, of being handled, left exposed to be clinically peered at and examined like a grapefruit in a grocery.

title: CLEVELAND MAFIA BROUGHT DOWN BY LOOSE TALK
description: It was Dec. 16, 1980, and Joseph (Joey) Gallo, who had ambitions to lead Cleveland's Mafia ''family,'' was breaking one of the organization's most important rules.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. LEADER SEES NO RECOVERY WITHOUT JOB PLAN
description: Lane Kirkland, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., said today that if unemployment continued at the ''intolerable'' rate of 9 or 10 percent there could be no sustained recovery this year or next.

title: CABBIES IN VIOLATION OF A HUMAN RIGHTS LAW
description: To the Editor:

title: HOT MARKET IN NEW STOCKS
description: The boom in initial public stock offerings that began in August is continuing, led by companies that provide either computer-related products or services for the medical profession.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why is it less dangerous if the nuclear reactor of a falling satellite (such as the Soviet Cosmos 1402) burns up in space than if it falls to earth in one piece? Aren't radioactive atoms just as present one way as another?

title: Parcells's Method
description: Bill Parcells, the Giants' new head coach, is so organized that he knows what he and his staff will be doing every day from now until training camp opens in late July. He recently distributed a memorandum to his assistants and Giants' executives listing a day-byday schedule.

title: E.P.A. Head Becomes Anne McGill Burford
description: Because of her marriage, Anne M. Gorsuch, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, has changed her name to Anne McGill Burford, according to her spokesman.

title: CBS SCORES A COUP IN YARBOROUGH'S CAR
description: E ven if Hollywood had devised the script, it could not have improved on the dramatic windup to last Sunday's Daytona 500-mile stock-car race. Fortunately, CBS Sports was on the scene for a ''live'' four-hour telecast that was as memorable as Cale Yarborough's thrilling last-lap victory.

title: Worker Is Injured In Industrial Blast
description: An explosion in an industrial oven today seriously injured a worker and broke windows and light fixtures at a Bristol spring manufacturer, fire officials said.

title: MIDEAST: BACK TO CAMP DAVID 'BARE ESSENTIALS'
description: To the Editor:

title: Two-Way TV Surgery
description: Dr. Charles D. Kelman, the ophthalmologist who invented the cataract removal procedure called phacoemulsification, plans to teach his technique, together with a new laser procedure, simultaneously to hundreds of doctors across the United States and Canada by two-way closed-circuit television.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 22, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Council for Namibia - 3:30 P.M.

title: NEW 'MISANTHROPE' FOR BRIAN BEDFORD
description: Brian Bedford, who has been railing at hypocrisy with searing wit as Alceste in Moliere's ''Misanthrope'' at Circle in the Square - a portrayal that has brought him critical praise -played the role once before. It was at Stratford, Ontario, a couple of years ago, and he was less than happy with the results.

title: Wise and Witty Tax Reform
description: Hidden away in Albany there's a Joint Legislative Commission to study the New York State tax laws. To avoid controversy, the chairman, Assembly Majority Leader Daniel Walsh, has concealed its existence for two years, but the first report of its advisory group suggests he should seek attention instead. The report is a model of good sense, clarity, brevity, even humor. Any commission that can produce documents like this will have important things to say about the improvement of a tax structure that's as strangely proportioned as a giraffe.

title: Katz Communications
description: Katz Communications will be taking over the job of national advertising representative for the TV stations of Metromedia, as that communications company closes down its 12-office, in-house rep company. The move will increase the Katz lead over other rep companies in the business. The Katz Independent division will be responsible for sales for WNEW, New York; WTTV, Los Angeles; WTTG, Washington, and KRIV, Houston, while Katz American division will represent WCVB, Boston, and WTCN, Minneapolis.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The biggest problem for us is the off-duty men we must assign for crowd control at the store.

title: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1983; International
description: Oil ministers from six Persian Gulf countries are to meet today to set a strategy for dealing with price reductions by North Sea producers and Nigeria. Algeria has also called for an emergency meeting of the 13-member Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to try to avoid a price war, which could bring the price of oil far below the official OPEC price of $34. (A1.) Prices on the spot market for oil dropped further in expectation of a cut by Saudi Arabia and other major producers. (D12.)

title: Chess: Vaganian of Soviet Takes The Hastings Tournament
description: England's traditional Hastings International Tournament was a great triumph for the 31-year-old Soviet grandmaster Rafael Vaganian, who scored 11-2 to outdistance his nearest rival by 2 1/2 points.

title: EGYPTIAN SAYS RADAR PLANES WERE SENT BY U.S. SOLELY FOR TRAINING
description: The Egyptian Defense Minister said today that four American electronic surveillance aircraft in his country were there for training purposes only and would leave when the training was over.

title: Decision File; Repair Kits Offered For 30,000 Slides
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission recently announced a program in which a toymaker and a distributor will repair 30,000 children's slides.

title: INVESTING A GERMAN VOTE ISSUE
description: West German business has been dragged, willy-nilly, into the country's bitter election campaign. At issue are charges - made by conservative Christian Democratic candidates and rejected by their liberal Social Democratic opponents -that a socialist victory would touch off an investment plunge and a flight of capital from Germany.

title: Magazine Advertising
description: Member magazines of the Publishers Information Bureau reported that their advertising pages rose 5 percent in January from a year earlier. The total was 8,643, a 414-page gain. Revenues increased eight percent, to $229.2 million.

title: 6 Injured in Pakistani Rioting In a Dispute Between Sects
description: Several thousand religious demonstrators rioted here tonight, fighting running battles with the police, witnesses said.

title: Bridge: A Rather Shaky Contract Helps Winners of Pro-Am
description: In some pairs events, the players are limited to a few simple conventions, thus minimizing the need for ''alert'' announcements and explanations.

title: ON A PRESIDENT'S DAY JOY MEANS 50% OFF...
description: Clutching torn shreds of newspaper that advertised discounts, sometimes wearing sneakers to make the walking easier, and often with the whole family trailing behind, thousands celebrated Washington's Birthday yesterday by hunting through racks and bins full of bargains.

title: MATHEMATICA'S SHIFT INTO SOFTWARE FIELD
description: Its roots are in academia. But Mathematica Inc. is one research and consulting firm that has subjected itself to the test of the marketplace by being publicly owned. And a very real test it has been, with the Reagan Administration's reduction of public policy research funding, Mathematica's main source of revenue.

title: WEIBOLDT'S CHIEF DEFINES ROLE
description: Jerome M. Schottenstein, an expert at liquidating failing retail stores, maintains he has been unfairly tarred over the years as a kind of exploiter of others' misfortunes. But now, in his new role as chairman of Wieboldt's, the venerable Chicago department store chain, he has a chance to show he can also nurse an ailing business back to health.

title: URUGUAYAN VOTERS HEED VOICE MUFFLED BY ARMY
description: ''Thank God, you're still well,'' a woman at the next table said to Jorge Batlle Ibanez in a restaurant here.

title: Market Place; Unlisted Issues Hot in London
description: LONDON THE London Stock Exchange index has been setting new highs, trading is heavy and overseas investors have taken big-name stocks such as the drug company Glaxo and I.C.I. Chemicals for heady rides. But it is the exchange's two-year-old Unlisted Securities Market that is stealing the hearts of daring investors.

title: FRENCH LEFT CLAIMS VICTORY IN OVERSEAS VOTE
description: The Government of President Francois Mitterrand claimed success today in elections for regional councils for four French overseas departments in the Caribbean, South America and the Indian Ocean.

title: BLADE YIELDS EVIDENCE OF OLDEST SILK
description: MINERAL traces on an ancient bronze weapon appear to have revealed that silk was used in China 1,000 years earlier than had been supposed.

title: Make Jobs, Not Just Waves
description: With unemployment still so high, the Reagan Administration feels as compelled as Congressional Democrats to show concern by proposing emergency jobs legislation. The President wants to spend $4.1 billion to stimulate employment and another $200 million for relief. The Democrats like the package, or say they would if it were fixed up a little. Both sides recognize that they must move fast, if only for appearances, and that's just what seems likely to emerge, a package that will make more waves than jobs. It's Government as usual, postponing the difficult issues.

title: No Headline
description: BOSTON COLLEGE DEFEATS UCONN, 86-80

title: U.S. Oil Use Down
description: United States oil consumption in January dropped 5.6 percent from January last year, the American Petroleum Institute reported. Its monthly statistical report, issued Friday, showed that consumption, based on withdrawals from primary storage, averaged 15 million barrels daily last month, down from 15.9 million a year earlier, despite a 1.5 percent increase in the amount of gasoline supplied by refiners.

title: Malta Negotiating With Hijackers
description: A hijacked Libyan airliner with about 160 passengers and crew aboard remained encircled at the airport here tonight while Prime Minister Dom Mintoff negotiated with the hijackers from the control tower.

title: ALASKA CAPITAL STAYS PUT, BUT TIME ZONES MAY NOT
description: Gov. Bill Sheffield is talking about something that forced Mayor William Overstreet of Juneau into a recall election three years ago. But it looks as though it will go through this time without a hitch.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Pride and the Pool Table

title: TARKANIAN ENJOYS HIS LIFE AT THE TOP
description: For almost two hours one recent hot, desert day, Jerry Tarkanian, the basketball coach of the nation's only undefeated, No. 1-ranked team - the University of Nevada-Las Vegas - ran practice as if he were directing a stage show on the Strip. He choreographed every step, pausing more often to criticize his squad than to praise it.

title: James Roosevelt Starts Social Security Lobby
description: James Roosevelt, Franklin D. Roosevelt's oldest son, announced today that he was forming a ''people's lobby'' to fight for the Social Security program his father began.

title: OLD GLOBETROTTER, NEW TRICKS
description: C urly Neal's schedule for Feb. 21, as part of the itinerary for the national unit of the Harlem Globetrotters, said ''New York New York.'' That is not the name of a city and its state. That meant there were two basketball exhibitions to be played yesterday at Madison Square Garden, one in the afternoon and one in the evening.

title: TANAKA UNDER GROWING PRESSURE TO QUIT ASSEMBLY
description: A recent opinion poll has shown that 75 percent of the Japanese public think that former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka, who is on trial in connection with the Lockheed bribery scandal, should resign from Parliament.

title: CHAMBER MUSIC: VERMONT PLAYERS
description: THE Vermont Festival Players perform at the Southern Vermont Art Center in Manchester every summer, ad Sunday night they gathered for some chamber music at the Abraham Goodman House.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SPLASHY

title: CHIEF OF STATE, 85, IS EXPECTED TO STEP DOWN SOON IN CHINA
description: A visiting Japanese labor union leader said today that he had been told that Ye Jianying, China's nominal head of state, would soon retire.

title: LEBANON FOR THE LEBANESE
description: Since the invasion of Lebanon last summer, the Israeli Government has taken a number of steps indicating that it may not plan to give up its effective control over southern Lebanon. Whether or not the two countries can reach an agreement on the withdrawal of foreign troops, Israel seems determined to prevent Beirut from re-establishing control over the region. We may well be watching the opportunity to restore Lebanon to the Lebanese run through our fingers.

title: East German Family Flees
description: An East German scientist, his wife and their two daughters fled to the West across the Baltic Sea, the West German coast guard said today. They said the family left the northern coast of East Germany after dark Saturday and landed on the West German coast early Sunday near Lubeck. The family was not identified.

title: Article 246579 -- No Title
description: Refco, a Chicago brokerage firm, and its chairman have agreed to pay fines totaling $525,000 relating to a complaint accusing the firm of violating Federal regulations on commodity speculation.

title: THE DANCE: NEW CAST IN 'FALL RIVER'
description: ABALLET can lack subtlety and still be true to life, for there are times when life is as violent as melodrama. ''Fall River Legend,'' Agnes de Mille's ballet about Lizzie Borden, is seldom subtle. Nevertheless, it is rooted in truth and, when well danced, it can be compelling. Sharing the bill with ''Square Dance'' and ''Firebird,'' it was compelling once again when a new cast appeared in it at Dance Theater of Harlem's performance Sunday afternoon at the City Center.

title: The French Correction
description: Once again, France seems determined to reclaim the word chauvinism. It has been pre-empted by feminists as their favorite pejorative, but originally it meant boastful devotion to one's country, as practiced by one Nicolas Chauvin.

title: Arrows' Coach Stepping Down
description: Don Popovic, who coached the New York Arrows to championships in each of their first four seasons in the Major Indoor Soccer League, plans to step down after this season.

title: BASEBALL
description: ATLANTA (NL) - Invited Gil Patter- s on, right-handed pitcher formerly with t he Yankees, to training camp at West P alm Beach, Fla. Patterson suffered rota- t or cuff injury in his throwing arm in 1977. OAKLAND (AL) - Signed Ted Bosley, o utfielder, to minor league contract that i ncludes tryout with the A's. Fred Stanley, i nfielder, arrived in spring training camp a t Phoenix without a contract. COLLEGE ALLEGHENY - Announced it will l eave the Presidents' Athletic Conference b efore the 1984-85 academic year to join a n ew conference of Division III colleges. T he other members of the new conference, a ll in Ohio, are Case Western Reserve Uni- v erity, Denison University, Kenyon Col- l ege, Oberlin College, Ohio Wesleyan Uni- v ersity and the College of Wooster. EAST CAROLINA - Named Charles E lmquist assistant football coach in c harge of tight ends.

title: Lloyd May Return
description: Dan Lloyd, the linebacker who was sidelined two seasons with cancer and who retired from the Giants last month, has been attempting a comeback with the New Jersey Generals. A decision regarding the signing of a contract was expected to be made by the United States Football League club and by Lloyd today, a club official who asked not to be named told The Associated Press yesterday.

title: Police in Israel Arrest Three Accused of Harassing Rally
description: The police in Jerusalem said today that they had detained three people accused of harassing marchers in a Peace Now rally on Feb. 10 that ended in a grenade attack that killed one demonstrator.

title: DID FLIGHT BEGIN ON THE GROUND OR IN THE TREES?
description: IN a quarry in Bavaria in 1861, workmen extracting slabs of limestone from the bed of a prehistoric sea discovered something like nothing they had ever seen before. It was the fossilized skeleton of a birdlike animal about the size of a pigeon. In some ways it resembled the giant reptilian flyers that once dominated the skies, but it had the clearly marked imprint of feathers attached to its forelimb.

title: OFFICIALS SAY QUEENS WATER PRESENTS NO HEALTH PROBLEM
description: New York City's Commissioners of Health and Environmental Protection, in response to a report in The New York Post yesterday, said there was ''no health problem associated with the water supply'' provided by the Jamaica Water Company to more than 500,000 Queens residents.

title: MUSIC: THE AMERICAN BRASS QUINTET
description: BRASS instruments seem as natural to Americans as the guitar is to Spaniards. They tend to define our musical personalities and underline our cultural history, and perhaps we have no patriotic gesture so sincere as the high school marching band and no sound more American than the jazz trumpet and trombone.

title: MONDALE BEGINS HIS '84 CAMPAIGN
description: Walter F. Mondale announced his Presidential candidacy today, saying improved education and economic growth would enable the United States to ''lead the world again.''

title: P.L.O. COUNCIL SAYS REAGAN'S PROPOSAL IS NOT ACCEPTABLE
description: The Palestine National Council has decided that President Reagan's Middle East plan is an unacceptable basis for solving the Palestinian problem, a P.L.O. spokesman said today.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Question of Rank

title: DR. HOWARD B. RASI
description: Dr. Howard B. Rasi, chief of plastic surgery at Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn, a consultant to other hospitals in Brooklyn and an assistant professor at the Downstate Medical Center of the State University of New York. died of a heart attack Saturday at his home in Huntington, L.I. He was 64 years old.

title: 2 Suspects Denied Bail In Seattle Killings
description: Two men arrested in the killings of 13 people in a gambling club in Seattle's Chinatown were ordered held without bail today because the police were still seeking a third suspect.

title: COPELAN A WINNER IN GULFSTREAM RACE
description: Copelan, who was virtually written off this winter as a Kentucky Derby prospect, today went to the head of the 3-year-old class with a surprisingly easy and impressive victory in the second and faster division of the Fountain of Youth Stakes at Gulfstream Park.

title: Papandreou Welcomes Soviet Premier
description: Prime Minister Nikolai A. Tikhonov of the Soviet Union arrived here today for a four-day visit.

title: Weighing In The Koch Caper
description: During a visit to Israel, Mayor Koch plans to enter Lebanon by the back, Israeli-held door, allegedly to bring news of New York to American marines patrolling Beirut. ''Ready or not here I come,'' he said when the State Department objected about this ''derogation of Lebanon's sovereignty.''

title: Melanson Staking His Claim to No. 1
description: Monday, statistics day, and Roland Melanson knew exactly where to turn in the 20-page printout. ''Here, I think it's usually in a few pages from the front,'' he said, thumbing directly to the goaltending statistics in the National Hockey League's weekly digest of numbers, percentages and averages. ''Yeah, there it is.''

title: Crackdown Urged On Teacher Credits
description: School administrators in New Jersey were warned today by the State Education Commissioner to crack down on the way teachers accumulate credits for graduate study.

title: Iranian Sees Soviet Envoy
description: The Iranian press agency said today that Ambassador Vil K. Boldyrev of the Soviet Union had been received by Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Vellayati. The meeting followed the reported arrest of Iranian Communists on charges of spying for the Soviet Union.

title: People
description: * Jonathan Olken named senior vice president/management director of the Media and Entertainment group of Della Femina, Travisano & Partners Inc.

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: NOT long ago our son John had just been through a practice run for the Preliminary Scholastic Aptitude Test (PSAT) and he expressed surprise that one of the questions had dealt with golf. ''A club is to golf ... '' (correct answer: as a bat is to baseball). Apparently, he said, questions that favor rich kids still have not been eliminated. Then, laughing, he added, ''Well, at least they didn't ask about polo.''

title: NKOMO TELLS ABOUT BEING QUESTIONED BY THE POLICE
description: Josuha Nkomo, Zimbabwe's opposition leader, said today that the police were investigating him, under laws inherited from the white minority Government, to see if he could be indicted on charges ranging from currency fraud to subversion.

title: Advertising; Sugarman Changing Foote Cone
description: IS Leonard Sugarman, the English import running Foote, Cone & Belding's creative department, bringing about the dramatic changes that were expected of him? One outsider who has viewed a reel of new television commercials, and some recent print advertising, would say Yes.

title: Salvador Rebels Report 3 Journalists Are Safe
description: Three journalists, including an American, who have been missing for the last week were purportedly interviewed Sunday night on a new rebel radio station.

title: Lendl Shocked In First Round
description: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia was upset by Pavel Slozil, an unseeded countryman, 3-6, 7-6, 7-5, in the opening round of the $300,000 Gold Coast Cup tennis tournament tonight.

title: Berle Play Postponed
description: ''Goodnight, Grandpa,'' the new play by Walter Landau starring Milton Berle, has postponed its opening to March 2 at the Entermedia Theater. The schedule of preview performances also has been revised.

title: TO HELP DEVELOPING COUNTRIES SUSTAIN GROWTH
description: There is a widespread belief in this country that we should cut loose from the problem of third-world debts. ''Don't bail out the banks,'' say those who share this view, or ''let the poor nations work out their own salvation.'' This is an understandable emotional reaction in difficult times, but if it were to influence policy makers the debts would rise and worse problems would follow.

title: LIBYAN AFFAIR OVER, U.S. SAYS AWACS WILL NOW LEAVE EGYPT
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the Awacs planes deployed in Egypt to help thwart a potential Libyan threat to the Sudan would leave Tuesday or Wednesday if the situation is calm.

title: Mets' Allen Able to Throw Without Pain
description: The Mets assembled all their pitchers and catchers today for the first time in spring training. And the most vocal and perhaps the most important of the 19 pitchers in camp was Neil Allen.

title: BALLET: 'INTERPLAY' AT ROBBINS WORK
description: JEROME ROBBINS'S exhilarating ''Interplay'' is a ballet of many moods, among them youthful high spirits, dreaming love and even a touch of urban disaffection.

title: G.& W. SET TO DISCUSS BLUHDORN POST
description: The president of Gulf and Western Industries said yesterday that its board of directors would meet this week to discuss who will succeed Charles G. Bluhdorn as chairman of the board and chief executive officer, who died Saturday.

title: Sale by Midland Bank
description: Midland Bank P.L.C. has sold an office property in the City of London for about $46 million.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 'Happy Birthday, Dear George'

title: 3 SEIZED IN BRONX SHOOTOUT IN POLICE RUSE TO BUY ARMS
description: A man and woman were shot yesterday during a gun battle in a Bronx motel parking lot after members of a joint F.B.I.-police antiterrorist unit surrounded a van transporting stolen guns and other weapons, the authorities said.

title: FOR BALMY NIGHTS: RUFFLES OR GLITTER OR SIMPLE SHIFTS
description: Covered up or bare-shouldered. Knee-baring or floor length. Figurerevealing or supple and flowing. These are some of the possibilities in evening clothes for the warm weather ahead. The time when women felt obliged to call up a friend to see what she was wearing to the party has indeed vanished. So has the era when everyone turned out in a reasonable facsimile of the same look at night. If anything, uniforms are even less evident in evening clothes than they are in day wear.

title: NUDE DANCERS REPLACED AT PARIS OPERAS
description: The American stage director Richard Foreman announced today that the 12 nudes who waltzed in his Paris Opera production of Johann Strauss's ''Die Fledermaus'' would not be on stage again.

title: Ex-Yank in Comeback
description: Gil Patterson, a former Yankee pitcher who had a career-stopping injury in 1977, his first major league season, is trying for a comeback with the Atlanta Braves. The 27-year-old right-hander was 1-2 when he suffered a rotator cuff injury.

title: FRANK COLMAN
description: Frank Colman, an outfielder with the Pittsburgh Pirates and New York Yankees in the 1940's, died Saturday of cancer. He was 65 years old. He appeared in 271 games over a sixyear career and had a lifetime batting average of .228.

title: CLUBS WELCOME NEOPHYTES INTO A STRANGE WORLD
description: CENTRAL to many a childhood is the clubhouse. Its rudimentary walls may be no fancier than nailed-together scraps from equipment crates and pallets, reminiscent of a Norman Rockwell painting and complete with a ''No Girls Allowed'' plaque over the door. Later its structures might be replaced by the sorority or fraternity houses, or merely the invisible enclosure of a clique. But the prerequisite to membership in the club would remain the same: a shared secret.

title: FINGERPRINTING OF CHILDREN SPREADING
description: More than 550 children lined up in the cafeteria of the Eastside Elementary School in Midwest City, Okla., last week to have their fingertips covered with ink and rolled onto white cards.

title: Famine to Feast For High Jumper
description: Two months ago, Jerome Carter started his indoor track season without high-jumping shoes. Now that the obscure 19-year-old student at Harford Community College in Bel Air, Md., has jumped 7 feet 7 inches, every shoe manufacturer wants to outfit him.

title: FRANK NOTESTEIN, DEMOGRAPHER, 80
description: Dr. Frank W. Notestein, a former research demographer at Princeton University who helped establish and guide major efforts in family planning and population control, died of emphysema Saturday at St. Mary's Hospital in Langhorne, Pa. He was 80 years old, and lived in Newtown, Pa.

title: No Headline
description: MANY STATES FACING NEED FOR NEW TAXES TO BALANCE BUDGETS

title: REGULATORS CRITICAL OF A.T.& T. PLANS
description: The National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners, an organization representing state and Federal regulatory officials, has sharply criticized a proposal by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to set up a nationwide central staff to coordinate the activities of local phone companies after they are divested by A.T.& T. this year.

title: 6 ARAB STATES SET OIL PRICE MEETING
description: Oil ministers from six Persian Gulf exporting countries are to meet Tuesday in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, to discuss a common strategy on oil prices, Saudi Arabia announced today.

title: DO ENORMOUS MAGNETS AFFECT THE HUMAN BODY?
description: WITH the development of powerful magnets for physics research, industrial uses and even transportation, increasing numbers of people are being exposed to magnetic fields thousands of times stronger than those in which humans evolved.

title: Circuitry of Future: Carved by Ion Ray
description: A new manufacturing technology could bring small businesses back into the rapidly maturing semiconductor industry, its proponents say.

title: ...UPSTATE, IT MEANS NEVER SAY SURRENDER
description: Washington never shopped here. If he had, he would certainly have mentioned it in his memoirs as among his most memorable battles.

title: PIANO RECITAL: KIMMELMAN
description: THE attention to music's expressive power displayed by the pianist Seth Kimmelman at the 92d Street Y on Sunday night would have been more effective had his expressions derived from the music itself rather than been imposed upon it.

title: California Tremors Linked to Magma
description: Early results of ground tests indicate that the thousands of earthquakes that jostled eastern California last month may have been accompanied by the movement of molten rock deep within the earth, scientists said today.

title: China Presses Asian Bank
description: China is pressing for the disqualification of Taiwan and its own admission into the Asian Development Bank, the last international agency where the island state is still recognized, Masao Fujioka, president of the institution, told reporters.

title: SENSE OF SMELL PROVES TO BE SURPRISINGLY SUBTLE
description: HOW can a worker in a rendering plant enjoy his lunch despite the noxious odors? How can something smelled today evoke memories from years past? Do women really have a keener sense of smell than men do?

title: WALKER CASE WILL BE INVESTIGATED
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association will investigate to determine whether Herschel Walker signed a contract with the New Jersey Generals last week, or even went so far as to conduct negotiations with them through his lawyer. Either action would jeopardize Walker's final season of collegiate eligibilty as a football player.

title: Weighing In; The Fat Vote
description: Because he has a lean and hungry look and Americans may prefer a President with a bit of meat on him, Senator Alan Cranston is said to be stuffing his face. His soups are creamy, his desserts gooey, his pasta prodigious.

title: A.M.A. JOURNAL JUMPS THE BELL ON BOXING
description: To the Editor:

title: Aetna Group Insurance Up
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company said that group life insurance sold by the company in the United States and Canada in 1982 rose 23.9 percent, to $22.8 billion, from $18.4 billion in 1981. The amount of group life insurance in force at year-end was up 12 percent, to $180 billion, the company reported on Friday.

title: Mexico to Cut Price
description: Mexico said today that it would lower its oil price Friday. A statement from both the Ministry of Mining and Petroleos Mexicanos, the Government-owned oil company, said the cut would be retroactive to all sales during February.

title: Hockey on Tape
description: Roger Neilson and Jay Grossman met five years ago at Neilson's summer hockey school in Port Hope, Ontario. Now Neilson is the coach of the Vancouver Canucks, and he calls 17-year-old Jay Grossman of Roslyn, L.I., ''a key man'' in the Canucks' preparation for National Hockey League games.

title: BILL IS SUGGESTED TO REMAKE E.P.A. AS INDEPENDENT UNIT
description: A group of House and Senate members will revive a proposal to give the Environmental Protection Agency some independence from Presidential control, it was announced today.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Bank of New England Corp. has elected J. Nicholas Rees vice chairman.

title: AFTER 12 YEARS, VIOLETS BLOOM
description: S hortly after New York University's basketball team completed its 1970-71 season, Mike Muzio was quietly informed that he would succeed Lou Rossini as the Violets' coach. On a gray March day a few weeks later, he was driving along the Grand Central Parkway with Dan Gassman, then a senior at South Side High School in Rockville Centre, L.I. That afternoon Mike Muzio had shown Dan Gassman around the University Heights campus in the Bronx, and now the coach was driving him home. As they talked, the radio was on.

title: Storm Closes Highways In Texas Panhandle
description: By The Associated Press A storm that left more than a foot of snow in eastern New Mexico and Colorado closed highways in the Texas Panhandle yesterday while heavy rains caused flooding in eastern Texas.

title: SFE TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
PEOPLE EXPRESS AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax credit...C-There are no comparable yr-ago results because thecompany began airline service in Apr 1981

title: GUIDRY OPTIMISTIC ON YANK CHANGES
description: Ron Guidry arrived at the Yankee camp for the start of his spring training today, and offered an explanation for his tardiness.

title: Salnikov Lowers Mark in Freestyle
description: Vladimir Salnikov of the Soviet Union lowered his world record in the 1,500-meter freestyle today by almost two seconds, establishing a second world swimming mark in less than a week.

title: BROADWAY EQUATION
description: ''42d Street'' * 2 =''84 Charing Cross Road'', MARY ELLEN COVIELLO

title: ATI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
CITY OPERA WILL OPEN WITH 'TURANDOT' JULY 7
description: The New York City Opera's first combined summer-fall season will open on July 7 with Puccini's ''Turandot.'' The performance will be the initial installment of a six-opera Puccini festival, and will feature the world stage premiere of Franco Alfano's entire completion of the unfinished ''Turandot'' score.

title: Q&A
description: Q. At two of my local supermarkets I can buy silver tip roast, which is consistently reliable, tender and tasty. I can find no reference to this in meat books, of which I own several. Can you explain this cut?

title: Two Held For Murder In Marshals' Slayings
description: Four people arrested in the slayings of two United States marshals were ordered held for Federal court after a preliminary hearing today at which the Government dropped murder charges against two of them. They continued to be held on lesser charges.

title: Things Multiply
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Lincoln Bus Line To Close Friday
description: The Lincoln Transit Company, which carries 2,000 round-trip commuters a day along Route 9 between Atlantic City and New York, announced today that it would cease operations after Friday's runs.

title: VALMONT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; the 1981 figures were to exclude discontinued operations; the latest qr loss includes a loss of $6,264,000 from discontinued operations

title: NEW GASOLINE TAX: CAPITAL USES ONLY
