title: BODY FROM SALVADOR THOUGHT TO BE U.S. WRITER'S
description: The remains of a body flown to New York from El Salvador on Saturday are probably those of a freelance writer from New Jersey who disappeared in San Salvador more than two years ago, the medical examiner in Rockland County, N.Y., says.

title: BREAKING HABIT: ROAD TO SUCCESS IS ROCKY
description: AS soon as Holcomb decided to quit smoking, he began to crave a cigarette. To help him over the hump, he envisioned a television screen that showed the message, ''I do not smoke.'' This image enabled him to resist the craving ... for about 15 seconds.

title: THE GRUELING ROAD OF EVELYN ASHFORD
description: On a glaringly bright Sunday morning, three tiring joggers chugged slowly round the quarter-mile track at Santa Monica High School. Pat Connolly checked her watch. It was 10:20, and it was quite clear that the small lithe figure of Evelyn Ashford was not where it was supposed to be.

title: HEALTH INFORMATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.A.W. URGES FRASER TO KEEP CHRYSLER SEAT
description: The likelihood of Douglas A. Fraser, the president of the United Automobile Workers union, remaining on the board of directors of the Chrysler Corporation appeared to increase today.

title: FINDING THE RICH BREW CALLED IRISH TEA
description: IT was only the middle of August but already we were sleeping under quilts and had the electric fire going in the mornings. We were living in Ireland and each day was an object lesson in the relative extremes of the famous weather. When one or the other of us would set out for the local village on his bicycle, a chilly rain might be blowing in off the coast. So he'd bundle up in a heavy sweater, poncho and neck scarf, but often he'd get only as far as Mr. O'Connor's gate before summer made a sudden reappearance and the extra clothes would get put into the carrier.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Citicorp's 91-day auction paper rates fell to 8.437 percent at the weekly sale, from 8.667 percent last week, with bids ranging from 8.42 percent to 8.44 percent. A total of $1.1 billion in bids were submitted, of which $150 million were accepted.

title: MAGNETICS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
500 Deposit Boxes Looted in Queens
description: More than 500 safe-deposit boxes at an office of a savings and loan association in Queens were looted of an undetermined amount of money and valuables by thieves who struck over the holiday weekend, the police reported yesterday.

description: President Reagan said today that he was prepared to explore alternatives to his proposed ban on all American and Soviet medium-range missiles in Europe if the principle of equality between the United States and the Soviet Union was respected.

title: JAPAN, BY SHIELDING FARMERS, RANKLES ITS TRADING PARTNERS
description: To anyone familiar with agriculture on the American scale - the endless fields of wheat and corn in the Middle West or the vast fruit and vegetable tracts of California - Japanese farms are a bit of a shock. In fact, most look like small, welltended garden plots.

title: Setback for Carlton
description: That $1 million arbitration award to Fernando Valenzuela of the Los Angeles Dodgers has upset Steve Carlton's hopes of becoming the highest-paid pitcher in baseball. Under an oral agreement worked out last month with the Philadelphia Phillies on a renegotiation of his current contract, the four-time Cy Young Award winner would get $1.15 million, but not until 1984.

title: NOW, A SELECT COMMITTEE FOR FAMILIES
description: Representative George Miller introduced legislation several years ago dealing with the problem of battered women. Before long, recalled the California Democrat, he had become ''the butt of a lot of jokes'' in the Capitol cloakroom, but the experience taught him ''a very tough lesson.''

title: Team America Is Taking Shape
description: When he was living in Brooklyn in the late 1960's, Alkis Panagoulias came up with the sure way to strengthen soccer in the United States.

title: TV: 'CRIME IN AMERICA' AS SEEN BY ABC
description: CRIME has always occupied a large part of television news, mostly as a subject for local stations. Now, however, the network news programs on ABC are examining what may be our most abiding social concern in a series called ''Crime in America.''

title: 100,000 PAY TO WATCH 'PIRATES' ON TV
description: Hollywood's initial entry into pay-per-view television, last Saturday night's premiere of Universal Studios's ''The Pirates of Penzance,'' captured less than 10 percent of the potential audience of about 1.2 million subscribers.

title: Waste Recovery Bonds Issued in Massachusetts
description: A $161.7 million issue of North Andover, Mass., resource recovery bonds was tentatively priced for sale through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company with yields of 10 1/8 percent for bonds due in 2002 and 10.18 percent in 2006. The bonds will finance a plant for generating electricity from garbage.

description: The Government has informed oil companies operating in Nigeria that their allowed profit margin per barrel has been increased by 40 cents, to $2, oil industry sources said today.

description: THE erosion of network TV audiences notwithstanding, the successful promoters of other media generally play it smart and promote their own favorites as a supplement to television rather than a substitute for it.

title: Richard Trying Again
description: Two and a half years after suffering a stroke that seemed certain to end his pitching career, J.R. Richard is making a new effort at a comeback with the Houston Astros. ''I believe I'm going to pitch in the big leagues this year,'' he said.

title: TAPE CITES TEAMSTERS-MAFIA DEAL
description: A wiretap tape was played in Federal court today on which Allen M. Dorfman, a murdered Chicago insurance executive, was heard saying the Kansas City Mafia had obtained a commitment that Roy L. Williams would be made president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Steelmet Files For Chapter 11
description: Steelmet Inc., a Pittsburgh-based recycler of secondary metals, said it had filed a petition for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, primarily because it had been unable to to reach satisfactory agreements with its institutional lenders on a debt restructuring plan.

title: COMMISSIONER PREDICTS RISE IN PILGRIM INMATES
description: The State Commissioner of Correctional Services said today that he might have to increase the number of inmates at Pilgrim State Psychiatric Center on Long Island before he could close it, as Governor Cuomo has promised.

title: COURT TO DECIDE CASE ON SEX BIAS
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether students' receiving Federal scholarships and loans automatically makes the college they attend subject to the provisions of a key Federal law against sex discrimination.

title: Only Resch Finds Fault With Resch
description: Chico Resch didn't relax in goal, but the anticipation of imminent victory was building Monday night at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. After all, there were less than 20 seconds remaining in the game, and the Devils were leading the Buffalo Sabres by 4-3.

title: Reginald Denham Memorial
description: A memorial service for Reginald Denham, the actor, playwright and director, will be held Monday at 3 P.M. in the chantry of St. Thomas Church at 53d Street and Fifth Avenue. Mr. Denham, who was 89 years old, died Feb. 4 after a stroke.

title: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1983; Markets
description: Stock prices fell sharply as concern that oil price cuts might damage the world's economy spread among investors. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 12.42 points, to 1,080.40. (Page D1.) But in the credit markets, traders drew a different conclusion - that the price cuts bode well for a further decline in inflation -and short- and long-term interest rates declined. (D9.) Short interest on the Big Board fell 2.2 percent in the month ended Feb. 15. (D16.)

title: CONRAIL ADVANCE
description: The Consolidated Rail Corporation said yesterday that it earned $54.6 million, or $2.14 a share, in the fourth quarter, more than double its profit of $26.4 million, or $1.03 a share, in the 1981 period. Earnings for the latest quarter were after special gains of $63.5 million.

title: Coach Is Recovering
description: The nation's leading high school hockey coach was recovering at Rhode Island Hospital in Providence yesterday after suffering a severe head injury during practice on Monday. The coach, Bill Belisle of Mount St. Charles Academy in Woonsocket, struck his head on the ice after having been clipped by a player who fell and slid into his legs.

title: Bulls 144, Nuggets 133
description: David Greenwood, who had been averaging just 7.8 points per game, scored 23 points to lead Chicago.

title: HOUSE E.P.A. PACT BACKED BY O'NEILL
description: The chairmen of three House subcommittees today called for a formal Congressional investigation into whether Attorney General William French Smith improperly sought to block the prosecution of the head of the Environmental Protection Agency for contempt of Congress.

description: Israeli officials said today that President Reagan's offer to guarantee the security of Israel's northern border could not take the place of a direct agreement with Lebanon.

title: Keep Airlines Accountable
description: An obscure international agreement to set new limits on airline liability to crash victims seems finally headed for Senate debate. Negotiated seven years ago but still unratified, it would both improve and diminish protection for travelers - and clearly improve the protection for airlines. The pact's weakness outweighs its strength.

description: The Supreme Court ruled today that a driver's refusal to submit to a blood alcohol test for intoxication could be used later as evidence against him at a trial on drunken driving charges.

title: Dooley Welcomes N.C.A.A. Inquiry
description: Vince Dooley, Georgia's football coach and director of athletics, said yesterday that he welcomed a National Collegiate Athletic Association inquiry on whether Herschel Walker had signed a contract with the United States Football League or had even negotiated with the new league.

title: Uniroyal Plant
description: Union rubber workers who agreed in December to cut wages and increase production at Uniroyal Inc.'s tire plant are credited with helping to bring some 600 employees back to work. Uniroyal said the facility would return to full production next Monday, using workers who were laid off in October. A shutdown of the plant was averted when workers agreed in mid-December to a package of concessions that included a $1.25 reduction in hourly wages and an increase in output by workers.

title: EMF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mitchell Energy
description: The Mitchell Energy and Development Corporation, based in Houston, said it had signed a partnership agreement with an unidentified investor to acquire up to $100 million in oil and gas properties during the next 18 months. Under the agreement, announced in principle last month, Mitchell will hold a 35 percent interest in the partnership, and will also act as operator of the acquired properties.

title: DE LA RENTA OFFERS SILK FOR SUMMER PARTIES
description: EVERY year Oscar de la Renta comes up with a group of free-flowing silk dresses in bold colors and patterns that would not go unnoticed in a tropical rain forest. The patterns are hand-painted and involve arresting geometric or floral patterns or a combination of the two. The cuts are full and away from the body. While the designer suggests they can be worn over swimsuits, they are most popular with hostesses - and guests - at summer parties in the country.

title: Dr Pepper Posts Loss
description: The Dr Pepper Company, a soft-drink maker, today reported a $4 million loss for the fourth quarter of 1982 despite a 47 percent sales increase, to $123.7 million. The loss compared with a profit of $7.3 million, or 35 cents a share, in the period in 1981. ''The level of sales activity in the second half of the year, particularly the fourth quarter, simply could not support heavy marketing and operating expenses,'' the company's chairman, W.W. Clements, said.

Later, Con Ed restored the dividend and its shares eventually rose to record highs.

This compares with $22,368 for an engineer and $16,980 for accounting graduates.

title: When Europe's Larder Overflows
description: Thanks to good weather and modern technology, the specter of world food shortages has receded. Yet gains in agricultural productivity are not welcomed everywhere. The Times's series on food and international trade documents that food surpluses bitterly divide the developed nations. Cool heads will be needed to prevent agricultural issues from further poisoning the Western alliance.

description: Joseph G. Barkan, the president of the Board of Education, has been jesting with friends, saying he is hurt because his name seems to be the only one missing from the long list of those being mentioned as possible successors to Frank J. Macchiarola as schools chancellor.

title: Agreement Is Reached In British Water Strike
description: Management and union negotiators agreed today on a wage package that should end Britain's first nationwide water and sewer strike.

title: Paris Opera Penalized For Misuse of Language
description: The Paris Opera has been ordered to pay $190 in damages for selling a program in English for a musical production, an organization for the defense of the French language says.

title: EX-CINCINNATI MAYOR WAS 104
description: Murray Seasongood, political reformer, former Mayor, lawyer, teacher, philanthropist and author, who left an indelible mark on Cincinnati, died at his home Monday at the age of 104.

title: KAM-KOTIA MINES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-AFter special charges of $1,870,000 for the latest yr and $1,282,000 for the 1981 yr

title: Nu-Med Purchase
description: Nu-Med Systems of Encino, Calif., said it would buy five acutecare hospitals, with 657 beds, and seven medical office buildings from Humana Inc., for more than $90 million. It said it expected to complete the acquisition in early April. The properties are in southern California.

title: FROM CULINARY EXPERTS, ACID TESTS OF A COOK'S ABILITY
description: CHEFS, cooking teachers and cookbook authors were asked the following question: ''If you wanted to test someone to determine if he or she had the makings of a superior cook, is there any one dish you would ask the person to prepare?'' Lydie Pinoy Marshall, author and cooking teacher

title: Selective Gains For Eurobonds
description: Fixed-interest Eurobonds, denominated in dollars, showed selective rises of about 1/4 point in slow trading after bond markets in the United States opened higher today.

title: GRAHAM MANUFACTURING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BLACKBURN PRIZE IS AWARDED
description: Marsha Norman has been awarded the fifth annual Susan Smith Blackburn Prize for her two-character play ''Night, Mother.'' The $2,000 prize is given every year to a woman for ''a work of outstanding quality for the English-speaking theater.''

title: NETS TRIUMPH ON KING'S SHOT
description: Albert King scored 26 points tonight, including a 12-foot baseline jumper with 23 seconds remaining that lifted the New Jersey Nets to a 110-108 victory over the Indiana Pacers.

title: MODULINE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Kenyan Leader Frees 473 Held After Uprising
description: President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya today freed 473 former servicemen and students awaiting trial on charges of involvement in an attempted coup last August.

title: PSA Bid Set Back
description: A Federal appeals court temporarily blocked a deal that would have allowed Pacific Southwest Airlines to lease planes from the Braniff International Corporation and start a Texas division.

title: Europe Warns U.S. on Trade
description: European foreign ministers meeting here on trade issues warned the United States today that further cut-rate farm trade, like recent subsidized sales of flour to Egypt, could damage relations with Europe.

title: Platte River Bonds Yield 5% to 9.2%
description: A $398 million issue of re-funding revenue bonds of Colorado's Platte River Authority was tentatively priced with yields ranging from 5 percent for bonds due in 1988 to 9.2 percent in 1996. Among longer-term bonds, those due in 2003 were tentatively offered to yield 9 3/4 percent, while 9 7/8 percent bonds were offered at slight discounts to yield 9.92 percent for the 2013 maturity and 9.95 percent for the 2018 maturity.

title: Atari Moving Most Production
description: Atari Inc. said yesterday that it would shift the bulk of its manufacturing - the production of its home computers and video games - from plants in Sunnyvale and San Jose, Calif., to Hong Kong and Taiwan. The move, intended to reduce costs, would permanently idle about 1,700 workers.

title: 'MUSIC FROM JAPAN' AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: Igor Stravinsky is said to have remarked on a visit to Japan years ago: ''How come that you all imitate my music, when you have such a rich tradition of your own?''

title: Louisiana-Belco Link
description: The Louisiana Land and Exploration Company and the Belco Petroleum Corporation confirmed yesterday that the two were discussing the possible acquisition of Belco by Louisiana Land. No agreement on terms had been reached, they said, nor is there any assurance of an agreement. Reports of the $700 million merger talks circulated on Wall Street last Friday.

title: FORWARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STUDIES LED TO IMMUNOLOGY
description: Dr. William C. Boyd, an expert in many fields whose early work in blood sciences led to modern immunology, died Saturday of complications from cancer at his home in Falmouth, Mass. He was 79 years old.

title: HOUSE UNIT BACKS BILL FOR NEW CONSERVATION CORPS
description: A House committee approved legislation today to create an employment program similar to the Civilian Conservation Corps, which provided jobs to three million Americans in the Depression.

title: James A. Christy, 53, Leader Of Transit Police Patrol Unit
description: James A. Christy, deputy chief inspector of the Transit Authority police, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in St. Albans, Queens. He was 53 years old.

title: Ranger's Buildup
description: Jerry Maloney, one of the Rangers' trainers, sometimes goes to unusual lengths to help his players. Maloney spent the better part of three hours Monday morning rebuilding one of Cam Connor's skates to put a lift in it.

Down, Not Out
description: Luckily, Randall (Tex) Cobb landed on his head. The heavyweight challenger, who absorbed a 15-round pounding from Larry Holmes last November without losing either his balance or his sense of humor, was driving in New Zealand on vacation last month.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1983
description: International

title: PRETORIA'S PROPOSALS MUST BE REJECTED
description: The following is adapted from a speech given last month in Johannesburg. The constitutional proposals cited are a package of reforms put forward by Prime Minister P.W. Botha that would replace the all-white, Westminster-style Parliament with a three-chambered legislature - one house each for whites, Indians, and people of mixed race, known as coloreds. Together, the three chambers would choose an executive president who would have much broader powers than the present Prime Minister. Allan Boesak, who is colored, is a minister in the Dutch Reformed Church

description: Pravda, the Communist Party newspaper, yesterday used what it said was a letter from a man in West Hartford, Conn., in an attempt to revive indirectly the idea of a summit meeting between Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, and President Reagan.

title: Stall Fails to Get Results
description: The Albuquerque High School girls' basketball team, shorter than its opponents, decided that the best strategy for beating Farmington Monday night was to pass as much as possible and to take a shot only at the end of each quarter.

title: DEATH TOLL IN ASSAM PUT AT 1,127 AS COUNTING OF VOTES CONTINUES
description: The Government informed Parliament today that the official death toll in three weeks of violence in India's northeastern state of Assam had reached 1,127 and that the figure was expected to rise as more casualties were tabulated.

title: G & K SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
VICTORY CLAIMED FOR WASHINGTON IN CHICAGO VOTE
description: Supporters of Representative Harold Washington, the 60-year-old son of a precinct captain in this city's famed Democratic political machine, claimed a razor-thin victory early this morning in the hotly contested three-way race for his party's mayoral nomination.

title: LANDMARK BAKESHOP IN SARATOGA SPRINGS
description: OUT-OF-TOWNERS who think Saratoga Springs is famous for its race track, ballet, sparkling water and symphony are aware of only fourfifths of the story. There is a landmark here known as Mrs. London's Bakeshop and Restaurant, a magnificently perfumed place where the aromas of vanilla and chocolate, almond paste and caramel, and jams and jellies intermingle.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Sports People column on Saturday incorrectly described the punishment imposed by the National Hockey League on two players for an off-the-ice fistfight. Each was suspended for four games.

description: F.D.R.: AN INTIMATE HISTORY. By Nathan Miller. 563 pages. Illustrated. Doubleday. $22.50.

HIGH COURT TO REVIEW OIL TAX
description: The Supreme Court, accepting an urgent appeal from the Justice Department, agreed today to decide whether the ''windfall profit'' tax on decontrolled crude oil is constitutional.

title: Libyans Accusing U.S.  Of Provocative Actions
description: The United States and Libya traded charges today at a Security Council meeting called by Libya to protest what it called ''provocative military actions'' off its coast.

title: Litton Gets Itek Shares
description: Litton Industries said today that 4.06 million shares of the Itek Corporation and $18.62 million principal amount of Itek's 8 percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2005 had been tendered.

SPACE SHUTTLE FLIGHT IS EXPECTED IN MARCH AFTER 2-MONTH DELAY
description: A second replacement engine has passed testing and the space shuttle Challenger should be ready for launching on its maiden flight March 19 or 20, the shuttle director, Lieut. Gen. James Abrahamson, said today.

title: Fears of Oil Price War Force the Pound Down
description: Fears of an oil price war drove the pound down today in heavy trading, leaving the British pound at its lowest value against the currencies of Britain's major trading partners since June 1978.

title: U.S. OFFERS TO BUY ALL HOMES IN TOWN TAINTED BY DIOXIN
description: The Federal Government offered today to buy out all homeowners and businesses in the Meramec River town of Times Beach, which has been afflicted by both flooding and contamination by dioxin.

title: TEXACO DISMISSES 5 AFTER ITS NEWARK BLAST INQUIRY
description: Texaco officials have dismissed five employees and suspended a sixth in connection with the Jan. 7 explosion and fire that burned for four days at the company's gasoline storage terminal here. One man was killed and 24 other people were injured.

title: ZENITH RADIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: From this vantage point, at least, it looks as if the trade press catering to the new technology is booming as much as the industries themselves. There is a constant flow of new publications.

title: Fire In the What?
description: This is the class in remedial cliches for advanced political journalists, and since the Presidential election is only a year and eight months away, let us proceed rapidly. What is the most important question facing the Republican Party today? Anyone.

title: TUCHOLSKY'S MEASURE
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT MAKES A GREAT COOK GREAT?
description: JUST as certain people have physical and temperamental characteristics that make them good marathon runners, or pianists, or bar bouncers, others have what it takes to become superior cooks. These individuals are often described as possessing a ''flair,'' a ''sixth sense,'' a ''magic touch'' -something special that elevates any food they prepare, whether poached eggs or poitrine de veau, into a sublime experience.

title: GEORGE B. NEWMAN
description: George B. Newman, a former president and chief executive officer of the Kelly-Springfield Tire Company, died Saturday at his home in Boca Raton, Fla. Mr. Newman, who was 76 years old, had been in poor health for several months.

title: HEARING ON BULLS OPENS
description: A Federal judge was told today that Marvin Fishman, a Milwaukee businessman, should be awarded control of the Chicago Bulls and $12.8 million in damages because his effort to buy the team was illegally blocked a decade ago.

title: FIDELITY MEDICAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHICAGO WARD'S GARBAGE CANS HOLD KEY TO POWER
description: ''If we didn't work our precincts, then the people would vote the way they actually feel,'' said Wayne Derengowski, dispenser of garbage cans, arranger of block parties, adviser on real estate tax protests, adjuster of parking tickets, and, above all, precinct captain for the Second Precinct of the 33d Ward.

description: Three Cosmos, including Ricky Davis and Jeff Durgan, will be among the 20 players named today to the first Team America squad of the North American Soccer League. Alkis Panagoulias, the coach of the team that is designed to be the nucleus of the United States 1986 World Cup squad, would like a couple of more players from the league champions.

title: 1. Musical Themes
description: When fashion favors black and white, trust Bloomingdale's to be right up to the moment with a department selling all black and white accessories. It's called Le Jazz Hot, and everything, handbags, belts, necklaces and earrings, is based on a musical theme -piano keyboards, notes, scores and the like. A leather keyboard belt is stiff enough and wide enough to pull in the waist for that 50's look some designers are trying to revive. By Marchant, it sells for $75. Le Jazz Hot is in the Arcade of the Lexington Avenue store.

title: Drolet Suspension Upheld by Court
description: The one-year suspension of Claude Drolet's harness-racing license has been upheld by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: SETON HALL DEFEATS PITT, 74-68
description: Seton Hall snapped a 17-game losing streak in the Big East Conference with a 74-68 victory tonight over Pittsburgh.

title: MILWAUKEE WESTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Reagan to End Boycott Of Nuclear Agency
description: President Reagan has decided to lift a United States boycott of the International Atomic Energy Agency imposed six months ago after it rejected Israel's credentials, the State Department announced today.

description: POETRY

description: Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink said today that he had abandoned discussions on raising any of the state's major taxes to provide more money in the state budget.

description: A review of the film ''The State of Things'' in Weekend on Friday incorrectly identified an actor who delivers a monologue about life in California. He is Geoffrey Carey.

title: 'The Joy of Football'
description: Dan Lloyd, the former Giants linebacker whose National Football League career ended after a bout with cancer, has signed a contract with the New Jersey Generals. Lloyd said he will be making less with the United States Football League team than he did when he played with the Giants.

title: HOSPITAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split paid Jan 17, 1983

title: LEON PODOLSKY
description: Leon Podolsky, an electrical engineer, inventor and the chief American delegate to the International Electrotechnical Commission for 30 years, died of meningitis Saturday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston.

title: Psychology Today Sale To Group Completed
description: The acquisition of Psychology Today magazine by the American Psychological Association was completed over the long weekend and, according to Don Kent, spokesman for the association, it fulfills a longtime dream of the association to have a consumer publication. There are no plans to change the magazine or its staff, he added.

title: MOLECULAR GENETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JETS GAIN TIE WITH ISLANDERS
description: Brian Hayward, the Winnipeg goalie, was a menacing factor, but perhaps not the biggest one. The Islanders' main foes tonight, in a 2-2 tie with the Jets, might have been themselves.

title: NEW ROCHELLE'S CAMPAIGN AGAINST DOWNTOWN BLIGHT
description: Sitting in his City Hall office amid a clutter of charts and documents, John L. Heller, New Rochelle's Commissioner of Development, recently discussed with a visitor some of the government-sponsored and private efforts that have given a modern look to his city's 10-block central business district in the last five years.

title: WINE TALK
description: IF you were to believe everything you read, you'd be convinced that anyone with the slightest interest in wine had a cellar full of first-growth Bordeaux and rare California chardonnay and drank Beaujolais only in the presence of his or her mother-in-law.

title: LATIN REFORM ESSENTIAL, REAGAN AIDE ASSERTS
description: The White House national security adviser, William P. Clark, said today that political as well as economic reforms were ''essential'' in Central America in order to avert a Marxist takeover of the region.

title: MARKETS ROILED BY OIL NEWS
description: As the price news from the oil world flowed through the financial markets yesterday, stocks sagged in accelerated trading with energy and bank issues the main casualties. To the credit markets, the oil trend suggested lower inflation and prices scored impressive gains.

title: CONNECTICUT NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SECRECY VS. SECURITY
description: Never, except in wartime, has America experienced such a rapid, extensive buildup of Government secrecy as in the last few years. The increase has come about through changes so disparate, often inconspicuous and at times so sudden as to elude adequate public debate. Together, these changes signal a sharp reversal of the last two decades' movement toward greater public access to Government information. It is time to assess their cumulative impact and to decide whether they truly serve the nation's best interests.

title: DONALDSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Comings and Goings
description: Ron Duguay of the Rangers will miss tonight's game against Hartford at Madison Square Garden. He aggravated a groin muscle pull. ... Tony (Red) Bruin, Syracuse's second-leading scorer, sprained his ankle and will probably miss tonight's game against St. John's.

title: IN THE EVENT OF PRESIDENTIAL VACUUM
description: Something there is in Washington that does not love a power vacuum. A vacuum interrupts the natural flow of things, leaving a hole occupied mainly by anxiety, ambitious politicians, wily bureaucrats and more than the usual amount of chaos. People do not quite know where they stand. Some run for cover; others start running for President.

title: G.N.P. GETS MORE VIGOR IN REVISION
description: The United States economy was not as weak in late 1982 as first thought, the Government reported today. The Commerce Department's revision of the gross national product for the fourth quarter showed a decline at an annual rate of 1.9 percent, rather than the 2.5 percent originally reported.

title: AUSTRALIAN VOTE: LABOR IS BUOYANT
description: Australians will vote March 5 in national elections called by Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser nine months ahead of schedule. They will choose between the Liberal-National Party coalition led by Mr. Fraser, which has governed this country for all but three of the last 34 years, and the Labor Party, headed by its newly elected leader, Robert Hawke.

title: DOCTORS PROMOTE OFFICE SURGERY
description: Many surgical patients can reduce their bills by 60 percent if they avoid hospitals, according to a society of 200 doctors that promotes surgery in doctors' offices.

title: JERSEY COURT WEIGHS WHEN TO CLOSE PRETRIAL HEARINGS
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court will hear arguments today on when pretrial court proceedings should be closed to the public to minimize news coverage that might hurt a murder defendant's chances for a fair trial.

title: A POWERFUL MINISLICER
description: ONE of the luxuries of restaurant kitchens that I have done without since my last job in one is a commercial meat slicer. These large, powerful machines can reduce a long roll of salami or an entire side of beef to sheer slices in seconds, a task that never can be done as quickly or precisely by hand.

title: CABLE-TV CHANNEL, SUBSIDIARY OF RCA, TO CLOSE WITH LOSS
description: The Entertainment Channel, a 24-hour pay-cable network that has sought to offer quality entertainment, will end its service on March 31 after nine months in operation.

description: Seventeen American and Japanese companies will form a group to make a new three-inch micro floppy disk and drive to compete with a Sony-led group making a 3.5-inch floppy disk and drive, Hitachi Ltd. said today.

title: Ohio Senate Passes $300 Million Tax Bill
description: A bill that would nearly double the state income tax squeezed through the Ohio Senate today after a State Senator who had been with his hospitalized wife in Florida flew back to cast the deciding vote.

title: CARTWRIGHT SHOT BEATS MAVERICKS
description: Bill Cartwright's slam dunk on a rebound of Paul Westphal's driving shot with six seconds to play last night gave the Knicks a 108-106 victory over the Dallas Mavericks at Madison Square Garden.

title: Percy Will Seek a Vote On Adelman Nomination
description: Senator Charles H. Percy said today that he will seek a committee vote Thursday on the nomination of Kenneth L. Adelman to be director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency.

title: Economic Scene; Oil Price Cut: Coping Is Key
description: CUTS in the price of crude oil by Britain, Norway and Nigeria have put extreme pressure on the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and have threatened to collapse the aspiring cartel's shaky price structure.

title: MONOPOLY LOSES ITS TRADEMARK
description: It wasn't a big antitrust case, but the Supreme Court yesterday left standing a lower court decision ending Parker Brothers' monopoly on Monopoly.

title: MERGER APPROVED BY PRESBYTERIANS
description: Regional units of the nation's two major Presbyterian churches, divided into Northern and Southern denominations since the Civil War, have ratified a plan to reunite and form one church.

title: STAGE: 'MOOSE MURDERS,' A BRAND OF WHODUNIT
description: FROM now on, there will always be two groups of theatergoers in this world: those who have seen ''Moose Murders,'' and those who have not. Those of us who have witnessed the play that opened at the Eugene O'Neill Theater last night will undoubtedly hold periodic reunions, in the noble tradition of survivors of the Titanic. Tears and booze will flow in equal measure, and there will be a prize awarded to the bearer of the most outstanding antlers. As for those theatergoers who miss ''Moose Murders'' - well, they just don't rate. A visit to ''Moose Murders'' is what will separate the connoisseurs of Broadway disaster from mere dilettantes for many moons to come.

title: FLORIO SAYS E.P.A. SANCTIONED CONTRACT FOR ACCUSED POLLUTER
description: The Environmental Protection Agency sanctioned the awarding of a $7.7 million contract for toxic waste cleanup to a company that a month earlier was accused by E.P.A. investigators of trying to cover up its own pollution problems, according to a Congressman whose House subcommittee is investigating the environmental agency.

title: CORRECTION
description: The television listings yesterday incorrectly identified Katharine Graham. She is chairman of The Washington Post Company.

title: Photos of French Notables
description: A selection of 40 black-and-white photographs of notable figures in French culture by Rogi Andre, usually on view at the Centre Georges-Pompidou in Paris, can be seen through March 25 at the French Institute-Alliance Francaise, 22 East 60th Street. Information: 355-6100.

title: BOBBY SHORT BACKS CENTRAL PARK STATUE TO HONOR ELLINGTON
description: Bobby Short, the nightclub singer and pianist, has commissioned a statue of Duke Ellington that he wants to have placed at the edge of Central Park at Duke Ellington Boulevard, formerly West 106th Street, and Central Park West. The statue has been commissioned from the sculptor Robert Graham, who lives in Venice, Calif.

description: A sister and brother were arrested yesterday in connection with the theft of jewelry from Cartier over the last few months, the police said.

description: ''I hope that this money will help the many needy and underprivileged people that exist in our area. In this time of economic hardship, I feel very fortunate to be making money while others are without employment.''
