title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 23, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Non-Use of Force - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: BRENTANO'S ON FIFTH IS JUST A GHOST NOW
description: IT'S hard to imagine New York - America -without Brentano's. When the well-known book chain filed for bankruptcy in May 1982 there were 28 branches. Not long ago only nine were left, with at least four scheduled for imminent closing. Last Saturday the flagship store on Fifth Avenue shut its doors

title: Snug Harbor Exhibition
description: Photographs, drawings, hurricane flags and an eight-foot woodcarved reproduction lighthouse are included in an exhibition called ''The Lighthouse,'' on view through March 6 at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center, 914 Richmond Terrace, in the New Brighton section of Staten Island.

title: Bridge: Polish Players Stand Out In Their New York Debut
description: Bidding to an unbeatable slam contract in the face of a gameforcing opening by an opponent is something that does not happen to the average player in a bridge lifetime. It happened to East-West on the diagramed deal from the New York Swiss Team Championship last Sunday, and, although they were not allowed to play the slam, the end result was entirely satisfactory.

title: Engravers Agree To Times Proposal
description: The Photoengravers Union agreed yesterday to accept a three-year contract extension for its 30 members employed at The New York Times.

title: VIOLINIST: AWARD RECITAL
description: AT the age of 22, Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg has a fully formed artistic personality. That is no mean feat, since products of our music education system and winners of our high-pressure competitions are often said to be soulless virtuosos, mechanical wonders who lack the heart possessed by their rougher forebears.

title: Connecticut Head Of G.O.P. Elected
description: Connecticut Republicans today elected Thomas J. D'Amore Jr. as their state chairman in a shift that marked the emergence of United States Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. as the leading figure of the party organization with which he has often feuded.

title: A MESSAGE FOR THE 'POOR ME GENERATION'
description: To the Editor:

title: Sullivan Award
description: Winners of the James E. Sullivan Memorial Award, presented by the U.S. Amateur Athletic Union each year to the nation's top amateur athlete: 1930 - Bobby Jones, golf. 1931 - Bernard Berlinger, allaround athlete. 1932 - James Bausch, all-around athlete. 1933 - Glenn Cunningham, track. 1934 - Bill Bonthron, track. 1935 - Lawson Little Jr., golf. 1936 - Glenn Morris, all-around athlete. 1937 - Don Budge, tennis. 1938 - Don Lash, track. 1939 - Joseph Burk, rowing. 1940 - Greg Rice, track. 1941 - Leslie MacMitchell, track. 1942 - Cornelius Warmerdam, pole vault. 1943 - Gilbert Dodds, track. 1944 - Ann Curtis, swimming. 1945 - Felix ''Doc'' Blanchard, football. 1946 - Arnold Tucker, football. 1947 - John Kelly Jr., rowing. 1948 - Bob Mathias, all-around athlete. 1949 - Dick Button, figure skating. 1950 - Fred Wilt, track. 1951 - Bob Richards, pole vault. 1952 - Horace Ashenfelter, track. 1953 - Sammy Lee, diving. 1954 - Mal Whitfield, track. 1955 - Harrison Dillard, track. 1956 - Patricia McCormick, diving. 1957 - Bobby Morrow, track. 1958 - Glenn Davis, track. 1959 - Parry O'Brien, shot-put. 1960 - Rafer Johnson, all-around athlete. 1961 - Wilma Rudolph, track. 1962 - Jim Beatty, track. 1963 - John Pennel, pole vault. 1964 - Don Schollander, swimming. 1965 - Bill Bradley, basketball. 1966 - Jim Ryun, track. 1967 - Randy Matson, shot-put. 1968 - Deborah Meyer, swimming. 1969 - Bill Toomey, decathlon. 1970 - John Kinsella, swimming. 1971 - Mark Spitz, swimming. 1972 - Frank Shorter, track. 1973 - Bill Walton, basketball. 1974 - Rick Wohlhuter, track. 1975 - Tim Shaw, swimming. 1976 - Bruce Jenner, decathlon. 1977 - John Naber, swimming. 1978 - Tracy Caulkins, swimming. 1979 - Kurt Thomas, gymnastics. 1980 - Eric Heiden, speedskating. 1981 - Carl Lewis, track and field. 1982 - Mary Decker Tabb, track.

title: MASLAND, C H, & SONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss after loss from discontinued operations of $326,000...C-Net income after loss from discontinued operations of $2,028,000; the 1981 income from continuing operations includes a pretax gain of $1,105,000 on sale of property

title: RATES LOWER ON OIL PRICE CUTS
description: Short- and long-term interest rates fell yesterday as traders concluded that the recent cuts in oil prices bode well for a further decline in inflation.

title: P.L.O. STRENGTHENS REBUFF TO REAGAN
description: The Palestine National Council formally endorsed a new strategic platform today after last-minute pressures from radical factions forced Yasir Arafat marginally to toughen the refusal to accept President Reagan's Middle East peace plan.

title: HEALTH CARE & RETIREMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Macy Rises By 28.4%; Stock Split
description: R.H. Macy & Company yesterday reported a 28.4 percent increase in net income in its fiscal second quarter, ended Jan. 29, on sales that were 15.7 percent higher than the same period a year earlier. The company also said its board yesterday approved a 3-for-2 stock split and a 5-cent-a-share quarterly dividend increase.

title: Pros and Cons In U.S. Views
description: A decline in oil prices would stimulate world economic growth but might put new strains on some heavily indebted developing countries, Treasury Under Secretary Beryl Sprinkel said today.

title: Flames 4, Oilers 1
description: Lanny McDonald scored two goals to break a Calgary scoring record in a game that was delayed 24 minutes by a bench-clearing brawl.

title: SWAN CONTENT TO BE UNNOTICED
description: In a camp of bright rookies and oldtime stars like Tom Seaver, the forgotten man of the Mets this spring seems to be Craig Swan, the best pitcher on the team last season.

title: DEPENDABLE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COTTON STATES LIFE & HEALTH INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
Tentative Pact Reached In Philadelphia Schools
description: Striking blue-collar school employees reached a tentative agreement today to end their 21-day strike, and union leaders said members would go back to work Thursday if they voted to accept the pact.

title: THE EFFECTS OF ROCK ON MUSICAL CULTURE
description: AT a recent international symposium sponsored by France's Ministry of Culture, some intellectuals worried about the pernicious cultural effects of the television program ''Dallas.'' Another, more pervasive, longer-lived American product - rock-and-roll -might provide a better case study. At recent concerts by Menudo and King Sunny Ade, New Yorkers have had the chance to see the effects of imported rock on other musical cultures. The results are conclusively inconclusive.

title: Tear Gas Used on Pakistanis
description: The police fired tear gas at several hundred demonstrators today after Sunni Moslems tried to attack a Shiite Moslem place of worship that was guarded by armed policemen, witnesses reported. The incident occurred during a brief relaxation of a curfew imposed on West Karachi to end violence that broke out Sunday in a dispute between Sunnis and Shiites over ownership of a mosque.

title: HORTICULTURAL GROUP ABLOOM IN SERVICES
description: In front of the Horticultural Society of New York people stare, poke fingers and tap on the glass. Passers-by at 128 West 58th Street now stop to look more closely at what appears to be a greenhouse filled with amaryllis, azaleas, asparagus ferns, hyacinths, primroses and paper-white narcissuses.

title: For Congress in Queens
description: It is too bad that the most obviously qualified Queens legislators, State Senator Emanuel Gold and Assemblyman Alan Hevesi, declined the Democratic Party's invitation to run for the House seat vacated by the death of Benjamin Rosenthal. Queens voters are thus left with a difficult choice among three other Democrats.

title: Dr. Melvin Herman, Columbia Researcher
description: Dr. Melvin Herman, founder and director of Columbia University's Community Services program, died of a heart attack Tuesday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. Dr. Herman, a resident of Scarsdale, N.Y., was 61 years old.

title: 6 OPEC NATIONS AGREE TO REDUCE THEIR OIL PRICES
description: Saudi Arabia said today that it and five other members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries had agreed to a reduction in the price of Saudi Light crude, which determines the price that other OPEC members charge for their oil.

title: THE MODERN ENSHRINEMENT OF ANCIENT FOLK MUSIC
description: AWANDERER through the less traveled thickets of the New York musical scene can hear some of the same sounds today that Bela Bartok must have heard a half century ago as he hiked through Hungary with his Edison phonograph and wax cylinders. Anxious to preserve a fading folk culture, the composer pleaded with peasants to sing the ''very old songs nobody remembers.''

title: COMMUNIST SUPPORTS MITTERRAND ON MISSILES
description: Georges Marchais, the French Communist leader, said today that he supported the position of President Francois Mitterrand's Government on the question of missiles in Europe - a position that is close to that of the United States.

title: Columbus Firefighters And Police Protest Pay
description: Most of the police officers and firefighters scheduled to report to work this morning called in sick to protest their failure to win pay increases. Overnight workers were ordered to stay on the job and officials said the city's 600,000 residents would be protected.

title: Cruise Missile Succeeds
description: The Air Force announced today the seventh successful test flight of its cruise missile, which with the Pershing 2 ballistic missile is to be deployed in Western Europe beginning in December.

title: DISMISSED OFFICIAL FAULTS E.P.A. CHIEF
description: Rita M. Lavelle, who was dismissed by President Reagan as assistant administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, charged today that she had been made a scapegoat and that her former chief, Anne McGill Burford, had provided ''no leadership at the top'' of the agency.

title: HANOI PLANS CUTS IN CAMBODIA FORCE
description: Vietnam said today that it planned to withdraw some of its troops from Cambodia this year and would consider yearly withdrawals after that.

title: PROTECTED PORPOISES
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place; Better Times For Aramco
description: OIL prices are sliding worldwide and nobody knows where they will level off. But industry analysts believe that the four Aramco partners - Exxon, Mobil, Texaco and Standard Oil of California - will fare relatively better than the major domestic integrated companies when crude prices drop. These integrated companies, which both produce crude oil and refine and sell oil products, include Getty Oil, Amerada Hess, Shell Oil, Philips Petroleum and Union Oil of California, among others.

title: GOODRICH HAS LOSS IN FOURTH QUARTER
description: The B.F. Goodrich Company yesterday reported a $33.7 million loss for the fourth quarter, contrasted to earnings of $32.4 million, or $1.69 a share, in the corresponding quarter of 1981. The company cited poor economic conditions and an extraordinary charge.

title: WHEN THE PLANTS TAKE OVER A HOME
description: ''SOME call it an addiction -even an obsession, but I know I can't live without them,'' said Lavia Berland of the nearly 600 plants that fill every window and spare space of her Upper East Side apartment.

title: South Africa and Angola Open Talks on Namibia
description: South Africa and Angola began talks in the Cape Verde Islands today on South-West Africa.

title: BLACK LANDMARKS IN NEWARK EXHIBIT
description: THE Newark Museum has observed Black History Month with lectures and exhibitions that include the traveling An Appraisal Smithsonian Institution show ''Black American Landmarks: Interpreters of History.'' The photographic panels, on view through Sunday, depict 22 sites that have been designated National Historic Landmarks by the Historic American Buildings Survey.

title: OF ISRAEL, LEBANON AND MAYOR KOCH
description: To the Editor:

title: UNDERSTANDING, SADNESS PERVADE CAMPUS MOOD
description: The news of Herschel Walker's plans to turn professional evoked feelings of disappointment, betrayal and sadness in this university town today.

title: Technology; Piracy in Era Of Computers
description: AFTER a number of false starts against the black market in computer software and hardware, efforts are under way to protect future computer products by making each one as distinctive as the person who uses it and thus harder to copy.

title: Plans Set to Move Sexual Rights Bill
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy said yesterday that she would move to have a homosexual rights bill discharged from the Council's General Welfare Committee as soon as Mayor Koch returned from a trip to Israel. He starts on the trip today.

title: MARRIED COUPLES SQUEEZE INTO PARENTS' HOMES
description: After several years on his own, Louis Florio, a 26-year-old supermarket produce man, is back home, living in his childhood bedroom in Selden, L.I. - with his wife, Maria, and their infant daughter, Tresa.

title: U.N. Council Takes No Action As Debate for Libyans Closes
description: The Security Council ended its debate tonight without taking any action on Libya's complaint against what it called ''provocative military actions'' by the United States off the Libyan coast.

title: LEGENDARY CAMPAIGN: PEPPER VS. SMATHERS IN '50
description: This is an inquiry into a political legend. The legend began 32 years ago in Florida's Democratic senatorial primary, and it reaches forward in time to the comfortable offices where today two aging men enjoy the rewards that often come with a long public life in this city. That is to say, one is rich in influence, the other in money.

title: 2 HIGH OFFICIALS OF E.P.A. RESIGN, REPORTEDLY AT WHITE HOUSE URGING
description: The inspector general and chief administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency submitted their resignations today. The actions were taken at the request of the White House, according to a senior Reagan Administration official.

title: PHYSICIAN MISCONDUCT SAID TO BE 'RIFE'
description: The State Health Commissioner said yesterday that there was an ''overwhelming'' problem of misconduct by physicians in New York. He called on hospitals and medical societies to fulfill their obligation under the law and report violations.

title: Columbia Gas Appeals Decision
description: A unit of the Columbia Gas System asked the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to reverse a decision that it make refunds of some of the charges it passed on to customers from the high cost it paid affiliated suppliers. The unit, the Columbia Gas Transmission Corporation, is based in Charleston, W.Va.

title: LOUIS BERNSTEIN
description: Louis Bernstein, a teacher and principal in the New York City school system for more than 50 years until his retirement in 1964, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Hollywood, Fla. He was 89 years old.

title: Poison Pens and a Sensible Tax
description: There's no precedent for the deluge of Congressional mail that the banks have stirred up against the new tax withholding from interest and dividends. There's also no sound reason for it; it should all be forwarded to the dead letter office.

title: China Confirms Ye Jianying Will Quit
description: Ye Jianying, China's 85-year-old nominal head of state, will announce his retirement Friday for reasons of age and poor health, a Foreign Ministry spokesman confirmed today.

title: Wenzel Captures Slalom in Sweden
description: Andreas Wenzel of Liechtenstein skied to his first World Cup victory in more than two years by winning a slalom here today.

title: CENTURY CLUB REVISITED
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Because of Barbara Lazear Ascher's article, I'm finally enlightened. She has placed metaphorical peepholes into the walls of those arcane manly gathering places. Never mind whether tree house or smoke-filled clubroom, my naive assumption of high-level talks behind forbidden doors (an assumption doubtlessly rooted in my effete female mentality) has been brightly dispelled. I can now thumb my nose at their ''off limits'' sign and say, ''Who cares?'' FLORENCE GERTNER, Brooklyn

title: WITHHOLDING TAX ON BANKS: BID FOR REPEAL
description: The banking industry's drive to repeal a key element in last year's tax bill that subjects interest and dividends to 10 percent withholding has produced one of the hottest and, some say, nastiest debates in recent years.

title: SCREEN: 'CAMERA BUFF'
description: ''Camera Buff'' was shown as part of the 1980 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from a review by Vincent Canby in The New York Times of Oct. 3, 1980. The film opened yesterday at the Film Forum, 57 Watts Street.

title: A LAWYERS' RULE WORTH TRYING
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts from remarks, page A10.
description: President Reagan, advocating an Arab-Israeli resolution of the Palestinian issue as ''the greatest security for Israel,'' said today that this would require ''providing something in the nature of a homeland'' for the Palestinians.

title: Eisenreich Is Back
description: Jim Eisenreich, the Minnesota Twins slugger who missed much of his rookie season last year because of a flareup of a mysterious nervous condition, is in training camp determined to succeed. But the 23-year-old outfielder, who was batting over .300 last June, still doesn't know what hit him or whether it will strike him again.

title: Hamburg Savings
description: The Hamburg Savings Bank of Brooklyn said it had acquired the College Point Savings Bank, a thrift institution in Bayside, Queens, that has four branches and $207 million in assets. The terms were not disclosed. The acquisition leaves Hamburg with 13 branches and more than $900 million in assets.

title: News of Walker Buoys His Future Teammates
description: Players at the New Jersey Generals training camp were excited today after learning that Herschel Walker was going to join them.

title: COURT RULES CITY WAS NOT LIABLE IN '70 EXPLOSION
description: The state's highest court ruled yesterday that New York City was not liable for a 1970 explosion that killed 12 people, even though a city building inspector had approved a defective gas line that caused the blast.

title: News Analysis
description: The Federal offer to buy all of the homes and businesses in Times Beach, Mo., was a solution to the dioxincontaminated town's problems that appeared to have largely satisfied all interests. But it avoids the bigger question of what is to be done about all the other places in this state that are contaminated with dioxin, some of which show higher levels and are geologically more difficult to deal with.

title: Ahmanson Up In 4th Quarter
description: H.F. Ahmanson & Company, parent company of Home Savings of America, the nation's largest savings and loan, reported fourth-quarter earnings of $16.6 million and a fullyear loss of $44.1 million.

title: Archbishop of Detroit Demands Nun Resign
description: The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Detroit today demanded the resignation of a nun who directs Michigan's welfare programs and refuses to oppose state payments for abortions.

title: Benefits Extended For Steelworkers
description: The Reagan Administration approved supplemental unemployment benefits today for 2,800 of 3,200 laid-off workers at the Bethlehem Steel Corporation plant in Lackawanna, N.Y.

title: Pushing for Kicks
description: For the Cosmos and the Toronto Blizzard, it may be just another exhibition game. But for many soccer lovers in the Minneapolis-St.

title: BRENT SUTTER'S GOAL GIVES ISLANDERS TIE
description: The Islanders have toyed with their opposition on some nights this season and fallen down like little tin soldiers on others.

title: Shultz Picks Members Of New Policy Council
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz today announced the composition of the State Department's newly organized Policy Planning Council, which is supposed to provide a broad perspective on foreign policy issues.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Insider Reports
description: The New York and the American stock exchanges issued yesterday their latest reports of changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchanges. The reports of changes follow: NEW YORK EXCHANGE

title: 6 Women Suspended
description: She wouldn't say what they had done exactly, but according to Joan Kowalewski, the coach of the Utica College women's basketball team, six team members were suspended for a ''blatant breaking of training rules'' last Saturday after a 77-71 defeat by Gannon College in Erie, Pa.

title: QUEENS BROTHERS GIVEN 16 YEARS IN BURGLARY CASE
description: Two Queens brothers were each sentenced yesterday to 16 years in prison after they pleaded guilty in Federal court to a charge linking them to 1,000 burglaries and attempted burglaries.

title: SQUEAL RULE'S INVITATION TO 'DISASTER'
description: To the Editor: If the ingestion or application of a prescription medicine or device were to provoke some serious consequences, with further and more complex treatment indicated, who would carry the responsibility for paying the bills? Would it be the parent who never gave permission in the first place?

title: BRIEFING
description: The Papers and a Smile

title: CENTURY CLUB REVISITED
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: CONCERT: SCHULLER CONDUCTS NEW JAPANESE MUSIC
description: THE way things are going these days it appears that national differences in musical composition will soon be wiped out entirely, unless, of course, they have been already. This realization impressed itself anew last night during the ''Music From Japan'' concert at Carnegie Hall.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Manhattans for a Cruise Off Manhattan?

title: People; ADVERTISING
description: * Stanley D. Levitz, executive vice president of Creamer Inc., has been appointed a director.

title: Wallace's Condition Good
description: Gov. George C. Wallace, hospitalized Monday with stomach pains, was reported in good condition today and responding to antibiotics to combat diverticulitis, an inflammation in the lower colon. The 63-year-old Governor was expected to remain in Jackson Hospital the rest of the week.

title: ACCORD IN BIAS SUIT ASSURES YOUTH DIVISION JOBS FOR 130
description: New York State has agreed to give permanent jobs to more than 130 temporary youth counselors as part of a settlement of a discrimination lawsuit - even though many of them failed or received poor grades on a Civil Service examination.

title: LABOR SECRETARY SHUNNED AT A.F.L.-C.I.O. PARLEY
description: Secretary of Labor Raymond J. Donovan, whose relations with union leaders have been strained, ventured today onto the winter meeting ground of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. in hope of winning back blue-collar voters who supported Ronald Reagan in 1980.

title: CON EDISON WINS 6.5% RISE IN RATES, HALF OF ITS REQUEST
description: Most residential customers of the Consolidated Edison Company will soon be paying 6.5 percent more a month for electricity under an increase approved today by the Public Service Commission.The increase is about half the amount the utility requested last fall.

title: 'Moose Murders' Closes
description: ''Moose Murders,'' the play by Arthur Bicknell, closed Tuesday evening after one performance and 13 previews at the Eugene O'Neill Theater. The drama was directed by John Roach.

title: TO BETTER BLACKS' LIVES
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Aide Sees Nothing New In P.L.O.'s Algiers Decisions
description: Foreign Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that the nine-day Palestine National Council session in Algiers had changed nothing.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bobby Hammond, the Giants' most valuable player in 1977, has been signed by the Jets as coach of the running backs. He replaces Ray Callahan, who is switching to defensive line coach. ... A case of bronchitis may keep Danny Tarkanian from starting at point guard for Nevada-Las Vegas in tonight's game at California-Fullerton.

title: ANDROPOV CALLS FOR ECONOMIC OVERHAUL
description: An article by Yuri V. Andropov today offered the Soviet leader's toughest indictment yet of the country's economic failings and outlined a fresh approach that would combine political flexibility, material incentives and a crackdown on those who, in his words, ''sponge on society.''

title: ARENS CONFIRMED AS ISRAELI DEFENSE MINISTER
description: Moshe Arens, the Israeli Ambassador to the United States, was confirmed as Defense Minister by the Israeli Parliament today. The vote was 61 to 51 with 2 abstentions.

title: BIG THREE AUTO SALES FALL 14.2%
description: The Big Three automobile manufacturers reported today that sales in the Feb. 11-20 period fell 14.2 percent from the comparable period of 1982.

title: Top House Democrats Back Broad $5 Billion Bill on Jobs
description: House Democratic leaders gave tentative approval today to an emergency employment bill that would provide about $5 billion for a wide variety of job-producing and humanitarian efforts.

title: DOW UP BY 16.54, TO 1,096.94
description: Buoyed by favorable economic news, the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday climbed 16.54 points, to 1,096.94, the second-highest close in its history.

title: INQUIRIES FOCUS ON FUGITIVE'S COLLEGE
description: Dennis Banks, the fugitive American Indian leader who fled California last month, is trying to gain sanctuary in New York State by stressing his recent record as a peaceful citizen and educator as evidence that he has reformed.

title: An Olympian Dispute
description: The 1984 Pasadena-Pomona-Palo Alto Olympics? According to the executive vice president of the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee, that might be an accurate designation of next year's Games if the operators of the Los Angeles Coliseum can't solve a ticklish dispute involving who gets the revenue from 150 luxury suites the football Raiders are supposed to build on the Coliseum rim. ''It's absolutely tragic, but it could be done,'' said the official, Harry Usher, insisting that the opening and closing Olympic ceremonies and the track and field events could be shifted from the Coliseum.

title: Bridge: Clever Defense Transforms An Easy Game Into Ashes
description: To go down in an apparently easy game contract is bad enough. But to do so because an opponent has cleverly led you astray is very irritating indeed.

title: MAKING AN EXIT
description: President Reagan told a joke about the Soviet leader, Yuri Andropov, to a group of right-wingers the other day. Seems that Leonid Brezhnev, on his deathbed, whispered to the man who would succeed him, ''Comrade Andropov, one last bit of advice: Make certain the Russian people follow you.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of Francis X. McGowan on Feb. 16 incorrectly identified his wife.

title: REP. WASHINGTON, CHICAGO VICTOR, SETS AMBITIOUS CITY HALL AGENDA
description: Representative Harold Washington, the victor in this city's three-way Democratic mayoral primary Tuesday, received the concession of Mayor Jane M. Byrne today and began to turn his political movement into what he expects to be a new city administration.

title: Kaye and Mariners Part
description: Danny Kaye and three other original owners of the Seattle Mariners have sold their remaining interest in the baseball club to George Argyros, a California businessman who paid $13 million for a 92 percent interest two years ago. The transaction leaves Argyros sole owner of the six-year-old club.

title: CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS CUTBACKS
description: Still shaken by large loan losses, the Continental Illinois Corporation is planning to reduce the level of its business loans by about 5 percent this year and cut its staff by 800, Roger Anderson, the banking company's chairman, said at a closed-door meeting of senior officers Tuesday afternoon.

title: Duty Studied in Warner Case
description: Judge Mary Johnson Lowe, saying she was ''troubled'' by the question of whether a Warner Communications executive had a legal duty to ''blow the whistle,'' reserved decision yesterday on motions to overturn his conviction on charges involving the purchase of stock in the Westchester Premier Theater. She could overturn the fraud conviction if she found that the executive, Solomon Weiss, was not legally obligated to disclose the scheme.

title: BREAKING PEMEX TO A HARNESS
description: During much of the Lopez Portillo administration that ended 10 weeks ago, Petroleos Mexicanos seemed like a state within a state and the Oil Workers Union acted like a company within a company.

title: THEY MAY NOT LOVE NEW YORK IN CONGRESS, BUT ANIMOSITIES ARE MELLOWING
description: Five years after Congress grudgingly provided loan guarantees for New York City, the animosity toward the city that had been so prevalent seems to have given way to a gentler attitude.

title: TV: A ROMANCE BY AGATHA CHRISTIE
description: PUBLIC television's ''Mystery!'' moves on to the second of four Agatha Christie stories tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13 with ''Magnolia Blossom,'' a very slight romantic tale of duty coming before happiness. It is the kind of exercise that offers, apparently straightfaced, lines such as, ''I know I am worthless, but I do love you.''

title: SOVIET LASER SEEN AS SUSPECT IN CRIPPLING U.S. SPY SATELLITE
description: Federal experts are trying to learn whether an Air Force spy satellite that malfunctioned over the Soviet Union may have been damaged by a Russian ground-based antisatellite laser, the magazine Aviation Week and Space Technology said today.

title: 12, INCLUDING JAVITS, GET FREEDOM MEDAL FROM THE PRESIDENT
description: President Reagan presented the Presidential Medal of Freedom to 12 Americans today, saying that each of them had ''touched all our lives.''

title: TURNER BID TO MERGE WITH NETWORK
description: Ted Turner, the cable television entrepreneur, has been talking to top officials at all three of the major television networks about the possibility of a merger with his company, Turner Broadcasting System Inc.

title: REAGAN CRITICIZED ON TRANSIT SUBSIDY
description: The 5-cent increase in the gasoline tax will not go into effect until April, but city and transit officials today were already angrily accusing the Department of Transportation of reneging on promises of using it to help failing public transit systems.

title: Accounts
description: * Cardio Fitness Systems Inc. to Korey, Kay & Partners.

title: Senator Will Again Seek Europe Troop Freeze
description: The Senator who succeeded last year in freezing United States Army and Air Force troop strength in Western Europe said today that he would try to achieve the same goal this year.

title: USA Cable Network In Promotion Drive
description: Next Monday in 28 markets, the USA Cable Network will break a television advertising campaign intended to increase consumer awareness of its programming, which is being offered free on most of the local cable systems there.

title: HIJACKERS FREE 158 ON LIBYAN JETLINER AND SURRENDER IN MALTA
description: Two hijackers who were later identified as Libyan Army lieutenants today released 158 passengers and crew members of a Libyan national airline jet they had hijacked Sunday, and surrendered to the Maltese authorities.

title: WESTCHESTER RESIDENTS TAKE GRIPES TO THE TOP
description: It's not very often one gets a chance to talk directly to the man at the top. But Westchester residents got an opportunity to do just that today when County Executive Andrew P.O'Rourke threw open the doors of his ninth-floor office to anyone who wanted to drop in.

title: Heart Surgery on TV Completed Successfully
description: A doctor performed successful triple bypass heart surgery on a retired insurance salesman tonight in an operation broadcast live on national television.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Feb. 11 misstated financial results of the United American Bank of Memphis for 1982. It had a profit of $961,000.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
CAPACIOUS STORAGE DRAWERS
description: IF you've got a work table with inadequate drawers for storage there are several kits that allow you to mount storage drawers under the table top. Made of plastic or steel they have the rough-and-ready look of a workshop, sewing table, or a high-tech kitchen.

title: SKEPTICS PELT SHULTZ WITH QUERIES ON REAGAN'S 'PROJECT DEMOCRACY'
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz ran into considerable skepticism today when he outlined the Administration's plans to spend $85 million in the next two years to promote President Reagan's

title: HERS
description: WELL, I can tell you what I'd do if I discovered that my husband was having a love affair. I'd go get a gun. None of the pertinent information would filter through the buzzing sound that fills the brain when the heart is hurt. I would forget the facts: that I adore him, that there's a family to consider, that he makes a better living than I, that criminal lawyers are expensive. The possibility of widowhood, poverty or prison would not deter. Infidelity is reason enough for strict gun control.

title: INDEPENDENT RIVALS SAY ARCO OWES TAX
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company avoided nearly $200 million in ''windfall profits'' taxes last year and used the savings to undercut competitors, independent gasoline retailers charged today. Arco denied the charges.

title: Adelman Panel Will Question; Columnist on; 'Sham' Quote
description: Kenneth L. Adelman, making his third appearance on Capitol Hill in his fight for confirmation as director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, will be confronted Thursday with a New York journalist who quoted him as calling arms reduction talks a ''sham.''

title: WALKER SIGNING GREETED WITH SHARP CRITICISM
description: Some major college football coaches threatened yesterday to bar any United States Football League representatives from their campuses after learning that Herschel Walker had given up his last season of eligibility at Georgia to sign with the New Jersey Generals of the new league.

title: Century Club Revisited
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: ALTHOUGH anyone can legally add extra telephones to existing lines by installing jacks or connections desired, many people are uncertain about the wiring required and what they can and cannot do.

title: Pros Held a Lure for Walker
description: Christine Walker had grown weary of the recruiters. Among those keeping tabs on her son, Herschel, was Mike Cavan, the quarterback coach at the University of Georgia. Cavan had spent nearly three months in Wrightsville, Ga., where he mingled with the townspeople and got to know the Walker family.

title: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1983; International
description: Saudi Arabia and five other OPEC members agreed to cut the price of Saudi Light crude, on which other OPEC prices are based, according to the Saudi Arabian oil minister. The proposed reduction was believed to $4 a barrel. It would be greater, the other members were warned, if they did not go along with the move. (Page A1.)

title: Expropriation in Spain
description: The Spanish Government said today it would expropriate banks and other property belonging to Rumasa, the country's largest holding company.

title: MISS MYERSON PLANS ARTS STRATEGY
description: Within moments of her appointment yesterday as New York City's Cultural Affairs Commissioner, Bess Myerson was spinning a strategy for getting more private support for the city's cultural institutions - a strategy aimed at winning contributions from small businesses that have not before patronized the arts.

title: BARUCH AND STATEN ISLAND GAIN
description: A 12-foot shot by Aubrey Smith in the final second of overtime teetered on the rim before falling in and giving Baruch College a 93-91 victory over Queens College yesterday in the opening game of the City University tournament quarterfinals.

title: Reading & Bates
description: The Reading & Bates Corporation said it would cut its capital spending to $225 million from $412 million last year. It cited the ''uncertain energy environment'' and efforts to make its balance sheet stronger. It also said it expects to report 1983 earnings of between $2 and $2.50 a share; it earned $2.43 a share in 1982.

title: State High Court Kills Sexual Loitering Law
description: The State Court of Appeals today struck down a state law preventing the soliciting of another consenting adult for ''deviate'' sexual acts.

title: WINNER IN ANOTHER CHALLENGE TO ESTABLISHMENT: HAROLD WASHINGTON
description: A decade ago, when Harold Washington was a State Senator, he walked out in disgust when Spiro T. Agnew appeared before the Illinois Legislature. After the death of Mayor Richard J. Daley, he challenged the Democratic machine's designee, Michael Bilandic, and ran a spirited protest campaign. In 1980 he routed the machine and won a seat in Congress. Representative Washington, who last night defeated both factions of the divided machine, has enjoyed challenging the establishment since he was first elected to public office 18 years ago. But the latest time out, defeating Mayor Jane M. Byrne and Richard M. Daley for the nomination for Mayor, gave him the most pleasure of all.

title: TEXAS BABY DEATHS INVESTIGATED
description: A special grand jury is investigating the deaths of as many as 47 infants at a county hospital here from 1978 through early 1982, the Bexar County District Attorney said today.

title: Knoxville Bank Hearing
description: A House panel has scheduled hearings March 15 and 16 on the collapse of the United American Bank of Knoxville, Tenn. The panel also is looking into the bank's regulatory supervision.

title: NOGUCHI IS DENIED REINSTATEMENT AS CORONER BY COAST CIVIL SERVICE
description: The Los Angeles Civil Service Commission today decline to reinstate Dr. Thomas T. Noguchi, whose flamboyance as Los Angeles County Coroner earned him national attention but sometimes trouble here.

title: NETS THWART BULLS WITH TIGHT DEFENSE
description: The Nets combined a disciplined defense with a sharing offense tonight for one of their easiest victories of the season, 119-86, over the Chicago Bulls at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Walton's Check Was in the Mail
description: Bill Walton almost went on strike, simply because he had not been paid by the San Diego Clippers, which is less simply explained. The National Basketball Association franchise is enmeshed in a tangle of lawsuits and countersuits.

title: HOME BEAT
description: BECAUSE Amber Lightfoot Walker, left, had always liked 19th-century decoupage objects, she decided to learn the process, which includes sealing and painting on glass or wood.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 24, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Palestinian Rights - 3 P.M.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OPENING

title: Babette Deutsch Memorial
description: A memorial service for Babette Deutsch, the poet, novelist, critic and editor who died last November at the age of 87, will be held at St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University, Broadway and 117th Street, at 4 P.M. today. Poetry will be read by William Jay Smith and May Swenson.

title: Racal Unit Cuts Staff in Florida
description: Racal Electronics P.L.C. said its Racal-Milgo subsidiary had reduced its staff in Florida by a further 300 workers, to 3,200.

title: World Bank Aid to Rise
description: The World Bank said today that it would increase disbursements by $2 billion from the fiscal year 1983 through 1985 because of the international economic downturn.

title: Yields of 6% to 11.11% Tentatively Set for City
description: A $150 million issue of New York City bonds was tentatively priced yesterday to yield from 6 percent for those due in 1984 to 10 percent in 1993, 11 percent in 2003 and 11.11 percent in 2013.

title: Dyson to Testify On Nuclear Plants
description: A House subcommittee today subpoenaed the chairman of the Power Authority of the State of New York, John S. Dyson, ordering him to testify next week about a safety investigation at the Indian Point nuclear power plants.

title: Scribner Official Named Warner Publisher Head
description: Franklyn L. Rodgers, president of the Scribner Book Companies the last five years, will become president of Warner Publisher Services beginning March 1. Sol Himmelman, the current president, will become vice chairman.

title: POLAND VS. ONE OF ITS FINEST FAMILIES
description: To the Editor:

title: FOR THEATER SET DESIGNERS, ALL HOME'S A STAGE
description: MODERN architects have generally avoided the theater as a source of images for legitimate architecture. To them, set design has long meant Miami Beach hotel lobbies, with overdesigned, overdressed interiors searching for a play. Set design architecture was considered exaggerated, decorative and stylized.

title: From London, Wary Approval
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher said today that a modest decline in oil prices was good for Britain because it would aid economic recovery and because the country was close to self-sufficiency in oil.

title: Salvadoran Troops Are Said to Break Siege
description: Advance army units broke a 13-day rebel siege around the town of Suchitoto today, but guerrillas seized another northern city and threatened a third near the nation's hydroelectric dams, officials said.

title: China Puts Guards on Planes
description: China has posted security guards on all its airline flights after a hijacking attempt was foiled in a midair struggle over Shanghai in July, a Chinese airline official said today.

title: Celanese Corp.  Restructuring
description: The Celanese Corporation said it would merge its three United States fiber divisions in a streamlining move at the company's division offices here. The Celanese Fibers Company, Fiber Industries Inc. and the Celanese Fibers Marketing Company, which employ about 10,000 people, are joining to form the Celanese Fibers Operations.

title: National Network Plans Five-Hour Debut Show
description: The Nashville Network, latest entrant in the cable television field, will debut next month with 18 hours a day of country-flavored programming. It will have a live premiere, five hour show March 7 from New York, Los Angeles, Chicago, Denver, Austin, Tex., and Nashville, with such stars as Roy Acuff, Minnie Pearl, Chet Atkins, Larry Gatlin, Ray Stevens, Rosanne Cash, T.G. Sheppard, Emmylou Harris, Bill Monroe, Tanya Tucker and Lynn Anderson.

title: TIMES BEACH IS MIXED ON BUYOUT
description: Sue Petty and her three children live on River Road, a once tranquil Times Beach address that looks like a junkyard since the Meramec River overflowed and demolished much of the town last November.

title: SOME BIAS ALLOWED UNDER VOTING LAW
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Voting Rights Act permits state and local governments to change their voting procedures in ways that perpetuate discrimination against members of minority groups so long as the change does not worsen existing discrimination.

title: VENEZUELA SETS CURRENCY CONTROLS
description: Faced with rapidly declining currency reserves, extensive foreign debts and a drop in income from oil exports, the Government today announced foreign exchange controls.

title: Relaxed Attitude For Steinbrenner
description: George Steinbrenner, who has been known to become upset when the Yankees lose exhibition games, made a startling pronouncement about exhibition games today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Action Industries Inc., Cheswick, Pa., said a shareholder group had filed a suit against the company charging that it had misled shareholders about its condition.

title: TOTO GARNERS 7 GRAMMYS
description: The easy-rock band Toto dominated the 25th Grammys on Wednesday night by winning seven awards, including best record for ''Rosanna'' and best album for ''Toto IV.''

title: Debt Issues
description: * Gulf States Utilities Co. filed for an offering of $100 million of first-mortgage bonds due in 2013, through First Boston Corp.

title: Sabres 4, Flyers 2
description: Dave Andreychuk, Dale McCourt and Ric Seiling scored third-period goals to break a 1-1 tie and help deal the first loss to the rookie goalie Bob Froese, who was 12-0-1.

title: News Analysis
description: While the Democrats of Chicago had winners and losers Tuesday in the mayoral primary, Democrats elsewhere just thought they had a winner.

title: SQUEAL RULE'S INVITATION TO 'DISASTERS'
description: To the Editor:

title: EXCERPTS FROM CONVERSATIONS WITH PRESIDENT REAGAN AT BREAKFAST MEETING
description: Following are excerpts from remarks at a breakfast meeting that President Reagan had with a group of reporters today, as transcribed by The New York Times: Guarantees for Israel

title: Mix-Up Delays Practice for Wilson
description: Call it a misunderstanding. Call it a lapse in telephone communications. Or, as the Mets suspect, charge an error to the president of the National League. Whatever it was, it cost Mookie Wilson one day of training in the art of bunting a baseball.

title: ROCK: CLAPTON ON TOUR
description: ERIC CLAPTON has been one of rock's finest guitarists since the 1960's, when his successive stints with the Yardbirds, the Bluesbreakers, Cream, Blind Faith and Derek and the Dominos inspired acolytes to scrawl ''Clapton is God'' on London walls. His bright, bell-like tone, immaculate control of sustained feedback and harmonics and graceful, precise articulation were impressive in themselves, but they also conveyed a heartfelt lyricism and a kind of luminous spirituality. Then the light seemed to go out.

title: COURT UPHOLDS EMPLOYER ON LIMITING MAIL ACCESS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the Constitution permits a public employer to give its employees' labor union access to employee mailboxes while denying it to rival unions.

title: A CHIEF EXECUTIVE ELECTED BY G.& W.
description: Martin S. Davis, 56 years old, was elected chief executive officer of Gulf and Western Industries yesterday, succeeding Charles G. Bluhdorn, who died on Saturday.

title: Sebastian Littauer, 82, Dies; Columbia Engineering Figure
description: Sebastian B. Littauer, professor emeritus of operations research at Columbia University's School of Engineering and Applied Science, died of a respiratory illness Sunday in St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Topics; Real Estate, of a Sort; A Star Is Born
description: The 15th-century Portuguese navigators, as they neared the Cape of Good Hope, saw two ''shynynge white cloudes ... like unto theym which are seene in the tracte of heaven cauled Lactea via, that is the mylke whyte waye.'' They called them Cape Clouds.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: 3 New Playwrights On the Black Experience

title: DEATH TOLL IN ASSAM REPORTED TO RISE TO 1500
description: The total number of dead in more than three weeks of election violence in the northeastern state of Assam reportedly rose to about 1,500 today as a police official said 400 more Moslems died in mass attacks last Friday than had originally been believed.

title: Topics; Real Estate, of a Sort; Free Parking
description: Parker Brothers, the Supreme Court affirms, must give up its trademark on Monopoly. The name of the classic board game has become a generic description, the courts say, like cellophane or thermos.

title: HOUSE PANEL WOULD RAISE SOCIAL SECURITY PAYROLL TAX
description: A House subcommittee today turned aside a plan to address the long-term financing of Social Security by increasing the retirement age and voted instead to raise payroll taxes and reduce benefits in the next century.

title: ASKEW, EX-GOVERNOR OF FLORIDA, TO SEEK PRESIDENTIAL NOMINATION
description: Reubin O. Askew, a former two-term Governor of Florida, announced today that he was seeking the Democratic nomination for President in 1984 on a platform calling for a ''new union'' of labor and management to rebuild American industry.

title: ASSAM TRAGEDY: HOW BENGALIS BECAME THE VICTIMS
description: In 1931, when the present state of Assam was part of British India, a census official exclaimed over the influx of hundreds of thousands of Bengali-speaking Moslems from nearby areas.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: QUEEN OBTAINS BAN ON GOSSIP ARTICLES
description: As part of a running battle between Buckingham Palace and Fleet Street, Queen Elizabeth II has for the first time taken legal action against a British newspaper.

title: Sun Yefang Dies at 75; Top Chinese Economist
description: Sun Yefang, a leading economist and an architect of China's modernization program, has died, the official New China News Agency said today. He was 75 years old.

title: POP: BARRY MANILOW ON BROADWAY
description: ''THE kid knows how to sell a song,'' a man in a tuxedo was overheard to exclaim during intermission at the opening Monday night of Barry Manilow's two-week Broadway engagement in the Uris Theater. With its anachronistic overtones of a Tin Pan Alley song plugger, this assessment both sums up Mr. Manilow's appeal and suggests his artistic limitations.

title: CYRIL S. STANLEY
description: Cyril S. Stanley, retired general counsel of Rockefeller Center Inc., died Tuesday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 89 years old and lived in Jamesburg, N.J.

title: PAVELICH SCORES 5
description: Dozens of bright red baseball caps were winging down from the Madison Square Garden seats. The electronic scoreboard was flashing the word ''AWESOME'' in capital letters. The organist was thumping a rendition of ''Pomp and Circumstance.'' And the Rangers had not even won yet.

title: Steel Industry Assails Japan
description: The American steel industry today revived its charges that Japan and Western Europe had conspired to control the international steel market.

title: Connors Upset
description: Mike Bauer, a virtual unknown on the tennis tour, upset Jimmy Connors today in the second round of the $225,000 Congoleum Classic today. Bauer, a Californian ranked 89th in the world, capitalized on a booming serve to gain a 6-3, 6-4 victory in the second round.

title: Rolm Sues Plessey
description: The Rolm Corporation said it had filed suit against Plessey Telecommunications of Britain, charging misuse of Rolm technology and copyrighted software. The suit, filed in the Federal District Court for the Northern District of California, charges that Plessey used Rolm technology and software to develop a private branch exchange telecommunications system, the IDX.

title: Swedes Crack Heroin Ring
description: The police said today that they had cracked an international drug-smuggling ring that used a Lebanese airline pilot to carry heroin under his cap on twice-weekly flights from Beirut to Stockholm. They said 30 Swedish, Lebanese and other drug dealers had been arrested. A Lebanese accused of being the leader of the gang was arrested in Cyprus, and Sweden is applying for his extradition.

title: CUOMO SEEKS LIMITED EXTENSION FOR J-51 TAX AID
description: Governor Cuomo has proposed extending a New York City program of property tax benefits for developers. But his plan would restrict the circumstances under which those benefits could be granted.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1983
description: International

title: TRACKING THE E.P.A. INVESTIGATIONS
description: The Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., called five subcommittee chairmen to his office Tuesday afternoon to smooth some of the inevitable conflicts that had arisen from their overlapping investigations of the Environmental Protection Agency. It was the kind of spectacle that has become characteristic of Congress: five minibarons being called to order by the monarch to avoid a civil war.

title: STAGE: 'LIVING QUARTERS'
description: THE great gifts possessed by the Irish playwright Brian Friel are all present, after a fashion, in ''Living Quarters.'' They include his rhapsodic command of language, his empathy for Irish families in conflict and his twinkling, even devilish wit. But next to the major Friel plays - ''Philadelphia, Here I Come!'' ''The Faith Healer,'' ''Translations'' - this one seems muted and thin. It's easy to see why ''Living Quarters,'' which was first produced at Dublin's Abbey Theater in 1977, has traveled so tardily to the United States and why its first American production is occurring in unpretentious circumstances at a young Off Off Broadway theater.

title: WHAT CREDIBILITY?
description: In his embarrassment in finally acknowledging a contract with the New Jersey Generals after having denied it repeatedly last week, Herschel Walker yesterday apologized for lying.

title: HEART ATTACK RISK UNRELATED TO NICOTINE LEVEL, STUDY SAYS
description: A yearlong study of hospitalized heart attack patients has shown that the risk of suffering a heart attack was just as great among smokers who used low-nicotine cigarettes as it was among those who used high-nicotine brands.

title: Anxious Listener
description: There was obviously something lost in the translation, but for three anxious hours, Vilomar Fernandez thought he had been deprived of the opportunity to defeat Alexis Arguello again. Fernandez was in his Bronx apartment, listening to a Spanish-language radio station last week, when he heard that Arguello, whom he was scheduled to meet in a junior welterweight fight in San Antonio this Saturday, had retired.

title: FIXED INCOME ISSUES DECLINE
description: Prices of fixed-income securities fell and yields rose yesterday after light but persistent profit taking developed toward the close. Government securities dealers attributed the selling to the report on durable goods orders for January and the expected profit taking after the substantial price rises on Tuesday.

title: There's No There There (2)
description: The vacuum at the center in Washington - the emptiness in the Presidency - is starkly exposed in the affair of Kenneth Adelman. His nomination to head the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency is more than a test of the Reagan Administration's seriousness on arms negotiations. It is a comment on the seriousness of Ronald Reagan's interest in governing.

title: Advertising Serving Up Lower Fat In Snacks
description: WHEN the Plaza Hotel serves Cremora instead of cream in the Baroque Suite, something is definitely up. What was up yesterday morning was a Borden news conference, and Borden makes Cremora as well as milk-based products like its Liteline cheeses, which were not only talked about but also served.

title: Selling Professionalism To Radio Listeners
description: When the management of CBS-owned AM radio stations decided to develop a single unifying campaign -instead of having each of the seven stations doing its own advertising with its own agency - it was natural that the management should turn to Trout & Ries, the positioning agency.

title: END RUN ON SALVADOR
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz is in danger of putting himself in the same class as the Watts and the Burfords and all the other Presidential appointees who are busily engaged in doing end runs around Congress and the law in order to carry out the policy objectives of the Reagan Administration.

title: AMERICAN AIRLINES TARGET OF U.S. SUIT
description: The president of American Airlines tried to enlist his counterpart at Braniff Airways, a major competitor, in a plan of ''collusive monopolization,'' the Government charged today.

title: INTERNING 'NONALIENS' IN '42 WAS AN ACT OF RACISM
description: Forty-one years ago last Saturday, Franklin D. Roosevelt signed Executive Order 9066, authorizing the forced evacuation and internment of 110,000 loyal Americans.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''No one realizes more than I that I am a human being.

title: Vice Chairman Position, Is Filled By The Limited
description: The Limited Inc., a major women's apparel and mail order retailer that has grown by acquisition in the last year, yesterday named Robert H. Morosky vice chairman.

title: Generals Get a Rush On Tickets
description: The New Jersey Generals reported having sold more than 1,000 season tickets in about 10 hours yesterday, after the announcement that Herschel Walker had signed with them.

title: The P.L.O. Versus the Palestinians
description: Midst fantasies about victories in Lebanon, the governing council of the P.L.O. prefers playing with words to reexamining its premises. It does not ''reject'' President Reagan's ideas for West Bank negotiations, it merely finds them ''unacceptable.'' What it really rejects is reality, diplomacy and, as always, Israel.

title: OPERA HAS BEEN PERFORMED OFTEN
description: Composed in 1830, ''I Capuleti e i Montecchi'' was Bellini's 10th opera. The libretto is Felice Romani's reworking of his own text for Nicola Vaccai's ''Giulietta e Romeo,'' which appeared five years before Bellini's work had its premiere in Venice.

title: Shop Renamed Bloom Agency
description: New York's Mathieu, Gerfen & Bresner, acquired last March by the Bloom Companies of Dallas, henceforth will be known as the Bloom Agency. And it has had its top management shifted a bit.

title: Nissan Trucks
description: The Nissan Motor Company said it would start to make trucks for the American market at its new plant here in June, rather than in August as previously expected. It cited faster progress in construction than expected and excellent results in its training program.

title: Stargell Too Expensive
description: When Willie Stargell retired last year, he said he would like to remain in the Pittsburgh Pirates organization, and spoke of becoming a minor league instructor.

title: California Dentist Barred After 3 Patients Die
description: A dentist accused of negligence and incompetence because three patients died after receiving anesthesia was ordered today to stop practicing dentistry temporarily.

title: Financial Aid Set for Brazil
description: The first two parts of a four-part financing program for Brazil will be signed on Friday, a spokesman for the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company said yesterday.

title: UNIONS EASE PAY RULES TO MAKE FILM IN QUEENS
description: A group of motion-picture craft unions has agreed to cut overtime costs for a film to be made in New York next summer. The producer says the agreement will save him up to $10 million, and the unions say it will assure increased employment. The agreement, which applies to one film, comes at a time of high unemployment in the industry. The producer, Robert Evans, said that as a result of the agreement, he had decided to make the movie in New York rather than London, where costs are normally lower. The film, ''Cotton Club,'' will go into production at the Astoria Studio in Long Island City, Queens, and other locations in the city next July 11, he said.

title: Cautious Mood On Eurobonds
description: The Eurobond market, after a flurry at the opening, was quiet today.

title: SUFFOLK REQUESTS A HALT IN SHOREHAM HEARINGS
description: Suffolk County asked the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today to halt its hearings on whether to license the nearly completed Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: A LAWYERS' RULE WORTH TRYING
description: To the Editor:

title: RUNNING AMERICAN: A FORMIDABLE TASK
description: When Robert L. Crandall took over as president of American Airlines in July 1980, the hard-driving executive who had made his mark in marketing and finance faced a formidable task. The airline had lost money in seven of the 11 preceding years.

title: Braniff-Eastern Deal Advances
description: An administrative law judge, Elias Rodriguez, recommended that the Civil Aeronautics Board approve an agreement to allow Eastern Air Lines to take over Braniff International's South American routes permanently.

title: OPERA: JUILLIARD TROUPE IN BELLINI'S 'I CAPULETI'
description: ''ICAPULETI E I MONTECCHI'' is an opera of definite dramatic appeal that sings from beginning to end and yet somehow does not seem able to keep its hold on the affections of the public. A work of Bellini's maturity that was immediately successful at its premiere in 1830, it can be rewarding for connoisseurs of his bel canto style even while exciting the uninitiated listener. It is therefore regularly revived and regularly cheered. It also is regularly forgotten.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Smart Shopping For Rikers Prisoners

title: LEBANON WELCOME REAGAN'S BORDER-SECURITY IDEA
description: Government sources expressed gratification today at President Reagan's statement that the United States would do everything necessary to guarantee Israel's border with Lebanon once Israeli troops withdrew from Lebanese soil.

title: WHEN CHILDREN EMPLOY THEIR MOTHERS
description: ''FROM 9 to 5 I'm Barbara,'' said Barbara Moses, 52 years old, who carries out administrative duties for her daughter, Rebecca, a New York fashion designer. ''After that I'm Mom.''

title: Q&A
description: Q. Vinyl wall covering was installed on the kitchen walls but without a border around the ceiling edge. I would like to put up a six-inch vinyl border. Can it be pasted on the wall covering, and if so what adhesive should be used?

title: Celtics 113, Lakers 104
description: Boston scored 14 of the last 16 points to gain the victory, its second in as many meetings with Los Angeles this season. Larry Bird led the Celtics with 32 points, 18 rebounds and 9 assists.

title: Riggins to Get U.S.F.L. Offer
description: John Riggins, the star running back for the Washington Redskins and the National Football League's leading free agent, agreed yesterday to meet with officials of the Michigan Panthers to hear an offer designed to lure him into the United States Football League.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Rockets vs. Milwaukee Bucks, at Houston. (Television - USA Cable, 8 P.M.) Colleges: Manhattanville at Army, 7:15 P.M.; Fordham at Manhattan, 8 P.M. (Radio - WFUV-FM, 90.7, 8 P.M.); New Hampshire at Fairfield, 8 P.M.; St. Peter's at Iona, 8 P.M.; New Haven at Adelphi, 8 P.M.; Indiana at Michigan (Television - WTBS, 8 P.M.); Wake Forest at North Carolina (Television -ESPN, 9 P.M.); U.C.L.A. at Southern Cal (Television - ESPN, 11 P.M.); Nebraska at Oklahoma (Television - ESPN, 1 A.M. Friday, tape); Wagner at Fordham, women, 7:30 P.M. Hockey Devils vs. Detroit Red Wings, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7:35 P.M. (Television - Sports@Channel and WHT, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WVNJ, 620; 7:30 P.M.) Swimming and Diving New York State Division III women's championships, at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, L.I. Preliminaries at 9:30 A.M., one-meter diving at 1 P.M. and finals in eight events 6:30-9:30 P.M. Jan Bender, a 21-year-old Stony Brook senior, was second in the nationals last season.

title: Socialist International Shifts Site of Its Congress to Lisbon
description: The Socialist International has switched the site of its congress in April from Sydney, Australia, to Lisbon because of the Australian general elections, the organization's president, Willy Brandt, said today.

title: Jersey Gets Chief Of Criminal Justice
description: A Hopatcong lawyer, Donald R. Belsole, was sworn in today as director of the State Division of Criminal Justice.

title: Blue-Collar; School Workers; Approve Pact in Philadelphia
description: Striking blue-collar workers for the Philadelphia school district overwhelmingly approved a contract offer tonight, ending a 21-day strike.

title: ST. JOHN'S DEFEATS SYRACUSE
description: St. John's overcame a zone defense and a full-court press in the second half last night in defeating Syracuse, 85-69, in a Big East Conference game at Alumni Hall.

title: GALLAGHER IS TO RETIRE AS CHIEF, DOME SAYS ,
description: John P. Gallagher will retire as chief executive officer of Dome Petroleum Ltd., the company said today. Dome, based in Calgary, Alberta, is negotiating a $1 billion rescue package with four large Canadian banks and the Canadian Government.

title: 3 Cosmos Named to Team America
description: Three Cosmos and three Tampa Bay Rowdies lead the list of 16 players named yesterday to Team America, the soccer team that will compete as the United States national team in international matches and as a franchise in the North America Soccer League this season. Four more players will be added to the team later by the head coach, Alkis Panagoulias.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Cynex Manufacturing Corp., Hillside, N.J., has elected Irving Green executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: SIR ADRIAN BOULT, CONDUCTOR FOR 60 YEARS, IS DEAD AT 93
description: Sir Adrian Boult, who championed 20th-century British music in his long career as conductor of the BBC Symphony Orchestra and the London Philharmonic Orchestra, died yesterday at a nursing home in Kent, England. He was 93 years old and had been ill for some time.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Big Time Coming At Brooklyn Bridge

title: CANDIDACIES SPAWNED BY THE U.S. TREASURY
description: To the Editor:

title: MET SETS '83-84 CENTENNIAL SEASON
description: The Metropolitan Opera's 1983-84 centennial season will open Sept. 26 with the first revival of Berlioz's ''Troyens'' since the opera's Met premiere in 1973.

title: 4 STATES AND CITY REACH PACT FOR ENLARGING 4 RESERVOIRS
description: New York State, New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware and New York City today reached agreement on a plan to enlarge four reservoirs to increase regional water supplies.

title: CALENDAR: A PARK VOLUNTEER PROGRAM
description: Learning and Involvement in the Environment, Central Park, Arsenal Building, Room 8B, 830 Fifth Avenue, 212-360-3462/72.

title: FORECLOSURES HEARING
description: Congress, which is considering a number of emergency measures to aid unemployed homeowners facing foreclosure, encountered vigorous opposition today from Federal banking regulators.

title: A FRESH START FOR DAN LLOYD
description: After all those hours that he invested to reclaim his health and to redevelop his athletic skills and after all the miles he recently traveled in search of employment, Dan Lloyd had to laugh at the thought that his professional football career was completing a circle.

title: CHANGES IN HOME-PHONE INDUSTRY: THE EFFECTS ON SERVICE AND PRICE
description: MA BELL - the deliverer, the fixer, the supplier of home telephones, the counter of message units, the provider of long-distance service - will soon become many companies scrambling to compete for the attention of consumers, who may be bewildered by what is happening to the phone company.

title: BLUNT TALK ON THE PHONE
description: The Government's case against American Airlines rests partly on this telephone conversation on or about Feb. 21, 1982, between Robert L. Crandall, president and chief executive of American, and Howard Putnam, president and chief executive of Braniff Airways.

title: Louisiana Bonds Yield 4.5% to 8.6%
description: A $145 million issue of Louisiana bonds was offered with yields ranging from 4.5 percent for bonds due in 1984 to 7.4 percent in 1993 and 8.6 percent in 2002-03.

title: ORDERS UP AGAIN FOR DURABLES
description: Orders placed with manufacturers of durable goods last month rose 4.5 percent after December's increase of 8.5 percent, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Trunk, Shea Aims At Health-Care Field
description: Trunk, Shea Inc. is a new specialty ad agency in the health-care field that has opened its doors in Clifton, N.J., and although it started without any business it got some yesterday. However, dePaul R. Trunk, the 44-year-old president, said that for the moment his lips are sealed as to the client's identity.

title: King's 40 Helps Knicks Win and Leave Cellar
description: Bernard King scored 40 points tonight to lead the Knicks to a 120-107 victory over the Detroit Pistons and out of last place in the Atlantic Division for the first time this season.

title: RICHEST FOOTBALL PACT LURES GEORGIA STAR TO NEW LEAGUE
description: Herschel Walker of the University of Georgia, widely considered the nation's best collegiate football playar, signed a precedentsetting contract yesterday with the New Jersey Generals of the new United States Football League.

title: GROMYKO ASKS U.S. MISSILE OFFER
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko said today in an interview in Pravda that there had been no change in the attitude of the West on medium-range missiles despite talk about adopting a more flexible position.

title: Baxter Travenol Official Named to Additional Job
description: Wilbur H. Gantz, executive vice president at Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc., has been named to the additional post of chief operating officer.

title: Portuguese Meets Reagan
description: President Reagan met today with the Portuguese opposition leader Mario Soares to discuss international issues and Portuguese politics, a White House spokesman said. The spokesman, Lyndon K. Allin, said the brief meeting was arranged while Mr. Soares was in the United States in his capacity as vice president of the Socialist International.

title: Broadway Blues
description: Chita Rivera's agent recently telephoned the Rangers to ask if the singer could render the national anthem before a game. Presumably, it would not be for the fee - $25, two tickets and two meals - but to publicize the Broadway musical ''Merlin,'' in which she is starring.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: SON OF THE REVOLUTION. By Liang Heng and Judith Shapiro. Illustrated. 301 pages. Knopf. $15.

title: Cuts Are Avoided In School Busing
description: Bus rides that were to have ended for 15,000 fifth and sixth graders who live between a mile and a mile and a half from public schools in the city will be continued, Mayor Koch and Joseph G. Barkan, the Board of Education president, announced yesterday.

title: REAGAN CRITICIZES BANKS OVER RATES
description: President Reagan suggested today that banks were keeping interest rates too high and that they should be able to bring them down ''another notch or two.''

title: Off-Duty Officer Hurt in Shooting
description: An off-duty city police officer was shot twice last night in an exchange of gunfire with an off-duty housing officer in a Bronx alley, the police said.

title: GREECE JOINS SOVIET IN URGING DEEP ARMS CUTS
description: Greece and the Soviet Union agreed today that nuclear-free zones were an important aspect of the disarmament process and they called for the limitation of armed forces and both conventional and nuclear arms to ''the lowest possible level.''

title: GCA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: B-Including tax credits of $5.5 million for the qr and $20.4 million for the yr...C-Net income

title: News Analysis
description: Campaign strategists and union allies of former Vice President Walter F. Mondale are pushing the A.F.L.- C.I.O. to speed its Presidential endorsement process by several months to give Mr.

title: William Eisendrath, Teacher And Organizer of Exhibitions
description: William N. Eisendrath Jr., a teacher and nationally known organizer of art exhibitions, died Monday in St. Louis after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: ESMARK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
description: Shr earnings and shrs outstdng reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in Dec 1982; results for the yr-ago first qr include operations previously considered subject to disposition but retained by a fourth qr decision change

title: VAIL ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
MONARCH INVESTMENTS LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
REAGAN'S COUNSEL ORDERED TO MAKE INQUIRY INTO E.P.A.
description: The White House counsel has been ordered to examine contacts between senior aides of President Reagan and the Environmental Protection Agency for any evidence of political manipulation, White House officials said today.

title: GLEASON WORKS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOUTHERN OSCILLATION IS BLAMED
description: Recent heavy snows in the Eastern states, unseasonal rains in the Southwest, sweeping fires in Australia, catastrophic floods in Ecuador and droughts in Malaysia are all at least partly the result, Government scientists say, of an oscillation in atmospheric circulation.

title: TENS OF THOUSANDS FLEE ASSAM STRIFE
description: Tens of thousands of Moslem immigrants have reportedly sought safety in refugee camps in the northeastern Indian state of Assam or fled to nearby states out of fear that more violence may erupt.

title: School Board's Vote Ends Philadelphia Strike
description: A 23-day strike by 4,000 bus drivers, custodians and boiler operators against the Philadelphia School District ended today when the school board voted, 6 to 2, to approve a negotiated contract.

title: ACKLANDS LTD reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
description: B-After special charges of $8,083,000 for discontinued operations...C-Net income including a special gain of $688,000

title: Short-Term Rates in Decline; Action by Fed Is Anticipated
description: Interest rates fell yesterday on speculation that the Federal Reserve Board might have embarked on a policy that would foster a decline in short-term interest rates.

title: Learning From Chicago
description: After Tuesday's primary in Chicago, only a massive and racially motivated defection of Democrats will keep Representative Harold Washington from becoming the first black mayor of the nation's second largest city. His defeat by a Republican is unlikely; as one Chicago alderman put it, Attila the Hun or Yuri Andropov could win Chicago's April election provided they ran as Democrats.

title: OVERSEAS SHIPHOLDING GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes a foreign currency loss of $2,138,000 and a loss of $1,534,000 on a vessel sale...C-Includes an unrealized foreign currency loss of $4,724,000...D-Includes an unrealized foreign currency gain of $7,446,000 or 29 cents a shr and a gain on vessels sales of $418,000 or 2 cents a shr...E-Inclu a gain of $6,858,000 or 27 cents a shr from recovery of prior yr's defer credits related to a British subsidiary, a gain of $3,228,000 or 13 cents a shr on a vessel sale and an unrealized foreign currency loss of $3,528,000

title: CENTRAL JERSEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Old hunt club and new steakhouse.
description: ''PRESENTEZ les desserts!'' the maitre d'hotel says impatiently to a captain. ''Ouvrez la serviette!'' the waiter says sotto voce as a busboy tries to cover a spot on a tablecloth with a folded napkin.

title: Apocalypse for sale.
description: THE illustrations from an unrecorded English Gothic manuscript of the last book of the New Testament, Revelation, which is often called the Apocalypse because it contains St. John's vision of the end of the world, will be on view this weekend at Sotheby Parke Bernet, York Avenue at 72d Street. The manuscript, produced in York, England, around 1270, contains 77 miniatures (as the paintings in medieval manuscripts are called regardless of their size), depicting battle scenes, dragons, eathquakes, angels, monsters, the Antichrist and a vision of the new Jerusalem. These have survived without most of the text.

title: MEXICO IN $5 BILLION LOAN PACT
description: Mexico today announced completion of negotiations with about 530 Western banks on the largest commercial loan in history - a $5 billion ''jumbo'' credit that should be ready for signing in New York late next week.

title: N.B.A. AND PLAYERS SCHEDULE NEW TALKS
description: The National Basketball Association and its players association will resume contract negotiations Tuesday for the first time since the players imposed an April 2 strike deadline.

title: Moslem Party Leader Is Jailed in Turkey
description: The leader of the Moslem fundamentalist National Salvation Party and 23 aides were found guilty today of trying to set up an Islamic state and were sentenced to prison.

title: CHICAGO MILWAUKEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $987,000 for the qr and $3,286,000 for the yr...C-Including tax credits of $399,000 for the qr and $2,609,000 for the yr

title: PLESSEY CO PLC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings are per American Depository Receipts

title: 16 Sites Studied For World Cup
description: The United States Soccer Federation has lined up 16 stadiums as possibilities for its 12 sites, should it win the bid to hold the 1986 World Cup soccer tournament. At a meeting in Stockholm May 19 of the Federation Internationale de Football Association, the United States will be competing with Brazil, Canada and Mexico in an effort to be selected the host for the tournament.

title: THE FIRES OF WAR PUT OUT, SLEEP OVERCOMES SINAI
description: Heading toward this spot at the southern tip of the vast Sinai Peninsula, the road along the Gulf of Suez sometimes runs past mounds of silky sand that hide the gulf's blue waters. This can result in an astounding sight - huge container ships heading for the Suez Canal seem to be sailing effortlessly over sandy wastes.

title: U.S. COMMAND SEEKS MOBILITY TO ELUDE ATTACK
description: The Defense Department has concluded that Soviet warheads could disable the land-based command posts that are intended to serve as the Government's nerve center in a nuclear war.

title: Burnup & Sims Reports a Loss
description: Burnup & Sims Inc., a Fort Lauderdale-based telecommunications company, reported a net loss of $1.8 million for the third quarter, ended Jan. 31, compared with earnings of $900,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter a year earlier.

title: KRATOS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; the latest qr and yr results of operations of Keuffel & Esser Co acquired Jan 1, 1982

title: DOWNEY SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Polish Bishops in Rome
description: The secretary of the Polish Roman Catholic Episcopal Conference and another Polish bishop arrived from Warsaw today for talks with Pope John Paul II. The Conference Secretary, Msgr. Bronislaw Dabrowski, and the Bishop of Tarnow, Jerzy Ablewicz, were expected to discuss arrangements for the Pope's scheduled visit to Poland starting June 18, Vatican sources said.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''Look, there's Rex Smith - he's adorable,'' squealed a partygoer in the British Embassy rotunda the other evening. The actor was making his way through a mob of people who were standing chest to chest and balancing drinks while eating crayfish and oysters from tiny plates.

title: GENERAL EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $671,000 from the settlement of litigations...C-Includinga gain of $4.8 million from the sale of coal operations in Colorado
