description: B-Including income of $2,369,000 from discontinued operations and extraordinaryincome of $111,658...C-Including income of $26,098 from discontinued operations

title: ENSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Calls for Verification In Toxin Weapons Pact
description: The United States will insist on a tough, on-site verification agreement with the Soviet Union to enforce a ban on chemical weapons, a top State Department official said today.

title: WARTIME INTERNMENT OF JAPANESE WAS 'GRAVE INJUSTICE,' PANEL SAYS
description: A Congressional commission concluded today that the relocation and internment of 120,000 Japanese-American citizens and resident aliens in World War II was a ''grave injustice.''

title: OPERA: NEW 'BOHEME' FACES
description: FRANCO ZEFFIRELLI'S monumental production of Puccini's ''La Boheme'' at the Metropolitan Opera has such a presence that it retains its character even with the inevitable shufflings of new cast members in and out of the proceedings. At Wednesday evening's performance, there was some unscheduled shuffling, since the Rodolfo, Dano Raffanti, withdrew after the second act and was replaced by Giuliano Ciannella.

title: ANALOG DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
Pension Case Suit by U.S.
description: The Labor Department said today that it had sued the Chemical Bank and four committee members of a now-bankrupt meatpacking company, accusing them of having violated pension laws.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A grave injustice was done to American citizens and resident aliens of Japanese ancestry who, without individual review or any probative evidence against them, were excluded, removed and detained by the United States during World War II.'' - Commission on Wartime Relocation and Internment of Civilians. (A12:6.)

title: EG & G Suspends Fuel Plan Work
description: EG & G Inc. said it had suspended design activities for the proposed New England Energy Park synthetic fuels project, pending a further review of long-term energy markets.

title: FILM: 'HOLLYWOOD OUT-TAKES,' SNIPPETS FOR TRIVIA COLLECTORS
description: THE material contained in ''Hollywood Out-Takes & Rare Footage,'' which opens today at the Waverly 1, is, with the exception of one sequence, strictly for collectors of movie trivia. The exception is a sequence shot for W.C. Fields's classic short ''The Dentist.''

title: CAREY TO SKIP ST. PATRICK'S MARCH IN CONFLICT OVER SUPPORT FOR I.R.A.
description: Former Gov. Hugh L. Carey said yesterday that he would not march in this year's St. Patrick's Day Parade because a supporter of the outlawed Irish Republican Army had been selected to lead it.

title: THE BETTER WAY
description: Not long before he formally became a Presidential candidate, Walter F. Mondale told dinner table companions in New York - including Charlotte Curtis of The New York Times - that ''we must build more prisons.'' And he said in his announcement speech in Minnesota that Americans want ''convicted criminals to go to jail again.''

title: INVESTIGATION IN TEXAS FOCUSES ON 12 CHILD DEATHS
description: A grand jury investigation into possible ''multiple infant homicides'' at a county hospital here centers on about 12 deaths that occurred over 15 months sometime from 1978 to early 1982, sources close to the inquiry said today.

title: MISS LAVELLE CALLS E.P.A. BADLY SPLIT
description: Rita M. Lavelle, the recently dismissed head of the Environmental Protection Agency's toxic waste program, today described the agency as split by bitter internal rivalries and lacking a clear chain of command or leadership.

title: INSTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Arrows Dismiss Coach
description: Don Popovic was abruptly dismissed as coach of the New York Arrows yesterday, just four days after he angered club officials by using an impromptu locker room interview in Buffalo to disclose plans to leave the Major Indoor Soccer League team at the end of this season. ''It was highly unfair to the players,'' declared the Arrows' president, Terry Leiweke, who said he had dismissed Popovic to avoid ''a lame duck position.'' Shep Messing, the team's star goalie, who has been on the injured reserve list since suffering a bruised kidney last week, was designated as interim coach during the search for a replacement.

title: 10.9% Jobless in Europe
description: Unemployment in the European Economic Community in January broke a record at 10.9 percent, up from a revised 10.3 percent in December and 9.3 percent in January 1982, the statistical agency Eurostat reported today. The number of jobless in the 10 member nations rose to 12.4 million from 11.8 million a month earlier and 10.7 million a year earlier, Eurostat said.

title: Brink's Trial Date
description: A trial date of March 21 was set yesterday for six defendants on Federal charges stemming from an investigation of the 1981 Brink's robbery and murders in Rockland County.

title: O'NEILL APPOINTS 7 TO HIGHER EDUCATION BOARD
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill today appointed seven members of a new 11-member board that will have extensive power to reorganize the management of the 22 state colleges and universities.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 25, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Non-Use of Force - 10:30 A.M. and 3:00 P.M.

title: CHRYSLER HAS LOSS OF $96 MILLION
description: The Chrysler Corporation reported today that its fourth-quarter loss had widened to $96.1 million, from $67 million a year earlier, chiefly because of a strike at its Canadian subsidiary.

title: PUBLISHING: WORD PROCESSOR TO BOOK
description: ARTHUR HAILEY is writing a novel about the pharmaceutical industry. Jane Howard is writing a biography of Margaret Mead. Raquel Welch is writing a beauty and fitness guide. Erica Jong's new volume of poetry will be published soon. And the Johns Hopkins University Press will publish up to 20 volumes culled from the papers of Thomas A. Edison.

title: THE CITY;
description: The State Commissioner of Social Services announced yesterday the award of $355,000 in grants to provide housing for homeless men and women, primarily in New York City.

title: Union Pacific Picks A Chief Executive
description: The Union Pacific Corporation said yesterday that William S. Cook would succeed James H. Evans as chief executive officer, effective May 1.

title: LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICIALS URGE CRIME CONTROL ACT FOR STATE
description: Law enforcement officials and experts, describing organized-crime groups in New York State as ''a plague'' and ''virtually immune'' from prosecution, yesterday called for the enactment of a special state crime-control act.

title: ANTI-TOLL MOVEMENT IN CONNECTICUT ATTRACTS SUPPORT
description: Fueled by three disparate elements - politics, regionalism and a tragic accident -momentum is building in the state government here to eliminate tolls on Connecticut's highways.

title: TORONTO-DOMINION BANK (CANADA) reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
AMERICAN REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income including a tax credit of $1,518,000

title: COLLEGE CENTERS ARE LIGHTING UP ARTS SCENE IN OUTER BOROUGHS
description: FROM Itzhak Perlman and Barbara Cook to the Nikolais Dance Theater - the range and quality of some of this weekend's offerings beyond Manhattan but still within the city limits reflect the growing importance of college-based arts centers in New York's outer boroughs. Led by the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts, the Colden Center in Queens and the three-year-old Lehman College Center for the Performing Arts in the Bronx, they are drawing not only performers but also audiences from Manhattan, while widening their programs to serve new and changing audiences close to home.

title: CHICAGO MAYORAL RACE GAINS G.O.P.'S INTEREST
description: The 48-day campaign in the general election for Mayor of Chicago informally opened here today with Bernard Epton, a Republican, planning his own upset attempt against Representative Harold Washington, who upset the city's regular Democratic machine Tuesday.

title: RECOGNITION EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Net loss; yr-ago results have been restated to reflect adoption of F.A.S.B. Statement No 43

title: SHARING JOYS OF PURIM AT A HASIDIC CELEBRATION
description: On Sunday, Hasidic families in Brooklyn's Crown Heights section will open their homes to visitors who want to share with them the joys of the Jewish festival of Purim. The excursion, sponsored by the 92d Street Y, will provide a rare glimpse into the way Hasidic Jews live, worship and celebrate. Visitors will share a festive family meal, look in on a Hasidic synagogue, view a parade of costumed youngsters and they may join in singing and dancing in the streets. With Purim falling on a Sunday this year, the Crown Heights tour is but one of an unusually large number of holiday celebrations.

title: JOHN OSENENKO
description: John Osenenko, a former manager of Special Features, the syndicate division of The New York Times, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home in Ocala, Fla. He was 65 years old and a former resident of the Floral Park section of Queens.

title: A BIG NIGHT FOR MOVIES
description: ON tap Sunday evening at 9 is something of a skirmish between the network movie schedules. CBS will offer the network premiere of ''9 to 5'' on Channel 2, featuring Jane Fonda, Lily Tomlin and Dolly Parton in the leading roles. The two other networks are relying on ambitious television movies. NBC has Dennis Weaver in ''Cocaine: One Man's Seduction'' on Channel 4, an earnest exploration of a drug habit. And ABC will present Lee Majors in ''Starflight: The Plane That Couldn't Land'' on Channel 7, still another reworking of the escapist adventure stuff that proved so popular in the film ''Airport.'' When a Middle-Aged Man Is Hooked by Cocaine

title: Studio School true to style.
description: Since its beginnings in 1964, the New York Studio School of Drawing, Painting and Sculpture, at 8 West Eighth Street, has gone its own way amid a succession of artistic fads and movements. The school was founded to provide intensive art study for students who believed art schools were inadequate for their needs, and it has been instrumental in keeping a particular approach to art - an approach based on the heritage of Paul Cezanne and Alberto Giacometti - alive.

title: PAY 'N SAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
THREE VIEWS OF HOW AND WHY WALKER TURNED PRO
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference held Wednesday in Athens, Ga., by Jack Manton, the attorney for Herschel Walker, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: WORK NOT IN REPERTORY NOW
description: Composed in 1830, ''I Capuleti e i Montecchi'' was Bellini's 10th opera. The libretto is Felice Romani's reworking of his own text for Nicola Vaccai's ''Giulietta e Romeo,'' which appeared five years before Bellini's work had its premiere in Venice.

title: J-51 LAG CALLED PERIL TO HOUSING PLANS
description: New York City housing officials yesterday released a list of 40 building rehabilitation projects they say may be jeopardized because the State Legislature has not extended a city tax benefit program.

title: MACMILLAN BLOEDEL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After gains from sale of U.S. tax benefits of $31.5 million for the qr and $36 million for the yr...C-Net income after a gain of $30 million from sale of subsidiary; the 1982 results included a nonrecurring expense of $65.7 million in severance and closure cost and provisions; the amounts are in Canadian funds

title: Daily Auctions By Freddie Mac
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, a Government agency known as Freddie Mac, will begin auctioning mortgage participation certificates daily instead of weekly beginning March 15, Kenneth J. Thygerson, president, said.

title: REAGAN AIDE STUDIES NOTES FROM E.P.A.
description: Fred F. Fielding, the White House counsel, is assembling memorandums and ''issue alerts'' sent from the Environmental Protection Agency to various officials over the last year as he begins the examination of whether there has been political manipulation of the toxic waste program, White House officials said today.

title: THREE VIEWS OF HOW AND WHY WALKER TURNED PRO
description: Vince Dooley was spending a routine day at the office when he received a telephone call from a reporter in Los Angeles inquiring about Herschel Walker last Thursday. The University of Georgia football coach listened as the caller asked whether there was any truth to the report that Walker was about to sign a contract with a United States Football League team. ''Nonsense,'' Dooley thought to himself, before dismissing the report as unfounded.

title: THE NEW BELGER HAS NEW CONFIDENCE
description: Don Paige saw his former Villanova teammate, Mark Belger, sporting a beard during the Wanamaker Millrose Games last month. That's Mark, doing what he wants, Paige observed.

title: TWO TIED WITH 65's IN THE DORAL OPEN
description: What with greens softened by recent rains and with no wind blowing, the Blue Monster Course of the Doral Country Club was more like a pushover today for the first round of the Doral-Eastern Open. In a field of 143 players, 69 broke the par of 72 and 17 others scored 72's. If these conditions continue, par will not be good enough to make the 36-hole cut.

title: SPAIN'S STUNNING TAKEOVER
description: In a stunning move, the Socialist Government today formally took over Rumasa, Spain's largest private financial enterprise.

title: Money Fund Lays Off 75
description: The Capital Preservation Fund, a money market mutual fund, said today that it laid off 75 employees in the past 10 days because of a drop in assets.

title: City Drops Plan For S.I. Coal Port
description: A proposal to have coal shipped by rail to western Staten Island, then moved in the form of slurry eight miles through a pipeline to a deep-water port on the island's eastern shore was abandoned yesterday by the Koch administration.

title: THE TRUCKERS' STRIKE THAT CONGRESS ASKED FOR
description: To the Editor:

title: Funny Money and the Poor
description: Case study in social engineering: How should Government help poor people get enough to eat?

title: Safety Officers End Columbus Job Action
description: The city agreed tonight to raise salaries for 2,000 police officers and firefighters, and officials in both departments said employees were returning to their jobs after two days of the ''blue flu.''

title: NO. 1 LAS VEGAS LOSES FIRST
description: Top-ranked Nevada-Las Vegas suffered its first loss of the season tonight as Leon Wood scored 21 points to lead Fullerton State to an 86-78 victory.

title: Ouster Asked for Author Of Birth Control Rule
description: A women's consumer group mounted a petition drive today calling for dismissal of the author of the proposal that would require parental notification when teen-age girls received contraceptives from federally financed clinics.

title: MUMPHREY RESENTS REMARKS
description: ''I can't figure out why they pick me,'' Jerry Mumphrey asked today. ''I think it's a lot of unnecessary pressure they're putting on me going into the season.''

title: Generals' Opener on TV
description: Herschel Walker's first appearance as a pro football player will be televised into the New York metropolitan area, ABC-TV announced yesterday.

title: SHULTZ SEEKS SUPPORT FOR FOREIGN AID BILL, ARGUING COST IS LOW
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz opened a public campaign today to win support for billions in foreign aid in the face of what he has been told is widespread opposition because of economic trouble at home.

description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,619,000 and a gain of $8,793,000 on the sale of discontinued operations

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Golden State Warriors, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, East Rutherford, N.J., 7:35 P.M. This is Golden State's only appearance in New Jersey this season. (Television - SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WVNJ AM, 620; 7:30 P.M.) Knicks vs. Indiana Pacers, at Indianapolis. Although they have beaten the Pacers only once in three games this season, the Knicks are on the upswing with 12 victories in their last 15 games and have moved out of last place in the Atlantic Division for the first time since Feb.3, 1982. (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M.).

title: WILSON FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
Two Die in Coast Bus Crash
description: A home-bound school bus and a dump truck collided near here today, killing the truck driver and one student and injuring 37 others. Officials speculated that the truck's brakes had failed.

title: Odeon Pope Trio
description: The saxophonist Odean Pope, who has previously appeared in the Max Roach Quartet, will lead his own trio tomorrow night at Soundscape, 500 West 52d Street (581-7032). The first set begins at 9. Admission is $7.

title: BRUNSWICK MINING & SMELTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Army-Navy Switch
description: J.O. Coppedge, the athletic director at the United States Naval Academy, has confirmed that negotiations are in progress which would result in the Army-Navy football game being played next fall at the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif. He made the statement as a supplement to a remark by Caspar Weinberger, the Secretary of Defense, at a press conference in Washington yesterday in which Mr. Weinberger referred to the site of the traditional service game being changed for this year.

title: IN JERSEY, A VOICE FOR WOMEN
description: A public advocate in government service is often caught between the pressures of politics and the call of conscience. Soon, Assemblywoman Joan R. Wright of New Jersey is likely to learn this lesson.

title: VORTEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: ART: ABSTRACT SCULPTURE BY VON SCHLEGELL AT PACE
description: SINCE he first abandoned painting for sculpture in the early 1960's, David von Schlegell has been a maker of highly assertive abstract forms in both wood and metal, ranging in inspiration from nature to machines, in scale from humble to very grand. If his work has not been remarkable for its innovation -like many of his contemporaries, he plainly owes a lot to David Smith and Alexander Calder - Mr. von Schlegell is still one of the most accomplished sculptors around, producing art of lyrical imagination, strong presence and superb craftsmanship.

title: MDC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1981 yr net is after $1.1 million gain from land sale

title: 'New Phase' for Walker
description: Herschel Walker, in an appearance today that lasted less than a minute, pronounced himself ''ready to step into another phase of my life.''

title: One E.P.A. Buy-Out Is Not a Policy
description: The Environmental Protection Agency deserves credit for moving to end the misery of Times Beach, Mo. It has promised the inhabitants of the dioxin-plagued, flood-struck hamlet that it will buy their now worthless homes. But relief for Times Beach does not mean the E.P.A. has made any general vow to be more assertive about public health.

title: GOLDFIELD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $215,375 for the qr and $839,935 for the yr...C-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $970,266 for the qr and $3,401,013 for the yr and a nonrecurring petax gain of $1,891,000 for the qr and yr from the sale of mining property

title: Ferraro Mends Quickly
description: It was only two weeks ago that Mike Ferraro, the first-year manager of the Cleveland Indians, underwent surgery for removal of a cancerous kidney, but the 38-year-old former Yankee coach is already at work at the Indians' training camp in Tucson, Ariz., and looking forward to full recovery.

title: Pipeline Spurns Amoco Unit's Gas
description: The Northwest Central Pipeline Corporation, a unit of the Northwest Energy Corporation, said that it would refuse to accept natural gas deliveries from 150 Wyoming wells operated by the Amoco Production Company because the gas contained more carbon dioxide than specified in its contract with Amoco Production, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana).

title: Bridge: Deal in London Long Ago Could Only Bring Disaster
description: If a player picks up a hand with three void suits he should suspect that the dealing was not according to Hoyle: Most probably, somebody is having a little joke. Even hands with two void suits are very rare, and if all four players are in the same condition we are right on the border of credibility.

title: JERSEY PASSES BILL RAISING CASINO GAMBLING AGE TO 21 FROM 18
description: The New Jersey Senate gave final passage today to a bill that raises the legal age for gambling in Atlantic City's casinos from 18 to 21.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE LITTLE DRUMMER GIRL. By John le Carre. 430 pages. Knopf. $15.95

title: E.P.A. WILL CLEAN UP THE WAUKEGAN HARBOR
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it was going ahead with plans for a multimillion-dollar cleanup of the PCB-polluted Waukegan harbor.

title: Tennessee Pickets Routed
description: The police used tear gas Wednesday to disperse about 400 striking production workers attempting to block an access road at a kitchen appliance plant. Two people were arrested and the windshields of about 10 cars were shattered in the latest violence in the monthlong strike at Magic Chef Inc.

title: Comings and Goings
description: In a minor league deal, the Mets sent Steve Ratzer to the Chicago White Sox for a player to be named. Ratzer, a 29-year-old righthander from St. John's University, was traded to the Mets from the Montreal Expos in 1981 for Frank Taveras.

title: CORPORATE FOODS LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
WEST CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1981 shr earnings were adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in May 1982

title: PAVELICH FINDS WAY TO 5 GOALS
description: When Mark Pavelich scored five goals in the Rangers' 11-3 embarrassment of the Hartford Whalers Wednesday night, it was like a science-fair display of the inventive ways Pavelich has discovered to make the most of his size. He certainly isn't the first player to overcome the handicap of being a small man among the bigger bodies favored by the National Hockey League in the past decade, but Pavelich has done something more: He has turned smallness into an advantage.

title: OPERA: BELLINI'S 'CAPULETI' AT JUILLIARD
description: ''I CAPULETI E I MONTECCHI'' is an opera of definite dramatic appeal that sings from beginning to end and yet somehow does not seem able to keep its hold on the affections of the public. A work of Bellini's maturity that was immediately successful at its premiere in 1830, it can be rewarding for connoisseurs of his bel canto style even while exciting the uninitiated listener. It is therefore regularly revived and regularly cheered. It also is regularly forgotten.

title: Antiquarian Book Fair
description: Art books, first and limited editions, children's books, books on English life, gardening and landscape architecture, and vintage valentines will be for sale this weekend at the fourth Greenwich Village Antiquarian Book Fair at Public School 3, 490 Hudson Street.

title: CUOMO DISCLOSES DETAILS OF BOND PLAN FOR TRANSIT
description: Governor Cuomo today announced the details of a $1.25 billion bond program to rehabilitate the state's roads and bridges and New York City's mass-transit system.

title: Jones & Laughlin To Reopen Plant
description: The Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation said today that it planned to reopen, in April, the former Crucible specialty steel plant, once Midland's largest employer, with an initial work force of 250 people.

title: ECKERD, JACK, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
Renaissance Lenders in Pact
description: Owners of Phase I of the Renaissance Center have tentatively agreed to share ownership with its mortgage holders, officials said today.

title: U.S. IS NONCOMMITTAL ON BRAZIL LOAN REQUEST
description: Brazilian officials asked the United States for additional credits of up to $400 million yesterday but were unable to win a commitment. The Secretary of the Treasury, Donald T. Regan, said no decision would be made until the Brazilians met with commercial banks in New York today, according to a spokesman.

title: DEVILS WIN ON LATE SURGE TO END SLUMP
description: Unlike some recent games, in which the Devils collapsed in the last period, tonight they scored three times in the third period and defeated the Detroit Red Wings, 4-1, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: HOLLY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
STANDARD MOTOR PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
U.S. JUDGE ORDERS GUARD AT DEATH CAMP DEPORTED
description: After six years of legal battles, a 75-year-old retired factory worker has been ordered deported for serving as a guard in a Nazi death camp where up to 800,000 prisoners were put to death during World War II.

title: New York Jail Plan Offered on Indian Leader
description: Governor Cuomo offered today to let the fugitive Indian leader Dennis Banks serve his time in a New York State prison, subject to approval by Gov. William J. Janklow of South Dakota and the courts.

title: URS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $369,000 for the latest first qr and $422,000 for the yr-ago first qr; shr earnings have been restated for a5 percent stock divd distributed earlier this month

title: BOEING SAYS U.S. BLOCKS LIBYA SALE
description: The Boeing Company said yesterday that the United States Government had turned down its request to sell Libya $600 million of commercial jet airliners. Russell G. Schley, a spokesman for the Seattle-based company, said Boeing had received notice earlier this week from the Commerce Department that the request had been denied.

title: PRATT & LAMBERT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Market Place; Analysts' View of Lilco
description: ON Wednesday morning, when the common stock of the Long Island Lighting Company was selling at 15 7/8, Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company recommended the stock on its all-office wire. The stock closed the day at 16 3/8, up 1/2, in heavy volume.

title: NICKNAMES: FROM 'TIP' to 'H'AARD HENRY'
description: Ronald Reagan is a man of many other names: The Gipper. Dutch. The Great Communicator. The Oldest and Wisest. The Defender.

title: MARRIAGE CONTRACTS UNSUITED FOR CIVIL COURTS
description: To the Editor:

title: A WRITER BREAKING INTO SONG
description: ''There's nothing more gripping than seeing a performer alone on stage. He's exposed. The entire soul is revealed, particularly in the case of someone who's spent his life hiding behind frogs, toads, grasshoppers and owls.'' The speaker is Arnold Lobel, creator of the two good friends Frog and Toad and a host of other beloved children's-book characters. Tonight, however, he'll sing, in an act with John Wallowitch, the composer and pianist, at the West Bank Cabaret.

title: MRS. KIRKPATRICK BREAKS A DATE
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief United States delegate to the United Nations, has withdrawn as the speaker at the spring commencement exercises at Smith College after being told that her security could not be assured during possible protest demonstrations.

title: GENESEE BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Sales figures exclude excise taxes

title: Workers in Jersey Back Ford Pact
description: Local union members have approved an agreement that, if signed by union leaders, will preserve hundreds of jobs at the Ford Motor Company plant here. But the cost-savings measures will have a price - 206 of the workers will join 1,600 other employees who, according to the United Automobile Workers, have already been laid off at the factory.

title: President Moves Up At Disney Productions
description: Ronald W. Miller, president and chief operating officer of Walt Disney Productions, was elected chief executive yesterday as E. Cardon Walker stepped down.

JORDANIAN SETS CONDITIONS ON MIDEAST
description: The Foreign Minister of Jordan said here today that Israel must first withdraw from Lebanon and agree to place no more Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank before negotiations for a comprehensive Middle Eastern settlement could be held.

NEW INDEX WILL LIST RELATIVE LEVEL OF DISCOMFORT
description: Government weather experts announced today that they had come up with a new index of discomfort, the weather stress index.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Calculating Our Daily Garbage

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1983
description: International President Reagan was rebuffed by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee over his nomination of Kenneth L. Adelman to be the nation's chief arms control official. But the panel refused to block the nomination entirely and sent it to the Senate floor with an unfavorable recommendation, setting the stage for a filibuster and for a debate over the wider issue of arms control. (Page A1, Column 4.) A drive on behalf of foreign aid was begun by Secretary of State George P. Shultz in the face of widespread opposition to Americans' helping other countries when there is economic trouble at home. Speaking in Atlanta, Mr. Shultz stressed that the billions of dollars sought for foreign aid were modest in comparision with other current expenses. (A1:6.)

title: A TOUGH ROAD TO THE WITNESS CHAIR
description: For several weeks a bipartisan group of Senators has been clamoring to hear testimony about rising weapons costs from a mid-level Pentagon civil servant, Franklin C. (Chuck) Spinney.

title: BRIEFS
description: * General Electric Co. said it had received $117.2 million in Navy and Air Force contracts for F-18 fighter engine production and for engine improvement work on the C-5 transport.

title: WINNERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings do not reflect the declared 4-for-3 stock split payable to shrhldrs of record Feb 15, 1983

title: MICHIGAN STUNS INDIANA, 69-56
description: Tim McCormick scored 18 points, including 9 during a decisive late spurt, to lead Michigan to a 69-56 upset victory over Indiana tonight.

title: Economic Scene; A Call in Bonn For U.S. Action
description: HELMUT SCHMIDT, the former German Chancellor, is calling for concerted Western action to head off a world depression, and urging Washington to provide the leadership.

title: POP JAZZ
description: FOR almost 30 years, Art Blakey, the drummer, whose strong, steady beat and massive press rolls can turn any ensemble into a juggernaut, has been conducting a fluid, floating school of jazz called the Jazz Messengers. The Messengers, which is usually a quintet or a sextet, has gone through a steady turnover of personnel for three decades, turning out a constant stream of new leaders of jazz groups, while maintaining a basic, readily identifiable style.

title: PHILHARMONIC: TROJAHN PREMIERE
description: EVERY intelligent composer engages in a continual wrestling match with tradition and in one sense cannot possibly win. Tradition, after all, is a heavyweight opponent with few defeats on its record. However, the composer, if talented enough to know what the struggle means and how to wage it, can avoid being totally crushed. The only works worth listening to reflect in some way this evasive action.

title: A CONSUMPTION TAX?
description: Keep your hand on your wallet. The Reagan Administration is talking about converting the income tax into a consumption tax.

title: JAZZ AND DANCE MAKE BEAUTIFUL MUSIC TOGETHER
description: FIFTY years ago, a program of jazz and dance wouldn't have raised an eyebrow. The two were inseparable - one reason the big bands kept on swinging was that nothing else made people happy on the dance floor. The increasing rhythmic freedom of be-bop and later developments turned jazz into concert music, but most jazz retains the steady pulse and subtle syncopation that sets heads bobbing and toes tapping. Even at its freest and most cerebral, jazz has held on to its physicality.

title: SIGMA-ALDRICH CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $628,000

title: FOR A COURSE CHANGE ON ARMS AND THEIR CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: SYLVAN COLE
description: Sylvan Cole, co-founder and retired chairman of National Shirt Shops, a nationwide chain of men's apparel stores, died Wednesday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 93 years old.

title: BRIEFING
description: Covering All Bases

title: TECO ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a gain from an accounting change of $4,953,000

title: GREATWEST HOSPITALS INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-The company said yr-ago results are not available due to restatement

title: DEFECTORS JOINING CITY BALLET
description: Valentina and Leonid Kozlov, the former Bolshoi Ballet dancers who defected to the United States in September 1979, have joined the New York City Ballet as principal dancers. An announcement is expected from City Ballet shortly, but a company spokesman confirmed that the Kozlovs were scheduled to perform in the City Ballet's spring season at the New York State Theater.

title: SYNAGOGUE COUNCIL ENDORSES NUCLEAR FREEZE
description: The Synagogue Council of America, representing six major organizations of Conservative, Orthodox and Reform Jews, has asked that the United States declare itself ''morally bound'' to work toward eliminating the threat of nuclear war. The council has urged President Reagan and the Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov, to seek a ''total cessation of the production and deployment of nuclear weapons.''

title: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1983; Markets
description: Stock prices surged to a new high, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing above the 1,100 level for the first time. Analysts cited continuing signs that the recession is ending and expectations that interest rates will continue to decline. The Dow gained 24.87 points, closing at 1,121.81. The two other major indicators, the Big Board's composite index and Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, also set new highs. Advances outnumbered declines by almost 3 to 1. Turnover soared to 113.2 million shares, from 84.1 million Wednesday. (Page A1.)

title: JAPANESE IN WEST VOICE GRIM PLEASURE
description: Japanese-Americans across the West seemed grimly pleased today that the Commission on Wartime Relocation and Internment of Civilians had found that ''a long and ugly history of racism'' led to their internment in World War II.

title: Agreement Is Reached On Steel Plant Wastes
description: The Reagan Administration, environmentalists and the steel industry agreed today on new regulations designed to reduce by 53,000 tons a year the toxic wastes that steel and iron plants pour into rivers and streams.

title: TOXIC WASTES TERMED AREA OF MOB PROFIT
description: Experts on organized crime told a panel of senators today that underworld operators engaged in the illegal disposal of toxic industrial waste were ''flourishing'' financially from virtually unchecked dumping and disposal violations.

title: Godfrey S. Rockefeller, Dies; Executive in Textiles Was 83
description: Godfrey S. Rockefeller, chairman of the Cranston Print Works, a Rockefeller-owned textile company, died of leukemia Wednesday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. The 83-year-old executive, whose grandfather, William Rockefeller, was a brother of John D. Rockefeller, was a resident of Greenwich.

title: MARINE LIAISON RULES IN BEIRUT BACKED
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that no orders had been issued to forbid United States marines in Lebanon from having direct liaison with Israeli military forces, as asserted by Israeli leaders.

title: News Analysis
description: Although the violence that surged through Assam and the tension that still grips the troubled northeastern state have genuinely and profoundly shaken much of India, there has been no rush to judgment, no calls for inquiries and few demands for the Government of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi to resign.

title: PANEL ASKS SENATE TO BACK ADELMAN FOR TOP ARMS POST
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee refused today to endorse President Reagan's nomination of Kenneth L. Adelman as the chief arms control official.

title: SHETLANDS TO PROTECT KNITTING TRADITIONS
description: The people of the Shetland Islands, a group of more than 100 windswept islets 100 miles off the northeastern tip of Scotland, are looking to their past to help them survive when their present runs out. The present, the exploitation of North Sea oil and the building of an oil-processing terminal on one of the islands, has brought the Shetlanders great prosperity in recent years and low unemployment compared with the rest of Britain.

title: GEORGE MCNEIL AT 75: ART ON THE WILD SIDE
description: GEORGE McNEIL was 75 years old this week, but you would never know it from his recent paintings, which can be seen at the Gruenebaum Gallery, 38 East 57th Street, through March 5. These are in every sense wild paintings - wild in color, wild in the power of the paint, wild in the acrobatics that he imposes upon the human body and wild in the high humor of his observation of everyday life.

title: ALUMAX INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: Alumax Inc is 50 percent owned by AMAX Inc, 45 percent owned by Mitsui & co and5 percent owned by Nippon Steel Corp

title: WALLACE, SAM P, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Move for Cadillac
description: The General Motors Corporation will move some car production from a Cadillac Motor Car division assembly plant in Detroit this summer, idling 1,200 workers, the auto maker said.

title: Green With Envy
description: While the Giants' Lawrence Taylor was enjoying his latest bonus, a $5,000 award as pro football's defensive player of the year, presented by Seagrams Seven Crowns of Sports, the team's new head coach, Bill Parcells, was laughing yesterday as he recalled how he got under the skin of his great linebacker.

title: Junior Achievements
description: Joe Frazier Jr. made his professional boxing debut last night by stopping Tony Glasco at 2:19 of the first round in a scheduled fourrounder.

title: NOT BY EUBIE BLAKE
description: To the Editor:

title: MOSCOW ON GENEVA
description: Is progress possible in the Geneva talks on medium-range weapons, or will the Iron Curtain of the ''zero option'' put an end to all hopes for a lasting peace and detente in Europe?

title: CITY ACCEPTS BID ON PART OF 3D WATER TUNNEL
description: New York City yesterday designated four companies as the winning bidders for final excavation work on a portion of the city's third water tunnel.

title: Bechtel Revenue Gains
description: The Bechtel Group Inc. reported a 20 percent increase in revenue despite a 46 percent decline in contracts. In a 19-page report, Stephen D. Bechtel Jr., chairman, reported that the private engineering and construction company's job awards fell from $10.6 billion in 1981 to $5.7 billion last year - the lowest level in three years.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Credit Suisse, the Swiss bank, is issuing $100 million of notes due in 1990, through Credit Suisse-First Boston; the notes are priced at par, bearing 10.5 percent.

title: New York Bond Issue Expands With Demand
description: Strong investor demand for New York City's bonds enabled underwriters to increase the size of the issue to $201.7 million from $150 million and to reduce yields offered on bonds with the longest and shortest maturities.

title: VOLCKER SAYS TAX RISE IS LIKELY TO BE NEEDED
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told the Senate Budget Committee today that, although it would be better if the Federal budget deficit were reduced by deep spending cuts, it would probably be necessary for Congress to raise taxes.

title: Coal-Hauling Rate Proposal
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission today proposed rules to limit railroad rates for hauling coal.

title: News Analysis
description: Saudi Arabia and its allies along the Persian Gulf have served an ultimatum on the rest of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries: Either accept their notion of where oil prices should come to rest and agree to a strict system of dividing world markets, or prepare for an all-out price war. In the view of oil experts here, this ultimatum, delivered after two days of talks among oil ministers in the Saudi Arabian capital of Riyadh, marks the beginning of the latest Saudi effort to reunite a divided OPEC under its own control. If Saudi Arabia succeeds, the accomplishment will have far-reaching political and economic implications.

title: BASEBALL
description: BALTIMORE (AL) - Announced John Lowenstein, outfielder, signed a three- year contract.

title: CALLAHAN MINING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $3,782,000 or 41 cents a shr on the sale of investment

title: DATUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TV: LIVE FILMING OF A HEART OPERATION
description: TELEVISION has explored something new, or if not entirely new, then certainly something on a new frontier. It was a heart operation, live from a hospital in Phoenix, seen over some public television stations at the same time it was happening. Channel 13 in New York, meanwhile, delayed the transmission, starting its videotape at 11:30 P.M. Wednesday, which was approximately when the operation was ending in Phoenix. The broadcast concluded early yesterday morning, with the patient alive but inert in an intensive care unit.

title: RELICS OF LITERARY LIVES ON VIEW AT GROLIER CLUB
description: ''Oddities and quiddities'' is the phrase of the bibliophile Arthur A. Houghton Jr. for the melange of literary memorabilia that has just gone on display at the Grolier Club.

title: British Trade Gap
description: Britain's merchandise trade showed a deficit of 491 million, or about $750 million, in January on a seasonally adjusted basis, compared with a revised surplus of 508 million, about $776 million, in December, the Department of Trade said today.

title: Soviet's Wheat Needs
description: The International Wheat Council today lowered its estimates of the Soviet Union's grain requirements in the 1982-83 crop year ending June 30, by one million metric tons, to 35 million. But it said that the Russians were poised to increase their wheat purchases by one million metric tons, to a record 19 million tons.

title: 'STREET MUSIC,' LIFE IN THE TENDERLOIN
description: ''STREET MUSIC'' is a comparatively elaborate first feature by Jenny Bowen, a San Francisco-based independent film maker, about some all-too-colorful characters in San Francisco's ''tenderloin'' district.

title: HEATING OIL PRICE RALLY SOFTENS WEEK'S DECLINE
description: Heating oil futures rebounded sharply yesterday on the belief that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would be able to stabilize its export prices at current levels. But many preciousmetals traders continued to sell silver and gold in the expectation that oil prices would decline further and thus delay the resurgence of inflation they believe is coming.

title: BUSINESS GROUPS JOIN FIGHT ON LOBBYING RULES
description: A broad assortment of business and nonprofit groups are speaking out against proposed Reagan Administration regulations they contend are designed to keep them from speaking out in the future.

title: INTER-REGIONAL FINANCIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: AN OLD SETTLEMENT HOUSE ATTRACTS LONELY YOUNG
description: When Tina Badolato moved to New York from Boston two years ago to pursue a theatrical career, she rented a studio apartment on the Upper East Side, got what she describes as ''tiny parts in minor movies,'' and faced a classic quandary: how to meet people in a city where she knew no one at all.

KOCH PICKS U.D.C. OFFICIAL TO HEAD BUILDINGS AGENCY
description: Robert Esnard, a vice president of the State Urban Development Corporation, was named Commissioner of the city's Buildings Department by Mayor Koch yesterday.

title: KOCH IS OFFERED COPTER TO BEIRUT ON MIDEAST TRIP
description: Hours before leaving for Israel, Mayor Koch said yesterday that he had been invited to fly to Beirut on an American ambassador's helicopter.

HOMAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KOCH TESTIFIES PENSION SEX-BIAS BILL WOULD COST CITY BILLION
description: Mayor Koch said today that legislation before Congress to outlaw sex discrimination in insurance and pension plans would cost New York City a billion dollars over 16 years.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES

THE VICE PRESIDENT: NO COMMENT ON THE FUTURE
description: The silence bordered on the monastic as Vice President Bush pondered the future. ''I'm not saying anything about that,'' he finally said, renewing his vow of abstinence from personal politics with a hair-shirt fervor that might delight President Reagan.

title: JACOBSON STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
WIND POWER: MORE THAN A DROP IN THE BUCKET
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; New Client, New Faces At D'Arcy
description: SINCE he had some positive news, Harold Bay, the 45-year-old president and chief executive of D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius, the multinational agency, announced it himself.

title: Judge Dismisses Puerto Rican Suit
description: A defamation suit that charged a Reagan Administration official with maligning New York City's 900,000 Puerto Ricans last year when he said in a speech that they were ''all on food stamps'' was dismissed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday.

title: Key Rates
description: *Maximum rateSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: THEATER: SIMON GRAY'S 'QUARTERMAINE'S TERMS'
description: AT one point in Simon Gray's ''Quartermaine's Terms,'' a woman passes up an invitation to see ''The Cherry Orchard,'' explaining that she's never found the comedy within all the ''doom and gloom'' of Chekhov's play. Chances are that this character wouldn't much like ''Quartermaine's Terms,'' either - but most every other theatergoer will. Mr. Gray, the British author of ''Butley'' and ''Otherwise Engaged,'' has written a play that is at once full of doom and gloom and bristling with wry, even uproarious comedy. The mixture is so artfully balanced that we really don't know where the laughter ends and the tears begin: the playwright is in full possession of that Chekhovian territory where the tragedies and absurdities of life become one and the same.

title: Right Is Wronged
description: It was bad enough being beaten at the buzzer in an overtime game. But when the Queens College basketball coach, Mike Eisenberg, learned on the morning after his team's 93-91 loss to Baruch in the City University tournament that he was indeed right in his protest of a referees' call, it made it even worse. No protests, no matter how legitimate, are allowed by the Eastern College Athletic Conference, whose rules govern the City University tournament.

title: A MYSTERIOUS ILLNESS HITS UPSTATE SCHOOL
description: It started back in October, when a handful of students at the Van Wyck Junior High School began complaining about eye irritations and a metallic taste in their mouths.

title: SUBARU OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
DOW INDUSTRIALS FINISH OVER 1,100
description: For the first time, the Dow Jones industrial average closed above the 1,100 mark yesterday. The stock market was buoyed by a growing confidence that the recession was ending and by expectations that interest rates would continue to decline.

title: BARBIE TO BE TRIED ON EIGHT CHARGES
description: Klaus Barbie, the Nazi fugitive, was told by French authorities today that he would be charged with eight specific counts involving ''crimes against humanity.'' But French officials said Mr. Barbie would not be tried for the killing of Jean Moulin, the French Resistance leader, or for the muders of other Resistance fighters.

title: STEVENS, J P, & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
Jury Finds 4 Guilty of Race Fix
description: Four men charged with tranquilizing harness race horses to help their betting chances were convicted today of criminal racketeering. A Federal jury of seven men and five women gave the verdict after nine hours of deliberation.

title: A Philadelphia Base for Cigna
description: The Cigna Corporation, which was formed last year with the merger of the INA Corporation of Philadelphia and the Connecticut General Corporation of Bloomfield, Conn., said that it would locate its headquarters in Philadelphia.

title: TWIN CITY BARGE & TOWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Kazan, away since 1964, is returning with his own play.
description: ELIA KAZAN, who has been busy as a novelist in recent years, is returning to the theater for the first time since 1964 to direct a new play - one that he has written himself. The play is called ''Cutting the Chain,'' and it will be produced by Cheryl Crawford, who was a co-founder with Mr. Kazan of the Actors Studio in 1947. Among their previous collaborations were Tennessee Williams's ''Camino Real'' and ''Sweet Bird of Youth,'' which Mr. Kazan directed and Miss Crawford produced.

title: CONDOMINIUM TOWN HOUSES FOR NASSAU
description: Two years ago Marvin Gerla and his brother Stanley were to be found in Great Neck, L.I., building a development of 80 condominiums on Ipswich Avenue, within walking distance of the railroad station. The building was called Cameo Plaza and apartments sold for $125,000 to $250,000.

title: CLOW CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $134,000 for the qr and yr from discontinued operations...C-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $5,011,000 for the qr and$5,468,000 for the yr

title: LABOR PARTY SUFFERS SEVERE DEFEAT, LOSING LONDON BASTION TO LIBERAL
description: Britain's Labor Party suffered one of its worst defeats since World War II on Thursday, losing a previously invulnerable parliamentary seat in a by-election that weakened Michael Foot's hold on the party leadership.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: DUPLEX PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
MARIANNA LEWIS, EDITOR, DEAD
description: Marianna Olmstead Lewis, assistant secretary and retired executive editor of the Foundation Center, a clearing house for information about foundation and corporate philanthropy, died of cancer Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 59 years old.

title: MISS SCHLAMME CELEBRATING SURVIVAL
description: ''BRECHT said, 'Change the world, it needs it.' I've always wanted to change the world in some way. I'm always battling the elements. I want to make a difference,'' Martha Schlamme said the other day. Indeed, the 55-year-old Viennese-born actress-singer and interpreter of Kurt Weill has developed a cabaret act of songs, poems and anecdotes that succeeds in inspiring as well as entertaining, with its wit, wisdom and musical taste.

title: Lord Arran, 72, Dies; Writer and Legislator
description: The Earl of Arran, an eccentric peer best known as a newspaper columnist, broadcaster and expert on badgers, died peacefully in his sleep Wednesday. He was 72 years old.

title: TWO RULES TO GUIDE SURROGATE MOTHERS
description: To the Editor:

title: PAMOUR PORCUPINE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Preferred Issues Flood the Market
description: While banking and utility companies continue to announce plans for new issues of adjustable-rate preferred stock, investment bankers say they are having a hard time distributing the flood of new issues.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Sign of Spring: To Market, to Market

title: Tax Fugitive Still Sought
description: Law-enforcement officials searched a home near Gackle today for Gordon Kahl, a 63-year-old tax protester who is wanted in the slaying of two United States marshals last week near Medina.

title: U.S. HAILS DECLINE IN OIL PRICES
description: The Reagan Administration today hailed the decline in world oil prices as a development that could speed economic growth, reduce debt pressures and act as a jobs bill in the United States by putting as many as 500,000 peoples back to work.

title: Friday; U.S. 'NEW WAVE' OLDIES
description: ''Shadows,'' the first film feature directed by the actor-director John Cassavetes, in 1959, had great impact on independent American film makers. Focusing on young people in the big city, it was shot in New York on a low budget - $15,000 - and was largely improvised. It will be shown tonight at 8 to start ''The American New Wave (1958-67),'' a retrospective at the Collective for Living Cinema, 52 White Street in TriBeCa, through Sunday, and then at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, next Tuesday through March 6. Also today: ''The Savage Eye'' (1959) by Ben Maddow, Sidney Meyers and Joseph Strick, about a young divorced woman's encounters with the seamier side of Los Angeles. Tickets: $4. Information: 925-2111. PHILHARMONIC FAMILIES

title: GENERAL BINDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Zapped

title: 3 CANADIAN FILMS CALLED 'PROPAGANDA' BY U.S.
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that three documentaries by the National Film Board of Canada -two on acid-rain pollution and an antinuclear war film nominated for an Academy Award - have been ruled ''political propaganda'' and must be labeled for showings in this country as the work of registered foreign agents.

title: North Korean Pilot Defects to the South
description: A North Korean pilot flying a fighter plane landed in South Korea today seeking asylum, the Defense Ministry announced.

title: MANVILLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $3.5 million for the qr and $9.9million for the yr...C-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $1.8 million for the qr and $3.1 million for the yr; the 1981 figures were restated

title: HOUSE PANEL VOTES FIXED PAYMENTS FOR MEDICARE
description: A House subcommittee today approved a proposal, supported by the Reagan Administration, that would fundamentally alter the way the Government pays hospitals for treating elderly patients under the Medicare program.

title: Funds' Assets Down Again
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds dropped $1.3 billion in the week ended Wednesday, to $191.1 billion, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. It was the 12th consecutive weekly decline, and followed the previous week's drop of $2.6 billion.

title: SALES DROP
description: The Manville Corporation yesterday reported a loss of $96.8 million for the fourth quarter, which it attributed to several extraordinary charges.

title: DANCE: A BOWERY REVUE
description: IT'S endearing that punk rockers, despite the batteries of acoustical equipment and the blunt-edged designer haircuts, are just kids at heart who like the idea of putting on a show together in the hallowed Judy-and-Mickey tradition. Such was the impression given by a revue presented on Tuesday at a loft theater on the Bowery, in the third week of the two-month Bowery Project festival of dance, music and performance events.

title: 2 Charged in Slayings Of 13 at Seattle Club
description: Prosecutors charged two young men today with aggravated first-degree murder in the slayings of 13 people at a Chinatown gambling club. The death penalty will be sought, the prosecutors said.

title: Agency Acquired
description: Bernard J. Miller Jr., chairman and president of Columbian Advertising, a Chicago sales promotion agency, has announced the acquisition of the Elliot J. Axelrod Association, a New York shop with the same specialty.

title: A CYNICAL, INEFFECTUAL JOBS BILL
description: With unemployment at 10.4 percent, President Reagan proposes a token jobs-creation bill. House Democrats, anxious not to lose a symbolic victory, rush to join him. Cynicism knows no bounds.

title: THREE VIEWS OF HOW AND WHY WALKER TURNED PRO
description: Through his lawyer, Herschel Walker expressed interest in the New Jersey Generals as early as mid-January, one month before signing the tentative contract that led to his being found ineligible as a collegian, according to a chronology offered today by officials of the team and the United States Football League.

title: NATIONAL PRESTO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
MOURNING FOR A LOST CAUSE
description: They can wear black and-red armbands all they want in Georgia as long as they make sure they know what they are mourning. The armbands are appropriate as long as the fans in Georgia know they are mourning merely the loss of one last exciting season from a superb football player, Herschel Walker.

title: NATIONS IN OPEC AND OUTSIDE SCURRY TO AVOID OIL PRICE WAR
description: Key representatives of oil-producing countries inside and outside OPEC met here today as the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries sought support to avert a threatened price war. The threat became acute last weekend when three major oil exporters cut prices below basic OPEC levels.

title: Of fantasy, responsibility and obsession.
description: FANTASY or obsession, which is somebody else's fantasy - is the subject of several new movies, and the other day Martin Scorsese, who directed ''King of Comedy'' (playing at the Coronet), and Paul Zimmerman, who wrote it, came to a press conference to talk about the fantasy of Rupert Pupkin.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Day for Singing 'The Unsung'

title: UNIVERSAL HEALTH SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ORGANIST: WILLIAM ALBRIGHT
description: WILLIAM ALBRIGHT ended his organ recital Monday night in the Park Avenue Christian Church - an event co-sponsored by the church's prestigious organ series and the New York City Chapter of the American Guild of Organists - with a Fats Waller arrangement of W.C. Handy's ''St. Louis Blues.''

title: Group to Buy Butcher Bank
description: James C. Berry, who succeeded Jake F. Butcher on Monday as chairman of United American Bank in Hamilton County here, said today that a Chattanooga investors group that he heads had agreed to buy the bank.

title: Jazz Forum Double Bill
description: The Jazz Forum, 648 Broadway, at Bleecker Street (477-2655), will present a double bill tonight and tomorrow night, with the flutist Lloyd McNeill and his sextet and the tenor saxophonist Andrew White and his quartet. Admission is $8, and the music begins at approximately 9:30.

title: FEDERAL REALTY INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Metzenbaum Criticizes Navy On Shipbuilders' Tax Breaks
description: The Navy is guaranteeing questionable tax breaks for shipbuilders through dummy ship-leasing corporations, Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum said today.

title: Second Russian Arrested In Spying Case in Italy
description: The Italian police arrested a Soviet citizen on spying charges today, the second in 10 days.

title: JERSEY UTILITY IS DENIED RATE RISE
description: The State Board of Public Utilities today rejected as untimely a $465 million rate increase request by Public Service Electric and Gas Company and authorized a $135 million reduction in energy adjustment costs for electricity.

title: MEDICAL GROUPS REBUT CHARGES BY ALBANY AIDE
description: Organizations representing most of New York State's physicians and hospitals yesterday criticized a statement by the State Health Commissioner that misconduct, impairment and incompetency were widespread among the state's 45,000 practicing physicians.

title: Deficit of $60 Million Foreseen in Hartford
description: The state deficit will surpass $60 million in this fiscal year and could thwart the Governor's plan to balance the budget by raising taxes in April, state officials estimated today.

LATIN AID BANK TO INCREASE CAPITAL
description: The 43-nation Inter-American Development Bank agreed today to increase its capital by $15 billion to channel more money into agriculture, water, hydroelectric and other long-term development projects in Latin America.

description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 40.

title: LABOR'S DEFEAT IN LONDON WEAKENS PARTY LEADER
description: Labor Party officials said today that the party's crushing defeat in Thursday's by-election in a London dock district had weakened Michael Foot's position as the party's leader.

title: Cardinals Almost Unchanged
description: For the first time since they won the World Series four months ago, the St. Louis Cardinals took the field today and opened spring training with essentially the same team that defeated the Milwaukee Brewers for the championship.

REAGAN CALLS REBUFF TO ADELMAN 'VERY IRRESPONSIBLE' AND 'INJURIOUS'
description: President Reagan, asserting the United States had been injured in the eyes of its allies, denounced the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today as ''very irresponsible'' in disapproving Kenneth L. Adelman as his nominee for arms control chief.

title: TWO MEN ARE ARRESTED IN SOHO RAPE AND ROBBERY
description: The police said last night that they had arrested two men in connection with a series of robberies in SoHo in the last two months in which one victim was raped and another was sexually abused.

title: SCHOOLS FOUND IN VIOLATION OF ORDER ON DISABLED PUPILS
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that New York City school officials had failed to comply with his three-year-old order to provide all handicapped students with special-education programs and services ''in a timely manner.''

title: ICAHN AND 2 OTHERS HOLD BIG STAKES IN G.& W.
description: Three multimillionaires have emerged as major investors in Gulf and Western Industries stock, Wall Street sources said yesterday. They were identified as Carl C. Icahn and Ivan Boesky, both of New York, and Carl Lindner of Cincinnati.

title: MRS. GANDHI REJECTS BLAME FOR KILLINGS
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi insisted today that she bore ''no direct responsibility'' for the massacres in Assam, though she conceded that India lacked the resources of richer countries to quell violent rampages or thoroughly prosecute wrongdoers.

title: HEATING OIL PRICES ARE CUT
description: Exxon USA and other major oil companies are cutting their home heating oil prices by as much as 4.75 cents a gallon to major distributors in the Northeast in moves analysts said would eventually be passed on to the consumer.

title: Barnes Suspended
description: In his four-year career with the National Basketball Association, Marvin Barnes, played with four teams: Detroit, Buffalo, Boston and San Diego. When he wore out his welcome in the N.B.A., Barnes shifted to the Continental Basketball Association, where he appeared in six games this season with the Detroit Spirits before undergoing a knee operation.

title: Red Sox Angered
description: Under the terms of their contracts, baseball players are expected to share a room with other players during spring training. If they'd rather live alone or with others, they are required to pay for the other half of their rooms, or about $125 a week in the case of the Holiday Inn in Winter Haven, Fla, where the Boston Red Sox stay.

title: Miller Brewing Plant
description: The Miller Brewing Company will complete a $410 million brewery here but will delay opening it, pending increased sales, William Howell, president of the brewer, said Thursday. He cited sluggish demand and added that Miller's production had been higher than anticipated at other sites.

title: TV Series Is Planned On the Smithsonian
description: The Smithsonian Institution and WETA-TV, the public-television station in Washington, has announced that the author David McCullough would be the host of a television series that will portray the Smithsonian's vast holdings.

title: BURNUP & SIMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Central Trust
description: The Central Trust Company of Toronto, which last month agreed to take over management of certain assets of the Crown Trust Company, which had been seized by the Ontario government, said it expected to make a small profit as a result of the transfer. Crown was one of three trust concerns seized by the government after an investigation into the financing and sale of 11,000 Toronto apartment units. Central said it would repurchase some Crown Trust mortgages as they mature, and that it would endeavor to renew deposit liabilities as they come due.

description: Extracts from equine arterial tissue may be used to control bleeding in humans.

title: A SPECIAL SELECTION AT GULFSTREAM PARK
description: The long, slow walks to the mutuel machines of Cargo The Groom were as much a rite of Florida racing as the annual flight of the flamingos at Hialeah. They were almost as rare and certainly more closely watched.

description: The Veterans Administration is threatened by a situation that could overwhelm its ability to provide medical care for the country's 28.5 million former military personnel.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Government regards with concern the massive and hitherto unprecedented manner in which the Soviet Union is interfering in the election and the internal politics of the Federal Republic of Germany.'' -Jurgen Sudhoff, a West German spokesman. (1:1.)

title: AUTO-TROL TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOUSE PANEL VOTES JOB BILL AND FUND TO HELP THE NEEDY
description: Congress took the first step today toward passing emergency job legislation. The House Appropriations Committee approved a $4.6 billion package aimed at creating jobs and providing humanitarian aid for unemployed workers.

title: Home Sales Rise Sharply
description: Sales of existing single-family homes jumped 15.5 percent in January from December, for the largest monthly rise on record, the National Association of Realtors said today.

title: Allen Miller Leads Doral by 1
description: Allen Miller, a tour struggler who improved his putting stroke with instruction from his wife, Cindy, also a professional golfer, took the lead by a stroke today in the second round of the Doral-Eastern Open.

Patents;
Classroom Computer Monitor
description: AN instrument for evaluating teachers and recording their classroom activities was patented this week. The device requires an observer in the classroom to punch a computer-connected keyboard to select and time various activities.

title: CANADIAN-FILMS RULING ASSAILED IN WASHINGTON
description: The Canadian Ambassador said today that he hoped the Justice Department would reconsider its rule that three Canadian films were ''political propaganda'' and must be labeled as such when shown in the United States.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Family of New York

title: Howatt Sent to Minors
description: The New Jersey Devils sent two of their experienced forwards, Garry Howatt and Yvon Vautour, to their Wichita farm team yesterday. Howatt had one goal and four assists in 36 games after being obtained from the Hartford Whalers early in the season.

PIANO: MISS ENGERER AT CARNEGIE HALL
description: When Brigitte Engerer, a French pianist who studied for seven years in Moscow, made her New York debut in 1979, her gifts were noted but it was felt she might sound better in a more spacious acoustical environment than that of Carnegie Recital Hall. Thursday night Miss Engerer returned to New York, performed in Carnegie Hall proper and more than justified the change of venue.

title: ROLLER DERBY TOUR TRIES A NEW IMAGE
description: Her name was on the rock-and-roll radio station when the telephone rang, and she just had to stop and listen to what they were saying about her. ''They're talking about me on the radio,'' said Darlene Langlois de la Chapelle, a member of the Los Angeles Thunderbirds of the International Roller League. ''Good stuff. I'll tell you in a minute.''

title: DANCE: CANADIAN PREMIERE FOR KUDELKA'S 'HEDDA'
description: James Kudelka is a young Canadian choreographer whose ballets are not nearly as well-known in the United States as they should be.

title: The E.P.A. Wasteland
description: To see what has gone wrong inside the Environmental Protection Agency, there is no need to peer through the acrid vapors that stream from its every window. The makings of the crisis were laid long ago with the people whom the President appointed -and the Senate confirmed - as the agency's top managers. The firing of Rita Lavelle and two other senior officials does not begin to reclaim the wasteland then created.

title: MARCHING TO ISRAEL
description: New York's leaders apparently feel that local affairs are going so well they can relax a bit and turn to the loftier calling of foreign diplomacy.

title: An Appreciation
description: It seems only too ironic that the last Tennessee Williams play to be seen on Broadway, ''Clothes for a Summer Hotel'' in 1980, was an attempt to exhume the ghost of F. Scott Fitzgerald. For what writer more than Mr. Williams exemplified Fitzgerald's notion that there are no second acts to American lives?

description: Questions appear on page 20. 1. The 21-month-old child, an American citizen, was reunited with relatives in the United States, four months after the murder of his parents and his subsequent disappearance in El Salvador.

description: DRAWING CARD

title: Miss Burnett, TV Director, Wed to Philip Voss Jr.
description: Whitney Ann Beekman Burnett, daughter of Hallie Burnett Zeisel of Raleigh, N.C., and the late Whit Burnett, was married yesterday to Philip Voss Jr., son of Marion Voss of Albany and the late Mr. Voss. Family Court Judge Shirley Wohl Kram performed the ceremony at the Metropolitan Club in New York.

title: NAMIBIA REBELS' MOVES SEEM TO SNAG SOUTH AFRICAN-ANGOLAN TALKS
description: The infiltration of an unusually large number of insurgents into South-West Africa appears for now to have sidetracked talks between South Africa and Angola on a preliminary cease-fire in the disputed territory.

title: Washington Post Company Venture
description: The Washington Post Company has agreed in principle to acquire about 50 percent of Sportschannel Associates, a New York-area sports programming network, from Cablevision Program Enterprises, it was announced.

title: STUDENTS AT TRINITY IMPRESS VISITING BRITISH HEADMASTER
description: Dr. John Rae - blue blazered, striped shirted, silver haired and headmaster of the Westminster School in London (founded 1560 by Queen Elizabeth I) - was talking the other day to parents, trustees and faculty of the Trinity School (founded 1709 by the British Society for the Propagation of the Gospel in Foreign Parts).

title: OIL-PRICE DECISION DELAYED BY MEXICO
description: Mexico delayed cutting its oil price today to give petroleum producing countries time to develop a strategy to prevent a price war.

title: South Korea Lifts Political Ban on 250
description: President Chun Doo Hwan today lifted a ban on political activity by 250 prominent South Koreans, but he kept the eight-year-old ban in force for 305 others, including two opposition leaders, Kim Dae Jung and Kim Young Sam.

title: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1983
description: International

title: Panhandle, Algeria Talks
description: The Panhandle Eastern Corporation of Houston has representatives in Algeria who are trying to renegotiate prices for the liquefied natural gas it is importing from Sonatrach, the Algerian gas company, a Panhandle spokesman said yesterday.

title: UNIONISTS ASK NO ENDORSEMENT UNITL AUGUST
description: The executive council of the A.F.L.- C.I.O. asked member unions today to withhold any individual endorsements of Presidential candidates at least until Aug. 1.

title: Israeli Refuses to Take Envoy Post in London
description: Eliahu Lankin, who fought against the British as a member of the Irgun underground organization, has refused to accept the post of Israeli Ambassador in London because of the outcry over the appointment.

title: PENTAGON AIDE TELLS SENATE PANELS OF POOR ESTIMATES ON ARMS COSTS
description: Two Senate committees, in an unusual joint hearing, listened today as a Pentagon analyst said that a failure to make better future estimates of weapon costs ''could destroy the fragile consensus'' for military spending.

title: Sabres Win, 7-6
description: Dave Andreychuk and Mal Davis of Buffalo scored third-period goals as the Sabres rallied for a 7-6 victory tonight over the Boston Bruins.

title: E.P.A. METHODS MAY FACE STUDY AT WHITE HOUSE
description: President Reagan is considering appointing David F. Linowes, a professor at the University of Illinois, to conduct a thorough study of the management problems at the troubled Environmental Protection Agency, a senior White House official disclosed today.

title: Indictment Upheld Against Actress
description: A Westchester County judge has refused to dismiss a misdemeanor weapons charge against the actress Jennifer O'Neill that was filed after she accidentally shot herself.
