title: A Small Fire At Cagney Home
description: A fire broke out today in the farm home of the actor James Cagney, but it was quickly doused and the 83-year-old star was unharmed, officials said.

title: Remembered Magic
description: No one who saw it ever forgot it: a woman with a broken mind taking the arm of the man who is to escort her to an asylum and saying with exquisite courtesy, ''Whoever you are - I have always depended on the kindness of strangers.''

title: FAMILIAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mrs. Cope Weds R.E. O'Sullivan
description: Penelope Bass Cope, daughter of Libby G. Bass of St. Louis and the late Morris Bass, was married yesterday to Robert Emmett O'Sullivan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Sullivan of Newark, Del. The Rev. Colleen M. O'Sullivan, the bridegroom's sister and a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Chapel of the Episcopal Cathedral Church of St. John in Wilmington, Del.

title: AIR MIDWEST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss; shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in 1982

title: GAZ METROPOLITAIN INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated due to a rate decision by Quebec Electricity & Gas board on Mar 12, 1982

title: Act on Shoreham, Cuomo Is Urged
description: County Executive Francis T. Purcell of Nassau said today he had urged Governor Cuomo to intervene in the dispute between Suffolk County and the Long Island Lighting Company over operation of the utility's nuclear power plant in Shoreham.

title: Martin Discusses the Lineup
description: As a member of the California Angels last season, Don Baylor noticed a distinct change in the Yankeelineup.

title: BAD TACK ON CUBA
description: We, as Americans, may travel freely to almost any country in the world - except to an island that lies just 90 miles off our coast. Under regulations promulgated last year by the United States Treasury Department, virtually all travel to Cuba from the United States is now forbidden. It is all too likely that the ban's impact on the Cuban economy will be slight in comparison to the harm that it causes to United States interests.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Catherine's Pistols: A Mystery No More

title: DENVER LAWYER'S ROLE IN E.P.A. DECISIONS IS FOCUS OF INQUIRIES BY CONGRESS
description: When Anne M. Gorsuch was appointed administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency in 1981, a Denver lawyer named James W. Sanderson looked like the logical choice to help her settle into the job.

title: Money Funds Rule Change
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today authorized money market funds to calculate and advertise their yields on a compound basis, putting them on a more equal footing with banks.

title: A Patch In Time
description: We went south to Virginia. There had been a death in the family, a death everyone was prepared for. She was the last of the generation born between 1881 and 1905, a child in the age of the horse and buggy, a vital young woman when the Charleston was the rage of the ballroom and, finally, a sole survivor crushed in spirit by the onset of blindness.

title: PIEDMONT NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
AUSTRALIA FEELS THE PINCH IN ITS 'HIP POCKET NERVE'
description: This seaside industrial city, in the lush Hunter River Valley where vineyards and vegetable farms intermingle with open-pit coal mines, seems on the surface to be typical of the bounteous life in Australia.

title: QUICKPRINT OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STANFORD OUSTS PH.D. CANDIDATE OVER HIS USE OF DATA ON CHINA
description: A graduate student nearly ready to take a Ph.D. has been dismissed from the doctoral program by the Stanford University anthropology faculty in a dispute over his use of information he collected at a village in China.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Feb. 13 on Edward M.M. Warburg's election as an honorary trustee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art cited his cultural affiliations incorrectly. He was a founder of the Museum of Modern Art and a trustee and organizer of its film library.

title: STILL WATERS IN SHULTZ'S SHAKEDOWN
description: In his appearance before the House Foreign Affairs Committee 10 days ago, Secretary of State George P. Shultz was told by Representative Gerry E. Studds that the main difference he saw between him and his predecessor, Alexander M. Haig Jr., was that there no longer were lines of people outside the room waiting to get inside.

title: U.S. Steel Move Draws Fire
description: The Pittsburgh-based United States Steel Corporation's decision to use foreign steel in a new Seattle skyscraper has angered West Coast steel fabricators.

title: CITY'S WORK CAMPS HOUSING FAR FEWER THAN ANTICIPATED
description: Six months after it started, Mayor Koch's work camp program for those who commit minor crimes is faltering. Last May, the Mayor said he hoped that up to 9,000 quality-of-life criminals - three-card monte players, small-time marijuana sellers, turnstile jumpers and the like - would be sent to the camps. Between last September, however, when the program began, and the end of January, only 338 such offenders served sentences in a work camp.

title: REPUBLIC AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from the sale of tax benefits of $17.8 million for the qr and yr and gains on the disposition of equipment of $47,000 for the qr and $2.6 million for the yr...C-Including income from the sale of tax benefits of $28.9 million for the qr and yr and gains on the disposition of equipment of $39.9 million for the qr and $13.4 million for the yr

title: Dailey's Apology
description: Quintin Dailey of the Chicago Bulls is sending a check and a letter of apology to Victoria Brick, the woman he assaulted in a University of San Francisco dormitory a year ago, according to Miss Brick's lawyer, Joseph O'Sullivan. When they are received, the lawyer said, his client will drop her suit against the basketball star, who pleaded guilty to assault after the incident in December 1981.

title: BRIEFING
description: Trade Commission Trauma

title: S. Dakota Governor Sues Newsweek for $10 Million
description: Gov. William J. Janklow of South Dakota filed a $10 million lawsuit Thursday against Newsweek magazine, contending it libeled him in an article that contained an accusation by the fugitive Indian activist Dennis Banks that Mr. Janklow had raped an Indian girl.

title: MERIDIAN, MISS., PLANNING TO BE A HIT
description: In 1864, four years after this eastern Mississippi city was chartered, Gen. William Tecumseh Sherman and 25,000 Union soldiers burned it to the ground. ''Meridian,'' Sherman is reported to have said, ''does not exist.'' That nebulous image still hounds the city.

title: UNIVERSAL-RUNDLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
Woman Appealing Guilty Verdict
description: A lawyer for Ilse Michelle Jacobs, who was convicted Thursday of attempting to murder her husband, said yesterday that he would appeal the verdict. Mrs. Jacobs is being held at the city's Correctional Institute for Women on Rikers Island until sentencing on March 21.

title: U.S. GIVES POLITICAL ASYLUM TO WHITE FOE OF APARTHEID
description: The Reagan Administration has granted political asylum to a white South African who opposes his country's system of racial separation and service in the military.

title: THE VOICE OF WILLIAMS
description: Two speeches of Blanche DuBois from ''A Streetcar Named Desire'':*

title: CALL FOR WESTWAY STUDY UPHELD BY APPEALS COURT
description: A decision that continues to block construction of the Westway project was issued yesterday by a Federal appeals court in Manhattan. The unanimous 86-page decision said that Federal agencies had violated environmental-protection laws by failing to make a proper study of the effect that a key landfill, planned as part of the project, would have on fish in the Hudson River, particularly striped bass.

title: LIFE INSURANCE FOR INVESTING
description: AMONG the many alternatives to traditional life insurance that have sprung up in recent years, variable life insurance is one of the least heralded.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: The rosy hindsight of old age met the limited vision of youth yesterday, and when it was over everyone saw things a bit differently. A gaggle of girls had encountered their first pair of buttoned kid gloves, a bunch of boys wrote with fountain pens and learned to like it, and 14 elderly people who have sometimes thought their time was past learned that, occasionally, there is no time like the present.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Aiming for Hard Covers

title: REAGAN'S NOMINEE BACKS COURT LIMIT
description: Margaret M. Heckler, President Reagan's nominee for Secretary of Health and Human Services, hinted today that she might tolerate Congressional efforts to strip the Supreme Court of its power to decide cases involving certain issues, such as abortion.

title: CROWN CORK & SEAL CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest periods reflect foreign currency translations losses of $17.1 million for the qr and $29.6 million fora the yr

title: Peking Criticizes Reagan For Remarks on Taiwan
description: China said today that comments President Reagan made about Taiwan marked a step backward in the American position on relations between their countries.

title: NATIONAL GAS & OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for a 7 percent stock divd in Dec 1982 and for a corporate reorganization

title: U.S. Appeals to South Africa
description: The United States has appealed to South Africa to commute death sentences imposed on six members of the outlawed African National Congress, Secretary of State George P. Shultz told the United Nations in a letter published today.

title: AREA COSTS ALSO UP 0.25%
description: Consumer prices in the New York-northestern New Jersey area rose two-tenths of 1 percent in January on a seasonally adjusted basis, continuing the favorable price trend of recent months.

title: LINCOLN WEST OPPONENTS SEEK RULING TO HALT PLAN
description: Opponents of the Lincoln West housing development planned for Manhattan's West Side told a judge yesterday that New York City had failed to analyze alternatives in its assessment of the project's environmental impact.

title: YARDNEY ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 30
description: The company is listed on the Boston Stock Exchange

title: WALKER HOME WITH SECURITY
description: A sign on Route 15 entering town proclaims, ''Welcome to Wrightsville, Home of Herschel Walker.'' Another red sign is posted at the main intersection congratulating Walker on winning the Heisman Trophy last year.

title: GAS WITHOUT WINDFALLS
description: To the Editor:

title: LEWIS CAPTURES 2 EVENTS
description: A rare double in the sprint and long jump by Carl Lewis, and worldindoor bests by Stephanie Hightower, Diane Dixon and Ray Sharp highlighted the USA/ Mobil indoor track and field championships last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: TV: MEMORIES OF SMALL TOWN IN GERMANY
description: ''Now ... After All These Years'' is an intelligent, sensitive and compelling television documentary about Rhina, a small town in Germany, from which the last Jew disappeared in 1939. In a way, it is one more film about the banality of evil, although to dismiss it as only that would be an injustice. It also resonates with thoughts about the future.

title: HISPANIC LAWYERS READY FOR ROBES
description: To the Editor:

BARNES ENGINEERING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $588,000 for the qr and $823,000 for the 6 mos

title: PRICE OF GAS FALL TO A 4-YEAR LOW AS SOME COSTS UNDER $1 A GALLON
description: Ninety-nine cent gasoline is back, for the first time in four years. Motorists in parts of the New York area - though not in New York City - and around the nation are buying regular leaded gasoline for less than $1 a gallon, and dealers say they expect prices to continue falling.

title: Elway's Options
description: Marvin Demoff is a Los Angeles lawyer who will represent John Elway in his negotiations with the Yankees and whatever National Football League team drafts him April 26. Demoff may try to persuade the Baltimore Colts, who have the first selection in the N.F.L. draft, to trade that choice to a team more preferred by Elway.

title: 'P' Film Ratings Rate an 'X'
description: Secretary Shultz sounded like Tom Paine as he pleaded with Congress for $85 million to promote freedom: ''Don't be nervous about democracy, about holding that torch up there.'' But that very day his colleagues at Justice shamed America's democracy by ruling that three Canadian documentaries be branded as propaganda before they could be shown in the land of the free.

title: INFORMATION ON DRUGS FOR PATIENT
description: PHYSICIANS and pharmacists fail to give nearly 80 percent of their patients any precautionary instructions on prescription drugs and hardly any consumer asks questions, according to a national survey done for the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Brock Rejects Steel Plea
description: The United States trade representative, Bill Brock, today rejected the domestic steel industry's request to investigate what the industry charges is a secret international marketing cartel formed by Japan and West Europe.

title: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 26, 1983; The Economy
description: Several major banks reduced their prime lending rates by half a point, to 10 1/2 percent, the lowest level since November 1978. The move, which followed intense pressure by the Administration for lower bank rates, was hailed by Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan. But the banks, citing a sharp drop in the cost of their funds, denied they were responding to ''jawboning.'' (Page 1.)

title: Offer to Riggins
description: The Michigan Panthers of the United States Football League reportedly have offered a three-year guaranteed contract to John Riggins, the Washington Redskins' running back.

title: Books of the Times; Industrializing War
description: THE PURSUIT OF POWER: Technology, Armed Force and Society Since A.D. 1000. By William H. McNeill. 405 pages. University of Chicago Press. $20.

title: MOTHERS DEFENDING RIGHTS OF CUSTODY
description: Some 500 divorced women in 30 states have formed an organization aimed at countering the swing in opinion away from mothers as the usual -and, normally, automatic - custodian of children.

title: ROBINTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REPORT ON INTERNMENT IS TOP NEWS IN JAPAN
description: The news media in Japan today prominently displayed the report by a Congressional commission that the internment of 120,000 Japanese-Americans in World War II was a ''grave injustice'' motivated by ''racial prejudice, war hysteria and failure of political leadership.''

title: U.S.-CANADIAN RELATIONS TAKE A TESTY NEW TURN
description: This week's falling out over three Canadian film documentaries was the latest in a series of incidents in recent months that have put the relationship between the United States and Canada to new tests.

title: European Trade Ruling
description: A special panel of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade has concluded that the European Economic Community's flour sales on 17 foreign markets were made at fair conditions and without any price undercutting, an official of the European Commission reported today. The United States Government had asked for the examination.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP SLIGHT 0.2%
description: Consumer prices rose a slight two-tenths of 1 percent in January, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today, indicating that last year's low level of inflation continues unabated.

title: BALDWIN & LYONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMERICAN WESTERN SECURITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PURIM MEANS HAMANTASCHEN
description: Although the prune-filled pastries known as hamantaschen are generally available throughout the year, they take on special significance tomorrow when Jews celebrate Purim. This springtime festival commemorates the deliverance of Jews from the despotic minister Haman, who had turned the King Ahasuerus against the Jews. The heroine of the story is Esther, the Jewish Queen, and the account of her bravery is read each year from the Scroll of Esther, or the story of Purim.

title: WELFARE VOUCHERS CAN SAVE PUBLIC FUNDS AND PRIVATE HOUSING
description: To the Editor:

title: Zimbabwe's Leader Says Foe Has Support of South Africa
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe today stepped up his attacks on the opposition leader Joshua Nkomo, accusing him of securing South African support to topple the Government.

title: SATELLITE TV ANTENNAS: NEW YORK CITY'S WORRY
description: To the Editor:

title: Dance Notation Award
description: Ben Sommers, head of the Capezio Foundation, which aids dance organizations, will receive the Dance Notation Bureau Service Award on March 23. He will be presented with the award by Agnes de Mille in a private ceremony in New York City.

title: LOUISIANA LAND, BELCO DROP MERGER
description: The Belco Petroleum Corporation and the Louisiana Land and Exploration Company announced individually yesterday that the two big oil companies had broken off merger talks. The two had confirmed earlier in the week that they were negotiating for Louisiana Land to buy Belco for about $28 a share, or some $700 million.

title: PAYCO AMERICAN CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
JOHN COWLES SR., MINNEAPOLIS NEWSPAPER PUBLISHER, IS DEAD AT 84
description: John Cowles Sr., who built a newspaper empire in Minneapolis and used it to fight for internationalism, education and religious tolerance, died at his home yesterday after a long illness. He was 84 years old.

title: TERADYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STATEN ISLAND, JOHN JAY IN FINAL
description: Staten Island rallied to defeat Lehman, 74-62, last night and reach the final of the City University tournament for the fourth time in five years.

title: Bridge: Bidding Contains Dangers Whatever the Situation Is
description: To what extent the old maxim ''Speech is silver, silence is golden'' applies at the bridge table is an interesting question. For the declaring side it is clearly true that the less speech, the better in reaching a given contract: Once the play begins, bidding clues to the declarer's hand are of value to the defenders.

title: Green All Round
description: Brad McAlester yesterday was claiming to be ''the losingest coach in Manhattan College's history.'' The 30-year-old part-time assistant coach certainly has the worst percentage -.000 - after the Jaspers were defeated Thursday night by Fordham, 74-65.

title: DOW DROPS 0.87 POINT, to 1,120.94
description: The stock market capped a historic week on an anticlimactic note yesterday, with prices largely unchanged from Thursday's highs. On Thursday, the Dow Jones industrial average closed above the 1,100 mark for the first time.

description: An all-Chopin recital by the pianist Alexis Weissenberg next Tuesday in Carnegie Hall has been canceled because of ''a severe and continuing influenza,'' according to a Carnegie Hall spokesman.

title: Holbein Works Coming To Morgan Library
description: ''Holbein and the Court of Henry VIII,'' a collection of 70 drawings and one painted miniature by Hans Holbein the Younger (1497/8-1543), that have never been displayed outside Europe, will be on view from April 21 to July 30 in the J. Pierpont Morgan Library, at 29 East 36th Street. The artwork, believed to be the greatest collection of portraits by Holbein, is from the collection of Queen Elizabeth II in the Royal Library at Windsor Castle.

title: THE FACTORS PUSHING PETROLEUM COSTS DOWN
description: The plunge in oil prices is grabbing headlines these days. But in fact a decline has been under way for some time. Tracing the economic and political developments that have shaped the oil market over the past few years shows how the stage was set for the price break.

description: Paul G. Drescher, retired executive vice president and treasurer of the Associated Hospital Service of New York, predecessor of Blue Cross-Blue Shield, died on Sunday at Brookhaven Memorial Hospital in Patchogue, L. I., after suffering a stroke. He was 79 years old and lived in Sayville.

title: CONCERT: THE YUVAL TRIO
description: Concerts Plus offered music and talk at the Abraham Goodman House Thursday night. The Yuval Trio -plus Sol Greitzer, viola, and Paul Sperry, tenor - played Dvorak's ''Dumky'' Trio, the Brahms G minor Piano Quartet and Irish, Welsh and Scottish folk-song settings by Beethoven; Susan Reed sang some of these same songs in their unadorned form, and Robert Sherman led the discussions.

title: Panel Named in Salvador To Broaden Election
description: The Provisional President of El Salvador appointed a three-member commission today to explore ways of bringing the moderate left into next year's presidential elections.

title: WEST GERMANS SAY SOVIET INTERFERES IN MARCH ELECTION
description: The Government of Chancellor Helmut Kohl accused the Soviet Union today of gross interference in next month's election.

title: RIO ALGOM LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Another Star Signs
description: The United States Football League showed it meant business when Herschel Walker signed a contract to play in the league, and there was more business being conducted yesterday involving big-name players.

title: Texas Bank in Shift
description: The First National Bank of Midland, a major lender to the energy industry, announced today that it had increased its provision for loan losses to $50 million, or 3.67 percent of its loans outstanding at the end of 1982, up from $11.2 million, or 1 percent of its total loans at the end of 1981.

title: Interest Rates Continue Lower; Money Down $1.5 Billion
description: Interest rates declined in all sectors of the credit markets yesterday as traders and speculators remained optimistic that lower inflation will combine with Federal Reserve monetary policy to bring down short- and long-term interest rates.

title: Dow Chemical Loses in Suit
description: The Dow Chemical Company must pay more than $26 million to a bank because of a mortar additive that caused deterioration in the bank's headquarters building, a Common Pleas Court jury has ruled.

title: Harris Steel Bid
description: The Harris Steel Group Inc. of Toronto announced that it intends to make a cash takeover bid for all the stock outstanding of G.& H. Steel Industries Ltd. at an expected price of about $5.75 a share, and that controlling shareholders in G.& H. had agreed to tender their shares. Harris said that David Hadden, chairman of G.& H., and Emil Weishaupt, president, who together control 71 percent of their company's stock, had both agreed to tender their shares under the offer. Harris added that the bid would be conditional on acceptance of at least 90 percent of the stock and the completion of satisfactory financial statements for the year ended Dec. 31, 1982.

title: MAJOR BANKS CUT KEY INTEREST RATE
description: Consumer prices rose a slight two-tenths of 1 percent in January, as inflation continued to abate. Page 29. By ROBERT A. BENNETT

title: BUFFALO WORKING TO HEAL AN ECONOMY HURT BY CHANGING TIMES AND TRENDS
description: Everyone in this predominantly blue-collar city on Lake Erie seems to know someone who is out of work. Here the economic statistics rapidly become names and faces - the husband or son who got laid off after 20 years in a factory, the neighbor who is fighting foreclosure proceedings, the parent who finds the heating bill is bigger than his Social Security check.

title: CANADA MALTING CO LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
MY SAWDUST MEMORIES
description: Back in those days, a nickel bought you all the sawdust you could eat, and the butcher said thank you when you bought it. The closest thing to a computer was the tiny abacus old Mr. Chang used in the back of that flooded basement Poppa rented to him, and we wanted nothing to do with it. We were all more innocent. I know my sister was, no matter what those unmarried headshrinkers on TV may think.

description: Bill Cartwright turned in a devastating offensive performance in the first half tonight and helped the Knicks to a 113-101 victory over the Indiana Pacers.

THE GOOD NEWS ON OIL PRICING
description: As the reality of an oil price cut draws nearer, businesses are beginning to count their prospective savings and to anticipate the lift that lower oil prices could provide the American economy.

title: Correction Officer Is Shot by Police
description: A City Correction Department officer was in stable condition yesterday after being shot when he pulled a gun on a city police officer, the police said.

title: BANKS SIGN BRAZIL PACTS FOR $8.4 BILLION IN CREDIT
description: Representatives of commercial banks around the world met at the Plaza Hotel yesterday to sign two agreements to help ease Brazil's credit problems. The bankers initialed a new $4.4 billion loan, as well as a refinancing package covering $4 billion of debt maturing this year.

(Television - Channel 2, 4:30 P.M.) Hockey Islanders vs.

title: Alexander Inc.
description: Alexander & Alexander Services Inc. said in a statement that there is no basis to market reports of a possible merger between it and the Sedgwick Group P.L.C. Sedgwick said it did not plan to bid for Alexander and Alexander.

title: HOSIERY: ADVENTUROUS CHOICES FOR SPRING
description: Hosiery has come into its own as a fashion accessory. Women are giving as much thought to the color of their legs as they do to a handbag or shoes. Manufacturers are off and running with colors and weaves that they had presented rather gingerly in the past, when they aimed at an avant-garde audience. Ladylike beiges are still to be had, of course, but the rainbow of colors is more tempting.

title: CPS CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Indiana Star Hurt
description: Ted Kitchel, Indiana University's leading scorer in basketball, will probably be out for the remainder of the season because of a back injury, a school spokesman said yesterday. Kitchel left the Michigan game Thursday and was hospitalized for the recurring injury, a school spokesman said yesterday.

title: Killer, Seeking Death, Forces Guard to Shoot
description: A condemned murderer was shot when he attacked a guard in court Thursday, and an associate of the man said later that he had been ''conducting his own execution.''

title: TENNESSEE WILLIAMS IS DEAD HERE AT 71
description: Tennessee Williams, whose innovative drama and sense of lyricism were a major force in the postwar American theater, died yesterday at the age of 71. He was found dead about 10:45 A.M. in his suite in the Hotel Elysee on East 54th Street.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Business People column on Feb. 16 incorrectly reported the residence of Arnold Bernhard's son and the son's connection with Ar- nold Bernhard & Company. He lives in Connecticut and has been a director since 1964.

title: THIS INTERRACIAL DRAMA IS RICH WITH RAW POWER
description: Whatever its problems - and they are distressingly real and numerous - public television can still pack a distinctive wallop. Right now, for instance, the system is in the midst of broadcasting Richard Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle, which, although packaged in a ridiculously drawn out schedule over many weeks, is provocative in concept and stunning in execution. And the ''American Playhouse'' series is concluding, this Tuesday evening at 9, a three-part dramatic presentation called ''The File on Jill Hatch,'' which represents an unusual effort on the part of television to deal, candidly and forcefully, with interracial relationships and racism. Both productions richly deserve to be seen. Neither would ever be likely to show up on the commercial networks or, for that matter, on the vast bulk of cable TV outlets.

title: LISTING ISSUES
description: It wasn't so long ago that the idea of disposable buildings seemed nearly as acceptable in America as disposable cigarette lighters. Today, however, the movement to preserve old structures and land has taken hold, and the Connecticut Trust for Historic Preservation believes it is time for a caucus of all the groups of preservationminded people across the Nutmeg State who have been working to save notable structures.

title: THINGS TO REVERE FROM 'FUNNY GIRL'
description: BEWARE: Nostalgia is getting nearer. Musicals of the 1920's and 1930's started -and exhausted - the trend. Last season, the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, Conn., dipped into the 1940's (''High Button Shoes'') and is doing so once more this year (''Miss Liberty''), but even that is somehow in the realm of the long ago and far away.

title: Anthony Cucolo Dies; Rockland Civic Leader
description: Anthony A. Cucolo Sr., an industrialist, philanthropist and civic leader in Suffern, N.Y., for a half century, died yesterday in Blake Memorial Hospital in Bradenton, Fla., after a long illness. He was 85 years old and had lived in Bradenton since 1971.

title: Q & A
description: Noneviction Rights

title: SURVIVING A NUCLEAR WAR IS HARDLY SURVIVING
description: When Charles Kupperman, adviser to the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, says, ''It is possible for any society to survive a nuclear war'' and ''Nuclear war is a destructive thing but still in large part a physics problem,'' what does he mean by ''survival''?

title: JOHN PAUL'S JOURNEY IS HIS HARDEST YET
description: On his 16 pastoral trips outside the Vatican, Pope John Paul II has faced adversity ranging from scorching desert heat to the shadow of political repression. But many church officials believe the Pontiff's plans to visit Central America starting Wednesday pose the most formidable obstacles he has yet confronted.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: THE remains of the Blizzard of '83 have disappeared quickly in the spring-like sunshine of the last several days, but although the snow may soon be gone, it won't be forgotten by ski-slope operators, the people who own car washes and the state's water companies.

title: Winners of Polk Award For Journalism Named
description: Long Island University has announced the winners of the 35th annual George Polk Awards in Journalism. Two correspondents of The New York Times, Thomas L. Friedman and David K. Shipler, shared the award for foreign reporting for their coverage of the Israeli invasion of Lebanon. And Richard Halloran of The Times won in the national reporting category for articles on Department of Defense planning for a possible nuclear war.

title: WHERE PENNY CANDY SHARE THE LIMELIGHT
description: It isn't the penny candy that brings most of the customers to the Country Store in Concord, Mass., but everyone agrees the place wouldn't be the same without it. In a part of the world where names like Emerson and Alcott are those of onetime neighbors and where the Minute Men were just local farmers, tradition is not a word to be used lightly. But somehow, although the store has been in existence only since 1938, its atmosphere is such as to make the word "tradition" seem appropriate. It's that kind of place, and penny candy is a Country Store tradition.

title: APPLAUSE FOR A CREDIT GUIDELINE
description: THE Federal Reserve's 1983 game plan reveals two important changes i n monetary policy making. First, along with its familiar monetary t argets, the Fed will use a new yardstick, the growth of total c redit, to gauge monetary policy. But second, the Fed will adhere l ess rigidly to any mechanical targets, for either money or credit.

title: Presbyterians Back Together
description: The Civil War created wounds in American society that are still healing, though by now pain exists only in collective memory. Last week, one old scar finally disappeared when major denominations of Presbyterians ratified a plan to unite after more than a century of schism.

title: New Orleans
description: To the Editor:

title: Sheriff Turns to Court To Stop Foreclosures
description: A sheriff who was jailed for three days for refusing to sign foreclosure deeds on homes has filed court action to try to stop the foreclosures of 13 homes.

title: Creativity Classes
description: To the Business Editor:

title: WHICH TAPE? AMID CHAOS, ORDER MAY BE EMERGING
description: In one of his frequent fits of melancholy, Max Weber, the great social theorist, defined history as a web of unintended consequences. This wry summary of events certainly applies to the history of cassette recording. Originally conceived as a mere dictating device by its Dutch inventors, cassettes were never intended for highquality music reproduction. It is ironic, therefore, that within the brief span of its young life, the cassette has grown into the primary music medium, outselling disks in most parts of the world.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Three former stars of the National Football League - Paul Hornung, Dick Butkus and Craig Morton - have joined ABC Radio Sports as commentators for games played by the United States Football League. ... Nathaniel Crosby was among 10 amateur golfers named to the United States team that will play in the 26th Walker Cup against a team from Britain and Ireland at Hoylake, England, May 25-26.

title: Ledgerdemain; A Babel of Steel
description: American Bridge has bought tons of Japanese and Korean steel to construct Columbia Center, a 76-story office tower in Seattle. There's nothing special about that - a lot of contractors use Asian steel because it is often cheaper than American.

title: BEHIND THE MICHALAK OUSTER
description: THE dismissal last week of Thomas Michalak as music director of the New Jersey Symphony was the culmination of a dispute with the orchestra's board of directors that began more than a year ago.

title: Carol E. Davis Is Engaged
description: The engagement of Carol Elizabeth Davis to Randolph Drake Roy has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. George Davis of Tenafly, N.J., the parents of the future bride. Mr. Roy is a son of Clare Roy of Lansdale, Pa. The couple graduated last year from Dartmouth College. Miss Davis is a paralegal with the New York law firm of Stults & Marshall and her fiance is a software engineer with the Digital Equipment Corporation in Maynard, Mass.

title: LEADERS OF INDIA GROUPS IN U.S. BLAME MRS. GANDHI
description: Some people from India living in the United States, outraged by the violence that has taken an estimated 1,500 lives in India's northeastern state of Assam, have denounced Prime Minister Indira Gandhi for blaming student agitators for the conflicts.

title: VIEWS FROM OVERSEAS
description: American designers, who have estab-lished themselves firmly in their own country over the last two decades, have now set their sights on Europe -long the major fashion influence for the Western world. And those involved in fashion in France, Italy and England - from designers to fashion editors to retailers - who have been watching the Americans' coming of age, have already formed opinions of the Americans' style.

title: WHAT WAS THAT WE SAW?
description: ''WILDLIFE private eye'' and ''winter sleuth'' are some of the aliases Doug Winkler has collected in his six years as a naturalist at the Garvies Point Museum and Preserve in Glen Cove.

title: 'A COUPLA CHICKS, AN ODD COUPLING'
description: THE methodical Maude Mix is sorting the laundry. Suddenly, she erupts into a devilish disco dance. Enter - without knocking - Hannah Mae Bindler, the hyperfriendly neighborhood spy; this is a secluded part of Westchester County, one of the ''top 10'' suburbs on the money meter.

title: A Possible Clue In AIDS Disease?
description: When scores of monkeys mysteriously sicken and die in a laboratory, it's sad for the monkeys and bad for researchers. But when the animal epidemic resembles a sometimes deadly human disease, ''acquired immune deficiency syndrome'' (AIDS), a tool for treatment may be at hand.

title: FROM RUSSIA WITH CANDOR
description: METROPOL Literary Almanac. Edited by Vasily Aksyonov, Viktor Yerofeyev, Fazil Iskander, Andrei Bitov and Yevgeny Popov. Foreword by Kevin Klose. Illustrated. 643 pp. New York: W.W. Norton & Co. $24.95.EVERYTHING about this anthology is remarkable: its inception, its fortunes, its contents. ''Metropol'' was first published in 1979 in the original Russian version by Ardis in Michigan and in a French translation by Gallimard in Paris. Its history has been told by Vasily Aksyonov, its instigator and prime mover, by Kevin Klose, a former Moscow correspondent for The Washington Post, in his foreword to the English translation, and in samizdat publications that have been reprinted in The Chronicle of Current Events, published in Russian in New York. This history is an amusing, bracing, tragic, heroic one, and ''fantastic,'' one would like to add, were it not that fantasy implies the unusual, whereas the events in this case are of a type all too commonplace in the Soviet Union.

title: Warren Stamp to Wed Elizabeth Fisher
description: Mr. and Mrs. Glendon R. Mayo of Hartford have announced the engagement of her daughter, Elizabeth Hawley Fisher, to Warren Gene Stamp Jr., son of Dr. Stamp of Charlottesville, Va., and the late Mary M. Stamp.

title: THE RATES STABILIZE, MAY CLIMB
description: INTEREST rates have stabilized in the past few months, but t here are faint signs that the rates may be starting to creep up a gain.

title: WHERE BLOOMSBURY FLOWERED
description: Bloomsbury. Where is it? What was it? It is by no means easy to answer these questions as precisely as one could wish. Look at a large-scale map of London showing the West Central District and there you will easily discover a big block representing the British Museum. With this near its base, you may describe a quadrilateral bounded on one side by Tottenham Court Road, the other side by Euston Road, on a third by Gray's Inn Road and finally, less neatly, New Oxford Street and Theobalds Road. That more or less is Bloomsbury.

title: Funding Concom
description: To The Business Editor:

title: 7 NAMED TO EDUCATION PANEL REFLECT STATE'S DIVERSITY
description: IN announcing his seven nominees last Thursday for the new 11-member Board of Governors for Higher Education, Governor O'Neill said he was adhering to the state law requiring the board to reflect Connecticut's ''geographic, racial and ethnic diversity.''

title: ANOTHER SIDE TO CHEAP FUEL
description: CHEAPER energy is obviously a good thing, and economists have said that the current price war among oil producers can provide a number of benefits for all industrial nations. For consumers, too, falling prices of home heating oil and at the pump are welcome allies in the private struggle to make ends meet.

title: A RESPECT FOR TRADITION
description: Contemporary photography of a no-frills sort is down but not out. It lives on despite the demise of many of the galleries that showcased and supported it, despite a shift toward a photographic practice addressed to the larger art world of painting and sculpture, and despite a stagnant marketplace. Fortunately, the artists who are today's torchbearers of what was once called ''straight photography'' are not as depressed as the economy. The proof, in this case, is in the pictures, and the pictures are in a show called ''New Work by Eight Photographers,'' at Daniel Wolf Gallery (30 West 57th Street, through April 2).

title: PRAVDA AGAIN CRITICAL OF BONN
description: The newspaper Pravda today renewed criticism of the West German Government for its resolve to go ahead with plans to deploy American missiles if it wins the March 6 election.

title: MANHATTAN CHURCH A LEADER IN SHELTER OF HOMELESS
description: A double row of cots, granite walls and a oak doorway make the room beneath St. George's Episcopal Church seem vaguely monastic. But the cots are occupied by a dozen homeless men and women seeking temporary refuge from the city night.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC
description: Two unusual vocal recitals are being offered on Monday night. The Swedish baritone Hakan Hagegard, will be making his Carnegie Hall debut at 8 P.M. And the Dutch baritone Max van Egmond will perform Schubert's ''Die Winterreise'' at Merkin Hall at the same time, accompanied by Malcolm Bilson on a Graf piano of the period.

title: FASHION AND FEMININITY, MORE OR LESS
description: Imagine, if you will, a person who expects that the fashion establishment is out to get her in any way it can - financially, esthetically and psychologically. Imagine further that this person is beyond surprise at any tomfoolery served up by the designers, and takes seasonal style pronouncements with a shaker full of salt. This is someone who asks nothing more of fashion than that she be sufficiently au courant not to be laughed out of Chock Full o'Nuts. All this being true, it may be a trifle surprising that this same woman is, nevertheless, as mesmerized by the machinations of the fashion establishment as the cobra is by the mongoose. The cobra probably knows that it's a damn fool before it even starts up with the mongoose, just as any sane person knows that paying any attention whatsoever to the goings-on of la mode is as dangerous as taking the first peanut at a cocktail party.

title: 20 Philippine Prisoners Suing On Grounds of Illegal Arrests
description: Twenty Filipino political prisoners who say they were arrested illegally and tortured have filed a $720,000 lawsuit against Gen. Fabian Ver, the chief of the armed forces, lawyers and the prisoners' relatives said today.

title: A FINE TRIBUTE TO MUSICAL THEATER
description: BEWARE: Nostalgia is getting nearer. Musicals of the 1920's and 1930's started -and exhausted - the trend. Last season, the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam dipped into the 1940's (''High Button Shoes'') and is doing so once more this year (''Miss Liberty''), but even that is somehow in the realm of the long ago and far away.

title: Margaret H. Prosser To Wed
description: The engagement of Margaret Howland Prosser to the Rev. David Bertles Stewart has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. F. Woodward Prosser of Chatham, Mass., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is a son of Potter Stewart, retired Associate Justice of the United States Supreme Court, and Mrs. Stewart of Washington and Sugar Hill, N.H.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: HEALTH INSPECTIONS ABOARD SHIP
description: The Queen Elizabeth 2, the pride of Britain's Cunard Line and one of the most luxurious ships afloat, has consistently failed to meet United States sanitary standards in repeated inspections covering more than a year. The situation raises once again the questions of how valid the standards are and how safe it is to travel on a liner that does not comply with the Federal health agency's guidelines. And it underlines a fact little known to many travelers: complete health-inspection reports on all cruise ships that call at U.S. ports are available to potential passengers.

title: New Riverkeeper To Patrol Hudson
description: A visible and functioning symbol of concern for the well-being of t he Hudson River, its denizens and the people who love it and use it,w ill be launched this spring: the beamy 25-foot Riverkeeper built fort he Hudson River Fisherman's Association.

title: 4th Heptagonals Title For Navy High-Jumper
description: Leo Williams of Navy cleared a meet record 7 feet 1 1/2 inches in the high jump today, helping his team to the lead after the first day of competition in the Indoor Heptagonals at Yale's Coxe Cage.

title: LINDA CROWLEY TO WED C.E. SATERSON MAY 14
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold F. Crowley of Fairview, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Crowley, to Constantine E. Saterson, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Saterson of Ridgewood, N.J. A May 14 wedding is planned in Los Angeles.

title: KNICKS TOP BULLS BY 94-79
description: The confidence of the Knicks in their ability to apply defensive pressure has grown so strong recently that little appears to faze them, not a 12-point deficit nor a 1-for-10 shooting performance in the first five minutes of a game.

title: NEW ORLEANS WORLD'S FAIR BATTLES FOR ITS LOGO
description: One autumn day in 1980, while New Orleans business leaders were working out arrangements to bring the 1984 World Exposition to Louisiana, a suburban lawyer was drifting along in a sailboat doing some creative musing of his own.

title: DANCE: 'MOMENTUM' AT BROOKLYN ACADEMY
description: Storms swept through the Brooklyn Academy of Music Thursday night, storms of music and storms of dance. These tempests were all part of ''Intuitive Momentum,'' a collaborative work by Max Roach, Bill T. Jones, Arnie Zane and Connie Crothers. Mr. Jones and Mr. Zane devised the choreography for themselves and three other dancers and the music was provided by Mr. Roach, one of the masters of jazz drumming, and Miss Crothers, a fine jazz pianist.

title: Martin Gives an Opinion
description: Manager Billy Martin was asked today if he ever had a team with a middle third of the lineup as potentially good as Dave Winfield, Steve Kemp and Don Baylor. He recalled the Minnesota trio of Rod Carew, Harmon Killbrew and Tony Oliva and the Yankees' 1977 trio of Thurman Munson, Chris Chambliss and Reggie Jackson.

title: SEEKS CHALLENGE
description: Herschel Walker went to work today. The all-America tailback and Heisman Trophy winner from the University of Georgia reported to the training camp here of the New Jersey Generals of the United States Football League and after a half-hour news conference Walker put on a white uniform with the No. 34 on the jersey.

title: REVISED 'MENU'
description: When a group of Italian investors decided to renovate the six-story building at 56 Beaver Street in Manhattan, built by the Delmonico brothers in the 1830's to house their famous restaurant, the intention was to create 39 luxury condominiums. But by the time the $6 million renovation was complete last fall, the residential condominium market had become soft.

title: Recent Sales
description: Danbury, Conn. $76,000 *2*1905 Village Square, 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*6-year-old townhouse condominium; monthly *2*common charges $119, taxes $980. Huntington, Conn. $270,000 *2*130 Driftwood Lane, 4-bedroom, 4-bath, 2-year-old *2*contemporary; central air-conditioning, gallery *2*over living room, 300-foot frontage *2*on lake; taxes $4,444. New Fairfield, Conn. $86,500 *2*37 Rita Drive, 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 14-year-old *2*raised ranch, 139 days on market; *2*1 acre; taxes $1,100. Eastchester, N.Y. $115,000 *2*103 Joyce Road, 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 33-year-old *2*frame colonial; den, eat-in kitchen, *2*above-ground pool, 54- by 100-foot *2*lot; taxes $2,150. New Rochelle, N.Y. $83,000 *2*14 Rockland Place, 5-bedroom, 3-bath, 58-year-old *2*frame colonial; screened porch, eatin *2*kitchen; taxes $1,031. White Plains, N.Y. $100,000 *2*10 Walworth Terrace, 3-bedroom, 2-bath, *2*31-year-old stone/frame colonial; upstairs *2*sundeck, 1-car garage, 61- by 104-foot lot; *2*taxes $2,163. OTHER AREAS Floral Park, L.I. $95,000 *2*15 Cisney Avenue, 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, *2*52-year-old Tudor; formal dining room; *2*taxes $2,400. Levittown, L.I. $64,000 *2*26 Schoolhouse Road, 4-bedroom, 1-bath, 35-year-old *2*Cape Cod; taxes $2,300. Livingston, N.J. $128,000 *2*3 Cherry Hill Road, 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, *2*13-year-old raised ranch, taxes $2,670.

title: Lisabeth A. Rehm Plans to Marry John A. Hopper
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack D. Rehm of Des Moines, Iowa, and Fenwick, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisabeth Alisan Rehm, to John Anthony Hopper, son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul F. Hopper of Greenwich, Conn., and Danby, Vt.

title: LAWYERS SAY DENNIS BANKS IS SET TO GIVE UP
description: Dennis Banks, a leader of the American Indian Movement who has been evading South Dakota authorities for eight years since being convicted for assault and rioting, plans to surrender to New York State authorities early next month, his lawyers said yesterday.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: REPRESENTATIVE James J. Florio, Democrat of Runnemede, was known as the nemesis of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency even before Congress began its investigations of the agency and its administrator, Anne McGill Burford, last fall. (Mrs. Burford is the former Anne Gorsuch.)

title: Slogan Trouble
description: Like a good college football cheer, a catchy state slogan can produce magic results, many tourism officials believe. As a rejoinder to ''I Love New York,'' for example, Connecticut came up in 1981 with ''Better Yet Connecticut.''

title: PHYSICIAN-ASSISTANT A BOON TO SURGEON
description: SOON after patients check into a hospital for surgery, they are visited by a white-coated man or woman who examines them, takes their medical history, explains hospital procedures and answers any questions they may have.

title: STELLA BLUM: A PASSION FOR COSTUME HISTORY
description: There is nothing about Stella Blum that suggests a great lady of fashion. Not for her the ivory cuff of grand gesture or the wardrobe whispering with black cashmere. She knits her own sweaters. Her jewelry is small. And her accent, like her origin, is traceable.

title: A SRICTLY-FOR-BUSINESS CONFERENCE CENTER
description: THE chairs are designed for 18 hours of sitting, the bedrooms c ontain dictionaries and thesauruses as well as Gideon Bibles, the r ooms are soundproof and the enticements of the Big Apple are 23 m iles away.

title: Ann W. Cox Has Nuptials In New York
description: Ann Whiting Cox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Coburn Cox Jr. of London and Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday to Stephen Mayr Bartram, son of Mrs. Austin L. Smithers of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Rensselaer Wardwell Bartram 3d of Palm Beach, Fla. The Rev. Hays Rockwell performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in Manhattan.

title: THE GEESE THAT CAN BRING US NUCLEAR WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: Janet Schumacher to Wed C.C. Alberti
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Warner Schumacher of Prairie Village, Kan., of the engagement of their daughter, Janet Lee Schumacher, to C. Christopher Alberti, son of Judge and Mrs. Charles R. Alberti of Williamstown, Mass.

title: THE EDGES OF THE GREAT WAR
description: AN ICE CREAM WAR By William Boyd. 408 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $17.95. WILLIAM BOYD'S first novel, ''A Good Man in Africa'' (1982), was a tight and bitter comedy about sexual embarrassment and the British presence in postcolonial Africa, an unlikely but almost entirely successful combination of Kingsley Amis and V.S. Naipaul. In his new novel he turns to the little-known East African theater of World War I, in which armies from the British and German colonies there faced each other across the border of present-day Kenya and Tanzania. The British expected the campaign to be a joke; their control of the seas would keep the undermanned and undersupplied Germans from fighting for more than a few weeks. Hence this novel's title - and its irony, for the Germans kept fighting until the Armistice. ''An Ice-Cream War'' is less fully realized than its predecessor, but it is a more ambitious novel, and Mr. Boyd's ironic vision of the way individuals are dwarfed by the history through which they live is a large achievement.

title: Lost Luggage
description: To the Editor:

title: 71ST NEEDIEST CASE APPEAL TO END WITH A RECORD
description: The 71st annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund is nearing an end with a record total in contributions in excess of $1.8 million from more than 13,000 donors.

title: 'Asking the Sun' In Earlier Times
description: In connection with the excellent article ''What Time Is It? Ask the Sun'' (Jan. 30), it might be of interest to Zvi Gezari, about whom the article centered, and readers to know that a sundial is mentioned in the Old Testament: ''And Isaiah the prophet cried unto the Lord; and he brought the shadow ten degrees backward by which it had gone down on the dial of Ahaz.''

title: No Headline
description: Michael Harwood's article was not only an important contribution to a better understanding of black holes and how they may apply to what we know about the real world, but also an important contribution to victims of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. A.L.S. is a progressive neurological disease that affects the motor neuron cells in the brain and spinal cord. In the terminal stages of the disease, the A.L.S. patient is unable to move or speak, but remains mentally healthy.

title: WHAT MAKES A GREAT SHOW?
description: On the face of it, ''How big is an exhibition?'' is one of the dumber questions. Like ''How wet is water?'' and ''How wide is Wednesday?'' It cannot be answered. It does mean something, though. There are times and places in which an exhibition cannot be too big. In 1980 the Picasso exhibition filled every known corner of the Museum of Modern Art. But it ran out of space, not out of energy. Besides, it was held at exactly the right time. Not only was a mass of new Picasso material coming into view, but the exhibition was the ideal end to the lifespan of the museum's old building.

title: TOWN RESISTS 2D MCDONALD's
description: McDONALD'S, the company that likes to promote its fast-food hamburger business as synonymous with the good things in American life, finds itself being grilled by the people of East Lyme.

title: 100 BIRD PAINTINGS BY FUERTES
description: LOUIS AGASSIZ FUERTES (1874-1927) was born in the year following Louis Agassiz's death. Although no relation to the great Swiss zoologist, Fuertes was named after him - by parents who hoped he would enter a sensible profession such as architecture or engineering.

title: AN APPEALING 'MASS APPEAL'
description: MILLBURN WITH its original star, Milo O'Shea, for whom the role of Father Tim Farley could well become a fixed annuity, and a most appealing performance by Shaun Cassidy as the rebel seminarian Mark Dolson, the two-character play with the clever, double-edged title, ''Mass Appeal,'' is being presented, good and fresh as new, at the Paper Mill Playhouse through next Sunday.

title: A BIT OF ADVICE TO THE PEOPLE OF KEARNY
description: EVEN Kearny's most loyal residents, I imagine, would probably admit that theirs is not the handsomest town in New Jersey. But the old adage, ''Looks aren't everything,'' is as much applicable to communities as to humans.

title: SPECIAL PROSECUTOR CONSIDERED IN MIAMI CASE
description: Gov. Bob Graham says his office is studying whether to appoint a special prosecutor to try a Miami police officer indicted this week on manslaughter charges in the fatal shooting of a black man two months ago. But the Governor said he was not inclined to intervene.

title: FASSBINDER STARS IN GREMM'S 'KAMIKAZE'
description: The late Rainer Werner Fassbinder appeared in a number of his own films, mostly in small roles, though he was the star of his ''Fox and His Friends,'' and his performance in ''Katzelmacher,'' one of his earliest and most characteristic works, was a key to that film's success.

title: London Teatime
description: To the Editor:

title: BUDGETING IN NASSAU: TRUTH OR CONSEQUENCES
description: FOR years, the Nassau Citizens Budget Committee has been urging local governments in Nassau County to change to true program budgeting so they could plan more rationally, monitor and control costs better, determine how best to provide services in a cost-effective manner - in short, make the best use of the public's money.

title: KEAN TRIES AGAIN FOR CORPORATE HELP
description: GOVERNOR KEAN, who admittedly attracted some criticism for affixing his name to a State Republican Committee fund raising letter seeking $1,000-a-year donors, has mailed another letter, this time seeking $3 million for a pet project of his in the state government.

title: WINFIELD IS HOPING YANKS WILL FOCUS ON PLAY, NOT FEUDS
description: Three minutes before nine o'clock this morning, Dave Winfield walked into the Yankee clubhouse at Fort Lauderdale Stadium carrying his equipment bag. He wore a light blue T-shirt, dark blue corduroy slacks and white sneakers. He did not wear a World Series ring.

title: WHAT RECOVERY?
description: To the Business Editor:

title: BEWARE OF ANOTHER OIL PRICE EXPLOSION
description: To the Editor:

title: Fasser's Swiss Bobsled Leads Four-Man Event
description: Ekkehard Fasser of Switzerland, chosen as an alternate for the world four-man bobsled championships, took a solid lead today with two sub-60 second runs on the Mount Van Hoevenberg course.

title: 2 RACES TO MORTON, MOLLOY TAKES TITLE
description: Tim Morton, a senior at St. Francis Prep, won two races, and Archbishop Molloy of Queens regained the team title yesterday in the 56th annual Catholic High Schools Athletic Association indoor track and field championships at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: THERESE KERESEY WILL WED IN JUNE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas M. Keresey of Palm beach, Fla., formerly of Mill Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter. Therese Keresey, to Kevin Randall Hennessy, son of Mrs. John Edward Hennessy of Sacramento, Calif., and the late Mr. Hennessy.

title: YOUTHS OFFER RIDES
description: THE peer pressure that often prompts teen-agers to drink and drive is being tried as a way of discouraging drunken youths from getting behind the wheel.

title: A Ferryboat Passenger Falls Off and Drowns
description: A passenger on a Circle Line ferryboat to Liberty Island fell overboard yesterday and was pronounced dead after a Coast Guard rescue vessel pulled him out of the water, a spokesman for the Coast Guard said.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: THE MOSQUITO COAST. By Paul Theroux. (Avon, $3.95.) In Paul Theroux's 1982 best seller, Allie Fox, an eccentric genius obsessed with what he sees as the cultural collapse of America, takes his patient wife and his four children and lights out for the jungles of Honduras to build a better world. Our critic, Thomas R. Edwards, praised the novel as a strong and disturbing fable, sophisticated entertainment and an ''impressively serious act of imagination.''

title: Pakistan Convicts American
description: A special military court in Rawalpindi convicted an American schoolteacher of two charges of illegal arms possession and sentenced him to 10 years in jail. The charges stemmed from the discovery of arms, ammunition and explosives in the home of Eugene Ray Clegg, 35 years old, of Castle Rock, Wash., who taught physics, mathematics and biology at Islamabad's International School. Arms packed in crates and labeled teaching aids were later found in Mr. Clegg's name at the airport, the court heard.

title: THE CASE FOR STAR VEHICLES
description: After seven flush years - financially, if not esthetically - Broadway is at least temporarily in trouble. The current season is playing to far fewer customers than it did last year, at the moment of writing at least 15 theaters are dark, etcetera, etcetera. You've read the papers. And, no doubt, you've shrugged and wondered what else anyone could possibly expect, considering the current state of the economy.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: DIRE MASTERY Discipleship From Freud to Lacan. By Francois Roustang. Translated by Ned Lukacher. 162 pp. Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins University Press. $16.50. ''Dire Mastery'' begins on a deceptively simple note, as a detective story might, depicting certain tensions in the personal and intellectual relationships between Sigmund Freud and some of his colleagues - Jung, Rank, Abraham, Tausk, Ferenczi - around the time of the founding of the International Psychoanalytic Association in 1910. Not far into the book, however, we find we have left the pleasant surface of an intellectual group biography and descended to a somewhat darker level, the pyschological underlife. Soon we are embroiled in the jealous passions, violent betrayals, suicidal allegiances and symbolic murder plots of a group Freud only halfplayfully called ''the savage horde.''

title: Twenty Years After 'The Feminine Mystique'
description: It is 20 years now since "The Feminine Mystique" was published. I am still awed by the revolution that book helped spark. That I was able to put it together at the time it was needed is something of a mystery to me. Even now, women -and men - stop me on the street to reminisce about where they were when they read it - ''I was in the maternity ward with my third kid, and then I decided to go to law school.''

title: Reagan Nudges Israel, but It's No Dice So Far
description: President Reagan last week urged Israel to accept American security guarantees on its northern borders and withdraw from Lebanon, but the Israelis stood their ground in more ways than one.

title: SUTTON PLACE RESIDENTS DIVIDED ON LANDMARK STATUS
description: IN 1921, Anne Morgan of the banking Morgans turned her back on a F ifth Avenue address in favor of 3 Sutton Place, becoming the s treet's first fashionable resident. Her double house is now the r esidence of the Secretary General of the United Nations.

title: Robert B. Day Is Dead at 89; Ex-Head of Catering Concern
description: Robert B. Day, retired chairman of the board of Robert Day-Dean, a New York catering concern, died Friday at his home in Pelham, N.Y. He was 89 years old.

title: Starting Out at 85
description: ''I am going into this because it's something new for me,'' said Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney, who will board broodmares at his farm in Lexington, Ky., for the first time since he inherited it 51 years ago. The farm had been strictly a private breeding establishment, but will now accept as many as 125 broodmares.

title: THE SOFT SELL
description: WHEN IT became known around town that John Loring - artist, former New York bureau chief of Architectural Digest and now senior vice president and design director of Tiffany & Company -had purchased a small Fifth Avenue apartment for his mother to use during her semiannual stays in New York, speculation was rife in certain quarters about whom he would choose to redesign the place. After all, it recently had been Mr. Loring's business to know the work of every notable designer in the city. A nod from him would certainly be regarded as a prized imprimatur.

title: HISTORIC HOMES IN HARLEM RESTORED
description: THE facades of 19 century-old houses in the Jumel Terrace Historic District of upper Manhattan have been r estored under an award-winning $397,000 preservation project. Except for one startling standout - 16 Sylvan Terrace, a white stucco-front building whose owners refused to participate - the wood-frame structures comprise two uniform 10-unit rows. They face each other across a narrow asphalt street that was once the main approach to theMorris-Jumel Mansion on Edgecombe Avenue between West 160th and West 162d Streets.

title: In This Next Scene . . .
description: One of the less obvious benefits of President Reagan's Hollywood background is that other members of the acting fraternity are only too happy to help out on those tough foreign policy problems. Take Clint Eastwood, known for his portrayals of cowboys and cops who wreak havoc on the unrighteous. According to a report in The Los Angeles Times last week, Mr. Eastwood financed a former Green Beret colonel's raid into Laos in search of American prisoners of war in November after first discussing it with Mr. Reagan. Mr. Eastwood and the White House had no comment.

title: ROCK: ZEVON AT BOTTOM LINE
description: Warren Zevon looked like a folk singer Tuesday at the Bottom Line, complete with acoustic guitars, beard and headband. He performed alone, a format most singer-songwriters reserve for folky music and tender sentiments.

title: CAIRO LAWYERS ASSAIL ISRAEL
description: Several hundred Egyptian lawyers burned Israeli flags at a rally today to mark the third anniversary of Egypt's establishing diplomatic relations with Israel.

title:
GARDENING;
USING FOLIAGE COLOR TO ACCENT GARDEN
description: THERE exists a long-standing disagreement among gardeners as to the merit of using trees and shrubs with colored foliage in the landscape. While some enthusiastically recommend their use as a means of creating interest, others decry their use, using such terms as gauche and overpowering to convey their distaste.

title: A LITERARY PILGRIM'S PROGRESS
description: Turn right from Holborn subway station up Southampton Row and almost immediately you plunge into the area of London immortalized by the Bloomsbury Group. Take the first turning on the left - Bloomsbury Way, thought hte first half has been renamed Vernon Place - and on the right you encounter Bloomsbury Square, which, in spring, will sparkling with daffodils. Turn left at its northern corner and you encounter the neoclassical facade of the British Museum.

title: LAWYERS FOR HAITIAN REFUGEES ASK CASES BE HEARD IN COUNTY
description: THE county chapter of the New York Civil Liberties Union is coordinating the preparation of plan that, if accepted, will allow an Immigration Court to be established in Westchester to hear the deportation cases of Haitian refugees living in the county.

title: FROM THE GERMAN
description: During the last few years the number of German books in translation has risen steadily, and they now outnumber translations from French literature, which had been by far the largest body of foreign literature available in this country for a generation. What effect this resurgence of German writers will have is an open question. One thinks of the popularity of Thomas Mann in the past. Could an entire army of writers not equal that now?

title: Uranium Deposits in China
description: China has enough uranium to meet all military and civil needs for the next 30 years, a senior Nuclear Industry Ministry official said today. The official, quoted by the New China News Agency, said that, in addition to its nuclear weapons program, present reserves would insure fuel for nuclear power stations with a capacity of 15,000 megawatts over the next three decades.

title: ISRAEL: VOICES OF MORAL ANGUISH
description: Nevertheless the people refused to obey the voice of Samuel; and they said, Nay; but we will have a king over us;/ That we also may be like all the nations; and that our king may judge us, and go out before us, and fight our battles. - I Samuel 8:19-20.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Decisions, Decisions

title: Vermont Approves Link To Canada's Power
description: New England's dream of forging a power partnership with Canada has cleared a crucial hurdle, setting the stage for huge amounts of power to begin flowing into the region in 1986.

title: JAZZ: MEL LEWIS ORCHESTRA
description: Mel Lewis is celebrating the 17th anniversary of his jazz orchestra by breaking with precedent. The band is playing at a different club for the first time since it made its debut on a Monday night in February 1966 at the Village Vanguard under the joint leadership of Thad Jones and Mr. Lewis. Mr. Lewis has been in sole charge for five years.

title: Marshall Goodman to Wed Miss Paradise, a Therapist
description: Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Paradise of Lawrence, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Paradise, to Marshall Goodman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Goodman of East Hills, L.I.

title: Tremors Are Reported Along Mississippi Coast
description: Unexplained tremors shook a 50-mile stretch of the Mississippi Gulf Coast today, knocking goods from store shelves and startling residents.

title: Caroline Watts Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles H. Watts of Freedom, N.H., and McLean, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Caroline Moore Watts, to Peter K. Collins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter C. Collins of Douglaston, Queens.

title: HE CAN MAKE THE KNOTTIEST MUSIC ELEGANT
description: ''The more I advance in life,'' the violinist Henryk Szeryng was saying, ''the more I feel that to understand music it helps to get close to the composer. If it's Brahms, we should be able to picture the way he behaved and the way he dressed, the way he was entertained and the way he was trying to be gracious.''

title: New Tax Measures Approved in Italy
description: An unpopular package of tax measures received final approval from Parliament today when the upper house passed it on a confidence motion.

title: Under Falsetto Pretenses
description: Just how creative were the Bee Gees when they wrote ''How Deep Is Your Love''? Not very, according to Robert Selle, an amateur songwriter from suburban Chicago, who claimed in a suit that the Bee Gees' 1975 hit was based on his own unpublished work, ''Let It End.''

title: 'PRIVATE LIFE,' RUSSIAN FAMILY PORTRAIT
description: Yuli Raizman's ''Private Life'' offers as detailed a look at ordinary Soviet life as any contemporary Soviet film that has yet been seen here. In addition, it's an effective and well-acted drama.

title: Miss McLaughlin to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. William F. McLaughlin of Richmond Hill, Queens, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Mary-Kate McLaughlin, to Thomas Tendy, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Tendy of Flushing, Queens. A September wedding is planned.

title: Arbitration Lament
description: Tal Smith, a former executive with the Houston Astros who represented major league teams in 13 of 30 salary arbitration cases this winter, believes that many teams are paying players inflated salaries to avoid the arbitration process.

title: LOWER PRICES IN ULSTER LURE SHOPPERS FROM SOUTH
description: The slogan brought wry smiles here but clearly it is working: ''Come to Belfast for bargain shopping.'' A spokesman for Belfast's City Council explained: ''The southern accents are definitely being heard in town. If you show them a bargain they forget about the risk.''

title: INVISIBLE FATHER
description: THE INVENTION OF SOLITUDE By Paul Auster. 174 pp. New York: SUN. Paper, $6. PAUL AUSTER'S book starts with an event at once ordinary and unique, commonplace and incommunicable. His father, after a divorce and 15 years of living alone in a big house in New Jersey, ''in the best of health, not even old, with no history of illness,'' suddenly died. Their relationship had been composed in great part of remoteness and absence. Most of the feelings it had engendered and fostered had been unarticulated and unnoticed. Indeed, his father's inability to notice him had seemed to Mr. Auster one of the principal and abiding elements of their knowing each other.

title: REAGAN TO ASK END OF PRICE CONTROLS FOR NATURAL GAS
description: President Reagan said today that he would ask Congress to end price controls on natural gas over the next three years. He emphasized that in that period the Government would prevent industry from passing higher costs to consumers.

title: A DOCTOR ON HEALING
description: THE YOUNGEST SCIENCE Notes of a Medicine-Watcher. By Lewis Thomas. 270 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $14.75.A DISTINGUISHED professor of physiology, in order to instill an appropriate degree of humility, would inform each incoming medical school class that medical intervention had unquestionably taken more lives than it had saved. Fortunately, by retiring in 1950, he was relieved of the need to find a new introductory ploy, for what may have been true before that time has certainly not been true since. The last 30 years have seen a transformation of the medical profession. What was formerly a care-and-comfort occupation has been converted into the life-saving activity it had always been thought to be by the layman.

title: Saving for an Un-Rainy Day
description: It may have taken the Lord to part the Red Sea, but only four Governors and a Mayor were required to divide the Delaware River. After four years of negotiations, the leaders of New Jersey, Pennsylvania, Delaware and New York State and City last week agreed on a plan that would continue sharp restrictions on the city's allotment of Delaware water during dry spells but increase storage facilities to make shortages less frequent.

title: DINING THAT IS NEARLY FLAWLESS
description: TAPESTRIES a well-named new restaurant in Greenwich - weaves the threads of stylish decor, a well-designed menu and artistically presented food into a gratifying dining experience.

title: No Headline
description: Nearly every post-Freudian psychological theoretician has emphasized the importance of culture and societal environment in the development of an individual's emotional life. The question arises around cultural adaptation.

title: Georgetown Beats Seton Hall by 71-60
description: Georgetown easily defeated Seton Hall, 71-60, today in a Big East Conference game at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: THE TYPOGRAPHY OF HELL IN BEIRUT
description: THE DECEPTION By Nicolas Born. Translated by Leila Vennewitz. 238 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $15.50. WAR is the ultimate obscenity, hence the ideal media event. But what you see and read is by no means all there is, and even the most conscientious coverage cannot begin to bridge the gap between mere objectivity and truth. What happens when a journalist tries to cross it on his own is part of Nicolas Born's complex, brilliant and brilliantly flawed novel, ''The Deception.''

title: THE NATURE OF VICTORY MAY BE AS IMPORTANT AS THE MARGIN
description: The election campaign has been as bitter as the winter that has gripped West Germany this icy February. A week from today, amid great suspense, the country will vote for a new parliament to guide West Germany through what promises to be its toughest days since the end of the war.

title: FOrward, Back On Voting Rights
description: The United States Supreme Court last week ruled, as it has before, that a key section of the Voting Rights Act permits state and local governments to revise their voting procedures in ways that perpetuate discrimination - so long as they do not worsen it. But in so doing, the Justices opened the way for an early test of another, equally key section of the law, rewritten by Congress last year.

title: Article 258071 -- No Title
description: A pothole has cost the city $600,000. A jury in Common Pleas Court awarded the money on Friday to Betty Rogers, a 28-year-old clerk.

title: CONSUMER RATES
John Porges, Leigh Simon Are Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. William E. Simon of New Vernon, N.J., and East Hampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Leigh Simon, to John Randolph Porges, son of John M. Porges of Coral Gables, Fla., and the late Anne E. Porges.

title: THE BIRTH OF SILICON STATESMANSHIP
description: FORMER California Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. made a surprise appearance at a personal computer i ndustry meeting recently in Palm Springs. Following speeches about d isk drives and operating systems, Mr. Brown took the podium and u rged industry executives to get more involved in politics.

title: Miss Straus Weds R.J. Tofel
description: Jeanne Helen Straus, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. Peter Straus of New York and Washington, was married in Manhattan yesterday to Richard Jeffrey Tofel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Tofel of Riverdale, the Bronx. Rabbi Mark Golub performed the ceremony at the Cottage on the Park at Hampshire House.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: No Holds Barred

title: RECITAL: CAROL ROSENBERG
description: Carol Rosenberger's piano recital in the 92d Street Y Wednesday night inspired a listener to think, after each of her performances, ''Yes, but . . . '' Miss Rosenberger could be an intriguing pianist; during certain of the Opus 126 Beethoven Bagatelles she was thoughtful, sharply articulating certain textures that are overlooked by others. And there were also moments in the Schubert Sonata in C minor (Op. Posth., D. 958) when she knew where the music was going and to what end.

title: HIGH-PRESSURE HOUSECLEANING
description: IF dioxin-poisoned Times Beach, Mo., looked like a bad place to be last week, the Environmental Protection Agency was no bed of roses. Some heads rolled in the name of ''management improvement,'' and multiple investigations kept everybody, from the agency's headquarters at Waterside Mall to the White House, on edge.

title: Triumph of Generosity
description: All the social indicators were grim when The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund launched its 71st annual appeal three months ago. The number of homeless, unemployed and destitute was higher than at any time since the Great Depression.

title: SUIT FILED TO ABOLISH MEDICAL MALPRACTICE PANELS
description: The head of the state's largest organization of trial lawyers has filed suit to abolish the special screening panels created eight years ago to hear all medical malpractice claims.

title: MOre Pressure On Loan Rates
description: ''Those consumer loan rates seem quite high,'' Federal Reserve Board chairman Paul A. Volcker said to Senator Lawton Chiles last week. ''That seems to be what you want me to say, and I'm saying it.'' The Florida Democrat, ranking minority member on the Senate Budget Committee, was evidently nowhere near so eager as the California Republican in the White House. ''There's no reason,'' President Reagan said, ''why the banks can't bring those interest rates down another notch or two'' to speed economic recovery.

title: Betty Ewing a Founder of Youth Court
description: On Feb. 13, Westchester Weekly section had an article in reference to the proposed Youth Court for the village of Tarrytown (''For Tarrytown Teen-Agers, a Court of Peers''). There was a serious ommission in the article that I wish to correct.

title: LEADING THE TEAMWORK OF 500 ENGINEERS
description: ONE day in the spring, Melvin S. Feder of Woodbury will make his way to the British Embassy in Washington. When he leaves, he will possess a gold medal on a gray and red ribbon that will be tangible evidence of his formal induction as an Honorary Officer of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire.

title: Busing Goes Metropolitan
description: Volunteering for a desegregation plan, even under duress, beats being saddled with one in St. Louis. Just before a hearing last week that would have led to court-ordered busing, 22 out of 23 suburban school districts proposed their own, and the nation's first, voluntary busing program involving a large city and its metropolitan area.

title: SHINNECOCKS HATCH AND INDUSTRY
description: WHEN Brad Smith was growing up, he used to swim in the cove where Heady Creek stretches across to the dunes of the ocean. The path to the bay was not paved and there was no building at the end. Now a newly blacktopped road leads to a 7,000-square-foot structure that houses the operations of the Shinnecock Tribal Shellfish Hatchery, of which the 27-year-old Mr. Smith is the manager.

title: Sports of The Times; An Outdoor Job for Rick Ownbey
description: RICK OWNBEY can remember the lock factory, the way the assembly line moved in front of him, door handles at a few miles per hour. His first job was to take a part and place it on each door handle.

title: AN ADULT 'CHILD'S' FILM, 12 YEARS LATER
description: RECENTLY, I saw the movie ''Fantasia'' again, with my 16-year-old son. The last time we saw it he was 4 years old. He enjoyed it a lot more this time and so did I.

title: Data Bank; Feb. 27, 1983

title: FREUD
description: To the Editor:

title: Emergency Rooms Shut On Weekends in Mobile
description: To keep out people who cannot pay their bills, all but one of the six hospitals in Mobile closed their emergency rooms this weekend.
