title: PESTICIDES FOUND IN SALT-WATER FISH
description: THE state's Department of Environmental Protection has determined that the same edible salt-water fish found to have potentially harmful levels of polychlorinated biphenyls also contain pesticides that could be dangerous to human health.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''After two decades of watching helplessly while their middle-class citizens pulled up stakes and headed for the suburbs, mayors and educators took heart during the 1970's over a projected 'return to the cities.'

title: China
description: To the Editor:

title: 'The Complete Poems 1927-1979'
description: ELIZABETH BISHOP'S steadily widening audience and her endurance among the readers she has once claimed are the reward of constancy to an ideal object. Her reputation is founded on perhaps 25 poems, among them ''Love Lies Sleeping,'' ''The Unbeliever,'' ''The Shampoo,'' ''Over 2,000 Illustrations and a Complete Concordance,'' ''Arrival at Santos'' and ''First Death in Nova Scotia.'' Altogether that looks like a modest achievement until one considers that most of the larger poetic reputations of the past century have been founded on similar evidence. The difference is that Bishop's masterpieces stand in a higher ratio to her work as a whole. She published little, because she would not release a poem that fell short of a complete conception; and what strikes one most in reading her poems again is the way they answer each other across pages or volumes, so that each plays its part: ''The Bight,'' for example, earning our esteem for the sake of its much fuller picture of the dream house sketched in ''The End of March''; the figure of streets coupled to stars, a mystery in ''Going to the Bakery,'' somehow clarifying a similar figure in ''Love Lies Sleeping.''

title: Silence Law Called A 'Linguistic Problem'
description: After reading the many pro and con statements on the Minute of Silence law for schoolchildren, I am struck by analogies from the pornography law.

title: Goggles for Erving
description: Julius Erving of the Philadelphia 76ers, whose right cornea was scratched in the game with the Chicago Bulls Friday night, is expected to play today against the Golden State Warriors. Erving, who was accidentally poked in the eye by Mark Olberding of the Bulls, was treated at a hospital and released.

title: Tina Kupferstein Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Earl A. Kupferstein of Glen Rock, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Tina O. Kupferstein, to Scott M. Gelber, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Gelber of Hillside, N.J. A late fall wedding is planned.

title: MINOR ART OFFERS SPECIAL PLEASURES
description: When we first read ''War and Peace,'' we are bound to know that we are in the presence of greatness - and to be perplexed. Just what is the nature of Tolstoy's achievement? The novel seems hardly written. It is simply like life itself. When we hear our first Mozart Sonata, we may recognize in it a kind of perfection. But the perfection seems utterly natural. It is there, like a landscape or a lovely face - just itself, as if it had always existed and could not be otherwise. And it is just such peak artistic experiences that point to the uses of the less than great.

title: ONION SNOW: IT CAN SNUFF OUT LIFE BEFORE LIFE HAS A CHANCE
description: WHEN she talked about ''onion snow,'' Marilyn's eyes glowed, and her naturally animated personality became even brighter. ''My husband asked me what it meant, for he had never heard of it before,'' Marilyn said as we sat at dinner in a dimly lit restaurant on Nassau Street in Princeton.

title: PARENTAL DISAPPROVAL VITAL TO OUR SOCIETY
description: To the Editor:

title: Plain Talk on Libyan Threat
description: The Administration last week took the lid off its cover story and acknowledged that it had dispatched the nuclear aircraft carrier Nimitz and four Awacs spy planes to help quash what it called a Libyan threat against the Sudan. Secretary of State George P. Shultz said the action succeeded in putting Libya's Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi ''back in his box where he belongs.''

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
'BUBBLE BABIES': AN EFFORT TO 'DROWN-PROOF' THE VERY YOUNG
description: AT first, it is a little unnerving to watch. Seven babies, ranging in age from 7 months to just more than 1 year, are being held underwater. Their mothers, who are standing waist-deep in a warm swimming pool, are grasping the infants firmly and taking turns dunking them, one-two-three.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE FARMING GAME By Bryan Jones. Illustrated. 221 pp. Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press. $15.95. Crazy Billy owns 160 acres of Middle Western farmland on which over the years he has raised the conventional cattle as well as geese, rabbits and buffaloes. Recently he has also taken a fly at growing organic turnips, artichokes, rape, pinto beans, kohlrabi, mint and ginseng root. Billy has a grain bin full of ginseng he can't unload; even his own livestock won't eat it.

title: Ellen G. Howe Is Married
description: Ellen Gardner Howe, a conservator at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, was married yesterday at the Unitarian Church of All Souls to Royce Augustine Hoyle 3d, an associate editor at Time magazine. The Rev. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Howe of Winnetka, Ill. Mr. Hoyle's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Hoyle Jr., live in Glencoe, Ill.

title: BESIEGED MULTI-TOWN NEARING AN END
description: AFTER more than 10 years in the planning stage, and almost five years as a state agency, the work of the Multi-Town Solid Waste Management Authority is grinding to a halt this week amid charges of mismanagement and overspending.

title:
DINING OUT;
A PLACE TO SPEND SEVERAL HOURS IN
description: EVERY neighborhood should have a restaurant like Benny's in Irvington. This fuss-free, unpretentious, congenial place, its tables set with paper place mats and paper napkins, attracts enthusiastic diners who chatter and wait happily at the bar for tables and for plain good food.

title: New York Times Magazine February 27, 1983
description: William Safire 19 On Language Right Stuff in the Belly Pulpit Russell Baker 22 Sunday Observer Back to the Dump John F. Burns 24 The Emergence of Andropov The Kremlin's new boss has started with a burst of image making at home and abroad. But there are questions as to how much has changed.

title: HOUSE THAT THEODORE ROOSEVELT LOVED GETS 'AUTHENTIC' LOOK
description: THESE days, the only big sticks seen at Sagamore Hill, Theodore Roosevelt's home in Oyster Bay, are apt to bear paintbrushes or hammers. Since 1978, the 26th President's Victorian home has been undergoing reconstruction, with additional projects scheduled through 1984.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN SARASOTA
description: Sarasota, a medium-sized city with 50,000 year-round residents, lies about midway along the Gulf Coast of Florida, about 45 miles south of Tampa. The city has the standard attractions of other Florida winter resorts mostly balmy days in the 60's and 70's, fine beaches, excellent fishing and boating, golf, tennis, smart shops, an abundance of moderate to luxurious lodgings and restaurants - but in addition it boasts of being the cultural capital of Florida.

title: TWO POOREST CITIES ASK FOR MORE AID
description: OFFICIALS in New Haven and Hartford learned recently that they run two of the country's poorest cities, and they want the state to take notice and help alleviate the situation.

title: WHERE GENERATIONS OF ACTORS HAVE DISPLAYED THEIR ART
description: Survival in the theater is an ancient script that tells the story not only of individual plays but of entire well-endowed companies. The Equity Library Theater is a survivor that, touch wood, has no ending in sight, even as it rounds out 40 years as a dramatic fixture in New York.

title: HANDS ACROSS THE WATER
description: The recent agreement between Toyota and General Motors to jointly produce small cars in California is part of a broad and accelerating trend that Kenichi Ohmae, managing director of McKinsey & Company in Tokyo, contends may be ''the peaceful solution to the trade issue.''

title: Unconventional Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: MOndale Enters With Both Feet; Askew Also Runs
description: Walter F. Mondale is ahead in the polls but seemingly haunted by recollections of 1974, when he abruptly dropped out of the race for the White House, declaring that he didn't have the ''overwhelming desire to be President.'' When he formally declared his candidacy last week, he sounded at times as though he was giving himself a locker-room pep talk.

title: The Sister Stays Put
description: Sister Agnes Mary Mansour protested too little, in the view of Archbishop Edmund Szoka of Detroit.

title: Rutgers Winner By 75-48
description: Coach Tom Young of Rutgers reached the 400-victory plateau today as the Scarlet Knights defeated George Washington, 75-48, in an Atlantic 10 conference game.

title: WILL A SOURCE OF CREATIVE URBAN DESIGN BE LOST?
description: That the state agency that in the early 1970's built Roosevelt Island and another 38,000 units of housing, and more recently managed to get the long-stalled New York City Convention Center, Portman Hotel and Battery Park City projects off the ground may now believe that it hasn't handled the building business right would seem an unlikely possibility. But that is precisely what seems to be happening at the New York State Urban Development Corporation, the quasi-public agency that was started in 1970 under Governor Nelson Rockefeller with the specific aim of rebuilding the state's cities. William Stern, the businessman and campaign finance chairman who was named by Governor Cuomo to head the agency, has said that his main interest is in using the U.D.C. as an economic development organization to stimulate the presence of ''high-tech,'' or computerrelated, businesses in New York State. As a first step, he has said that he wants to change the name of the agency to the New York State Development Corporation.

title: Jawboning, Soviet Style
description: Yuri V. Andropov hammered at his most challenging theme last week, the failings of the Soviet economy and the lackluster performance of bureaucrats and workers who make the wheels turn, or not. The occasion was the 100th anniversary of the death of Karl Marx (March 14, 1883),the philosophical founder of the Soviet state, who may now be spinning in his grave along with Mr. Andropov's predecessor, Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: SULLIVAN FAMILY ASKS, 'WHY?'
description: ALTHOUGH her two-year fight to find her missing brother is over, Donna Igoe of this Bergen County community said last week that the case ''still has to be pursued.''

title: Elizabeth Lazarus And Gary Stanley To Marry in May
description: Mrs. Simon Lazarus Jr. of Cincinnati has announced the engagement of her daughter, Elizabeth Lazarus, to Gary Lamar Stanley, son of Mr. and Mrs. B.M. Stanley of Atlanta. The wedding is planned for May 7.

title: CONCERT: NEIL YOUNG AT THE GARDEN
description: Neil Young exemplifies the rock star as a rugged individualist fond of inscrutable gestures. During his sold-out concert in Madison Square Garden Thursday, the singer sat perched beneath a giant television screen that would occasionally illustrate songs. At intermission, it showed an unctuous interviewer chatting with people backstage. And between interviews, it ran clips of 1950's television fare, including a Wonder Bread commercial.

title: PENGUINS SET BACK DEVILS, 5-4
description: Doug Shedden had two goals and two assists to lead the Pittsburgh Penguins to a 5-4 victory over the Devils tonight.

title: Pizza Pollution
description: They welcomed Jeno's frozen pizza plant in Wellston, Ohio, when it opened in February 1982. The jobs for 1,000 people eased a local unemployment rate of about 20 percent.

title: SURGE AT DENVER'S PENNY STOCK MARKET
description: LAST July, with investor interest in Denver's sagging penny stock market on the wane, Jim Hornung trimmed his sales staff to 13 and cut overhead expenses to the bone. ''We were lucky to write 25 tickets a day,'' recalled Mr. Hornung, who is president of Rocky Mountain Securities and Investments Inc., a local brokerage house that trades in the over-the-counter market here. ''We were doing everything we could just to hang in there.''

title: Cynthia K. Miller To Marry in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Orlando J. Miller of Teaneck, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Kathleen Miller, to Matthew Richard Korn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Korn of Stamford, Conn.

title: PAMELA BARNS TO WED JOEL HELLER IN AUGUST
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Douglas H. Barns of Cooperstown, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Jane Barns, to Joel Boone Heller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton F. Heller Jr. of New Canaan, Conn.

title: BELGIUM'S SPA EN FRANCAIS
description: T he pale winter sun had barely risen over the deep forests of the Ardennes when 25 students, all of us aspiring to speak French, were summoned to our first class.

title: Space Telescope Getting an Eyeful
description: Stellar births and deaths are usually private affairs. Neither is visible to the eye, since in neither case can a star emit light.

title: THE CITY BALLET HAS BEEN DANCING BRILLIANTLY
description: The passion with which the New York City Ballet has danced during the season that has just ended has been matched only by its new overall technical brilliance. Rarely has the company been seen in such superb dancing condition. The reasons for this resurgence may be different. Like the planets, several factors have come together for a felicitous result.

title: SUPERFLUOUS FLOURISHES
description: Nobody really needs such things as a widebrimmed hat, a pair of lacy stockings, fancy gloves, a glittery choker, a bow tie or, for that matter, a lace-edged pocket handkerchief.

title: Touro Synagogue
description: To the Editor:

title: THE STYLISH LOOK
description: Certainly, it is not unreasonable to expect stylishness in new fashions, at least from the capable and trend-setting designers of the world. Their job, after all, is to periodically create new clothes that are attractive and modish, ideally even smart and chic.

title:
ART;
THREE AWARD WINNERS POSE CHALLENGES TO CONVENTION
description: ANTITRADITIONALISTS have clearly carried the day in ''Expo II,'' the nationwide art competition sponsored by the Northport Galleries. The three winners, Doris Lanier of New York City, Margaret Howlett of Tuckahoe, N.Y., and Neal Drobnis of Brookline, Mass., all try to reach us with innovations in expressive content and expressive uses of materials, and each is represented in the galleries' current awards show by several compelling examples that really drive themselves into our consciousness.

title: Adele Joyner Is Betrothed To Walter Mills Braswell
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Joyner of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Adele Marie Joyner, to Walter Mills Braswell, son of Mrs. James Porter Braswell of Plainfield, N.J., and the late Mr. Braswell.

title: Long Island Goes Nuclear or Bust
description: Long Islanders - indeed, all New Yorkers -face a difficult choice: live with the menace of nuclear power or pay dramatically higher electricity bills. Peter Cohalan, the Suffolk County Executive, has decided that the nearly completed $3.2 billion Shoreham nuclear plant must never be allowed to operate, and Governor Cuomo seems content to let him impose that judgment. Neither man seems to have adequately reckoned with, no less admitted, the drastic economic consequences.

title: Hollace Roe Has Nuptials
description: Hollace Lindsay Roe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Andrew Roe of Greenwich, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday to Ernesto Jose Mejer, son of Mrs. Jose Antonio Mejer of Palm Beach, Fla., formerly of Havana, and the late Mr. Mejer. The Rev. John Olofson, a Methodist minister, and the Rev. Thomas Guinan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich.

title: ISRAELIS REPORT SUCCESS OF NEW TYPE OF MISSILE
description: Israel disclosed this week that a new type of air-to-air missile had been used in Lebanon and had contributed to the victories over Syria in dogfights last June.

title: Sindy Solomon Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Solomon of Plainview, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sindy Solomon, to Andre Fedida, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abner Fedida of Merrick, L.I. A June wedding is planned. Miss Solomon, a registered nurse, is taking premedical courses at Queens College. Her fiance is a medical student at St. George's University in Grenada, the West Indies.

title: INDONESIA REOPENS AN ANCIENT TEMPLE
description: President Suharto officially reopened the temple of Borobudur this week after an eight-year effort by the Indonesian Government, Unesco and private organizations to restore it from the ravages of centuries of erosion, earthquakes and plunder.

title: Linda Lee Cushing to Wed Christopher McInerney
description: Dr. and Mrs. Charles Richmond Cushing of Fairfield, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Lee Cushing, to Christopher Michael McInerney, son of J. Barrett McInerney of Pittsfield, Mass., and the late Mrs. McInerney.

title: A HORSE RACE FOR HIGH STAKES AT TEACHERS' PENSION FUND
description: THE competition had thinned from seven investment managers in July t o three. Now, at an October meeting in Albany, each of the finalistsw as ready to make a pitch to the board of the New York State T eachers' Retirement Fund, which would decide the winner. At stake w ere hundreds of thousands of dollars in fees for managing a $250 m illion portfolio, one of the largest awards of pension assets in 1 982.

title: SAILING THE SEA AND DEDUCTING THE COST
description: SOME call it ''the Loveboat bill.'' Others believe that it is an i mportant piece of legislation that will be a boon to American cruisel ines and provide more jobs for American workers.

title: SUFFOLK SEWERS: QUESTIONS LINGER OVER FINANCING
description: THE $1 billion Southwest Sewer District is nearing completion, but the nettlesome burden of financing the project has barely begun. And each taxpayer in Suffolk County may be wondering how much will come out of his pocket whether he lives in the sewer district or not.

title: Correction
description: An item in Travel Advisory on Feb. 13 gave an incorrect date for a Boston Architectural Center tour of France. The tour runs from May 20 to June 3.

title: A GAZA TOWN IS A CASUALTY OF THE PEACE
description: Ahmed Hammad stood in Israeli-held territory and gazed through four chain-link and barbed-wire fences, past a blacktop security road and across 50 yards of cleared no man's land into Egypt, where his brother's wife and children were waving to him.

title: CULTURAL COLLOQUIUM IN PARIS: THE REAL ACHIEVEMENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: A SPRING CORNUCOPIA OF SHOWS
description: MARCH not only means the advent of spring - the 21st, to be exact - but also a lot of good antiques shows. From Thursday through Saturday, the Junior Woman's Club of Ridgewood will hold its annual antiques show at the Woman's Club, 215 West Ridgewood Avenue. This is a nice small event, with 28 dealers displaying wares ranging from country to sophisticated, plus some added specialties such as clocks and jewelry.

title: FROM THE BOER WAR BRUCE BERESFORD TURNS TO TEXAS LIFE
description: ''Ihave a feeling it really doesn't matter what other films I make,'' says Bruce Beresford. ''I'll always be introduced as Bruce Beresford who made 'Breaker Morant' ''

title: Miss Fox and P.H. Congleton to Marry at Groton
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard K. Fox of Groton, Mass., and Lancaster, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carole Denise Fox, to Ens. Peter H. Congleton of the Navy, son of Sandra Orr Congelton of Somerville, Mass., and Richard J. Congleton of Groton, Mass., and Oxford, Me.

title: ON FILM, PINTER'S 'BETRAYAL' DISPLAYS NEW SUBTLETIES
description: Aman and a woman - not young, not old - are sitting in a pub; the silence between them reverberates with conflicting emotions. Even a casual observer might discern that they are hardly strangers, and yet there is no easy intimacy; they are guarded, defensive, their familiarity fraught with tension. The man is jittery; the woman looks infinitely sad. They do not meet each other's eyes.

title: Candace Scott Appleton To Wed Douglas Roy Ruff
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L.T. Appleton 3d of Ocean City, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Candace Scott Appleton, to Douglas Roy Ruff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy David Ruff of Westbury, L.I. The wedding is planned for May 21.

title: HOUSTON DEFEATS RICE BY 86-52
description: The second-ranked Houston Cougars, led by Clyde Drexler and Akeem Abdul Olajuwon, defeated Rice, 86-52, tonight to extend their unbeaten streak to 18 games.

title: WHAT GOOD DOES SPRING TRAINING DO?
description: THE annual rite of spring training is in full course for major league baseball clubs. ''Rite'' is an undoubted word for it. In one respect, at least, spring training is like an egg cream or the city of Vienna: If it didn't exist, somebody would have to invent it.

title: Teacher Criticizes Jobless Pay System
description: I sympathize with the writer of the letter (Jan. 23) who detailed a frustrating bout with the state's unemployment compensation system. As a substitute teacher who has no employment during the summer and no assurance of work for the next school year, I am denied unemployment compensation.

title: JERSEYAN KEY TO DAVIS CUP
description: WHEN the United States faces Argentina in the opening of the Davis Cup matches in Buenos Aires Friday, the outcome may hinge on what Alex Mayer Sr. taught his son, Gene, on New Jersey tennis courts many years ago.

title: BARNARD SHIFTING CURRICULUM TO GIVE MATH MORE EMPHASIS
description: Barnard College has adopted new curriculum requirements that reflect the growing significance of mathematics in a computer-oriented society, the changing career goals of its students and the school's new relationship to Columbia College.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Auto Racing

title: SENATE CREATES AN ARMS-CONTROL FORUM
description: President Reagan was obviously annoyed. The Senate Foreign Relations Committee's rejection, by a 9-to-8 vote, of Kenneth L. Adelman as director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency was a painful embarrassment. Politically, President Reagan could be hurt even more. The Senate floor debate on Mr. Adelman's nomination seems likely to become a forum for broad questioning of Mr. Reagan's own commitment to successful arms negotiations, and a divisive Senate discussion is likely to add to West European opposition to the Administration's arms-control approach.

title: CLOSTER
description: BY the time the first Northern Railroad Company train chugged t hrough in 1859, Closter was already, in a modest way, a commercial c enter for the small suburban communities of northeastern New Jersey.S everal general stores were operating on Closter's main street and b lacksmiths, grist mills and lumberyards provided essential services f or the area's businesses and residents.

title: OWNERS ARE DISMAYED BY PRICED-BASED ASSESSMENTS
description: OFFICE tenants in the city, the real-estate industry and the city i tself have a heavy stake in conversations that have begun with Koch a dministration officials on the way the city assesses commercial p roperty.

title: HOW AN ORCHESTRA CHOSE ITS NAME
description: WHAT'S in a name? That depends. When the people who founded the New York Virtuosi, who perform this afternoon at 3 P.M. at the Wunsch Arts Center in Glen Cove, looked around for a name for their chamber orchestra - which draws heavily on New York Philharmonic musicians for its members - they wanted to keep it ''short and simple,'' said its music director, Kenneth Klein.

title: PRINCETON UPDATING ITS HOCKEY RINK
description: PRINCETON UNIVERSITY is renovating one of its oldest athletic buildings - Baker Memorial Hockey Rink -while preserving its cathedral-like stone facade and slate roof.

title: By Sports of The Times; The $5 Million Contract
description: HERSCHEL WALKER's $5 million three-year contract with the New Jersey Generals is as uncomplicated as an off-tackle play. According to sources in Georgia and in the United States Football League, the 20-year-old running back already has collected $2 million: his $1 million signing bonus and his $1 million salary for the Generals' 18-game season that opens next Sunday in Los Angeles.

title: MARCHING IN THE PARADE
description: THERE has always been a parade. At least as long as I can remember. I know because one of my grandfathers marched in it. Only one, and I remember asking why the other one didn't. My mother told me it was because he had ''lost'' his pension and was ashamed. I never understood that, and now I finally do.

title: TWENTY YEARS AFTER THE FEMININE MYSTIQUE
description: It is 20 years now since "The Feminine Mystique" was published. I am still awed by the revolution that book helped spark. That I was able to put it together at the time it was needed is something of a mystery to me. Even now, women -and men - stop me on the street to reminisce about where they were when they read it - ''I was in the maternity ward with my third kid, and then I decided to go to law school.''

title: Tarkanian Explains
description: In reply to recently published criticisms of poor academic achievements by basketball players who have performed for him during his nine years at Nevada-Las Vegas, Coach Jerry Tarkanian yesterday cited weak scholastic credentials of the players as the main reason for their poor record of graduation. Speaking from Morgantown, W.Va., where his top-ranked Runnin' Rebels play West Virginia today, Tarkanian said that only six players who enrolled at Las Vegas since 1974 had received undergraduate degrees, because ''more than half of them are junior college transfers and almost all of them are innercity kids.''

title: Mary Joel Holin Is Wed
description: Mary Joel Holin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Holin of Baltimore, was married yesterday to Peter A. Feiden, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elliott Feiden of Mamaroneck, N.Y. Rabbi Morton Kanter and the Rev. Jerry Hall, a Roman Catholic chaplain at Georgetown University, performed the ceremony at the Cloisters, a children's museum in Brooklandville, Md. The bridegroom, a housing specialist with the Agency for International Development in Washington, has been assigned to Nairobi, Kenya, where the couple will live.

title: Setting the Record Straight on Salads
description: Alas, another error in history, this time committed by Constance Alexander (''The Visigoths' Legacy: Salad Bars,'' Jan. 23). It is a fact, albeit buried in the historical annals, that the salad bar predated the Visigoths by at least three centuries and was one of the immensely significant contributions of the Sondergartensons.

title: A LUXURY HOTEL IN THE AMAZON
description: Most travelers to Brazil fly unaware over Manaus, a booming city in the middle of the Amazonian jungle. Even those who have heard of Manaus usually know this jungle-surrounded city 1,000 miles up the Amazon River from the Atlantic Ocean primarily because of its splendid 19th-century opera house, built when the city was the center of the Brazilian rubber boom. Few travelers are aware that just a few minutes from Eduardo Gomes International Airport there is a sophisticated resort hotel that ranks with some of the best in the world.

title: ZIMBABWE KILLINGS SAID TO REACH 1,000
description: Reports from rural missions, schools and hospitals in the province of Matabeleland indicate that the death toll in violence in the last month may have been as high as one thousand people, with many more beaten and tortured by Zimbabwe's Army.

title: IS KORCHNOI GETTING WORRIED?
description: Poor form continues to plague Viktor Korchnoi as his quarter-final Candidates Match with the Hungarian grandmaster Lajos Portisch approaches.

title: A JEWISH LEGACY DRAWS TO A CLOSE IN NORTH CHINA
description: Hannah Agre huddled forlornly on a wooden chair in her small room, probably the last survivor of the European Jews who migrated to China.

title: A YOUNG CANDIDATE BOWS OUT
description: WHILE it did not rock the nation, or even get discussed on Agronsky & Company, his announcement not to run took me by surprise. In fact, it made me reevaluate the whole political system.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Hit Stuff?

title: AND BEAR IN MIND
description: Other recent books that in the opinion of the Book Review staff are of particular literary, topical or scholarly interest: THE AFRICANS, by David Lamb. (Random House, $17.95.) A study of the continent today.

title: STARTING WITH HOMER
description: ANCIENT WRITERS Greece and Rome. Edited by T. James Luce. Volume One: Homer to Caesar. Volume Two: Lucretius to Ammianus Marcellinus. 1,148 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $110.

title: MANY PARTIES COMPETING IN SENEGALESE VOTE TODAY
description: Senegalese voters will choose from an array of parties and candidates in elections on Sunday, but President Abdou Diouf and the ruling Socialist Party seem likely to be returned to power.

title: Sevres
description: To the Editor:

title: WEST POINT FOCUS
description: To the Editor:

title: RIGHT STUFF IN THE BULLY PULPIT
description: Does John Glenn have the Right Stuff in his head, and the fire in the belly, to ascend the bully pulpit? Here is a report on three etymological finds that will delight all dedicated phrase detectives: A few weeks ago, it was pointed out here that fire in the belly - that burning lust for office without which no candidate can be taken seriously - was traced by the Oxford English Dictionary to a citation in 1951. The lexicographers had a hunch the phrase was of British origin, recently imported into American political parlance.

title: IN NEW HAVEN, A NEW KING OF BABY BOOM
description: ''IT was shocking. And wonderful. I think my heart stopped. I will never forget that moment.'' ''That moment,'' according to the speaker, a 38-year-old Fairfield County woman, was when she returned home on a late December day from her job as an account executive for a New York City firm and found out that she was pregnant.

title: U.S. JOBS LEGISLATION WOULD HELP L.I.R.R. ON ITS ELECTRIFICATION
description: The emergency jobs legislation adopted by the House Appropriations Committee today contains $15 million for the electrification of the Long Island Rail Road from Northport east to Smithtown.

title: CHRISTMAS PAST, A FILLY, WINS GULFSTREAM HANDICAP
description: It was hard to pick between the filly and the colt on paper, and only a neck separated them at the finish line today at Gulfstream Park: Christmas Past, the champion 3-yearold filly of last year, running against colts under high weight; and Crafty Prospector, a lightly raced but brilliant colt with a rich future.

title: DANCE: BATTERY TROUPE PERFORMS 'CASTE SYSTEM'
description: The curtain went up on a program by the Battery Dance Company Thursday at Pace University's Schimmel Center and revealed dim figures bathed in the silvery obfuscation of a scrim, with tall, square light sculptures framing the assembly. The dance was ''The Caste System,'' a new piece by the company founder, Jonathan Hollander. But the rest was disappointing.

title: SHELLFISH IN THE SOUND
description: A GROUP of marine researchers and a team of divers will embark on a unusual project this spring in which the depths of Long Island Sound will be tested for commercial shellfish production.

title: Sally S. Stewart To Marry July 9
description: Mr. and Mrs. James William Stewart Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sally Slaughter Stewart, to Dr. Mark William Mohney, son of Dr. and Mrs. Glenn E. Mohney of Venice, Fla.

title: The New Math In Chicago
description: The history of Chicago politics being what it is, the late Mayor Richard J. Daley may not only have turned over in his grave last week, but also got up to vote. The remnant of the political machine he founded was defeated and it appeared the next Mayor of the nation's second largest city would be a black man.

title: A DOCTOR ON BEING SICK
description: VITAL SIGNS A Young Doctor's Struggle With Cancer. By Fitzhugh Mullan, M.D. 203 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $12.50. FITZHUGH MULLAN was 32, with a wife and a 3-year-old child, when he learned that cancer was eating away at his chest, and he didn't know how to behave. Young people do not have rules or protocols for dying. Further, Fitzhugh Mullan was a doctor, and for a doctor to become a patient is an altogether disorienting reversal, a loss not just of health but of identity. He showed the classic signs of doctors who get sick: a sense of being betrayed by his own body; a detachment; an objectifying of his illness, as though he were making clinical notes on somebody else's case. ''Vital Signs,'' written in that predictably detached way, is his story of what happened. And what happened was awful.

title: WINNING HIGHER UTILITY RATE IS CALLED A MATTER OF TIMING
description: On Wednesday, Con Edison won a $240 million rate increase. The next day, the Public Service Electric and Gas Company in New Jersey lost a bid for a $465 million increase and was ordered to cut energy passalong costs to consumers by $135 million.

title: THE BRIGHTEST AND THE BEST
description: There are accomplished and sound designers in all the major fashion capitals of the world, but those of Europe - particularly Paris - often provided the punctuations of any season's collections. It is partly because of their impressive talents, and also because of their access tot he supporting creative crafts.

title: EXCESS WATER IN SOUTH FLORIDA THREATENS WILDLIFE
description: After suffering one of its most severe droughts only 18 months ago, south Florida now has an excess of water that threatens fauna and flora in Everglades National Park and the St. Lucie River estuary.

title: Correction
description: The article ''Why 'Tucker's Witch' Missed'' in the Arts and Leisure section on Nov. 21 incompletely described the credits of William Bast and Paul Huson, the creators of the television series.

title: Stepien Expects Accord Soon on Cavaliers Sale
description: Ted Stepien, owner of the Cleveland Cavaliers, said today that he expected to reach a tentative agreement by Monday or Tuesday for sale of his team to a group headed by the real estate developer John Ferchill.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: PREHISTORIC TIMES

title: Suellen T. Wilson To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Fredric J. Wilson Jr. of Old Greenwich, Conn., and West Stockbridge, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Suellen Todd Wilson, to Jeffrey Weston Wheeler of Boca Raton, Fla., son of Mrs. Weston Wheeler and Thomas B. Wheeler of Loudonville, N.Y. A May 14 wedding is planned.

title: CRITICS PRESS FOR PROGRAMS TO BACK UP DRINKING AGE
description: ALTHOUGH the state's legal drinking age was raised to 21 on Jan. 1, liquor merchants in this university town do not expect to feel the first major impact until September. That is because most students were within the legal drinking age before the new law took effect.

title: BLACK JUDGES CRITICIZE KOCH ON COURT POSTS
description: A delegation of black judges met with Mayor Koch last week and accused his administration of being less than vigorous in appointing blacks as judges in the Criminal and Family Courts.

title: ART SAMPLER
description: WHEN ''chiaroscuro'' is mentioned, perhaps the brooding canvases of Caravaggio come to mind, their somber shadows contrasting with their theatrical bursts of light. Or perhaps the religious works of Rembrandt in which the heavy darkness and the effulgent glows of light seem like metaphors for evil and good.

title: FRENCH POETRY IN A POT
description: ''Eating pot-au-feu is an act that gives significance to life,'' writes one French food critic. A bit precious, to be sure, but few peasant dishes are as fragrant, satisfying or healthfully nourishing, as a superb pot-au-feu, served in two or three courses on an unhurried Sunday afternoon.

title: Cuomo Turns To Minority Appointments
description: After two months on the job, Governor Cuomo is beginning make good on campaign promises to give minorities a greater role in state government. Last week he announced the appointment of three black and five Hispanic officials and a three-part program to boost minority hiring.

title: A BID FOR TRACKING NOMINAL G.N.P.
description: MONETARY policy is floundering. Now that the Federal Reserve has b acked away from its 1981 policy of extreme monetary contraction, it h as embarked on a course of rapid growth. Many economists have a pplauded the expansionary impact of the latest turnaround. Others a re concerned that we are in just another go phase in the sad historyo f stop-go monetary policy.

title: ITALY FERRE
description: Without question, Gianfranco Ferre stands out as the most interesting design talent now working in Milan. His clothes are original, yet they are eminently comfortable, based on simple, wellcut designs that have a casual precision.

title: Voting Brings Murderous Days To Assam State
description: The northeastern Indian state of Assam last week became a horrifying flashpoint of the subcontinent's poverty and ethnic and religious hatred. More than 1,500 people have been killed.

title: POST OFFICE TO ACCEPT WEIGHTIER PACKAGES
description: Starting next week, Americans may send larger and heavier packages through the mail, the Postal Service announced Friday.

title: Deborah E. Curtis Planning Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Peck Curtis Jr. of Rochester have announced the engagement of their daughter, Deborah Eaton Curtis, to William Michael Donovan, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Francis Donovan of Lynnfield, Mass., and Marco Island, Fla. A September wedding is planned.

title: Lyle Kendall to Be Bride Of Philip Molinari in July
description: Dr. and Mrs. Allen B. Kendall of Rumson, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Lyle Kendall, to Philip L. Molinari, son of Mr. and Mrs. Tullio J. Molinari of Tuckahoe, N.Y. A July wedding is planned.

title: ELIZABETH ARRIVES FOR COAST HOLIDAY
description: Queen Elizabeth II sailed into San Diego Bay aboard her yacht today and had her first look at the West Coast of the United States.

title: A SECOND LOOK AT KANBAN
description: Japanese companies are famous, even notorious, for pursuing information about American methods and markets. But the number of comparable efforts by American concerns in Japan is small, even though the pitfalls of being blind to trends and techniques developing in Japan have become all too apparent to American industry.

title: Jane A. Parsons Bride Of Justice Arnold Fein
description: Associate Justice Arnold L. Fein of the State Supreme Court was married yesterday to Jane Askin Parsons, a psychiatric social worker. State Supreme Court Justice Martin B. Stecher performed the ceremony in the courthouse of the Appellate Division (First Department), of which the bridegroom has been a member since 1978.

title: What Recovery?
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Sheri Lynn Ross Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mrs. Philip B. Kimmel of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Donald M. Ross of New York of the engagement of their daughter, Sheri Lynn Ross, to Joseph R. Mendes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond F. Mendes of Marlborough, Mass. A September wedding is planned.

title: NEW RANK RAISES HOPES OF COLLEGES
description: AFTER Tuesday, there will be no more four-year state colleges in Connecticut. Instead, the present Eastern, Western, Southern and Central Connecticut State Colleges will collectively comprise Connecticut State University.

title: DANCE JUBILATION! COMPANY AT RIVERSIDE CHURCH THEATER
description: The Jubilation! Dance Company, which performed Wednesday at the Theater of the Riverside Church, lives up to its name with accomplished dancers who really do look jubilant. But that keen edge of excitement and the clarity with which they dance is dimmed a little by the familiarity of what they dance.

title: Stacey Coleman Plans To Marry R.R. Morse
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herbert R. Coleman of Cliffside Park, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Stacey Ann Coleman, to Robert Randolph Morse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry E. Morse of Palos Verdes, Calif. An October wedding is planned.

title: Annals of Medical Misbehavior
description: Some doctors are notorious for keeping patients waiting, but it's nothing compared to the time the New York State Health Department takes getting to notorious doctors. Officials reported last week that more than 1,400 complaints against physicians were awaiting action, most for up to two years but a few dating to 1976.

title: N.Y.U. Yes, But Violets No
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: A STUDY of a master plan for the Westchester County Airport prepared for the county in October 1980, strongly recommended the addition of a short third runway, 2,900 feet long, to enable slow-moving planes to fly in their own traffic stream and not be mixed in with fastmoving planes, particularly jets.

title: SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 27, 1983
description: International

title: FOR FOSTER, 1983 IS YEAR TO PROVE HIMSELF
description: George Foster sat on a wooden stool in the cold and windy training camp of the Mets today and considered the numbers: He is 34 years old, he is earning close to $2 million a year, he just had the worst season of his career.

title: A Historic Inn In San German,; Near San Juan
description: In the town of San German, whose roots run four centuries deep into the history of Puerto Rico, a restored home - hewing to tradition with its arches, latticework, ornate verandas, antique tiles and frescoes - has been designated the latest member of the island's parador system.

title: CELEBRATING WOMEN'S HISTORY WEEK
description: THE struggles and achievements of women past and present and the issues facing women today will be the focus of events commemorating Women's History Week, from next Sunday through March 13. Sponsored by several county organizations and colleges, the programs will extend beyond the designated week and run throughout March. Related events will also be held in April and May.

title: Spain Bursts A Private Bubble
description: Spain's largest private enterprise, a high-flying symbol of the country's takeoff in the '60's, was shot down last week. The Government took over Rumasa, a conglomerate it contended was mismanaged so badly that it had become a threat to the economy.

title: DIRECTORS COME TO GRIPS WITH HISTORY
description: As history reinvents itself, so have filmmakers always explored ways in which to interpret those reinventions. From D.W. Griffith to Sergei Eisenstein, from Abel Gance to Cecil B. DeMille, from Erich von Stroheim to Darryl Zanuck, historical films, including two especially successful current releases, have been designed to exploit, teach, amuse, bore and titillate us. Some work in thoroughly conventional ways, as Richard Attenborough's ''Gandhi,'' and some so obliquely that history would appear to be a second thought, as in Ettore Scola's ''Nuit de Varennes,'' which is actually about nothing less than the entire French Revolution.

title: And Still Champion
description: The London Economist has been around a long time and should know better. A few weeks ago it said ''E.T.'' was ''the world's most successful movie,'' with $200 million from rentals to date.

title: Letters; Is 3% Law Illegal?
description: To the Editor:

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS
description: Optimists triumph. Those who see oil price cuts as beneficial and not potentially disruptive gained the ascendancy last week, and as other news on falling interest rates and low inflation poured in the stock market soared. The first reaction of the market on Wednesday was to falter after the five Arab members of OPEC agreed on a reported $4-$6 price cut. But after digesting the news, the Dow Jones industrial average on Thursday spurted 24.87, to 1,121.81, and closed above 1,100 for the first time ever. On Friday, the market dipped 0.87 point, to close at 1,120.94, up 28.12 on the week. Chief among the cheer leaders was President Reagan, who saw ''good news for the world economy'' in the falling oil prices.

title: Dr. John Lattimer Is Awarded Valentine Medal for Urology
description: Dr. John K. Lattimer, professor and chairman emeritus of the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, has been given the Valentine Medal and Award for outstanding work in urology.

title: Press Ban; Is Protested
description: In weighing the often conflicting demands of a free press and a fair trial, should the fact that a defendant faces the death penalty in any way tip the scales against reporters? New Jersey, one of 36 states to reinstate capital punishment in the last decade, became one of the first to consider that question last week.

title: AIRING BIGOTRY CHARGES
description: AN unusual tribunal is scheduled to hear next Friday an unusual case in an unusual ''courtroom,'' as the Nassau County Republican leadership attempts to remove from the party a Republican who has been accused of bigotry.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: POLITICS being what it is, elected and politically appointed jobs tend to be on the impermanent side. Do the men and women whose jobs get carried away on the tides of public opinion head for the unemployment lines?

title: RANGERS BEATEN BY 6-3
description: The Nordiques scored two goals in 30 seconds midway through the final period tonight and went on to a 6-3 victory over the Rangers at the Colisee.

title: Q&A
description: Question: My husband and I are planning a trip to New Orleans in April. Can you give us information on what kind of weather to expect as well as what to do and see in the New Orleans area at that time of year? -H.P., Clark, N.J.

title: JAZZ UPSETS LAKERS AS EAVES SCORES 20
description: Jerry Eaves scored 20 points tonight to lead the Utah Jazz to an upset victory over the Los Angeles Lakers, 101-92.

title: No Headline
description: GERULAITIS WINS IN KUWAIT BY 7-6, 4-6, 6-3

title: STATE'S THRIFT BANKS SHOWING GROWTH
description: SIX Connecticut savings banks showed enough growth in 1982 to make their way onto the list of the 100 largest savings banks in the country, giving Connecticut 14 of the spots on the list, a number exceeded only by New York.

title: 'GHOSTS' AGAIN, BUT RESPECTABLY
description: IN his ever more enlightening ''Director's Notebook,'' a by-now indispensable feature of the Nassau Repertory Theater's program, Clinton J. Atkinson anticipates a seasoned theatergoer's exclamatory question: ''Not another production of 'Ghosts'?''

title: AIMING HIGH AT PETERS VALLEY
description: EVEN on a gray February morning, Sheila Stiven can project confidence in a bright future for the Peters Valley Craft Center. ''I want the whole place to sparkle,'' she said recently, with the conviction of purpose.

title: CHICAGOAN SEES HIS VICTORY AS MINORITY GROUP 'LESSON'
description: Harold Washington, the black Congressman who rode atop an overwhelmingly racial vote to upset the Democratic machine in the three-way mayoral primary here this week, sees nationwide significance in the election results.

title: Asa Shiverick 3d Weds The Rev. Weatherhead
description: The Rev. Martha Melissa Weatherhead, daughter of Mrs. Stephen John Knerly of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, was married there yesterday to Asa Shiverick 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Shiverick Jr. of Hunting Valley, Ohio. The Rev. Dr. Henry W. Andersen performed the ceremony at the Fairmount Presbyterian Church.

title: 'THE GIFT,' A FARCE SET IN A HOTEL IN VENICE
description: The title of ''The Gift'' refers not to a thing but to a person. She is a high-priced call girl hired as a going-away present for a retiring bank employee (Pierre Mondy) by his friends, who hope this will put spice back into his marriage (even though he is married to Claudia Cardinale, who does not lack for spice). Well, look, either you find this an enchanting notion or you don't. In the former case, you're probably an admirer of the school of French bedroom farce to which ''The Gift'' is an unsurprising but good-natured addition, and perhaps you will enjoy this film for the three S's that are its staples: scenery, silliness and skin. Otherwise, better not bother.

title: Questions Confronting Job Seekers
description: The discussion of the Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory (M.M.P.I.) is misleading (''Touchy Questions Confront Job Seekers,'' Feb. 6). The questions listed do not all appear in the M.M.P.I.; some of the questions do ask for personal information.

title: Miss Duffy Is to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Duffy of East Aurora, N.Y, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Burns Duffy, to Ian R. Grosse, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Grosse of Tybee Island, Ga.

title: THE APPEAL OF MILITARY DETAILING
description: One of the interesting trends in fashion this year is the fact that designers have moved on from taking ideas from civilian men's wear for women's clothes to borrowing from men's military uniforms. Here, a fashion historian takes a look at some of these new clothes and offers her opinion on what, exactly, is the appeal.

title: CHERYL DIRENZO TO MARRY THEODORE JOSEPH STRATIGOS
description: Mr. and Mrs. August Di Renzo of Muttontown, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cheryl Marie Di Renzo, to Theodore Joseph Stratigos, son of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher Stratigos of Massapequa Park, L.I. The wedding is planned for next winter.

title: SCARSDALE WOMAN SHARES HER SUCCESS
description: ''MEN are competitive by nature - all their training and education prepare them for the business world - but women have to learn to compete,'' said Patricia Duncanson of Scarsdale, president of the Duncanson Electric Company and chairman of the Governor's Advisory Council on Minority Business Enterprises.

title: LISTLESS ISLANDERS FALL TO RED WINGS, 5-3
description: These are the same New York Islanders, similar in face, style and design to the Islanders who won Stanley Cups in 1980, 1981 and 1982. Similar in every way - except results.

title: BRIDGE REPAIRS ARE SET
description: THE 56-year-old Benjamin Franklin Bridge, a crucial link for moving people between New Jersey and Pennsylvania in the Philadelphia area, is coming apart at the seams and will have to undergo costly, extensive repairs.

title: PATIENCE: A LOST VIRTUE?
description: THAT honking from the car behind me at the tollbooth cannot be the sole outlet for its driver - a well-dressed man in a handsome new car. Can't he understand that something has gone awry? The toll collector is trying to make change and use a handkerchief at the same time.

title: PARIS CHANEL AND CHLOE
description: Of all the top-notch fashion designers, none is more prolific than Karl Lagerfeld. Officially, he is the designer for the French ready-to-wear house of Chloe.

title: THE MAN WHO HAS A CORPORATE TIGER BY THE TAIL
description: WAYNE M. HOFFMAN has put aside the leisure comforts and inner-circle privileges of the powerful Republican, corporate-executive crowd of Palm Springs. He has not played a round of golf with former President Gerald R. Ford, his friend and adviser, in many months and his handicap has suffered, climbing to a duffer's grade of 20 from a respectable nine.

title: Bonnie H. Hunt To Wed in May
description: Dr. Donald C. Hunt and Elizabeth A. Hunt, both of Middlebury, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Bonnie Heather Hunt, to Gregory Gilson Hogan, son of Dr. and Mrs. Gilbert F. Hogan of Woodbridge, Conn., and Quechee Lakes, Vt.

title: 'The Invention of Solitude'
description: Paul Auster's book starts with an event at once ordinary and unique, commonplace and incommunicable. His father, after a divorce and 15 years of living alone in a big house in New Jersey, ''in the best of health, not even old, with no history of illness,'' suddenly died. Their relationship had been composed in great part of remoteness and absence. Most of the feelings it had engendered and fostered had been unarticulated and unnoticed. Indeed, his father's inability to notice him had seemed to Mr. Auster one of the principal and abiding elements of their knowing each other. ''It was not that I felt he disliked me. It was just that he seemed distracted, unable to look in my direction. And more than anything else, I wanted him to take notice of me. ... The more aloof he was, the higher the stakes became for me. ... I realized that even if I had done all the things I had hoped to do, his reaction would have been exactly the same. Whether I succeeded or failed did not essentially matter to him. ... his perception of me would never change ... we were fixed in an unmoveable relationship, cut off from each other on opposite sides of a wall. Even more than that, I realized that none of this had anything to do with me. It had only to do with him. Like everything else in his life, he saw me only through the mists of his solitude.''

title: CAPE TOWN AUTHORITIES SEIZE HUNDREDS OF BLACK SQUATTERS
description: The authorities raided a squatter camp on the outskirts of Cape Town on Friday, arresting hundreds of squatters for being in the city illegally under South Africa's black influx control laws.

title: MUSIC: CONCERT FOR BACH SYMPOSIUM
description: As the concluding musical event in the three-day Columbia Bach Symposium Friday night, the organizers of that convocation outdid themselves. They brought together for the first time two of our very best early-music groups, Pomerium Musices, Alexander Blachly's 12-member chorus, and Concert Royal, James Richman's originalinstruments ensemble.

title: WHAT THE STATE MUST DO TO WIN HIGH-TECH RACE
description: HIGH TECHNOLOGY. It is a fast track and everybody has joined the race. Connecticut's official entry came in December, when Governor O'Neill named a state commission charged to develop a plan to attract high-technology industries here.

title: ANOTHER THREAT TO BIG OIL'S PROFITS
description: IT'S been an anxious week for the American oil industry. The mighty OPEC cartel, which helped the oil companies garner huge profits in t he 1970's, raised widespread fears of a price collapse as it feuded over how much to cut its prices. In an atmosphere of chaos, the cost of oil was falling to levels that most analysts would have thought i mpossible only a few months ago.

title: Susan Elliot Billerbeck To Wed D.W. Whalen
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harry A. Billerbeck of Middletown, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Elliot Billerbeck, to Daniel William Whalen, son of Dr. and Mrs. Gerald F. Whalen of Shrewsbury, N.J. An August wedding is planned.

title: Sine Nomine to Sing Rare Choral Works
description: The Sine Nomine Singers, conducted by Harry Saltzman, will offer rarely performed choral works tonight at 8 o'clock in Merkin Hall at Abraham Goodman House, at 129 West 67th Street.

title: BRAZIL'S BEAT ALTERS BLACK POP
description: Rarely in the recent history of American popular music have black and white pop been as effectively segregated as they are today. Only two of last week's top 10 singles and one of the top 10 albums were by black artists, and while the percentage of black music disks on the best-seller charts has been somewhat higher at various times during the past few years, last week's figures are by no means unusual.

title: 3 YOUTHS TO PLAY WITH PHILHARMONIA
description: IN the first concert of its kind in the county honoring young artists, three teen-age musicians will perform with the Philharmonia Virtuosi at the State University of New York at Purchase next Sunday.

title: U.S. Warns Scientists Of Lethal Africa Virus
description: Medical researchers have found that an African virus under study in American laboratories is a strain of the lethal Rift Valley fever virus, and Federal health officials warn that it requires special research care.

title: OVERHAULING MONTGOMERY WARD
description: ONE recent evening, Stephen L. Pistner, president and chief executive of Montgomery Ward & Company, left his office and headed for his car. He was carrying a lamp.''I have a passion for fixing things,'' he said. ''This lamp has been giving me a hard time, but I'll work on it some more tonight.''

title: The Alhambra
description: To the Editor:

title: ROBERT J. WILSON, AIRLINE PIONEER AND BUSINESS LEADER, DIES AT 80
description: Robert J. Wilson, one of the nation's early airline executives and the executive secretary of the National Alliance of Businessmen from 1969 to 1978, died of cancer Friday in Miami. He was 80 years old.

title: My Reception, Your Shivaree
description: Since I am a Middle Westerner transplanted 20 years ago to the East, I especially enjoy William Safire's discussions of regional language differences, such as ''My Reception, Your Shivaree'' (On Language, Jan. 23). He mentions the Dictionary of American Regional English, which will be published soon.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
BUYER'S FEES BECOMING INCREASINGLY COMMON
description: The practice of charging a buyer's fees is a relatively recent development at numismatic auction sales held in the United States, but it appears to have gained a firm foothold and is now considered almost the rule rather than the exception.

title:
GARDENING;
USING FOLIAGE COLOR TO ACCENT GARDEN
description: THERE exists a long-standing disagreement among gardeners as to the merit of using trees and shrubs with colored foliage in the landscape. While some enthusiastically recommend their use as a means of creating interest, others decry their use, using such terms as gauche and overpowering to convey their distaste.

title: THE COVENANT OF ISRAEL
description: The Kahan commission's report on the massacre in Lebanon reminds us that one of the major concerns facing modern Israeli society is the challenge of integrating Judaic morality with national power. The command to become a holy nation is given a firm basis in reality when a society does not evaluate its political and military options solely by the law of national self-interest.

title: THE EMERGENCE OF ANDROPOV
description: In less than four months as leader of the Soviet Union, Yuri V.

title: JAZZ
description: While the Kool Jazz Festival was in town last June, Steve Getz, then the manager and booker of Fat Tuesday's, put together a complementary festival in the Third Avenue jazz club, a highlight of which was the reappearance for two nights of the Jazztet, a six-piece group organized in November, 1959, by the saxophonist Benny Golson and the trumpeter-flugelhornist Art Farmer.

title: No Headline
description: February 27, 1983 NONFICTION ANCIENT WRITERS: Greece and Rome. Edited by T. James Luce. 10 DIRE MASTERY: Discipleship From Freud to Lacan.

title: Quebec Breaks Off Talks With Teachers Abruptly
description: After just a few minutes at the bargaining table, Quebec officials abruptly broke off negotiations Friday evening with leaders of 71,000 teachers who have temporarily halted their provincewide strike.

title: FROM GOETHE'S PEN TO SHAW'S SOCKS
description: Percy Bysshe Shelley's silver rattle, a lock of John Keats's hair and one of Amy Lowell's 40 pipes are among the mementos of 80 writers on view in ''Honour'd Relics,'' an offbeat, thoroughly engaging exhibition at the Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street, through March 31.

title: Mets Tickets Go on Sale This Tuesday at Shea
description: The Mets announced yesterday that tickets for all home games for the 1983 season would go on sale Tuesday at Shea Stadium.

title: 'COOKING' AND OTHER WAYS TO GIVE WOOD A CURVED SHAPE
description: BENDING ordinary wood or plywood to a curved shape can enhance many home woodworking projects - for example, when building furniture with curved legs or cabinets with curved fronts, or when making curved railings, and even for building homemade sports equipment such as a toboggan or custom-made curved backpacking board.

title: BOUNDARY DISPUTE IN 25TH YEAR
description: Andrew Kish tells his story in impatient, sometimes vehement, bursts -a story of many arrests over a minor dispute, of the death of his wife and the arrests of two of his sons. It is a story of a battle that has been going on for 25 years, with no ending - happy or otherwise - in sight. CARTERET THIS borough is classified as ''urban suburban'' by the state, probably because more than 20,000 people are fitted into its 4.9 square miles.

title: FOR CYPRIOTS, OLD DIVISIONS ONLY DEEPEN
description: The imaginary line that cuts across this island of 650,000 people divides it these days into two increasingly estranged worlds.

title:
ANTIQUES;
A SUGAR BOWL FULL OF SYMBOLS
description: DURING the 17th through the early 19th centuries, as with other imported luxuries of the time - salt, spices, tea and coffee - the use of sugar called for a variety of decorative as well as useful utensils.

title:
DINING OUT;
A TULIP-ACCENTED TOUCH OF ITALY
description: THE number of attractive restaurants that make dining out a total experience has increased with the opening of Il Tulipano, a stunningly appointed Italian restaurant in the Essex County community of Cedar Grove.

title: PERSHINGS PUT MOSCOW ON 6-MINUTE WARNING
description: Consider the justifications that have been offered for Pershing 2, an expensive weapon of advanced technology that the Pentagon wants to deploy later this year before it is fully tested.

title: 'An Ice-Cream War'
description: William Boyd's first novel, ''A Good Man in Africa'' (1982), was a tight and bitter comedy about sexual embarrassment and the British presence in postcolonial Africa, an unlikely but almost entirely successful combination of Kingsley Amis and V.S. Naipaul. In his new novel he turns to the little-known East African theater of World War I, in which armies from the British and German colonies there faced each other across the border of present-day Kenya and Tanzania. The British expected the campaign to be a joke; their control of the seas would keep the undermanned and undersupplied Germans from fighting for more than a few weeks. Hence this novel's title - and its irony, for the Germans kept fighting until the Armistice. ''An Ice-Cream War'' is less fully realized than its predecessor, but it is a more ambitious novel, and Mr. Boyd's ironic vision of the way individuals are dwarfed by the history through which they live is a large achievement.

title: ITS CREATOR SAYS HAIL AND FAREWELL TO 'M*A*S*H'
description: Tomorrow night at 8, ''M*A*S*H'' leaves prime-time television after presenting 251 episodes dealing with life - and death -in the 4077th Mobile Army Surgical Hospital during the Korean War; the two-and-a-half-hour special depicts the final days of that war and their effect on the characters portrayed by Alan Alda, Mike Farrell, Henry Morgan, Loretta Swit, Henry Ogden Stiers, Jamie Farr and William Christopher - actors who have spent more time in our living rooms than some of our own relatives.

title: PADILLA-SALAZAR 5,000 RACE TAKES SPOTLIGHT TODAY
description: Evelyn Ashford and her coach, Pat Connolly, penciled in the Vatican exhibit at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and shopping for clothes and toys as musts. Billy Olson had tickets for a Broadway show. Ed Kania planned to visit friends. And Dan Ripley said he would be content with a walk to Gimbels, a few games of Scrabble with Earl Bell's parents and just ''hanging around.''

title: IN WINTRY PARK, IT'S TENNIS SEASON
description: A PENETRATING southwesterly wind gusted across Scalzi Park here on a recent Saturday. Coupled with a 25-degree temperature reading, the gusts drove the wind-chill factor down around zero.

title: THE ROAD TO TOXIC POLLUTION
description: RINGWOOD TALES passed from generation to generation have left the clannish people of the Ramapo Mountains with a wealth of information - some accurate, some mere fantasy - about their 200 years in this sparse hill country of Passaic County.

title:
GARDENING;
USING FOLIAGE COLOR TO ACCENT GARDEN
description: THERE exists a long-standing disagreement among gardeners as to the merit of using trees and shrubs with colored foliage in the landscape. While some enthusiastically recommend their use as a means of creating interest, others decry their use, using such terms as gauche and overpowering to convey their distaste.

title: SELLING 'LOCATION'
description: Slightly different versions of the two styles of homes that Abraham Greenhouse and Leonard Gold are putting up in Roslyn can be spotted all around Long Island. One is a contemporary with slanted wood siding, the other a brick-faced colonial with a columned entry.

title: JENNIFER MULLER'S DANCE HERITAGE
description: Jennifer Muller is unusual in today's dance world. Her dancing and choreography reflect the vibrant, heroic tradition of early modern dance translated by a contemporary artist.

title: RULE CHANGE SET FOR U.S. TIMBER SALE BIDDING
description: The Agriculture Department is changing the rules for the way it sells national forest timber in the West to gain revenue it has been missing because it does not know exactly what it is selling.

title: Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: 'High-Tech Drive': A Lack of Cooperation
description: Re: ''High-Tech Drive Spurs Rivalry Among Colleges'' (Jan. 30): Resistance to proposed new degree programs from within the academic community is fairly common in New York State, and the certification process includes provisions for registering substantive objections. (In this context, Polytechnic Institute of New York - PINY - vigorously opposed New York University's recently approved Ph.D. program in applied science.)

title: Mailbox; Points at Issue On Ring Safety
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Suriname's Strongman Selects a Premier
description: Suriname's strongman, Lieut. Col. Desi Bouterse, has named Errol Alibux, a sociologist and former Cabinet minister, as the country's new Prime Minister.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Winter Clearance In Women's Fashions

title: IN AUSTRALIA, CANDIDATES DO THEIR BEST TO SAY THE WORST
description: In what will probably prove to be a futile call for moderation, The Sydney Morning Herald complained last week that in the national election campaign, ''any outrageous assertion can be made on the grounds of winning the hearts, if not the minds, of voters.'' The election, according to the newspaper, has become ''a matter of who can tell the most convincing lies. It is now a case of anything goes.''

title: WORK FOR TAXES: ALBANY TO WEIGH A SCARSDALE PLAN
description: FACED with the problem of residents - many of them elderly - struggling to pay their property taxes, the Scarsdale Village Board has asked the State Legislature for permission to enact a ''work for taxes'' program. The effort has prompted a companion bill that would establish a two-year pilot project to test the program in other communities.

title: Ian R. McPherson Engaged to Suzanne L. Sheeran
description: Kathryn L. Sheeran of Upper Montclair, N.J., and James Jennings Sheeran of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Suzanne L. Sheeran, to Ian Robert McPherson, son of Monica G. McPherson of Atlanta and the late Hugh A. McPherson.

title: TOMORROW, A JOB
description: IT'S Monday morning. The kids are back in school. My husband kisses me goodbye and leaves for work. I'm alone! I put the kitchen in order and straighten up the den in minutes. I've no time to waste. Today is the day. I'm going to get a job, I am. This time I'm determined to see it through.

title: ROYAL YACHT: NO POOL, NO BALLROOM AND NO NEED FOR NONSENSE
description: Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip held a reception on board the Britannia today less than two hours after the sleek navy blue yacht docked here.

title: Miss Brown Is to Wed Richard Gwathmey Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward W. Brown Jr. of Baltimore have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gwendolyn Cochran Brown, to Richard B. Gwathmey Jr., son of Mrs. Gwathmey of Louisa, Va., and Wilmington, N.C., and the late Mr. Gwathmey.

title: PARIS THE LASTING QUALITY OF SAINT LAURENT
description: Yves Saint Laurent's couture and ready-to-wear collections have influenced fashion for more than two decades.

title: DIANE SPUNIK ENGAGED TO JAMES J. CHUDOMEL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Snupik of Vestal, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Diane Marie Snupik, to James John Chudomel, son of Helen Wheeler Chudomel of River Edge, N.J., and the late John W. Chudomel. The wedding is to be in April.

title: DETECTING A DISGUISE
description: Sherlock Holmes enthusiasts will recall that the great detective frequently astonished Dr. Watson by popping up as an ostler, an old seaman, or a Nonconformist clergyman. The good Watson, of course, never pierced the impenetrable masquerade, but this suggests a question for the Baker Street Irregulars: Would Holmes, the eagleeyed detective, have seen through Holmes, the master of disguise?

title: MASS MARKET
description: Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: SHORT CUTS
description: Since styles in hair are closely related to those in clothes, American fashion designers, who have created sleek, sophisticated clothes for spring, recommend that haircuts follow suit.

title: DIOXIN 'DETECTIVE' WOULDN'T GIVE UP
description: The efforts to track down and clean up the dioxin waste feared to be contaminating scores of sites in Missouri called for skilled environmental detective work.

title: Freud
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Boudin's Lawyers Move for Separate Trial
description: Lawyers for Kathy Boudin have moved to have her tried separately from four of her co-defendants in the Brink's murder and robbery case.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest. Adjustable-rate mortgages have rates that vary during the term with one of the recognized credit indexes.

title: COMPETITIONS OPEN TO ASPIRING ARTISTS
description: THE path to a successful musical career is strewn with high hopes and lost dreams. In fact, there are so many obstacles to be overcome, so many frustrations to be endured, that many potentially splendid artists simply give up the fight.

title: Carter Is Signed by U.S.F.L.
description: Anthony Carter, the threetime all-America receiver from the University of Michigan, signed a contract today to play with the Michigan Panthers of the United States Football League.

title: D'AUBUISSON GIVES DEMOCRACY SOME ROPE
description: Roberto d'Aubuisson, the President of El Salvador's Constituent Assembly, winced. More than 400 straw-hatted, brown-faced campesinos lined the gallery of the assembly last week and shouted down at him, ''Long live agrarian reform!''

title: WILLIAMS CHOKED ON A BOTTLE CAP
description: Tennessee Williams choked to death on a plastic cap of the type used on bottles of nasal spray or eye solution, New York City's Chief Medical Examiner said yesterday.

title: DANGEROUS GROUND
description: WHEN flood waters of the Meramec River swept over this workingclass hamlet in December, few residents would have predicted the wave of political crisis that now engulfs the Environmental Protection Agency and laps at the steps of the White House. Yet the anguish here resonates clearly with concern in Washington over whether enough is being done to safeguard the nation from environmental hazards.

title: CRIME
description: Newly entering the crime field are Julie Smith and Magdalen Nabb. Miss Smith, who lives in Berkeley, Calif., uses a San Francisco setting in DEATH TURNS A TRICK (Walker, $11.95). Miss Nabb, who lives in Florence, writes out of her Italian experience in DEATH OF AN ENGLISHMAN (Scribners, $10.95).

title: THE DIRECTIONS OF THE INNOVATORS
description: One man's revolution is another's status quo, but there is no question that the goings-on in fashion through most of the 1960's were a radical change from anything that happened before. Women wore their hemlines shorter than they had at any time in the history of the Western world, baring much more leg than they had even in the 1920's, that other period of fashion upheaval. Even those whom the French discreetly refer to as ''of a certain age'' turned up their skirts one more inch at regular intervals and figured they looked younger each time. Younger women had no problem. They bought minis and then microminis.

title: The World of Soviet Psychiatry
description: Having studied the problem of the misuse of psychiatry for the last 12 years, and having visited the Kashchenko Psychiatric Hospital in Moscow, I read with interest Walter Reich's article ''The World of Soviet Psychiatry'' (Jan. 30).

title: Dr. Mark Berman Weds Miss Graf
description: Debbie Graf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolf F. Graf of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Dr. Mark Berman, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Berman of the Bronx. Rabbi Maurice Corson, assisted by Cantor Lawrence Avery, performed the ceremony at the Fountainhead.

title: OVERFLOW SWAMPS OPEC'S OIL PRICES
description: The world watched in fascination last week as OPEC appeared to be losing what was left of its grip on the price of oil. The $34 a barrel price that the oil producers cartel established more than two years ago had already slipped. The uncertainty sent prices of securities, commodities and currencies alternately slumping and surging, plainly reflecting lack of confidence in predictions of the potential size and duration of the oil price decline and its likely political, economic and financial effects.

title: Travel in France
description: To the Editor:

title: HOUSING FOR AGED MAKES SOME GAINS
description: MORE than 15,000 elderly Long Islanders have been waiting, some for as long as seven years, for other elderly people to either die or be moved to nursing homes, so that the highly prized subsidized housing they occupy will become available.

title: NEW YORK OF 70'S PORTRAYED BY U.S. DATA AS A CITY IN FLUX
description: New York City experienced its largest population decline in history in the 1970's, but it continued to be a magnet for immigrants, who came to make up a quarter of the people.

title: Davis's Hot Streak
description: Walter Davis turned in a near-perfect shooting performance Friday night in the Phoenix Suns' victory over the Seattle SuperSonics.

title: Erica Lehrer to Wed Richard A. Goldman in June
description: Mrs. Jesse Schupack of Short Hills, N.J., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Erica Lehrer, to Richard Alan Goldman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Goldman of Baldwin, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Saving the Past
description: To the Editor:

title: THE COSTLY BLUNDERS OF CENTRAL BANKERS
description: IN the 1970's, the banks were part of the solution. If they had not l ent large sums to less developed countries, the oil shocks of 1 974-75 and 1979-80 would have done far more damage to the whole w orld economy.

title: BACK TO THE DUMP
description: When I was a boy everybody urged me to get plenty of sunshine, so I got plenty of sunshine for a long time. One day while I was absorbing July sun as fast as I could, a doctor asked what I thought I was doing.

title: CONNECTICUT HEEDS THE CALL OF THE WILD
description: But for one bizarre twist, it was a classic murder case. Two hunters moved through the woods, perhaps 200 yards apart, in search of deer. One suddenly spotted an adult black bear approaching his companion, poised, he thought, to attack. He fired a single shot and killed the animal. It was the first black bear slain in Connecticut in 18 years. A Connecticut Superior Court judge dismissed the criminal charge - illegal killing of a bear - against Brian Ferratto last month. But for conservationists and outdoorsmen throughout Connecticut, the case raised questions about encounters between humans and wild animals.

title: LIZ CLAIBORNE AND A LANDMARK
description: FROM the bedroom window of her Fire Island retreat, Liz Claiborne can see the lighthouse that has become the symbol of her commitment to her community.

title: PLAN TO GROW STURDY FLOWERS FOR LONG-LASTING BOUQUETS
description: What homeowner has not longed for a cutting garden with unlimited quantities of flowers? Immediately images of lavish estates of an earlier age come to mind with formal gardens and formal gardeners to tend them. For today's needs, however, a simple bouquet is enough.

title: Dede Neal to Wed Rep. Thomas Petri
description: Anne deHayden Neal of Washington, general counsel for the Office of Administration at the White House, and United States Representative Thomas E. Petri of Fond du Lac, Wis., will be married March 26. The engagement was announced by the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. James T. Neal of Noblesville, Ind.

title: Sin and Taxes
description: A carpenter who employed several workers at his shop near New Castle, Pa., declined to pay the Federal Social Security and unemployment taxes required of all employers. As a member of the Old Order Amish Church, he said, it was his belief that paying taxes was a sin.

title: UNDER INDEPENDENCE, POLITICS IS TRIBAL
description: In the days of Zimbabwe's seven-year war, when a white minority fought for and lost a country then called Rhodesia, this city went under the name of Salisbury and, even in the darkest days of the conflict, seemed an unlikely island of tranquility and order.

title: FIT FOR THE STREET
description: Manhattan women with an eye for new fashion ideas have been spotted pulling in their waistlines and slimming their skirts to a straw, as shown in these photographs taken on the street. The resulting fitted look often incorporates a bold sexiness.

title: FOR 2 TEAMS, SPRING TRAINING IN CUBA
description: THE boys of spring are heading for Cuba. Shortstops, outfielders and pitchers have been raking leaves and shoveling snow for $3.50 an hour to raise the plane fare to Havana. Parents and coaches have organized tag sales and flea markets.

title: Lifetime Judge
description: After 33 years on the Federal bench, Judge Harold R. Medina stepped down in February 1980 at the age of 92. But he made it clear that he was retiring, not resigning.

title: Euromissile Facts and Feints
description: If we read him right, President Reagan has made an important correction in the Administration's approach to the Euromissile negotiations in Geneva. He entered the talks a year ago primarily to gain time to deploy new American land missiles on the Continent. Now he seems determined to keep the allies on course toward deployment primarily to see what reductions in Soviet forces this will purchase at the table.

title: Back to The Basics
