description: VOLUMES have been written about ''new'' combinations of sauces and flavors for the delight of those who dine on pasta. They include such good things as pine nuts and assorted vegetables to go on a creamy dish of spaghetti primavera. Or fettuccine with prosciutto and a delicate blend of mascarpone and Gorgonzola cheese. Or such oddsounding blends as broccoli, pine nuts and raisins. Walk into any of the very finest Italian restaurants in Manhattan and chances are the maitre d'hotel will propose for you the chef's latest pasta ''invention.''

title: REMEMBERING MEMORY LANE IN OSSINING
description: OSSINING is a town that traffics in memory. Its sinuous Main Street is being outfitted with a new but vintage-looking facade. Appearing like a setting from a picture book, Ossining is a hospitable spot for the series of works entited "Photo Memory" by Roger Welch at Elizabeth Galasso Fine Art Leasing, through April 1.

title: THIS HOLIDAY IS A KILLER
description: I had been looking forward to my old public school reunion with a mixture of enthusiasm and apprehension. It would be splendid to see the old chaps from Prince College, and its sister academy, Victoria College, again - especially for as stirring an occasion as the school's centenary. Driving toward my destination, the faded Victorian seaside resort of Southport, in Lancashire, I began reliving ancient memories of my first century on the cricket pitch, the cold porridge and the canings.

title: MISS SPATH PLANS TO MARRY IN FALL
description: Dorothy S. Spath of New Berlin, Wis., and Robert B. Spath of Elm Grove, Wis., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathryn Spath, to Alexander Robert Scott, son of Colleen Dewhurst of South Salem, N.Y., the actress, and George C. Scott of Greenwich, Conn., the actor and director.

title: CLASHES AND ARSON REPORTED IN ASSAM
description: Violence continued today in India's northeastern state of Assam where at least 1,500 people have died in three weeks of sectarian violence and riots.

title: BOYS & GIRLS GAINS SEMIFINAL
description: While the attention from fans and opponents was focused on Dwayne (the Pearl) Washington of Boys & Girls High School in yesterday's P.S.A.L. basketball quarterfinal, Washington's teammate Elmer Anderson took over the spotlight. Anderson scored 24 points in an 83-56 victory over South Shore, and along the way he surpassed his school's 1,000-point scoring plateau.

title: ON THE EDGE OF ZIMBABWE
description: Since it became independent under a majority black government, nearly three years ago, Zimbabwe has defied the grim predictions of its ill-wishers. The economy has not collapsed; it has grown. There has been no mass exodus of whites, least of all in the crucial farming sector; there are more white farmers today than at independence. A democratic parliament continues to sit.

title: LETTER URGES U.S. TO SEEK ISRAELI MILITARY DATA
description: An advertisement in the Sunday issue of The New York Times, said to be signed by more than 130 retired admirals and generals, calls on the United States to reach an agreement with Israel so that it can learn about weapons and tactics used by the Israelis in Lebanon.

title: JACQUES BENOIST-MECHIN, EX-VICHY AIDE, DIES
description: Jacques Benoist-Mechin, a French historian who served in the Vichy Government and was condemned to death for treason after World War II, died Thursday in Bichat Hospital in Paris after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

title: Wilkins Cited As Early Signer
description: Jack Manton, the attorney-adviser who directed Herschel Walker's jump from the University of Georgia to the New Jersey Generals of the United States Football League, reportedly signed Dominique Wilkins, the former Georgia basketball star, to an agent's contract before the forward's junior year.

title: SPRAYING TIME IS ALMOST HERE
description: IT IS not too early to think about a spring ritual that often culminates in the bombardment of gypsy moth settlements with chemical pesticides.

title: JOURNEY TO THE TOP OF THE WORLD
description: I was riding down a graveled highway in Tibet one chilly summer afternoon and had just reached the continental squeeze, the invisible line north of the Himalayas where the Indian subcontinent collided with Asia 50 million years ago.

title: FEAR OF PANIC CITED IN REPORT ON DEATH
description: THE recent death, from spinal meningitis, of a 15-year-old high school student here was not made public until the following week, municipal and state officials said, because they wanted to avoid panic.

title: NANCY A. SPREEN ENGAGED TO JOSEPH F. DEL NEGRO JR.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Spreen of Mahway, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Ann Spreen, to Joseph Francis Del Negro Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Del Negro of Washington Township, N.J.

title: NEW PENALTIES WEIGHED FOR DRUNKEN DRIVING
description: WITH alcohol consumption linked to 42 percent of all fatal automobile accidents in the state in 1981, the last year for which such data are available, bills calling for more-severe penalties for drivers involved in drinking-related accidents abound in the Legislature.

title: U.S. SAYS IT STANDS BY CHINA PACT
description: The State Department today denied charges from Peking that recent remarks by President Reagan totally disregarded the main principles of the Chinese-American accord on the Taiwan arms issue. The department said Mr. Reagan wanted ''a strong, stable relationship'' with China.

title: COMPUTER IS KEEPING TRACK OF SMOKY FIREPLACE IN WEST
description: When owners of the $1 million homes in this Rocky Mountain hideaway snuggle up in front of their fireplaces, a computer that has their phone numbers will be watching and waiting.

title: A FASHION OBSERVER'S RUMINATIONS
description: There comes a time in the life of every home when all the appliances break down. The vacuum cleaner wheezing its last is the signal for the steam iron to start spitting which in turn is the command for the dishwasher to leak. This is precisely the moment at which one realizes that the living room needs painting, and the bathroom tiles new grout. It is also, given a change of subject and verb, precisely what has happened to my wardrobe. Crackup.

title: A FABLE OF INNONCENCE AND SURVIVAL
description: TZILI The Story of a Life. By Aharon Appelfeld. Translated by Dalya Bilu. 185 pp. New York: E.P. Dutton. $12.95.

title: COLLEGE HEADS FIGHT RECRUITING ABUSES
description: A panel of presidents of large colleges and universities has been formed to investigate abuses in the recruitment of high school athletes.

title: JEAN D'ARCY, SERVED IN FRENCH TELEVISION IN ITS PIONEERING ERA
description: Jean D'Arcy, a pioneer of French television and founder of Eurovision, died here on Jan. 19 after a heart attack. He was 69 years old.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE LOST SISTERHOOD Prostitution in America, 1900-1918. By Ruth Rosen. Illustrated. 245 pp. Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins University Press. $18.50.The Progressives called prostitution the Social Evil - an ominoussounding euphemism that betrays the inflated moral enthusiasm with which these reformers set out to attack a vaguely defined problem. It was as if all the world could be set right by making the brothels disappear from America's cities. Ruth Rosen, a professor of history at the University of California, in her perceptive book ''The Lost Sisterhood'' shows that the early 20th-century campaign against prostitution absorbed a broad array of middle-class social and political concerns in a society where class structure and relations between the sexes were rapidly changing. The Social Evil symbolized the decline of traditional morals, the commercialization of human relations, the rise of a threatening urban working-class culture, the exploitation of labor, even the spread of contagious disease.

title: EMPLOYING THE DRIED BEAN FOR TASTE AND NUTRITION
description: IN the chilly days of waning winter, few foods are as satisfying and warming as dishes made with dried beans. They provide gustatory pleasure as well as a useful helping of calcium, vitamin A and protein, all at small expense. Although the protein in dried beans lacks some of the essential amino acids, by serving beans with grains of some sort, even a slice or two of wheat bread, this deficiency is balanced.

title: French Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: MARDI GRAS GALA

title: WHat They Did To the Nisei
description: Ten weeks after the attack on Pearl Harbor, in what has come to be widely regarded as another kind of infamy, President Roosevelt signed Executive Order 9066. It led to the uprooting and internment in barbed wire-enclosed ''relocation camps'' of 120,000 Japanese American citizens and resident aliens.

title: WILL THE 1980'S WITNESS A NEW SURGE OF BLACK POLITICAL GAIN?
description: It has been 15 years since former Mayor Carl Stokes of Cleveland proved that a black can win at urban politics where members of his own race make up a substantial minority, provided he can hold on to his own constituency and appeal to a small percentage of the white majority.

title: FEDERAL BUDGET AFTER 1984
description: Last month, five former Secretaries of the Treasury - Michael Blumenthal, John Connally, Douglas Dillon, Henry Fowler and William Simon - along with former Secretary of Commerce Peter G. Peterson and about 500 other signatories published a ''Bipartisan Budget Appeal'' to the President and Congress. The appeal emphasized the dangers of the huge deficits pending in the Federal budget in the ''outyears,'' 1985 and beyond, and set forth the outlines of a program for bringing them down.

title: CLASSICAL GREECE OFF-SEASON
description: For many travelers, the advantages of a winter-season holiday in Greece can well be worth the sacrifice of swimming and sunning: a climate comparable to early autumn in the northern United States (comfortable sweater-weather with many more sunny days than gray ones), low-season rates, the absence of crowds of tourists and the opportunity to see Greece in a refreshingly less commercial atmosphere. All this makes excellent conditions for exploring at leisure the classical sites, their physical, emotional and intellectual impact not blunted by heat and crowds.

title: 'ARABELLA'-WILL IT STAY IN THE MET'S REPERTORY?
description: Is there room in the lifeboat for ''Arabella''? You know the lifeboat I mean: the allegorical craft, usually sailing under a Hollywood registry, that can hold just so many survivors and not one body more. Anyone else who swims up and tries to climb aboard is beaten off with oars. Now and then, an occupant may die of thirst, which opens a space for one of those clinging to the gunwales, perhaps a pregnant woman or a child with a puppy.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: STEINBERG DRAWINGS

title: Koch Gets Ace and 65 for Lead
description: Gary Koch, a modest professional who has won two tournaments in his seven years on the PGA Tour, rushed out of the field today with a 65 that gave him a four-stroke lead in the third round of the Doral-Eastern Open.

title:
GARDENING;
USING FOLIAGE COLOR TO ACCENT GARDEN
description: THERE exists a long-standing disagreement among gardeners as to the merit of using trees and shrubs with colored foliage in the landscape. While some enthusiastically recommend their use as a means of creating interest, others decry their use, using such terms as gauche and overpowering to convey their distaste.

title: Airport Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Perez Dominance Absent As Delta Residents Vote
description: Voters turned out in force today in the first Plaquemines Parish election in years not dominated by the arch-segregationist Leander H. Perez Sr., who died in 1969, or his sons.

title: That Will Be All
description: The power of British royalty may not be what it once was, but Queen Elizabeth II nevertheless managed to stop The Sun in its tracks last week.

title: CONGRESS PRESSES ON AID TO JOBLESS
description: Congress is moving swiftly on two fronts to extend unemployment benefits in the nation's most distressed regions and help states finance the added cost.

title: Staten Island and John Jay in City Final
description: Staten Island rallied to defeat Lehman, 74-62, Friday night and reach the final of the City University tournament for the fourth time in five years.

title: Christine Lozier Wed at St. Bart's
description: In the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Church in Manhattan yesterday Christie Allison Lozier, daughter of Raymond W. Lozier of Suffield, Conn., and the late Mrs. Lozier, was married to Poul-Erik Heilmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Heilmann of Greenwich, Conn., and Norwood, Va. The Rev. Andrew Mullins performed the ceremony.

title: STATE SEEKS TO STOP TICKET SCALPING
description: MANY New Jerseyans are forgoing concerts and sports events these days rather than pay $50 to $125 for tickets that normally cost $10 to $15.

title: The Inspiration of Dr. Hawking
description: Michael Harwood's profile of Dr. Stephen W. Hawking is inspiring to read on more than one level (''The Universe and Dr. Hawking,'' Jan. 23).

title: A NEW TRY FOR TRUTH IN FUNERALS
description: Sidney A. Miller ordered a $95 pine coffin for his deceased uncle in 1981. That's not what he got. A Baltimore funeral director persuaded Mr. Miller's mother to buy a $1,350 ''funeral package'' that included among other items a $470 casket, $75 for ''body deodorants'' and $35 for a rabbi who did not attend the service. Elizabeth Miller said she ''felt uncomfortable questioning the funeral director about prices.'' Besides, she said, ''He told me the pine coffin had holes.''

title: STEWARD OF THE PRESIDENT'S POLICIES
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ONE-WOMAN WELCOME WAGON
description: WHEN we moved to Thornwood shortly after World War II ended, my husband and I and our three small children were the youngest family on the block, and I was surely among the most bewildered and homesick housewives on any block. Uprooted from my city apartment, transported to the beyond, I had no idea how life was conducted in a singlefamily residential setting.

title: REQUESTS IN '82 FOR PISTOL LICENSES SET RECORD
description: A record 9,268 applications were filed for handgun licenses last year in New York City - almost 1,000 more than the year before and more than twice the number before the State Legislature passed a tougher handgun law in August 1980.

title: VILLANOVA BEATS ST. JOHN'S BY 1
description: John Pinone, Villanova's senior center, sank a 20-foot jump shot at the buzzer of overtime today to give the Wildcats a thrilling 71-70 victory over St. John's in a battle for first place in the Big East Conference.

title: JEWS ISSUE APPEAL ON SOVIET AT MADRID TALKS
description: A delegation of prominent Jews from Europe and the United States met this week with representatives at the Madrid conference on security and cooperation in Europe to express concern over what they said was increasing repression against Jews in the Soviet Union.

title: BALI
description: To the Editor:

title: Anthony Crosland
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGHLIGHTING THE REGIONS OF ITALY
description: THANKS to an ongoing series of special regional menus, Don Ciccio Il Pescatore restaurant in Freeport offers one of the more interesting and ambitious selections of Italian dishes on the Island. For those who seek some adventure and variety in Italian dining, this restaurant would be worth visiting.

title: THE RACE TO PRODUCE VIA COMPUTER
description: The key to realizing the dream of highly automated plants flexible enough to switch deftly from one task to another - the much-touted ''factory of the future'' - lies in using the computer as much as possible in the design and manufacture of products.

title: IRAN'S BAHA'IS: SOME CALL IT GENOCIDE
description: For centuries the city of Shiraz, in southwestern Iran, has been a center of Persian poetry and intellectual life. The very word ''Persian'' comes from Pars, the name of the region centering on Shiraz. It is also the birthplace of the Bab, a 19th-century prophet whose teachings led to the creation of the Baha'i faith.

title: STAYING FIT SAFELY
description: The physical fitness boom has spurred hundreds of thousands of Americans to sign on the dotted line at health clubs across the country. But in their zeal for fitness, many are tripped up by injury and prevented from reaching their goals. To stay healthy in a health club, fitness seekers should exercise with caution. This means first checking that the club is staffed by professionals and maintained at satisfactory levels of safety. In addition, workout programs should be tailor-made and exercises should be performed correctly.

title: CUOMO SIGNS FIRST NEW STATUTES AS GOVERNOR
description: Governor Cuomo signed bills into law this week to make state-chartered banks competitive with federally chartered ones and to let the Westchester County cities of New Rochelle and Mount Vernon collect more of the county sales tax.

title: DANCE
description: Concerts by modern-dance choreographers come in all shapes and sizes. But ballet companies, usually requiring a large corps, rarely give beginning choreographers a chamber-size framework to feel their oats.

title: THE HERSCHEL WALKER CASE: SOME LESSONS ABOUT AGENTS
description: I'VE been wondering about something: If Herschel Walker got so much money from the New Jersey Generals without anyone bidding against them, how much more could he have earned if he had waited a year, finished his college eligibility and let the National Football League bid against the United States Football League for his talents?

title: ONE BENEFIT OF VOLUNTEERING CAN BE A JOB
description: JUDY NATHAN may begin her day editing a videotape. Rita Posner, a children's librarian, starts by helping a 10 year old find a book about space. Kevin Whelan, a physical-therapy aide, spends part of his morning helping a child onto a prone board to improve his circulation. For Barbara Arzonetti, teacher-in-charge of a school system, a morning may mean talking to parents about a child's progress or interviewing a job applicant.

title: LESLIE FANWICK IS PLANNING TO WED JEFFREY LISS IN MAY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Fanwick of Stamford, Conn., have announce the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Fanwick, to Jeffrey Liss, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Liss of Fresh Meadows, Queens. A May 29 wedding is planned.

title: Fallout From Canadian Films
description: When do documentaries on the dangers of acid rain and nuclear war constitute ''political propaganda?'' When they try to influence public opinion about foreign policy, according to the Justice Department, which last week stamped the propaganda label on three documentaries from Canada's National Film Board.

title: PRESIDENT SEEKING $60 MILLION MORE IN AID TO SALVADOR
description: The Reagan Administration, worried about the ''discouraging'' military situation in El Salvador, is seeking an extra $60 million in arms aid for the Central American nation this year, according to State and Defense Department officials.

title: MARY SEXTON TO MARRY MICHAEL G. MEZZAPELLE
description: Mr. and Mrs. John P. Sexton of Janmaica Estates, Queens, and Point Lookout, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, mary Sexton, to Michael G. Mezzapelle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Domnic M. Mezzapella of Stanford, Conn. The wedding is planned for July.

title: Poodle Top Breed; Cockers Moving Up
description: For the 23d consecutive year the poodle, which comes in three varieties determined by size - standard, miniature and toy - is the country's most popular breed. But the poodle is being challenged strongly by the cocker spaniel.

title: YONKERS OFFICIALS DIFFER ON PIER ISSUE
description: IN the plan for a proposed multimillion dollar waterfront development project recently approved by the Yonkers City Council, a three-story retail emporium and an office complex would be built on the waterfront and a restaurant would be constructed on the Yonkers Pier. But the plan for the restaurant has attracted opposition from a citizens group. While some call it a dispute, others suggest it is simply a misunderstanding between Mayor Angelo R. Martinelli's office, two members of the City Council and the citizens group.

title: A WHITE WOMEN'S GROUP COUNTERS APARTHEID
description: A couple of years ago, in what seemed a small gust of liberalizing energy, a South African Cabinet minister announced he was ''declaring war'' on the reference book all blacks must carry when they are in an area that is legally proclaimed white.

title: Future Events Diverse Dinner Dates
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. Patron Saint March 1 - The St. David's Society of the State of New York will honor Kenneth D. Taylor, Canadian Consul General in New York and former Ambassador to Iran, at its annual St. David's Day dinner dance in the Plaza's Baroque Room. The consul, whose father was born in Wales, will receive the society's William R. Hopkins Medal for his role in helping six United States diplomats escape from Teheran during the hostage crisis. On the menu will be such Welsh fare as leek and potato soup and, for entertainment, traditional Welsh airs sung by Lisbeth Lloyd, a 1982 St. David's Society scholarship winner. Proceeds to scholarships for students in the arts. Tickets: $50, from 924-8415.

title: ART
description: Somewhere in the output of almost everyone who has ever painted portraits there is a subsection called ''The Artist's Wife.'' Rembrandt and Rubens are only two of the great masters who did some of their finest work under this heading, and the tradition has never gone out.

title: Seeking Ouster Of Bobby Knight
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: U.S. RIGHTS REPORTS ON 12 NATIONS CRITICIZED
description: Three human rights monitoring groups have criticized the Reagan Administration's 1982 country reports for what they termed a distortion of the rights records of 12 nations.

title: EDUCATION: TO CHERISH
description: Will the 98th Congress continue financial aid programs for college students that have helped to make it possible for 12,358,000 young people to attend college and for 3,200 institutions of higher education to survive? The answer is in doubt.

title: CALIFORNIA WEIGHS PLAN TO CURB WELFARE FRAUD
description: Gov. George Deukmejian is seeking to extend throughout California a program that officials in suburban Orange County say has substantially reduced payments to welfare cheats.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: A good suspense novel is processed twice - once as it is read from beginning to end, and a second time as the meaning of the solution washes back over the story, rearranging the landscape. The instant when the tide turns is the critical point, a moment of shock.

title: A PLUM IN PAWLING
description: World traveler that he was, Lowell Thomas nevertheless had a constant home base on Quaker Hill in Pawling, N.Y., from 1926 until his death in 1981. The broadcast journalist began with a 32-room house and 80 acres, which he acquired with a $1,000 down payment.

title: A BREAK FOR TRADITION
description: In the men's-wear industry, the styles for next fall are already decided. The clothes have been shown by both designers and manufacturers, and stores throughout the country have already placed their orders. Although the garments won't arrive until early June, some of the more significant shifts in the collections are worth discussing now. And major among them is what has happened at Calvin Klein's men's-wear division.

title: Development Commissioner; ONES AND TWOS BECOMING ILLEGAL THREES
description: THOUSANDS of one- and two-family homes throughout New York City have been illegally converted into multiple dwellingsi n violation of zoning ordinances and the housing laws, according to c ity officials who were asked to assess the problem.

title: BRINK'S CASE TRIAL IS DEFERRED AGAIN
description: The state trial in the $1.6 million Brink's robbery and triple murder in October 1981 has been delayed again and will probably not start until June.

title: CENSUS DATA REVEAL 70'S LEGACY: POORER CITIES AND RICHER SUBURBS
description: Despite hopes and claims of a great revival in American cities in recent years, new census information discloses that over the past decade cities continued to grow poorer while their suburbs became even richer.

title: ONE EYE ON THE BUDGET, THE OTHER ON '84
description: Four weeks after receiving President Reagan's proposed budget for 1984, Congress has concluded that in many respects it will not do: Prospective deficits - more than $100 billion a year, even in 1988 - are too large, Mr. Reagan would spend too much on the military and his standby tax increases for 1985 are too iffy and too late. On that much there is a fair measure of agreement, but on little else. By party, region and ideology, the lawmakers are divided about such basic issues as raising revenue and how to cut military and health care spending.

title: Supreme Court Makes It Tougher For Drunk Drivers
description: For people who drink, drive and are stopped, there's no place to hide. If they submit to the blood-alcohol test for intoxication, they may be found legally drunk.

title: ROBERT WILSON PLANS AN OLYMPIC EVENT
description: Robert Wilson calls his vast, multi-media works ''operas'' even though it is he, not his composers, who is generally the dominant creative force. Yet although he is widely regarded as American's leading vanguard theatrical artist, Mr. Wilson has not had a major work presented in his native country since ''Einstein on the Beach'' at the Metropolitan Opera House in 1976. Since then, major Wilson productions - although none on the scale of the five-hour ''Einstein,'' let alone the 12-hour ''Life and Times of Joseph Stalin'' at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 1973 - have taken place in Lyons, Milan, Paris, Berlin and Munich, but not in the United States.

title:
THE MAKING OF A WRITER;
I ALWAYS WANTED TO GO TO PATAGONIA
description: BRUCE is a dog's name in England (not so in Australia) and was also the surname of our Scottish cousins. The etymology of ''Chatwin'' is obscure; but my bassoon-playing Uncle Robin maintained that ''chettewynde'' meant ''winding path'' in Anglo-Saxon. Our side of the family traces its descent from a Birmingham button maker, yet there is a dynasty of Mormon Chatwins in a remote part of Utah, and recently I heard of a Mr. and Mrs. Chatwin, trapeze artists.

title: This Week:
description: Be prompt to start indoors seed of impatiens, browallia, lobelia, coleus, petunia, snapdragon, verbena and vinca. . . . Where needed prune dogwood, Japanese maple, fruit trees and grapevines. . . . Finish planning vegetable/flower garden and mail nursery orders. On Pruning

title: N.R.C. ORDERS TEST AT 48 ATOM PLANTS
description: The Salem 1 nuclear power plant in South Jersey was shut down manually Friday after the failure of two electrical switches that were supposed to shut the plant down automatically. Today the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said it had told operators of 48 other water-pressurized reactors throughout the country to test for similar defects.

title: HIGH STYLE
description: When American designers set their sights on clothes for evening, their sense of drama reached full expression. Forget such mundane matters as money; it is assumed that women will always spend it for glamorous evening wear.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: UNLIKE the thoughts of youth, the thoughts of the very old are not long thoughts. They come and go in flashes of the distant past, many wars, booms, recessions and depressions ago. Those who work in such places as the South Shore Nursing Home in Freeport know this. They greet the patients briskly, heartily and to the point: Breakfast. A change of clothes. A bath. Something to do with now, a momentary distraction from then, the dim shadow-time in which they dwell and are inclined to brood.

title: DISKS ATTEST TO THE VERSATILE TALENTS OF JOHN WILLIAMS
description: It's easier than ever to admit a liking for the lighter things in life. Light beers, cigarettes and soft drinks are edging their fullbodied competitors off store shelves, while the nouvelle cuisine celebrates the triumph of insubstantiality in many of our finest restaurants. Nothing that is weighty is safe these days, not even battleships.

title: SALVADORANS SEE A SIGN OF HOPE IN POPE'S VISIT
description: Many Salvadorans, from the country's political leadership to the people in the war-ravaged villages, share the hope that when Pope John Paul II arrives here next week he will be able to galvanize support for discussions with the leftist opposition,

title: SLOOP SCARLETT O'HARA S.O.R.C. WINNER
description: Scarlett O'Hara, a white 42-foot sloop owned by Monroe Wingate of Piedmont, Calif., was declared the overall winner today of the six-race Southern Ocean Racing Conference, considered the national grand prix yacht-racing championship.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: AS the General Assembly's Government Administration and Elections Committee was hearing testimony last week about the influence of large contributors in financing election campaigns, the Democratic State Central Committee announced plans to seek more small contributors.

title: No Headline
description: Dr. Snezhnevsky may well have ''guffawed'' at his meeting with Dr. Reich when discussing the need for psychotherapy research, and plenty of Americans would have agreed. It was well known at the time of a visit I made there two years ago that the chief himself made rounds daily to see his own patients and do his brand of psychotherapy.

title: EFFECT OF ENDING CONTROL OF GAS COST IS UNCERTAIN
description: Supporters of the Reagan Administration's plan to decontrol the price of natural gas say that price increases would be minimal, perhaps 5 to 10 percent in homeowners' bills over the next two years. The increase could be somewhat more if inflation rose from its low levels.

title: PROFESSIONAL STRATEGIES
description: THE WORLD, THE TEXT, AND THE CRITIC By Edward W. Said. 327 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $20. PROFESSOR Stanley Fish of Johns Hopkins tells us that this book by Edward Said, the critic and professor of literature at Columbia University, ''speaks with a particular and moving urgency to the issues facing criticism today.'' A word, as so often, gives the game away. Urgency? Is science about to destroy the world, or the superpowers each other? Is capitalism or communism about to collapse? Quite possibly. And the scientist, economist or political theorist who takes up a pen to face these matters might reasonably claim, or have it claimed on his behalf, that the task was an urgent one. But in this context the word is factitious.

title: WOMAN IS WARDEN AT MEN'S PRISON
description: ''IS Anna Zaremba Thompson there?'' ''Anna, who?'' exclaimed the surprised male voice that answered the telephone at the Litchfield Correctional Center, a minimum-to-medium security prison for men. ''Oh,'' the voice added after a moment, ''You mean the new warden.''

title:
STAMPS;
INTERPEX OPENS AT THE COLISEUM ON MARCH 10
description: The coming of INTERPEX, the big stamp show put on by the American Stamp Dealers Association in the early part of the year, is always a big event for collectors. This year the International Philatelic Exhibition, to give INTERPEX its full title, will be held March 10 through March 13 at the New York Coliseum. The exhibition will be celebrating its 25th anniversary, marking a quarter century of growth that has made it the second largest philatelic event in the United States. It is surpassed in size only by the ASDA's annual fall stamp exhibition.

title: AIDE SAYS CUOMO IS UNHAPPY WITH COURT'S BUDGET
description: Governor Cuomo is ''not happy'' with the $575 million budget proposed by the state's court system because it does not make the cuts in personnel that state agencies are being asked to make, Mr. Cuomo's Budget Director said.

title: THE TRIAL OF HUDSON CORRUPTION CASES
description: Hudson County Prosecutor Harold J. Ruvoldt Jr. was back on the job Wednesday, nearly three weeks after a Federal jury acquitted him of extortion. After thinking it over, New Jersey Attorney General Irwin I. Kimmelman said he could find no reason not to reinstate Mr. Ruvoldt, who was the 13th official in Hudson County indicted in the last three years. That, in turn, has given the Federal prosecutor, who is reportedly preparing cases against a host of present and former county and local officials, something to think about.

title: AN ATHLETE, A COCAINE ADDICT: JOHN DREW FIGHTS FOR HIS LIFE
description: SALT LAKE CITY THE tall young man is speaking softly now, so his words can hardly be heard. But the words come quickly because he is eager to tell his story. ''Hi, I'm John,'' he says, ''and I'm a drug addict.''

title: Portugal's Premier Resigns Party Post
description: The departing Prime Minister, Francisco Pinto Balsemao, stepped down as leader of the Social Democratic Party today after losing a key vote at a party congress.

title: A TRIO, BARITONE, PIANIST AND GUITARIST ARE RECITALISTS
description: The Apple Trio is composed of the soprano Joyce Guyer, the flutist Sandra Church, and the pianist Nancy Revzen. At their debut concert in Abraham Goodman House on Monday night, they impressed the listener as performers who were, for the most part, too good for their material.

title: KOHL TAKES HIS CASE TO MIDDLE CLASS
description: To the stirring strains of West Germany's national anthem, the face of Helmut Kohl appears on the screen.

title: GREGORY ALTSCHULLER
description: Dr. Gregory Altschuller, an internist who was on the staff of Roosevelt Hospital for 30 years, died Friday of cancer at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 87 years old, and a resident of Manhattan.

title: MORE MOVIE ROLES SOUGHT FOR STATE
description: IN the climactic scene of the new motion picture ''Without a Trace,'' a New York City detective, played by the actor Judd Hirsch, searches for a a kidnapped boy. The scene, which was filmed in Bridgeport's South End, with boarded houses and industrial smokestacks as a background, does little to soften the Park City's image. But Bridgeport did benefit from the film - by some $60,000 that 20th-Century Fox Pictures spent in the city during the four-day shoot.

title: Silence Law Gets The Treatment
description: Maybe no one knows what lurks in the hearts and minds of legislators when they vote, but the American Civil Liberties Union last week made an effort to find out. In a continuing bid to overturn a law that requires public schools to begin each day with a moment of silence, the A.C.L.U. sent out 54 interrogatories - or list of questions - to past and present legislators seeking to determine their reasons for voting on the bill that became law on Dec. 15.

title: FICTION
description: 1 3 22 SPACE, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) The story of the American space program told through fiction. 2 1 16 MISTRAL'S DAUGHTER, by Judith Krantz. (Crown, $15.95.) The art world of the 20's and the fashion industry of the 80's. 3 4 16 2010: ODYSSEY TWO, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Ballantine/Del Rey, $14.95.) A continuation of the tale begun in ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' 4 5 26 THE VALLEY OF HORSES, by Jean M. Auel. (Crown, $15.95.) A continuation of the saga of human survival at the dawn of civilization begun in ''The Clan of the Cave Bear.'' 5 7 3 FLOATING DRAGON, by Peter Straub. (Putnam, $15.95.) An unspeakable horror invades a suburban commuter town. 6 2 26 MASTER OF THE GAME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Morrow, $15.95.) The hidden truth behind a woman business tycoon's rise to power. 7 6 20 FOUNDATION'S EDGE, by Isaac Asimov. (Doubleday, $14.95.) The struggle to keep civilization alive in a crumbling empire: science fiction. 8 10 2 ELLIS ISLAND, by Fred Mustard Stewart.

title: Arguello Easily Outpoints Fernandez
description: Alexis Arguello scored a 10-round unanimous decision today over Vilomar Fernandez in a junior welterweight nontitle bout.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. PUSHES RETRAINING FUNDS
description: The executive council of the A.F.L.- C.I.O. today urged the Reagan Administration to provide an additional $1 billion to retrain and assist workers who have permanently lost their jobs through plant closings or the introduction of new technology.

title: Vanessa Louise Perot to Marry Paul Alfred Gilbert
description: Vanessa Louise Perot, a press assistant and legislative correspondent to Representative Bill Green, Republican of New York, and Paul Alfred Gilbert, a candidate for a master's degree at the Colgate Darden Graduate School of Business Administration of the University of Virginia, plan to be married May 28 in Charleston, S.C.

title: MORALITY AND INVENTION IN A SINGLE THOUGHT
description: THE COMPLETE POEMS 1927-1979. By Elizabeth Bishop. 287 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $17.50. ELIZABETH BISHOP AND HER ART Edited by Lloyd Schwartz and Sybil P. Estess. 360 pp. Ann Arbor: University of Michigan Press. Cloth, $18.50. Paper, $8.95.

title: PARIS WEARABLE FASHION
description: One of the easiest things for a designer to create is a never-seenbefore silhouette. Give a good imagination free rein - and the assistance of some expert needle people - and almost any fashion dream can be translated into a clothing reality.

title: THE QUEEN IN MONTCLAIR
description: Alicia de Larrocha, the undisputed queen of pianists, will perform in Montclair Wednesday evening. Critics say that Miss de Larrocha, who made her debut in 1939, maintains inordinately high standards, despite a grueling schedule of 100 concerts a season.

title: Smug Insularity Of Darien
description: Is Stamford Darien's problem? Quoted statements in a Times article (''A Town vs. a Region,'' Feb. 6) place the blame for the regional need for more housing units on Stamford's ''conscious decision to raze housing for corporations,'' and Stamford's failure to restore housing torn down in the urban renewal area. These statements appear to have been accepted as fact by your writer and may be by your readers if they are not exposed to the facts.

title: False Alarm in Housing
description: The vision was ominous. Housing experts predicted that when mortgage rates finally fell, millions of American families shut out of the housing market would surge forth, sending housing prices skyward. The situation was said to be all the more dire because it was the baby boom generation that had reached home-buying age just as interest rates and housing prices soared out of reach.

title: Guatemala Extends Siege
description: The Guatemalan Government extended for a further 25 days its eight-month-old state of siege measure suspending constitutional rights because of continuing leftist guerrilla activity, the presidential office said today. Political sources said the state of siege would expire on March 23, exactly a year after President Efrain Rios Montt seized power in a coup.

title: July Wedding Set By Miss Hoadley
description: Mr. and Mrs. David N. Hoadley of Brookside, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gretchen Hoadley, to Stephen Barnett Burke, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel B. Burke of Rye, N.Y. A July wedding is planned.

title: TASHI SURVIVED SOME WRENCHING UPHEAVALS
description: They have survived the departure of one of their founders, a marriage and divorce between two of their members, the complexities of bi-coastal residences, and illness. They have survived with the spirit, enthusiasm and innovative programming that have always been their hallmark. Today, they begin the observance of their 10th anniversary with the first of three concerts at the 92d Street Y. For the small group of musicians who collectively call themselves Tashi, it is an anniversary worth celebrating.

title: JUAREZ WORKS HARD TO CLEAN UP STREETS AND IMAGE
description: It was once called ''a sin center'' where nightclubs doubled as brothels and quickie divorces were a major industry. Now the Mexican border town of Juarez is trying to clean up its streets and its image.

title: CONCERT 'EN FAMILLE'
description: Some family members from within the larger family of the New York Philharmonic gave an evening of chamber music at Cooper Union Friday night. The four string players divided into two couples - Gabriel and Diana Banat, violins, and Jon and Jacqueline Deak, bass and cello.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE Kings Park Senior High School Prom is next Friday, and the school's principal, Mary DeRose, is trying to make sure that the joy of one of the evenings of anyone's lifetime is not marred by alcohol and drunken driving.

title: UTAH'S WELL-GROOMED SKI RESORT
description: T o all but the fanatically dedicated few, a ski vacation can seem like an endurance test. There is the arduous trip to the mountain, the waiting in lift lines, the surly ski-bum-cum-lift attendants who release the chairlift so that it slams into your calf, the overpriced food and the bone-numbing cold.

title:
CAMERA;
PUSH PROCESSING SOLVES LOW LIGHTING PROBLEMS
description: There are many times when a photographer will come across a situation where where light levels are too low to get a good exposure, or when light levels are such that only a slow shutter speed can be used - a shutter speed that is insufficient to stop the action. Of course one can always use flash, but in some cases flash is impractical or inconsiderate, or it won't have the coverage to light the entire scene.

title: NETS ARE OVERCOME BY HAWKS, 95-88
description: It is a strange time of the season for the Nets, just after they have built a comfortable cushion in the standings and just before a final push for the playoffs. In between, they are encountering teams to which the games have been more critical, more meaningful.

title: OUT OF THE JUNKYARD OF HISTORY ROLLS THE SPACE-AGED SOAP BOX
description: GONE are the days of scouring junkyards for discarded carriage wheels and scrap wood. It is all very official now. Guidelines are strict, specifications exact. But in surviving nearly half a century marked by war, prosperity, social upheavel and the dawn of the computer, there seems to be only one thing about this American institution that hasn't changed much - the children.

title: DAVIS REJECTS MOVE TO TEAM AMERICA
description: Ricky Davis said yesterday that he had decided to remain with the Cosmos rather than join Team America, a squad of American players that will operate as a franchise in the North American Soccer League and also as the national team of the United States.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SPEAKING VOLUMES

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Lost: a Heroic Bear

title: OUTDOORS: AN EQUIPMENT SHOW FOR ALL SEASONS
description: WEARY anglers gain considerable sustenance from intense perusal of tackle catalogues, but many find it more exciting to attend a show where much of the newest gear is displayed.

title: Dance Notation Award
description: Ben Sommers, head of the Capezio Foundation, which aids dance organizations, will receive the Dance Notation Bureau Service Award on March 23.

title: SIMON GRAY'S VERSION OF A PLAYWRIGHT'S LIFE
description: SIMON GRAY, the British playwright, says he is ''revoltingly curious about conversations.'' He wanders around cities such as New York and London, his ears like dish antennae, absorbing scraps of errant dialogue. ''I can't resist listening,'' he says. He treasures one he overheard recently on the London subway, when a young woman told her girlfriend, ''And then he put his hand up my skirtyou know the one - the blue dirndl skirt.''

title: Cannon Is Content
description: Dr. Billy Cannon said by phone from his office in Baton Rouge, La., that he was disappointed his caller was not asking him to make a comeback in pro football.

title: Rumasa Head Ends Silence
description: The president of Rumasa, the Spanish holding company that was nationalized by the Government last week, said today that he would challenge the takeover.

title: CHAD SENSES MENACING LIBYA SHADOW
description: After 17 years of sporadic civil war and nine months of recent peace Chad, the poorest nation in Africa, sees itself again threatened by Libya's hopes to extend its influence south of the Sahara and east to the Sudan.

title: 'Penzance' Gross Called 'Tepid' for First 4 Days
description: ''Pirates of Penzance,'' the Universal Pictures film that had a simultaneous premiere last week in theaters and on pay television, grossed $255,496 in its first four days at the box office in 91 theaters across the country, according to Daily Variety, the showbusiness newspaper, which called the return ''tepid.''

title: FINAL TO HIGUERAS
description: Jose Higueras scored a 6-4, 6-2 victory over Eliot Teltscher today and won the $255,000 Congoleum Classic tennis tournament. The 29-year-old Spaniard earned $32,000.

title: SCHOOLS AND DRAFT: A BAD TIE
description: A recent amendment to the Military Selective Service Act will deny Federal financial aid under Title IV of the Higher Education Act to college students who cannot prove they have registered for the draft. There are serious objections to this law.

title: Brooklyn's Boys of TV
description: THE title was appropriated by the author Roger Kahn from the phrase of a poet. Dylan Thomas once wrote, ''I see the boys of summer in their ruin...'' But the title of Roger Kahn's book continues to define a certain team in a certain time - the Brooklyn Dodgers of three decades ago. At its spring training base in Vero Beach, Fla., now, the Dodger organization talks of the coming baseball season being the 25th anniversary of the club's arrival in Los Angeles. But to anyone who remembers those Dodgers, the club's emphasis is backwards. It's the 25th anniversary of the Dodgers abandoning Brooklyn.

title: Deak-Perera Names Futures Unit Head
description: Deak-Perera, known for its currency and precious-metal operations, plans to expand its futures affiliate and market its services to wealthy investors. Stephen Greenberg will be president and chief executive officer of the affiliate.

title: Kohl and Vogel Share A Past in Hitler Youth
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl and his challenger in the election next week, Hans-Jochen Vogel, both belonged to the Hitler Youth, their parties said today. The statements came after a newspaper article about Mr. Vogel that his supporters called ''character assassination.''

title: 2 More Publishers Set Computer Magazines
description: More on magazines of a technical nature. Back Stage has brought out its first issue of a planned six-a-year publication called Computer Pictures.

title: LIST OF CORPORATE ISSUES LOOKS LIGHT
description: The credit markets face a period of relatively light supply, except for tax-exempt securities, where volume is moderately heavy. Securities firms have scheduled nearly $800 million of corporate debt issues for sale this week, while the Treasury market enjoys a respite, with no note or bond financings expected over the next three weeks.

title: Argentina Gets Loan
description: A $500 million short-term loan offered to Argentina by the Bank for International Settlements last month has been made available, Economy Ministry sources said. Banking sources said earlier that the loan had been stalled by problems in arranging collateral.

title: Luxembourg Skier Winner in Slalom
description: Marc Girardelli of Luxembourg turned in two outstanding runs to score his first World Cup ski victory in a special slalom race today.

title: QUESTIONS ARE RAISED ON E.P.A. STUDY
description: The Justice Department is not aggressively pursuing allegations of political manipulation of toxic waste funds by the Environmental Protection Agency, according to Administration officials and agency employees.

title: MUSIC: MISS HILLS CONDUCTS REQUIEM
description: MARGARET HILLIS'S reputation as a choral conductor is once removed from the concert stage itself. As director of the Chicago Symphony Chorus, she has for many years prepared singers for performances conducted by others, but Saturday night's Brahms Requiem at Carnegie Hall was hers alone - the New York Choral Society, its good-size orchestra and the evening's soloists, Marvis Martin and William McGraw, all under her command.

title: TAX-PROCESSING DISKS BIG SELLERS FOR COMPANY
description: Soon after he purchased his first personal computer in 1975, Gerald D. Smith, then a designer of computer-based accounting systems for business, figured it would take about six months to create a program capable of processing individual tax returns in about 10 minutes.

title: Sine Nomine Singers Perform Dvorak's Mass
description: Dvorak's Mass for Mixed Chorus and Organ (Op. 76), performed by the Sine Nomine Singers in Merkin Hall on Saturday night, is more a comfortable and comforting work than an awesome or inspiring one. Henry Saltzman, conducting the singers, made it even more intimate and down-to-earth than usual.

title: Amex Gold Option
description: The American Stock Exchange has applied to the Commodity Futures Trading Commission for permission to open a market in options on gold bullion, the exchange said yesterday. Arthur Levitt Jr., chairman of Amex, said, ''The gold options would be an extension in effect of the stock options market we have operated successfully since 1975.'' The options would be traded on the exchange's new subsidiary, the Amex Commodities Corporation, in units of 100 ounces.

title: Elections Are Held in Senegal With President Diouf Favored
description: Senegalese voted in presidential and National Assembly elections today, with President Abdou Diouf and the ruling Socialist Party favored to win. Radio broadcasts reported tonight that with about 20 percent of the election districts reporting, President Diouf and his party were winning about 80 percent of the vote.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Hot Dog Science
description: John R. Darsee began his research career at Emory University, Atlanta, where his seniors viewed him as ''clearly one of the most remarkable young men in American medicine.'' Such praises elevated him to the Harvard Medical School where, on May 21, 1981, colleagues observing surreptitiously saw him forge data for an experiment on heart drugs.

title: Opium Is Seized in Chicago
description: Three men carrying 14 pounds of opium worth $24 million were arrested Saturday night by undercover agents in a parking lot near O'Hare International Airport.

title: Music Noted in Brief; Henryk Szeryng Marks 50 Years of Performance
description: Henryk Szeryng, the violinist, celebrated 50 years before the public Sunday with an afternoon of music at Avery Fisher Hall. The composers represented formed a kind of musical United Nations - with Leclair and Bach from the Baroque and Prokofiev, Ponce, Szymanowski and Gershwin from our own time.

title: Washington Watch; 2 Key Subjects At Roundtable
description: THE Business Roundtable, the lobbying organization made up of the chief executives of 200 of the country's biggest corporations, will consider urging that President Reagan soften his positions on two issues to which he has been most committed - tax indexation and military spending. The businessmen fear that the vast Treasury borrowing necessary to finance the budget deficit will squeeze them out of the credit markets just as the economy is beginning to revive.

title: A Soviet Daily Reports Fatal Bombings in Kabul
description: Several people were killed last week and more than a dozen wounded in three bomb explosions in Kabul, the capital of Afghanistan, the Soviet Army daily Krasnaya Zvezda reported today.

title: PRINCETON IS GIVEN A REPRIEVE
description: Pete Carril, the Princeton coach, acknowledged that he had all but given up on his team's chance for the Ivy League title after a loss at Cornell last Feb. 5. Penn emerged from that weekend's action with a two-game lead over Princeton and in position to win its 12th title in the last 21 years.

title: WOMEN'S NEW ROLE IN COMICS
description: The societal shift that has put vast numbers of middle-income women behind desks rather than behind baby carriages is beginning to be recognized by one of society's more conservative institutions - the comic pages of daily newspapers.

title: Allison Captures Richmond 400
description: Bobby Allison took the lead for good with 71 laps to go today and held off a late charge by Dale Earnhardt to win the $203,000 Richmond 400 Grand National stock car race.

title: COGHLAN WINNER IN FIRST SUB-3:50 INDOOR MILE
description: On a track he helped design, Eamonn Coghlan ran the first sub-3:50 indoor mile - 3 minutes 49.78 seconds - today during the Vitalis/U.S. Olympic Invitational meet.

title: Pola Kostrukoff Is Dead at 83; Prominent Fashion Designer
description: Pola Kostrukoff, a prominent fashion designer in the 1940's and 50's who created the inauguration gown worn by Bess Truman in 1949, died Friday of cancer at her home in Island Park, L.I. She was 83 years old.

title: Black and a Woman Win Seats in Delta Vote
description: In the first council election in 16 years, a woman and a black man were elected in Plaquemines Parish, which was controlled for half a century by the Perez family.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Political Export

title: NEW GOVERNMENT INSTALLED IN ASSAM'S CAPITAL AMID TIGHT SECURITY
description: A new government was installed today in the Indian state of Assam, where violence related to state elections has claimed the lives of an estimated 2,000 people over the last three weeks.

title: MET PITCHING OF FUTURE STIRS DREAMS OF THE PAST
description: GEORGE BAMBERGER, who had to be coaxed into returning as manager of the Mets this year, is kind of giddy these days. He watches the assembly line of young pitchers firing baseballs in the Mets' training camp, and says:

title: PERILS OF BEING THE PROSECUTION TEAM
description: The call to the United States Attorney's office from the neighborhood school here last spring was succinct. School authorities said that two men who had been parked outside all morning might be planning to kidnap the daughter of a Federal prosecutor, E. Lawrence Barcella Jr.

title: CONCERT: BEETHOVEN ARIAS
description: THE opportunity to examine the lesser known aspects of a great composer are always welcome. At Alice Tully Hall on Saturday, Karen Williams, Shirley Love, Paul Sperry and John Ostendorf, in tandem with the Philharmonia Orchestra of the Manhattan School of Music, presented Beethoven's complete concert arias and songs with orchestra.

title: ESTATE IS ROYAL SETTING FOR ROYAL VISIT
description: Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip were treated to a slice of the American dream today when they traveled to Rancho Mirage, 15 miles southeast of Palm Springs, to lunch at one of the country's most luxurious estates.

title: MOON'S CHURCH TO PAY TOWN $1 MILLION IN TAX AGREEMENT
description: The Unification Church has agreed to pay the Town of Greenburgh in Westchester County more than $1 million in back and current property taxes. The town had begun foreclosure proceedings against 353 acres of church property as well as a mansion owned by the church's founder, the Rev. Sun Myung Moon.

title: Machine Tools Fell In January
description: Orders for machine tools, a major economic barometer, dropped 55.4 percent in January from the levels of a year earlier and were 24.3 percent below the previous month, the National Machine Tool Builders' Association reported yesterday.

title: MUSIC: SCHUBERT'S SEVENTH
description: SCHUBERT'S other ''Unfinished'' Symphony is his Seventh in E major. It is also his unknown symphony because unlike the Unfinished Eighth, only 110 measures of this 1821 composition were completed.

title: News Analysis
description: Moshe Arens took over as Israel's Defense Minister today amid speculation about how he will approach policy decisions on the withdrawal of Israeli troops from Lebanon and possible negotiations with

title: 'M*A*S*H,' 11 YEARS OLD, ENDS TONIGHT
description: About the only thing that could rival the advertising revenues CBS will collect for the final episode of ''M*A*S*H,'' tonight from 8:30 to 11 P.M., is the number of people who watch the program. Not since the network answered the question ''Who shot J.R.?'' in ''Dallas'' has there been the potential for such a large turnout for a single television episode.

title: NIGERIAN REFUGEES' AFRICAN HELPERS
description: To the Editor:

title: ETHNIC NUANCES IN THERAPY
description: THIS may be a great nation of immigrants, but there is also a lot ofd iscomfort about the public discussion of ethnic differences. On o ccasion, a particular immigrant group's thrift or industry may be l auded in political speeches, but more realistic discussions of ethnic traits often seem tainted with the sins of stereotyping. Indeed, it sometimes seems that the only widespread attention given to ethnicity these days is the stream of often cruel jokes that spreads seismically through informal personal networks in every community.

title: Concessions Granted to Sikhs By Mrs. Gandhi's Government
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi today announced religious concessions for India's Sikhs, including permission to carry daggers, symbolic of the religion, on domestic airline flights.

title: Morocco and Algeria Hold Talks on Sahara
description: King Hassan II and President Chadli Benjedid of Algeria held direct talks for the first time Saturday to find a solution to the conflict in Western Sahara that has strained their relations for seven years.

title: Social Democrats Elect Leadership in Portugal
description: Portugal's Social Democratic Party, elected a new three-man leadership today headed by former Prime Minister Carlos Mota Pinto to run in general elections in April.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: TERM RATES Last Week In Percent) Tax-Exempt Bonds* 9.34 An Index of yields for long-term A-rated general obligation bonds compiled weekly by The Bond Buyer. Aa Utility Bonds* 12.25 Salomon Brothers estimate for new long-term issues.

title: STRAWBERRY DRAWS ATTENTION
description: Darryl Strawberry, a 6-foot-6-inch power hitter at the age of 20, spent his first day in a major league training camp today, and said: ''I know I can hit in the big leagues, and I know I can help the Mets.''

title: LET OUR HUMANISTS BEFRIEND THE COMPUTER
description: To the Editor:

title: Mexican Oil Price
description: Energy Minister Francisco Labastida Ochoa denies Mexico said it would cut oil prices, newspapers here said today. The Government had said new prices would be announced, but Mr. Labastida told reporters upon returning from Paris meetings with foreign oil officials: ''We never said that we were going to lower the price.''

title: Books Of The Times
description: THE LONDON EMBASSY. By Paul Ther- oux. 248 pages. Houghton Mifflin Com- pany. $13.95.

title: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1983
description: The nation's governors want higher taxes and less spending in the military sector to cut the Federal budget over the next five years, rather than any further reduction in social expenditures. (Page A1.)

title: CABARET: DARYL SHERMAN WITHOUT PIANO
description: DARYL SHERMAN, a singing pianist, made her debut as a nonpianoplaying stand up singer last week at the Village West, Hudson at Bank Streets. She uses her new freedom of movement to reach out to her listeners with a soft-voice expressiveness.

title: Not Retired Yet
description: When is Billie Jean King going to retire from tournament tennis? ''People have been asking me that question since I was 23 years old,'' she said last week. ''Now I'm 39 and have been playing pretty well during the first part of this year.

title: MIDEAST OIL STATES, FEELING PINCH, SAID TO REDUCE WESTERN HOLDINGS
description: Sharply lower oil exports and falling prices are prompting producing countries in the Middle East to begin to pull money out of Western securities markets and banks, according to Government, banking and other sources.

title: Yanks Add Rowland Office
description: Looking for what they called experienced outfield insurance, the Yankees have decided to add Rowland Office to the roster of their Columbus farm team.

title: VANDALS DESTROYING CROPS AND COWS IN JERSEY
description: Dairy cows have been randomly shot and killed. A few cattle have been butchered in the field. Trees have been felled. Tractor tires have been slashed. Barns and wheat fields have been burned. Harvesting combines worth $100,000 have been disabled. Irrigation pumps have been shattered with sledgehammers.

title: Holbert Winner Of Miami Race
description: Al Holbert today won the first Budweiser Grand Prix of Miami, a race through the downtown streets that was stopped short by a rainstorm.

title: CONGREGANTS SEE A ROLE FOR FAITH IN WORK PLACE
description: Stephanie Cimaglia, an I.B.M. marketing representative, stood at the altar of her church to testify about what prayer could do for industrial relations.

title: PATERNO'S NO. 1 PLATFORM
description: JOE PATERNO, the Penn State football coach, tells this story: Several years ago, an offensive tackle named Craig Lyle was on his team. Lyle would become a bornagain Christian, and later a preacher. In some of his sermons Lyle preached about love, using his football experience, of all things, as an example in his text.

title: Massachusetts Trooper Slain After Stopping Car
description: Seven people were arrested today in connection with the fatal shooting the night before of a Massachusetts state trooper who was making a routine traffic check.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: William H. McMaster Jr., 72; Ex-Morgan Guaranty Official
description: William H. McMaster Jr., a retired vice president of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York, died Thursday at the Moorings Park Health Center in Naples, Fla. He was 72 years old and lived in Naples and Rhinebeck, N.Y.

title: GOVERNORS' GROUP CALLS ON REAGAN TO SLASH DEFICITS
description: Leaders of the National Governors Association called on the Federal Government today to reduce the growth of military spending, maintain the current level of social welfare spending and consider raising taxes to slash the Federal budget deficit over the next five years.

title: Ill Wind in Zimbabwe's Bush
description: ''The soldiers came to our village. They burned our huts and called for the young men who had left the army. Then they killed 15 of them.'' The words were uttered by an elderly woman, but not in Central America. Her country, alas, is Zimbabwe.

title: NEW TEAM AT E.P.A. TO BE GIVEN TIME TO MAKE PROGRESS
description: The Reagan Administration has decided to give the head of the Environmental Protection Agency and her new management team time to improve the agency's performance before taking further action, a White House official said today.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Denmark will offer a seven-year, two-stage syndicated credit package totaling $1.3 billion. The first part, by Morgan Guaranty Trust Co., is for $700 million with an interest rate based on the United States prime rate; the second is for $600 million based on the London interbank offered rate.

title: ALLEN S. RUPLEY, EX-CHAIRMAN OF W.R. GRACE, IS DEAD AT 80
description: Allen S. Rupley, who rose from the mailroom to become chairman of the board of W.R. Grace & Company, died Saturday at Doctors Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Princeton Library Given $4.5 Million
description: A $4.5 million gift from the Firestone Foundation will help finance the enlargement of Princeton University's Harvey S. Firestone Memorial Library, the university announced.

title: SUN BELT CITIES PROSPER AS THOSE IN NORTH DECLINE
description: The talk of Phoenix this winter has been mostly about hard times, of unemployment, cutbacks in public services and the spectacle of hundreds of homeless people camped out on vacant lots, making parts of downtown look a little like Calcutta.

title: A Stockholder Renews Fight for GAF Control
description: Samuel J. Heyman, a Westport, Conn., real estate developer, has renewed his effort to take control of the GAF Corporation, a maker of chemicals and building materials, GAF confirmed yesterday.

title: W.Va. Tops Vegas, 87-78
description: Greg Jones scored 32 points today to lead West Virginia to an 87-78 victory over top-ranked Nevada-Las Vegas. The defeat was the second in four days for the Rebels after they had won their first 24 games this season. California State at Fullerton upset them last Thursday night.

title: IAN SMITH, STILL DEFIANT, RAILS AGAINST MUGABE...
description: Ian D. Smith, the last Prime Minister of white-ruled Rhodesia and the most prominent white politician in black-ruled Zimbabwe, is a man with grievances.

title: Arafat Says Israelis Showed Weakness in Siege of Beirut
description: Yasir Arafat, leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said today that if a single Arab power had joined in the war in Lebanon last summer, ''Israel would have been defeated and we would have entered Jerusalem.''

title: 'Smart Card' Consultant Widens Hunt for Clients
description: Arlen R. Lessin went to an electronics show in Los Angeles in 1980, saw a demonstration by the French of their ''smart card'' technology and became a proselyte.

title: DANCE: CANADA'S NEW BALLET HEROINE
description: Canadian ballet has a new heroine. The fact that Evelyn Hart of the Royal Winnipeg Ballet danced the title role in ''Giselle'' at the O'Keefe Center in Toronto on Saturday night might not seem immediately significant to North American balletgoers.

title: NEW SQUAD OF E.P.A. INVESTIGATORS HIRED BUT GIVEN LIMITED POWERS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency's newly hired staff of 24 criminal investigators is starting work just as Congressional attention has begun to focus on reports that organized crime has entered the profitable business of illegal dumping of hazardous industrial wastes.

title: TREASURY BORROWING SETS HIGH
description: Record Treasury borrowing to finance the Federal deficit dominated the nation's credit markets in the fourth quarter of 1982, according to estimates published by the Federal Reserve Board last week. At the same time, private credit demands dropped because of a sharp contraction in corporate borrowing. This played an important role in helping to reduce interest rates.

title: Swiss Avalanche Kills Two
description: An avalanche killed two Swiss skiers today and critically injured three others, the police said.

title: STRATEGY IN VENTURE OF G.M. AND TOYOTA
description: Executives of the General Motors Corporation are describing the proposed joint venture with the Toyota Motor Corporation to produce a small car in Fremont, Calif., as an experiment to see if Japanese cost-saving techniques can be applied in this country.

title: YIELD DECLINE LED BY BONDS
description: Treasury bond yields declined more last week than other market interest rates did. That was in contrast to the 1982 experience, when short-term interest rates fell more readily.

title: UNDERSTUDIES ENJOY A NIGHT OF GLORY
description: Vincent Sardi called it ''an evening in the theater that's long overdue,'' and few in the audience would have disagreed. Nor would they have disputed the restaurateur's definition of the subject at hand.

title: DANCE: MARY OVERLIE'S 'HISTORY' SOLO
description: EXPOSE a leading postmodernist to the world of Diaghilev and, if it's a postmodernist of Mary Overlie's intelligence and developed sensibilities, you get a small jewel of a dance like ''History.''

title: FOR STUDENTS, A DRAMATIC SHIFT IN GOALS
description: Male and female college students are beginning to share the same goals for careers and family life, representing a dramatic shift in attitudes over the last decade.

title: A New Chief for Epyx, Game Software Maker
description: Michael V. Katz, former marketing vice president at Coleco Industries, has been named president and chief executive officer of Epyx, a privately owned maker of game software for personal computers.

title: Evolution Of a Team
description: ''IT'S as quiet as a cemetery here,'' said Walt Frazier. This was more than a month ago, and the former Knick star sat in Madison Square Garden watching his former team, then in last place in the Atlantic Division, clank through another dank and deadly effort.

title: DENT SAYS BASEBALL CAN BE FUN AGAIN
description: Before a game between Texas and California last September, a couple of former Yankee stars stood in the outfield and compared notes on their plights in the recent past.

title: Watery Future For Ex-Adman
description: ''It's a dream come true,'' said Bob Foster, 46-year-old longtime advertising space peddler. Currently in residence at Sports Illustrated, he was peering into his immediate future.

title: The U.N. Today; Feb. 28, 1983; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Trade Law Commission, Working Group on International Contract Practices - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COUNCIL

title: Why Gold's Price Fell; Commodities
description: IF anyone was surprised by last week's price break for gold and silver futures, it was not the professionals who watched the interest rate on Eurodollars since bullion prices began soaring early last December.

title: AN ALBANY TOUR: OFF THE BEATEN PATH IN SEARCH OF 'ENDANGERED' LEGISLATION
description: A group of 17 state assemblymen has introduced the bill to end all bills - or at least some of the less important ones.

title: PRINCESS ROONEY IS DOUBTFUL STARTER
description: The long-awaited seasonal debut of Princess Rooney was thrown into doubt today as an intense winter storm crossed the Miami area. Frank Gomez, who trains the undefeated 3-year-old filly, said he would scratch her from the Bonnie Miss Stakes at Gulfstream Park Monday if the track was still muddy by post time.

title: Davis Outpoints Baltazar in Jersey
description: Howard Davis Jr. was knocked down twice with left hooks today, but he got up twice and went on to score a unanimous 10-round decision over the previously undefeated Tony Baltazar in a nationally televised lightweight fight at Resorts International.

title: QUEBECERS MAKING A POINT
description: In the next few months, Premier Rene Levesque and the other leaders of the Parti Quebecois will renew their drive to achieve independent political status for Quebec. This time, they will emphasize economic as well as linguistic issues and, recent statements suggest, will press for sovereignty in the context of some sort of ''North American Common Market.''

title: TALKS TO RESUME TODAY ON THREAT OF 2 RAIL STRIKES
description: Negotiations are scheduled to resume this morning in New York and New Jersey to avert threatened walkouts at midnight by trainmen and conductors on lines run by Metro-North and NJ Transit.

title: NEW ACCORD REPORTED NEAR FOR STEEL UNION AND INDUSTRY
description: Top bargainers from the United Steelworkers of America and seven major steel companies met this evening, with the possibility of continuing talks through the night, in an effort to work out a new steel industry labor agreement.

title: Los Angeles Police Unit Is Being Dismantled
description: The intelligence unit of the Los Angeles Police Department, whose roots go back to the 1920's, will be dissolved at the end of the week amid accusations its officers spied on citizens, public figures and their civilian bosses.

title: KICK WHEN DOWN
description: To rejuvenate our economy for the next decade, to improve the standard of living in the have-not nations and to reduce the risk of war, the United States should be doing everything in its economic power to drive the world price of oil below $20 a barrel.

title: TREASURY CHIEF INDICATES JOBS BILL MIGHT WIN WHITE HOUSE BACKING
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that the $4.6 billion jobs bill backed by the Democratic leadership in Congress, though $300 million larger than President Reagan wanted, is apparently not too large for the Administration to accept.

title: Coaches Moving On
description: Joe Puggelli and Rick Starace are breaking up the co-coaching act that has made McBurney School of Manhattan one of the metropolitan area's most amazing football teams for the last two seasons. When Tom Monaco, the regular coach, left McBurney to relocate in Kentucky after the 1980 season, Starace and Puggelli, who had been assistants, volunteered to split the job.

title: DANCE: INNER CITY ENSEMBLE AT RIVERSIDE
description: SOME spirited teen-agers from Paterson, N.J., brought a rousing program of drama and dance to the Theater of the Riverside Church on Saturday afternoon. They were members of the Inner City Ensemble Dance and Theater Company, founded in 1973 by Ralph Gomez.

title: TAKEOVER IS ARRANGED FOR FAILED COAST BANK
description: Five California banks agreed to assume the assets and take over the management of the seven branches of the failed American City Bank, the California State Banking Department announced tonight.

title: Be Merry but Don't Drink Cheap Oil
description: Sober pronouncements from the oil sheiks are, for once, making Americans smile. With the world drowning in expensive, unwanted fuel, Saudi Arabia struggles to avert an all-out price war among the oil exporters. The price is sure to fall to $30 a barrel from the current $34 OPEC benchmark, and it could fall much more.

title: FLYERS BLANK ISLANDERS
description: The Islanders mustered only 17 shots tonight, tying their season low, and lost to the Philadelphia Flyers, 2-0.

title: HOW A CABLE CHANNEL FLOPPED
description: Like a Broadway producer whose show has flopped, Arthur R. Taylor, chairman of The Entertainment Channel, last week contemplated the ruins of his failed pay-cable network: ''It was like putting on a beautiful play every night to a theater with too few seats,'' he said. The Entertainment Channel, he added, ''was a noble thing to do.''

title: PUBLIC COLLEGES STRIVE TO REDUCE FACULTY LAYOFFS
description: New York State's public universities, facing layoffs that could cut deeply into academic programs, are trying to negotiate alternatives with the Governor and the State Legislature.

title: Auburn U. President Resigns After Criticism
description: President Hanly Funderburk of Auburn University, who was criticized by the faculty for reportedly stressing the fiscal rather than educational health of the institution, resigned Saturday and took a job at the school's branch campus in Montgomery.

title: Jan Stephenson Wins By 5 Strokes in Tucson
description: Jan Stephenson scored birdies on five of the last six holes today and coasted to a five-stroke victory in the 54-hole $150,000 Tucson Open.

title: Selling a Sport
description: When Marty Fletcher took over as head coach of Virginia Military Institute's basketball program this season, there was almost nowhere to go but up. The Keydets had lost 25 of their 26 games in 1981-82, transforming Charlie Schmaus from a basketball coach to a real estate salesman.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, FEBRUARY 28, 1983
description: International A cutback of Western investments has been started by oil producers in the Middle East, according to Government, banking and other sources in the United States. The Treasury Department is expected to issue figures this week showing that investments in the United States of Middle East producers declined in the fourth quarter of last year. (Page A1, Column 4.) El Salvador ordered an investigation of the reported killing of 18 people by soldiers in the Western province of Sonsonate. (A1:5.)

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball City University of New York tournament, championship game, Staten Island vs. John Jay, at Nat Holman Gymnasium, Convent Avenue and West 138th Street, 7:30 P.M. Admission free.

title: 60-Second Debate; Should Congress veto a Federal Trade Commission rule to require undertakers to itemize prices?
description: Michael Pertschuk Federal Trade Commissioner:

title: VERMONT MAYOR, A SOCIALIST, SEEKING A NEW TERM
description: It is plain, from a picture hanging on the outer wall of the the Mayor of Burlington's office, where tradition came to an end.

title: STUDY OF MX MISSILES OPTIONS FAVORS MOBILE OFF-LAND SITES
description: An analysis of the MX missile issue prepared for Congress suggests that making the missiles freely mobile and basing them off land would best enable them to survive a Soviet attack and retaliate.

title: Lloyd Traded, Retires
description: Dan Lloyd, a linebacker whose National Football League career ended after a bout with cancer, said today that he has chosen to retire from the United States Football League rather than agree to a trade that would send him from the New Jersey Generals to the Birmingham Stallions.

title: 76ERS TOP WARRIORS FOR NINTH IN A ROW
description: Maurice Cheeks scored a career-high 32 points and Moses Malone got 28 as the Philadelphia 76ers gained their ninth straight victory by defeating the Golden State Warriors today, 115-104.

title: Suspect Found Hanged in Cell
description: A 22-year-old Fairfield man hanged himself in his cell at the Bridgeport Police Department, authorities said. The man, Peter A. Adintori 3d, was found hanging shortly after he was charged Friday night with breach of peace, criminal mischief, threatening, possession of a weapon and possession of hashish, according to Detective Richard Petitte.

title: IN THE GULF, SPENDING AS USUAL
description: Snapshots of economic life in this Persian Gulf city-state on the day after Saudi Arabia said it was ready to let oil prices fall:

title: Devils Lose, 6-2; 38th Assist for Housley
description: Tony McKegney scored two goals and Phil Housley, a rookie defenseman, added three assists to lead the Buffalo Sabres to a 6-2 victory over the New Jersey Devils tonight.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I've been reading him since I was a child and now I teach him.

title: SPICE ISLAND STRAINS
description: This brilliantly green island republic of 100,000 people in the south Caribbean is worrying its neighbors and provoking harsh frowns from the mighty U.S. It is another example of the dilemma of social reform and American foreign policy.

title: RESUME THE SEARCH FOR MOZART'S FIRST
description: To the Editor:

title: Quick Opening for Mr. Walker
description: Herschel Walker has caused Georgia fans to mourn and college coaches to cry foul by signing before graduation with the New Jersey Generals of the new United States Football League. But the University of Georgia junior, last season's Heisman Trophy winner, has probably run the best play of his life.

title: Switches Working At Indian Point 2
description: Switches at the Indian Point 2 nuclear power plant in Buchanan, N.Y., that are designed to shut down the plant automatically have been tested and found free of defects, according to Consolidated Edison, which operates the plant.

title: Champions Beaten In Skate Sprints
description: Akira Kuroiwa of Japan won the men's world sprint title today, and Karin Enke of East Germany edged the defending champion, Natalya Petruseva of the Soviet Union, to take the women's title in the World Sprint Speed Skating Championships.

title: FOUR BATTLE FOR HOUSE SEAT LEFT BY LATE REP. ROSENTHAL
description: Three Democrats and a Republican are running for the House of Representatives in a Queens special election tomorrow that has become a test of traditional shoe leather campaigning against modern electronic techniques.
